NURS majors only. A-F only..
metadata: Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing Nursing (NURS)

subject: LLEA
title: Gods, Heroes, and Dragons: Germanic Myth, Legends, and Fairy Tales (3)
desc: Study of Germanic myth, legends, and fairy tales. Analysis of narratives from ancient times to the modern era from multiple theoretical perspectives.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: ANTH
title: Historical Ecology (3)
desc: Examines the recursive relationship between humans and the environment across deep time. (Fall only)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Love (3)
desc: Explores love from multiple anthropological viewpoints: biological, cultural, archaeological. (Spring only)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: CINE
title: Screenwriting Capstone (3)
desc: Culmination of beginning and advanced screenwriting classes. Students will write a treatment and first act for a feature-length project or pilot script and series bible for a television project. Repeatable one time. SCA majors only. Pre: 350 and 450.
metadata: DA ACM: The School of Cinematic Arts (CINE) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: PHIL
title: Hawaiian Philosophy: Aloha ‘Āina (3)
desc: Introduction to Indigenous Hawaiian philosophy and how to engage with Aloha ‘Āina relying upon a methodology and pedagogy consistent with the philosophy being discussed. Pre: 100 or above, HAW 100, HWST 107, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: QHS
title: Biostatistics Concepts for Clinical Researchers (3)
desc: Provide biostatistical concepts to clinical researchers. Students will obtain the ability to demonstrate an understanding of key biostatistical concepts in clinical research; and interpret statistical findings most commonly reported in clinical and healthcare literature. Graduate students only.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: LIS
title: Archival Access, Representation and Use (3)
desc: Principles and techniques for arrangement and description of archival materials. Topics include basic metadata standards, authority sources, record context, series identification, scope, and content. LIS majors only. Graduate students only. Pre: 654.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: IS
title: One Health: Preparing for the Next Pandemic (3)
desc: Focuses on the COVID-19 pandemic as a case study of a global health problem that is optimally approached from a One Health perspective. A-F only. Pre: ANSC 200, BIOL 101, MICR 130, PH 201, or consent of instructor. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as TRMD 350)
metadata: DB Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: TRMD
title: One Health: Preparing for the Next Pandemic (3)
desc: Focuses on the COVID-19 pandemic as a case study of a global health problem that is optimally approached from a One Health perspective. A-F only. Pre: ANSC 200, BIOL 101, MICR 130, PH 201, or consent of instructor. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as IS 350)
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Tropical Medicine and Medical Microbiology (TRMD)

subject: QHS
title: Mathematic Preparation for Quantitative Health Sciences (3)
desc:
Mathematics preparation for quantitative health sciences. Includes selective topics in 
linear algebra, advanced calculus and probability theory. A-F only.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: ME
title: Mechatronics (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Modern mechatronics components and design principles; functionality of products, processes and systems; electrical circuits and mechanical components; programming and control; hands on technology; application case studies. ME, ECE, CE, ICS majors only. Pre: junior standing or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: HWST
title: Native Hawaiian Composition (3)
desc: Focus on studying and Applying Native Hawaiian composition practices from the nineteenth century into the present day. Pre: 107 and HAW 100.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: SUST
title: He Ali‘i Ka ‘Āina; Land, Resources, and Leadership (3)
desc: Seminar focused on leadership challenges in Mālama ‘Āina to bridge ancestral and contemporary systems to better steward resources, produce abundance, work with and in community, and pivot large institutions for a better Aloha ‘Āina future. (Cross-listed as HWST 659)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: CEE
title: Construction Law (3)
desc:
In-depth exploration of the legal regimes governing construction. Construction contracts, contractors, and subcontractors. Breach of contracts, claims and litigation in construction 
projects. CEE, CNST majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 375. (Spring only)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Construction Safety (3)
desc: Safety and health concepts, laws and requirements for civilian and contractor personnel in construction, including applications in project management and construction activities. CNST, CEE majors only. A-F only. Pre: 375.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: ANTH
title: Household Archaeology (3)
desc: Focuses on the differences in the composition, activities, roles, and relationships to be observed archaeologically between households that comprised ancient communities and how these differences inform us about the dynamics of social change. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 210.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: COA
title: Adult Development and Aging (3)
desc: Overview from a multidisciplinary, life-span perspective. Includes research techniques, personality development, family relationships, occupational attainment, death. Pre: PSY 100. Recommended: 240. (Cross-listed as PSY 342)
metadata: DS Center on Aging (COA) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: COA
title: Back to the Future: Aging in Today’s Society (3)
desc: By 2050, more than a quarter of the world’s population will be 60 years of age or older. Explores what we know about aging today to encourage a lifetime of aging well. A-F only. Pre: PH 201 or SW 360 or WGSS 305 or PSY 100 or HDFS 230 or NURS 200; or consent. (Cross-listed as PH 435 and SW 435)
metadata: Center on Aging (COA) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: ME
title: Space Exploration (4)
desc: Introduction to science and engineering of Solar System exploration with laboratory exercises. Covers planetary science, model-based systems engineering, mission planning, constraints on payload and spacecraft design, human spaceflight technology. Research projects emphasize written communication. A-F only. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as EPET 201)
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: HON
title: Transformational Research Experiences for Early Undergraduates (3)
desc: Introduction to exploring discover-based investigation, with hands-on experiences in a wide range of science fields. Divided into 4-week learning modules led by researchers at several UH Mānoa research facilities on and off campus. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. (Cross-listed as UROP 299)
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: COA
title: Survey of Sociology of Aging (3)
desc: Aging as a social phenomenon, including social impacts of growing elderly population and emerging social patterns among the elderly. Important theoretical perspectives and cross-national research. Pre: SOC 100 or a 200-level sociology course, or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 353)
metadata: DS Center on Aging (COA) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: CEE
title: Coastal Modeling (3)
desc: Coastal modeling using the SMS Surface-Water Modeling software. Applications to solving coastal problems for different ocean hazard scenarios by applying models for tides, waves, coastal circulation, wave-current interaction, sediment transport, and/or morphology change. Pre: consent; knowledge of ORE 607 desirable. (Cross-listed as ORE 624 and SUST 624)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: SUST
title: Coastal Flood Mitigation (3)
desc: Design and solutions to coastal flood mitigation problems. Topics include climate adaptation; engineering solutions and best practices to mitigate coastal risk under different ocean hazard scenarios; and ecological approaches to mitigate coastal risk. Pre: consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable. (Cross-listed as CEE 621 and ORE 621)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: ORE
title: Coastal Flood Mitigation (3)
desc: Design and solutions to coastal flood mitigation problems. Topics include climate adaptation; engineering solutions and best practices to mitigate coastal risk under different ocean hazard scenarios; and ecological approaches to mitigate coastal risk. Pre: consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable. (Cross-listed as CEE 621 and SUST 621)
metadata: Ocean and Resources Engineering (ORE) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: CEE
title: Coastal Flood Mitigation (3)
desc: Design and solutions to coastal flood mitigation problems. Topics include climate adaptation; engineering solutions and best practices to mitigate coastal risk under different ocean hazard scenarios; and ecological approaches to mitigate coastal risk. Pre: consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable. (Cross-listed as ORE 621 and SUST 621)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: SUST
title: An Introduction to Integrative Systems Biology: Hawaiian Biomes as a Framework (4)
desc: Lecture/discussion introduces students to the field of biology through the integration of microbiology and macrobiology into a single, comprehensive systems biology with a focus on Hawaiian biomes and ecosystem sustainability. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as OEST 103)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: ME
title: Capstone Project: Producing a Science Satellite (4)
desc: Develops a space mission with a multidisciplinary team of engineers and scientists. Will build a small spacecraft and payload and seeks to answer important science questions. Emphasizes review report and proposal writing. A-F only. Pre: 400. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as EPET 401)
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Space Mission Design (4)
desc: Covers all aspects of spacecraft design, subsystems, science payload, systems engineering, project management, budgets, and ethical issues that are important to consider in producing a fully successful mission. A-F only. Pre: 301. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as EPET 400)
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Space Science and Instrumentation (4)
desc: Essential techniques for remote compositional analysis of planets; understanding spectroscopy, mineralogy, and geochemistry of planetary surfaces and their measurement. Design of space flight instrumentation. A-F only. Pre: EPET 201, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 101L and ERTH 105, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 107; and CHEM 161 and PHYS 272. (Fall only) (Crosslisted as EPET 301)
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: JOUR
title: Sports Media (3)
desc: A practice-based writing approach to the production of sports media in contemporary mediums of all types (written, audio, video, etc.) for various communication contexts (e.g., journalistic, public relations, etc. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: COA
title: Directed Reading and Research forJuniors and Seniors (V)
desc:
Individual reading or research under supervision of COA-affiliated faculty. Repeatable two 
times, up to nine credits. Juniors and seniors only. Pre: consent of instructor.
metadata: Center on Aging (COA) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: COA
title: Directed Reading and Research for Freshmen and Sophomores (V)
desc:
Individual reading or research under supervision of COA-affiliated faculty. 
Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. Freshmen and sophomores only. A-F only. Pre: instructor consent.
metadata: Center on Aging (COA) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: ERTH
title: Earth Materials and Structures (4)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Lecture and lab that covers formation, occurrence, and identification of common minerals, rocks, and geologic structures. Lab work will include study of hand-samples, thin-sections, and field experiences. A-F only. Pre: 200 or 201. (Fall only)
metadata: DP DY Earth Sciences (ERTH) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: WGSS
title: Oceanic Gender, Sexual, and Kinship Identities (3)
desc:
Oceania-centric perspective. Analysis of imperialism, colonialism, gender, sexuality, race, 
ethnicity, and queer(ed) relations and identities in Hawai‘i and the Pacific. Junior standing or higher. Pre: one DS or DH course, or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 391)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: SUST
title: Installation/Performance–Material in Context (3)
desc: Studio investigation of the transformation of space (ecological, social, political, psychological) through artist intervention. Experiments in non-object based interventions and into the evocative potential of materials. Engages writing and oral expression as significant analytical tools. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: ART 116 or consent. (Cross-listed as ART 439)
metadata: DA Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Society and Environment (3)
desc: Relationship of humans with natural environment; role of culture in ecological systems. Pre: 152. (Cross-listed as ANTH 335)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: ANTH
title: Society and Environment (3)
desc: Relationship of humans with natural environment; role of culture in ecological systems. Pre: 152. (Cross-listed as SUST 335)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: SNSK
title: Introduction to Sanskrit II (3)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101.
metadata: HSL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Sanskrit (SNSK)

subject: PHYS
title: Modern General Relativity (3)
desc: Differential geometry, special relativity, Einstein equations, gravitational phenomena, equivalence principles, black holes, gravitational waves, cosmology, relativistic stars, experimental tests, computational techniques. Graduate students only in PHYS or ASTR. (Alt. years: fall) (Crosslisted as ASTR 760)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: ANSC
title: Laboratory Skills in Animal Science (2)
desc: Provides students with basic and essential laboratory skills required in various fields of animal science such as nutrition, genetics, reproductive physiology, meat science, clinical pathology, parasitology, and animal handling. ANSC majors only. A-F only. Pre: (200 or 201, and BIOL 171 and 171L and CHEM 161) with a minimum grade of D-. (Fall only)
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: PACE
title: Greek and Roman War Literature (3)
desc: Survey of war-related literature from Greece and Rome, its major themes, and how it reflects the wide range of social, political, intellectual, and literary perspectives on war found in the ancient world. Pre: sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as CLAS 325)
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Education (3)
desc: Uses tools of philosophical inquiry to explore historical and contemporary perspectives on the nature of education, including concepts of knowledge, teaching, learning, and human flourishing. Repeatable one time. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: ECON
title: Econometrics III (3)
desc: Will equip students with the ability to undertake, understand, and critically assess empirical research using state-of-the-at econometric methods. Pre: 628 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Macroeconomic Theory III (3)
desc: Will equip students with the ability to understand, undertake, and critically evaluate theoretical and quantitative research in modern macroeconomics with a focus on the application of the search and matching methodology. Pre: 607 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: COM
title: Information Technology and Health Communication (3)
desc: Combined lecture-discussion on the application of ICTs for health communication from the aspect of technologies, systems, services, and policies. COM majors only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: LLEA
title: Death and Dying in Literature and Film (3)
desc: Exploration of death and dying in literature and film as manifested across time and cultures throughout the world. Analysis of narratives from ancient times to the modern era from multiple theoretical and cross-cultural perspectives.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: COA
title: Ethics, Aging & Society (3)
desc: Addresses ethical issues in gerontology and long-term care for older adults as raised by public policy, health care problems, and social attitudes toward elders. Explores established practices and new directions for ethics in aging. A-F only. (Cross-listed as IS 305)
metadata: DH Center on Aging (COA) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SUST
title: History of the Indian Ocean World (3)
desc:
Explores the transnational history of the Indian Ocean world, especially the region connected by the western monsoon. Topics include travel, trade, religion, colonialism, nationalism, diaspora, and globalization, including actors like slaves, sailors, women, and 
merchants. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as HIST 401)
metadata: DH Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Coastal Geology (3)
desc: Geological history and geologic framework of the Hawaiian shoreline. Modern climate change, paleoclimate, focus on sea level change. Modern coastal management and problems in the coastal environment. Coastal planning. Repeatable one time, credit earned one time. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as ERTH 620)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: ASTR
title: Cosmology Seminar (1)
desc: Students and researchers will review and discuss the most important and exciting cosmological results in depth. ASTR and PHYS majors only. Graduate students only.
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Programming and Algorithms for Astronomers (2)
desc:
Distillation of modern computer science fundamentals and paradigms, with applications 
to astronomy. Common algorithms and essential programming techniques. Assignments include extensive Python programming practice. Open to graduate students in any physical science. Graduate students only. (Alt. years)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: WGSS
title: Advanced Queer Theory (3)
desc:
Advanced graduate seminar on the key ideas within queer theory. Students will become familiar with theories of queer relationality, queer of color critique, globalization of 
sexuality, disability and transgender studies, and queer indigeneities. Pre: undergraduate or graduate course work in women’s, gender, sexuality, or LGBTQ studies.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Indigenous Feminisms (3)
desc:
Examines the origins and futures of Indigenous feminist theory and praxis. Topics explored include cultural revitalization, colonialism, and sexual violence in Indigenous 
communities, citizenship and sovereignty, and contemporary Native gender roles and identity. Pre: 151 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: HIST
title: Rivers, Seas, and Society in Southeast Asia (3)
desc: The rivers, seas, and extensive coastlines are a dominant environmental feature in Southeast Asia. Focuses on the dynamic interaction of water and society in shaping the history of the region.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HWST
title: He Ali‘i Ka ‘Āina; Land, Resources, and Leadership (3)
desc:
Seminar focused on leadership challenges in MVâlama ‘Āina to bridge ancestral and 
contemporary systems to better steward resources, produce abundance, work with and in community, and pivot large institutions for a better Aloha ‘Āina future. (Cross-listed as SUST 659)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: DNCE
title: Advanced Hip Hop (V)
desc: Hip Hop studio practice, technique, and performance at the advanced level. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. Pre: 241 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: SLS
title: Multilingual/EL Pedagogy (3)
desc: Examines practices, theories, research, and perspectives on multilingual/EL teaching approaches. Topics include culturally and linguistically responsive approaches, collaboration, lesson planning, and adapting materials to promote the growth and development of multilingual/ EL learners. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as EDCS 644)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: EDCS
title: Multilingual/EL Pedagogy (3)
desc: Examines practices, theories, research, and perspectives on multilingual/EL teaching approaches. Topics include culturally and linguistically responsive approaches, collaboration, lesson planning, and adapting materials to promote the growth and development of multilingual/ EL learners. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as SLS 644)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: SUST
title: The Ethics of Climate Change and Geoengineering (3)
desc:
Provide a scientific basis to examine the consequences of climate change and the 
proposed geoengineering solutions, and examine the fundamental ethical basis that underlies environmental policies. A-F only. Pre: OCN 310. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as OCN 411)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: LING
title: Bad Words (3)
desc: An examination of the link between language and society through the use and perception of taboo words.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LAIS
title: Asians and Pacific Islanders in Latin America (3)
desc: Survey of the history and culture of Asian, Polynesian, and Pacific Islander communities in Latin America. Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: DNCE
title: Intermediate Hip Hop (V)
desc: Hip Hop studio practice, technique, and performance at the intermediate level. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: COA
title: Introduction to Applied Gerontology: Helping Yourself and Others to Thrive in Later Life (3)
desc: Introduction to essential information on aging and the field of gerontology. Counters ageist stereotypes, develops skills for translating research into practice, and provides an introductory survey course for the undergraduate certificate in aging. A-F only. (Crosslisted as IS 206)
metadata: DS Center on Aging (COA) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: CHEM
title: Computational Modeling in Chemistry (3)
desc: Theory and application of computational modeling in chemistry. Statistical theory behind molecular dynamics simulations, application to modeling chemical systems, computer programming, and analysis of results. Graduate students only.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: HIST
title: Women in Oceania (3)
desc: Uses research and writing to explore historical processes that have impacted the lives of Indigenous women in Oceania and women’s engagements with those processes over time, with a focus on women’s voices, agency, and empowerment.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: ANTH
title: Advanced Household Archaeology (3)
desc: Focus on  the differences in the composition, activities, roles, and relationships to be observed archaeologically between the households that comprised ancient communities, and how these differences inform us about the dynamics of social change. Graduate students only.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Professional Studies III (3)
desc: Planning and methods seminar in conjunction with practice teaching. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: FDM
title: Capstone Portfolio (3)
desc: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Includes extensive instruction in writing and communication. Pre: 492 and senior standing.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: SUST
title: Applied Forest Ecology (3)
desc:
Application of ecological theory to sustainable management of forest resources in Hawaii and beyond, including silviculture 
(production of timber and nontimber forest products), restoration (restoring damaged or degraded forests), and conservation (conserving existing forest resources). A-F only. Pre: (311/NREM 310 and NREM 380) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as NREM 480)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: NURS
title: Women, Newborn, and Family Health (3)
desc: Nursing care and health promotion for women, newborn, and families in acute care and community settings. Utilization of family theories and assessment tools for providing culturally sensitive, client-centered care. NURS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 220 and 220L and 213.
metadata: Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing Nursing (NURS)

subject: SUST
title: Introduction to the Environment and Sustainability Lab (1)
desc: Introduction to a variety of quantitative and qualitative approaches and methodologies to describe and assess key components to the environment. A-F only. Pre: 112 (or concurrent) or GES 102 (or concurrent) or OCN 102 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as GES 102L and OCN 102L)
metadata: DY Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Educational Psychology (3)
desc: Psychology applied to education, including cognitive, sociocultural, and multicultural approaches to teaching, learning, development, and research. Develops knowledge and written communication skills through and introduction to classroom, assessment, instruction, motivation, classroom management, and standardized testing. (Cross-listed as EDEP 311)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: LWPA
title: Human Rights in Asia (V)
desc: A survey of human rights norms, institutions, and implementation mechanism of international human rights law in light of the rapid development of regional cooperation and integration in Asia.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: MBBE
title: Sensors and Instrumentation for Biological Systems (3)
desc: Design course focused on fundamentals of electronic interfacing, control and automation, including biological processes. Topics include sensor physics, basic instrumentation, digital communication, and programming of microcontrollers and other portable computer systems. Pre: (160, 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Cross-listed as BE 420 and ECE 422)
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: CINE
title: Virtual and Augmented Reality Programming (3)
desc: Students will learn to develop virtual reality and augmented reality applications with turnkey tools as well as through programming. Prior programming experience is not required for this course. Pre: any 215 or ICS 110(Alpha) or ICS 111. (Cross-listed as ICS 486).
metadata: ACM: The School of Cinematic Arts (CINE) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: BOT
title: Tropical forest Ecology (3)
desc:
Introduction to the ecological processes and principles of tropical ecosystems, and to conservation issues facing tropical forests, with a particular emphasis on the neotropics. 
A-F only. Pre: BIOL 171 and BIOL 172, or BOT 101; and BIOL 265.
metadata: DB Botany (BOT) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ERTH
title: Summer Fieldschool Program: Hydrogeophysics in Volcanic Environments (V)
desc:
Will cover the full hydrogeophysical workflow including theory, acquisition design, field data acquisition, data processing, data inversion, and hydrogeological interpretation. Methods include ambient seismic, 3D electrical resistivity tomography and induced 
polarization, and self-potential. Pre: consent. (Summer only)
metadata: Earth Sciences (ERTH) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: QHS
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Directed reading/research in quantitative health sciences. Students will work closely with a QHS faculty member or mentor who will guide them through quantitative methodologies and/or the process of conducting a research study. Repeatable three times or up to 12 credits. A-F only.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: LING
title: Language Endangerment and Revitalization (3)
desc: An overview of language endangerment, especially in the Pacific and Asia, and a critical examination of the strategies that are being developed to combat it. Pre: one of LING 102, 150B, 150C, 105, 320, SLS 150, SLS 301, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: JPN
title: Introduction to Teaching Japanese as a Foreign Language (3)
desc: Introduction to instructional approaches for Japanese language classroom teaching that focus on everyday language use. Students develop instructional materials, pedagogical practices, and assessment tools for engaged and effective teaching and learning of Japanese. Pre: 350 (or concurrent) and 401, 403, 404, or 405 (or concurrent); or instructor’s consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: KOR
title: Reading and Translating Korean Poetry (3)
desc: Introduction to modern Korean poetry and translation for students with third-year level Korean abilities. Students will learn how to interpret poems and translate them from Korean to English. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: DL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: WGSS
title: Queer Theory (3)
desc: Intensive survey of the key theories, texts, and questions of the interdisciplinary fields that make up queer theory. Pre: 141 or 151 or 392 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Introduction to LGBTQ+ Studies (3)
desc: Introduction to a survey of the key terms, texts, and histories of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities with special attention to Hawai‘i and Oceania. A-F only
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: ORE
title: Ocean Engineering and Resilience in a Changing Climate (3)
desc:
Focus on understanding the changing ocean conditions (e.g. waves and sea levels) 
relevant to the resilience of practical ocean engineering applications. Graduate students only. Pre: 607 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: Ocean and Resources Engineering (ORE) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: NURS
title: Women, Newborn, and Family Health Lab (3)
desc: Nursing care and health promotion for women, newborn, and families in acute and community settings. Utilization of family theories and assessment tools when providing culturally sensitive, family-centered care. Emphasis on teaching writing for the profession. NURS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. CR/NC only. Pre: 220 and 220L and 213.
metadata: Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing Nursing (NURS)

subject: MBBE
title: Synthetic Biology (3)
desc: Introduction to principles, tools, and applications of synthetic biology; molecular techniques and design/analysis of synthetic gene circuits, synthetic-biology parts/devices, CRISPRbased systems, engineered microbial cell factories, for industrial, agricultural, medical applications. A-F only. Pre: (PHYS 152 (or PHYS 272), BIOL 275/275L) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MKT
title: Sustainable Marketing (3)
desc: Provides environmental knowledge and managerial tools that help for profit and not-for-profit organizations address pressing issues like global warming, plastic pollution, and fair trade while earning surplus revenue and remaining socially accountable. Pre: BUS 312 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: LIS
title: Responding to Reading in Libraries (3)
desc: Research-intensive seminar that explores the reading process in library contexts and similar settings. Critical examination of ways in which library and literacy services impact reading engagement and interests of library users. LIS majors only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: HIST
title: Library Treasures: Exploring Special Collections & Archives (3)
desc: Conduct original research using general library materials, special collections, rare books, archives, and manuscripts, maps, and other historical documents that are uniquely available at libraries and archives at UH and beyond. Repeatable one time.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: ECE
title: Computational Media Systems (3)
desc: Intermediate object-oriented programming within the context of interactive media systems and video game development. Topics: classes, objects, inheritance, polymorphism, abstract classes, interfaces, event-driven programming, vectors, geometric primitives, game mechanics, and relevant design patterns. ECE, CENG, ICS, CM, CSCI, THEA, DNCE majors only. A-F only. Pre: 160 or ICS 111 or instructor approval. (Cross-listed as ICS 369)
metadata: College of Engineering Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

subject: ECE
title: Linear Algebra and Machine Learning (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab)   Mathematical and algorithmic fundamentals of linear algebra and their applications and illustrations to machine learning. Lab introduces programming with data and uses machine learning libraries for an introduction to commonly used technologies. MATH, ECE, CENG, CECE, ME, ICS majors only. A-F only. Pre: MATH 242 or MATH 252A or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)

subject: CINE
title: Storyboarding and Animatics (3)
desc: Exposes students to the history, application, format, styles, and methods of creating storyboards and animatics. Visual storytelling will be analyzed by examining the foundational components of the visual language of a film. SCA majors only. A-F only. Pre: 255.
metadata: DA ACM: The School of Cinematic Arts (CINE) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: COM
title: Digital Storytelling (3)
desc: Focus on development of narrative-based creative activities in all mediums (text, audio, video, etc.) within communication contexts, i.e., journalism, film, public relations, etc. COM majors only. A-F only. Pre: instructor approval.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: DNCE
title: Advanced Dance Technology and Live Performance (3)
desc: Advanced skills in dance and technology in live performance. Emphasis on New Media. Graduate students only. Pre: 362 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: CHEM
title: Experimental Methods in Materials Research (3)
desc:
(1 Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Common experimental techniques in materials testing and research: x-ray diffraction, optical and electron microscopy, thermal and mechanical properties, 
electrochemical methods—theory and hands-on experience. Pre: 351 (or concurrent) or ME 341. (Crosslisted as ME 435)
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: SUST
title: Global Environmental History (3)
desc: Explores the influence of nature–climate, topography, plants, animals, and microorganisms–on human history and the way people, in turn, have influenced the natural world around them. (Cross-listed as HIST 157)
metadata: FGC Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Beaches, Reefs, and Climate Change (3)
desc: Global and local aspects of climate change and paleoclimate; beach and reef processes and response to climate change; management of coastal environments; field study local sites. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as ERTH 420)
metadata: DP Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Historical Ecology of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: The Hawaiian socio-ecosystem is the product of centuries of human land use and resource exploitation. Explores the events and processes that have shaped the islands’ ecology and future sustainability. A-F only. (Cross-listed as ANTH 204)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: LIS
title: Masters Seminar II (2)
desc: Seminar for graduating students focused on the refinement and completion of the culminating portfolio or thesis. Peer mentoring, faculty, and student presentations. MLISc degree required course. Graduate students only. CR/NC only. Pre: 691.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: SLS
title: Basic Language Concepts for Second Language Learning, Teaching, and Use (3)
desc: Introduction to language structure and function in the domains of sound, words, sentences, and discourse, with specific focus on description, analysis, and research into learner language. Pre: Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: ASL
title: Advanced American Sign Language II (3)
desc: Development of advanced receptive and expressive conversational skills in American Sign Language (ASL). Pre: 301. (Spring only)
metadata: American Sign Language (ASL) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: SPED
title: Leadership in Special Education (3)
desc: Seminar on topics related to leadership in the field of special education, including issues for teacher leaders, administrators, and teacher preparation personnel. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: ASL
title: Advanced American Sign Language I (3)
desc: Development of advanced receptive and expressive conversational skills in American Sign Language (ASL). Pre: 202. (Fall only)
metadata: American Sign Language (ASL) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: ART
title: Genres of Japanese Cinema (3)
desc: History of Japanese cinema, including silent films, samurai films, monster films, and literary adaptations, analyzed through the lens of genre theory. Students demonstrate mastery of assigned readings and lecture content via weekly writing assignments. A-F only. Pre: 175 and 176. (Summer only)
metadata: DH Art & Art History (ART) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: SUST
title: Science and Science Curriculum, PK-12 (3)
desc:
Application of recent developments in science, sustainability, curriculum development, and learning theory to pre-kindergarten through secondary school. Science philosophy, content and methodology stressed, including inquiry, nature of science, sustainability, and 
science literacy. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as EDCS 623)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: MCB
title: Cell and Molecular Biology (3)
desc: Integrated cell and molecular biology for life science majors. Modern advances in recombinant DNA technology. A-F only. Pre: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 171/171L and CHEM 272. (Cross-listed as BIOL 275)
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: BOT
title: Biostatistics (4)
desc:
(3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to statistical approaches in biology. 
Students will learn how to formulate hypotheses, test them quantitatively, and present results. Students will analyze biological datasets using the computer language R. A-F only. Pre: 101 or BIOL 171 or BIOL 172; MATH 134 or higher, or MATH assessment exam. (Cross-listed as BIOL 220)
metadata: FQ Botany (BOT) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Biostatistics (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to statistical approaches in biology. Students will learn how to formulate hypotheses, test them quantitatively, and present results. Students will analyze biological datasets using the computer language R. A-F only. Pre: 171 or 172 or BOT 101; MATH 134 or higher, or MATH assessment exam. (Cross-listed as BOT 220)
metadata: FQ Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences School of Life Sciences

subject: ART
title: Experimental Art and Animation (3)
desc: Provides students an opportunity to experiment with new mediums while collaborating with artists from different backgrounds, such as art, theatre, dance, film, and animation. SCA, ART, THEA, DNCE majors only. Pre: 113 or CINE 216 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 353 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 356 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as CINE 314 and THEA 314)
metadata: DA Art & Art History (ART) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: NURS
title: Gerontology, Health Care, and the Law (Elder Law) (V)
desc: Provides a basic foundation for studies at the intersection of gerontology, health care, and the law and places an emphasis on proactive and preventive law for older adults in society. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Cross-listed as COA 449)
metadata: Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing Nursing (NURS)

subject: ICS
title: Capstone Project (3)
desc: Project-based course where students work in teams on a software project. Knowledge acquired in the computer science curriculum will be applied to design and implement a software product with potential real-world applicability. Repeatable one time. CS majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: GES
title: Introduction to the Environment and Sustainability Lab (1)
desc: Introduction to a variety of quantitative and qualitative approaches and methodologies to describe and assess key components to the environment. A-F only. Pre: 102 (or concurrent) or OCN 102 (or concurrent) or SUST 112 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as OCN 102L and SUST 112L)
metadata: DY Global Environmental Science (GES) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: OCN
title: Introduction to the Environment and Sustainability Lab (1)
desc: Introduction to a variety of quantitative and qualitative approaches and methodologies to describe and assess key components to the environment. A-F only. Pre: 102 (or concurrent) or GES 102 or (or concurrent) SUST 112 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as GES 102L and SUST 112L)
metadata: DY Oceanography (OCN) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: CINE
title: (Alpha) History and Film (3)
desc: Explores the many relationships between history and film including how film has reflected and shaped society in the past and our relationship to the past. (C) Europe: emphasis on writing as historians and film critics; (E) world/ comparative: significant attention paid to developing writing skills that involve critically comparing history-related cinematic representations across regions and cultures. Repeatable one time for different alphas. (C Cross-listed as HIST 452C; E Cross-listed as HIST 452E)
metadata: DH ACM: The School of Cinematic Arts (CINE) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: SUST
title: Anthropology and the Environment: Culture, Power, and Politics (3)
desc: Investigates environmental problems from an anthropological perspective, and examines the cultural politics of contestations over resources, rights, and the meanings of nature. Pre: ANTH 152 or ANTH 415 or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as ANTH 482)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: NURS
title: Child and Family Health Lab (3)
desc: Nursing care and health promotion lab for children and families. Application of concepts related to the delivery of family-centered holistic, culturally sensitive, therapeutic nursing care to children and families in acute care and community settings. NURS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 213 and 220 and 220L. Co-requisite: 322.
metadata: Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing Nursing (NURS)

subject: NURS
title: Child and Family Health (2)
desc:
Nursing care and health promotion for children and families. Emphasis on concepts related to the delivery of familycentered holistic, culturally sensitive, therapeutic 
nursing care to children and families in acute care and community settings. NURS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 213 and 220 and 220L. Co-requisite: 322L.
metadata: Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing Nursing (NURS)

subject: ES
title: Ethnic Studies in the Digital World (3)
desc: The digitally networked world mediates race and ethnicity–and vice-versa. We will challenge racism and discrimination manifested in social media, changing notions of identity and group belonging, ewaste, gaming, big data, and more.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Politics of Men and Masculinity in U.S. Culture (3)
desc: Examines American understandings of man, manhood, and masculinity, at the intersection of gender, race, class, and sexuality in the context of American nation and empire building in the 19th and 20th centuries. A-F only. Pre: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, or WGSS 202; or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 456)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Food, Culture, and Empire in U.S. and Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Examines the cultural, historical, and political processes that have informed our understandings and practices involving food. We will analyze food and foodways in the U.S. and Hawai‘i. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: at least one course in WGSS or ES; or consent by instructor. (Cross-listed as AMST 448 and WGSS 450)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: WGSS
title: Food, Culture, and Empire in U.S. and Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Examines the cultural, historical, and political processes that have informed our understandings and practices involving food. We will analyze food and foodways in the U.S. and Hawai‘i. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: at least one course in WGSS or ES; or consent by instructor. (Cross-listed as AMST 448 and ES 450)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainability Capstone (3)
desc: Capstone for undergraduate students in interdisciplinary studies focusing on sustainability. The capstone experience provides an opportunity for students to gain knowledge and research experience in an applied setting. Repeatable one time. IS majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: REL
title: Religion and Food (3)
desc: Writing-based seminar exploring foodways as a basic component in the practice of religions. Examines theoretical issues, foodways as creators of community and identity, sustainability, and other ethical issues, abstinence and fasting, and healing. Pre: 150. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Ka Baibala ‘Ôlelo Hawai‘i (The Bible in Hawaiian) (3)
desc: Survey of and selected readings from the Hawaiian Bible (Baibala Hemolele). Conducted in Hawaiian. Repeatable one time. Pre: HAW 201.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: PH
title: Tobacco & Community Disparities (3)
desc: Assessing the facilitators and barriers of smoking initiation, cessation, and exposure to second-hand smoke within communities. Use of photovoice and its application to policy and addressing disparities. A-F only. Pre: 201.
metadata: DS Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PHIL
title: Understanding Place: Philosophical Inquiry and Community (3)
desc: Uses tools of philosophical inquiry, specifically p4cHI pedagogy, to develop a deep understanding of lived environment in a Hawaiian context while drawing on urban planning theories and methods to empower students as agents of change. Repeatable one time. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL or PLAN, or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: MUS
title: Curtain Up! Broadway Musicals, Then and Now (3)
desc: Traces the history of the Broadway musical in a survey of works from the mid-1800s through the recent “Hamilton” phenomenon, and explores their developmental process, structure, and sociocultural, religious, and political contexts. Pre: 106 or consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 362)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Music (MUS)

subject: LING
title: Philippine Sociolinguistics: Language Use, Ideologies, and Identities (3)
desc: Examines the intersection between language and society, specifically Philippine languages in various communities. Explores how language policies, discourses, and ideologies shape people’s use of language. Emphasis on developing oral communication and written skills. Sophomore standing or higher. (Cross-listed as IP 394)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: IP
title: Philippine Sociolinguistics: Language Use, Ideologies, and Identities (3)
desc: Examines the intersection between language and society, specifically Philippine languages in various communities. Explores how language policies, discourses, and ideologies shape people’s use of language. Emphasis on developing oral communication and written skills. Sophomore standing or higher. (Cross-listed as LING 394)
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: SOC
title: Criminal Justice Organizations (3)
desc: Examines major criminal justice organizations–police, courts, and prisons. Using organizational theory, identifies the role of organizational goals, structure, resources, legitimacy, culture, and front-line workers in shaping criminal justice policy and practice. Pre: 100 or a 200-level SOC course, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: ES
title: The Sounds of Race and Inequality (3)
desc: Explore inequality as manifested and contested in silence, music, dialect, nature, voice, and acoustic space by listening through a matrix of race, ethnicity, gender, class, and sexualities. Combination of hands-on work and current scholarship.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Sports (3)
desc: Explores sports from anthropological viewpoint: biological, cultural, linguistic, and archaeological. Open to nonmajors. Sophomore standing only.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: SUST
title: Strategies in Hawaiian Resource Use (3)
desc: Analyzing diverse land and water use strategies of O‘ahu, from traditional Hawaiian, scientific and economic perspectives, through classroom and on-site lectures. Topics include traditional Hawaiian methods, modern development, threatened ecosystems, ecotourism and scientific research. A-F only. Pre: 217/HWST 207 or 317/HWST 307 or SUST/HWST/356. (Cross-listed as HWST 459).
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: LWPA
title: Human Rights in Asia (V)
desc: Offered to provide advanced human rights courses at the Law School. The purpose is to convey an understanding of the current situation concerning human rights in Asia, and to facilitate a chance to think about what the future may bring.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Contracts (V)
desc: Law of private agreements. Focuses on common law doctrines with some attention to key Uniform Commercial Code provisions. Examines the bases of promissory liability, contract formation, defenses to enforcement, contract interpretation, breach, and remedies. (Fall only)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: PLAN
title: Facilitation: Facilitating Community and Organizational Change (3)
desc: Advanced conflict resolution course. Covers key issues in the prevention, management and resolution of multiparty conflicts. Combined lecture, discussion, and simulations. A-F only. Graduate students only or departmental approval. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as PACE 668)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to International and Global Studies (3)
desc: Introduces undergraduate students to the major political, social, economic, cultural, technological, and historical dimensions of globalization. Special attention will be paid to globalization process that have impacted Hawai‘i and the Asia-Pacific region. A-F only. (Cross-listed as POLS 160) FGB
metadata: FGB College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: BIOL
title: Biology of the Invertebrates Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Pre: 172 and CHEM 161, or consent. Corequisite: 485.
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: PHIL
title: The Meaning of War (3)
desc: Exploration of ethical questions related to the many facets of war–e.g., patriotism, tribalism, holy war, self-sacrifice, cowardice, media coverage, propaganda, torture, genocide, pillage, suicide tactics, battlefield immunity. (Cross-listed as PACE 387)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: SUST
title: Scientific Principles of Sustainability (3)
desc: Introduction to the scientific principles of sustainability, including the ecology of managed and natural ecosystems, global change biology, ecological principles of natural resource management, renewable energy technologies, and the environmental impacts of humans. (Cross-listed as NREM 251 and TPSS 251)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: MBBE
title: Molecular Diagnostics: Principles and Practices (3)
desc:
Molecular diagnostics principles, comparative genomics, genome annotation and 
bio-informatics, phylogenetics, gene target selection, advanced primer, and probe design. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as PEPS 627)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: PEPS
title: Molecular Diagnostics: Principles and Practices (3)
desc: Molecular diagnostics principles, comparative genomics, genome annotation and bio-informatics, phylogenetics, gene target selection, advanced primer, and probe design. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as MBBE 627)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: ORE
title: Surf Science and Culture Lab (1)
desc: Practical laboratory dedicated to wave science covering generation, propagation, transformation, and coastal processes related to surfing and the ocean environment through technology. A-F only.
metadata: DY Ocean and Resources Engineering (ORE) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ORE
title: Surf Science and Culture (3)
desc: Introduction to wave science covering generation, propagation, transformation, and coastal processes related to surfing and the human interaction with the ocean using Western science and cultural perspectives. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: DP Ocean and Resources Engineering (ORE) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: CINE
title: Directing the Motion Picture (3)
desc: Students direct a narrative live-action short film from pre- through post-production, learning how to develop a directorial vision and how to implement it through storyboarding, scheduling, and collaborative skill sets. SCA majors only. Pre: 310, 350 and 370.
metadata: DA ACM: The School of Cinematic Arts (CINE) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ART
title: Art of India and South Asia (3)
desc: Art and architecture of South Asia in historical and cultural context. Art of India and South Asia. Pre: 175 or consent.
metadata: DH Art & Art History (ART) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: WGSS
title: Gender and Sport (3)
desc: Explores the influence of gender in sport from cultural, psychosocial, and political perspectives. Through extensive writing, students examine gendered experiences of participants, spectators, and employees in sports organizations. A-F only. Pre: one DS course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: AMST
title: Trans* Studies: Trans(feminine/ masculine/gender nonconforming/sexual) (3)
desc: Focus on various aspects of Trans* identities, biographies, cultural productions, and communities. It also addresses issues on racism, medical intervention, dating, societal condemnation, mental health, and incarceration. Junior standing or higher. (Cross-listed as WGSS 493)
metadata: DH American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: BIOL
title: The Biology of Fungi Lab (1)
desc: Will introduce the diversity, ecology, evolution, and biology of the Kingdom Fungi. Focus on our current understanding of fungal evolution and diversity and how fungi interact with environments and hosts. Pre: (430 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as BOT 430L and TPSS 432L)
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: TPSS
title: The Biology of Fungi Lab (1)
desc:
(1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to the morphology and life cycles of 
organisms in the Kingdom Fungi. Focus on learning how to identify a diversity of fungi based on macro- and microscopic features. Field trips to collect specimens. Pre: (BOT 430 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C. or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as BIOL 430L and BOT 430L)
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: SUST
title: Environmental Management Systems (3)
desc: Introduction to the process of developing Environmental Management Systems that address the principles outlined in ISO14001:2015. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as OCN 442 and TIM 462)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: TPSS
title: The Biology of Fungi (3)
desc:
Will introduce the diversity, ecology, evolution, and biology of the 
Kingdom Fungi. Focus on our current understanding of fungal evolution and diversity and how fungi interact with environments and hosts. Pre: (BOT 201, BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as BIOL 430 and BOT 430) DB
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: BIOL
title: The Biology of Fungi (3)
desc: Will introduce the diversity, ecology, evolution, and biology of the Kingdom Fungi. Focus on our current understanding of fungal evolution and diversity and how fungi interact with environments and hosts. Pre: (172, BOT 201) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Spring only) (Crosslisted as BOT 430 and TPSS 432)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: WGSS
title: Gender in Action Cinema (3)
desc: Investigates gender representation in the evolving genre of American action cinema through combined stylistic and cultural analysis, with special attention to the relationship of gendered action to categories of morality, race, class, and nation. Junior standing or consent. (Cross-listed as AMST 446)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: THEA
title: Experimental Art and Animation (3)
desc: Provides students an opportunity to experiment with new mediums while collaborating with artists from different backgrounds, such as art, theatre, dance, film, and animation. SCA, ART, THEA, DNCE majors only. Pre: ART 113 or CINE 216 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 353 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 356 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as CINE 314 and ART 315)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Theatre and Dance

subject: CINE
title: Experimental Art and Animation (3)
desc: Provides students an opportunity to experiment with new mediums while collaborating with artists from different backgrounds, such as art, theatre, dance, film, and animation. SCA, ART, THEA, DNCE majors only. Pre: 216 (or concurrent) or ART 113 or CINE/DNCE/THEA 353 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 356 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as ART 315 and THEA 314)
metadata: DA ACM: The School of Cinematic Arts (CINE) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: MBBE
title: Food Engineering (3)
desc: Principles and applications of thermodynamics, electricity, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, psychrometry, and material and energy balances of food processing and preservation. Pre: (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, PHYS 151 or PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as BE 411 and FSHN 411)
metadata: DP College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: THEA
title: Historic Costume and Decor (3)
desc: Overview of visual styles in fashion, textiles, architecture, ornament, and furniture for production and entertainment design through lecture, lab, and discussion.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Theatre (THEA)

subject: PHYL
title: Directed Reading or Research (V)
desc: Students will learn fundamental concepts and multiple techniques in molecular biology, physiology, and histology for cardiovascular research through the projects in the lab. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned to two credits only. Junior or senior standing only. CR/NC only.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHIL
title: Existentialism: Freedom, Being, Death (3)
desc: Introduction to the major thinkers and the fundamental concepts and debates of Existentialism, taking Existentialism as a global movement expressed not just in philosophical texts, but also in literature and film. A-F only.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: OCN
title: The Ethics of Climate Change and Geoengineering (3)
desc: Provide a scientific basis to examine the consequences of climate change and the proposed geoengineering solutions, and examine the fundamental ethical basis that underlies environmental policies. A-F only. Pre: 310. (Alt. years: spring) (Crosslisted as SUST 414)
metadata: Oceanography (OCN) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MUS
title: Introduction to Research in Music Education (3)
desc: Introduction to research techniques in music education, including topic selection, literature review, and presentation of information in written form. A-F only. MUS majors only. Graduate students only. Pre: 651 (with a minimum grade of B-)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Music (MUS)

subject: ME
title: Nanosystems (3)
desc: Fabrication, design, and analysis of physical systems, sensors, and actuators at the nanoscale and microscale, including electrostatic and electromagnetic interactions, signal transduction, and measurements. Course work will focus on literature review and integration of current research. Engineering majors only. Graduate students only. (Spring only
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: MATH
title: Key Elements of Topology (1)
desc: Key concepts of Topology for graduate students in mathematics; topological spaces; separation axioms, compactness, connectedness; continuity. MATH majors only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Key Elements of Linear Algebra (1)
desc: Key concepts of linear algebra for graduate students in mathematics. Specific topics include vector spaces, linear transformations, multilinear forms, and Jordan decomposition. May not receive credit for both MATH 411 and MATH 610. MATH majors only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: (Alpha) Career Skills for Graduate Students in Mathematics (1)
desc: Seminar addresses issues important in the career of a mathematician, beginning from their time in graduate school, through navigating the job market and on to their eventual work in industry or academia. (B) teaching. Repeatable unlimited times, repeatable one time for (B). MATH majors only.  Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: ICS
title: Deep Learning with Neural Networks (3)
desc: Graduate course on deep learning with artificial neural networks. Provides practical techniques for modeling image, video, text, and graph data with supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning approaches. Includes instruction in the latest software frameworks. Graduate students only. Pre: 635 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Virtual and Augmented Reality Programming (3)
desc: Students will learn to develop virtual reality and augmented reality applications with turnkey tools as well as through programming. Prior programming experience is not required for this course. Pre: any 110(Alpha) or 111 or CINE 215. (Cross-listed as CINE 419).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: HIST
title: Global History of Sport (3)
desc:
Explores the relationship between sport and society in historical perspective. Analyzes global processes of imperialism, nationalism, globalization, and international relations, 
and studies themes such as the politics of race, class, and gender.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: DNCE
title: Topics in Dance (V)
desc: Readings, research, and/or field and movement experiences. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: ATMO
title: Paleoclimate Model-Proxy Synthesis (3)
desc: Basics of Earth System Model development, parameterizations, intermodel variability and design of paleoclimate simulations. Types of proxies, tools and techniques for paleoclimate record development and reconstructions. Hypothesis testing and methods for proxy-model comparison studies. ATMO, GEO, EPET, NREM, OCN, and ORE majors only. Graduate students only. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ASAN
title: Telecom and the Internet in East Asia (3)
desc: Offers interdisciplinary approach to study of internet and telecommunications in East Asia. Examines growth and development of telecommunications networks in China, Japan, South and North Korea. Focuses on contemporary social media and government policy. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ART
title: Materials in Contemporary Art (3)
desc: Explores the physical, historical, symbolic, and contextual capacity of materials, as well as the mutually constitutive roles of artist and materials within the creative process. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Art & Art History (ART) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ART
title: Methods in Contemporary Art (3)
desc: Examines processes of inquiry and experimentation within studio practice. Students explore a range of research methods as a way to challenge habitual methodologies and expand notions of art and art making. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Art & Art History (ART) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ANTH
title: Islands as Model Systems: Human Biogeography of the Pacific (3)
desc: Applying the concept of islands as “model systems;” explores the impacts of human populations on the natural ecosystems of oceanic islands, and the reciprocal effects of anthropogenic change on human cultures. A-F only. Pre: 323 or consent.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Primate Behavioral Ecology (3)
desc: As primates are our closest living relatives, studying the range of variation in areas like life history, diet, communication, and social systems within the order primates can inform on how we ourselves evolved.
metadata: DB Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Indigenous Peoples and Cultures of North America (3)
desc: Survey of Indigenous peoples of North America. Integrates documentary records, ethnography, and archaeology to explore variability among native communities. Contemporary topics include political recognition and self-determination, health and education, and natural resources and economic development.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Historical Ecology of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: The Hawaiian socio-ecosystem is the product of centuries of human land use and resource exploitation. Explores the events and processes that have shaped the islands’ ecology and future sustainability. A-F only. (Cross-listed as SUST 204)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: CINE
title: Capstone Creative Production (3)
desc: Emphasis on advanced production skills in creating a capstone project in live-action fiction film, animation, documentary, or new media. Screenwriting students may also develop a feature screenplay or television pilot and series bible. Repeatable one time. SCA majors only. Pre: 405 or 410 or 420 or 455 or 475.
metadata: DA ACM: The School of Cinematic Arts (CINE) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Euclidean and NonEuclidean Geometries (3)
desc: Axiomatic geometry and introduction to the axiomatic method; Euclidean geometry; hyperbolic geometry, and other nonEuclidean geometries. Pre: 243 or 253A, and 321 (or concurrent); or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: SPED
title: Global and Historical Perspectives of Disability in the Media (3)
desc: Explores the history of disability representation across cultures. Emphasis is placed on examining evolving perceptions of disability as depicted in art, literature, print, film, and digital media. A-F only. FGB
metadata: FGB College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: PORT
title: Intensive Intermediate Portuguese (6)
desc: Intensive Intermediate Portuguese course covers content of 201 and 202 combined. Hybrid format combines 3 credits online and 3 credits face to face. Pre: 102 or 103. (Spring only)
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Portuguese (PORT)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Cultural and Literary Geographies (3)
desc:
Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, genres, or writers relating to space 
and place as the basis for literary inquiry. Topics may include migration, diaspora, and local histories. Repeatable one time. Pre: ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Cultural Identities and Literature (3)
desc:
Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, genres, and writers in relation to 
cultural identities such as race, ethnicity, class as the basis for literary inquiry. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: EDCS
title: Graduate Certificate Capstone (3)
desc: Independent study and/or seminar for students working on a capstone for a graduate certificate. Repeatable three times. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: STEM Pedagogy (V)
desc:
Introduction to STEM education pedagogy with emphasis on ethical issues and effective oral communication. Designed to 
integrate educational theory, pedagogy, content, and practical concerns into teaching practices in the STEM fields. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: LTEC
title: Design-Based Research in Education (3)
desc: Provides an introduction to design-based research in education. Reviews different design-based methods and guides students through the process of conducting original design-based research. Focuses on the gap between research and practice. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 667 (with a minimum grade of B) and 668 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: ME
title: Nanosystem and Microsystem Design (3)
desc: Fabrication, design, and analysis of physical systems, sensors, and actuators at the nanoscale and microscale. Microfabrication/nanofabrication, fabrication process design, electrostatistic and electromagnetic interactions, signal transduction, measurements. Course work will focus on process and system design. ENGR majors only. Pre: 331 (with a minimum grade of C-), 375 (with a minimum grade of C-), or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ICS
title: Programming Approaches to Software Quality Assurance (3)
desc:
Examination of best practices associated with developing and supporting software 
applications with respect to potential security risks. Will augment software engineering practices learned in other courses with the basic principles of cybersecurity. Pre: 314 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: EDEP
title: Applied Psychology: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: Coverage in-depth of some areas of theory and research. Repeatable to six credit hours. Pre: PSY 100. (Crosslisted as PSY 489)
metadata: DS College of Education Educational Psychology (EDEP)

subject: LLEA
title: Culture of Two Germanies: 1945-1989 (3)
desc: (taught in English) Literature, culture, and film of East and West Germany, 1945-1989. Credit cannot be earned for both LLEA 415 and GER 415. Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Literary Forms, Genres, and Media (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, or movements in literary forms, genres, and media. Repeatable one time. Pre: ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Theories and Methods of English Studies (3)
desc: Intensive study of questions, issues, traditions, and movements in the field of English Studies. Recommended for students planning to pursue postbaccalaureate degrees. Pre: ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Literature and the Environment (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of intersections between literature and the environment, including issues such as climate change, technology, pollution, land and land use, interspecies relationships. Pre: One ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Fiction (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the form, function, and development of fiction genres such as short story and the novel in English. Repeatable one time for different topics. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: SUST
title: Literacy Across the Disciplines (3)
desc: Explores theoretical and practical principles of literacy and sustainability across academic disciplines, investigating the role of language and literate practices of reading, writing, speaking, visualizing, and representing in social, cultural, and educational contexts. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Crosslisted as EDCS 608)
metadata: Sustainability (SUST)

subject: CLAS
title: Understanding Ancient Religions (3)
desc: Comparative and historical survey of the religious beliefs and practices in ancient times throughout Egypt, Mesopotamia, Syria-Canaan, Anatolia, Persia, Greece, and Rome. A-F only. (Cross-listed as REL 211)
metadata: DH Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: REL
title: Understanding Ancient Religions (3)
desc: Comparative and historical survey of the religious beliefs and practices in ancient times throughout Egypt, Mesopotamia, Syria-Canaan, Anatolia, Persia, Greece, and Rome. A-F only. (Cross-listed as CLAS 211)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: ARCH
title: Beginning Design Studio I (4)
desc: Exploration of critical judgment and means to conceptualize, develop, represent, and both visually and orally communicate form and space, including freehand drawing, mechanical drawing, physical model making, diagramming, and computer graphic techniques. ENVD majors only. A-F only. Pre: 102.
metadata: DA Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: Design Fundamentals Studio II (4)
desc: Continued exploration of design processes. Introduction to CAD technologies, material exploration, and creative exploration including the relationship between digital, physical, and materials aspects of design. ENVD majors only. A-F only. Pre: 101.
metadata: DA Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: EDEF
title: Seminar in Comparative/International Education (3)
