desc: Advanced reading, research and writing in selected topics dealing with comparative and international education, including such themes as policy studies, minority education and educational reform. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Educational Foundations (EDEF)

subject: EDEF
title: History of American Higher Education (3)
desc: Genesis and evolution of college and university from
metadata: College of Education Educational Foundations (EDEF)

subject: EDEF
title: Recent History of American Education (3)
desc: Contemporary American education in recent historical perspective; focuses on the educational changes brought about by WW II, the Cold War, civil rights and other social movements. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Educational Foundations (EDEF)

subject: EDEF
title: Education and Social Change (3)
desc: Study of classical and contemporary theories of social change as these relate to school, the profession of teaching, planning of change, and social stability. Pre: consent
metadata: College of Education Educational Foundations (EDEF)

subject: EDEF
title: Education in the Classical Tradition (3)
desc: Classical European, Chinese, Indic, and Islamic traditions in the history of education; emphasis on ways in which they shift, interact, and collide from the early modern period to the present.
metadata: College of Education Educational Foundations (EDEF)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to Data Analysis (3)
desc: Basic analytic skills widely used in quantitative analysis of social science data, including descriptive statistics, rates and probability, comparison of groups, introduction to causal relationships, and application of these techniques to real life examples. A-F only.
metadata: FQ College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: ARCH
title: Introduction to the Built Environment (3)
desc: Introduction to the breadth of design in today’s global culture. Exploration of human responses to place, climate, culture, communication, and technology, with emphasis on the impact of scientific knowledge on environmental design. Open to nonmajors. A-F only.
metadata: DS Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: NREM
title: Sustainable Nutrient Management in Agroecosystems (4)
desc:
(3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Biological, chemical, and physical processes governing the cycling of nutrients in agroecosystems, crop and livestock production, and the effects on surrounding unmanaged 
ecosystems. Pre: (TPSS 304 and CHEM 161) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent. (Cross-listed as TPSS 450) DB
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Natural Resources and Environmental Management (NREM)

subject: EDEF
title: The History of Education in Hawai‘i From Pre-contact to Statehood (3)
desc: History of educational though and practices from pre-contact Hawaii through statehood. Social, intellectual, political, and cultural influences on indigenous, territorial, and state educational institutions; emphasis on white-settler colonialism, multiculturalism, assimilation, resistance, indigenous, and immigrant experiences. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Spring only
metadata: College of Education Educational Foundations (EDEF) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: AMST
title: American Experience: Culture and the Arts (3)
desc: Literature and modern media; visual and performing arts; material culture and architecture; foodways and ritual as meaning-making processes that have shaped the diverse identities, spaces, and communities of the Americas. Writing emphasis, interdisciplinary perspectives.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: WGSS
title: (Alpha) Research Seminar in Chinese Literature (3)
desc: Study of authors, a genre, a period, or a problem. (M) modern; (T) traditional. Repeatable one time for (M). A-F only for (M). Pre: 613, 615, 650, or EALL 611; or consent for (M); CHN 612 or consent for (T). (Cross-listed as CHN 753 (Alpha))
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Research in Feminist Studies: Capstone Experience (2)
desc: Provide women’s studies graduate certificate students with an opportunity to design, develop and complete a research project culminating in a publishable quality work and a professional quality seminar presentation. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender: Law and Conflicts (V)
desc: Examines how international law and domestic legal systems address and resolve conflicts regarding women’s rights, gender roles, and gender identity. Takes a comparative approach with emphasis on the Asia-Pacific region. (Cross-listed as LAW 547 and PACE 637)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Feminist Criminology (3)
desc: Key themes in feminist criminology are explored including focus on masculinities and crime, race and intersectionality, global criminology, and the ways in which the criminal justice system controls women and girls. A-F only. (Cross-listed as SOC 625)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Topics in Feminist Social Policy Research (3)
desc: Feminist social scientists from a variety of fields have explored issues of gender, social change and social justice. Draws from their work to critically examine strategies for conducting social policy research that is feminist in values and impact. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Feminism and Its “Others” (3)
desc: Relationship between feminist and other sites of critical insight and scholarship that have contributed to creating anticolonial, antiracist, antihomophobic theory, method and action. Questions the legacy of feminist coalition practices and engages the ongoing transformations that have begun to produce new alliances and coalitions that disrupt traditional boundaries of identity and power. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Writing and Publishing in an Interdisciplinary Field (3)
desc: Writing-intensive and publishing-focused class, students learn how to publish in an interdisciplinary field. Readings and assignments are designed to help students succeed in academic publishing. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Feminist Theory (3)
desc: Selected ideas from contemporary feminist theory concerning power, knowledge, and self; articulating women’s voice; deconstructing gender. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as POLS 615C)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Feminist Research and Methods of Inquiry (3)
desc: Examination of an emergent body of literature about how to shape questions concerning gender, sex, race, class, colonialism, and other vectors of power. Includes methods from social sciences and humanities and debates in the philosophy of science. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women in American Culture (3)
desc: Historical/contemporary status of women in the U.S.; women’s roles as defined by legal, educational, political, economic, and social institutions; implications for social science method. (Cross-listed as AMST 612)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Faculty Seminar Series (1)
desc: Seminar/discussion to introduce students pursuing the Graduate Certificate to the Woman’s Studies faculty and their areas of research, and to initiate student’s graduate studies in a woman’s studies field. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Transnational Feminist Teaching and Research (3)
desc: Introductory graduate seminar designed to develop common vocabulary and explore the core debates in transnational feminist teaching and research to encourage critical reflection about teaching assumptions, approaches, and techniques in the contemporary college or university environment. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable one time, up to six credits. WS students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Teaching Women’s Studies (3)
desc: Strategies for teaching women’s studies; addressing complex issues of gender, race, nation, class, sexuality and culture in a contemporary multiethnic campus environment. Emphasis on classroom techniques, teaching pedagogies, and hands-on experience. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 151 and one or more WS course with a grade of B or better in all relevant courses, instructor recommendation; or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Selected Topics (3)
desc: Problems and issues for reading and research: feminist theory, criticism, affirmative action, etc. Repeatable two times. Pre: any WS course in appropriate area.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Trans* Studies: Trans(feminine/masculine/ gender nonconforming/sexual) (3)
desc: Focus on various aspects of Trans* identities, biographies, cultural productions, and communities. It also addresses issues on racism, medical intervention, dating, societal condemnation, mental health, and incarceration. Junior standing or higher. (Cross-listed as AMST 437)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Revolution (3)
desc: Conditions under which women’s activism and participation in protest and revolutionary movements developed in the 19th- and 20th-centuries. Cross-cultural comparisons. (Cross-listed as ASAN 492 and HIST 492)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Social Sciences Internship (V)
desc: Internship in public, private, or non-profit organizations providing opportunity for practical experience and application of social sciences concepts and theories. Three to six credits per semester; repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. Consent of instructor. (Cross-listed as SOC 494 and SOCS 489)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Studies in Literature and Sexuality and Gender (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected problems and issues in the construction and representation of sexuality and gender in specific genres, social and cultural contexts, thematic or figurative clusters. Repeatable one time. Pre: ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent. (Cross-listed as ENG 482)
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Film (3)
desc: Exploration of film as a philosophical and artistic form in the context of gender, race, and sexuality. Pre: one of 151, 175, 176, or THEA 201; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Science, Sex, and Reproduction (3)
desc: Explores anthropology’s critical analysis of approaches to reproductive health and procreation, primarily in developing countries. Examines sex and reproduction as sites of intervention from public health, development, and biomedical specialists, while also considering local strategies. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 151 or ANTH 152 or ANTH 301. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as ANTH 465)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender Issues in Asian Society (3)
desc: Construction of gender identities in contemporary Asia. How these interface with other aspects of social difference and inequality (e.g. with class, religion, ethnicity). (Cross-listed as ASAN 463)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Globalization in Asia (3)
desc: History, culture, and contemporary reality of Asian women in Asia and the U.S. Includes critical analysis of American feminist methodology and theory. Pre: one of 360, 361, 439, AMST 310, AMST 316, AMST 318, AMST 373, AMST 455, POLS 339; or consent. (Crosslisted as AMST 438 and POLS 372)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Feminism, Nation and Empire (3)
desc: Examines U.S. feminist movements in the 19th and 20th century by exploring how U.S. racism, nationalism and imperialism have provided the context from which feminism emerged. A-F only. Pre: 151, 360; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Politics of Men and Masculinity in U.S. Culture (3)
desc: Examines American understandings of man, manhood, and masculinity, at the intersection of gender, race, class, and sexuality in the context of American nation and empire building in the 19th and 20th centuries. A-F only. Pre: one of 151, 175, 176, or 202; or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 457)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender, Sexuality, and Global Popular Culture (3)
desc: A study of gender, race, and sexuality as constructed in contemporary global popular culture, including music, films, novels, television shows, and internet culture. A-F only. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender Issues in Education (3)
desc: Examines historical and current gender issues in education as they intersect with ethnicity and class. We pay close attention to the writing process and the skills needed to compose a well-written research paper. Pre: 151 or consent. (Cross-listed as EDCS 453 and EDEF 453)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: VIET
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: VIET
title: Introduction to Vietnamese Literature (3)
desc: Selected readings in major genres; emphasis on analysis. Modern literature. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: VIET
title: Fourth-Level Vietnamese (3)
desc: Continuation of 401. Pre: 401 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: VIET
title: Fourth-Level Vietnamese (3)
desc: Continuation of 302. Emphasis on cultural understanding through modern literary Vietnamese. Pre: 302 or equivalent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: VIET
title: Third-Level Vietnamese (3)
desc: Continuation of 301. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: VIET
title: Third-Level Vietnamese (3)
desc: Continuation of 202. Emphasis on increased proficiency and cultural understanding through interaction with Vietnamese media, including newspapers, radio, film, etc. Pre: 202 or equivalent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: VIET
title: Intermediate Vietnamese II (3)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201 or consent.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: VIET
title: Intermediate Vietnamese I (3)
desc: Continuation of 102. After completion, most students should be able to use all major sentence patterns to produce sounds, combinations of sounds, tones, and intonation and have some understanding of Vietnamese culture. Pre: 102 or equivalent.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: VIET
title: Elementary Vietnamese II (3)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101 or consent.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: VIET
title: Elementary Vietnamese I (3)
desc: Listening, speaking, reading, writing. Structural points introduced inductively. Meets one hour, three times a week.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Vietnamese (VIET)

subject: URDU
title: Reading and Writing in Urdu (1)
desc: Introduces students to the Nastaliq (Urdu) script, alphabets, their various forms, and combination rules. Reading and writing is emphasized. A-F only. Pre: HNDI 102 or consent. Co-requisite: HNDI 201 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Urdu (URDU)

subject: PLAN
title: Dissertation Research (1)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. S/U only. PhD student only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Urban Design Studio (6)
desc: Group experience in defining urban and regional design problems and potentials, developing and evaluating alternatives, formulating strategies for implementation. PLAN and ARCH majors only. A-F only. Pre: (600 and 601) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Directed Project (V)
desc: Individual project in analysis, plan preparation and evaluation, and policy/ program evaluation. PLAN majors only. Pre: 600, 601; and consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Planning Practicum (6)
desc: Team experience in defining and addressing a current planning problem; identification, substantive review, research design, preparation and presentation of analysis. Topic varies. Limited to 10 students. Pre: 600, 601; and consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Seminar in Planning Practice (3)
desc: Project planning, programming, and similar topics. Pre: 600 and 601, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Seminar in Planning Theory (3)
desc: Special topics in theory, history, analysis. Pre: 600 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Homeland Security: Terrorism (3)
desc: Combined lecture/discussion in disaster management and humanitarian assistance track focusing on developing a multidisciplinary understanding of international terrorism and anti-terrorism planning and response. Pre: 670 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Limited to MURP students under Plan A. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent of instructor and department chair.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Land Use Management and Control (V)
desc: Survey course of public land use management. (Cross-listed as LAW 580)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Site Planning (3)
desc: Fundamental principles that guide site planning, including planning and design determinants of the site taking into account its regional context, site-specific characteristics and applicable codes, ordinances, and standards. PLAN and ARCH majors only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Historic Preservation Planning (3)
desc: Local-level historic preservation, with an emphasis on historic districts, design guidelines, regulatory controls, and community consensus-building. (Cross-listed as ARCH 677)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Recording Historic and Cultural Resources (3)
desc: Techniques in recording and evaluation of historic buildings and other resources, with an emphasis on field recordings and state and federal registration procedures. Graduate students only or consent. (Cross-listed as ANTH 676 and ARCH 676)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Preservation: Theory and Practice (3)
desc: History and philosophy of historic preservation movement. Analysis of values and assumptions, methodologies and tactics, implications for society and public policy. (Cross-listed as ARCH 628)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Disaster Recovery: Theory and Practice (3)
desc: How do communities recover from disaster? Provides students with an overview of recovery theory and an understanding of how planners, policy makers, and ordinary citizens rebuild communities, cities, and nations following catastrophic events. A-F only. Graduate standing only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Information Systems for Disaster Management and Humanitarian Assistance (3)
desc: Combined lecture/laboratory in disaster management focusing on essential methodological and practical issues that are involved in spatial analyses using GIS and other information technologies to inform decision making related to natural hazards, disasters, and human attempts to respond to these through mitigation and planning activities. Pre: 473 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Humanitarian Assistance: Principles, Practices and Politics (3)
desc: Combined lecture/ discussion aimed at understanding the theoretical basis and working structure of humanitarian assistance programs and international responses to natural and human-induced disasters. Pre: 670 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Disaster Science: Understanding Hazards and Disasters (3)
desc: Combined lecture/ discussion focusing on the scientific understanding of the forces and processes underlying natural hazards; and human attempts to respond to these through mitigation and and planning. Pre: 670 or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ERTH 604)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Interdisciplinary Seminar in Disaster Management and Humanitarian Assistance (3)
desc: Overview to the field of disaster management and humanitarian assistance with a specific focus on risk reduction. Includes background knowledge and skills for preparedness, response, recovery, mitigation, and adaptation to hazards and threats. Graduate students only or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Collaboration Between Sectors (3)
desc: Examine theories and practices of multisector collaboration (public, private, nonprofit). The use of collaboration as an alternative way of solving public problems. (Cross-listed as PACE 661)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Planning Research Methods (3)
desc: Advanced methods and deterministic and stochastic models used in urban and regional planning.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Applied Geographic Information Systems: Public Policy and Spatial Analysis (3)
desc: Use of advanced and specialized spatial methods and models in urban and regional planning. Uses GIS software and builds upon 601. Skills are useful applied to planning, economic development, and environmental planning and resource management. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Policy Implementation and Program Evaluation (3)
desc: Implementation and evaluation in public policy analysis; philosophical and methodological issues; impact of policies and plans; use of evaluation research in program implementation.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Research Design Seminar (3)
desc:
Research design and preparation of thesis proposal. Normally 
taken after admission to candidacy in MURP. Pre: (600 or 601 or 603) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Asian Cities: Historical Evolution of Urban Form (3)
desc: Examination of the impact of economy, society, and history on urban form; case studies of the evolution of Asian urban form. Pre: 310 or ASAN 312. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ASAN 649)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Urban Transportation Policy and Planning (3)
desc: Theory and practice of urban transportation planning in developed and developing countries with an emphasis on the U.S., Asia, and Pacific region. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Urban and Regional Planning for Sustainability (3)
desc: Focus on ideology, conceptual models, accounting frameworks, appropriate technologies, and indicators of planning for sustainability. Central and local policies, plans, and best practices in various countries and settings will be covered. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Cross-listed as SUST 647)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Land Use Planning (3)
desc: Issues and methods of urban land use planning practice and plan making. A-F only. (Cross-listed as ARCH 641)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Project Planning and Management (3)
desc: Examines project management in theory and practice and the roles and responsibilities of the project manager. Focuses on planning, organizing, and controlling the efforts of projects. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Planning Urban Infrastructure (3)
desc: Introduction to the planning of various urban infrastructures. Explores approaches and tools to plan, evaluate, and regulate urban infrastructure systems in support of sustainable and resilient cities and communities.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Neighborhood and Community Land Use Planning (3)
desc: Land use planning for urban neighborhoods and small towns. Theory and practice of neighborhood planning. Neighborhood and community dynamics, reinvestment, and stabilization.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Land Use Policies and Programs (3)
desc: Land use public policy planning in urban and regional settings. Growth management and land use guidance systems. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Community-based Natural Resource Management (3)
desc: Concepts and theories of community, resource access, and governance. Practical challenges to CBNRM in contemporary political economy. Graduate students only. (Cross-listed as GEO 639)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Environment and Development (3)
desc: Theories and practice of development; how changing development paradigms shape different ideas concerning the environment and the management of natural resources; emerging debates in development and environment in post-modern era. (Cross-listed as GEO 637)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Culture & Urban Form in Asia (3)
desc: Cultural and historical impact on urban form, contention of tradition and modernity in urban space, spatial expression of state and society, perception and utilization of urban design, evolution of urban form in selected Asian capitals. Pre: 310, 600, or ASAN 312. (Cross-listed as ARCH 687 and ASAN 636)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Shelter and Services in Asia (3)
desc: Examines government and non-government organizations’ responses to urban and rural shelter issues and services in Asia.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Globalization and Urban Policy (3)
desc: Urbanization and urban policies in the Asia and Pacific region with focus on the international dimension of national and local spatial restructuring.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Planning in Hawai‘i and Pacific Islands (3)
desc: Urban and regional planning in island settings. Experiences in Hawai‘i, Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. Graduate students only. (Cross-listed as SUST 632)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Urban and Regional Planning in Asia (3)
desc: Key issues and policies in urban planning, rural-urban relations, rural regional planning, and frontier settlement in Asia and the Pacific. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Negotiation & Conflict Resolution (3)
desc: Negotiation as a foundational skill of conflict resolution; mastery of negotiation skills for strategic dispute resolution; non-routine problem-solving, creating partnerships and alliances; crafting optimal agreements. Students participate in simulations and acquire vital leadership skills. Graduate standing only. Pre: one of the following courses with a minimum grade of B: 627; or PACE 429, PACE 447, PACE 477, PACE 647, PACE 652, or PACE 668; or COMG 455 or SOC 730; or LAW 508; or MGT 660. (Cross-listed as PACE 629)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Urban Environmental Problems (3)
desc: Seminar that examines environmental problems associated with urbanization. Reviews strategic approaches and collaboration among key actors to address such problems. (Cross-listed as SUST 628)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Negotiation and Mediation in Planning (3)
desc: Applicability and limitations of selected approaches; role of planners; impact on planning.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Topics in Resource Management (3)
desc: for different resource systems including land, water, energy, coastal resources, forests and fisheries. Course focus varies from year to year. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Climate Change, Energy and Food Security in the Asia/Pacific Region (3)
desc: Analysis of planning responses to human-induced climate change and related environmental problems. Part of the Asia/Pacific Initiative taught in collaboration with universities throughout the region via videoconferencing. (Cross-listed as SUST 625)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Environmental Valuation and Policy (3)
desc: Build valuation skills to assess best use, conservation, and policies relating to environmental amenities. Provides an overview of policy solutions to environmental degradation used by planners.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Advanced Environmental Impact Assessment (3)
desc: Theory and practice of environmental impact assessment. Policy and planning frameworks supporting environmental assessment in the U.S. and abroad. Cumulative environmental effects and strategic environmental assessment. (Cross-listed as GEO 622)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Environmental Conflict Resolution (3)
desc: Explore how environmental conflicts emerge and the efforts to find common ground for resolution. Examine the issues, debates, and theoretical aspects that help to explain and frame environmental conflict. Graduate students only. (Cross-listed as PACE 621)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Environmental Planning and Policy (3)
desc: Overview of urbanization and environmental change. An examination of environmental laws, policies, planning and urban design strategies designed to minimize and mitigate urban impacts. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Cross-listed as SUST 620)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Multiculturalism in Planning and Policy (3)
desc: Graduate seminar focuses on issues of governance, policy and planning in diverse multicultural societies. Differences in backgrounds, languages, privilege, preferences and values are often expressed in planning and policy controversies such as affirmative action and land use planning. Will examine these controversies and explore theories of governance in a multicultural setting.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Community Economic Development (3)
desc: Community-based economic development approaches and methods explored with an emphasis on low income communities. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Community-Based Planning (3)
desc: Planning and programmatic aspects of community-based development projects. East-West and local planning perspectives on participatory development and intentional communities.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Housing (3)
desc: Housing delivery systems as an aspect of urban and regional planning.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Community Planning and Social Policy (3)
desc: Social issues and conditions; consequences of social policies experienced by different groups; community social plans and programs organized by various kinds of agencies and organizations. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Politics and Development: China (3)
desc: Consists of three parts: key theories for socialist transition as basis for seminar discussion, policy evolution to illustrate the radical changes, and emerging and prominent current development and practice. (Cross-listed as ASAN 608 and POLS 645C)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Introduction to Public Policy (3)
desc: Perspectives on policy analysis; basic approaches to the study of public policy, political economy, and policy evaluation. (Cross-listed as POLS 670)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Comparative Planning Histories (3)
desc: Provides students with an overview of the history of urban and regional planning in the U.S., Europe, and Asia, and the role that planning has played in shaping contemporary urban settlements. Graduate standing only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Planning Models (3)
desc: Allocation, decision, derivation, and forecasting models used in the analysis of demographic, economic, land use, and transportation phenomena in urban and regional planning. Repeatable one time. PLAN majors only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Qualitative Methods in Planning (3)
desc: Provides a general introduction to qualitative research methods for planning and planning research. Includes data collection methods (focus groups, interviews, ethnography, participant observation, and participatory action research) and various analytic methods and approaches. Graduate standing only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Urban Economics (3)
desc: Reviews and builds skills in applying basic theories and principles of urban and regional economics in contemporary U.S., Hawai‘i and Asia-Pacific. Repeatable one time. PLAN majors only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Advanced Planning Theory (3)
desc: Advanced planning theory for PhD students (others by petition) to prepare for careers in planning education and/or high level professional practice. Covers key contemporary planning policy issues and themes from the perspective of values, explanations of the real world, policy alternatives and implementation. Students must have passed 600 or equivalent (by petition) with a B or better. Repeatable one time. PhD students only or by consent. A-F only. Pre: 600 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Planning Methods (3)
desc:
Introduction of the basic methods in planning, including problem definition, research design, hypothesis testing, statistical reasoning, forecasting and fundamental data analysis techniques required by the planning program and the 
planning profession. Repeatable one time. PLAN and ARCH majors only. Pre: one of ECON 321, GEO 380, or SOC 476.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Public Policy and Planning Theory (3)
desc: Designed to a) impart a historic and comparative perspective on the evolution of urban and regional planning in public policy; b) explore the spatial and built environment dimensions of society, planning and policy; c) assess the justifications for planning and differing processes of planning in the U.S. and AsiaPacific with a focus on the role of the planner in policy formulation and implementation. Graduate students only or with permission. A-F only. Repeatable two times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Housing, Land, and Community (3)
desc: Analyzes availability for housing, particularly affordable housing, and its relationship to use of land and building of community. Examines public policies impacting housing, land use, and community development and ways they can be improved.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: GIS for Community Planning (3)
desc: Exploration of geographic information systems (GIS) area analysis techniques for spatial information management in community planning. Students will learn the basic concepts and principles, and practical skills of GIS through lectures, discussions, and labs. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Asian Cities: Evolution of Urban Space (3)
desc: Reviews the evolution of Asian urban space. Political history, migration, culture, and production are the determinants of urban changes. Uses visual material to illustrate the change in Asian cityscape. Pre: 310 or ASAN 310 or ASAN 312, or consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 449)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Principles of Environmental Management Systems (3)
desc: Introduction to the process of developing Environmental Management Systems that address the principles outlined in ISO14001:2015. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Sustainable Asian Development: Impact of Globalization (3)
desc: Investigates the impact of globalization on sustainable development in Asia. Globalization and sustainability often contradict, raising serious planning issues. Examines how these issues affect Asian development policies and urban planning. Pre: 310 or ASAN 310 or ASAN 312, or consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 438)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Urban Geography (3)
desc: Origins, functions, and internal structure of cities. Problems of urban settlement, growth, decay, adaptation, and planning in different cultural and historical settings. Dynamics of urban land use and role of policies and perceptions in shaping towns and cities. Pre: GEO 102 or GEO 151 or GEO 330, or consent. (Cross-listed as GEO 421)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Environmental Hazards and Community Resilience (3)
desc: Examines resilience thinking as it relates to making cities resilient to environmental hazards in the context of climate change. Draws on relevant theories, policy, and case studies in urban planning. Emphasis on instruction in writing. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Environmental Impact Assessment (3)
desc: Introduction to analytical methods for identifying, measuring, and quantifying the impacts of changes or interventions in resource, human-environment, and other geographic systems. Junior standing or higher, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Directed Reading in Planning (V)
desc: Independent research on topics in urban and regional planning. Pre: 310.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Introduction to Planning (3)
desc: Perspectives on planning; planning tools and methods; specific Hawai‘i planning–research problems from a multidisciplinary approach. Junior standing or higher or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Survey of Urban Sociology (3)
desc: Urban processes and social problems, such as poverty, crime, racial segregation, homelessness, housing policy, urbanization, and neighborhood ethnic diversity. How places shape identity and opportunity. Research methods applied to communities, places, and neighborhoods of Hawai‘i. Pre: SOC 100 or a 200-level SOC course, or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 301)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: PLAN
title: Sustainable Cities (3)
desc:
How do we plan cities to meet long-term social, economic, and 
environmental needs? Students will learn about sustainability as it relates to issues like energy, transportation, housing, land, water, and food. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. (Cross-listed as SUST 114)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Urban and Regional Planning (PLAN)

subject: UNIV
title: Collaborative Learning: Foundations of Tutoring (3)
desc: Theory and practice of collaborative learning in academic contexts. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent.
metadata: Office of Student Success University (UNIV)

subject: UNIV
title: Mānoa Peer Advisor Leader Training and Leadership Practicum (6)
desc: A reflective apprenticeship in which Peer Advisor Leaders solidify their understanding of advising and learn more about leadership and deepen their facilitation, communication, collaboration, and leadership skills by mentoring a cohort of peer advisor trainees. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: 350 (or equivalent course) (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only
metadata: Office of Student Success University (UNIV)

subject: UNIV
title: Mānoa Peer Advisor Training Course (6)
desc: Intensive course designed for peer advisor trainees to learn General Education requirements, university policies and procedures, and campus resources. Trainees also develop skills and strategies necessary to provide quality advising to their fellow students. A-F only (Summer only)
metadata: Office of Student Success University (UNIV)

subject: UNIV
title: Academic Exploration Through Advising (3)
desc: Major exploration designed to assist exploratory students in the process of researching personal, career, and educational goals through writing and the impact of these goals on the decision-making process. Emphasis on written self-reflection and identity. Sophomore standing. A-F only.
metadata: Office of Student Success University (UNIV)

subject: UNIV
title: Your Academic Journey (1)
desc: Provides exploratory students with the knowledge/skills to thrive in college and beyond. Utilizes writing as a tool for research, analysis, exploration, and reflection. Topics include major and career exploration, personal interests, and goal-setting. May not be taken concurrently or after UNIV 340. Freshmen and sophomores only. Exploratory designations only. A-F only.
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Office of Student Success University (UNIV)

subject: UNIV
title: Academic and Career Exploration (1)
desc: Seminar introduces exploratory students to major and career exploration resources, guides students in developing personal, academic, and career goals and plans, and encourages frequent self-reflection. Develops written communication skills. A-F only.
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence University (UNIV)

subject: UNIV
title: Academic and Personal Exploration (1)
desc: Seminar introduces students to goal setting, time management, major exploration, academic planning, service-learning opportunities, student/faculty meetings, financial literacy, and encourages frequent self-reflection. Instructor approval required. A-F only.
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence University (UNIV)

subject: UNIV
title: Passages (3)
desc: Interactive course develops mentoring skills and relationships with peers, mentors, and “elders.” Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (Summer only)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Office of Student Success University (UNIV)

subject: UNIV
title: Metacognitive Strategies for College Success (3)
desc: Theories of the memory processes and the application of the Information Processing Systems in developing metacognitive strategies for college classroom success. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Office of Student Success University (UNIV)

subject: TPSS
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Special Topics (V)
desc: Specialized topics from various areas of plant and soil research such as experimental techniques, growth regulation, morphogenesis, genetics and breeding, culture and nutrition of tropical crops. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: In-depth study of specialized problems. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/ NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Plan B Master’s Project (3)
desc: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in TPSS program.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Geospatial Analysis of Natural Resource Data (3)
desc: The application of geostatistics to estimate spatial dependence to improve soil and regional sampling; provide insight into underlying soil, geographic, and geologic process, and to provide quantitative scaling up of point measurements to fields, regions, and watersheds. State-space modeling also will be included. A-F only. Pre: GEO 388 or ZOOL 631; or consent. (Cross-listed as GEO 680)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Plant Growth and Development (3)
desc: Contemporary literature is used as the basis for understanding the physiology for whole plant growth and development. Aspects covered include vegetative and reproductive development, seed dormancy, senescence, abscission, and relevant biochemical and molecular processes. Pre: 470 and MBBE 402, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Sustainability of Food Systems (3)
desc: Explores sustainability and resilience of food systems with an emphasis on Hawaiʻi, using interdisciplinary approaches to assess impacts. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Graduate Seminar (1)
desc: Presentation of research reports; reviews of current literature in plant and soil sciences. Repeatable four times. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Orchidology (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Classification, culture, cytogenetics, breeding of orchids. Pre: consent. Recommended: 200/SUST 211 and 402.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Environmental Landscape Technologies and Systems (3)
desc: Understanding the science and art of green landscape technologies, with a comprehensive understanding of LID (low impact design) principles and practices; to increase knowledge to help produce more viable and enduring built landscapes. TPSS majors only. A-F only. (Cross-listed as ARCH 658)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Grant Writing for Graduate Students (1)
desc: Combined lecture/discussion on grants and grant writing. Designed to introduce graduate students to grants and grant proposal writing through lectures, class discussion, writing assignments, and peer review. Open to CTAHR graduate students only; others with consent. (Cross-listed as ANSC 657 and FSHN 657)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Environmental and Cultural Landscape Studio (4)
desc: Exploring, understanding, and implementing Hawaiian and Western cultural and environmental landscape design principles. A concentrated look at how to think about creating and respecting a sense of place through landscape design. TPSS and LAND majors only. A-F only. (Cross-listed as ARCH 656)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Communications in the Sciences (1)
desc: (3-hr Lec/Lab combination) Laboratory-type course for improving communication abilities in the sciences and engineering. Presentations to lay audiences are emphasized. Hands-on experience in techniques and methods is provided.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Information Research Skills (1)
desc: Examines the use of libraries and information technology for scholarly investigation in support of scientific research; provides experience utilizing and critically evaluating a variety of print and electronic sources in basic and applied sciences. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as ANSC 652, FSHN 652, and NREM 652)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Soil Plant Nutrient Relations (4)
desc: (2 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Soil-plant interactions, emphasis on characteristics of tropical soils and plants influencing nutrient uptake by plants. Diagnostic methods to identify nutrient deficiencies and element toxicity. Pre: 450 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (Cross-listed as NREM 650)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Advanced Soil Chemistry (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Physio-chemical processes in soils and soil solutions, with emphasis on ionic equilibria, mineral stability, organic complexation, and surface sorption of major plant nutrients and heavy metals. A-F only. Pre: 435 and CHEM 351, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Landscape Plants: Identification and Use (3)
desc: Introduction to the identification, recognition, and use of plants in landscape design and built environment applications. Students will be introduced to a variety of landscape plants commonly used in Hawai‘i and the tropics. TPSS majors only. A-F only. (Cross-listed as ARCH 634)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Quantitative Genomics and Evolution (3)
desc: Overview and lab-based course exploring theory and methods to understand genome evolution and adaptation; focus will be on a range of organisms. Pre: (453 and 603) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Molecular Genetics of Crops (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Applications of molecular genetics to crop improvement. Pre: (453 and MBBE 402) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Nutrition of Tropical Crops (3)
desc: (1 2-hr Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Mineral nutrition of plants in relation to plant metabolism, mechanisms of ion uptake, long-distance transport of solutes, and interactions at the root-soil interface. Special emphasis on problems associated with tropical crops. Pre: 450 and 470, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Advanced Soil Microbiology (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Study of biochemical and biogeochemical transformations mediated by soil microorganisms, emphasis on processes important to plant growth productivity and environmental quality. Pre: 304 and MICR 351, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Experimental Design (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Design of experiments and variance analyses in biological and agricultural research. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: ZOOL 632. (Cross-listed as ANSC 603)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Crop Modeling (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of modeling crop growth and development, model types, techniques, simulation. Modeling influence of climate/environment on phenology, growth, development of horticultural crops. Pre: 470 and NREM 310, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Directed Studies (V)
desc: Supervised individual instruction in field laboratory and library. Repeatable up to six credits. CR/NC only. Pre: 364 or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Internship (1)
desc: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Placement with an approved cooperating supervisor/employer. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Experimental Topics (V)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics, problems. Offered by visiting faculty and/or for extension programs. Repeatable. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Weed Science (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Weed classification, identification, adaptations for weediness; principles of weed control; properties, uses, and action of herbicides. Lab: pesticide application equipment and techniques, no-till farming, greenhouse and field experiments. A-F only. Pre: (200/SUST 211 and CHEM 152) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as PEPS 481) DB
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Life in the Soil Environment Lab (1)
desc: Laboratory to accompany 480. Technical examination of bacteria, fungi, protists, nematodes, arthropods, and other invertebrate, and the essential functional roles these organisms contribute to sustainability of the planet. Repeatable one time. Pre: BIOL 171L and 172L, or MICR 351L, or consent. Co-requisite: 480. (Crosslisted as BIOL 480L)
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Life in the Soil Environment (3)
desc: An interdisciplinary study of the diverse life in the soil beneath our feet that includes bacteria, fungi, protists, nematodes, arthropods, invertebrate, viruses, and the essential functional roles these organisms contribute to sustainability of the planet. Repeatable one time. Pre: TPSS/PEPS/SUST 371 or BIOL 375, or MICR 351, or consent. (Cross-listed as BIOL 480)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Plant Nutrient Diagnosis in the Tropics (3)
desc: Designed for students to identify essential nutrients required by plants; diagnose nutrient disorders in plants; and propose environmentally sound solutions to correct disorders. Pre: 304/NREM 304 (or concurrent) and BIOL 172. (Cross-listed as NREM 475)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Post-Harvest Physiology (3)
desc: Comparative physiological and biochemical processes during growth, maturation, ripening, and senescence in fruits, vegetables, and flowers related to changes in quality and storage life. Tropical commodities emphasized. A-F only. Pre: 200/SUST 211, BIOL 171, or BOT 201; CHEM 152; or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Principles of Plant Physiology Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Principles of experimentation in plant physiology, includes individual investigations. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Plant Physiology (3)
desc: Integration of form and function from cellular to whole plant levels in processes from seed germination, through photosynthesis, growth, and morphogenesis, to flowering and senescence. A-F only. Pre: BIOL 171 or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Irrigation and Water Management (3)
desc: Basic soil-water-plant relationships, irrigation water requirements, irrigation efficiencies, different methods of irrigation, planning, design and management of an irrigation system, fertigation and impact of irrigation on soil and water quality. Pre: NREM 203 (or equivalent) and NREM/TPSS 304 (or equivalent), or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as NREM 463)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Soil Plant Environment (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Bio-physical processes in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum that influence crop growth and development. Methods to estimate the impact of soil and climate on crop performance. Use of crop models to simulate effects of planting date, plant spacing and density, fertilizer rate, rainfall or irrigation, and daily weather on crop yield and farm income. Pre: 304 and either PHYS 151 or PHYS 170, or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Plant Breeding and Genetics (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Unique aspects of plant genetics and applications to crop improvement, with emphasis on breeding plants in Hawai‘i. Pre: BIOL 375 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Sustainable Nutrient Management in Agroecosystems (4)
desc:
(3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Biological, chemical, and physical processes governing the cycling of nutrients in agroecosystems, crop and livestock production, and the effects on surrounding unmanaged 
ecosystems. Pre: (304 and CHEM 161) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent. (Cross-listed as NREM 460) DB
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Tissue Culture/Transformation (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Application of plant tissue culture for plant scientists; study of the growth and development of plant tissues in culture as influenced by chemical and environmental factors, and the regeneration of plants following plant transformation by biolistics and other molecular approaches. Pre: 420 or consent.  DB
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Environmental Soil Chemistry (3)
desc: Study of soil chemical processes such as weathering, adsorption, precipitation, and ion exchange; causes of soil acidity, alkalinity, and salinity; reactions between soils and fertilizers, pesticides, or heavy metals. Management strategies to minimize environmental contamination by nitrate, phosphate, and trace elements such as As, Pb, and Se. A-F only. Pre: 304 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Indigenous Crops/Food Systems (1)
desc: Schemes for managing sequences and combinations of crops and crop production activities. Ecosystem and social determinants. Multiple cropping. Analysis of alternative cropping systems. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Nursery Management (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Management practices in production and operations of commercial nurseries in Hawai‘i. Pre: 200/SUST 211 and 364; or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business and Economic Analysis (3)
desc: Introduction to quantitative decision-making methods for effective agribusiness management in resource allocation, scheduling, logistics, risk analysis, inventory, and forecasting. Emphasis on problem identification, model formulation and solution, and interpretation and presentation of results. Pre: ECON 130 or NREM/ SUST 220, and ECON 321 or NREM 310; or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Tropical Seed Science (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of seed science, seed physiology, seed production, and genetic modification. Hawai‘i’s seed industry and biotechnology. A-F only. Pre: 364 (recommended) and 420 (recommended), or consent.
metadata: DB DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Plant Propagation (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Theoretical and applied aspects of seed and vegetative propagation technology involving fruits, flowers, vegetables, and landscape plants. Pre: 200/SUST 211 or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Turfgrass Pest Management (3)
desc: Provides students with knowledge and real world experience on common turfgrass pests and management strategies in Hawai‘i, with emphasis on integrated pest management. Common cool-season turfgrass and pest management are also discussed. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as PEPS 418)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Introduction to Social, Ethical and Political Issues Associated with Biotechnology (3)
desc: Introduces concepts of biotechnology, fundamental issues associated with use of this technology, with special emphasis on agricultural biotechnology. A-F only. Pre: 200/SUST 211 or BIOL 171 or NREM 210, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Extension Education & Outreach (2)
desc: Introduces an essential component of the Land Grant Mission. Students will explore the foundational components of extension education including agent expectations, program development and evaluation, audience engagement, building partnerships, funding structures. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Cross-listed as TAHR 415)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Sustainable Soil and Plant Health Management (2)
desc: Provides knowledge and understanding of soils, agroecology, and sustainable approaches for plant health management, and prepares students for applied research in various tropical cropping systems. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as PEPS 410 and SUST 410)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Cultural Biogeography (3)
desc: Co-evolution of human societies and plants over the last 10,000 years. Foraging, farming and urban societies economies; spread and modification of selected plants; issues of preservation of genetic resources and traditional plant knowledge. The form and function of gardens. Pre: junior standing or higher, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Turfgrass Management (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Adaptability and selection, establishment, and cultural practices of grasses for various types of turf. Pre: 200/SUST 211 or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Tropical Fruit Production (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Botanical aspects and horticultural management practices of selected tropical and subtropical fruit crops, with emphasis on small scale commercial production in Hawai‘i. Pre: 300 or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Flower and Foliage Crop Production (4)
desc: Biology and production of cut flowers, blooming potted plants, foliage plants under field and protected cultivation in Hawai‘i and globally. Pre: 300 or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Vegetable Crop Production (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Crop biology, requirements, and production techniques for commercial vegetable production in Hawai‘i will be stressed. Pre: 300 or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Genetics: Theory to Application (3)
desc: Fundamentals of genetic theory using traditional breeding and biotechnological procedures in insect and plant pathogen management for sustainable agricultural production. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Cross-listed as PEPS 371 and SUST 371)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Ornamental Plant Materials (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Identification, origin, use, and cultural requirement of trees, shrubs, vines, and groundcovers used in Hawaiian landscapes. Pre: 200/SUST 211 or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Horticulture: Theory and Practice (3)
desc: Techniques of culture and management of horticulture crops. Pre: consent.
metadata: DB DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Tropical Landscape Planting Design Studio (4)
desc: Students will develop basic skills of residential landscape graphic and design processes in order to clearly articulate the ability to think, analyze, and extend a physical solution in the proper scale. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as ARCH 354)
metadata: DA College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Landscape Graphics Studio (4)
desc: Basic skills of landscape graphic communication through a creative process model. Learning free hand and technical drafting techniques to creative effective landscape graphics. Pre: consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as ARCH 353)
metadata: DA College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Landscape Architecture History (3)
desc: Survey of the history of landscape architecture from Mesopotamia to present. Review of the physical, cultural, social, economic, and political factors, as well as the environmental concerns, horticultural techniques, and technological innovations of historic landscapes. A-F only. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as ARCH 352)
metadata: DH College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Enterprise Management (3)
desc: Introduction of practical concepts and methods used in business management. Introduce broad range of business strategies. Understand the critical role each strategy plays. Facilitate student’s practice of analytical and critical thinking through case studies. (Cross-listed as NREM 351)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Tropical Landscape Practices (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Concepts and techniques of landscape installation and management in the tropics. Pre: 200/ SUST 211 and 369; or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Managerial Accounting (3)
desc: Principles and methods of agricultural accounting. Preparing and interpreting financial statements. Sources and costs of credit, capital budgeting, tax management, estate planning. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, or consent. (Cross-listed as NREM 341)
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Renewable Energy and Society (3)
desc: Combined lecture/discussion regarding the ability of renewable energy technologies to meet local, national, and global energy demands and their potential impacts on the environment and society. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Farm & Food Marketing (3)
desc: Problems, agencies, functions, costs, prices, regulations affecting marketing: proposed improvements. Pre: ECON 130, NREM/SUST 220; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Current Topics in Plant Science (1)
desc: Undergraduate seminar that provides the presentation and discussion of topics of current relevance to students preparing for careers in applied plant sciences. Oral focus designation. A-F only. Pre: 200/ SUST 211 or NREM 210, or consent. (Cross-listed as NREM 311)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Fundamentals of Soil Science Laboratory (1)
desc: Field and analytical methods for exploring the origin, development, properties, and management of soils, with an emphasis on tropical and Hawaiian soils. A-F only. Pre: (CHEM 161 and CHEM 161L) with a minimum grade of C. Co-requisite: 304. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as NREM 304L)
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Fundamentals of Soil Science (3)
desc: Origin, development, properties, management of tropical soils; classification of Hawaiian soils. A-F only. Minimum prerequisite grade of C or consent. Pre: (CHEM 161 and 161L) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. Co-requisite: 304L. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as NREM 304)
metadata: DP College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Tropical Production Systems (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Comparisons and contrasts of crop management systems, techniques, and technologies in protected and open field production of tropical crops. Pre: 200/SUST 211 or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Scientific Principles of Sustainability (3)
desc: Introduction to the scientific principles of sustainability, including the ecology of managed and natural ecosystems, global change biology, ecological principles of natural resource management, renewable energy technologies, and the environmental impacts of humans. (Cross-listed as NREM 251 and SUST 251)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Organic Food Crop Production (2)
desc: Combined lecture/lab on the theory and practice of certified organic food production. Field visits to organic farms/markets included. Open to nonmajors. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as SUST 221)
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Aquaponics (3)
desc: Basic online course integrates aquaculture (raising fish and prawns) with hydroponics plant cultivation in water. Includes the basic design and construction of an aquaponics feed system. Repeatable one time. (Summer only)
metadata: DB DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Agriculture, Environment, and Society (3)
desc: Relationship of plants, soils, and the environment, and how they relate to cultural practices and society in agroecosystems with an emphasis on Hawai‘i as a model system. (Cross-listed as SUST 211)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Natural History Field Trips on Hawai‘i Island (1)
desc: Field trips for Natural history and Conservation of the Hawaiian Islands. A-F only. Co-requisite: 156. (Summer only)
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: Sustainable Food and Energy (Field Course) (V)
desc: Examines the nexus of food, energy, and water in Hawai‘i for sustainable development. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. (Cross-listed as SUST 156)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TPSS
title: (Alpha) Plants for People (1)
desc: The origins: social, cultural, and ceremonial traditions; culture; food and nutritional properties. Processing of a variety of tropical horticultural plants are presented, with tasting sessions and optional field trips. Topics will rotate among (B) beverage crops (e.g., coffee, tea, chocolate, kava, fruit juices); (C) herbs, spices, and flavoring (selection of examples to be determined); (D) tropical fruits (assortment offered depends on availability during semester); (E) ornamental plants (flowers, houseplants, popular landscape plans, bonsai, ethnic ornamentals). Does not count towards TPSS major. Pre: consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences (TPSS)

subject: TRMD
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral thesis. Approval of department faculty is required. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Tropical Medicine and Medical Microbiology (TRMD)

subject: TRMD
title: Special Topics in Tropical Medicine (V)
desc: Advanced instruction in frontiers of tropical medicine and public health. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Cross-listed as PH 756)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Tropical Medicine and Medical Microbiology (TRMD)

subject: TRMD
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Approval of department faculty required. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Tropical Medicine and Medical Microbiology (TRMD)

subject: TRMD
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Directed research in medical microbiology (bacteriology, parasitology, virology). Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Tropical Medicine and Medical Microbiology (TRMD)

subject: TRMD
title: Plan B Master’s Project (3)
desc: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in TRMD.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Tropical Medicine and Medical Microbiology (TRMD)

subject: TRMD
title: Seminar in Tropical Medicine and Public Health (1)
desc: Weekly discussion and reports on current advances in tropical medicine and public health. Repeatable unlimited times. (Cross-listed as PH 755)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Tropical Medicine and Medical Microbiology (TRMD)

subject: TRMD
title: Epidemiology of Tropical Infectious Diseases (3)
