metadata: DH Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Structure of Thai (3)
desc: Introduction to information structure of Thai as a basis for developing reading skills. Analysis of rhetorical, sentence, and word structure from different types of written texts. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: DH Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Thai Language in the Media (3)
desc: Development of reading and aural comprehension of authentic Thai language used in print and broadcast media through reading Thai newspapers, viewing and listening to Thai television and radio programs. Oral and written reports. Repeatable one time. Pre: 402, 404 (or equivalent), or consent.
metadata: Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Accelerated Fourth-Level Thai (6)
desc: Continuation of 303. Meets six hours a week. Advanced conversation and reading of specialized, scholarly texts. Pre: 303.
metadata: Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Fourth-Level Thai II (3)
desc: Continuation of 401. Pre: 401.
metadata: Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Fourth-Level Thai I (3)
desc: Continuation of 302/303. Advanced conversation and reading of specialized, scholarly texts. Pre: 302 or 303 or equivalent.
metadata: Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Accelerated Third-Level Thai (6)
desc: Continuation of 202. Meets six hours a week. Advanced conversation and reading; emphasis on modern written texts. Lab work. Pre: 202 or equivalent.
metadata: Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Third-Level Thai II (3)
desc: Continuation of 301. Pre: 301 or equivalent.
metadata: Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Third-Level Thai I (3)
desc: Continuation of 202. Advanced conversation and reading, emphasis on modern written texts. Regular on-line lab work. Pre: 202 or equivalent or consent.
metadata: Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Intensive Intermediate Thai (10)
metadata: HSL Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Second-Level Thai II (3)
desc: Continuation of 201. Integrated development of skills in listening, speaking, reading and writing in Thai script. Pre: 201 or consent.
metadata: HSL Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Second-Level Thai I (3)
desc: Continuation of 102. Integrated development of skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Thai script.  Pre: 104 and 106, or 102 .
metadata: HSL Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Elementary Thai II (3)
desc: Continuation of 101. Emphasizes reading, writing, listening, and speaking modern standard Thai. Structural points are introduced inductively. Regular on-line lab work and review of audiovisual materials. Pre: 101, or 103 and 105, or consent.
metadata: HSL Thai (THAI)

subject: THAI
title: Elementary Thai I (3)
desc: First semester of elementary Thai. Emphasis on the development of communicative competence in both oral and written language and exposes students to the culture of Thailand.
metadata: HSL Thai (THAI)

subject: TAHT
title: Fourth-Level Tahitian Abroad (3)
desc: Continuation of 458. A-F only. Pre: 401 or 458, and consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: TAHT
title: Fourth-Level Tahitian Abroad (3)
desc: Full-time formal instruction at the University of French Polynesia in Tahiti. Fourth-year level in Tahitian language and culture. A-F only. Pre: 302 and consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: TAHT
title: Fourth-Level Tahitian (3)
desc: Continuation of 401. Pre: 401 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: TAHT
title: Fourth-Level Tahitian (3)
desc: Continuation of 302. Advanced conversation, reading, and writing with focus on modern formal and colloquial Tahitian styles. The language in the realms of storytelling, radio, folklore, traditional and modern writing. Survey of modern and classical language. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: TAHT
title: Third-Level Tahitian (3)
desc: Continuation of 301. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: TAHT
title: Third-Level Tahitian (3)
desc: Continuation of 202. Conversation, advanced reading, composition. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: TAHT
title: Second Year Tahitian II (3)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201 or consent.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: TAHT
title: Second Year Tahitian I (3)
desc: Intermediate core skills of listening, speaking and knowledge of grammar for spoken Tahitian in a condensed format. Meets three 50-minute sessions weekly. Pre: 102.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: TAHT
title: First Year Tahitian II (3)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101 or consent.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: TAHT
title: First Year Tahitian I (3)
desc: Basic core skills of listening, speaking and grammar of spoken Tahitian in a condensed format. Meets three 50-minute sessions weekly.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Tahitian (TAHT)

subject: SUST
title: Research Seminar: Agricultural Geography (3)
desc: (Cross-listed as GEO 763)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainability & Resilience Seminar (1)
desc: Weekly seminar covering research, processes, and initiatives related to sustainability and resilience in practice. The intent is to foster intellectual engagement and to help and encourage students to spawn their own original research ideas. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Marine Renewable Energy (3)
desc: Ocean thermal energy conversion (OTEC) systems: applicability, thermodynamics, design challenges; wave energy converters: floating devices, oscillating water column, optimal hydrodynamic performance; current, tidal, and offshore wind power. Pre: ORE 607; basic knowledge of thermodynamics desirable. (Cross-listed as ORE 677)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sociology of Sustainability (3)
desc: Analyses of sustainability, environmental, and technoscience issues from sociological perspectives. Graduate students only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as SOC 670)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Hawaiian Vascular Plants (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Identification, systematics, evolution, and biogeography of native plants. Field trips. Pre: 461 or consent. (Cross-listed as BOT 661)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Advanced Environmental Benefit Cost Analysis (3)
desc: Advanced environmental benefit-cost analysis will require that proficiency be demonstrated on fundamentals and address topics related to sustainability, including income equality, non-market goods, risk, cost of public funds, and the social discount rate. (Cross-listed as NREM 658)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Kānāwai Lawai‘a: Hawa‘i’s Ocean and Fisheries Laws (3)
desc: Seminar on pre-contact, customary laws on fishing and ocean stewardship, their codification in written laws during the Hawaiian Kingdom period, and changes and impacts through U.S. annexation and statehood, including current models of ocean governance. (Alt. years: Fall) (Cross-listed as HWST 652)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Urban and Regional Planning for Sustainability (3)
desc: Focus on ideology, conceptual models, accounting frameworks, appropriate technologies, and indicators of planning for sustainability. Central and local policies, plans, and best practices in various countries and settings will be covered. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Cross-listed as PLAN 647)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: (Alpha) Seminar (3)
desc: Study in trends, research, and problems of implementation in teaching field. (P) place-based education. Each alpha repeatable two times. COE-related majors only. Pre: graduate and/or undergraduate courses in education and/ or social sciences or consent. (Cross-listed as EDCS 640P)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Land Systems Science (3)
desc: Through discussion of primary land systems science literature and use of environmental modeling software, this interdisciplinary course explores how drivers, states, and trends in human appropriation of land affect socio-ecological system function. Pre: NREM 477 or NREM 677 or GEO 470 or GEO 476 or ERTH 460 or ERTH 461. (Alt. years: Fall) (Cross-listed as NREM 640)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Environmental Resource Economics (3)
desc: Principles of policy design and evaluation for environmental resources management, forestry and watershed conservation, and sustainable economic development. Pre: ECON 604 or 606; or consent. (Cross-listed as ECON 638)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Resource Economics (3)
desc: Analysis of problems of development and management of natural resources with emphasis on resources in agriculture and role in economic development. Pre: ECON 608 and 629. (Cross-listed as ECON 637 and NREM 637)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Renewable Energy Economics and Policy (3)
desc: Analysis of economic and policy aspects of renewable energy use, and interactions of markets for renewable energy and other energy options. Evaluations of policies to develop renewable energy options. Pre: college calculus and principles of microeconomics; or consent. (Cross-listed as ECON 636)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Planning in Hawai‘i and Pacific Islands (3)
desc: Urban and regional planning in island settings. Experiences in Hawai‘i, Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. Graduate students only. (Cross-listed as PLAN 632)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Urban Environmental Problems (3)
desc: Seminar that examines environmental problems associated with urbanization. Reviews strategic approaches and collaboration among key actors to address such problems. (Cross-listed as PLAN 628)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Climate Change, Energy and Food Security in the Asia/Pacific Region (3)
desc: Analysis of planning responses to human-induced climate change and related environmental problems. Part of the Asia/Pacific Initiative taught in collaboration with universities throughout the region via videoconferencing. (Cross-listed as PLAN 625)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Environmental Planning and Policy (3)
desc: Overview of urbanization and environmental change. An examination of environmental laws, policies, planning and urban design strategies designed to minimize and mitigate urban impacts. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Cross-listed as PLAN 620)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Advanced Methods in Wildlife Management & Conservation (4)
desc: Introduces advanced techniques for wildlife management and conservation. In addition to hands-on training, students will learn underlying biological and ecological principles, as well as quantitative skills, with an emphasis on sustainable management. A-F only. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as NREM 610)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Predicting and Controlling Degradation in Human-Dominated Terrestrial Ecosystems (3)
desc: Historic, present, and projected trends in understanding and managing human-dominated ecosystems; predicting, measuring and mitigating degradation especially in terrestrial ecosystems with a focus on small volcanic islands in tropical settings. A-F only. Pre: NREM 301/ SUST 311 and NREM 304 (or equivalent) and NREM 600. Recommended NREM 461, or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as NREM 612)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Resource and Environmental Policy Analysis(3)
desc: Exploration of institutional and policy dimensions of natural resource development, management, allocation, markets and pricing, focusing on their environmental impacts. Emphasis on policy analysis using case studies and empirical findings. Original paper required. A-F only. Pre: grade of Cor above in ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as NREM 611)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Seminar on Water in History (3)
desc: Explores how various forms of salt, fresh, and brackish water have played transformative roles in the evolution of human communities throughout history. (Cross-listed as HIST 608)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainability & Resilience Seminar (1)
desc: Weekly seminar covering research, processes, and initiatives related to sustainability and resilience in practice. The intent is to foster intellectual engagement and to help and encourage students to spawn their own original research ideas. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Environmental Problem Solving (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Senior-level capstone for NREM and related majors. Ecosystem management within problemsolving context. Applications of research and analytical methods, management tools to case studies. Focus on student teamwork and oral communications. NREM majors only. A-F only. Pre: Senior standing or consent. (Cross-listed as NREM 494)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: American Environmental History (3)
desc: Survey history of the complex relations between American societies and diverse U.S. ecosystems, from European contact and colonization to the present. (Cross-listed as AMST 425 and HIST 480)
metadata: DH Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Global Ethnic Conflict (3)
desc: Ethnic conflicts cause most wars on our globe today. Examines causes of ethnic conflict, including climate change. Will evaluate approaches to building peaceful relations between groups and developing sustainable relationships with the environment. Junior standing or higher. Pre: one DS or DH course or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 460)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Hui Konohiki Practicum (3)
desc: A “hands-on” internship in an environmental or resource-management organization in Hawai‘i. The experience will be broadened and supplemented by classroom lectures, discussion and analysis from traditional Hawaiian, scientific and economic perspectives. A-F only. Pre: 217/HWST 207 or 317/HWST 307 or SUST/HWST 356. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as HWST 460)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Project Evaluation and Resource Management (3)
desc: Principles of project evaluation and policy analysis. Shadow pricing, economic cost of taxes and tariffs; public policy for exhaustible, renewable, and environmental resources. Pre: 301. (Cross-listed as ECON 458)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: ‘Āina Mauliola: Hawaiian Ecosystems (3)
desc: Comprehensive analysis of traditional Hawaiian and modern resource management practices. Rigorous overview of the dominant physical and biological processes from the uplands to the oceans in Hawai‘i. Pre: 217/HWST 207 or 317/HWST 307 or SUST/HWST 356. (Cross-listed as HWST 457)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Natural Resource Issues and Ethics (4)
desc: Overview of the history of land, resources and power in Hawai‘i; players and processes influencing land and natural resources policies today explored from Native Hawaiian and other viewpoints. Extensive use of case studies. Pre: HWST 207/SUST 217 or HWST 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356 (Cross-listed as HWST 458 and NREM 458
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Hawaiian Sovereignty in Pacific Context (3)
desc: Causes and dynamics of ethnic conflicts with attention to problem resolution; (B) Middle East; (C) Hawaiian sovereignty in Pacific context. Pre: one DS or DH course, or consent for (C). (Cross-listed as ES 455C)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Wildlife Ecology and Management (3)
desc: Lecture-based overview of the history, ecology, and management of wildlife species from around the world and Hawai‘i. Pre: BIOL 172 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as NREM 450)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Natural History of Hawaiian Islands (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 1-hr Lab) Geography, geology, climatology, biotic environment of Pacific Basin and Hawaiian Islands; endemism and evolution in terrestrial and marine biota. Pre: one semester of biological sciences at college level. (Cross-listed as BIOL 454)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Climate Modeling, Data Analysis and Applications (3)
desc: Introduction to regional and global climate modeling for environmental scientists and engineers. Learn principles of climate modeling, how to access and use climate data for sustainable engineering and environmental management solutions, and effectively communicate results. A-F only. Senior standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as ATMO 449 and CEE 449)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Hawaiian Ethnobotany (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Methods and techniques of handling and identifying plant materials used by early Hawaiians and modern Hawaiians for house and canoe construction, clothing, household and fishing items, medicine, and food preparation. Reading, laboratory, and fieldwork. Pre: BOT 440 or consent. (Cross-listed as BOT 446)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Ethnoecology and Conservation (3)
desc: Ecological implications of cultural uses of plants. Examines the biological basis for, and ecological effects of traditional and local resource management systems. Pre: BOT 305 or BIOL 265/265L or consent. (Cross-listed as BOT 444)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Infrastructure: Project Impacts, Policy and Sustainability (3)
desc: Evaluation of infrastructure impacts. Impacts regulation and mitigation. Effects of environmental and other policies on infrastructure. Infrastructure relations to sustainability. Energy consumption, transportation efficiency and infrastructure recycling. Lectures and presentations by experts and enrolled students. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: senior standing, open to engineering, science, urban planning, and economics majors. (Cross-listed as CEE 444)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Principles of Sustainability Analysis (3)
desc: Key principles of sustainability and its analysis. Quantification of environmental impact/assessment using target plots, mass/energy balances, and life cycle analyses (cradle to gate/grave) applied to products, processes, or systems. Use of SimaPro. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as CEE 441 and OCN 441)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Vulnerability & Adaptation on Coastal Infrastructure (3)
desc: Assessing vulnerability of coastal communities to climate change stressors and providing technical engineering solutions for adaptation. Senior standing or higher. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as CEE 440)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Use, Re-use, and Radical Re-use (3)
desc: Explores the related concepts of use, re-use, and radical re-use through an exploration of new applications of traditional fiber techniques and contexts of making. Engages writing as a significant tool for art-making and analysis. A-F only. Pre: ART 116 or consent. (Cross-listed as ART 436)
metadata: DA Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Interdisciplinary Science Curriculum (3)
desc: Conceptual schemes and processes for integrating science curricula within the sciences and with subject areas. Methods and models of curricular integration such as interdisciplinary, culturally relevant, place and community-based learning. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as EDCS 433)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Environment, Resources and Society (3)
desc: Human interaction with the environment. How market, property institution, and technological change affect the environment. Epistemological basis of environmental policies. Debates on controversial environmental issues. Pre: 102, 151, or consent. (Cross-listed as GEO 426)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Environmental Geochemistry (3)
desc: Theory and applications of contaminant/pollutant distribution in the hydrosphere-geosphere-biosphere-atmosphere system, remediation methods, prevention, industrial/agricultural best practices. Topics include aqueous geochemistry, organic, inorganic, gas phase, and ecosystem impacts of environmental contaminants. Pre: CHEM 161 and CHEM 162, or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as ERTH 425)
metadata: DP Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Agriculture, Food and Society (3)
desc: Examines historical and contemporary development of the global agro-food systems. The impacts of technological, political and economic changes to food security, environment and development. Open to nonmajors. Pre: junior standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as GEO 422)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Biocontrol of Invasive Species (3)
desc: Biological control of invasive insects and weeds using natural enemies; biological control as a cornerstone of sustainable pest management; contributions of biocontrol to economic, environmental, and societal sustainability; reduced dependence on pesticides; increased sustainability of pest management. Pre: PEPS 363 or consent. (Cross-listed as PEPS 422)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainable Tourism Policies and Practices (3)
desc: Seminar examining the social, environmental, economic factors of sustainable tourism development. Emphasis on methods and processes and the role of stakeholders (government, industry, host community, tourists). Group projects. A-F only. Pre: 101 and departmental approval. (Cross-listed as TIM 420)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Community and Natural Resource Management (3)
desc: Theory and tools for working with groups and communities in the management of natural resources is presented using a participatory format. Topics include sustainable development, extension programming, participatory learning and communication, evaluation, and conflict management. Pre: two social science courses (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as NREM 420)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Nature-Based Tourism Management (3)
desc: Principles of nature-based tourism, including a survey of impacts, objectives, planning, and management systems. Junior standing or higher. Pre: TIM 101 or GEOG/TIM 324. (Cross-listed as GEO 415 and TIM 415)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Past Global Change and the Human Era (3)
desc: Study of past environments to understand present and future global change. Focus on terrestrial Quaternary environments and global processes. Pre: junior standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as GEO 411)
metadata: DP Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: The Ocean Economy (3)
desc: Examination of society’s interaction with the ocean. Topics include: ocean recreation, shipping, boat building, ports, offshore energy production, aquaculture, fishing, coastal construction, and coral reef protection. Pre: 120 or 130, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ECON 409)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Methods in Wildlife Management & Conservation (4)
desc: Introduces fundamental techniques for wildlife management and conservation. In addition to hands-on training, students will learn underlying biological and ecological principles, as well as quantitative skills, with an emphasis on sustainable management. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: BIOL 171. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as NREM 410)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainable Soil and Plant Health Management (2)
desc: Provides knowledge and understanding of soils, agroecology, and sustainable approaches for plant health management, and prepares students for applied research in various tropical cropping systems. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as PEPS 410 and TPSS 410)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Politics of the Ocean (3)
desc: Study of the ocean as a political place. Engagement with theories, policies, and lived-experiences of the ocean through a political lens, including literature and experiential learning. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: any 100 or 200-level POLS course, or consent. (Cross-listed as POLS 387)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Environmental Law and Politics (3)
desc: Focuses on theories, laws, policies, ethics, and sustainable futures of Hawai‘i and the U.S. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: any 100 or 200 level POLS course, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as POLS 380)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Genetics: Theory to Application (3)
desc: Fundamentals of genetic theory using traditional breeding and biotechnological procedures in insect and plant pathogen management for sustainable agricultural production. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Cross-listed as PEPS 371 and TPSS 371)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainability, Technoscience, and Social Justice (3)
desc: Examines politics of sustainability and technoscience with an explicit attention to social justice and power relations in society. A-F only. Pre: WS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or consent. (Fall only) (Crosslisted as SOC 367 and WS 367)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Basic Environmental Benefit Cost Analysis (3)
desc: Fundamentals of benefit-cost analysis with extensions to environmental impacts and projects; case studies. Pre: 220/NREM 220 or ECON 130 or consent. (Cross-listed as NREM 358)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Aloha Kanaloa-Marine Resources and Abundance (3)
desc: Undergraduate course exposing students to the resources and processes of the ocean, research, and management approaches, as well as a Hawaiian worldview of oceanic elements. Junior standing or higher. Pre: HWST 107. (Cross-listed as HWST 356)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Economic Change and Hawai‘i’s People (3)
desc: Hawai‘i’s economic transformation from sustainable communal subsistence through mercantile capitalism, plantation capitalism, and global finance capital and impact on its people. Alternative sustainable enterprises for a self-sufficient island economy. Pre: one DS or DH course. (Cross-listed as ES 350)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainable Development (3)
desc: Transdisciplinary introduction to sustainable development. Interactions between environment, economy, and public policy, especially in Hawai‘i. Topics include: curse of paradise, global warming, energy use, health, poverty, population, water resources, traffic congestion, biodiversity, pollution controls. Pre: 120 or 130 or 131, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ECON 350)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Land Tenure and Use in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Dynamics of change: indigenous Hawaiian land tenure; Great Mahele and Kuleana Act; ethnic succession of land ownership; concentration of ownership today; effects of land development on ethnic communities. Pre: one DS or DH course. (Cross-listed as ES 340)
metadata: DH Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Human Values and the Environment (3)
desc: Examination of nature-culture dynamic over a range of contexts–literary ecology, systems ecology, political ecology, eco-feminism, environmental ethics–in order to articulate new possibilities for interdisciplinary understanding of the human place in nature. A-F only. Pre: any ENG DL or PHIL or GEO course, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as IS 340)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Energy Economics and Policy (3)
desc: Analysis of economic and policy aspects of energy use, and interactions of markets for various nonrenewable and renewable energy options. Evaluations of policies to develop alternative energy sources. Pre: ECON 120 or ECON 130 or ECON 131. (Cross-listed as ECON 336)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Climate Change and Cultural Response: Past, Present, and Future (3)
desc: Climate change is a reality, yet there is much uncertainty about how it will affect our lives. Investigates cultural response to climate change, using studies of the past to plan for the future. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as ANTH 333)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Economics of Global Climate Change (3)
desc: Nature and causes of global climate change and economic solutions. Topics include valuing climate change impacts, energy solutions, environmental implications, societal adaptation, and international cooperation. A-F only. Pre: 120 or 130 or 131, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ECON 332)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Culture and Environment (3)
desc: Critically examines changing views of nature, nature-culture relationships, and perceptions of the environment across different cultures. (Cross-listed as GEO 330)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Geography, Environment, and Society (3)
desc: Examines the geography of resources and environmental change with a holistic and multi-scale perspective. Social approaches to resolving environmental problems. Sophomore standing or higher. (Cross-listed as GEO 325)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Communicating Sustainability (3)
desc: Application of scientific communication theory, strategic communication, and multimedia techniques to select issues of environmental sustainability. COM majors only. A-F only. Pre: COM 201 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent. (Cross-listed as COM 325)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Global Environmental Politics (3)
desc: Evolution of international politics, law and decision-making on a variety of environmental concerns; from endangered species to pollution to climate change. Interaction of population, development, and environment in global governance. (Cross-listed as POLS 324)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Applied Principles of Environmental & Energy Policy (3)
desc: Introduction to the methods and techniques of environmental and energy policy in relation to energy systems. Analysis of enacted policies from case studies to understanding the effectiveness, challenges, contradictions, and limitations of each. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: any 100 or 200 level OCN course, or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as OCN 321 and PPC 340)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Globalization and Environment (3)
desc: Debates on globalization and development, population and resources; root causes of environmental degradation; impacts of globalization on environmentalism and environmental change; social approaches to managing environmental change. Junior standing or higher. (Cross-listed as GEO 322)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Hawai‘i and the Pacific (3)
desc: Hawai‘i as part of the Pacific community: selected historical and contemporary problems of Pacific areas; cultural and economic imperialism, land alienation, and the impact of development on Pacific peoples. Pre: one DS or DH course. (Cross-listed as ES 320)
metadata: DH Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Environment and Agriculture (3)
desc: Overview of environmental issues related to agriculture, specifically pest management issues, and options for environmentally responsible management and amelioration of these impacts. Ethical issues on impact of agriculture on the environment will be discussed. (Cross-listed as PEPS 310)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Race, Indigeneity, and Environmental Justice (3)
desc: Introduction to environmental justice, explores the premise that all people have a right to a life-affirming environment. Will examine environmental racism, and the geographical dimensions of race and indigeneity. Pre: one DS or DH course, or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 308)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Malama ‘Āina Resource Management Visual Technologies (3)
desc: Requires a broad set of knowledge systems. Will introduce students to a variety of visual technologies for use in resource management and the ethical application of these technologies. Pre: 107. (Cross-listed as HWST 307)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Environmental Ethics (3)
desc: Application of traditional moral theories to environmental issues. Development and evaluation of specific environmental ethical theories. Application of ethical theories to environmental decision-making. A-F only. Pre: 210 or GEO 101 or PHIL 101 or PHIL 103. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as NREM 306)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Water and Society (3)
desc: Interaction of people with water at household, community, regional, national, and international scales, from cultural, political, economic, and biophysical perspectives. Pre: sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as GEO 305)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Global Environmental Issues (3)
desc: Use and abuse of natural resources and humanity’s progress toward developing a sustainable relationship with its supporting environment. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as GEO 302)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Plant Conservation Biology Lab (1)
desc: Introduction to approaches, methods, and analyses used in the study and practice of plant conservation, with an emphasis on experimental design and problem-solving. Includes both laboratory and field components. A-F only. Pre: BOT/BIOL 305 or consent. Co-requisite: BOT 301. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as BOT 301L)
metadata: DY Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Plant Conservation Biology (3)
desc: Introduction to the concepts and principles of plant conservation biology and to plant conservation-inpractice in Hawai‘i and elsewhere. A-F only. Pre: BOT/ BIOL 305 or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as BOT 301)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Natural Resource and Environmental Policy (3)
desc:
Introduction to natural resource and environmental public policy at U.S. federal, Hawai‘i 
state, local, and international levels. Policy principles, legal structure, governmental agencies, statutes and programs, analytical techniques, program assessments, and contemporary ethical issues. A-F only. Pre: SUST/ NREM/PEPS 210 or or NREM/SOCS/TPSS 251 or (BIOL 101 or higher) or GEO 101 or (ERTH 101 or higher); and NREM/SUST 220 or one ECON course or two DS courses. (Cross-listed as NREM 302)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Conservation Ethics (1)
desc: Introduction to and discussion of ethical issues associated with biodiversity, ecology, and conservation biology. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: any DB course or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as BOT 300)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Natural Resources Management (3)
desc: Biological and physical science aspects of natural resource management at local, national, and global scales. Topics covered include resource management of soil, water, forests, wetlands, coasts and wildlife. A-F only. Pre: (NREM/TPSS 251 or 210; CHEM 151 or higher; and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as NREM 301)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Introduction to Sustainability from Social Science Perspectives (3)
desc: Introduction to key concepts and theories in social sciences in relation to sustainability issues. (Cross-listed as SOC 230 and TAHR 250)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Hawaiians (3)
desc: The sustainable social system, culture, spirituality, language, land stewardship, and governance of Native Hawaiians. Transformation of the sustainable Hawaiian social system by a capitalist economy. Resiliency, land issues, and Native Hawaiian quest for sovereign governance. (Cross-listed as ES 221)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Organic Food Crop Production (2)
desc: Combined lecture/lab on the theory and practice of certified organic food production. Field visits to organic farms/markets included. Open to nonmajors. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as TPSS 220)
metadata: DY Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Agricultural and Resource Economics (3)
desc: Introduction to basic economics concepts, including demand, supply, exchange, market price and market failure. Economic evaluation and policy for the uses of various natural resource endowments, especially in production agriculture, is included. A-F only. (Cross-listed as NREM 220)
metadata: DS Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Hawaiian Perspectives in Ahupua‘a (3)
desc: Examination of the ahupua‘a system as it was conceptualized by the ancient Hawaiians, and exploration of its relevance in modern society; an introductory class to the malama ‘aina track designed to build critical writing skills. A-F only. Pre: 107. (Cross-listed as HWST 207)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Agriculture, Environment, and Society (3)
desc: Relationship of plants, soils, and the environment, and how they relate to cultural practices and society in agroecosystems with an emphasis on Hawai‘i as a model system. (Cross-listed as TPSS 200)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Introduction to Environmental Science (3)
desc: Analysis of our environment with emphasis on understanding relationships and interactions of physical, biological, technological, and political components using scientific methods of inquiry. Food supply and safety, water quality, pollution control, biodiversity, environmental policy. Open to nonmajors. (Cross-listed as NREM 210 and PEPS 210)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainable Food and Energy Field Course (V)
desc: Examines the nexus of food, energy, and water in Hawai‘i for sustainable development. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. (Cross-listed as TPSS 156)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Chemistry in a Sustainable World (3)
desc: Introduction to chemistry for non-science majors. Discussion of the role of natural and man-made chemicals in everyday life, with an emphasis on sustainable and environmentally-sensitive use of chemicals to improve our world. A-F only. Students who successfully completed CHEM 100 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 120/CHEM 110 without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 120/CHEM 110 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 100 without instructor override. (Cross-listed as CHEM 110)
metadata: DP Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Humans and the Environment (3)
desc: Prepares students to make decisions such as where to build/buy a house, sustainable use of natural resources, and what environmental actions relevant to society and Earth’s ecosystem are appropriate on a local and global scale. A-F only. (Cross-listed as ERTH 106)
metadata: DP Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainability in a Changing World (3)
desc: Environmentally sustainable and non-sustainable practices, and the impacts of climate change, on the development and spread of human societies from pre-history to the 1500s in Asia, Africa, Europe, the Americas, and Hawai‘i/Oceania. Active learning environment. (Cross-listed as OCN 105)
metadata: FGA Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Sustainable Cities (3)
desc:
How do we plan cities to meet long-term social, economic, and 
environmental needs? Students will learn about sustainability as it relates to issues like energy, transportation, housing, land, water, and food. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. (Cross-listed as PLAN 101)
metadata: Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Quantifying Global and Environmental Change (3)
desc: Introductory mathematical approaches to quantifying key aspects of global and environmental change. Includes data analysis, graphical representation and modeling of population growth, greenhouse gas emissions and fate, sustainable resource utilization, and sea level change. A-F only. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as ERTH 102)
metadata: FQ Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Introduction to the Environment, Climate Change, & Sustainability (3)
desc: Introduction to the environment, climate change, and sustainability as they apply to ecosystems. Sustainability will be introduced through active learning exercises that address sustainable development and the three pillars of sustainability. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Cross-listed as GES 102 and OCN 102)
metadata: DB Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SUST
title: Biology & Society Laboratory (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Explores connections between biological principles and everyday life with a focus on the environment. Topics include environmental health and sustainability with examples from Hawai‘i. Not a BIOL major elective. (Cross-listed as BIOL 101L)
metadata: DY Office of Academic Excellence Sustainability (SUST)

subject: SURG
title: (Alpha) Electives in Surgery (V)
desc: Advanced clinical experience in: (B) urology; (C) ophthalmology; (D) otolaryngology; (E) plastic surgery; (F) neurosurgery; (G) orthopaedics; (H) anesthesia; (I) surgical intensive care; (J)Sub-I – general surgery; (K) Sub-I – pediatric surgery; (M) diagnostic radiology; (N) radiation oncology; (O) EM Sub-I; (P) extramural elec in surg; (Q) Sub-I – cardiovascular; (R) surgical research; (S) surgical anatomy; (T) preceptorship in Asia; (U) biomedical technology design; (X) transplant surgery; (Y) bedside ultrasounds; (Z) laparoscopic skills. Repeatable one time for all except (U), (X), (Y), and (Z); repeatable two times for (U) and (X). Medical students only for (U), (X), (Y), and (Z). CR/NC only. Pre: 532 for all except (M), (U), and (Y); and consent for (R) and (S); admission into JABSOM for (U) and (Y).
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Surgery (SURG)

subject: SURG
title: Emergency Medical Care (6)
desc: Clinical experiences in management of medical, surgical, and psychiatric problems requiring urgent care. Pre: 532 and fourth-year standing.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Surgery (SURG)

subject: SURG
title: Surgery Longitudinal Clerkship (5)
desc: A clinically based, year-long, introductory in general surgery and selected subspecialties. Outpatient-conducted one day per week for six months in a community-based, ambulatory care facility. Inpatient-conducted for four weeks in an acute-care hospital facility. Repeatable one time.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Surgery (SURG)

subject: SPED
title: Grant Development/Procurement (3)
desc: Overview of grant development and procurement processes related to special education personnel preparation and research and demonstration programs. Students design a grant proposal related to a particular problem or need within their employment settings. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Special Topics in Exceptionalities (3)
desc: Critical examination and discussion of historical or current topic in early intervention, special education, and/or developmental disabilities. Repeatable two times. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Single-Case Experimental Design (3)
desc: Advanced single-case experimental design; examines the logic of internal and external validity of small “N” design and its functionalist foundations. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Professional Seminar in Exceptionalities (1)
desc: Professional norms, duties, and expectations of leaders in exceptionalities; transitioning from practitioner to researcher and leadership roles; familiarity with current research and trends in the field of exceptionalities. Repeatable five times. PhD in EDUC majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Doctoral Internship (6)
desc: Supervised internship (minimum 18 hours per week) in program development and administration or research in the student’s area of emphasis. EDUC majors only. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Seminar in Exceptionalities (3)
desc: Current and historical topics, issues, and trends in the field of exceptionalities. Repeatable with different content. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Individual reading/research. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent of instructor and department chair.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Plan B Master’s Project (3)
desc: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Special Education.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Research Practicum in Special Education (3)
desc: Directed research experience to demonstrate mastery of research skills and techniques through developing and writing research proposals. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 642 or consent, or departmental approval. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Applied Behavior Analysis Fieldwork (V)
desc: Field experience in applied behavior analysis supervised by a Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA). The format is a combination of fieldwork and seminar meetings. Repeatable nine times, up to 20 credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Ethics and Professional Conduct (3)
desc: Focuses on content on the Behavior Analysis Certification Board’s code for ethical conduct as well as advanced concepts, principles, and processes of applied behavior analysis. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Advanced Principles of Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) (3)
desc: Focuses on the definitions and characteristics of applied behavior analysis and the concepts, principles, and processes. Concepts related to ethics and behavior change procedures will also be introduced. A-F only. Pre: 603.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Transition/Supported Employment (3)
desc: Transition planning for youth with disabilities in preparation for employment as adults in private and public sector businesses. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Seminar on Universal Design for Learning (3)
desc: Seminar on issues of research and practice on the application of universal design for learning in K-12 and higher education settings. Focus on culturally and linguistically diverse students diversity, non-traditional students and students with disabilities. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Seminar in Early Childhood Special Education (3)
desc: Study of issues/trends. Research and program development in early childhood special education. Repeatable one time. Pre: (631 and 635) with a minimum grade of B- or better, or consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Seminar on Severe/Multiple Disabilities (3)
desc: Research, program development trends/issues in the area of severe/multiple disabilities (birth through adulthood). College of Education majors only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Seminar on Applied Research/Special Education (3)
desc: Study and development of applied research topics in special education. Repeatable two times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Issues in Special Education (3)
desc: Seminar on issues, trends, research, and program development in the field of special education. (B) current issues and trends; (C) technology; (D) foundations; (E) developmental disabilities; (F) cultural and linguistic diversity; (G) evidence-based practices; (H) single case research. Repeatable one time per alpha, repeatable two times for (H). A-F only. Pre: 603 for (H).
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Seminar on Mild/Moderate Disabilities (3)
desc: Study of issues, research, program development in the area of mild/moderate disabilities. Repeatable two times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Advanced Fundamentals of Language and Literacy (3)
desc: Advanced linguistic structures of written English related to reading, spelling, and writing for older students. Covers diagnostic assessment, planning, instruction, and progress monitoring for students with Dyslexia or related reading difficulties. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Fundamentals of Language and Literacy (3)
desc: Introduction of basic linguistic structures of written English related to reading, spelling, and writing for beginning or struggling readers. Covers evidence-based practices for teaching literacy to students with Dyslexia and related reading difficulties. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Topics and Issues in Reading Difficulties (3)
desc: Introduction of foundational knowledge of language and literacy development. Current topics and issues related to literacy development in students with Dyslexia and related reading difficulties. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Procedures for Early Childhood Special Education (3)
desc: Assessment and intervention strategies to promote behavior change with young children with disabilities. Promoting child skill gains and integrated programming options. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Inclusive Physical Activity (3)
desc: Advanced knowledge on issues of socio-cultural, learning styles, diversity, and exceptionalities, and how these influence instruction, engagement, and behavior in physical activity settings across the lifespan. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as KRS 634)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Motor Development/Intervention for Students with Severe Disabilities (3)
desc: Normal/ abnormal motor development; description/etiology of physically disabling conditions influencing motor development; analysis/application of assessment/intervention strategies to promote motor development; positioning and handling skills. Pre: 614 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Language/Communication Intervention-Communication Disorders/Autism (3)
desc: Current research in normal language learning, assessment, planning, implementation, evaluation of language delayed/disordered children, including children with autism. Procedures for attaining language/functional communication objectives using ongoing routines/activities. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Early Intervention for Special Populations (3)
desc: Issues important to early childhood special education. Early screening and assessment, working with families, curriculum options/models, program evaluation. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Positive Behavioral Support-Severe Disabilities and Autism (3)
desc: Principles and laws governing human behavior and positive methods for eliminating significant behavior problems for students with severe disabilities and autism. Emphasis on the functions of behavior, experimental techniques for documenting behavior change, and the use of technologies for improving behavior in school and community settings. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Clinical Practice Special Projects (V)
desc: Development and implementation of a field-based research professional development project under the direction of the student’s advisor; limited to students enrolled in the interdisciplinary program. Repeatable up to 9 credits. A-F only. Pre: advisor’s approval.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Internship (V)
desc: Supervised education/ community experiences with special needs populations, preschool through postsecondary settings. A-F only. Repeatable two times, up to six credits.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Advanced Practicum (6)
desc: Supervised education/community experiences; minimum of 20 hours weekly with special-needs population (MR, LD, SED, SMH); pre-school through postsecondary settings (public/private). Related seminar or equivalent and completion of SPED core required. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Field Experiences in Special Education (3)
desc: Students spend a minimum of nine hours per week in settings appropriate to concurrently enrolled courses; supervision provided by participating teacher and college supervisor. Repeatable three times. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Teaching Skills for Social Competence (3)
desc: Issues in social development, self-determination, and social skills competence training for children and youth with disabilities; experience in group social skills training and development of individualized programs. Pre: either 485 or 630, and either 611 or 614; or consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Children’s Literature for Deaf Students (3)
desc: Introduction to English literature translated into American Sign Language (ASL) including discussion of ASL literature genres, the importance of translation, selection of literature; story reading, book reading, and retelling. Taught in ASL. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 609 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Language Arts Strategies: Students with Mild/Moderate Disabilities (3)
desc: Basic concepts related to language, language development, and recognition of language-related learning problems of students with mild/moderate disabilities; strategies for teaching language arts curricula (listening, speaking, reading, writing) to students of all ages with learning problems. A-F only. Pre: 304 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Strategies Across Content Area (3)
desc: Strategies for teaching math, science, and social sciences to students of all ages with mild/moderate disabilities; selection of appropriate materials, teaching techniques, curriculum development. Pre: 611 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Adaptations and Special ProceduresStudents/Severe Disabilities/Autism (3)
desc: Adaptations and special intervention procedures to support the participation of individuals with severe motor, communication, and/or adaptive behavior disabilities in inclusive school and community settings. Includes lab work. SPED majors only. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Transition Strategies for Deaf Students (1)
desc: Collaborative model for facilitating the transition of deaf and hard-of-hearing students to develop appropriate transition plans and effective plans of study. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 606, 607 and 608; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Collaboration–Working with Deaf Students in Inclusive Settings (3)
desc: Collaboration skills for working with general education teachers, specialists, paraprofessionals, families and community members to support the success of deaf students in inclusive settings. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 606, 607 and 608; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Family-Centered Approaches in Deaf Education (1)
desc: Prepare teachers to deliver family-centered home-based services to families of deaf children using the SKI-HI model. Course will be taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 606, 607 and 608; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Assessment and Instruction—Severe Disabilities and Autism (3)
desc: Basic principles of assessment, instruction, and curriculum development; application of formal and informal assessment procedures for goal selection, formulating instructional plans, and adapting instructional materials to accommodate learning needs of students with severe disabilities and autism. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Advanced Assessment and Curriculum Development (3)
desc: Assessment methods and techniques that emphasize the bond between curriculum-based assessment and curriculum-based programming. Planning and cyclical instruction across content areas based on ongoing diagnostic assessment. SPED majors only. A-F only. Pre: 461 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Methods and Strategies for Students with Mild/Moderate Disabilities (3)
desc: Techniques for providing effective instruction including: best instructional practice, lesson planning, teacher-directed and student-mediated instructional strategies, and curricular approaches for working with students with mild/moderate disabilities. A-F only. Pre: 304 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Advanced Assessment and Curriculum Development–Deaf (3)
desc: Assessment methods and techniques used with deaf students that emphasize the bond between curriculum-based assessment and curriculum-based programming through planning and providing cyclical instruction across content areas based on ongoing diagnostic assessment. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 609 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Seminar in Bilingual Deaf Education (3)
desc: Study of issues, trends and methods in ASL/ English bilingual education for deaf students. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 606, 607 and 608; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Literacy Development for Deaf Students (6)
desc: Basic concepts related to language, language development and recognition of language-related learning problems of deaf students; strategies for teaching reading and writing to deaf students. Repeatable one times. A-F only. Pre: 461 and 606, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Audiology and Spoken English for Deaf Students (3)
desc: Developmental principles of audiology and speech (i.e., spoken English) will be used to examine assessment procedures and intervention strategies appropriate to deaf students in a variety of educational placements. Classroom applications will be presented. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: admission into Deaf Education program or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Language Development for Deaf Children (3)
desc: General theories of first and second language development applied to development of ASL and English in deaf children. Relationship of theory to educational practice. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: admission into Deaf Education program or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Collaboration in School and Community Settings (3)
desc: Collaboration skills necessary to function as team members and to ensure the success of students with disabilities in inclusive school and community settings. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Principles of Behavior (3)
desc: Principles and laws governing behavior and methods that can be used to accomplish educationally relevant changes in student performance. Emphasis on the conceptual basis for changing behavior and use of technologies for changing behavior in school and community settings. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Special Education Law and Compliance (3)
desc: Examination of the federal, state, and local government roles in special education with special emphasis on case and regulatory law. Focus on understanding special education law necessary in providing services to students with disabilities in a variety of placements. Appropriate for special/general education teachers, administrators, or related service providers. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Instructional/Assistive Technology and Universal Design for Learning (3)
desc: Strategies for using instructional and assistive technology, digital tools and media, and Universal Design for Learning to support learning needs of students with disabilities and other diverse learners in the K-12 classroom. Pre: one of 480, LTEC 414, or LTEC 442.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Foundations of Exceptionality (3)
desc: Theoretical, legal and multicultural foundations for assessing, teaching and developing individual service plans across the lifespan for persons with disabilities. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Internship, Special Education (6)
desc: Supervised field activities involving the programming and instruction of special-needs students within training programs in Hawai‘i and the Pacific Basin. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Practicum in Special Education (3)
desc: For in-service school/community personnel to present new ideas, approaches, instructional methods, materials for teaching exceptional individuals. (B–E) general SPED; (F–G) secondary programming/ SPED; (H–I) bilingual/multicultural/special needs; (J–K) severe disabilities; (M–N) early childhood/ special needs; (O–P) career/vocational/special needs; (Q–R) computer/special needs; (S–T) arts/special needs; (U–W) computer training/special needs; (X–Y) consultant skills/special needs; (Z) Ho‘okoho. Repeatable eight times. CR/NC only. Pre: teaching or related work experience.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Practicum in Special Education (2)
desc: For in-service school/community personnel to present new ideas, approaches, instructional methods, materials for teaching exceptional individuals. (B–E) general SPED; (F–G) secondary programming/SPED; (H–I) bilingual/multicultural/special needs; (J–K) needs; (Q–R) computer/special needs; (S–T) arts/ special needs; (U–W) computer training/special needs; (X–Y) consultant skills/special needs; (Z) Ho‘okoho. Repeatable nine times. CR/NC only. Pre: teaching or related work experience.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Practicum in Special Education (1)
desc: For in-service school/community personnel to present new ideas, approaches, instructional methods, materials for teaching exceptional individuals. (B–E) general SPED; (F–G) secondary programming/ SPED; (H–I) bilingual/multicultural/special needs; (J–K) severe disabilities; (M–N) early childhood/ special needs; (O–P) career/vocational/special needs; (Q–R) computer/special needs; (S–T) arts/special needs; (U–W) computer training/special needs; (X–Y) consultant skills/special needs; (Z) Ho‘okoho. Repeatable nine times. CR/NC only. Pre: teaching or related work experience.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Internship in Special Education-Post Baccalaureate Programs (V)
desc: Supervised teaching experience in PreK-12 educational settings appropriate to SPED-Pcert program emphasis (mild/moderate or severe/autism); supervision provided by master teacher/university mentor, and university supervisor. Must enroll for two consecutive semesters. Repeatable two times, up to 14 credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Student Teaching in Special EducationPost Baccalaureate Programs (6)
desc: Supervised student teaching with a master teacher in PreK-12 educational settings appropriate to SPED-Pcert emphasis (mildmoderate, severe/autism); minimum 280 hours in minimum 11 weeks. Supervision by master teacher and university supervisor. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Field Experience in Special Education-Post Baccalaureate (V)
desc: Students spend between 100-135 hours over a semester in settings appropriate to SPED-PCert program emphasis (mild/moderate or severe/autism); supervision provided by participating teacher and/or college supervisor. Repeatable one time, up to 6 credits. Post-Baccalaureate in Special Education only. A-F only. Pre: 304 or 412.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Post-Baccalaureate in Special Education Program Seminar (1)
desc: Mandatory program seminar for Post-Baccalaureate in Special Education (PBSPED) teacher candidates; access to tools and skills necessary for distance education program success; Introduction to the Special Education teaching profession. Post-Bac in SPED majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Individual reading, research, and/or projects under direct supervision of instructors. Repeatable nine times. Pre: consent of instructor or department chair.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Characteristics/Strategies for Teaching At-Risk Students (3)
desc: Survey of educational, behavioral, and emotional characteristics of students who are at-risk for school failure and strategies to work with such students. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Theoretical Basis for Teaching Special-Needs Students (3)
desc: Survey of biophysical, behavioral, social/ecological, psychodynamic/ psychoeducational, cognitive/developmental, counter-theoretical approaches to teaching exceptional students. Opportunity for the development and/ or strengthening of one’s own theoretical frame of reference.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Classroom Organization and Management (3)
desc: Knowledge and skills related to basic organizational management of an inclusive classroom, including scheduling, grouping, and stress and time management; techniques of applied behavior management, emphasizing behavior change and practical implementation of learning principles. (B) elementary/special education, V credits; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable up to six credits for (B). A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Instructional and Assistive Technology (V)
desc: Addresses instructional and assistive technologies for special education and general education settings; technology-based instructional strategies that support inclusion and address academic and behavioral objectives; and application of Universal Design for Learning to support access to the general curriculum for diverse students in the PreK-12 classroom setting. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one time per alpha; repeatable up to six credits for (B). A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Assistant-Level Applied Behavior Analysis Fieldwork (V)
desc: Field experience in applied behavior analysis at the assistant level supervised by a Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA). The format is a combination of fieldwork and seminar meetings. Repeatable nine times, up to 20 credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Assessment, Planning, and Instruction for Students with Severe Disabilities/ Autism (3)
desc: Techniques in the assessment, planning, and instructional process appropriate for students with severe disabilities/autism. Focus on program development to facilitate the inclusion of students with disabilities into general education settings. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education, emphasis on writing instruction in teaching special education; (D) unclassified. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Assessment, Planning, and Instruction for Students with Mild/Moderate Disabilities (3)
desc:
Techniques in the assessment, planning, and instructional process appropriate for students with mild/moderate disabilities. Stress on program development to facilitate inclusion of students with 
disabilities into general education environment. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood elementary/special education; (D) unclassified; (E) secondary. BEd in SPED majors only for (E). A-F only. (Spring only for (E))
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Preschool Children–Special Needs (3)
desc: Examination of application of current research and practices for serving preschool children with special needs. Pre: HDFS 230 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Programs for Infants/Toddlers (3)
desc: Examination of current theory, research, issues, and models in programs for infants and toddlers including criteria for evaluation and planning. A-F only. Pre: HDFS 230 (or concurrent) and HDFS 331 (or concurrent), or consent. (Cross-listed as EDCS 451)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Seminar in Special Education (3)
desc: Study of issues, trends, and research into special education programming and service delivery. Repeatable two times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Educating Exceptional Students in Regular Classrooms–Secondary (3)
desc: Teaching secondary students with disabilities and those who are gifted/talented. Meeting academic/social needs, classroom management, motivation, peer interaction. Collaboration between special and regular educators. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Educating Exceptional Students in Regular Classrooms–Elementary (3)
desc: Teaching elementary students with disabilities and those who are gifted/talented. Meeting academic/social needs, classroom management, motivation, peer interaction, collaboration between special and regular educators. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Disability and Diversity in Physical Activity (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 1-hr. Lab) Participants will explore issues related to individuals with exceptionalities, how these affect learning and behavior in the health and physical activity settings. Oral communication practice and skills are worth >30% grade. Required field experience. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Partnerships with Families and Professionals (V)
desc: Knowledge and skills for relating effectively with families and professionals on behalf of the children and youth with and without disabilities. Coverage of the context in which family members and school personnel interact. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Strategies for Reading Difficulties (V)
desc: Overview of methods, programs, and strategies for reading instruction designed to improve the performance of elementary students, grades K-6, who experience difficulties in reading acquisition, fluency, and comprehension. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Education Program for the Gifted/ Talented (3)
desc: Utilization and evaluation of teaching/ learning models for gifted/talented students, including consideration of roles, expectancies for learning, and organizational procedures.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Education of Gifted Students (3)
desc: Characteristics and educational provisions for gifted children and youth with particular attention to psychological aspects of creativity
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Individuals with Severe Disabilities/ Autism (3)
desc: Etiology, characteristics, and development of individuals with severe disabilities and autism; historical, theoretical, and legal issues affecting individuals with severe disabilities and autism; multicultural, family, and consumer issues; professional and ethical issues in providing services. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Writing for Educational Professionals (3)
desc: Instruction on learning to write as professional educators. Strategies for developing and enhancing professional writing for the field of education. Peer and instructor feedback on writing throughout course. Technologies used to assist with writing. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Field Training in Special Education (3)
desc: Students participate in classroom settings appropriate to concurrently enrolled courses; supervision provided by department field supervisor; (B) first semester; (C) second semester, with ethical issues in education discussed and applied in field settings; (D) third semester, with emphasis on writing and oral communication for application in field settings. SPED majors only. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only. Pre: 304 (or concurrent) or consent for (B); 400B for (C); 400C for (D).
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Student Teaching in Special Education Modified (V)
desc: Modified student teaching for students from another institution completing student teaching at UH or for students who have prior extensive teaching experience. A-F only. Pre: requirements for registration listed under “Student Teaching,” approval of review committee and consent.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Seminar for Student Teachers in Special Education (V)
