desc: Seminar relating current educational theories with experiences. (B) elementary/ special education; (C) early childhood education/ special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only. Pre: requirements for registration listed under “student teaching.” Co-requisite: 390B for (B); 390C for (C); 390D for (D).
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: (Alpha) Student Teaching in Special Education (V)
desc: Full-time supervised experience in school. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one per alpha. A-F only. Co-requisite: 391B for (B); 391C for (C); 391D for (D).
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Young Children with Communication Needs (3)
desc: Communication development of infants and young children, ages birth through age 8, with and without disabilities. Assessment and intervention to support the development of communication skills in inclusive community and school environments. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Field Training – Blended ECE (4)
desc: Students spend 15 hours per week in settings appropriate to concurrently enrolled classes; supervision provided by participating teacher and college supervisor. Repeatable two times. A-F only. (Cross-listed as STE 315)
metadata: College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Foundations of Inclusive Schooling (3)
desc: Foundations of “special education” exploring philosophies, diverse and historical viewpoints, laws, and service delivery. Students reflect upon texts, films and interviews with persons with disabilities, their families and professionals to understand the culture of disability. A-F only.
metadata: DS College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPED
title: Disability and Diversity in the Media (3)
desc: Explores the changing disability experience as described in contemporary film, literature, advertising, news, sports and dialogue with persons with disabilities in the Pacific region and around the world. A-F only.
metadata: DS College of Education Special Education (SPED)

subject: SPAN
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent of department chair.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Seminar in Hispanic Literature (3)
desc: A period, author, genre, or region. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Spanish-American Short Story and Essay (3)
desc: Study of representative writers from various periods: Sor Juana, Palma, Quiroga, Reyes, Borges, etc. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Spanish-American Poetry (3)
desc: Study of representative poets from all periods: Martí, Darió, Mistral, Guillén, Neruda, Paz, etc. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Colonial Spanish-American Literature (3)
desc: Spanish-American literature from period of discovery to independence. Representative authors such as Sor Juana, Bernal Díaz del Castillo. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Spanish-American Novel (3)
desc: Critical analysis of major Spanish-American novels. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: (Alpha) 20th-Century Spanish Literature (3)
desc: Representative works from 20th-century literature. Genres: poetry, theater, essay, novel. (B) generation of 1898; (C) pre-Civil War; (D) post-Civil War. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: 19th-Century Spanish Realism (3)
desc: Nineteenth-century Spanish realism in the novel. Authors include Galdós, Clarin, Alarcón, Pardo Bazán, Blasco-Ibáñez, Valera. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: (Alpha) Golden Age Literature (3)
desc: Spanish literature from the 16th and 17th centuries. (B) theater; (C) prose; (D) poetry; (E) Cervantes. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Medieval Spanish Literature (3)
desc: Representative readings in prose and poetry, from origins through 15th century. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Topics in Spanish Applied Linguistics (3)
desc: Supervised participation in online course at UNED University (Spain) relevant to student’s specialization for Second Language Studies or Spanish Applied Linguistics. Students also complete projects and meet with advisor to check progress. Repeatable two times for different topics. Graduate students only. Pre: Spanish Proficiency assessment: B- (CERFL) or Advanced low (ACTFL).
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Seminar in Spanish Applied Linguistics (3)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Independent study of approved readings and research with faculty supervision. A-F only. Repeatable two times. Pre: consent of instructor and departmental approval.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Studies in Latin American and Iberian Film (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics in Latin American and/or Iberian cinemas; e.g. national or regional cinemas, periods, movements or issues, major filmmakers, film theory and criticism. Repeatable two times. Pre: 320, 361, 371, or 396; or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: (Alpha) Topics in Hispanic Scholarship (3)
desc: Hispanic authors, periods, or themes. (B) literature and society; (D) literature and film. Repeatable for other topics, but not for the same topic. Pre: 320, 361, or 371; or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Hispanic Theater (3)
desc: Study of representative authors and plays from Spain and Latin America. Repeatable one time. Pre: one of 361, 362, 371, or 372; or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Hispanic Women’s Literature (3)
desc: Women’s literary and cultural expressions in Latin America and Spain. Pre: one of 320, 361, or 371; or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: U.S. Latino Literature (3)
desc:
Study of the literature of U.S. Hispanics written in Spanish or 
bilingually. Pre: 320, 361, or 371; or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Intensive Fourth-Level Spanish Abroad (V)
desc: Intensive course of formal instruction on the fourth-year level in Spanish language and culture in a Spanish-speaking country. For semester programs only. Pre: 360 or equivalent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Fourth-Level Spanish Abroad (3)
desc: Continuation of 458.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Fourth-Level Spanish Abroad (3)
desc:
Intensive course of full-time formal instruction on the fourth-year level in Spanish linguistics, civilization, culture, and 
literature in a Spanish-speaking country. Pre: any two of 301; 303, 358, 359, or 360.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics (3)
desc: Analysis of morphology, syntax, and semantics. Pre: 330 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Historical Spanish Linguistics (3)
desc: Evolution of Spanish from Latin; modern social and geographical dialects. Pre: 330 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Spanish-English Translation (3)
desc: Factors in the art of translation. Practice in translating material from Spanish to English and the reverse. Pre: 305 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Building Advanced Fluency (3)
desc: Advanced practice; emphasis on building active vocabulary. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Spanish Language in Society (3)
desc: Explores issues in Spanish language in society (media, communication, advertising, government, technology). Introduces and examines current sociolinguistic and sociopragmatic issues. Pre: 330 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Independent study of approved reading with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: 301 (or concurrent), consent and departmental approval.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Introduction to Hispanic Film (3)
desc: Introduction to the study and analysis of genres, techniques, and cinematic styles as used in Hispanic film. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: (Alpha) Reading Latin America (3)
desc: Culture and history of Spanish America through literature; (B) warriors, nuns, and rebels; (C) the magical and the real. Repeatable one time for different alphas. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: 301, or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: (Alpha) Reading Spain (3)
desc: Reading and discussion of narratives from and about Spain; (B) heroines, knights, witches; (C) love, loss, liberty. Repeatable one time for different alphas. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: 301, or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Intensive Third-Level Spanish Abroad (V)
desc: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in Spanish language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in a Spanish-speaking country. Pre: 202 or equivalent
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Third-Level Spanish Abroad (3)
desc: Continuation of 358.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Third-Level Spanish Abroad (3)
desc: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in Spanish language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in a Spanish-speaking country. Pre: 202 or 259 or equivalent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: (Alpha) Latin American Cultural Studies (3)
desc: Survey of the history, traditions, and cultures of Latin America; (B) empires and traditions; (C) nations, identity & the arts. Repeatable one time for other topics, but not for the same topic. Pre: 301 or consent
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Spain: Traditions & Trending (3)
desc: Survey of the history and cultures of Spain. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: From Comics to Classics (3)
desc: Introduction and development of Spanish skills for critical reading and writing, rhetoric, and vocabulary. Choices with particular emphasis on literary analysis and academic writing. Online course. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Introduction to Spanish-English Interpreting (3)
desc: Students will begin to develop the listening and memory skills for direct and inverse interpretation. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: 301 or 310, or consent
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: (Alpha) Spanish in Use (3)
desc:
Spanish language as used in specific professions; (B) marketing, tourism & business; (C) health & public safety. 
Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: 301, or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Introduction to Spanish-English Translation (3)
desc: Practical introduction to written Spanish-English translation through the translations of texts from Spanish to English and the reverse. Includes an emphasis on composition and style. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Conversation II (3)
desc: Continuation of 303. Pre: 303 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Conversation I (3)
desc: Intensive practice in spoken Spanish, focusing on the preparation and completion of oral tasks and presentations. Pre: 202 or 259, or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Language and Writing I (3)
desc: Improvement of Spanish vocabulary, language accuracy, and expression of ideas in Spanish through writing. Pre: 202 or 203 or 259, or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Legends, Stories, and Current Events (3)
desc: Development of language skills through reading of literary and cultural texts. Pre: 202 (or concurrent) or 203 or 259.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish Abroad (3)
desc: Continuation of 258.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish Abroad (3)
desc: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction on the second-year level in Spanish language and culture in a Spanish-speaking country. Pre: 102 or 103.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Intensive Spanish for Business (6)
desc: SPAN 201 and 202 content combined, oriented to business Spanish. Three 50-minute sessions per week plus online work. Pre: 102 or 103.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish (3)
desc: Continuation of oral practice and grammar study; increasing emphasis on reading and written composition. Pre: 102 or 103.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Intensive Elementary Spanish (6)
desc: Course content of SPAN 101 and 102 covered in one semester. Three two-hour sessions per week.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish (3)
desc: Conversation, grammar, reading. Pre: 101.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish (3)
desc: Conversation, grammar, reading.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SOC
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Urban Sociology (3)
desc: Demographic trends in urban growth: nature and dimensions of urbanization and urbanism; ancient, American, and Third World cities; ecological theories of urban growth; lifestyles.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Development in Asia (3)
desc: Theories and available research methods examined for applicability to developing areas; specific examples from Asia. A-F only. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Social Movements (3)
desc: Study of sociology of social movements, plus independent student research. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Social Structure and the Individual (3)
desc: Intensive study and individual research projects in a selected topic. Theoretical and methodological issues in relating social and individual levels of analysis. Recommended: 612.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Conflict Analysis/Resolution (3)
desc: Seminar on the analysis of conflict resolution. Faculty from law, planning, political science and guest practitioners will present multidisciplinary analysis and intervention strategies on contemporary conflicts. A-F only. Graduate students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Race and Ethnicity (3)
desc: An examination of how ideas of “race” and “ethnicity” are constructed, and how this reflects and shapes social structures and relationships: (B) antiracism studies; (C) ethnic identity and nationalism: cooperation and conflict; (D) race, place, and inequality. Repeatable up to two times in different alphas. Graduate students only. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Modern Chinese Society (3)
desc: Developmental policies, social change, and impact on modern Chinese social institutions. Includes China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan. May include social and demographic change, population, social stratification, gender, and family problems. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Modern Japanese Society (3)
desc: Social and behavioral studies of Japanese values, social organization, and personality development. Problems of value conflict, political protest, world role, tradition, and social change. Repeatable one time only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Social Change–Pacific Islands (3)
desc: Analysis of social change; transformation from subsistence societies to commodified, wage-labor societies with participation in world economy.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Comparative Study of East Asia (3)
desc: Comparative analysis of social organization, social processes, and change of both capitalist and communist countries of East Asia, with each other and other areas of the world. Repeatable one time. Pre: 611 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Comparative Family and Gender (3)
desc: Discusses the major perspectives on family and gender relations and examines related empirical research. Emphasis is on the cross-cultural comparisons across the U.S. and Asia in the context of globalizing economies and cultures. A-F only. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as GHPS 719)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Aging, Culture, and Health (3)
desc: Overview of the major theories, perspectives, and empirical findings relating to aging in various cultural contexts. SOC, PSY, NURS, SW, PH majors only. Pre: 606 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Advanced Medical Sociology (3)
desc: Application of theoretical paradigms and methodologies to the examination of selected research topics in the field of medical sociology. Repeatable one time. Pre: 615 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Current Issues in Sociology (3)
desc: Substantive areas that are of current interest and the focus of research, but not addressed in other courses. Repeatable two times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Sociology of Knowledge (3)
desc: Sociological theory applied to bases of knowledge in everyday life, professional communities, and the sciences. Research and theory-building activities of sociologists; ethnomethodology; construction of social structure, culture, and consciousness. Repeatable one time only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Cultural Analysis (3)
desc: Contemporary issues in cultural sociology, covering key theoretical perspectives, analytic methods and substantive areas for empirical research. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Advanced Statistics (3)
desc: Dealing with advanced statistical methods beyond multiple linear regression, such as logit, event history analysis, and multi-level analysis. Emphasis is on applications of the techniques to social science research. Repeatable one time only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Evaluation Research (3)
desc: Research design, data collection, field problems and analysis in the evaluation of social programs. Examples from criminal justice, corrections, drug treatment, mental health, and public health.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Sociology of Sustainability (3)
desc: Analyses of sustainability, environmental, and technoscience issues from sociological perspectives. Graduate students only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as SUST 670)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Teaching Seminar (3)
desc: Examines research on teaching, learning, and ethics, as well as practical skills for teaching at the university level. Syllabi and teaching philosophies are developed, which are useful for the academic job market. Graduate standing only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Methods of Demographic Analysis (3)
desc: Statistical evaluation and analysis of population data; data sources; population growth; composition; standardization of rates; mortality and the life table; nuptiality and fertility; distribution, migration, urbanization; projections and stable population theory. (Cross-listed as PH 659)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to Human Population (3)
desc: Comparative analysis of quantitative and qualitative aspects of population; factors affecting size, distribution, and composition; impact of population size and composition on society.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: American Punishment (3)
desc: Examines the history of American criminal punishment, from the birth of the penitentiary to the rise of the prison-industrial complex. A-F only. Graduate students only. (Cross-listed as AMST 638)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Criminal Justice System (3)
desc: Examination of the criminal justice system; the exercise of discretion and limits placed upon it. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Criminology (3)
desc: Major current theories, history of their development, elaborations of typologies, implications for treatment modalities.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Feminist Criminology (3)
desc: Key themes in feminist criminology are explored including focus on masculinities and crime, race and intersectionality, global criminology, and the ways in which the criminal justice system controls women and girls. A-F only. (Cross-listed as WGSS 625)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Social Stratification (3)
desc: Classical theories of social class, contemporary developments; crucial research issues, appropriate methodologies. Repeatable one time only. Classified graduate students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Sociology of Mental Health and Illness (3)
desc: Examines sociological research and theories about mental health and illness. A key question in medical sociology will be addressed: What is the relationship between society and mental health? Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Stress and Health (3)
desc: Analysis of current theory and empirical research on relationship of stress and health; sociological, psychological, and community psychiatry models and current issues.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Medical Sociology (3)
desc: Covers the major paradigms in medical sociology for analyzing social epidemiology, the political economy of health systems, health service organizations, health and wellness behaviors illness perception and help-seeking, doctor-patient interaction, and adaptations to illness. Graduate students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Organizational Analysis (3)
desc: Theoretical approaches to organizations; organizational structure and process; organizational pathologies and effectiveness; the organization and its environment.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Contemporary Sociological Theory (3)
desc: Seminar offers a critical overview of major perspectives and representative works in sociology theory from the 1960s to the present, including intellectual contexts and historical development. A-F only. Graduate students only.  (Spring only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Classical Sociological Theory (3)
desc: Seminar offers a critical overview of major perspectives and representative works in sociological theory from 19th-century to the 1960s, including intellectual contexts and historical development. A-F only. Graduate students only. Pre: consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar Qualitative Research (3)
desc: Advanced seminar on conducting fieldwork in natural social settings with emphasis on qualitative techniques, political and ethical considerations, data management and assessment, interpretation and reflexive writing. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey Research Design and Analysis (3)
desc: Survey study designs, survey sampling, questionnaire construction, interviewing, pre-tests, pilot studies, logic of measurement and association, table construction, and elaboration models. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as EDEA 608 and EDEP 602)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Seminar in Methods of Content Analysis (3)
desc: Content analysis combines quantitative and qualitative methods to analyze text systematically. Covers sampling and case selection; manual and computer-assisted methods of coding and analyzing textual data; writing reports using content analysis data. Repeatable one time. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Research Methods and Design (3)
desc: Emphasis on theory selection, theory construction, and choice of research strategies.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Regression Analysis Laboratory (1)
desc: Lab for computer analysis skills is required for students taking 605. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 605.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Statistics for Regression Analysis (3)
desc: Dealing with the multiple linear regression and logistic regression models, focusing on modeling, i.e., specification of the explanatory variables to answer different research questions. Emphasis on applications using statistical package programs. SOC 605L is required.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Directed Reading or Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: 300 and consent of instructor.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Topics in Sociology: Student Projects (V)
desc: Students create their own study group and solicit an advisor from faculty. Consult department for assistance.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Topics in Sociology (3)
desc: Topics course that explore current issues and try new ideas. Repeatable two times. Pre: 300 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Social Sciences Internship (V)
desc: Internship in public, private, or non-profit organizations providing opportunity for practical experience and application of social sciences concepts and theories. Three to six credits per semester; repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. Consent of instructor. (Cross-listed as SOCS 489 and WGSS 489)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Politics of Multiculturalism (3)
desc: The development of ethnic relations and political approaches to multiculturalism in two multiethnic nations: Canada and the U.S. A-F only. Pre: 300 or one 300 level ES course, or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 492)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Discussion Group Leader–Freshman Seminar (6)
desc: A unique opportunity for students to gain leadership, teaching, and public speaking skills as a SOC 100 leader for a section of 10 freshmen students while being mentored weekly by a faculty course coordinator.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Field Research Methods (3)
desc: Techniques for collecting and analyzing qualitative data. Participant observation; small groups in natural settings; community studies. Grounded theory; theories of everyday life; reality construction.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Social Statistics Laboratory (1)
desc: Required lab for computer applications for analysis of sociological data. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 476.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Social Statistics (3)
desc: Common statistical procedures emphasizing univariate and bivariate description; some attention to multivariate techniques and statistical inference, within context of research procedures. Pre: 300 or consent. Co-requisite: 476L.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Survey Research (3)
desc: Survey research design and analysis, including theory selection instrument construction, sampling techniques, data collection, computerized data analysis, and writing up research reports of the findings.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Popular Culture (3)
desc: Popular culture as manifested in film, sports, TV, comics, magazines, etc.; relation to sociological theories and studies.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Sports and Society (3)
desc: Critical perspectives on sports and society. Topics include power and inequality; mobility, status, and economics; youth development; globalization; gender; and violence in sports and the wider society. Pre: 300 and 321. (Spring only)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Sociology of the Arts (3)
desc: Relation of art to society; role of artist, audience, critic, patron, museum; Western and other societies; attitudes toward new styles.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Racism and Ethnicity in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: The historical and contemporary social processes involved in inter-ethnic relations in Hawai‘i. Pre: 300 or one ES 300 level course, or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 456)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Sociology of Religion (3)
desc: Seminar in research on sociological aspects of religious sectarianism; attention to Hawai‘i. Pre: 300 or consent. (Cross-listed as REL 452)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Medical Sociology (3)
desc: Application of sociological theories and concepts to medical social situations and behavior; problems of obtaining data for research.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Sociology of Aging (3)
desc: Social and research issues significant to delivery of long-term care services to the elderly; cost, quality, availability of services, evaluation of programs, role of family, formal and informal care services.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Marriage and Family: A Feminist Perspective (3)
desc: Sex-role socialization, motherhood, work-family conflicts. Alternative family structures in U.S. and other countries. Recommended: at least one WGSS course. Pre: 300, or WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course; or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 452)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Marriage and the Family (3)
desc: Theory and methods of studying social interaction in marriage and the family; examination of marriage, mating, love, and choice. Empirical research emphasizing Hawai‘i.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Gender Violence Over the Lifecycle (3)
desc: Examines the problem of violence, particularly sexual violence, over the life cycle. Offers gendered perspective in activities aimed at prevention and treatment of violence, and cross cultural perspectives. Pre: 300, WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course; or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 446)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Gender Violence (3)
desc: Historical and structural theories of gender-based violence, including domestic and sexual abuse, prostitution, trafficking, cross-cultural perspectives, social policy and practices. Junior standing or graduate standing only. Pre: 300 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Social Structure and the Individual (3)
desc: Effects of social institutions on individuals. Role of socioeconomic status, cultural background, family structure, peer group, schools, and occupational roles in socialization.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Women and Crime (3)
desc: Women’s relations with the criminal justice system; types of women’s offenses; responses to women’s crime; women as victims; women as workers in the criminal justice system. Recommended: at least one WGSS course. Pre: 300, or WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course; or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 435)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Law and Social Change (3)
desc: Interrelationships between legal orders and other social institutions; use of “law” to change major status relationships, e.g., boss-worker, woman-man, child-adult.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Punishment & Society (3)
desc: Institutions, organizations, and individuals charged with carrying out punishment in the criminal justice system and beyond. DS
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Advanced Criminology & Juvenile Delinquency (3)
desc: Research in systematic social deviation. Scaling and measurement of delinquents/ criminals, official data, gangs, identification and measurement of delinquent/criminal value orientations, etc. DS
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Organizations and Society (3)
desc: Schools, hospitals, industries, prisons, and government agencies analyzed in terms of self-actualization, alienation, human relations, communication, leadership, organizational conflicts.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Women and Work (3)
desc: Gender and race of paid and unpaid work in the formal and informal sectors of the economy; carework in households; unemployment; ethics of revaluing feminized work; labor rights: scope: local and global. Pre: 300, or one 300-level WGSS or ES course; or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 418 and WGSS 418)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Technology and Society (3)
desc: Nature of technology, social forces that affect its adoption; impact on society; innovation.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Economy and Society (3)
desc: Study of the dominant trend of economic change and its impact on society; globalization of economic activities and transformation of industrial society to postindustrial one; corporate restructuring and downsizing and their impact on employment and income distribution; gender relations in workplaces; the impact of globalization on the newly industrializing countries. Pre: 300 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Population and Society (3)
desc: Global and U.S. patterns of population growth; composition and distribution, elementary demographic techniques; development issues and population policy. Pre: 300 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Social Stratification (3)
desc: Approaches to research in social inequality: community studies; historical and cross-cultural analyses of poverty, working class, middle class, power structure, social mobility, etc.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Analysis in Urban Sociology (3)
desc: Urbanization in developed and developing countries, the rural-urban continuum, structure and process of metropolitan regions, theories of urban location and growth, housing and urban renewal.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Food, Body, and Women: Analysis of Biopolitics (3)
desc: Explores how food, body, and other “matter of life” are imbedded in biopolitics from the feminist perspectives. A-F only. Pre: WGSS 300, or one 300-level WGSS or ES course, or consent. (Spring only).
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Law, Politics and Society (3)
desc: Relationships between law, politics, and society will be explored. Emphasis is placed on several dimensions of legality: legal “indeterminacy” and some of the many things that law does for us and to us; law’s response to violence; the connections between law and social change; access to the law and its sociological dimensions; how/why law fails and what happens when it does. A-F only. Pre: 100 or any 200 level SOC course, or a 100 level or 200 level POLS course, or consent. (Cross-listed as POLS 374)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Sustainability, Technoscience, and Social Justice (3)
desc: Examines politics of sustainability and technoscience with an explicit attention to social justice and power relations in society. A-F only. Pre: 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course, or consent. (Fall only) (Crosslisted as SUST 367 and WGSS 367)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Sociology of Gender (3)
desc: Effect of sex and gender roles (both traditional and nontraditional) on attitudes and behavior within the family and educational, economic, and governmental systems. Recommended: at least one WGSS course. Pre: 100 or any 200-level SOC course, WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course; or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 362)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Sociology of Korea (3)
desc: Social institutions, family, education, religion, cultural values, social classes, economic development, social movements, gender relations, North-South relations, and unification issues. A-F only. Pre: 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Japanese Society and Culture (3)
desc: Persistence and change in economy, policy, religion, education, family, and other institutions of modern Japan.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Chinese Society and Culture (3)
desc: Social institutions, family, community, education, stratification, government, economy; impact of modernization and revolution on their contemporary transformation. A-F only.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey of Medical Sociology (3)
desc: Social factors in disease and treatment; illness behavior, roles of patients and healers; nature of healing professions; use of medical services; alternative systems of medical organization.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey of Sociology of Aging (3)
desc: Aging as a social phenomenon, including social impacts of growing elderly population and emerging social patterns among the elderly. Important theoretical perspectives and cross-national research. (cross-listed as COA 353)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey of Sociology of Education (3)
desc: Formal education as one aspect of socialization. Emphasis on American system; business, military, and religious institutions.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey of Social Psychology (3)
desc: Major principles; social attitudes, theories of conformity and change, person perception and attribution theory, social role, role conflict and role behavior, group structure, and behavior.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Deviance and Social Control (3)
desc: Interrelations of deviance, criminology, juvenile delinquency, corrections, social control, sociology of law. Key concepts, theories. DS
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Drugs and Society (3)
desc: Use of mood- and mind-altering drugs in America among adults, youth, and cross-culturally. Illicit drug culture, psychedelics, and perception; social norms and deviant behavior.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Criminology (3)
desc: Concepts used in crime, law enforcement, criminal justice, and corrections. Types of criminal behavior; costs and effects of control.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Sociology of Law (3)
desc: Law as a political enforcement of the social order; how it is organized and operates; determinants of effectiveness; ways it adapts to and facilitates changing social conditions.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey of Sociological Theory (3)
desc: Major theorists and their influences, from Comte to today.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Women and Social Policy (3)
desc: Social and economic policies affecting women in families, education, social services, government, health care, the economy; public policy implementation and development; policy impact on women. Pre: 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or WS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course; or consent. (Cross-listed as WS 318)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey of Social Change (3)
desc: Causes, processes, and effects of social change, using single and multi-cause models in simple and complex industrialized societies.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey of Sociology of Work (3)
desc: Work from viewpoint of individuals; meaningfulness versus productivity; how work, economics, and the industrial system affect individual goals.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey of Social Inequality and Stratification (3)
desc: Introduction to social stratification theory and research; definition and measurement of socioeconomic status; racial, ethnic and gender inequality; differences in lifestyles and life chances; social mobility.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Women and Health (3)
desc: Explores current issues in the conceptualization and delivery of health care for women. Pre: 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or WGSS 151 or WGSS 202, or POLS 110; or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 305)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Survey of Urban Sociology (3)
desc: Urban processes and social problems, such as poverty, crime, racial segregation, homelessness, housing policy, urbanization, and neighborhood ethnic diversity. How places shape identity and opportunity. Research methods applied to communities, places, and neighborhoods of Hawai‘i. (Cross-listed as PLAN 301)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Principles of Sociological Inquiry (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 2 50-min Lab) Basic methods of sociology for production and analysis of data. Foundations for understanding research and for advanced courses in methods and statistics. Restricted to students in the honors program and required for students taking the honors track in sociology. A-F only.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Principles of Sociological Inquiry (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 2 50-min Lab) Basic methods of sociology for production and analysis of data. Foundations for understanding research and for advanced courses in methods and statistics.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to Sociology of the Family (3)
desc: Family patterns, mate selection, parent-child interaction, socialization of roles, legal sanctions, trends in organization, functions.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to Juvenile Delinquency (3)
desc: Forms of juvenile deviance; conditions and processes that result in alienation and deviance of youth. Juvenile corrections as institutionalized societal responses.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to Social Problems (3)
desc: Theoretical and substantive survey of the nature and causes of social problems; selected types: poverty, inequality, deviance, etc
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to Race and Ethnic Relations (3)
desc: Race and ethnic relations in world perspective; social, economic, and political problems associated with perception, existence, and accommodation of these groups within the wider society. (Cross-listed as ES 214)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to Sociology (3)
desc: Basic social relationships, social structures, and processes.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SW
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable one time.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Advanced Social Welfare Policy Analysis and Change (3)
desc: Builds on 630 and emphasizes a more thorough and comprehensive examination of major policies, programs, and populations central to a concentration (Health, Mental Health, Gerontology, Child and Family). Students learn a more focused and applied analysis of the relationship between social policy, research, and social work practice. SW majors only. A-F only. Pre: 606 and 607; 630 and 631; 640 and 650; 659 and 660; 690 and 691.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Specialist Field Education II (V)
desc: Continuation of 790. A-F only. Pre: 790 and; 718 (or concurrent); or 723 (or concurrent); or 725 (or concurrent); or 727 (or concurrent) (all with a minimum grade of B-).
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Specialist Field Education I (V)
desc:
Instruction in the field is continued. The field experience in the second year provides an opportunity for the student to test out 
concepts, principles, theories, and alternate approaches in actual practice settings. SW majors only. A-F only. Pre: 717 (or concurrent) or 722 (or concurrent) or 724 (or concurrent) or 726 (or concurrent) (all with a minimum grade of B -).
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Seminar on Women and Health (3)
desc: Women’s health and the role of women health professionals. Current literature and research regarding attitudes, roles, rights, and health care. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Cross-listed as NURS 744)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Cultural Factors in Work with Hawaiians (3)
desc: Hawaiian culture, past and present. Explores and examines possible approaches to working with Hawaiians and part-Hawaiians. Special emphasis on supports in the Hawaiian system that may promote maximal functioning for those Hawaiians experiencing problems in today’s society. Meets seminar requirement. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Seminar in International Social Work (3)
desc: Approaches to social problems and trends in the profession in international, cross-cultural perspectives. Emphasis on developmental aspects of social work. Political, economic, social, and cultural forces shaping social welfare in national development. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Dissertation Seminar (3)
desc: Culminating experience in social welfare doctoral specialization; integration of PhD core and specialization course work. Pre: classified student in PhD in social welfare program or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Qualitative Research: Philosophical, Methodological and Analytic Approaches (3)
desc: Theories and methods of qualitative research; problem formulation, informant selection, study design, data collection and analysis utilizing qualitative approaches. Repeatable three times. A-F only. Pre: 640 or 651 or equivalent; departmental approval.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Quantitative Methods II (3)
desc: Empirical research methodology with emphasis on design principles and measurement theory; design and measurement issues and problems in cross-cultural research. A-F only. Pre: PhD candidate in social welfare or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Analysis and Development of Knowledge for Social Work (3)
desc: Focuses on developing an understanding of philosophy of science, theory development, social work epistemology, and the analysis and development of knowledge for social work practice. A-F only. Pre: PhD candidate in social welfare or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Individual or Group Research Project– Plan B (V)
desc: Same as 743. A-F only
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Individual or Group Research Project– Plan B (V)
desc: Same as 743. A-F only. Pre: 743.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Individual or Group Research Project— Plan B (V)
desc: Independent research (group of two to seven students or by an individual student) undertaken under the sponsorship of a faculty advisor. Elements are selection of a topic related to the practice of social work or knowledge relevant to that practice, utilization of empirical research methodology in collecting and analyzing original data, and preparation of a scholarly paper. SW majors only. A-F only. Pre: 650.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Review of Research in Social Work (3)
desc: In-depth study of research in a substantive area. Each seminar will be devoted to a particular topic: e.g., foster care of children, effectiveness of social work intervention, etc. SW majors only. Pre: 650.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Work and the Law (3)
desc: Knowledge of judicial systems and law relevant to social work practice in corrections, child-family welfare, health, and mental health. Skills for effective participation in the legal process are acquired in moot court and in practice for testifying. SW majors only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Policy Analysis (3)
desc: Students pursue in-depth a specific topic in the areas of social planning, social policy analysis, evaluation of social programs, administration, supervision, and consultation. Selectively a comparative perspective is introduced and case studies used to illustrate concepts, principles, and techniques, with implications for practice. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. Pre: 630 or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Seminar in Social Work with Older Adults (3)
desc: Designed for gerontology specialization students to gain advanced knowledge for working with diverse older adults and their families. Emphasis on strength perspectives on aging. SW majors only. Pre: 726.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Work Practice with Older Adults (3)
desc: Designed to provide students with an in-depth understanding of theoretical formulations and intervention strategies for working with older adults and their families. Emphasis on diversity/justice. SW majors only. Pre: completion of foundation courses.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Work Practice in Mental Health (3)
desc: Prepares students for social work practice in mental health settings, with a focus on history and policy in the U.S. and Hawai‘i, as well as culturally-grounded and evidence-based practice. SW majors only. Pre: 724.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Seminar in Social Work Practice in Mental Health (3)
desc: Prepares students for social work practice in mental health settings. Focused on engagement and assessment while emphasizing cultural, person in environment, and strengths-based approaches. SW majors only. Pre: completion of foundation courses.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Seminar in Social Work Practice in Health Care (3)
desc: Through the use of case studies developed by the students, social work practice is examined in three areas of health care: primary care provided in health departments and medical groups, hospital-based services, and long-term care. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. Pre: 722.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Work Practice in Health Care (3)
desc: Didactic and experiential learning activity focuses on the major role functions of the social worker in the health field including assessment, contracting, counseling, advocacy, case management, discharge planning, family group work, community and team building. Covers health care policy, research directions in practice and social work management issues. SW majors only. Pre: completion of foundation courses.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Seminar in Social Work Practice with Children and Families (3)
desc: Designed for students in the child and family concentration and builds upon past knowledge and skill development in practice classes and in the practicum. Students integrate, demonstrate, and extend earlier learning, acquire new knowledge, and learn and practice new skills. Organized around student case presentations in a consultation format. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. Pre: 717.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Work Practice with Children and Families (3)
desc: Advanced practice course for students specializing in social work with children and families. Designed to provide students with an in-depth understanding of both theoretical formulations and therapeutic techniques for practice in the field of family and child welfare. Emphasis placed on the development of specialized knowledge and skills for assessment, intervention, and evaluation of a variety of common child and family practice situations. SW majors only. Pre: completion of foundation courses.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Therapeutic Strategies with the Older Adult (3)
desc: Focuses on interdisciplinary strategies with older adults: individual, family, and group therapy; eclectic mental health approaches; case management; and environmental intervention. Emphasis placed on the use of these strategies as preventive, as well as supportive, measures for the well, transition, and frail elderly. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Methods of Group Psychotherapy (3)
desc: Designed specifically to train students in the theory and practice of leading psychotherapy groups; it includes historical developments, research, theories, and application of group psychotherapy, group techniques and exercises. SW majors only. Pre: 607 or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Independent research under supervision of a thesis committee. Includes formal proposal and defense of finished research. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Students, on the basis of special interest, select a faculty member to work with on a problem for which planned individualized study or research is deemed advisable. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Health and Aging (3)
desc: Biological and physiological changes associated with aging. Social and psychological factors associated with health maintenance. Major threats to health, changing patterns of morbidity and mortality of the aged. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Generalist Field Education II (3)
desc: Field education is the signature pedagogy of social work education. Students will engage in supervised social work practice and have the opportunity to apply generalist knowledge, skills, values, and ethics to practice. A-F only. Pre: 690 and 607 (or concurrent) and 631 (or concurrent) (all with a minimum grade of C).
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Generalist Field Education I (3)
desc: Field education is the signature pedagogy of social work education. Students will engage in supervised social work practice and have the opportunity to apply generalist knowledge, skills, values, and ethics to practice. A-F only. Pre: 606 (or concurrent)(with a minimum grade of C).
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Marriage and Family Therapy (3)
desc: Introduction to couple and family therapy offers an overview of family systems perspective, theory and technique relevant to informing effective social work case planning, case management, advocacy, and interaction with clients. SW majors only. Graduate students only.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Topics in Social Welfare (V)
desc: Current trends in field of social welfare. Recent courses have focused on forensic social work, immigrants and refugees, and leadership in human services. Meets seminar requirement. Repeatable one time in different topics. SW majors only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Community and Public Health Practice (2)
desc: Community organization and development applicable to the delivery of health services. Understanding community dynamics, mobilizing community groups for effective health care practice and delivery. SW majors only. Pre: PH 647 or consent. (Cross-listed as PH 671)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Child Welfare as a Field of Social Work (3)
desc: Emphasis on the developments in child welfare; issues, concerns with regard to needs and rights, and the application of social work services to problems associated with needs for protection. Review of historical, theoretical, empirical, and legal findings for skill development in intervening in dysfunctional parent/child interaction. SW majors only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Treatment of Chemical Dependency (3)
desc: Introduction to treatment of alcoholism and other chemical dependencies. Application of social work strategies in work with individuals and families in the disease and recovery process. Repeatable one time. SW majors only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Human Behavior in the Social Environment II (3)
desc: Focus on human development across the lifespan with attention given to unique challenges and opportunities faced in each phase. Emphasis is placed on “populations at risk” and the strengths and assets unique to diverse populations. A-F only. Pre: 659. (Spring only)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Human Behavior in the Social Environment I (3)
desc: Examination of complex factors that privilege some and oppress/marginalize others; challenges commonly held tropes and complicates the discourse regarding individual, family, group, organizational and community development within the social environment. SW majors only. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing. (Fall only)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Multivariate Methods (3)
desc: Multivariate forms of multiple linear regression, analysis of variance, and analysis of co-variance. Multiple discriminant analysis, canonical correlation, and principal components analysis are discussed. SW majors only.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Applied Regression and Analysis of Variance (3)
desc: Introduction to linear statistical models as principle of data analysis. Topics include multiple regression models with continuous and categorical predictors. ANOVA with multiple factors, ANOVA with repeated measures, and ANCOVA. Pre: 601 or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Quantitative Methods I (3)
desc: Introduction to quantitative methods in behavioral sciences. Introduction to general linear model as principle of data analysis. Course requires basic statistics. (Meets PhD common inquiry methods requirement or elective.)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Research Designs and Data Analyses for the Evaluation of Practice Effectiveness (3)
desc: Extending the study of scientific methods introduced in 640. Covers the range of empirical research methods and data analytic procedures suitable for knowledge building and practice evaluation at all levels of intervention from case to program. A-F only. Pre: 640. (Spring only)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Introduction to Scientific Methods and Principles in Social Work (3)
desc: Understanding and interpreting results of nomothetic and idiographic research; design principles and statistical analyses and their relationship to practices; use of published research. SW majors only. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing. (Fall only)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social and Cultural Aspects of Aging (3)
desc: Overview of aging from the biopsycho, socioeconomic and cultural perspectives. Explores common theories of aging. Emphasis on bridging the gap between the realm of concepts and theories, and the world of practice in gerontology. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Death and Dying (3)
desc: Physical, social, cultural, psychological, and spiritual dimensions of dying, death, and bereavement. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Policies, Programs and Services on Aging (3)
desc: Explores policies, programs, and services for older adults. Students learn about the aging network, assess older adults’ needs, link older adults to appropriate services in the community, and track legislative bills that address older adults’ quality of life. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Organization and Administration in Social Work (3)
desc: Introduction to formal organization theory. Social service administration examined and implications for service delivery systems developed. SW majors only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Work Practice in Communities and Organizations (3)
desc: Community conceptualization; organized roles of developer, enabler, broker, mediator, and advocate; diagnostic and problem-solving technology; the special characteristics of the social worker as community organizer; matrix of structural objectives; sources and use of power; how to build an organization; and interorganizational negotiation. SW majors only. A-F only. Pre: 606, graduate standing, and consent. (Spring only)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Welfare Policy and Services (3)
desc: Examines in a historical and comparative framework the economic, social, political, organizational, and administrative factors influencing the development, formulation, and implementation of social welfare policies in the U.S. Provides opportunity for the application of various models of social policy analysis in major areas of social welfare programming and service delivery. SW majors only. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing. (Fall only)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Work Practice with Families and Groups (3)
desc: Practice course builds upon the generalist framework and foundation content presented in 606. Special emphasis is given on models for assessment, intervention, and evaluation of practice with families and groups. Relevant theories of groups and the principles of group dynamics and group work methods are examined in regard to task, therapeutic, psychoeducational, and social development groups. Family content includes structural, behavioral, communication/experiential, and culturally-specific theories of intervention. A-F only. Pre: 606.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Work Practice with Individuals (3)
desc: Beginning practice course introduces students to the basic processes of social work and the roles and skills needed for generalist practice. Relevant theories of social work practice with individuals are explored for the efficacy with various problems and for their applicability to practice with various ethnocultures, social classes, and oppressed populations. Interviewing and interpersonal skill development are incorporated. A-F only. Pre: admission to MSW program. (Fall only)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Planned individualized study or research in special area related to social work practice interest. Up to 3 credit hours. Pre: majors only, senior standing, and consent of program chair and faculty advisor.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Undergraduate Field Education III (4)
desc: Advanced instruction to field education; application of social work knowledge, skills, and values to the field experience. Pre: 490 complete with C or better, and majors only. Co-requisite: 403.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Undergraduate Field Education II (4)
desc: Intermediate instruction to field education; application of social work knowledge, skills, and values to the field experience. Pre: 391 complete with C or better, and majors only. Co-requisite: 402 and 440.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Topics in Social Welfare (V)
desc: An examination of current trends and issues in social work. SW majors only.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Welfare Concepts and Issues in Gerontology (3)
desc: Aging and its effect on the individual, family groups, associations, and communities. Impact of aging on social service delivery systems, public policy and role of social work. Pre: senior standing or consent.
metadata: DS Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Services with Children (3)
desc: Study of current social services for children in the U.S. with focus on familiarization of child welfare programs and services in Hawai‘i. Pre: senior standing or consent.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Research Development in Social Welfare (3)
desc: Introduction to and application of language of research, theoretical concepts underlying advancement of knowledge, practical steps in research. SW majors only. Pre: completion of required junior-level SW courses (i.e., 302, 303, 325, 326, 360, 361, and 391) with C or better. Co-requisite: 402 and 490.
metadata: DS Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Back to the Future: Aging in Today’s Society (3)
desc: By 2050, more than a quarter of the world’s population will be 60 years of age or older. Explores what we know about aging today to encourage a lifetime of aging well. A-F only. Pre: 201 or SW 360 or WGSS 305 or PSY 100 or HDFS 230 or NURS 200; or consent. (Cross-listed as COA 435 and PH 435)
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: General Social Work Practice IV (3)
desc: Examination of practice methods and intervention models; identification and analysis of issues related to practice. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction congruent with professional expectations. Pre: 402 (C or better) and majors only. Co-requisite: 491.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: General Social Work Practice III (3)
desc: Use of problem-solving processes and ethical models of decision-making in practice with individuals, families, groups, and communities. Pre: 303, 326, and 361 complete with C or better; and majors only. Corequisite: 440 and 490.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Undergraduate Field Education I (3)
desc: Introduction to field education; application of social work knowledge, skills, and values to the field experience. CR/NC only. Pre: 302, 325, 326 (or concurrent), 360, and 361 (or concurrent) complete with C or better; and majors only. Co-requisite: 303.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Topics in Social Welfare (V)
desc: An examination of current trends in the field of social welfare. SW majors only.
metadata: DS Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Human Behavior and the Social Environment II (3)
desc:
Focus on human development across the lifespan with attention given to unique 
challenges and opportunities faced in each phase. Emphasis on “populations at risk” and the strengths and assets unique to diverse populations. SW majors only. 
Pre: 360 with a grade of C or better. Recommended: 200. DS
metadata: DS Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Human Behavior and the Social Environment (3)
desc: Examination of complex sociocultural factors that privilege some and oppress/marginalize others. Challenges commonly held tropes and complicates the discourse regarding individual, family, group, organizational and community development within the social environment. SW majors only. Recommended: 200. DS
metadata: DS Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: Social Welfare as a Social Institution (3)
desc: Study of U.S. social welfare institutional structures, programs, and policies addressing human need; focus on Hawai‘i’s legislative processes and social service programs; emphasis on oral communication inherent to advocacy, legislative, and policymaking processes. SW majors only. Pre: 325.
metadata: DS Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: History of Social Welfare (3)
desc: Historical developments and implications of social welfare activities, institutions, and policies and European backgrounds; introduce social welfare developments in selected non-European countries. SW majors only. Recommended: 200.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: General Social Work Practice II (3)
desc: Introduction to practice skills with individuals, families, groups, and communities. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction congruent with professional expectations. Pre: 302 (complete with C or better) and majors only. Co-requisite: 391.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: General Social Work Practice I (3)
desc: Orientation to practice principles, concepts, values, knowledge base, and their application. Pre: 200 (complete with C or better) and majors only.
metadata: Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SW
title: The Field of Social Work (3)
desc: Orientation to the profession of social work; historical development, values and philosophy, scope and aims.
metadata: DS Social Work (SW) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: SOCS
title: Ocean Policy and Management (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary approach to problems relating to humans and their interactions with the world’s oceans and coasts. Focus includes institutions for governing the world’s oceans and coasts at all scales and on the role of scientific knowledge in managing marine and coastal resources. Repeatable one time. Pre: OCN 331, GEO 435, or consent. (Cross-listed as. (Cross-listed as OEST 735)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Social Sciences (SOCS)

subject: SOCS
title: Topics in Teaching Innovations (3)
desc: Examination and critical analysis of contemporary curriculum and instruction issues in social sciences. Concepts, theories, principles underlying active learning, critical thinking, values inquiry, assessment, and multidisciplinary approaches to integration of knowledge.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Social Sciences (SOCS)

subject: SOCS
title: Social Sciences Internship (V)
desc: Internship in public, private, or non-profit organizations providing opportunity for practical experience and application of social sciences concepts and theories. Three to six credits per semester; repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. Consent of instructor. (Cross-listed as SOC 494 and WGSS 489)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Social Sciences (SOCS)

subject: SOCS
title: Social Sciences Service Learning and Micro Internship (V
desc: For students undertaking service-learning or micro-internship options separately or for another class. Discussions and research related to learning experiences and issues encountered while in the field. Repeatable up to three credits.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Social Sciences (SOCS)

subject: SOCS
title: Scientific Principles of Sustainability (3)
desc: Introduction to the scientific principles of sustainability, including the ecology of managed and natural ecosystems, global change biology, ecological principles of natural resource management, renewable energy technologies, and the environmental impacts of humans.
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Social Sciences (SOCS)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to Sustainability from Social Science Perspectives (3)
desc: Introduction to key concepts and theories in social sciences in relation to sustainability issues. (Cross-listed as SUST 250 and TAHR 250)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOCS
title: Statistical Analysis for Social Sciences (3)
