desc: Statistical reasoning in the analysis of social science data, including descriptive statistics, exploratory data analysis, inference measures of association, decomposition of variance, and regression analysis. Lab required. Pre: any 100 level social science course or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Social Sciences (SOCS)

subject: SOCS
title: Street Science: Evaluating and Applying Evidence in Daily Life (3)
desc: Develops necessary tools for effective reasoning and problem-solving through use and application of analytic techniques, including question formation, understanding/interpreting data presented in the public sphere, and evaluating the validity of sources. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Social Sciences (SOCS)

subject: SOCS
title: Leadership and Social Issues (3)
desc: Fosters understanding of key societal and community issues, social science perspectives on them, the qualities of effective leadership, and invites examination of personal responsibilities, intentions, and abilities to make a difference on those issues. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Social Sciences (SOCS)

subject: SOCS
title: First Year Experience (1)
desc: Brings together topics, discussion, and peer support to increase success at UH Mānoa and the College of Social Sciences. The emphasis is on knowledge, skills, and behaviors leading to graduation and sharing the first-year experience.
metadata: College of Social Sciences

subject: SLS
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: One credit is necessary for dissertation writing. Repeatable unlimited times. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Apprenticeship in Teaching (V)
desc: An experienced-based introduction to college-level teaching; graduate students serve as student teachers to professors; responsibilities include supervised teaching, and participation in planning and evaluation. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: graduate standing and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Seminar in Second Language Research (3)
desc: Research methodologies in second language and multilingual contexts. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Seminar in Second Language Use (3)
desc: Second language/dialect use in multilingual communities. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Seminar in Second Language Acquisition (3)
desc: Issues in theory and research in second language acquisition of child and adult. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Seminar in Second Language Education (3)
desc: Current issues and problems. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Individual research in the various fields of second language studies. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent of instructor.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Individual reading in various fields of second language studies. CR/ NC only. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent of instructor.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies (V)
desc: Enrollment for degree completion. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned up to six credits. CR/NC only. Pre: master’s Plan B or C candidate and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Teaching Practicum (3)
desc: Student teaching in a language learning classroom. Repeatable one time in a different instructional context. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: (Alpha) Topics in Second Language Studies (3)
desc: Variable topics in special areas of second language studies: (E) second language learning; (N) second language analysis; (P) second language pedagogy; (R) second language research methodology; (U) second language use. Repeatable one time for different alphas. Pre: 650 for (E); consent for (N) and (P); 660 or consent for (U).
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Discourse Analysis in Second Language Research (3)
desc: Survey of approaches to discourse; microanalytic qualitative research; theory and methodology. Pre: 660 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Qualitative Research (3)
desc: Philosophical and theoretical approaches, methodology, and ethics in second language qualitative research.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Survey Research Methods in Second Language Studies (3)
desc: Hands-on experience in language survey research including planning and creating survey instruments (both interviews and questionnaires), administering, compiling and analyzing survey data (quantitatively and qualitatively), and reporting the results. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Applied Psycholinguistics and Second Language Acquisition (3)
desc: Theory and research in psycholinguistics as related to second language perception, production, acquisition, and instruction. Pre: 601 or LING 422, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Classroom Research (3)
desc: Survey of research on second language classrooms and analysis of methodological issues.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Research in Language Testing (3)
desc: Advanced issues in language testing research including recent developments in the following areas: language testing hypotheses, item analysis, reliability, dependability, and validity. Pre: 611, 670, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Quantitative Research (3)
desc: Quantitative research methods; design of research studies; techniques in collecting data; statistical inference; and analysis and interpretation of data.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Sociolinguistics and Second Languages (3)
desc: Theoretical and applied aspects of language, culture, and society, and research methods in sociolinguistics, as they relate to second and foreign language issues. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Acquisition (3)
desc: Survey of theories and research on second language learning by children and adults, learning naturalistically and in formal settings. Relationships are explored between SLA research and language teaching. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Comparative Grammar and Second Languages (3)
desc: Comparative study of two or more languages. Consideration of language transfer in second language learning, role of typological features. Pre: consent
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: English Grammar (3)
desc: Descriptive English grammar in relation to second language learning and teaching.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Program Development (3)
desc: Designing, implementing, and evaluating language programs; systems-based approach to program and curriculum development. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Reading (3)
desc: Survey of research in reading process; teaching methodology; psycholinguistic investigations; comparison of reading in first and second languages. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Language and Learning Technologies (3)
desc: A wide range of emerging technologies for language learning and research will be explored. Online/faceto-face discussions and hands-on experiential learning are integrated with learner’s goals, best practices, and theoretical foundations. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Writing (3)
desc: Problems in teaching second language composition. Survey materials; use, modification, and development. Error analysis. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Listening and Speaking (3)
desc: Key issues; overview and critique of published materials; practice in developing syllabi and other materials. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Alternative Approaches to Second Language Teaching (3)
desc: Examination, comparison with conventional approaches; interpersonal relationships in language teaching. Pre: consent
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Introduction to Teaching Second Languages (3)
desc: Survey and analysis of second language teaching traditions and perspectives. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Introduction to Second Language Studies (3)
desc: Introduction to basic professional and research issues in second language studies; integration of theory, research, and practice for prospective second or foreign language teachers and researchers. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: For interdisciplinary studies majors. Pre: a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in major, or consent of department chair. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Testing (3)
desc:
Measurement and evaluation of achievement and proficiency in second 
language learning. Pre: 302 or 303 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Professionalism in SLS (3)
desc: Capstone for SLS majors. Reflection on experiences via the major, articulation of professional values, exploration of diverse approaches to professionalism in SLS, and formal compilation of a professional portfolio. SLS majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 302 and 303.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: (Alpha) Topics in Second Language Studies (3)
desc: Variable topics in special areas of second language studies: (E) second language learning; (N) second language analysis; (P) second language pedagogy; (R) second language research; (U) second language use. Repeatable three times in different topics. Pre: 302 (or concurrent) for (E), (N), (R), (U); 303 (or concurrent) for (P). Not applicable toward graduate degrees offered within SLS.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Practicum for Future Language Professionals (3)
desc: Students observe and assist mentor teachers (minimum of 40 hours) at cooperating schools in multilingual contexts, examining the intersection of theory and practice in language learning and teaching and applying knowledge from other SLS courses. A-F only. Pre: 302 and 303.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: English Phonology (3)
desc: Introduction to English phonetics and phonology. Includes an emphasis on the oral presentation of key phonological concepts and provides experience in English pronunciation tutoring. Pre: 302 (or concurrent) or 600 (or concurrent).
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Language Concepts for Second Language Learning and Teaching (3)
desc: Language analysis— phonology, syntax, semantics, discourse for teaching second languages.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Pidgin and Creole English in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Major historical descriptive, pedagogical aspects; pidgin and creole languages, linguistic change, language variation. Work with actual language data. Laboratory work required.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Instructional Media (3)
desc: Theoretical foundation and practical applications of using electronic and audiovisual media in second language teaching. Pre: 303 (with minimum grade of C), or 600 (with minimum grade of B or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Multilingual Education (3)
desc: Survey and analysis of current thinking and practices in multilingual and multicultural education, including bilingual education; special emphasis on ESL/EFL. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Techniques in Second Language Teaching: Listening and Speaking (3)
desc: Methods and materials. Issues in teaching; survey of available materials and practice in their adaptation. Includes an emphasis on instruction and feedback in oral communication. Pre: 302 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Techniques in Second Language Teaching: Reading and Writing (3)
desc: Methods and materials. Issues in teaching; survey of available materials and practice in their adaptation. Includes an emphasis on instruction and feedback in oral communication. Pre: 302 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Teaching (3)
desc: Survey of methodology; basic concepts and practices; emphasis on teaching second languages through oral instruction. Pre: 302 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Second Language Learning (3)
desc: Theoretical foundations for the learning and teaching of second/ foreign languages. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. Pre: upper division standing.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Bilingualism: Cognition and Culture (3)
desc: Introduction to bi-/multilingualism as a phenomenon at the level of society and as a characteristic of individual speakers; discussion of recent media reports and popular myths about bilingualism in relation to research-based evidence.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Topics in Learning and Using Second Languages (3)
desc: Reviews practices of second language learning, use, and maintenance. Introductory exploration and analysis of selected topics with a specific theme indicated by course title listed in the class schedule. Repeatable one time for different topics, up to six credits with consent.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Introduction to Second Language Learning and Technology (3)
desc: Introduction to the use of technology in second language learning; pros and cons of specific new applications and established technologies; project-based and oriented; developing multilingual/ multicultural understanding through technology. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Learning Languages and Communicating Interculturally in a Global Multilingual World (3)
desc: Historical/global perspective on being/becoming multilingual/multicultural, encompassing cases of second language learning, teaching, use, growth, change, loss across the world, ancient times to present, supporting individuals’ motivations and abilities concerning second languages and cultures.
metadata: FGC College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SLS
title: Introduction to Pidgin in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Introduction to contemporary Pidgin in Hawai‘i, in relation to the role of Hawaiian and Languages of the Asia-Pacific region; language rights; sociolinguistics of Pidgin and Hawaiian in institutional, educational, and interpersonal contexts. DS
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Second Language Studies (SLS)

subject: SNSK
title: Advanced Readings in Sanskrit (3)
desc: Advanced study of Sanskrit literature (kâvya) and systematic thought (sâstra), alongside reading and discussion of scholarship on these topics. Specific content will change each semester. Repeatable unlimited times for different topics. Pre: intermediate-level SNSK (or equivalent). Contact instructor with questions.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Sanskrit (SNSK)

subject: SNSK
title: Fourth-Level Sanskrit (3)
desc: Continuation of 481.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Sanskrit (SNSK)

subject: SNSK
title: Fourth-Level Sanskrit (3)
desc: Continuation of 382. Reading, analysis, and interpretation of various Vedic or Sanskrit texts selected according to students’ interests. Pre: 382.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Sanskrit (SNSK)

subject: SNSK
title: Third-Level Sanskrit (3)
desc: Continuation of 381. Introduction to Veda.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Sanskrit (SNSK)

subject: SNSK
title: Third-Level Sanskrit (3)
desc: Continuation of 282. Reading and analysis of various classical texts. Pre: 282.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Sanskrit (SNSK)

subject: SNSK
title: Intermediate Sanskrit II (3)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Sanskrit (SNSK)

subject: SNSK
title: Intermediate Sanskrit I (3)
desc: Continuation of 102. Reading and analysis of classical texts with review of grammar. Pre: 102.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Sanskrit (SNSK)

subject: SNSK
title: Introduction to Sanskrit I (3)
desc: Introduction to basic Sanskrit grammar; reading and analysis of progressively difficult classical texts.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Sanskrit (SNSK)

subject: SAM
title: Traditional Samoan Literature (3)
desc: A survey of the major genres of traditional Samoan literature. Taught in the Samoan language. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Structure of Samoan (3)
desc: Study of modern Samoan grammar including some sociolinguistic background. Pre: 202 or LING 102, or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Samoan Oral Traditions II (3)
desc: Continuation of 431. Pre: 431 or consent.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Samoan Oral Traditions (3)
desc: Historical survey and analysis of the oral traditions and genealogies of Samoa with special emphasis on the relationship of these traditions with Samoan ceremonial speech. Pre: 302.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Samoan Ceremonial Speech (3)
desc: Continuation of 421. Pre: 421 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Samoan Ceremonial Speech (3)
desc: Development of oratory skills in Samoan ceremonial speech. Emphasis on institutionalized applications such as the kava ceremony and formal speechmaking. Pre: 302 or 322, or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Samoan Conversation: Contemporary Contexts (3)
desc: Systematic practice on various topics for control of spoken Samoan in modern contexts. Pre: 202 or equivalent; or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Samoan Conversation: Traditional Contexts (3)
desc: Systematic practice on various topics for control of spoken Samoan in traditional contexts. Pre: 202 or equivalent; or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Third-Level Samoan: Contemporary Culture (3)
desc: Continuation of 202. Advanced reading and composition with development of language structure integrated in a variety of communicative and creative activities based on selected contemporary cultural topics. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Third-Level Samoan: Traditional Culture (3)
desc: Continuation of 202. Advanced reading and composition with development of language structure integrated in a variety of communicative and creative activities based on selected traditional cultural topics. Meets three times weekly; additional lab work. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Overview of Samoan Literature in English (3)
desc: Survey of major writers of Samoan literature in English; lectures, discussions, short paper.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Intermediate Samoan (4)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201 or consent.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Intermediate Samoan (4)
desc: Continuation of 102. Meets four hours weekly. Intermediate-level reading, writing, and conversation practice. Pre: 102.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Elementary Samoan (4)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101 or consent.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: SAM
title: Elementary Samoan (4)
desc: Listening, speaking, reading, writing skills. Structural points introduced inductively. History and culture. Meets four hours weekly.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Samoan (SAM)

subject: RUS
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Independent study of approved reading with faculty supervision. Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. Pre: 303 (or equivalent), consent or departmental approval.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Seminar (3)
desc: Literary or linguistic topics, movements, genres, or their representatives. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. Pre: consent of chair.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Intensive Fourth-Level Russian Abroad (V)
desc: Intensive advanced courses of formal instruction on the fourth-year level in Russian language and culture in Russia. Pre: 360 or equivalent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Topics in 19th- and 20th-Century Russian Literature (3)
desc: Continuation of 451. Pre: 312, LLEA 352, or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Topics in 19th- and 20th-Century Russian Literature (3)
desc: Focus upon the selected writings of one major Russian writer of the 19th century (e.g., Pushkin, Gogol, Lermontov, Dostoevsky, or Tolstoy) or 20th century (e.g., Bely, Blok, Bulgakov, Chekhov, Pasternak, Sholokhov, or Solzhenitsyn). Repeatable unlimited times with consent. Pre: 312, LLEA 351; or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Russian Novel (3)
desc: Origin and development from 18th century to present. Pre: three years of Russian language or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Russian Short Story (3)
desc: Origin and development (19th and 20th century); the major writers. Pre: three years of Russian or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Russian Folklore (3)
desc: Selected Russian folk narratives, bylinas, songs, and proverbs. Influence of folklore on major Russian authors. Pre: 312 or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Advanced Reading of Russian Press (3)
desc: Materials from Soviet/Russian newspapers and magazines. Pre: 311 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Advanced Reading and Translation: Modern Prose (3)
desc: Readings in various fields, emphasizing idiomatic usage. Pre: 312 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Advanced Conversation and Composition (3)
desc: Continuation of 403. Pre: 403.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Advanced Conversation and Composition (3)
desc: Systematic practice on selected topics; vocabulary building and development of fluency; writing short reports, narratives. Pre: 304 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Independent study of approved reading with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times or up to six credits. A-F only. Pre: 202 and consent and departmental approval.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Intensive Third-Level Russian Abroad (V)
desc: Intensive course of formal instruction on the third-year level in Russian language and culture in Russia. Pre: 202 or 260.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Readings in Russian Civilization and Literature (3)
desc: Continuation of 311. Pre: 311.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Readings in Russian Civilization and Literature (3)
desc: Mid-level readings in Russian civilization and literature of edited and adapted texts. Pre: 202.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Russian Structure (3)
desc: Advanced grammar; complexities of standard contemporary Russian; word formation and verb system. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Advanced Russian (3)
desc: Continuation of 303.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Advanced Russian (3)
desc: Systematic practice for control of spoken and written Russian, vocabulary building, fluency in various subjects, accuracy in sentence structure, phrasing stylistic appropriateness. Pre: 202.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Intensive Intermediate Russian Abroad (V)
desc: Intensive course of formal instruction on the second-year level in Russian language and culture in Russia. Pre: 102.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Russian Phonetics (3)
desc: Basic theory of Russian sound system; practice in pronunciation, intonation, and fluency. Pre: 102 or 201 (or concurrent).
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Intermediate Russian (3)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201 or consent.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Intermediate Russian (3)
desc: Reading, conversation, grammar, composition. Pre: 102 or consent.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Elementary Russian (3)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101 or consent.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: RUS
title: Elementary Russian (3)
desc: Conversation, reading, writing, grammar.
metadata: HSL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Russian (RUS)

subject: REPR
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: admission to candidacy (PhD program).
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Reproductive Biology (REPR)

subject: REPR
title: Special Topics in Reproductive Biology (V)
desc: In-depth discussion of selected areas of reproductive biology, with special emphasis on recent research results and methodologies. May be retaken for credit. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Reproductive Biology (REPR)

subject: REPR
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: admission to candidacy (master’s program).
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Reproductive Biology (REPR)

subject: REPR
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Reproductive Biology (REPR)

subject: REPR
title: Seminar in Biomedical Sciences (1)
desc: Presentation and discussion of current research topics in biomedical sciences. Repeatable nine times. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as CMB 611)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Reproductive Biology (REPR)

subject: REPR
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Reproductive Biology (REPR)

subject: REL
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent of thesis chair.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Topics in Religious Studies (3)
desc: Topics in the study of religion with special emphasis on theoretical approaches and concerns. Specific topics to be preannounced. Repeatable one time. Pre: 600 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Plan B Research (3)
desc: Research for master’s degree Plan B. Restricted to students in the Religion Masters Program in Plan B. Enrollment must be approved by student’s project committee. A-F only. Pre: consent of committee.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: (Alpha) Pedagogy in Religion (3)
desc: Theory, preparation, and practice in the teaching of religious studies at the community college level: (B) teaching religion; (C) teaching religion practicum. REL majors only. A-F only.Pre: 650 for (B); 600, 650 and (B) for (C).
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Polynesian Religions (3)
desc: Selected historical, thematic, and textual research topics in Polynesian and Hawaiian religious traditions: (B) Polynesian religions; (C) Hawaiian religion. Each alpha repeatable up to nine credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: (Alpha) Seminar on South Asian Religions (3)
desc: Selected historical, thematic, and textual research topics in Indian religious traditions: (B) Indian religions; (D) Indian Buddhism. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits for (B). A-F only
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: (Alpha) Seminar on East Asian Religions (3)
desc: Selected historical, thematic, and textual research topics in East Asian religions and traditions: (B) Chinese religions; (C) Japanese religions; (D) East Asian Buddhism. Repeatable up to six credits for (D), up to nine credits for (B) and (C). A-F only. Pre: 661B or 661C for (D).
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: History and Theory of the Study of Religion (3)
desc: Survey of development of history of religions; application of methodologies from anthropology, history, philosophy, political science, psychology, and sociology.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Directed Reading or Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. Pre: consent of instructor and department chair.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Seminar in Religion (3)
desc: Topics pre-announced each semester. Pre: upper division standing or consent. Repeatable one time.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Polynesian Religions (3)
desc: Introduction to field, comparison of several traditions; beliefs and practices from analysis of texts. Historical interactions with Christianity. Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Buddhism in Japan (3)
desc: Major features and trends in thought, institutions, and practices in the context of Japanese history and culture, 6th–20th century. Pre: 204 or 207, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Field Methods in Religion (3)
desc: Introduction to theoretical and methodological approaches to doing fieldwork in the study of religion. Application of these in studying Hawai‘i’s diverse religious environment. Pre: 300 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: New World Rituals and Ideologies (3)
desc: Study of cross-cultural patterns in ritual behaviors and creolization of African, indigenous, and Iberian ideological frameworks in the Americas. Topics may include syncretic religions (voodoo, candomble), Andean Christianity, spiritual conquest, conceptions of death, etc. Sophomore standing or higher. Minimum C- required grade for prerequisites. Pre: LAIS 360, or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as ANTH 478 and LAIS 478)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Daoism: Philosophy and Religion (3)
desc: Seminar on religious Taoism, its historical development and its role in the present-day context. Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Seminar on Buddhism (3)
desc: Selected historical, thematic, and textual research topics in Buddhism; topics and geographical focus to be announced each semester.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Sociology of Religion (3)
desc: Seminar on research in sociological aspects of religious sectarianism, historical and current; special reference to Hawai‘i. Pre: SOC 300 or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 455)
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Sacred Places (3)
desc: Lectures and seminars provide a cross-cultural survey of sites which societies recognize as sacred and their cultural, ecological and conservation aspects. Junior standing or higher. Pre: consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as ANTH 445)
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Spiritual Ecology (3)
desc: Lectures and seminars provide a cross-cultural survey of the relationships between religions, environment and environmentalism. Junior standing or higher. Pre: consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as ANTH 444)
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Anthropology of Buddhism (3)
desc: Selected aspects of national, regional and local manifestations of Buddhism are explored through the perspective of anthropology with an emphasis on the daily lives of monks, nuns and lay persons in their socio-cultural contexts. Pre: 207, 422, 475, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as ANTH 443)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Health/Medicine in Religion (3)
desc: Issues of health and disease in the light of religious beliefs and practices with a focus on ethical matters shaping policies in the U.S. and the world. A-F only.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Anthropology of Magic, Witchcraft, and Religion (3)
desc: Cults, legends, millennial movements, myths, possession, rituals, sacred healing, shamanism, sorcery, spirits, symbolism, witchcraft, and other forms of religious and symbolic expression and experience, from small scale to highly urban societies. Pre: ANTH 152. (Cross-listed as ANTH 422)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Life and Teachings of Jesus (3)
desc: Critical study of synoptic gospels and of extra-Biblical sources. Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Directed Reading (3)
desc: Pre: one 200-level REL course and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: On Death and Dying (3)
desc: Aspects of death and dying; relation to our culture and society, to understanding of each other and of ourselves. (Crosslisted as COA 394)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Hawaiian Gods (3)
desc: The traditions and practices related to one or more major indigenous gods, or class of gods, will be studied by the interpretation and analysis of primary texts. Develops written communication skills. Repeatable one time. Pre: 205 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Mysticism East and West (3)
desc:
Mystic traditions of the West from desert monasticism to 
Renaissance mystics compared with those of South and East Asia. Focuses on the ethical lives of these mystics, and developing oral communication skills. Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Classical Hindu Mythology (3)
desc: Study of major myths of Epic Sanskrit literature, primarily with focus of the Ramayana and Mahabharata. Literary sources will be tapped for appreciating myths and epics, especially with reference to dharma, karma, ways of life. Sophomore standing or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as IP 374)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Vedic Hindu Mythology (3)
desc: Study of major Hindu myths of the Vedic Sanskrit literature within the perspective of ancient Indian civilization. Literary sources will be tapped for understanding creation, cosmogony and celestial, atmospheric and terrestrial divinities. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as IP 373)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Prophecies of the Last Days (3)
desc: In-depth look at ancient Judeo-Christian apocalyptic texts and the communities in which they originated, followed by a survey of the medieval and modern day heirs of apocalyptic traditions. Pre: 150 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Religion and Art (3)
desc: The uses of art in religion are studied with historical examples. Pre: 150 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Love, Sex, and Religion (3)
desc: Love and sex as themes in religions of Asia and the West. Pre: 150 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Women and Religion (3)
desc: Examining roles of, and attitudes toward, women in major religious traditions through autobiographies, films, and primary texts. Pre: 149 or WGSS 149 or REL 150 or HIST 151 or WGSS 151. (Cross-listed as WGSS 356)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Islam in History (3)
desc: Examination of the historical connections between Islam and other civilizations will focus on the role of Islam in world history. Pre: 150 or 209 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Witches and Witchcraft (3)
desc: Persecution of witches, witchcraft in Europe, 1300–1700, examined as crisis of church and theology; origins, effects on church and society. Pre: one of 201, HIST 151, HIST 152, PSY 100, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Sufism: Mystical Traditions of Islam (3)
desc: Introduction to the history, literature, and worldview of Sufism. Students will encounter the following topics in relation to Islamic mysticism: asceticism, monotheism, philosophy, love, union, sainthood, ecstatic experience, and spiritual uses of art. Pre: 209 or 383 or PHIL 330 or HIST 354, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Christian Ethics in Modern Life (3)
desc: The meaning of Christian faith for the moral life with reference to contemporary moral issues. Pre: 150 or 151, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Religion, Politics, and Society (3)
desc: Exploration of the diverse approaches and perspectives that American religious groups embrace in addressing controversial and diverse issues of contemporary American life. Emphasis on considering and discussing ethical approaches and practicing oral communication. DH
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Religion and Conflict in American History (3)
desc: Analyzes selected historical examples of religious conflicts in America, discerning characteristic patterns of American religious discourse, and identifying the social structures, interests, and ethical principles at stake in conflicts about religion. Sophomore standing or higher. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as AMST 345)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Cults and New Religions (3)
desc: Study of cults and new religious movements in America, the Pacific, and East Asia; examining types, causes, and functions of these movements. Pre: 150 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Global Christianity (3)
desc: Christianity as a transcultural religion, through the study of Christian art, literature, ritual, and theology in diverse cultures; including the Near East, Africa, Latin America, and the Pacific. Pre: 150, 201, or 210; or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Zen (Ch’an) Buddhist Masters (3)
desc: Study of lives, teachings, practices of Zen masters in China, Japan, Korea, and the West. Pre: one of 150, 203, 204, 207; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Creation and Evolution (3)
desc: An exploration of interactions between science and religion with a focus on cosmogonies. Pre: 150 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Biblical Hebrew II (3)
desc: Reading of selected prose passages from the Hebrew Bible; essay-based analysis of literary forms, with attention given both to stories important to the development of the Abrahamic religions and writing-based interpretation of religious traditions. Pre: REL/CLAS 301 with C- or better. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as CLAS 302)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Biblical Hebrew I (3)
desc: Orthography and structure of Biblical Hebrew, history and development of Hebrew as the sacred language of Judaism, overview of religious and historical development of the Hebrew Bible. Pre: sophomore standing or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as CLAS 301)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Myth, Religion, and Society (3)
desc:
Theories and methods used in the study of myth, ritual, and 
religion. Sophomore standing or higher. (Cross-listed as CLAS 300) DH
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding Christianity (3)
desc: History of ideas concentrating on events, persons, and issues with the greatest impact on the evolution of Christianity.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding Islam (3)
desc: Historical survey of the beliefs and practices of Islam as a world religion, including the prophet Muhammad, scriptures, philosophy and science, theology, law, major sectarian movements, relations with other religious traditions, and fundamentalism. (Alt. years)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding Judaism (3)
desc: Survey from origin to modern times with an emphasis on writing-based analysis of Jewish thought in Talmudic and Medieval Periods.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding Buddhism (3)
desc: Survey of major forms and practices.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding Hawaiian Religion (3)
desc: Major teachings and practices from ancient times to present, their cultural influence; analysis of religious texts; relation to other traditions of Oceania and to Christianity.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding Japanese Religions (3)
desc: Broad survey, with primary focus on Shinto, Buddhist, and modern sectarian movements, analyzed in relation to social and cultural themes of major historical periods.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding Chinese Religions (3)
desc: Taoist, Confucian, Buddhist and folk beliefs and practices in their social and historical context. Repeatable one time.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding Indian Religions (3)
desc: Historical survey of the teachings and practices of major religious traditions of India.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding the New Testament (3)
desc: Origin and development of early Christian message as set forth in the New Testament; special attention to Jesus and Paul.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Understanding the Old Testament (Hebrew Bible) (3)
desc: Examines the Old Testament (Hebrew Bible) as an expression of the religious life, history, and thought of ancient Israel and as a sacred text within later Judaism and Christianity.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Religion and the Meaning of Existence (3)
desc: Basic ideas and issues in contemporary religious thought about the meaning of existence.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Introduction to the World’s Major Religions (3)
desc: Buddhism, Christianity, Confucianism, Hinduism, Islam, Judaism, Shinto, Taoism and indigenous traditions of Hawai‘i and/or Oceania.
metadata: FGC College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: REL
title: Introduction to the World’s Goddesses (3)
desc: Cross-cultural analysis of the religious narratives, beliefs, practices, iconography, and sacred sites related to female deities in the Americas, Polynesia, Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Europe from prehistory to 1500 C.E. (Crosslisted as WGSS 149)
metadata: FGA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religion (REL)

subject: RE
title: Real Estate Investment Analysis (3)
desc: Development of strategic business plans for the optimization of a firm’s real property assets. Includes facilities utilization audits, contingency planning, and the impact of new techniques.
metadata: Real Estate (RE) Shidler College of Business

subject: RE
title: Real Estate Finance and Investment (3)
desc: Financial and investment techniques used to evaluate real property and real estate security investments.
metadata: Real Estate (RE) Shidler College of Business

subject: RE
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in a special area within the major field under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and faculty advisor. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Real Estate (RE) Shidler College of Business

subject: RE
title: Current Topics in Real Estate Analysis (3)
desc: Consideration of various special concepts and problems in real estate. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Real Estate (RE) Shidler College of Business

subject: RE
title: Administration of Real Property Assets (3)
desc: How business firms and investors manage their real property assets in terms of the legal, financial, and physical dimensions of real property. Case studies in hotels, condominiums, and office buildings in the environment in Hawai‘i. Business majors only.
metadata: Real Estate (RE) Shidler College of Business

subject: RE
title: Real Estate Appraisal/Analysis (3)
desc: Analysis of real property, including feasibility analysis, market analysis, income property capitalization, and general real estate valuation techniques.
metadata: Real Estate (RE) Shidler College of Business

subject: RE
title: Real Estate and Environmental Law (3)
desc: Property rights, land tenure, agency, contracts and negotiation theory, title conveyancing and escrow, mortgage instruments, fair housing, state and federal environmental policy.
metadata: Real Estate (RE) Shidler College of Business

subject: RE
title: Principles of Real Estate (3)
desc: Principles affecting the allocation and utilization of real estate resources, including legal, physical, economic elements; valuation; market analysis; finance; investments, and public and private externalities affecting the allocation and utilization of real estate resources.
metadata: Real Estate (RE) Shidler College of Business

subject: QHS
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Directed research in quantitative health sciences. Students will work closely with a QHS faculty member or mentor who will guide them through the process of conducting a research study. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only.
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Biostatistical Consulting Practicum (V)
desc:
Under the supervision of biostatistics faculty members, students will have the opportunity to provide statistical 
consultations to biomedical researchers and gain hands-on experience conducting biostatistical analysis in solving real-life analytic problems. Repeatable two times, up to six credits. A-F only. Pre: 675 (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of B.
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Biostatistical Consulting (2)
desc:
Investigate the roles and responsibilities of the biostatistician as both consultant and collaborator with biomedical researchers, guide students in enhancing problem-solving and 
communication skills, and provide opportunity to observe real-life biostatistical consultations. A-F only. Pre: 601 and 602 (or equivalent) with minimum grades of B, and consent.
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Special Topics in Quantitative Health Sciences (V)
desc: Special topics in quantitative health sciences. Reflects special research interest of QHS faculty or guest lecturers. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only.
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Secondary Data Analysis Practicum (2)
desc: Introduces students to issues in working with complex data sets and adds the hands-on experience needed to conduct individual research using secondary databases. A-F only. Pre: (601 (or equivalent) and 650) with a minimum grade of B, which can be taken concurrently.
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials (2)
desc:
Covers basic and advanced statistical methods utilized in clinical trials design, conduct, and data analysis. Topics cover statistician’s role in drug development and DSMB, 
statistical theory in phases I-IV clinical trial designs and analysis. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or equivalent) with a minimum grade of B or consent.
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Introduction to Clinical Trials (2)
desc: Introduction to clinical trials. Topics include history, definitions/terminology, adverse events, FDA and government regulatory agencies, ethics; monitoring committees, recruitment, introduction to protocol development, basis designs. A-F only.
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Bioinformatics II (3)
desc: Focus on bioinformatics approaches for functional genomics related to DNA, RNA, and protein. It will provide of virus, bacteria, and human genome and bioinformatics approaches to human disease. A-F only. Pre: 610 (or equivalent) (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Bioinformatics I (3)
desc:
Provides fundamental concepts in bioinformatics with strong emphasis on hands-on training. Topics such as molecular biology, sequence alignment, biological databases, phytogeny, 
and genomics including microarray and RNA-sequence analysis. Repeatable one time, but credit earned one time only. Open to nonmajors. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed with TRMD 653)
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Generalized Linear Model (3)
desc: Statistical theory of Linear Model and Generalized Linear Model, algorithms use for estimation, inference concepts, and assessment of goodness-of-fit. Covers Proportional Hazard Model and Generalized Estimating Equations. A-F only. Pre: 601 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: QHS
title: Fundamentals of Biostatistics (3)
desc: Fundamental biomedical statistics concepts and tools will be introduced, as well as their applications to biomedical data. Students will perform hands-on analysis using statistical software and learn to interpret and present the results. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as TRMD 655)
metadata: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine Quantitative Health Sciences (QHS)

subject: PPC
title: Applied Principles of Environmental & Energy Policy (3)
desc: Introduction to the methods and techniques of environmental and energy policy in relation to energy systems. Analysis of enacted policies from case studies to understanding the effectiveness, challenges, contradictions, and limitations of each. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: any 100 or 200 level OCN course, or consent. (Cross-listed as OCN 321 and SUST 323)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Public Policy Center (PPC)

subject: PUBA
title: Survey of Public Policy and Analysis (3)
desc: Students will learn about the policy making process, the results of policy decisions and how public policy is assessed, analyzed, and responded to. Also discusses important policy issues that currently fill the political landscape. Junior standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PH
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Pre: consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: (Alpha) Exploration in Public Health (V)
desc: Investigation of emergent fields of inquiry in public health. (B) biostatistics; (D) environmental health; (E) epidemiology; (H) health policy and management; (I) Native Hawaiian and Inigenous health; (S) social and behavioral health sciences; (U) public health. Repeatable unlimited times. PH majors only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Special Practicum/Project (V)
desc: Supervised practical training beyond the required practicum in an area of particular interest. Provides additional opportunity to synthesize, integrate, and apply practical skills and knowledge in a public health work environment. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: completion of practicum and consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: (Alpha) Current Issues and Topics in Public Health (V)
desc: Current and emerging issues and topics related to public health. (B) biostatistics; (D) environmental health; (E) epidemiology; (H) health policy and management; (I) Native Hawaiian and Indigenous Health; (S) social and behavioral health sciences; (U) public health. Repeatable unlimited times. PH majors only for (D) and (I).
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Advanced Public Health Practice (3)
desc: Observation, study, and supervised practical work in student’s area of specialization. A-F only. Pre: public health degree candidate and completion of 15 PH credit hours and consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Integrative Seminar (2)
desc: Integrative seminar in public health required as part of the student capstone experience to bring together key aspects of their courses, competencies, and practicum. A-F only. Pre: completed PH field practicum and consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Seminar in Public Health Sciences (V)
desc: Topics related to recent developments in major areas; student and faculty research activities. Sections: (1) biostatistics; (2) environmental health; (3) epidemiology; (4) public health nutrition. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Environmental Health Lab Methods (2)
desc: Hands-on training for laboratory methods used in monitoring and detecting environmental health risk factors; learning and application of immunological-, animal cell culture- and molecular biology-based techniques for studying environmental pathogens and toxic pollutants. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Public Health Proposal and Dissertation Writing (2)
desc: Intended for doctoral students to complete and defend their proposals and dissertations. Research and presentation methods will be reviewed, and students will be provided critiques by instructor and classmates on their written and presented work. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: consent or PhD in PH or EPID only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Research Practicum (V)
desc: Hands-on research experience with a faculty mentor. Meet in small groups to discuss issues related to research in public health. Final project will be submission of a publishable quality paper. Graduate standing in PH only. A-F only. Pre: 602 and 623 and 655 and 663 and 681 and 770(Alpha), or departmental approval.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Teaching Practicum (V)
desc: Provide doctoral students with theoretical and practical teaching and course development experiences under the guidance of a faculty mentor. Students will have a portfolio documenting their accomplishments. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate standing in PH only. A-F only. Pre: 602 and 623 and 655 and 663 and 681 and 770(Alpha), or departmental approval.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: (Alpha) Doctoral Seminar in Translational Research (3)
desc: Required for students in the PhD PH program. (D) evidence-based public health; (E) health policy and leadership. A-F only. Pre: departmental approval.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Health Program Evaluation (3)
desc: Examines advanced principles of and frameworks for evaluation. Students integrate utilization-focused evaluation methods to improve service delivery and quality, outcomes and impact to improve community and population health. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Evolution, Epidemiology, and Public Health (2)
desc: Will explore several aspects of human health through the perspective of how natural selection and evolution influence disease risk, with the aim of improving treatment and prevention. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: 663 (with a minimum grade of B).
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Special Topics in Tropical Medicine (V)
desc: Advanced instruction in frontiers of tropical medicine and public health. Repeatable unlimited times. Repeatable unlimited times. (Cross-listed as TRMD 705)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Seminar in Tropical Medicine and Public Health (1)
desc: Weekly discussion and reports on current advances in tropical medicine and public health. Repeatable unlimited times. (Cross-listed as TRMD 690)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Neuroepidemiology (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion providing an overview of the epidemiology of neurological and neurodegenerative diseases and their risk factors, and methodological considerations for the study of these diseases. Pre: 663 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Survival Analysis (3)
desc: Construction and interpretation of various types of life tables, treatment of censored data, proportional hazards, relative risk regression models, and parametric survival analysis. Pre: 655 or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Applied Longitudinal Data Analysis (3)
desc: Covers modern methods for longitudinal data analysis. Topics include random effects and growth curve models, generalized linear models for longitudinal data including generalized estimating equations, and generalized linear mixed models. A-F only. Pre: 656 and 658, or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Social Epidemiology (3)
desc: Examine the epidemiologic study of the social distribution and social determinants of states of health, including the identification of social-environmental exposures and their relation to physical and mental health outcomes. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Health Behavior Change (3)
desc: Provide an understanding of the relationship between health behaviors and outcomes including psychological, physiological, and quality of life aspects. It will also focus on the major theories of behavior and behavior change. Emphasis will be placed on understanding concepts, principles, explanations, and how these are translated into practical interventions for adoption and maintaining behavior change. A-F only. Pre: 623 or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Epidemiology of Diabetes and Obesity (2)
desc: Provides an overview of the epidemiology and prevention of metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and associated complications. Discusses methodological issues associated with evaluating these in epidemiologic studies. A-F only. Pre: 663 or consent. (Cross-listed as FSHN 749)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Chronic Disease Epidemiology (3)
desc: Will cover selected topics in chronic diseases with critical analysis of the current epidemiologic literature. Methodologic issues, contemporary findings and recommendations for future research will be discussed. A-F only. Pre: 663 or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Statistical Methods in Epidemiological Research (3)
desc: Multiple variable statistical methods currently used in chronic disease epidemiology. Logistic regression, conditional logistic regression, proportional hazards regression modelling, generalized estimating equation-based methods, delta method approximations, exact tests. Pre: 656 and 658 and 664.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Qualitative Research for Public Health Sciences (3)
desc: Provides a basic understanding of qualitative research approaches, methodologies, and techniques and for public health research and practice (needs assessment, program development, and evaluation strategies). Graduate students only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Survey Methods for Indigenous People (V)
desc: Advanced application of health disparities research methodologies to address health and social injustices faced by Indigenous people. Grounded in survey design, implementation, and analyses through a public health and Indigenous lens. PH majors only or consent. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Indigenous Applied Research Methods (V)
desc: Qualitative research methods design, implementation, and analysis with special focus on methodological, ontological, and ethical issues unique to conducting research with Indigenous communities. PH majors only. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Community-Based Participatory Research (3)
desc: Explores ways academic and lay communities collaborate on research, key theoretical perspectives in the development of CBPR, and the challenges in implementing CBPR approaches. Format includes lectures, discussions, readings, writing assignments, and a fieldwork project. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Health Promotion Research (3)
desc: Focus on research methods commonly used in health promotion. Topics will include randomized trials, quasi-experimental design, sampling, measurement, and correlational studies. Labwork will focus on the use of SPSS to analyze data for applied research problems. A-F only. Pre: 623 and 655, or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Health Communication (3)
desc: Skills-oriented course introduces the basic structure of health communication strategies in different settings, selected elements of communication theory, the development of health communication material, and a practical training in motivational counseling skills. Pre: 623 or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Promoting Physical Activity (3)
desc: Overview of the theoretical and applied study of physical activity epidemiology. Physical activity content includes benefits, factors that influence, levels, valid instruments to assess, and programs to promote physical activity. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as KRS 695)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Fundamentals of Environmental Epidemiology (2)
desc: Examines the complex relationship between environmental contaminants and human health. Emphasis on environmental epidemiology study design, environmental exposure monitoring and risk assessment, disease and environmental exposure mapping, and spatial data analysis and modeling with GIS. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Global Health Challenges (3)
desc: Addresses critical, contemporary, and transnational issues best addressed by cooperative international action. Health issues are examined in the context of intersecting effects of limited resources, socioeconomics, politics, and environmental change. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Nutritional Epidemiology (3)
desc: Dietary, biochemical, anthropometric and clinical methods used for evaluating nutrition and diet in the etiology and epidemiology of disease. Pre: 663 and FSHN 685, or consent. (Cross-listed as FSHN 689)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Indigenous Peoples’ Food Systems, Environment and Health (3)
desc: Explores Indigenous Peoples’ food systems as local food resources Indigenous People acquire through specific cultural knowledge of traditional territories. Global forces transforming these food systems and their impact on population health and nutrition are explored. PH majors or consent. Graduate students only. (Cross-listed as FSHN 688)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Advanced Child and Adolescent Nutrition (3)
desc: Addresses nutrition, growth, and development in children and adolescents and nutrition-related issues, such as childhood obesity and chronic disease risk factors, with a focus on current research in the Pacific region. Pre: FSHN 370 or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as FSHN 686)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Supplemental and Nutritional Approaches in Disease Prevention and Treatment (3)
desc: Examines a variety of issues associated with nutritional and supplemental approaches to reduce disease incidence, morbidity, and mortality in relation to public health prevention strategies. PH majors only. (Cross-listed as FSHN 684)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Global Nutrition (2)
desc: Examination of global food and nutrition problems, programs, issues, policies, and strategies for improvement. A-F only. Pre: statistics and consent. (Alt. years: fall) (Cross-listed as FSHN 683)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Environmental Determinants of Health (3)
desc: Environmental factors in personal and community health; implications for public health practice. Consideration of major issues from local, U.S., and international perspectives.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Health Emergencies in Large Populations (3)
desc: Health Emergencies in Large Populations is run by the Center for Excellence in Disaster Management and Humanitarian Assistance and the Red Cross. It provides knowledge, practical skills, and networking for global health practitioners. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Managing Global Health Service Delivery (3)
desc: Provides knowledge, skills, attitudes and resources that health managers require to manage and maintain the quality of partnerships, facilities, programs, community services, people, drugs, and information in limited resources settings. PH majors only. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Hawai‘i Public Health Policies on Infectious Diseases (1)
desc: Examines quarantine/ isolation of patients infected with Hanson’s disease. Focus on PH policies before 1823 and after; analysis of other infections in Hawai‘i and the world to examine differences in policies and their effect on the public. Graduate students only. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Community Engaged Research and Practice (2)
desc: Explores collaborative and engaged approaches with communities in public health research and practice. With a focus on Indigenous Peoples’ health, we delve into Indigenous knowledge and empowerment in evaluation, needs assessment, intervention, and health promotion. PH majors or consent. Graduate students only. Pre: 655 and 673.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Advanced Native Hawaiian Health Determinants (3)
desc: Applications of evidence-based knowledge about the social determinants of health in the formation of research, policy, and program development for improving population health and reducing health disparities for Native Hawaiians. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Native Health Ethics, Law, and Policy (3)
desc: Review theories and laws concerning health care ethics, policy, and practice using Indigenous case studies. Topics include Indigenous health systems, advocacy, and the intersecting issues of self-determination, ethics, agenda setting, and the policy cycle. A-F only. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as LAW 594)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Leading and Managing Health Programs (3)
desc: Assess how to organize community partnerships to create and communicate a shared vision for a changing future; discuss solutions to organizational and community challenges; maximize motivation to reach public health goals. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Community and Public Health Practice (2)
desc: Community organization and development applicable to the delivery of health services. Understanding community dynamics, mobilizing community groups for effective health care practice and delivery. Pre: 647 or consent. (Cross-listed as SW 674)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Epidemiological Study Design Critique (2)
desc: Critique of study design using published public health literature. Emphasis on exchange of ideas, alternative approaches; stresses epidemiology as science of public health. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. Pre: 663 or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Infectious Disease Micro II (3)
desc: Will cover different families of animal viruses of importance to human diseases. The genome, structure, replication, as well as host immune responses, epidemiology, clinical features, and animal models will be presented. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: TRMD 604 and MICR 351, or consent. (Cross-listed as TRMD 605)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Seminar in Infectious Disease Control (3)
desc: Strategies for controlling important infectious diseases in the Pacific area. Emphasis on epidemiology, ecology, and public health principles. Pre: 663 (or concurrent) and one semester in microbiology, or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Concepts in Immunology and Immunopathogenesis (2)
desc: Immunological concepts relating to infectious diseases and host pathogen interactions. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: MICR 461 (or equivalent) or consent. (Cross-listed as TRMD 604)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Principles of Epidemiology II (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion on: design and interpretation of experimental and observational studies; causation and casual inference; biases in study design; random error and statistics role in epidemiology; and epidemiological data analysis. A-F only. Pre: 655 and 663, or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Principles of Epidemiology I (3)
desc: Introduction to epidemiologic principles and methods. Topics covered include: outbreak investigation, measures of morbidity and mortality, measurements of risk, biological variability, screening, measurements of error, sampling, statistical significance, study design, and association and causation.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Methods of Demographic Analysis (3)
desc: Statistical evaluation and analysis of population data; data sources; population growth; composition; standardization of rates; mortality and the life table; nuptiality and fertility; distribution, migration, and urbanization; projections and stable population theory. (Cross-listed as SOC 659)
