metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Computer Applications in Public Health (3)
desc: Applications of computers to problems common to public health. Emphasis on data analysis and processing using existing computer programs.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Biostatistics II (3)
desc: Poisson distribution, Fisher’s exact test, contrasts in ANOVA, two way ANOVA, multiple linear regression and analysis of covariance, path analysis, logistic regression, method of maximum likelihood, likelihood ratio tests. Pre: 655, completion of one semester of calculus; or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Biostatistics I (3)
desc: Introduction to statistical methods for public health sciences. Probability, experimental design, t tests and analysis of variance, 2X2 contingency tables, linear regression, introduction to life tables.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Global Health and Human Security (3)
desc: Provides the knowledge, skills, and attitudes required to successfully manage health security crises and protect human vulnerability in the global context with a special focus on problems with high likelihood and risk in the Pacific.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Interdisciplinary Seminar (1)
desc: Topics such as contemporary issues in global health and population studies, international health programs, demographic methods, global economy and health, human right and humanitarian assistance, social justice, global environmental changes and health. Pre: consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Ecological Epidemiology (2)
desc: Applications of population biology, pathogen/host life history, and population genetics to infectious disease epidemiology, including micro- and macroparasites, and implications to disease control and prevention of strategies. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as TRMD 650)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Needs Assessment (3)
desc: Knowledge and skills acquisition in conducting needs assessment in public health practice.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Program Planning, Management, Evaluation, and Leadership (3)
desc: Foundation to inform, educate, and improve health for individuals, communities, and populations. Knowledge/acquisition of skills through program planning, management, evaluation and leadership that span the social-ecological range from individual-level to population-level programs. EPID and PH majors only. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Grant Writing in Public Health (2)
desc: Lecture/discussion on grant writing with public health focus. Includes basic components of grant proposals, assessing appropriate funding opportunities, data sources/resources for justifying grants, and the funder’s perspective. Student will prepare a brief foundation grant proposal. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Advanced Topics in Health Policy (3)
desc: Examines major federal and local policies that impact health and health care delivery in the U.S. and other nations; considers effectiveness of these policy-making institutions for improving population health; covers methods in policy analysis. A-F only. Pre: 602 or consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Indigenous Health Seminar (3)
desc: Examines public health through an Indigenous lens, integrates competencies across all public health disciplines, and will apply them in context of working for and with Indigenous communities to improve health and wellness. PH majors or consent. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Indigenous Health Activism (1)
desc: Examines how Indigenous Peoples and their allies (individually and collectively) accomplish social change in society. A-F only. Graduate students only. Pre: consent of instructor.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Cultural Competency in Health Care (3)
desc: Presents both analytical and practical approaches to cultural competency domains, concepts, models, frameworks, patterns and communication that occur in cross-cultural healthcare situations. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Health Economics (3)
desc: Integrated concepts in health economics and its application towards health policy issues; market failures in health care; factors affecting U.S. health care spending potential impact on equity/efficiency stemming from changes in health care delivery. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Introduction to Health Promotion Theory and Methods (3)
desc: Individual and community health; implications for public health practice, individual and social change processes.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Public Health Biology (3)
desc: Writing-intensive asynchronous computer-based course examines biological processes and challenges relevant to the public health professional. Topics include anatomical, pathophysiological, and molecular bases of public health; genetics, immunology, ethics; disease prevention, control, and management. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as CMB 610)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: U.S. Health Care Services and Policy (3)
desc: Overview of the historical, conceptual, ethical and political context for health care delivery in the U.S. Explores current trends, practices and issues in the delivery of health care services in both private and public sector.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Public Health Foundations (V)
desc: Focus will provide a broad introduction to the field of public health and orientation to overarching issues in the field. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to six credits. PH majors only. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: (Alpha) Current Issues and Topics in Public Health (V)
desc: Current and emerging issues and varying topics related to public health. (B) biostatistics; (E) epidemiology; (H) health policy and management; (S) social and behavioral health sciences; (T) public health. Each alpha repeatable one time. Open to nonmajors. Sophomore standing and above. A-F only. Pre: 201.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Public Health Undergraduate Capstone Seminar (3)
desc:
Synthesis of public health knowledge, skills, and practice acquired during the public health 
undergraduate degree. Students also reflect on, finalize, and present written applied learning experience projects at a public form. Senior standing and higher. A-F only. Pre: completed public health applied learning experience and consent.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Public Health Applied Learning Experience (3)
desc: Allows students to execute an independent, mentor-supervised, applied learning project as implementation of skills learned in previous public health coursework. Applied project is a required component of the public health undergraduate degree program. Pre: 420 and 480.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Application of Public Health Principles in Research and Practice (4)
desc: Introduction to a diverse range of public health projects and associated methods while working to develop a written applied learning project literature review. Students will present their findings at a public forum. PH majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 203 and 310.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Social Determinants of Indigenous Peoples’ Health (3)
desc: Examines indigenous peoples’ health inequities using social determinants of health framework: considers this approach within the historical, political, cultural, and social context of Indigenous population’s health status to generate solutions. A-F only. Pre: 201.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Introduction to Environmental Microbiology (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion. Will define the nature and biological activities of microorganisms in different environments and evaluate the effects of these microbes on human activities and health. Junior standing or higher. Pre: MICR 130 or MICR 351 or BIOL 171.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Back to the Future: Aging in Today’s Society (3)
desc: By 2050, more than a quarter of the world’s population will be 60 years of age or older. Explores what we know about aging today to encourage a lifetime of aging well. A-F only. Pre: 201 or SW 360 or WGSS 305 or PSY 100 or HDFS 230 or NURS 200; or consent. (Cross-listed as COA 435 and SW 435)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Health Policy and Management (3)
desc: Examines the role that health policy and management plays in population-based public health practice, including the delivery, quality, and costs of health care and the structure, process, and outcomes of health services delivery. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 201 and 202.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Social Behavioral Health II: Health Promotion in Communities (3)
desc: Introduction to health education and health promotion programming in public health, and to social/behavioral theories used to develop health interventions that affect communities, institutions, and policies. Introduction to common program planning models. A-F only. Pre: 420.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Social Behavioral Health I: Health Promotion for Individuals and Groups (3)
desc: Focus on the application of social and behavioral theory in health education, and how health promotion programs are constructed for various populations with an emphasis on cultural diversity and social determinants of health. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 202 and PSY 100.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Nutrition and Disease Prevention (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion. Examines a variety of issues associated with the effects of diet on disease incidence, morbidity, and mortality in relation to public health prevention strategies. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 310.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Advanced Epidemiology (3)
desc: Students will gain a deeper understanding of the core concepts used in epidemiologic research and practice. Upon completion, students will have the knowledge and skills necessary to conduct an epidemiologic study. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 201 and 310.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Introduction to Biostatistics (3)
desc: Basic biostatistics methods in public health and biomedical research. Topics covered include data collection, data analyses, and interpretation of statistical results. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Public Health Biology and Pathophysiology (3)
desc: Explores the biological basis of human disease and the role public health measures play in reducing both the extent and impact of chronic and acute diseases on individuals and society. A-F only. Pre: 201, and one of the following: BIOL 101 or BIOL 171 or BIOL 172 or PHYL 103 or PHYL 141 or FSHN 185.
metadata: DB Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Public Health and the Environment (3)
desc: Examines a variety of issues associated with environmental effects on disease incidence, morbidity, and mortality in relation to public health prevention strategies. Sophomore standing and above.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: The United States Health Care System (3)
desc: Overview of the U.S. health care system. Topics will include health economics, health service expenditures, comparative health systems, health policy, and issues of cost containment, access, and quality of care. A-F only. Pre: 201.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Youth Risk and Protection–Public Health Research, Practice, and Policy (3)
desc: Application of public health, related to youth health risks and protective factors using an eco-developmental framework. A-F only. Pre: 201 and PSY 100.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Introduction to Epidemiology (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion on the fundamental principles of epidemiology, exploring patterns of disease, threats to health and EPI methods for prevention, control, and treatment. PH majors only. A-F only. Pre: 201, and 210 or MATH 140X or MATH 161 or higher; or instructor approval.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Native Hawaiian Health Determinants (3)
desc: Seminar to work with faculty in applying evidence-based knowledge on social determinants of health in the formation of research, policy, and program development for improving population health and reducing health disparities for Native Hawaiians. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 201 and 202. (Spring only)
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Seminar in Public Health Issues (3)
desc: Seminar will explore current issues and case studies in epidemiology, issues and causes of chronic and infectious diseases, how the environment interacts with health, and how social and behavioral factors affect personal health.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Quantitative Reasoning for Public Health (3)
desc: Inductive and deductive reasoning; tabular, symbolic, verbal, and graphical forms of functions and relations; graphs and pictorial representations of data; interpretations of probabilistic data; surveys and statistical studies as related to public health. PH majors only. A-F only.
metadata: FQ Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Introduction to Global Health (3)
desc: Introduction to the basic principles of global PH. Topics include the application of these principles to global PH issues, exploration of links between health, economic, and social status, health disparities and global interventions. A-F only. Pre: 201 and a FW course.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Public Health Issues in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Application of general public health concepts and tools with broader public health issues as they relate to the State of Hawai‘i. A-F only. Pre: 201.
metadata: Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PH
title: Introduction to Public Health (3)
desc: Introduces public health concepts with an emphasis on principles and tools for population health, disease prevention, health professions and healthcare systems, and public health professions and systems. A-F only.
metadata: DS Public Health Sciences (PH) Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health

subject: PUBA
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Capstone Seminar (3)
desc: Culminates public administration core courses by incorporating theoretical, analytical, and practicum observations into examination of public issues of importance to Hawai‘i and the region. A-F only. Pre: (601, 602, 607) with a minimum grade of B.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Certificate Practicum (3)
desc: Students in the nonprofit management track of the certificate will learn by doing and observing in a nonprofit organization selected in consultation with the student’s advisor. PUBA graduate certificate students only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: MPA Practicum (3)
desc: Placement in public, private, and nonprofit organizations to observe and analyze organizational functions and processes while undertaking projects of use to the host agency. Repeatable one time. PUBA majors only. A-F only. Pre: with a minimum grade of B: 602, 603, and 604.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Special Topics (3)
desc: Topics of current interest in the field of public service and public administration, taught by regular and visiting faculty. Repeatable for different topics up to six credit hours. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Indigenous Governance (3)
desc: Overview of indigenous governing systems, particularly in the Americas and the Pacific. Students will learn the legal frameworks and principles of these systems, and how services are provided to citizens. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: International Perspectives on Public Administration (3)
desc: Key dimensions of public administration systems on a global scale; historic and contemporary forces shaping national systems; the dimensions that distinguish them, the opportunities and constraints for comparison and the transfer of knowledge and experience. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or departmental approval.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Nonprofit Management Practices and Tools (3)
desc: Skills and tools needed by nonprofit managers. Topics include but are not limited to grantwriting, strategic planning, business practices, program evaluation, and advocacy. A-F only. Pre: 630 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Nonprofit Management (3)
desc: Fundamental aspects of managing a nonprofit organization: overview of the nonprofit sector; mission and scope of nonprofit organizations; organizational structures and functions; resource and volunteer development; major management issues. A-F only Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: ICT Policy and Planning (3)
desc: Processes and methods of planning appropriate to the information and communication sectors, including future economic, social, political, technical, and environmental perspectives. Pre: COM 611 (or concurrent) or consent. (Cross-listed as COM 660)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Managing Workplace Diversity and Inclusion (3)
desc: Examines rationales, impacts, and various dimensions of diversity and inclusion beyond race and gender. Students learn and apply public management tools used to foster workplace diversity and inclusion. A-F only. Pre: 606 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Collaboration for Public and Nonprofit Leaders (3)
desc: Theories, skills, and tools needed to effectively manage networks in government and nonprofit organizations; explores how to administer, assess performance, and evaluate success in these dynamic new partnerships. Graduate students only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Law, Economics, and Public Administration (3)
desc: Explore U.S. law as applied to public institutions using economic lens. Rationale of property, contract, and tort law; evolution of administrative law, economic efficiency of common law system, effects of legal rules on economic behavior. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Strategies of Change: Leaders and Leadership (3)
desc: Explores the key elements of leadership in public settings by examining what leaders actually do, looking at popular media portrayals of leadership, and talking together with guests about the challenges of leadership, effective followership, and positive change. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: The Political Environment of Public Organizations (3)
desc: Seminar on the role of public managers in shaping public opinion and public policy. Using evidence from theory and practice presents students with tools for understanding management roles within a political context. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Reforming Public Organizations (3)
desc: Looks at the challenges and opportunities for changing public organizations so that they may be more successful in meeting their public responsibilities and better places for people to work. Focus is on the creation of positive images of organization and effective change strategies. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Program Evaluation for Public and Nonprofit Organizations (3)
desc: Methods for evaluating the effectiveness of programs in the public and nonprofit sectors; performance measurement to inform managerial decision making. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Policy Analysis and Implementation (3)
desc: Explore contemporary policy issues relating to public administration practice. Develop analytic techniques and models of public policy-making processes, administrative rules, and policy implementation strategies. Learn how social forces, political, and economic pressures influence policy orientation. PUBA majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Public Budgeting (3)
desc: Institutions and issues related to public-sector budgeting at federal, state, and local levels. Process of developing public budgets and constraints on public policy reflected in budgets. PUBA majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Public Administration Research Methods (3)
desc: Introduction to research methods for public administrators to understand the principles and methods used to conduct and analyze valid research. Examples are oriented to the field; theory and hands-on practice utilized. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: 601. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Public Administration Personnel Management (3)
desc: Understand the pivotal role that effective human resource management (also known as personnel management) plays in improving organizational effectiveness. Topics include managing diversity, employment law and discrimination, performance appraisal, and labor-management relations. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Effective Communication in Public Administration (3)
desc: Knowledge and skills to effectively communicate in the public sector. Focus on communication foundations and skills, levels and contexts of public sector communication, and handling challenges such as diverse and multi-cultural settings. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Leadership and Ethics (3)
desc: Applies leadership and ethical theories to public and non-profit sectors, focusing on ethical leadership; emphasizes critical thinking to address value conflicts; and teaches moral reasoning as a practical professional skill. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Organizations: Theory and Change (3)
desc: Explores characteristics and structural, human resources, political, and cultural frames of organizational theory. Focus on organizational change strategies and theories. Discusses how to use these frames and theories in everyday management of public service organizations. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as CEE 620)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Introduction to Public Administration (3)
desc: Develop a comprehension of the history and foundation of public administration. Topics include economic, political, and social dynamics; decision-making and leadership theories, management challenges, human resources, budgeting, program evaluation, policy, and technology. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Directed Reading and Research in Public Administration (V)
desc: Independent research and reading on topics in public administration, public service, and community development. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Practicum and Internship (3)
desc: The practicum and internship in Peace and Conflict Resolution provides an opportunity for students to apply the skills and concepts learned in earlier courses. Pre: any two other PACE courses or consent. (Cross-listed as PACE 495)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Multicultural Leadership in Public Service (3)
desc: Develop students’ culturally agile leadership to allow them effectively lead in work on international, regional, and local projects and problems of compelling public interest that cross cultures. Junior standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Foundations of Nonprofit Management (3)
desc: Broad overview of nonprofit organizations, including what it means to be a nonprofit, strategies of nonprofit organizations, and the management of nonprofits. Topics include advocacy, leadership, and evaluating success. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PUBA
title: Research Methods for Policy Evaluation (3)
desc: Explores methodological approaches to the evaluation of public policies and strengths and weaknesses of various social science research methods. Students will learn how to employ them to determine the effectiveness of various public policies. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 304, 330, or PLAN 310.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Public Administration (PUBA)

subject: PSY
title: Directed Reading or Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Directed Reading or Research (V)
desc: Repeatable eight times, up to nine credits. Pre: 100 and consent of instructor.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Special Topics in Psychology (3)
desc: Covers topics of current or special interest not covered in regular course offerings or advanced topics seminars. Repeatable two times. Pre: 100.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Community Psychology Research (3)
desc: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Community Psychology Seminar (3)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Practicum: Behavioral Change and Community (3)
desc: Supervised experience in educational, mental health, correctional, consulting, or community action agencies. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Cultural Community Psychology (3)
desc: Graduate seminar on cultural considerations and issues in the history, methods, theories, interventions, and professional roles in community psychology. Small class size (up to 10). Open to graduate students.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Applied Psychology: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: Coverage in-depth of some areas of theory and research. Repeatable to six credit hours. Pre: 100. (Cross-listed as EDEP 489)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Consumer Behavior (3)
desc: Analysis of consumer behavior and motivation; principles of learning, personality, perception, and group influence, with emphasis upon mass communication effects. Pre: BUS 312 or consent. (Cross-listed as MKT 311)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Community Psychology (3)
desc: Examination of human functioning in social and ecological context. Topics include stress, health, intergroup relations, culture, ethnicity, social competence, and community empowerment. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Research in Clinical Psychology (3)
desc: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable 30 times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Internship in Clinical Psychology (1)
desc: Repeatable one time. Pre: consent of instructor.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Health Psychology: Behavioral and Biological Bases (3)
desc: Psychological and biological bases of health psychology and behavioral medicine. Overview of cognitive, behavioral, and psychophysiological mechanisms; theories and methods of prevention in physical disease. Pre: 670 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Psychological Therapies (3)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Clinical Psychology (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Psychopathology (3)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Adult Treatment: Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (3)
desc: Training in cognitive-behavioral strategies for treating adults. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in Clinical Studies Program only. PSY major only. Pre: 670 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Child Treatment (3)
desc: Psychological interventions for youth, as well as parent training. Repeatable two times. Pre: 670 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: External Practicum (3)
desc: This supervision-style class will cover cases and issues related to student’s clinic work, supervision, or educational goals while training in external practicum sites. Repeatable ten times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Adult Practicum (3)
desc: Supervised clinical assessment and treatment of adults. Repeatable ten times, up to 33 credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Child Practicum (3)
desc: Supervised clinical assessment and treatment of children and adolescents. Repeatable ten times, up to 33 credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychopathology (3)
desc: Comprehensive study of the mental disorders across the lifespan. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Treatment Research (3)
desc: Idiographic and nomothetic approaches to clinical treatment research methods and findings. Pre: 670 (or concurrent) and 671, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Advanced Assessment (3)
desc: Conceptual and methodological foundations of clinical applications of assessment. PSY majors only. A-F only. Pre: 671 and 672 and enrollment in Clinical Studies Program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Assessment II (3)
desc: Administration and interpretation of cognitive-intellectual and personality assessment devices. A-F only. Pre: 670 and 671 or consent and enrollment in Clinical Studies Program.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Assessment I (3)
desc: Psychometric theory; ethics; diversity issues; principles and methods of cognitive-intellectual, neuropsychological, and personality assessment. A-F only. Co-requisite: 670 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology (3)
desc: Preparation for becoming a clinical psychologist with emphasis on scientist-practitioner model, professional ethics, diversity and professional development. Pre: graduate student in psychology or consent of instructor.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Advanced Topics in Adjustment/ Treatment/Prevention (3)

subject: PSY

desc: Survey of major theories, concepts, research, and application regarding communication and social support in interpersonal relationships. (Cross-listed as COMG 490)

subject: PSY

desc: Psychological principles for understanding and dealing with wellness and illness. Theories and research on stress-related disorders; prevention of stress through lifestyle and healthy behaviors. Pre: 100 or consent. Recommended: 220 or 322.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Abnormal Psychology (3)
desc: Nature and causes of psychological disorders. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology (3)
desc: History, theories, nature of psychological problems, methods of assessment, forms of intervention, current developments. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Personal Development (3)
desc: The application of psychology to the understanding, management, and enhancement of one’s life.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychology of Personality (3)
desc: Scientific study of personality, its meaning, assessment, development, relation to cultural-social determinants. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Research in Social Psychology (3)
desc: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Social Psychology (3)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Social Psychology of Love and Sex (3)
desc: Seminar in psychosocial aspects of human sexual relationships. Social psychology of cognitive, emotional and physiological arousal, interpersonal attraction, mate selection, and antecedents and consequences of intimate relationships. Pre: consent. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Applied Social Psychology (3)
desc: Problems in use of social psychology principles in human affairs; multidisciplinary considerations.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychology and Social Issues (3)
desc: Conflict, dissent, community issues, problems; social change and its relation to mental disorder.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Cross-Cultural Psychology (3)
desc: Application of psychological theories to cross-cultural phenomena; assessment of cross-cultural processes and social motivations; culture and personality; research evaluation and design.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Social Psychology (3)
desc: Theories and research in social cognition and behavior.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Social Psychology: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: In-depth coverage of some area of theory and research in social psychology. Repeatable to six credit hours.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychology of Human Sexuality (3)
desc: Psychosocial aspects of human sexual relationships. Social psychology of emotional and physiological arousal, interpersonal attraction, and societal regulation of intimate relationships. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Cross-Cultural Psychology (3)
desc: Psychological theories and cultural systems; understanding of own and other cultures; psychological and cultural perception of social motivation; cultural similarities and differences in interpersonal relations. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Social Psychology (3)
desc: Cognitive, behavioral, and emotional effects of people: interpersonal relations, attribution, attitudes, group behavior, stereotypes, social roles, aggression, helping, self-concept; applications. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Research in Developmental Psychology (3)
desc: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Developmental Psychology (3)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Cognitive Development (3)
desc: Familiarizes students with current research and theory in cognitive development through readings of original journal articles and monographs. Pre: 640 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Developmental Foundations (3)
desc: Historical, theoretical, and methodological foundations of developmental psychology.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Development Psychology: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: In-depth coverage of some area of theory and research in developmental psychology. Repeatable to six credit hours. Pre: 240, 341, or consent

subject: PSY
title: Clinical Child and Adolescent Psychology (3)
desc: Social and emotional maladjustment in children and adolescents, developmental disabilities, pediatric psychology, psychological interventions with children and adolescents. Pre: 100. Recommended: 240.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Adult Development and Aging (3)
desc: Overview from a multidisciplinary, life-span perspective. Includes research techniques, personality development, family relationships, occupational attainment, death. Pre: 100. Recommended: 240. (Cross-listed as COA 342)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Social Development of Children (3)
desc: Survey of the social and emotional development of children and adolescents. Pre: 240 or HDFS 230.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Developmental Psychology (3)
desc: Emotional, mental, physical, social development from infancy to adulthood; interests and abilities at different age levels. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Research in Psychology (3)
desc: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Comparative Psychology (3)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Physiological Psychology (3)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Behavioral Neuroscience (3)
desc: Relation of central and peripheral nervous systems to behavior.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychopharmacology (3)
desc: Basic principles of pharmacology as they apply to the brain and specific psychological disorders such as anxiety, depression, post-traumatic stress disorders, schizophrenia, psychosis, memory, and drug use. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Selected Topics in Comparative Psychology (3)
desc: Intensive review of comparative, communicative, sensory, or learning mechanisms in animals. Pre: 631.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Comparative Cognition (3)
desc: Survey of the historical and contemporary study of cognition across species, including learning, memory, attention, navigation, reasoning, social interaction, and communication.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychobiology: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: Indepth coverage of some area of theory and research in psychobiology, physiological psychology, or sensory processes. Repeatable to six credit hours. Pre: 100.
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Sensation and Perception (3)
desc: In-depth coverage of the basic principles involved in sensing and perceiving our environment. A-F only. Pre: 100.
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychopharmacology (3)
desc: Coverage of the principles of pharmacology in relation to the effects of drug actions on the brain and behavior. A-F only. Pre: 230 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Behavioral Neuroscience (3)
desc: Coverage of the relationship between the brain and body on learning and memory, stress, motivated and regulatory behavioral functions, and mental disorders. A-F only. Pre: 230 or BIOL 172, or consent.
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Psychobiology (3)
desc: Survey of study of behavior from a natural sciences viewpoint. Evolution, ethological analysis of behavior genetics, neural mechanisms, drugs and behavior, biological development. Pre: 100.
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Research in Experimental Psychology (3)
desc: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Learning (3)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Experimental Psychology (3)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Thinking (3)
desc: Provides an introduction to higher cognition (thinking and reasoning) and its foundations, particularly as they relate to the larger field of cognitive science. A-F only. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Cognitive Psychology (3)
desc: In-depth survey of the computational and representational structures and processes of cognition. Special attention devoted to consideration of the relationship between brain, mind, and computation. Pre: 325 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Principles of Learning (3)
desc: Survey of the principles of learning, including important discoveries in the development of the study of learning, major theories, and both basic and applied research in contemporary literature.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Experimental Psychology: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: In-depth coverage of some area of theory and research, in cognitive psychology. Repeatable to six credit hours. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Cognitive Psychology (3)
desc: Survey of cognitive processes involved in perception, attention, memory, language, problem-solving, reasoning, judgment, intelligence and consciousness, among others. Pre: 100 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychology of Emotion (3)
desc: Survey of traditional views and leading theories, and research in related topics. Pre: 100. Recommended: 220 or 322.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Learning and Motivation (3)
desc: Theoretical interpretations; survey of major theorists and contemporary controversial issues; major influences in classical and instrumental conditioning. Pre: 100. Recommended: 220.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Statistical Techniques (3)
desc: Frequency distributions; graphic methods; central tendency; variability; correlation; reliability; tests of significance. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Behavioral Psychology (3)
desc: Outline of basic learning principles. A general, unified approach to study of human personality and behavior. Based upon a learning conception; various areas of psychology and the other social sciences are treated. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Research in Psychometrics (3)
desc: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in Quantitative Psychology (3)
desc: Specific and newly emerging topics in statistics, including casual inference, analysis of missing data, and statistical machine learning. Content varies and focuses on advanced topics not covered in other PSY methods and statistics courses. Repeatable two times. PSY majors only. A-F only. Pre: 610 (with a minimum grade of B) or instructor consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Analysis of Multilevel Models and Longitudinal Data (3)
desc: Theories and applications of analysis of nested (clustered) data. Topics include fixed and random effects, intra-class correlation, cross-sectional multilevel models, and multilevel models, and multilevel models with repeated measures and longitudinal data. Requires basic knowledge of regression.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Categorical Data Analysis (3)
desc: Theories and methods for data analysis with categorical and discrete variables. Topics include contingency tables; logistic regression; log-linear models; and introduction to generalized linear models. Pre: 610, EDEP 604, or consent. (Cross-listed as EDEP 618)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Advanced Psychometrics (3)
desc: Theories and applications of modern psychometrics. Topics include unidimensional and multidimensional models of item response theory, detecting biased items, measurement invariance, scaling methods, and current issues in psychometrics. Pre: 616, EDEP 616, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Measurement in Education and Social Sciences (3)
desc: Test theories and applications in education and social sciences. Topics include the true score model; reliability; generalizability theory; validity; item response theory; and applications in research. Class requires knowledge in ANOVA and regression.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Multivariate Analysis (3)
desc: Analysis of multiple dependent variables. Topics include multivariate normal distribution, Hotelling’s 72, multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA), discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, canonical correlation, and principal components analysis (PCA). Pre: 610, EDEP 604, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Factor Analysis and Structural Equation Models (SEM) (3)
desc: Theories and applications to latent variables models. Topics include path analysis, exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis, structural equation models (SEM), multi-sample SEM, mean structure, latent growth curve models, and multilevel SEM. Requires basic knowledge of regression.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) and Related Methods (3)
desc: Introduction to ANOVA and its extensions from both traditional and general linear model approaches. Topics include single and multi-factor ANOVA, multiple comparisons, analysis of covariance (ANCOVA), and repeated-measures ANOVA.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Introduction to Regression (3)
desc: Introduction to quantitative methods in behavioral sciences and the general linear model with a focus on regression. Topics include correlation, bivariate and multiple regression, mediation, and moderation. Requires basic statistics. (Meets PhD common inquiry methods requirement or elective.)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychometrics: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: In-depth coverage of some area of theory, research, or methodology relevant to individual differences, measurement, or aspects of psychometrics. Repeatable to six credit hours. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Survey of Research Methods (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Survey of standard methods and related conceptual issues employed in psychological research. Both experimental and non-experimental methods will be reviewed. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in History and Theory of Psychology (3)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar in General Psychology (3)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Minimum of six credit hours is required. Repeatable six times up to seven credits.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Methodologic Foundations of Psychology (3)
desc: Methods used in psychological research; observational, correlational, and experimental types of design.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: General Psychology: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: In-depth coverage of some area of theory and research. Repeatable to 6 credit hours. Pre: 100.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Teaching General Psychology (V)
desc: Supervised experience. Pre: 100, at least 12 additional credit hours in psychology, and written consent. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Practicum in Psychology (V)
desc: Supervised psychological experience in school, clinic, hospital, industry, social welfare, government, etc. Pre: 100 and consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Seminar on the Psychology of Knowledge (3)
desc: Selected topics in the psychology of knowledge and mind from Western and/or non-Western perspectives. Repeatable in different topics up to 9 credit hours. Pre: 100 and written consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: History of Psychology (3)
desc: Origin and development of contemporary points of view. Pre: 100. Recommended: 9 credit hours in psychology.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Psychology of Gender (3)
desc: Survey of topics in psychology relevant to gender and its impact on the lives of women and men: socialization of gender, mental health, racial identity, majority-minority status, sexual orientation, life-span issues and violence. A-F only. Pre: 100 or WGSS 151. (Cross-listed as WGSS 202)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSY
title: Survey of Psychology (3)
desc: An overview of the field: psychophysiology, perception, learning, cognition, stress, personality, social psychology.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Psychology (PSY)

subject: PSTY
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Psychiatry (PSTY)

subject: PSTY
title: Philosophy & Human Suffering (1)
desc: To see how various philosophies and religions have tackled the question, “why is there suffering in the world?” Read short excerpts from “classic” texts and discuss in a welcoming atmosphere and draw own conclusions. Medical students only. CR/NC only. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Psychiatry (PSTY)

subject: PSTY
title: (Alpha) Electives in Psychiatry (V)
desc: Senior medical student elective providing advanced instruction on the theory and methods of mental health research as well as supervised participation in an assigned research project in the Department of Psychiatry. (B) adult inpatient PSTY; (C) child PSTY; (D) forensic PSTY; (E) journal editing; (F) community mental health; (G) PSTY aspects of OBGN, PED, MED, SURG; (H) sub-internship in adult PSTY; (I) substance abuse; (J) PSTY aspects of rehab medicine; (K) PSTY aspects of SURG; (M) PSTY consult liaison; (N) post-traumatic stress disorder; (O) extramural elective in PSTY; (Q) geriatric PSTY; (R) rural child PSTY; (S) public and rural PSTY; (T) mental health research. CR/NC only. Pre: 531 or 532, and fourth-year standing.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Psychiatry (PSTY)

subject: PSTY
title: Psychiatry Longitudinal Clerkship (5)
desc: Year-long clerkship in ambulatory setting, including knowledge, skills, attitudes for assessment, diagnosis, and management of psychiatric problems in medical practice, inpatient, and emergency room settings. Emphasis on development and application of psychosocial cultural formulations in all areas of psychiatric and medical practice. Repeatable two times. MD majors only. Pre: third-year standing and concurrent registration in 532 courses. Co-requisites: FMCH, MED, OBGN, PEDS, SURG 532 and SURG 535.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Psychiatry (PSTY)

subject: PSTY
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Individualized directed readings and/or research in mental health and psychiatry under the supervision of an instructor. Open to non-majors. Repeatable up to four times. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Psychiatry (PSTY)

subject: PRAK

subject: PORT

desc: Intensive practice in spoken Portuguese, focusing on the preparation and completion of oral tasks and presentations. 40% or more of the grade is based on 3-4 oral communication presentations. Pre: 202.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese (3)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese (3)
desc: Reading, conversation, writing, laboratory drill. Pre: 102 or 103.

title: Intensive Elementary Portugese (3)
desc: Intensive elementary Portuguese course covers content of 101 and 102 combined. Hybrid format combines 3 credits online and 3 credits face to face. HSL. (Fall only)

subject: PORT
title: Elementary Portuguese (3)
desc: Conversation, grammar and reading. Continuation of 101. Pre: 101.

subject: PORT
title: Elementary Portuguese (3)
desc: Conversation, grammar and reading.

desc: Repeatable unlimited times.

desc: Analysis of political development, international relations, decision-making processes, and systems of political thought in regions and subregions of the world. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Decolonial Futures (3)
desc: Topic engages probable and preferable futures of indigenous struggles and resistances. Emphasis placed on the ethics and responsibilities used to move towards those futures.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Indigenous Nations and the Problems of Sovereignty (3)
desc: Examines intersections of sovereignty and indigenity from comparative and critical perspectives. Engages indigenous studies of sovereignty and of alternative political frameworks. Repeatable one time. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Seminar: Public Policy (3)
desc: Pre-announced topics. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent of instructor. At least one section a year.

subject: POLS
title: Seminar: Public Administration (3)
desc: Pre-announced administrative theory, comparative and development administration, and functional aspects. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Seminar: Comparative Government and Politics (3)
desc: Pre-announced topics. Repeatable unlimited times. At least one section a semester.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Seminar: International Relations (3)
desc: Pre-announced problems of both international organization and politics. Repeatable unlimited times. At least one section a semester.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Seminar: Indigenous Theory (3)
desc: Pre-announced topics may include gender and sexuality studies, postcolonial theory, colonial discourse analysis, globalization, historiography; emphasis on indigenous epistemologies and the work of native scholars. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Seminar: Political Thought (3)
desc: Pre-announced topics. Repeatable unlimited times. At least one section a year.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Writing Politics (3)
desc: Seminar on the politics of writing, grammar, translation, argument, genre, and style with significant content on indigenous issues of oral traditions, alternative modes of writing and argument, and language continuance.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Seminar: Research Methods (3)
desc: Conceptual strategies, data collection approaches, and data analysis techniques appropriate to political inquiries. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Graduate Intern Seminar (3)
desc: Seminar for those seeking internship experience. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 672 and 673 or consent for the alternative futures option; 620 or consent for the indigenous politics option; consent of advisor for all other options.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Colloquium (3)
desc: Specialized subjects in political science.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Teaching Initiative in Political Science (3)
desc: Combines the study of the theoretical and practical aspects of teaching political science with supervised classroom teaching of POLS 110. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Politics of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Examinations from several perspectives of the political, economic, and cultural forces that historically formed Hawai‘i and contemporary political themes, issues, and processes. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: (Alpha) Topics in Asian and/or Pacific Politics (3)
desc: (C) Korean politics. Graduate students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Contemporary Native Hawaiian Politics (3)
desc: Study of political and social movements, political status, national and cultural identities, and issues of representation of Native Hawaiians.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Asian and/or Pacific Politics (3)
desc: Political development, international relations, decision-making processes, and systems of political thought in all or part of Asia and/or the Pacific. Repeatable three times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Nonviolent Political Alternatives (3)
desc: Exploration of nonviolent, non-killing alternatives in political science research, teaching, and public service.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Topics in Public Policy (3)
desc: Particular political processes, specific political institutions, or particular policy area. Graduate students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: The Future of Political Systems (3)
desc: Normative and descriptive forecasts of political institutions, systems, subsystems, and behaviors. Design of preferred systems.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Politics of the Future (3)
desc: Introduction to political futures studies; images of future, theories of social change, methods of social forecasting and designing preferred futures. Graduate students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Introduction to Public Policy (3)
desc: Perspectives on policy analysis; basic approaches to the study of public policy, political economy, and policy evaluation. (Cross-listed as PLAN 607)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Topics in Public Law and Judicial System (3)
desc: Recent issues and practices in public law; particular judicial systems. Graduate students only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Law and Politics (3)
desc: Law, courts, and rights as a political resource; analyses of public law (including court decisions), other forms of dispute management, and judicial behavior and policy-making. Pre: 110.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Comparative Public Administration (3)
desc: Detailed examination of implementation of governmental policy in different countries. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Political Leadership (3)
desc: Exploration of political leadership as a focus for research, teaching, and applied political science.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Public Administrative Theory (3)
desc: Focus varies among theoretical, comparative and developmental approaches to study of administration. One section each semester.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: American Political Institutions in Comparative Perspective (3)
desc: Consideration of American political institutions and development relative to American philosophical foundations and non-American political forms. Federalism as an expansive devise will be emphasized, as will American influence and penetration abroad. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: (Alpha) Politics and Development: Topical (3)
desc: (F) political ecology and development.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

title: Comparative Politics (3)
desc: Emphasis on Asia, theories of development, and comparative methods. At least one section a semester.

title: (Alpha) Topics in International Relations (3)
desc: (B) international relations and war; (E) international organization; (F) modeling international systems. Graduate students only. Pre: consent.

subject: POLS

subject: POLS

subject: POLS
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Pre: consent.

metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS

desc: Theory and practice of democratic organizations: women’s and feminist organizations; co-ops, communes, and collectives; indigenous people’s organizations; workplace democracy and social change. A-F only. Pre: any 100- or 200-level POLS course or 390 (or concurrent) or WGSS 151, or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 394)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Advanced Topics in Law, Policy, and Society (3)
desc: Studies integrating concerns of public law, public policy, public administration, and social movements. Pre: any 100- or 200-level POLS course, or consent.

desc: Introductory survey and analysis of methods used in empirical research, policy analysis, and social criticism.

metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS

desc: Study of the ocean as a political place. Engagement with theories, policies, and lived-experiences of the ocean through a political lens, including literature and experiential learning. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: any 100 or 200-level POLS course, or consent. (Cross-listed as SUST 387)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Public Policy-Making (3)
desc:
Students develop understanding of theory, practice, and ethical issues of public policy-making. Combines lecture/discussion and fieldtrips. Students develop policy analysis and strategic plans that identify issues, interests, and methods of influence. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: HON 101 or HON 291(Alpha), or departmental approval. 
(Cross-listed as HON 301)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: American Politics (3)
desc: Institutions (parties, interest groups, legislatures, executives, local government); policies (national defense, poverty, energy, etc.), politics (symbolism, inequality, race, and gender).
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Women and Politics (3)
desc: Women’s role in political institutions and processes in the U.S. and other countries. Female and male approaches to power; feminist political goals and actions. Pre: any 100 level POLS course (or concurrent), WGSS 151 (or concurrent), or WGSS 362 (or concurrent); or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 384)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Politics and Public Policy II (3)
desc: Overview of the policy-making process in various political arenas (families, cities, nations, etc.); emphasis on conceptual and empirical analysis. Pre: any 100 level POLS course or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Political Leadership (3)
desc: Exploration of concepts and theories of political leadership, partly through biography, as preparation for public service or advanced scholarly inquiry. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

desc: Historical emergence of modern bureaucracy; mutual impact of administrative forms on social life; relation of bureaucracy to capitalism and patriarchy; constitution of the administered individual. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS

desc: Focuses on theories, laws, policies, ethics, and sustainable futures of Hawai‘i and the U.S. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: any 100 or 200 level POLS course, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as SUST 380)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Power in America (3)
desc: Analysis of sources of political, economic, and social power in the U.S. and the institutions through which it is exercised. PSophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Topics in American Politics (3)

subject: POLS
title: Topics in Law and Politics (3)
desc: Current issues; recent research findings; practical research undertaken by student. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent.

metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

title: Constitutional Law I: Institutional Power (3)
desc: Provides students with methods for interpreting U.S. Supreme Court decisions and analyzes the U.S. Supreme Court’s jurisprudence on institutional authority, including the Judiciary, Executive, and Legislative branches and their relationships to power. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Law, Politics and Society (3)
desc: Relationships between law, politics, and society will be explored. Emphasis is placed on several dimensions of legality: legal “indeterminacy” and some of the many things that law does for us and to us; law’s response to violence; the connections between law and social change; access to the law and its sociological dimensions; how/why law fails and what happens when it does. A-F only. Pre: a 100 level or 200 level POLS course or SOC 100 or any 200 level SOC course, or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 374)

subject: POLS
title: American Politics (Elections) (3)

Pre: one of 339, AMST 310, AMST 316, AMST 318, AMST 373, AMST 455, WGSS 360, WGSS 361, WGSS 439; or consent. (Cross-listed as AMST 438 and WGSS 462)

metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS

desc: Studies in political theory, media, and methods that analyze their interrelations in a globalized world. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent.

Through movies and documentaries, students will learn major sociopolitical issues including military dictatorship, democratization, and globalization that Korea underwent for the last several decades. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

A-F only. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 308).

Grounded in Native Hawaiian perspectives, with an emphasis on comparative study and dialogue. Pre: any 100- or 200-level POLS course, or consent.

subject: POLS

subject: POLS

desc: Introduces undergraduate students to the major political, social, economic, cultural, technological, and historical dimensions of globalization. Special attention will be paid to globalization process that have impacted Hawai‘i and the Asia-Pacific region. A-F only. (Cross-listed as SOC 180)
metadata: FGB College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Introduction to Global Politics (3)
desc: Foundations in global politics from political, historical, and multicultural perspectives. A-F only.

subject: POLS
title: Introduction to American Politics (3)
desc: American political processes and institutions, as seen through alternative interpretations. Emphasis on opportunities and limitations for practical political participation.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Introduction to World Politics (3)
desc: Power and contemporary world politics since 1945 with emphasis on the U.S. role.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Introduction to Political Science (3)
desc: Discussion of politics as an activity and of political problems, systems, ideologies, processes.

subject: PEPS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Directed research, critical reviews in environmental protection sciences, entomology, or plant pathology. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

desc: Examine approaches to weed biological control of invasive plants in various environments with different agents (insects, pathogens, and vertebrates), integration with other management tactics, sociopolitical aspects, and history of the practice. Graduate students only. Pre: 421 or 422 or consent. (Alt. years)

desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Fundamental concepts. Critical study of major biological control projects. Pre: 421 or consent. Recommended: 662; and ZOOL 631 or 632.

title: Insect Ecology (3)

metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Systematics and Phylogenetics (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Classification and study of diversity among insects and other life forms. Use of morphological and molecular characters to reconstruct evolutionary histories. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Seminar in Plant Pathology (1)
desc: Seminar on research and topics in plant pathology. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Molecular Plant–Fungal Interactions (3)
desc: Focuses on the actions of plant pathogenic fungi/ oomycetes and their host responses at the molecular and cellular level. Current genetic and genomic approaches to study plant-fungal interactions will be discussed. Graduate standing only. Pre: consent. (Every 2 years) (Cross-listed as MBBE 652)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Insect Physiology (4)
desc: (2 Lec) Study of the principal physiological and biochemical functions in insects, with emphasis on hormonal interactions. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Diagnosis and Management of Tropical Plant Diseases Laboratory (2)
desc: Diagnosis and management of plant pathogen and pest problems in laboratory and field. Taught concurrently with 615. A-F only. Pre: (605 and 606) with a minimum grade of B, or equivalent. Co-requisite: 615. (Summer only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Diagnosis and Management of Tropical Plant Diseases (3)
desc: Iterative and interactive course integrating plant pathogen and pest biology with diagnostic and management approaches. Will use biological information about pathogens, anthropods, and abiotic stresses to diagnose diseases, disorders, or other injuries of plants. A-F only. Pre: (605 and 606) with a minimum grade of B, or consent. Co-requisite: 615L. (Summer only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Biology of Plant Pathogens: Bacteria and Viruses (4)
desc: (2 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Principles and concepts in pathogen biology, epidemiology, and management of plant diseases caused by bacteria and viruses. Laboratory techniques for isolation and identification of pathogens and disease diagnosis. A-F only. Pre: 605 (with a minimum grade of B). (Spring only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Biology of Plant Pathogens: Fungi and Nematodes (4)
desc: (2 Lec, 2 3-hr. Lab) Principles and concepts in pathogen biology, epidemiology and management of plant diseases caused by fungi, oomycetes, and nematodes. Laboratory techniques for isolation and identification of pathogens and disease diagnosis. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Agrosecurity and Food Safety (2)
desc: Concepts of agrosecurity and food safety (including plant and animal biosecurity), global impacts of introduced pests and diseases, and current mechanisms for interception of pests and mitigation of disease. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Conduct original research in environmental protection sciences. Limited to qualified undergraduate students. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: PEPS Capstone (4)
