desc: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development, Directed Research, field studies, employment with cooperating businesses, government or schools are all options. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Topics in Plant & Environmental Protection (V)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems. May be offered by visiting faculty, extension faculty or research faculty. Repeatable two times.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Insect-Plant Interactions (3)
desc:
Study of the coevolutionary relationships between insects and 
plants, with emphasis on the behavior, physiology, and symbiotic relationships of insects. Discussed in the context of sustainable agriculture, anthropogenic change, and climate change. A-C only. Pre: 363 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent. DB
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Weed Science (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Weed classification, identification, adaptations for weediness; principles of weed control; properties, uses, and action of herbicides. Lab: pesticide application equipment and techniques, no-till farming, greenhouse and field experiments. A-F only. Pre: (CHEM 152 and TPSS 200/ SUST 211) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as TPSS 481) DB
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Medical and Urban Entomology (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1-3-hr hybrid Lab) Biology, ecology, health and economic impacts, and control of urban insect pests and medically important arthropods that act as vectors of diseases. Pre: (363 or BIOL 265) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Cross-listed as TRMD 463) DB
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Environmental Law (3)
desc: Exploration of federal laws, regulations, and precedents that govern our interaction with the environment. Analysis of laws regulating air, water, toxins, pests, endangered species, and environmental justice. Pre: junior or senior standing.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Plant Disease Management (3)
desc: Diagnosis, epidemiology, and integrated management of important plant diseases and pathogens for key plants and cultivated crops in various agroecosystems in Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and the global tropics. Pre: 405. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Biocontrol of Invasive Species (3)
desc: Biological control of invasive insects and weeds using natural enemies; biological control as a cornerstone of sustainable pest management; contributions of biocontrol to economic, environmental, and societal sustainability; reduced dependence on pesticides; increased sustainability of pest management. Pre: 363 or consent. (Cross-listed as SUST 422)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Foundations of Pest Management (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles and concepts of insect pest management using biological, ecological, cultural, behavioral, legislative, microbial and chemical methods. A-F only. Pre: one of the following: 250 or 363, BIOL 171, BIOL 172, or BOT 101; or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Turfgrass Pest Management (3)
desc: Provides students with knowledge and real world experience on common turfgrass pests and management strategies in Hawai‘i, with emphasis on integrated pest management. Common cool-season turfgrass and pest management are also discussed. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as TPSS 418)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Sustainable Soil and Plant Health Management (2)
desc: Provides knowledge and understanding of soils, agroecology, and sustainable approaches for plant health management, and prepares students for applied research in various tropical cropping systems. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as TPSS 410 and SUST 410)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Plant Pathogens and Diseases (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Classification, morphology, ecology, and biology of bacteria, fungi, nematodes, and viruses that attack economic crops. Etiology and control of plant diseases. Pre: 210/SUST 210 or BOT 101 or MICR 130, or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Genetics: Theory to Application (3)
desc: Fundamentals of genetic theory using traditional breeding and biotechnological procedures in insect and plant pathogen management for sustainable agricultural production. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Cross-listed as SUST 371 and TPSS 371)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: General Entomology Laboratory (1)
desc: Laboratory in the biology and classification to family level of Hawai‘i’s insects and arthropods. A-F only. Pre: (363 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. DY
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: General Entomology (3)
desc: Biology, diversity, and ecology of insects with emphasis on Hawaiian fauna. Classification to order level. A-F only. Pre: (BOT 101 or ZOOL 101 or BIOL 171) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. DB
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Invasive Pest Species (3)
desc: Ecological, economic and sociological impacts of invasive species on tropical ecosystems; characteristics of invasive species and vulnerability of habitats; ethical issues on impacts of management options on evolution, biodiversity and eco-stability and human life. Open to nonmajors. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Ecology of Infectious Diseases and Symbioses (3)
desc: Introduction to the ecology of infectious diseases of animals, plants, and humans. Factors affecting disease transmission and virulence. Effects of human activities and environmental change on disease transmission. Emphasis on issues pertinent to Hawai‘i. A-F only. Pre: (BIOL 171 and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as OCN 340)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Environment and Agriculture (3)
desc: Overview of environmental issues related to agriculture, specifically pest management issues, and options for environmentally responsible management and amelioration of these impacts. Ethical issues on impact of agriculture on the environment will be discussed. (Cross-listed as SUST 320)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: The World of Insects (3)
desc: Biology/ecology of insects with emphasis on relationships to plants, animals, and especially people in Hawai‘i and the tropics. Open to nonmajors. A-F only.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PEPS
title: Introduction to Environmental Science (3)
desc: Analysis of our environment with emphasis on understanding relationships and interactions of physical, biological, technological, and political components using scientific methods of inquiry. Food supply and safety, water quality, pollution control, biodiversity, environmental policy. Open to nonmajors. (Cross-listed as NREM 210 and SUST 210)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Plant and Environmental Protection Sciences (PEPS)

subject: PHYL
title: Human Physiology: Integrative Systems (4)
desc: Senior-level course in integrative systems (central nervous system and endocrinology). Complements 401. Pre: 401 and either BIOC 341 or CHEM 152, or consent.
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Human Physiology: Organ Systems (4)
desc: Basic function of the major organ systems in man. Covers cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, acid-base, and gastrointestinal physiology. Pre: 302 or equivalent with consent.
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Human Anatomy and Physiology Lab (1)
desc: Continuation of 301L. Pre: 301/301L, or consent. Co-requisite: 302.
metadata: DY John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Advanced Anatomy and Physiology (4)
desc: Continuation of 301. Pre: 301/301L or consent.
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Human Anatomy and Physiology Lab (1)
desc: Laboratory study of human anatomy and physiology by means of models, histology slides, experiments, and demonstrations. Co-requisite: 301 or consent.
metadata: DY John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Advanced Anatomy and Physiology (4)
desc: Integrated presentation of human anatomy and physiology. An optional laboratory (PHYL 301L) is available separately. Pre: BIOL 171 and BIOL 172, or any PHYL course; and CHEM 161 (or higher) or any BIOC course; or consent.
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Human Anatomy and Physiology Lab (1)
desc: Anatomy, histology, physiology, biochemistry, genetics of human organ systems presented in integrated anatomy-physiology format. Priority to students in nursing. Pre: 142 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DY John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Human Anatomy and Physiology (3)
desc: Continuation of 141. Pre: should have an understanding of basic physiology concepts as presented in 141 or equivalent.
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Human Anatomy and Physiology Lab (1)
desc: Anatomy, histology, physiology, biochemistry, genetics of human organ systems presented in integrated anatomy-physiology format. Priority to students in nursing. Pre: 141 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DY John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Human Anatomy and Physiology (3)
desc: Anatomy, histology, physiology, biochemistry, genetics of human organ systems presented in integrated anatomy-physiology format. Priority to students in nursing. Pre: high school chemistry.
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Physiology and Anatomy Lab (1)
desc: Laboratory to complement 103. Co-requisite: 103.
metadata: DY John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYL
title: Human Physiology and Anatomy (5)
desc: Introduction to human physiology and anatomy designed to serve the needs of dental hygiene students and others interested in pursuing health-related careers.
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Physiology (PHYL)

subject: PHYS
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Solid-State Theory (3)
desc: Crystal symmetry, electronic excitations in solids, transport theory, optical properties, cohesive energy, lattice vibrations, electron-phonon interaction, magnetism, superconductivity. Pre: 785. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Solid-State Theory (3)
desc: Crystal symmetry, electronic excitations in solids, transport theory, optical properties, cohesive energy, lattice vibrations, electron-phonon interaction, electron-electron interaction, magnetism, superconductivity. Pre: 670. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Nuclear and Particle Physics II (3)
desc: Quantum chromodynamics; electroweak interactions; the standard model. Techniques of particle physics. Pre: 777 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Nuclear and Particle Physics (3)
desc: Nuclear physics; electrodynamics; hadron structure and partons. Techniques of particle physics. Pre: 481 and 671. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Field Theory II (3)
desc: Local gauge invariance, Yang-Mills theory: quantum chromodynamics, spontaneous symmetry breaking and Goldstone bosons; the standard electroweak theory; grand unified theories. Pre: 772. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Field Theory I (3)
desc: Relativistic wave equations and their solutions. Dirac’s theory of the electron, propagator techniques. Applications to quantum electrodynamics. Pre: 671. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Statistical Physics II (3)
desc: Nonequilibrium thermodynamics, transport theory, fluctuation dissipation theorem, many-body Green’s function methods, normal Fermi and Bose liquids, superfluidity, superconductivity. Pre: 670 and 730. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Statistical Physics I (3)
desc: Equilibrium thermodynamics; Gibbs ensembles; quantum statistics; ideal and non-ideal Fermi; Bose and Boltzmann gases; phase transitions; and critical phenomena. Pre: 670. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Advanced Topics in Condensed Matter Theory (3)
desc: Topics in condensed matter theory, e.g., group theory, many-body techniques, renormalization group, density functional theory, other topics of current interest. Repeatable four times. Pre: 670 and consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Special Topics: Experimental Physics (3)
desc: Topics in current experimental research in low-energy physics, high-energy physics, cross-disciplinary physics. Repeatable in different topics. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Topics in Particles and Fields (3)
desc: Topics in current theoretical research; e.g., unified field theories, general relativity, gravitation, and cosmology. Repeatable four times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Seminar on Elementary Particle Physics (1)
desc: Reports and discussion on recent developments in elementary particle physics. Repeatable four times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Seminar on Atomic and Solid-State Physics (1)
desc: Reports and discussion on recent developments in atomic, surface, and solid-state physics. Repeatable five times with consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Condensed Matter Seminar (1)
desc: Results and discussions of current topics in condensed matter physics. Repeatable six times with consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Seminar (V)
desc: Discussions and reports on physical theory and recent developments. CR/NC only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Mechanics (3)
desc: Physical basis and formulation of quantum theory. Exact solutions of Schroedinger equation and their applications. Approximation methods. Applications to atomic, nuclear, and molecular physics. Pre: 670.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Mechanics (3)
desc: Physical basis and formulation of quantum theory. Exact solutions of Schroedinger equation and their applications. Approximation methods. Applications to atomic, nuclear, and molecular physics. Pre: 400 or 481 or 600 and MATH 402.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Advanced Optics (3)
desc: Contemporary advanced applications in optics including nonlinear optics and optical parametric oscillators, atomic lasers and laser systems, and free-electron lasers. Pre: 460. (Alt. even years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Electrodynamics II (3)
desc: Relativistic electrodynamics, radiation by charged particles. Pre: 650. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Electrodynamics I (3)
desc: Potential theory, Maxwell’s equations, electromagnetic waves, boundary value problems. Pre: 450; and 600 (or concurrent), or MATH 402. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Analytical Mechanics (3)
desc: Dynamics of particles, particle systems; rigid bodies; Lagrangian and Hamiltonian equations; special relativity. Pre: 600 (or concurrent); or MATH 402.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Methods of Theoretical Physics (3)
desc: Mathematical tools of theoretical physics. Continuation of 400 but with an independent selection of topics. Pre: 400 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Physics Workshop for Teachers (V)
desc: Major concepts of physics taught by means of hands-on conceptual activities for elementary and secondary teachers. Restricted to in-service teachers, or consent. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as NSCI 505)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Modern Physics (3)
desc: Introduction to nuclear and elementary-particle physics. Pre: 480 (or concurrent).
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Professional Ethics for Physicists (1)
desc: Student seminar on ethical principles and their application to research in physics and astronomy and closely-related fields. Historical examples will be presented and discussed by the participants. PHYS, ASTP, and ASTR majors only. A-F only. Pre: 310 or ASTR 300 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Advanced Physics Laboratory II (2)
desc: Advanced experiments involving measurement of the muon lifetime, crystal x-ray diffraction, nuclear magnetic resonance, the Mössbauer effect, and numerical simulations. Development of professional writing skills; preparation of formal reports in style of scientific journal articles. Pre: 274L, 480, and 480L; or consent.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Mechanics II (3)
desc: Continuation of 480; atomic physics, scattering, perturbation theory. Pre: 480.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Advanced Physics Laboratory I (2)
desc: Advanced experiments involving nuclear spectroscopy, angular correlations in positronium annihilation, optical polarization, chaos, measurement of speed of light, numerical simulations. Development of professional writing skills; preparation of formal reports in style of scientific journal articles. Pre: 274L and 480 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Mechanics I (3)
desc: Wave mechanics, Schroedinger equation, angular momenta, potential problems. Pre: 274, 310, 350, 400 (or concurrent); either MATH 244 or 253A; and either MATH 311 or 307; or consent.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Modern Electronics for Physicists (3)
desc: Introduction to high performance solid state instrumentation by means of practical research electronics: printed circuit board design/fabrication; complex programmable logic design/verification; integrated circuit SPICE simulation. Detector fabrication and test emphasis during final project. Pre: 475 (or equivalent) or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Electronics for Physicists (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Investigation of Kirchoff’s Laws, electromagnetic circuit theory. Fourier analysis and stability theory with circuits. Applications to physical measurements are stressed. A-F only. Pre: junior standing, and 152L or 272L.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Physical Optics (3)
desc: Fundamentals of classical physical optics emphasizing linear systems theory, including optical fields in matter, polarization phenomena, temporal coherence, interference and diffraction (Fourier optics). Specialized applications include Gaussian beams, laser resonators, pulse propagation, and nonlinear optics. Pre: 450 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C) or ECE 372 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C-), or consent. (Cross-listed as ECE 470)
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Electromagnetic Waves (3)
desc: Field equations, plane, spherical and guided waves. Pre: 350.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Solid-State Physics II (3)
desc: Energy-band calculations, optical processes, Josephson effect, theories of dielectrics and magnetism, physics of color centers, order-disorder transformation. Pre: 440.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Solid-State Physics I (3)
desc: Crystal structure: lattice vibrations; phonon effects; electronic processes in solids (metals, semiconductors, and superconductors). Pre: 274 and 350 (or concurrent).
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics (3)
desc: Laws of thermodynamics, heat transfer, kinetic theory, statistical mechanics. Pre: 274 and MATH 244 or MATH 253A.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Applications of Mathematics in Physical Sciences (3)
desc: Mathematical methods, techniques; applications to problems in physical sciences. Pre: MATH 244 or MATH 253A, and MATH 307 or 311; or consent. Recommended: upper division mathematics course.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Individual Work in Advanced Physics (V)
desc: Limited to students with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in physics.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Electricity and Magnetism (3)
desc: Electrostatic and magnetostatic fields in vacuum and in matter; induction; Maxwell’s equations; AC circuits. Pre: 272 or 272A; and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). (Fall only)
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Theoretical Mechanics II (3)
desc: Rigid-body mechanics continued, fluid dynamics, wave motion, theory of relativity. Pre: 310.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Theoretical Mechanics I (3)
desc: Particle dynamics, rigid-body dynamics, planetary motion. Pre: 170 or 170A; 272 or 272A; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). Recommended: MATH 302 (or concurrent). (Fall only)
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Computational Physics (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr. Lab) Analysis of physical systems and problem solving using computers and numerical methods. Development of scientific writing skills; preparation of formal reports in style of scientific journal articles. Pre: 152 or 272 or 272A, and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics III Lab (2)
desc: (1 4-hr Lab) Experiments illustrating selected concepts of 274, including diffraction and interference of light, wave nature of matter, photoelectric effect, atomic spectra, and semiconductors. Pre: 152L or 272L, and 274 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics III (3)
desc: Relativity, introduction to quantum mechanics, atomic and nuclear physics, and physical optics. Pre: 152 or 272 and MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics II Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Similar to 152L but at 272 level. Pre: 151L or 170L, and 272 (or concurrent) or 272A (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Honors General Physics II (3)
desc: Special format for topics: electricity and magnetism and geometric optics. A-F only. Pre: 151 or 170 and MATH 242 or MATH 252A, MATH 216 may be substituted with consent. Co-requisite: 272L.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics II (3)
desc: Electricity and magnetism and geometric optics. Pre: 151 or 170 and MATH 242 or MATH 252A, MATH 216 may be substituted with consent.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics I Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Similar to 151L but at 170 level. Pre: 170 (or concurrent) or 170A (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Honors General Physics I (4)
desc: Special format for topics: mechanics of particles and rigid bodies, wave motion, thermodynamics and kinetic theory. Pre: MATH 242 (or concurrent) or MATH 252A (or concurrent). MATH 216 may be substituted with consent. Co-requisite: 170L
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics I (4)
desc: Calculus-based mechanics of particles and rigid bodies: kinematics, force, energy, momentum, rotation, gravitation, fluids, oscillations and waves. Intended for physical science and engineering majors. Pre: MATH 242 (or concurrent) or MATH 252A (or concurrent). MATH 216 may be substituted with consent.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: College Physics Lab II (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Optics, electric and magnetic fields, DC and AC circuitry. Pre: 151L or 170L, and 152 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: College Physics II (3)
desc: Electricity, magnetism, optics, modern physics. Pre: 151 or 170.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: College Physics Lab I (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to experimental analysis, physical observation and measurement, experiments on conservation laws, fluid friction, oscillations. Pre: 151 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: College Physics I (3)
desc: Non-calculus physics. Mechanics, wave motion, heat. Pre: MATH 140X, or 215 or higher; or qualifying score on math placement exam.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: How Things Work: Physics for Everyday Life (3)
desc: Introduction to physics and science in everyday life. It considers objects from our daily environment, and focuses on the principles such as motion, forces, heat, electromagnetism, optics, and modern physics. A-F only.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Physics in the Arts (3)
desc: Introduction to physics of sound and light, with applications to music and visual arts: sound perception, harmony, musical scales, instruments; lenses, cameras, color perception and mixing. Uses algebra and geometry. Intended primarily for non-science majors.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Survey of Physics Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Hooke’s law, falling bodies, collisions, Boyle’s law, electric and magnetic fields, induction, waves, optics. Pre: 100 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHYS
title: Survey of Physics (3)
desc: Mechanics, electricity and magnetism, waves, optics, atomic and nuclear physics. Only algebra and geometry used. For non-science majors.
metadata: DP College of Natural Sciences Physics (PHYS)

subject: PHIL
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Comparative Philosophy (3)
desc: Comparison of widely differing philosophical traditions. Specific topic changes each semester. Consult department for more information. Repeatable two times with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Japanese Philosophy (3)
desc: Various periods, movements, and thinkers in Japanese philosophy. Topic changes each semester. Consult department for more information. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 380.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Yi Jing (3)
desc: Metaphysical, epistemological, ethical, and axiological views of Yi Jing and its claim as foundational work for classical Confucianism, Daoism, and Neo-Confucianism. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Chinese Philosophy (3)
desc: Fundamental issues, problems, movements, and schools of Chinese philosophy, such as classical Confucianism, Daoism, Legalism, Chinese logic, and Neo-Confucianism. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 370.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Buddhist Philosophy (3)
desc: Major philosophical problems in the development of Buddhist thought during its formative period. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 360.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Indian Philosophy (3)
desc: Major philosophical problems in the development of Indian thought during its formative period. Repeatable two times with consent of instructor and Graduate Chair. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 350.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Philosophical Texts (3)
desc: Reading, analysis, and critical discussion of one (or of several closely related) philosophical text in its original language (sometimes in conjunction with established translation). Repeatable two times with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar on Philosophical Periods (3)
desc: Close study of a period of significant and connected philosophical activity within a philosophic tradition. Repeatable two times with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Islamic Philosophy (3)
desc: Major philosophical problems in Islamic thought. Focus either on a specific topic or one author. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Philosophical Topics (3)
desc: Close study of a topic of important philosophical controversy. Repeatable two times in the MA program; an additional three times in the PhD program. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Seminar on Individual Philosophers (3)
desc: The most significant texts of an important philosopher. Repeatable three times in the MA program; an additional four times in the PhD program. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to six credits. Pre: master’s Plan A candidate and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to 30 credits. Pre: graduate standing and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Daoism (3)
desc: Critical examination and evaluation of major philosophical ideas in Lao Zi, Zhuang Zi, and the Neo-Daoists. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 370.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Neo-Confucianism (3)
desc: Logic, epistemology, metaphysics, and ethics of major Chinese Neo-Confucian philosophers, 11th–16th century. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 370.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Confucianism (3)
desc: Ethical, social, institutional problems in classical theory. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 370.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: History and Theory of Science (3)
desc: Exploration of problems at the intersection of historical studies of science as a process and philosophical analysis of basic concepts of the sciences. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 308 or 316.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Studies in Hermeneutics (3)
desc: Important debates concerning the methodology of textual interpretation. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophical Foundations of Cultural Criticism (3)
desc: A survey of the philosophical texts, thinkers, concepts, and theoretical approaches that are used in cultural criticism. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Studies in Epistemology (3)
desc: Key issues in contemporary philosophical debates about knowledge. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 307.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Studies in Aesthetics (3)
desc: Key issues in contemporary aesthetics, against background of traditional Western and Eastern theories. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 306.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Studies in Philosophy of Religion (3)
desc: Key issues in theory of religious experience, language, reasoning. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 305.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Studies in Metaphysics (3)
desc: Key issues in ontological and cosmological theory. Problems of materialism, idealism, phenomenalism, etc. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 304.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Studies in Ethics (3)
desc: Key issues in contemporary philosophical debates about ethics. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 301.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Teaching Philosophy (3)
desc: Supervised work in elementary, middle, and high school classrooms, facilitating philosophical inquiry with students. Repeatable one time. Pre: 492 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy with Children (3)
desc: Experience theory and practice developing intellectually safe philosophical communities of inquiry in contexts from kindergarten through university and beyond. Pre: any course 200 or above in PHIL or EDUC, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Undergraduate Capstone (3)
desc: Capstone seminar for undergraduate majors. Concentration on a topic of current philosophical concern. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: declared major in PHIL with at least six courses 200 or above in PHIL, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Individual Philosophers/Topics (3)
desc: Examination of work of a major Eastern or Western philosopher, or topic of philosophical concern. Repeatable three times. Pre: 100, 101, 102, 103, 211, 212, 213, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Symbolic Logic (3)
desc: Intermediate-level course covering proof techniques for classical, first-order predicate calculus, and an introduction to meta-theory. Pre: 110 or any course 200 or above in ICS or MATH; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Gender and Environmental Philosophy (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary approach to feminist perspectives on environmental issues; critical analysis of eco-feminism as political movement with reference to race and coloniality; cross-cultural comparison of differently-imagined relationships to non-human others, with emphasis on ethics and writing. Pre: any course 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS or any course 200 or above with a DB or DP designation, or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 438)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Language (3)
desc: Contemporary theories in semantics and syntax; problems of meaning, reference, speech acts, etc. Pre: any course 200 or above in PHIL or LING, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophical Psychology (3)
desc: Classical and modern theories of mind, cognition, and action.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Feminist Issues in Philosophy (3)
desc: Examination of basic feminist issues in philosophy, and of responses to them. Pre: any course 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS, or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 419)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy in Literature (3)
desc: Philosophical themes in the literary mode in world literature.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: (Alpha) Western Movements and Periods (3)
desc: (B) Greek; (C) late antiquity; (D) medieval; (E) Renaissance; (F) continental rationalism; (G) British empiricism; (H) German idealism; (I) 19th century; (J) 20th century. Repeatable two times in different alphas, not in same alpha. Pre: any course 200 or above in PHIL, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Zen (Ch’an) Buddhist Philosophy (3)
desc: Development and philosophical significance of basic precepts, explored through translations of Chinese and Japanese sources.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Phenomenology (3)
desc: Methods of analyzing the structures of experience, as developed by Husserl, Heidegger, Merleau-Ponty, Sartre, etc.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to a maximum of 6 credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Japanese Philosophy (3)
desc: Survey of central thinkers and schools from ancient to modern. Pre: 21 credits.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Chinese Philosophy (3)
desc: Survey of important schools and thinkers in classical Chinese traditions: Confucianism, Daoism, Mohism, Legalism. A significant emphasis will be placed on developing the ability to write clearly, critically, and coherently.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Buddhist Philosophy (3)
desc: Survey of central thinkers and schools. (Cross-listed as ASAN 360)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Indian Philosophy (3)
desc: Survey of major orthodox and heterodox systems: Vedas, Upanishads, Bhagavadgita, Vedanta, Jainism, Buddhism. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL or PALI or SNSK; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Islamic Philosophy (3)
desc: Survey of major Islamic philosophers and schools. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL or ARAB, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: American Philosophy (3)
desc: Survey of major philosophers and schools in development of American thought up to modern times. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Ethical Issues in the Law (3)
desc: Exploration of ethical issues that have come before (mainly U.S.) courts, including but not confined to, medical and criminal justice ethics. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 101 or a course numbered 200 or above in PHIL or HIST or ENG or with a DS designation; or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Law (3)
desc: Historical and contemporary issues in law and legal theory. Law and morality; legal responsibility, justice, rights, punishment, judicial reasoning. Pre: any course 101 or above in PHIL or above 100 in BLAW or POLS or SOC, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Critical Thinking: Pre-Law (3)
desc: Introduction to concepts and techniques for evaluating arguments with special emphasis on their application both to questions of law and to issues in jurisprudence. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL or POLS or SOC, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Science, Technology, and Society (3)
desc: Investigation of some of the complex interconnections between science, technology, and society. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL or in a course with either DB or DP or DS designation, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: The Role of Models in Global Environmental Science (3)
desc: Introduction to philosophy of science for those with some background in the natural sciences. Special emphasis on issues arising from the construction and use of models. Pre: any course 200 or above in PHIL or any course 200 or above with either DB or DP designation, or consent. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as OCN 315)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Critical Thinking: Pre-Medicine (3)
desc: Scientific and social perspectives on the nature of disease and their impact on medical practice. Exploration of these topics through reading, writing and critical inquiry. Pre: any course in PHIL, 100 or above; or any two BIOL, CHEM or PHYS courses; or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy and Evolution (3)
desc: Explores the ethical and epistemological implications of the theory of evolution. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Ethics in Practice (3)
desc: Team-taught exploration of five contemporary ethical issues using a variety of philosophical approaches and methods. Pre: any 101 course or above in PHIL or above 100 in POLS or SOC; or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy and Aesthetics of Film (3)
desc: Aesthetics and ontology of film and video, based on readings in the philosophy of film and the viewing of a number of films per semester.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Ethics in Health Care (3)
desc: Ethical issues in application and organization of biomedical resources; professional responsibility, confidentiality, euthanasia, experimentation on human subjects, etc. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL or MED or NURS or with a DB designation; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Science (3)
desc: Problems and methods. Domains of inquiry, methods of validation, and attendant moral concerns. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL, or 200 or above with either DB or DP designation; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Theory of Knowledge (3)
desc: Problems and methods in epistemology. Nature of knowledge, its varieties, possibilities, and limitations. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL, or 200 or above with either DB or DP or DS designation; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Art (3)
desc: Problems and methods in aesthetic valuation and in appreciation, creation, and criticism of artworks.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Religion (3)
desc: Problems and methods. Nature of religious experience, alternatives to theism, existence of god, relation between faith and reason, nature of religious language.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Metaphysics (3)
desc: Problems arising from attempts to categorize rationally what is, and what appears to be. Among others, topics may include universals and particulars, personal identity, freedom and determinism, and time. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Social Philosophy (3)
desc: Problems and methods in examination of contemporary life, values, and institutions in light of traditional philosophical problems of freedom, justice, authority, equality. Pre: any course 101 or above in PHIL or above 100 in POLS or SOC, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Political Philosophy (3)
desc: Problems and methods in philosophical theories of political legitimacy. Pre: any course 101 or above in PHIL or above 100 in POLS or SOC, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Ethical Theory (3)
desc: Problems and methods in theory of moral conduct and decision. Pre: any course 101 or above in PHIL or above 100 in POLS or SOC; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Business Ethics (3)
desc: Case studies and critical analyses of ethical issues in business. Readings from business, philosophy, law, etc. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL or BUS or BLAW, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Women Philosophers (3)
desc: Introduces students to the ideas of women philosophers. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL or WGSS, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as WGSS 219)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Modern Philosophy (3)
desc: Introduction to the history of philosophy based on texts or translations of “modern” works, that is works originally written in a modern European language.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Medieval to Enlightenment Philosophy (3)
desc: Introduction to the history of philosophy based on translations of texts originally written by men and women in post-classical Latin and Arabic. Significant attention is paid to developing writing skills.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Ancient Philosophy (3)
desc: An introduction to the history of philosophy based on translations of texts originally written in classical Greek or Latin.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to World Philosophy II (3)
desc: Philosophy attempts to understand the human being and the societies they form. Introduces students to the notion of world philosophy, focusing upon thinkers who have helped to shape our present. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: FGB College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to World Philosophy I (3)
desc: Introduction to philosophy as it has manifested itself differently across cultures throughout the world. Focus on the development of philosophical thought from its beginnings up until 1500 CE.A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: FGA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Inductive Logic (3)
desc: Introduction to the theory of arguments based on probabilities and to the theory of decision-making in the context of uncertainty. A-F only.
metadata: FQ College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Deductive Logic (3)
desc: Principles of modern deductive logic.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy: Environmental Philosophy (3)
desc: A critical examination of environmental issues; analyzing the nature of the human being, the nature of nature, and the relationship of the human being to nature.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Asian Traditions (3)
desc: Universal themes and problems from Asian perspective.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy: Morals and Society (3)
desc: Philosophical attempts to evaluate conduct, character, and social practices. DH
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy: Survey of Problems (3)
desc: Introduction to the kinds of problems that concern philosophers and to some of the solutions that have been attempted.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Philosophy (PHIL)

subject: PHRM
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: Neuropharmacology (2)
desc: Physiology and pharmacology of central and peripheral nervous systems, focusing on synaptic chemistry and signaling. A-F only. Pre: CMB 606, or consent from the course director. (Cross-listed as CMB 640)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: Systemic Pharmacology (9)
desc: Provides instruction at an organ systems/functional level covering major organ and functional systems of the human body. Concepts in pharmacological research at the animal, organ system and whole human level will also be considered. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: General Pharmacology (3)
desc: Pharmacodynamics, receptor theory, modeling, clinical trials and the FDA will be covered. Concepts in ADME/T and clinical research are also considered. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: Research in Pharmacology (V)
desc: Pharmacology research elective for medical students. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: MDED 551 or consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: Principles of Pharmacology (1)
desc: Pharmacology elective course for medical students. MD students only. CR/NC only. Pre: MDED 554 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: Selected Topics in Pharmacology (V)
desc: Elective for medical students in Pharmacology. Repeatable up to 12 credits. CR/NC only. Pre: MDED 551.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Directed reading and research in experimental pharmacology. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: General Pharmacology (3)
desc: Similar to 201 but wider in scope of drugs discussed. Intended for undergraduates in the health sciences and related fields. Pre: mammalian physiology.
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PHRM
title: Introduction to General Pharmacology (2)
desc: Drugs discussed with emphasis on sites and mechanism of action, toxicity, fate, and uses of major therapeutic agents. Pre: mammalian physiology and dental hygiene major.
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Pharmacology (PHRM)

subject: PER
title: Introduction to South/Southeast Asian Film, History, Theory and Appreciation (3)
desc: Study and analysis of South/Southeast Asian films–history, forms, development, theoretical framework and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical and aesthetic context. (C) Iranian. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as PER 368)
metadata: DH

subject: PED
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pediatrics (PED)

subject: PED
title: (Alpha) Electives in Pediatrics (V)
desc: Fourth-year elective in pediatric sub-specialty areas in which medical students may receive clinical experiences and an in-depth study of selected sub-specialty areas within the field of pediatrics. (B) adolescent medicine; (C) ambulatory pediatric care; (E) clinical genetics; (F) Sub-Internship in neonatology; (G) pediatric cardiology; (H) Sub-Internship in pediatric emergency medicine; (I) Sub-Internship in pediatric hematology/ oncology; (J) Sub-Internship in infectious diseases; (K) Sub-Internship in pediatrics–general ward in pediatrics; (M) extramural electives in pediatrics; (N) pediatric rheumatology; (P) developmental behavioral pediatrics; (Q) pediatric international preceptorship (3 cr.); (R) Sub-Internship in pediatric critical care;. (S) pediatric radiology; (T) pediatric ultrasound; (U) pediatric nephrology; (V) pediatric sports medicine. CR/NC only. Repeatable two times per alpha, up to 36 credits; not repeatable for (Q). Pre: 531 or 532.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pediatrics (PED)

subject: PED
title: Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship (5)
desc: Year-long clerkship in ambulatory setting, covering evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment of childhood diseases. Emphasis on primary prevention, normal growth and development of the neonate to adolescent, and arrangement of pediatric care, including outpatient, inpatient, and emergency room experiences. Repeatable two times. Pre: third-year standing and concurrent registration in 532 courses. Co-requisite: MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, and SURG 532.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pediatrics (PED)

subject: PED
title: Introduction to Research Methodology, Biostatistics, and Epidemiology (1)
desc: Interactive seminar series to cover the following topics: data types, descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, selecting a statistical test, data distributions, measures of data spread, statistical test assumptions, standard deviation vs. standard error, etc. Repeatable one time. Medical students only. CR/NC only. Pre: MDED 551.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pediatrics (PED)

subject: PED
title: Pediatric Seminars (1)
desc: Interactive weekly lecture/seminar designed to teach topics in pediatrics and supplemented by small group 2-hour encounters with faculty clinicians in pediatric emergency medicine, inpatient pediatric, and enonatology to gain exposure in pediatric hospital care. Repeatable one time. Medical students only. CR/NC only. Pre: MDED 551.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pediatrics (PED)

subject: PACE
title: Advanced Topics: Conflict Theory (3)
desc: Advanced seminar covering issues of policy and practice in peace and conflict management theory. Repeatable one time. Graduate standing only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to 9 credits. A-F only. Pre: departmental approval or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Conflict Resolution Practicum (V)
desc: Practice in conflict resolution skills. Open to candidates for Certificate in Conflict Resolution. Repeatable one time or up to three credits. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Topics: Conflict Theory (V)
desc: Recent issues of policy and practice in peace and conflict management theory. Repeatable up to 12 credits. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Facilitation: Facilitating Community and Organizational Change (3)
desc: Advanced conflict resolution course. Covers key issues in the prevention, management and resolution of multiparty conflicts. Combined lecture, discussion, and simulations. A-F only. Graduate students only or departmental approval. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as PLAN 668)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Family Mediation (3)
desc: Theory and skills for practicing divorce and custody mediation. Negotiation and conflict intervention skills used by social workers, lawyers, and other intervenors in family conflict. Focus on Hawai‘i’s divorce and custody laws and practices. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Conflict Management for Educators (3)
desc: Conflict resolution theory and practice for administrators, faculty and staff in educational organizations. K-12, community colleges and universities. Application and theory of negotiation, mediation, facilitation and hybrid ADR processes. Pre: EDEA 601 or EDEA 650, or consent. (Cross-listed as EDEA 652)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Dispute Resolution System Design (3)
desc: Conflict prevention, management and resolution in the workplace. Design and implementation of effective systems integrating ADR and recent advances in dispute resolution methodology to government, health, nonprofit, educational, private sector and other institutions. Pre: graduate standing, or departmental approval.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Mediation: Theory and Practice (3)
desc: Combined lecture, discussion, and mediation simulations. Theory of ADR field. Theory of major different models of mediation, both in the U.S. and internationally. Application of mediation process to categories of disputes, family, workplace, and international. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing, or departmental approval. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Seminar: Social Studies (3)
desc: Study in trends, research, and problems of implementation in teaching field. Repeatable two times. Pre: teaching experience or consent.(Cross-listed as EDCS 640K)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Gender: Law and Conflicts (V)
desc: Examines how international law and domestic legal systems address and resolve conflicts regarding women’s rights, gender roles, and gender identity. Takes a comparative approach with emphasis on the Asia-Pacific region. (Cross-listed as LAW 547 and WGSS 647)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Negotiation & Conflict Resolution (3)
desc:
Negotiation as a foundational skill of conflict resolution; 
mastery of negotiation skills for strategic dispute resolution; non-routine problem-solving, creating partnerships and alliances; crafting optimal agreements. Students participate in simulations and acquire vital leadership skills. Graduate standing only. Pre: one of the following courses with a minimum grade of B: 429, 447, 477, 647, 652, or 668; or PLAN 627; or COMG 455 or SOC 730; or LAW 508; or MGT 660. (Cross-listed as PLAN 629)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Environmental Conflict Resolution (3)
desc: Explore how environmental conflicts emerge and the efforts to find common ground for resolution. Examine the issues, debates, and theoretical aspects that help to explain and frame environmental conflict. Graduate students only. (Cross-listed as PLAN 621)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Practicum and Internship (3)
desc: The practicum and internship in Peace and Conflict Resolution provides an opportunity for students to apply the skills and concepts learned in earlier courses. Pre: any two other PACE courses or consent. (Cross-listed as PUBA 495)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Hiroshima & Peace (3)
desc: 10-day intensive course at Hiroshima City University, Japan, in the 2-weeks before the annual August 6 commemoration of the atomic bombing. Home-stay with Japanese family. Sophomore standing. A-F only. Pre: any 200 level social science course, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Topics in Peace and Conflict Resolution (3)
desc: Recent issues, practices in peace and conflict resolution. Repeatable one time. Pre: any DS course, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Managing Human Conflict (3)
desc: Introduction into the field of conflict analysis and resolution through the examination of theory and role-play. Major theories of conflict studies are considered and the forms of conflict resolution, such as negotiation, mediation, and arbitration. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: any 200-level DS course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: International Law and Disputes (3)
desc: Management, prevention, resolution of international disputes and the role of international law. Pre: any Social Science 100 or 200 level course, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Culture and Conflict Resolution (3)
desc: Conflict resolution techniques for major world culture. Emphasis on cultures of the Pacific Basin, Pacific Islands, and Asia. Pre: any DS course, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Advocating for Children: Rights and Welfare (3)
desc: Multi-disciplinary advocacy for children’s rights and welfare in various social and political systems; the role of families, justice, economics, media, race, culture, environment on policy-making for children. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: any 200-level DS course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Introduction to Facilitating Organizational Change (3)
desc: Explores the characteristics of organizations from different perspectives including structural, political, ethical, and cultural frames from organizational theory and practice. Focuses on how to design organizational change strategies and facilitate their implementation. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: any 200-level DS course (with a minimum grade of C+).
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Indigenous Nonviolent Action in the Asia-Pacific (3)
desc: Study of nonviolent methods (i.e., United Nations structures, international law, boycotts, and peaceful protest) used to gain political goals and examines their successes, failures, and the prospects for those that remain ongoing. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: any 200-level DS course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Protest Under Occupation (3)
desc: Explore nonviolent protests when one Independent State controls the territory of another Independent State (or international organization, such as the United Nations), without the transfer of sovereign title. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: any 200-level DS course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Introduction to Mediation (3)
desc: Learn the core components of the mediation process and the tools for empowering mediation participants to reach customized resolutions. Emphasis on learning and applying the skills through exercises and mock mediation sessions.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Geography of Peace and War (3)
desc: Geographical factors underlying conflict in the world. Pre: sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as GEO 436)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Leadership for Social Change (3)
desc: In-depth study of current models and emerging theories of ethical leadership in community service; development of tangible leadership skills, including communication, conflict resolution, team-building, and management skills. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: any 200-level DS course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Negotiation (3)
desc: Negotiation theory, negotiation skills and application of negotiation in conflict prevention, conflict management and conflict resolution with an emphasis on oral communication and contemporary ethical issues. Pre: any Social Science 100 or 200 level course, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Introduction to Human Rights: International and Comparative Perspectives (3)
desc: Introduction to international, regional, and domestic human rights law; comparative perspectives on the theoretical origins of human rights and policy debates on the protection of human rights, dispute resolution, and enforcement mechanisms. Pre: any 100 or 200 level social sciences course, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Terrorism (3)
desc: Multidisciplinary approach to the origins, dynamics, and consequences of international terrorism, including the psychological, legal, ethical and operational concerns of counterterrorism. Pre: any 200-level DS course, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Gandhi, King, and Nonviolence (3)
desc: Life and thought of Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King, Jr. Pre: any Social Science 100 or 200 level course, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: History of Peace Movements (3)
desc: Examination of two centuries of U.S., European, Australian, and Hawaiian peace, thought, and action. Also surveys early Christian and secular attitudes to war. Open to nonmajors. Pre: any DS course, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Peace Processes in Philippines and Hawai‘i (3)
desc: History of Philippine Islam and the Moro struggle, the peace process in Mindanao and sovereignty movement for Hawaiian nation. 75 min. Lec, 75-min. joint online discussion with Philippine students. Junior standing only. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as ASAN 407)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Directed reading in peace and conflict resolution. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Nonviolent Political Alternatives (3)
desc: Exploration of scientific and cultural resources for nonviolent alternatives in politics. Pre: any 100- or 200-level POLS course; or consent. (Cross-listed as POLS 396)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Aggression, War, and Peace (3)
desc: Biocultural, evolutionary, and cross-cultural perspectives on the conditions, patterns, and processes of violence, war, nonviolence, and peace. Pre: ANTH 152. (Cross-listed as ANTH 345)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Personal Peace: Stories of Hope (3)
desc: Interviewing, writing, and publishing stories of those who have overcome great difficulties to find personal peace. Pre: grade of B or better in ENG 100 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Survey Peace and Conflict Studies (3)
desc: Survey of basic concepts, ethical relationships, methods, and debates in modern peace research and the oral skills needed for conflict resolution studies. Pre: any social science 100- or 200-level course or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: The Meaning of War (3)
desc: Exploration of ethical questions related to the many facets of war–e.g., patriotism, tribalism, holy war, self-sacrifice, cowardice, media coverage, propaganda, torture, genocide, pillage, suicide tactics, battlefield immunity. (Cross-listed as PHIL 387)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PACE
title: Survey of Conflict Management (3)
desc: Survey of contemporary conflict management and resolution: negotiation, mediation, conciliation, ombuds, fact-finding, facilitation techniques, arbitration, and litigation. Pre: any social science 100- or 200-level course or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Peace Studies (PACE)

subject: PATH
title: Electives in Pathology (V)
desc: Individualized instruction in clinical and/or anatomic pathology. Third-year elective. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pathology (PATH)

subject: PATH
title: Introduction to Pathology and Laboratory Medicine (1)
desc: Provides an introduction to the practice of pathology and laboratory medicine and the role pathologists and the laboratory play in the diagnosis and management of disease. MD students only. CR/NC only. Pre: MDED 554 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pathology (PATH)

subject: PATH
title: (Alpha) Unit VII Electives in Pathology (V)
desc: Individualized instruction in laboratory medicine for the practicing physician, clinical and anatomic pathology: (B) advanced topics in clinical immunology; (C) anatomic pathology; (D) clinical pathology; (E) pathologic aspects of aging, nutrition, and/or alcoholism; (F) extramural elective in pathology. Repeatable four times. CR/NC only. Pre: BIOM 555.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pathology (PATH)

subject: PATH
title: Pathology Practicum (V)
desc: Required autopsy experience involving dissection and microscopic examination of tissues and detailed evaluation of disease process. CR/NC only. Pre: third-or fourth-year standing.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pathology (PATH)

subject: PATH
title: Unit V Block Elective (V)
desc: Required elective for second-year medical students, objectives to be determined by contract. One option is a review of USMLE Part I. CR/NC only. Pre: BIOM 551.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pathology (PATH)

subject: PATH
title: Unit V Concurrent Elective (1)
desc: Elective course for second-year medical students. CR/NC only. Pre: BIOM 551 and consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pathology (PATH)

subject: PATH
title: Unit II Concurrent Elective (1)
desc: Elective course for first-year medical students. CR/NC only. Pre: BIOM 551 and consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pathology (PATH)

subject: PATH
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Pathology of aging, nutrition, alcoholism, and immunology. Open to selected undergraduate students. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pathology (PATH)

subject: PATH
title: Immunopathology Seminar (1)
desc: Autoimmune diseases and transplantation immunity. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Pathology (PATH)

subject: PALI
title: Intermediate Pali II (3)
desc: Continuation of 481.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Pali (PALI)

subject: PALI
title: Intermediate Pali I (3)
desc: Continuation of 382. Reading various Hinayâna texts. Pre: 382.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Pali (PALI)

subject: PALI
title: Elementary Pali II (3)
desc: Continuation of 381.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Pali (PALI)

subject: PALI
title: Elementary Pali I (3)
desc: Reading simple texts from Pali canon. Grammar taught as needed for the reading. Pre: SNSK 182 or equivalent).
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Pali (PALI)

subject: PACS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Master’s Portfolio Project (V)
desc: Independent study for students working on MA portfolio projects. A grade of satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in PACS.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Graduate Seminar: Change in the Pacific (3)
desc: Interrelationship of change in selected Pacific Islands regions, institutions, and processes. Repeatable two times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Women in Oceania (3)
desc: Will look at feminist theory, ethnography, culture, activism and globalization in the context of writing, research and film on or by Women in Oceania. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Researching Oceania: Creative and Conventional Methods of Inquiry (3)
desc: Graduate seminar. Literacy, theory and method in the creation of a Master’s research project. Pre: 601 and 602.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Re/Presenting Oceania: Pacific and American Perspectives (3)
desc: Graduate seminar. Critical analysis of the way physical, social and cultural aspects of Oceania have been represented in scholarly and popular media. Co-requisite: 601.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Learning Oceania (3)
desc: Graduate seminar. Introduction to the nature and origins of Pacific Studies as an organized field of study. Epistemological, conceptual, political and ethical issues facing students of the region today. Co-requisite: 602.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Culture and Consumption in Oceania (3)
desc: Lecture on changing patterns of consumption in Oceania, and the historical, political, cultural, artistic, and economic forces shaping such practices. Pre: upper division standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Moving Images in the Pacific Islands (3)
desc: Critically examines indigenous and foreign representations of the Pacific Islands and is designed to make film a central focus of inquiry for students interested in the contemporary Pacific. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Topics in Pacific Islands Studies (3)
desc: Repeatable two times.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Studies in Hawaiian and/or Pacific Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, writers, movements, or genres in the field of Pacific literature. Repeatable one time. Pre: ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course. (Crosslisted as ENG 474)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Drama and Theatre of Oceania (3)
desc: Survey of the contemporary drama and theatre of Oceania that combines island and Western traditions. Includes Papua New Guinea, Hawai‘i, Fiji, Samoa, Australia, New Zealand. Pre: ANTH 350 or THEA 101, or consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 462)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Pacific Islander Collaborative Research (3)
desc: Engage in intensive collaborative research with a Pacific Islander community in Hawaiʻi, culminating in a research paper and public presentation. Oral communication is an essential component of this course. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to 12 credits.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Pacific Islands Studies (PACS)

subject: PACS
title: Literature of the Pacific (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the literature of the Pacific, including Pacific voyagers and contemporary writings in English by Pacific Islanders. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as ENG 371)
