metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Music (MUS)

subject: MUS
title: Fundamentals of Music (3)
desc: Basic organization concepts in music and introduction to music theory. Learning through hands-on experience with creative activities in various media. Focused listening, composing original meolodies, utilizing technology to explore how music is created, basic notation.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Music (MUS)

subject: MUS
title: Music in World Cultures (3)
desc: Folk, popular, and art music from major regions of the world, with emphasis upon Asia and the Pacific; representative styles and regional characteristics.
metadata: FGB College of Arts, Languages & Letters Music (MUS)

subject: MUS
title: Introduction to Music Literature (3)
desc: Elements, styles, and forms of music, from listener’s standpoint.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Music (MUS)

subject: MCB
title: Bacterial Genetics Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Techniques for study of transfer and expression of prokaryotic genes: transformation, conjugation, transposon mutagenesis, preparation and analysis of plasmid and chromosomal DNA. Pre: 475 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as MICR 475L)
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: MCB
title: Bacterial Genetics (3)
desc: Genetic analysis and molecular basis of transmission replication, mutation, and expression of heritable characteristics in prokaryotes. Pre: MICR 351 or BIOL 275, or consent. (Cross-listed as MICR 475)
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: MCB
title: The Biology of Cancer (3)
desc: Integrative, in-depth focus on the genetics, cell biology, and molecular basis of cancer. Combination of classroom lectures and problem-based discussions in small groups. Addresses ethical implications of cancer research and treatment. A-F only. MCB or BIOL majors only. Senior standing or higher. Pre: BIOL 407 (or concurrent) and BIOL 408 (or concurrent) or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as BIOL 472)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: MCB
title: Immunology Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Basic exercises and experiments in immunology, immunochemistry, immuno-biology to illustrate principles of 461. Pre: 461 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as MICR 461L)
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: MCB
title: Immunology (3)
desc: Structure and biological actions of antigens and antibodies; fundamentals of antibody synthesis; the relation of immunology to biology and medical sciences. Pre: MICR 351 or BIOL 171; or consent. Recommended: BIOL 275/275L. (Cross-listed as MICR 461)
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: MCB
title: Advanced Molecular and Cellular Biology Laboratory (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) A laboratory to accompany 407 and 408. Pre: BIOL 407 (or concurrent) or BIOL 408 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as BIOL 408L)
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: MCB
title: Molecular Cellular Biology II (3)
desc: Cell structure and function. Structure, chemistry, and functions of organelles and macromolecules. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 407; or consent. (Cross-listed as BIOL 408 and MBBE 408)
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: MCB
title: Molecular Cell Biology I (3)
desc: Relationship between structure and function at macromolecular level. Pre: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275/275L and CHEM 273, or consent. (Cross-listed as BIOL 407)
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: MCB
title: Research Ethics (1)
desc: Introduction to the ethical issues faced by individuals and institutions involved in scientific research. Based on case studies, students will discuss and write about ethical issues in research. Issues include humans and animals in research, mentoring, authorship, ownership of data, genetic technologies and record keeping. This course is designed for students with majors in the natural sciences. A-F only. Pre: BIOL 171 (or concurrent), or MATH 307 (or concurrent), or MATH 311 (or concurrent), or PHYS 170 (or concurrent), or CHEM 272 (or concurrent); or consent. (Cross-listed as MICR 314)
metadata: DS College of Natural Sciences Molecular and Cell Biology (MCB)

subject: MBBE
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to 64 credits.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Advanced Special Topics in MBBE (V)
desc: Study and discussion of advanced special topics and problems in molecular biosciences and bioengineering. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Advanced Lab Techniques (1)
desc: (1 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Advanced laboratory techniques used in food science and human nutrition research. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent and 402/402L, and FSHN 477; or BIOC 441. (Cross-listed as ANSC 687 and FSHN 687)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Advanced Bioinformatics Topics for Biologists (4)
desc: Teaches problem-solving with bioinformatic tools. Real-world problems will be provided and worked out, students encouraged to provide their own research problem where they require assistance. Graduate student must work on genomics research project requiring bioinformatic analysis, working knowledge of UNIX OS, Perl, Java or C. A-F only. Pre: (ICS 471 and ICS 491 and ICS 691 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Methods in Plant Molecular Biology (3)
desc: (1 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Advanced methodology and research strategies. Hands-on laboratory training in basic and current molecular procedures for plant research. Pre: one of BIOC 481 or BIOL 407.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Molecular Plant–Fungal Interactions (3)
desc: Focuses on the actions of plant pathogenic fungi/ oomycetes and their host responses at the molecular and cellular level. Current genetic and genomic approaches to study plant-fungal interactions will be discussed. Graduate standing only. Pre: consent. (Every 2 years) (Cross-listed as PEPS 652)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Signal Transduction and Regulation of Gene Transcription (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion on molecular mechanisms involved in the transmission of regulatory signals from the cell surface to the nucleus. A-F only. Pre: undergraduate level biochemistry, molecular biology, biology, nutrition; or override/ consent by professor. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: DNA and Genetic Analysis (3)
desc: Combined lecture-lab for students interested in genetic analysis of humans, animals, and other species. Molecular techniques, such as PCR, DNA marker identifications, transgenics, expression analysis and functional genomics, are included. Open to non-majors. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Cross-listed as ANSC 650 and FSHN 650)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Biological Instrumentation (3)
desc: System integration for computer-based control, automation, and study of biological systems. Topics include physical, chemical, and biological sensors, actuators, digital interfacing/communication, image analysis, and structured code for microcontrollers and other portable computers. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as BE 625)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Metabolic Engineering (4)
desc: Principles and methodologies of metabolic engineering. Concepts of metabolic networks. Establishment of metabolic flux analysis and metabolic control analysis. Systems biology framework for integration of mathematical modeling and global measurements at metabolite, protein and transcription levels. Pre: BIOL 275, MATH 311, and MICR 351; or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Plant Biochemistry (3)
desc: Comprehensive study of chemical constituents and biochemical processes unique to the plant kingdom with emphasis on selected aspects of current interest. A-F only. Pre: 402 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Molecular Biosciences Seminar (1)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems in plant physiology, biochemistry, and molecular biology. Repeatable three times. A-F only
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Advanced Food Science I (3)
desc: Advanced topics in chemical and physical characteristics of foods as well as their role in human nutrition. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: graduate student status with undergraduate courses in organic chemistry, microbiology, additional biological science, physics, and biochemistry. Basic knowledge of food science is expected; or consent. (Cross-listed as FSHN 607)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Molecular Biology and Genetics (3)
desc: Graduate-level basic course on molecular biology and genetics. Prepares students to understand advanced concepts in related subjects such as biochemistry, cell biology, cancer biology, immunology, plant genetics, and genomics. Pre: 402/BIOL 402 (with a minimum grade of B or higher), or with consent from instructor. (Alt. years: fall) (Cross-listed as MICR 602)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Molecular Cell Biology (3)
desc: Provide fundamental concepts and dynamic characteristics of the molecules of the prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell, their biosynthesis and regulation, and the mechanisms that regulate cellular activities. A-F only. Pre: basic course in cell and molecular biology, or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as MICR 601)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Supervised individual instruction in laboratory research problems in biochemistry, molecular and cellular biology, genomics, and genetics. Repeatable 3 times or up to 16 credits. Limited to qualified undergraduate students. A-F only.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Special Topics in MBBE (V)
desc: Study and discussion of special topics and problems in molecular biosciences and bioengineering. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Topics for Biologists (3)
desc: Focuses on the use of computational tools and approaches to analyze the enormous amount of biological data (DNA, RNA, protein) available today. A-F only. Pre: (BIOL 171 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as BIOL 483)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Biotechnology for Teachers (3)
desc: Principles, methods, classical examples, recent development, benefits and concerns of modern biotechnology. Pre: BIOL 304 or equivalent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Bioreactor Design and Analysis (3)
desc: Application of mass/energy balances and reaction kinetics for the design and analysis of bioreactors for microbial, plant, and animal cell cultures. Pre: ME 322 (with a minimum grade of C-) or BE 373 or CEE 320; or consent. (Cross-listed as BE 460) DP
metadata: DP College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Environmental Biochemistry (3)
desc: Biochemical and chemical principles of occurrence, distribution, biotic and abiotic conversion, fate, and impact of synthetic and natural molecules in the environment. Important pollutants will be used as case studies to illustrate the principles. A-F only. Pre: CHEM 152 or CHEM 272, and CHEM 162 or CHEM 171; or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Molecular Cellular Biology II (3)
desc: Cell structure and function. Structure, chemistry, and functions of organelles and macromolecules. Pre: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 407; or consent. (Cross-listed as BIOL 408 and MCB 408)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Marine Functional Ecology and Biotechnology (3)
desc: Marine functional genomics, biodiversity of marine natural habitats, marine microbial communities and their ecological functions, interactions of marine microbes and their host, climate change and marine biodiversity, marine biotechnology. A-F only. Pre: OCN 201 or MICR 130, or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as OCN 403)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Principles of Biochemistry Lab (2)
desc: (1 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles and techniques of biochemical laboratory. Teaches biochemistry laboratory methods as well as technical writing in the form of experimental reports. A-F only. Pre: (402 (or concurrent), BIOL 402 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C.
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Principles of Biochemistry (4)
desc: Molecular basis of living processes in bacteria, plants and animals; emphasis on metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins and nucleic acids. Pre: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275/275L, CHEM 272 and CHEM 273; or consent. (Cross-listed as BIOL 402)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Molecular Biotechnology (3)
desc: General principles, applications, and recent advances of the rapidly growing science of biotechnology. Topics include impact of biotechnology on medicine, animal sciences, environment, agriculture, forensics, and economic and socio-ethical issues. Pre: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275 or consent. (Cross-listed as BIOL 401)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Essential Biochemistry (3)
desc: Introduction to basic concepts of cellular biochemistry and metabolic pathways as applied to nutritional, medicinal and environmental biochemistry. A-F only. Pre: (CHEM 152 or CHEM 272) with a minimum grade of C, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MBBE
title: Biotechnology: Science and Ethical Issues (3)
desc: Introduction to the concepts, goals, ethical issues and consequences of biotechnology using real-life case studies of GMOs, cloning, DNA fingerprinting, gene therapy and genetical engineering. Pre: BIOL 171 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent. (Cross-listed as BIOL 304)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Molecular Biosciences and Bioengineering (MBBE)

subject: MSL
title: Advanced Military Research (V)
desc: Directs the student to conduct detailed research on a military topic and present to the department leadership plus assist MSL 400 series students on a battle analysis. Repeatable up to eight credits. Must be in Military Science and Leadership Program or Military Service member in junior or greater standing. Pre: departmental approval.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Transition to Lieutenant (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 2-hr Lab) Explores dynamics of leading in complex situations of current military operations. Examines differences in customs and courtesies, military law, principles of war, and rules of engagement in the face of international terrorism. Interaction with nongovernment organizations, civilians on the battlefield, and host nation support are examined and evaluated. Case studies, scenarios, and What Now, Lieutenant? exercises prepare cadets to lead as commissioned officers in the U.S. Army. A-F only. Pre: 401 or consent.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Leadership Challenges and Goal Setting (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 2-hr Lab) Develops proficiency in planning, execution, and assessment of complex operations; students will learn to assess risk, make ethical decisions, function as a staff member, and provide leadership performance feedback to subordinates; emphasis on oral communication. A-F only. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Fundamentals of Leadership (3)
desc: Introduces students to the fundamentals of leadership. Activities challenge students to connect theory to practice, develop positive relationships through application of effective leadership concepts for leader development, and team-building. A-F only.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Limited to military science students who have had at least one previous military science course for which a grade of B or higher was earned and a cumulative GPA of 2.0 or better. Pre: consent.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: History of Military Warfare (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion on the art and science of warfare concentrating on U.S. military history from the Colonial Period to present. Generally restricted to Army ROTC students, requiring twenty pages of graded writing assignments. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: ROTC Advanced Camp (6)
desc: Five-week summer field training exercise conducted at Fort Knox, Kentucky. Arduous and intensified leadership training is conducted throughout the five-week period. Required for U.S. Army commissioning. Pre: 302 and consent.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Leading Small Organizations II (4)
desc: (2 Lec, 2-hr Lab) Intense situational leadership challenges to build awareness and skills in leading small units. Decision-making, persuading, and motivating team members under fire are explored, evaluated, and developed. Military operations are reviewed to prepare for the ROTC Advance Camp. Cadets apply principles of Law of Land Warfare, Army training, and motivation to troop leading procedures; and are evaluated on what they  know  and  do  as leaders. A-F only. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Leading Small Organizations I (4)
desc: (2 Lec, 2-hr Lab) Challenges cadets to study, practice, and evaluate adaptive leadership skills with demands of the ROTC Advanced Camp. Challenging scenarios related to small unit tactical operations will develop self-awareness and critical thinking skills. Cadets will receive systematic, specific feedback on their leadership abilities, and analyze/evaluate their leadership values, attributes, skills and actions. A-F only. Pre: 101, 102, 201, and 202; or 203; or consent.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: ROTC Basic Camp (6)
desc: Four-week summer course conducted at Ft. Knox, Kentucky. Substitutes for ROTC basic course (101, 102, 201, and 202) and fulfills course requirement for admission to ROTC advanced courses. Credit will be given for 203 or basic courses, but not both. Pre: consent.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Intermediate Military Science II (3)
desc: Challenges of leading complex, contemporary operational environments. Dimensions of cross-cultural challenges of leadership in a constantly changing world are highlighted and applied to practical Army leadership tasks and situations. Cadets develop greater self awareness as they practice communication and team building skills, and tactics in real world scenarios. Provides a smooth transition to MSL 301.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Intermediate Military Science I (3)
desc: Explores creative and innovative tactical leadership strategies and styles through historical case studies and engaging in interactive student exercises. Cadets practice aspects of personal motivation and team building by planning, executing, and assessing team exercises. Focus is on continued development of leadership values and attributes through understanding of rank, uniform, customs and courtesies.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Introduction to Military Science II Lab (1)
desc: Practical application in adventure training, Army field craft, rifle marksmanship, land navigation, drill and ceremonies, physical training. Co-requisite: 102.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Introduction to Military Science II (2)
desc: Overviews leadership fundamentals such as setting direction, problem-solving, listening, presenting briefs, providing feedback and using effective writing skills. Explores leadership values, attributes, skills, and actions in the context of practical, hands-on, and interactive exercises. Cadre role models and building stronger relationships among cadets through common experience and practical interaction are critical.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Introduction to Military Science I Lab (1)
desc: Practical application in adventure training, Army field craft, rifle marksmanship, land navigation, drill and ceremonies, physical training. Co-requisite: 101.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Introduction to Military Science I (2)
desc: Introduces cadets to personal challenges and competencies critical for effective leadership; personal development of life skills such as goal setting, time management, physical fitness, and stress management related to leadership, officership, and the Army profession. Focus on developing basic knowledge and comprehension of Army Leadership Dimensions while understanding the ROTC program, its purpose in the Army, and its advantages for the student.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MSL
title: Introduction to Physical Fitness (1)
desc: Hands-on participatory course following the Army’s physical fitness program. Classes conducted three days per week with Army ROTC cadets. Focus is on aerobic conditioning, muscular strength and endurance. Repeatable three times. A-F only.
metadata: Military Science and Leadership (MSL) ROTC

subject: MICR
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Special Topics in Microbiology (V)
desc: Selected topics in any aspect of microbiology. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Advanced Plant-Bacteria Interactions (3)
desc: Molecular biology, genomics, molecular genetics, and infection mechanisms of bacterial plant pathogens and symbionts. Pre: PEPS 606 (with a minimum grade of B or better) or consent. (Cross-listed as PEPS 746)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Selected problems in microbiology. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Research Literature Review (1)
desc: Review of primary literature in a selected area of microbiology. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. Pre: graduate status or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Seminar (1)
desc: Required of graduate students. Repeatable unlimited times; only one credit will count toward the degree.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Molecular and Cellular Bacterial Pathogenesis (3)
desc: Detailed examination of the molecular and cellular mechanisms of bacterial pathogenesis. Overview of key literature, synthesis of scientific problems into research proposals. Pre: 431, 463, or 470; or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Host-Parasite Relationships (3)
desc: Mechanisms of pathogenicity of microorganisms and defense mechanisms of human and animal hosts. Review of contemporary literature. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Advances in Microbial Ecology (3)
desc: Highlights in microbial ecology; interaction of microorganisms with abiotic and biotic components of their environments. Modern techniques for study of autecology and synecology of microorganisms. Pre: 485 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Bacterial Genetics (3)
desc: Directed study and discussion of research literature on bacterial and bacterial virus mutation, genetic recombination, evolution and control mechanisms. Pre: graduate standing; undergraduates that have taken 475 may register with consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Regulations of Gene Expressions in Microorganisms (3)
desc: Use of bioinformatic tools to understand comparative genomics, metabolic pathways, and protein evolution. A-F only. Pre: 351 and one 400 level MICR course, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Advanced Virology (3)
desc: Detailed reports and discussions on selected advanced topics and current research literature. Pre: 463, 490, BIOC 441; or consent. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Advanced Marine Microbiology (3)
desc: Advanced studies of marine microorganisms in diverse habitats with consideration of applications of marine microbes, interactions with higher organisms, phylogeny and diversity, and past and current methods. A-F only. Pre: 351 and 401, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Advanced Microbial Physiology (3)
desc: Selected topics. Pre: 431 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Microbial Genome (3)
desc: Advanced studies of Microbial genome: relation to functional genomics, structural genomics, and proteomics. A-F only. Pre: 351 and one 400-level MICR course, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Advanced Immunology (3)
desc: Detailed reports and discussions on selected advanced topics and current research literature. Pre: 461 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Research Ethics (1)
desc: Introduction to ethical issues faced by individuals and institutions involved in scientific research. Moral reasoning, humans and animals in research, mentoring, authorship, ownership of data and genetic technologies. MICR graduates only. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in MICR or related field, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Molecular Biology and Genetics (3)
desc: Graduate-level basic course on molecular biology and genetics. Prepares students to understand advanced concepts in related subjects such as biochemistry, cell biology, cancer biology, immunology, plant genetics, and genomics. Pre: MBBE 402/BIOL 402 (with a minimum grade of B or higher), or with consent from instructor. (Alt. years: fall) (Cross-listed as MBBE 602)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Molecular Cell Biology (3)
desc: Provide fundamental concepts and dynamic characteristics of the molecules of the prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell, their biosynthesis and regulation, and the mechanisms that regulate cellular activities. A-F only. Pre: basic course in cell and molecular biology, or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as MBBE 601)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Virology Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) General laboratory techniques and related theories in virology; including isolation, cell culture, assay, purification, and identification of viruses. Pre: 351/351L or BIOL 275/275L and 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Virology (3)
desc: Basic principles of virus biology. Topics include methods for virus study, virus structure, replication, gene expression, pathogenesis and host response. Pre: 351 or BIOL 275, or consent.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Microbes and Their Environment Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Techniques for study of interaction of microorganisms with and within their natural habitats; symbiosis between microorganisms and plants and animals; role of microorganisms in element cycling; food fermentation by bacteria. Pre: 485 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Microbes and Their Environment (3)
desc: Distribution, diversity, and roles of microorganisms in terrestrial, freshwater, and marine ecosystems. Importance of bacteria in pesticide degradation, bioremediation of oil spills, sewage treatment, biocontrol, food fermentation. Pre: BIOL 171 and CHEM 272, or consent.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Bacterial Genetics Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Techniques for study of transfer and expression of prokaryotic genes: transformation, conjugation, transposon mutagenesis, preparation and analysis of plasmid and chromosomal DNA. Pre: 475 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as MCB 475L)
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Bacterial Genetics (3)
desc: Genetic analysis and molecular basis of transmission replication, mutation, and expression of heritable characteristics in prokaryotes. Pre: 351 or BIOL 275, or consent. (Cross-listed as MCB 475)
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Bacterial Molecular Pathogenesis Laboratory (2)
desc: Modern techniques to study infectious diseases. Covers tissue culture and animal models to study virulence of extracellular and intracellular infecting bacteria, bacterial resistance mechanisms toward antibacterial drugs, and virulence factor assays. A-F only. Pre: 351 and 351L, 470 (or concurrent). (Fall only)
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Bacterial Molecular Pathogenesis (3)
desc: Fundamental mechanisms of bacterial infectious diseases or pathogenesis at the molecular level. Emphasis on bacterial virulence and host-pathogen interactions. Pre: 351/351L or consent.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Microbiology of Pathogens Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Characterization of bacterial pathogens. Isolation, identification, and diagnosis. Pre: 351L. Co-requisite: 463 or consent.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Microbiology of Pathogens (3)
desc: Host-parasite relationships in microbial diseases of humans and animals with emphasis on bacterial pathogens. Pre: 351. Co-requisite: 463L or consent.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Immunology Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Basic exercises and experiments in immunology, immunochemistry, immuno-biology to illustrate principles of 461. Pre: 461 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as MCB 461L)
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Immunology (3)
desc: Structure and biological actions of antigens and antibodies; fundamentals of antibody synthesis; the relation of immunology to biology and medical sciences. Pre: 351 or BIOL 171, or consent. Recommended: BIOL 275/275L. (Cross-listed as MCB 461)
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Microbial Physiology Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Components and metabolism of the bacterial cell; emphasis on techniques of analysis of metabolism and molecular structure. Co-requisite: 431.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Microbial Physiology (3)
desc: Fundamental physiological and metabolic processes of bacteria; emphasis on growth, functions of cell structures, varieties of energy metabolism, metabolic regulation, and differentiation at the prokaryote level. Pre: 351.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Marine Microbiology Laboratory (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 401. Pre: BIOL 275/275L and BIOL 301 (or concurrent)/301L (or concurrent) and OCN 201; or 351/351L; and 401 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Marine Microbiology (3)
desc: Evolution, ecology, biochemistry, genetics and physiology of marine bacteria by examining defined systems and organisms. Pre: BIOL 275/275L and BIOL 301 (or concurrent)/301L (or concurrent), and OCN 201; or 351/351L; or consent.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Introductory Bioinformatics (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introductory bioinformatics will provide a basic foundation of biological information (DNA, protein, genome and proteome) by using information technology (IT). A-F only. Pre: BIOL 275 and BIOL 275L, or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Biology of Microorganisms Lab (2
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Laboratory exercises to accompany 351. Pre: CHEM 272/272L, and BIOL 171, or equivalent. Co-requisite: 351.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Biology of Microorganisms (3)
desc: Anatomy, chemistry, physiology, genetics, development, and environmental interactions of microorganisms. Pre: BIOL 171 or equivalent, CHEM 272/272L; or consent. Co-requisite: 351L. Recommended: BIOL 275/275L.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Research Ethics (1)
desc: Introduction to the ethical issues faced by individuals and institutions involved in scientific research. Based on case studies, students will discuss and write about ethical issues in research. Issues include humans and animals in research, mentoring, authorship, ownership of data, genetic technologies and record keeping. This course is designed for students with majors in the natural sciences. A-F only. Pre: BIOL 171 (or concurrent), or MATH 307 (or concurrent), or MATH 311 (or concurrent), or PHYS 170 (or concurrent), or CHEM 272 (or concurrent); or consent. (Cross-listed as MCB 314)
metadata: DS College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: Microbiology Laboratory (2)
desc: (2 2-hr Lab) Primarily for students in nursing and dental hygiene. Pre: 130 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MICR
title: General Microbiology (3)
desc: Role of microorganisms; how they affect people, property, and the environment. A basic survey course covering broad aspects of biochemistry, genetics, molecular biology, and physiology; host-parasite relationships, public health, bacterial, mycotic and viral diseases; epidemiology; ecology of soils and water; environmental pollution; food microbiology; industrial applications at an introductory level. Not open to those with credit in 351 or equivalent.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Microbiology (MICR)

subject: MED
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medicine (MED)

subject: MED
title: (Alpha) Electives in Medicine (V)
desc: Fourthyear electives in which students study selected topics within field of medicine. (B) extramural electives in medicine (miscellaneous); (C) internal medicine seminar; (D) infectious disease; (E) internal medicine sub-internship; (F) research in bioethics; (G) neurology critical care; (H) medical informatics; (O) obesity medicine. Repeatable one time for (C)–(E); not repeatable for (F); repeatable two times for (B), (C) and (H); repeatable three times for (G). CR/NC only. Pre: 531 or 532 for (B), (C), and (O); 541 for (E) and (H).
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medicine (MED)

subject: MED
title: (Alpha) Electives in Medicine (V)
desc: Fourth-year electives in which students study selected topics within field of medicine. (B) allergy/immunology; (C) cardiology; (D) medicine elective in Asia; (E) dermatology; (F) endocrinology; (G) gastroenterology; (H) general internal medicine: ambulatory care; (I) general internal medicine: inpatient; (K) hematology; (M) nephrology; (N) neurology; (O) nuclear medicine; (P) oncology; (Q) pulmonary diseases; (R) research in medicine; (S) rehabilitation medicine; (T) rheumatology; (U) heart failure/electrophysiology; (W) internal medicine sub-internship. MD students only for (U). CR/NC only. Pre: 531 or 532 for (C), (E), (F), (G), (H), (K), (M), (N), (O), (Q), (R), (S), and (T); 532 for (U); 541 for (D) and (W).
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medicine (MED)

subject: MED
title: Advanced Medicine Clerkship (6)
desc: Required 4 weeks duration for fourth-year medical students. Advanced experiences in ambulatory and hospital-based medical care. Proficiency in this course may be established by examination. CR/NC only. Pre: fourth-year standing and completion of 531, or consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medicine (MED)

subject: MED
title: Internal Medicine Longitudinal Clerkship (5)
desc: Six-month long clerkship in ambulatory setting, and four-week hospital-based experience. Repeatable one time. Pre: third-year standing and concurrent registration in 532 courses.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medicine (MED)

subject: MEDT
title: Seminar in Medical Technology (1)
desc: Analysis of research and recent literature pertaining to various aspects of medical technology. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Clinical Training in Medical Technology (28)
desc: Application of theory and simulated laboratory experiences in immuno-hematology, clinical chemistry, microbiology, parasitology, hematology, coagulation, urinalysis, immunology, to meet stated career entry-level competencies. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. Pre: BS in MEDT.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Clinical Microbiology Preceptorship (5)
desc: Clinical training for students with bachelor’s degree in microbiology to be able to qualify as clinical microbiologists in a healthcare setting. Includes specimen procurement, processing, detection and identification, susceptibility testing, and other diagnostic technology. CR/NC only. Pre: departmental consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable one time.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Special Topics in Medical Technology (V)
desc: Acquaints student with role of the medical technologist and overlap of major sciences in clinical situations to help student develop qualities unique to med technology. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Professional Issues in Medical Lab Science (1)
desc: Discussions about various professional issues through oral presentations and critiquing of peer presentations. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 451L.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Clinical Lab Methods and Analyses II (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Continuation of 477. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. A-F only. Pre: 477.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Clinical Lab Methods and Analyses I (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Lab experiments illustrating fundamental principles and methods of clinical laboratory analyses. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. A-F only. Pre: 471.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Clinical Biochemistry II (4)
desc: Continuation of 471. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. Pre: 471 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Clinical Biochemistry I (4)
desc: Biochemical processes in human health and disease states. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. Pre: CHEM 273 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: DB John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Immunohematology (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Antigen-antibody relationships in human blood, study of blood groups, clinical problems in transfusion. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. Pre: MICR 461 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Hematology Lab (2)
desc: Laboratory to accompany MEDT 451. Emphasis on writing to study content. MEDT majors only. Pre: consent. Co-requisite: 451.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Hematology (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Fundamental study of blood in normal and pathological states: formation, development, and classification of blood cells. MEDT majors only. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Clinical Parasitology (2)
desc: (1 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Modern diagnostic practices in parasitology. Repeatable one time. Pre: MICR 351 or consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Clinical Lab Management (3)
desc: Student will become familiar with fundamental administration of a clinical laboratory to include technical, personnel, and financial management areas. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: The Clinical Laboratory II (3)
desc: Theory and clinical application of medical technology methods and healthcare professional relationships. Companion course to MEDT 301; and required, for second bachelor’s degree students who were admitted to MEDT major. MEDT majors only. Second Bachelor’s degree standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 251 or consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: The Clinical Laboratory (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Theory and clinical application of medical laboratory methods and healthcare professional relationships. MEDT majors only. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Introduction to Medical Technology II (2)
desc: Basic principles and lab skills in medical technology (medical lab science). Required for second bachelor’s degree students (not MLT credentialed) wishing to major in medical technology. Second bachelor’s degree students only. A-F only. Pre: 151, CHEM 161/CHEM 161L, BIOL 171/BIOL 171L (or concurrent)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MEDT
title: Introduction to Medical Technology (2)
desc: Designed to acquaint students to the field of medical technology (clinical laboratory science). Repeatable one time.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Technology (MEDT)

subject: MDHX
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical History (MDHX)

subject: MDED
title: Research in Medical Education (V)
desc: An elective for medical students to work on research projects related to improving medical education, student wellness, and community health under the direction of a faculty member in the Office of Medical Education. Repeatable nine times, up to six credits.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: (Alpha) Topics in Medical Education (V)
desc: Summer selectives in medical education for second-year medical students. (B) rural health preceptorship; (C) health issues of the Pacific Basin; (D) projects in medical education; (E) manikin simulations; (F) learning resources; (G) cardiovascular case maps; (H) pulmonary case maps; (I) clinical skills preceptors; (J) global health perspectives. Repeatable up to four credits. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 554. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: (Alpha) Preclinical Electives (V)
desc: Elective for first and second year medical students. (B) projects in medical education; (C) healer’s art; (D) introduction to student research; (E) health and wellness; (F) quality improvement; (G) introduction to ultrasound. Repeatable one time, up to two credits. MD majors only for (G). CR/NC only. Pre: 551.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 4 Community Health (2)
desc: Field experience placing student in community settings to work with health care professionals as they provide services to patients. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 583 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 3 Community Health (2)
desc: Field experience placing student in community settings to work with health care professionals as they provide services to patients. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 582 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 2 Community Health (2)
desc: Field experience placing students in community settings to work with health care professionals as they provide services to patients. Repeatable two times. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 581 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 1 Community Health (2)
desc: Field experience placing students in community settings to work with health care professionals as they provide services to patients. Repeatable two times. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: consent. Co-requisites: 551 and 571. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 7 Clinical Skills (2)
desc: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 7. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 576 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 6 Clinical Skills (3)
desc: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 6. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 574 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 4 Clinical Skills (2)
desc: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 4. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 573 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 3 Clinical Skills (2)
desc: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 3. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 572 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 2 Clinical Skills (2)
desc: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 2. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 571 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Introduction to Clinical Skills (2)
desc: Introductory lectures and laboratories on history taking and physical exam skills. Repeatable one time. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: consent. Co-requisite: 551. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: (Alpha) Senior Seminars (1)
desc: Review of topics and issues that will prepare senior students for the end of their undergraduate training and the start of their internship. (B) Week 1; (C) Week 2; (D) Week 3. CR/ NC only. (Fall only for B); (Spring only for C and D)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Third Year Colloquia (2)
desc: A series of lecture-discussions intended to broaden the perspectives of the Unit VI experiences and healthcare problems. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. Pre: 551 and 557.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 7 The Life Cycle Tutorials (4)
desc: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for second-year medical students focusing on the life cycle health care problems. CR/NC only. Pre: 556 and 556L. Co-requisite: 557. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 7 The Life Cycle (7)
desc: Concepts focusing on the life cycle through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 7 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. Pre: 556 and 556L. Co-requisite: 557L. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 6 Locomotor System, Nervous System, and Behavioral Problems (6)
desc: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for second-year medical students focusing on neurological/ locomotor systems and behavioral health care problems. CR/NC only. Pre: 554 and 554L. Co-requisite: 556. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 6 Locomotor System, Nervous System and Behavioral Problems (8)
desc: Concepts focusing on the locomotor/neurological systems and behavioral problems through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 6 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. Pre: 554 and 554L. Co-requisite: 556L. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 4 GI/Endocrine Tutorials (4)
desc: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for first-year medical students focusing on gastrointestinal and endocrine health care problems. CR/NC only. Pre: 553 and 553L. Co-requisite: 554. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 4 GI/Endocrine (7)
desc: Concepts focusing on gastrointestinal and endocrine systems through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 4 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. Pre: 553 and 553L. Co-requisite: 554L. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 3 Renal/Hematology Tutorials (4)
desc: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for first-year medical students focusing on renal and hematology health care problems. CR/NC only. Pre: 552 and 552L. Co-requisite: 553. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 3 Renal/Hematology (7)
desc: Concepts focusing on renal and hematologic systems through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 3 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. Pre: 552 and 552L. Co-requisites: 553L. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 2 CV/Pulmonary Tutorials (4)
desc: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for first-year medical students focusing on cardiovascular and pulmonary health care problems. CR/NC only. Pre: 551 and 551L. Co-requisite: 552. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 2 CV/Pulmonary (7)
desc: Concepts focusing on cardiovascular and pulmonary systems through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 2 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. Pre: 551 and 551L. Co-requisite: 552L. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 1 Health and Illness Tutorials (3)
desc: Introductory series of problem-based learning tutorials for first-year medical students focusing on concepts of health and disease through MD 1 health care problems. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 551. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: MD 1 Health and Illness (5)
desc: Introduction to concepts of health and disease through lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 1 health care problems in tutorials. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: consent. Co-requisite: 551L. (Fall only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: (Alpha) Senior Interdisciplinary Electives (V)
desc: Fourth-year elective in which students study selected interdisciplinary topics. CR/NC only. (B) medical education elective; (C) complementary and alternative medicine; (D) leadership in underserved care; (E) Junior PBL course director. MED majors only for (D). CR/NC only for (D) and (E). Pre: FMCH, MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, SURG 531 or 532. (Spring only for (D) and (E))
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Clinical Skills Assessment (1)
desc: Required comprehensive interdepartment multidisciplinary assessment program for fourth-year medical students. CR/NC only. Pre: FMCH, MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, SURG 531 or 532.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Unit 8 Block Selective (V)
desc: Through lectures, self-assessments and independent study, second-year medical students will consolidate their knowledge of the application of the biological sciences to patient care. CR/NC only. Pre: 557.
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: MDED
title: Evidence-Based Medicine (1)
desc: Critical appraisal track designed to improve the student’s ability to seek and evaluate new medical knowledge. MD majors only. CR/NC only. (Spring only)
metadata: John A. Burns School of Medicine Medical Education (MDED)

subject: ME
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: candidacy for PhD in mechanical engineering.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Directed Instruction (V)
desc: Student assists in undergraduate classroom and/or project instruction under the direction and close supervision of faculty member. CR/NC only. Pre: admission to PhD candidacy or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Thesis for degree of MS in mechanical engineering. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: admission to candidacy and consent of thesis advisor.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Directed Reading or Research (V)
desc: Directed study on subject of mutual interest to student and a staff member. Student must find faculty sponsor before registering. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Advanced Topics in Mechanical Engineering (V)
desc: Highly specialized topics in thermosciences, mechanics, materials, system, or design. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Seminar (1)
desc: Current problems in all branches of mechanical engineering. All graduate students are required to attend; registrants are expected to present talks. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: High Growth Entrepreneurship (V)
desc: An interdisciplinary (JD-MBA) course examining legal, business, and technology issues related to building high growth companies. Student teams develop company feasibility reports and skills necessary to advise or build high growth businesses. Recommended: 531. Law, MBA, and ME students only. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as LAW 560 and MGT 653)
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Advanced Dynamics (3)
desc: Lecture on rigidbody dynamics. Topics include: dynamical systems; motion representation and constraints; Newtonian mechanics; Lagrangian mechanics; Hamilton’s principle; stability analysis; introduction to multibody dynamics. Pre: 375 or equivalent, or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Finite Element Analysis (3)
desc: Introduction to finite element analysis and design in mechanical engineering. Applications to machine design, vibrations, elasticity, heat transfer. Pre: 360, 371; or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Continuum Mechanics (3)
desc: Cartesian tensors in mechanics, coordinate transformations, analysis of stress and strain, principal values, invariants, equilibrium and compatibility equations, constitutive relations, field equations. Problems in elasticity. A-F only. Recommended: 371 or CEE 370, or consent. (Cross-listed as CEE 671)
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Introduction to Fuel Cell Technology (3)
desc: Working principles of all major fuel cell types; fundamentals of proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells; state-of-the-art theoretical models and diagnostic technologies for PEM fuel cells. A-F only. Pre: 422 (or equivalent) or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Automatic Control (3)
desc: Linear optimal feedback control, discrete time optimal control, fundamentals of adaptive control, application to motion and force control of robot arms and manipulators. Pre: 451, ECE 351; or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Surface Phenomena (3)
desc: Fundamental and modern concepts of colloid and surface science. Main topics include surface thermodynamics, capillarity and wetting phenomena, surface forces, surfactants, and particles. Pre: 311 or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Nanoscience and Nanotechnology (3)
desc: Science and applications of nanotechnology. Synthesis of nanostructures; nanoscale structure characterization by electron microscopy and Raman spectroscopy; electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties of nanostructures; fabrication of nanodevices; energy, environmental, and biological applications of nanomaterials. A-F only.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Mechanics and Design Composites (3)
desc: Introduction to composites; anisotropic elasticity and laminate theory; hygrothermal effects; composite beams, columns, rods, plates, and shells; energy method; failure theories; joining of composites, computer-aided design in composites. Pre: 371 or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Clinically Driven Design and Development (3)
desc: Exploration of simple, cost-effective alternatives in medicine through different stages of concept generation, design analysis, and prototype validation and investigation of their commercialization potential. Graduate students only. Pre: 341 or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Fundamentals of Electrochemistry (3)
desc: Thermodynamics of cells, electrode kinetics, mass transfer by migration and diffusion, microelectrode techniques, forced convection, impedance, doublelayer structure, and absorbed intermediates in electrode processes. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Corrosion Theory (3)
desc: Application of electrochemical theory and materials science to corrosion and oxidation reactions. Effect of environment, especially marine. Cathodic protection, coatings, inhibitors, treatment of water systems. Pre: 331.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Rheology (3)
desc: Vector and tensor operations. Constutive equations. Generalized Newtonian fluids and linear viscoelastic fluids. Rheometry and experiments. Flow of suspensions. Advanced topics and rheology of polymers, food products, biomaterials and asphalt, laboratories. Pre: 626 or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Viscous Flows (3)
desc: Formulation and properties of the Navier-Stokes equations; exact solutions; creeping flows; lubrication theory; laminar boundary layers; laminar stability, and transition to turbulence; turbulent boundary layers. Pre: 322.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Numerical Methods in Fluid Mechanics and Heat Transfer (3)
desc: Integration of ordinary differential equations. Finite difference solutions of partial differential equations with applications to conduction and convection. Introduction to finite element methods. Pre: 422, and either MATH 190 or ECE 160.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Microfluidics and Nanofluidics (3)
desc: Introduction to fundamental understanding of fluid mechanics and transport phenomena at micro-nanoscale; electrokinetics; chemical separation; colloids and emulsions; biophysics; micro-nanofabrication.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Convection Heat Transfer (3)
desc: Heat transfer in laminar and turbulent boundary layers. Analogy between heat, momentum, mass transfer. Pre: 422 and 626.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Biological Fluid Mechanics (3)
desc: Review of Newtonian fluid mechanics. Blood rheology and flow in elastic tubes. Murray’s Law and pulsatile flow propagation. Microcirculation dynamics and biological transport. Aquatic movement and comparative biological examples. Pre: 322 and 422, or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Boiling and Two-Phase Flow (3)
desc: Two-phase flow pattern and flow pattern maps; two-phase flow models (homogeneous, separate, drift flux, annular); laminar and turbulent film condensations; boiling incipience; pool boiling heat transfer; flow boiling heat transfer; critical heat flux (CHF). A-F only. Pre: 422 (or equivalent) or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Advanced Aerodynamics (3)
desc: Advanced topics in aerodynamics, two- and three-dimensional wing theory, slender-body theory, lifting surface methods, vortex and wave drag, analytical and numerical methods, for computing unsteady aerodynamic behavior and introduction to flightdynamics. A-F only. Pre: 322 and 626, or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Introduction to Statistical Thermodynamics (3)
desc: Fundamentals of statistical thermodynamics. Main topics include entropy, Boltzmann law, thermodynamic driving forces, statistical mechanics, chemical equilibria, solutions and mixtures, and applications of statistical thermodynamics in biology, chemistry, physics, and nanoscience. A-F only. Pre: 311 or 611.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Advanced Thermodynamics (3)
desc: Introduction to general principles of classical thermodynamics. Main topics include equilibrium conditions, thermodynamic relations, Legendre transformations, Maxwell relations, stability of thermodynamic systems, phase transitions, and critical phenomena. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: 311 or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Renewable Energy Engineering and Sustainability (3)
desc: Analysis of principles of operation of renewable energy systems, and its interactions with sustainability. Fundamentals of renewable energy production, storage, and distribution. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Project (V)
desc: Investigation of advanced problems in mechanical engineering design or development. Student must find faculty sponsor before registering. A-F only. Pre: senior standing.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering (3)
desc: Specialized topics in thermosciences, mechanics, materials, systems, or design. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering (3)
desc: Specialized topics in thermosciences, mechanics, materials, systems, or design. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Design Project II (3)
desc: (1 Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Continuation of design project initiated in ME 481. Extension of conceptual design to final design. Manufacturing of prototype: material and part selection, procurement, manufacturing specifications/ drawings. Testing of complex systems. Extensive oral communication required. A-F only. Pre: 481.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Design Project I (4)
desc: (2 1-hr Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Heuristic application of engineering design process and project planning via a significant, open-ended design project that includes realistic constraints involving economics, environmental sustainability, manufacturability, ethics, health, safety, society, and politics. Extensive written communication required. A-F only. Pre: 322, 341, 372, and 375; or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Thermofluid Measurements and Design (3)
desc: Measurement techniques in thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, and heat transfer. Hands-on experience with instrumentation. Open-ended design of thermofluid systems. Contemporary engineering ethics issues. Final report and presentation are required. A-F only. Pre: 422 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Fundamentals of Acoustics (3)
desc: Plane and spherical acoustic waves. Transmission, reflection, radiation, and absorption. Near and far fields, radiation patterns. Applications to noise control. Instruments. Pre: 375, ECE 211; or consent.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Mechanical Vibrations (3)
desc: Response of machines and systems to transient and periodic excitation. Vibration isolation and transmissibility. Modal analysis of multi-degree-of-freedom systems. Applications to design. Pre: 371, 375; or consent.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Experimental Stress Analysis (3)
desc: (1-3 hr Lab) Techniques of experimental stress analysis: strain and deflection measurement of beams and shafts, strain to stress conversion, principal and maximum shearing stresses, failure in biaxial stress states, stress concentrations, residual stresses, buckling, creep, electrical resistance strain gages, brittle coatings, photoelastic methods, transducers. A-F only. Pre: 371 and departmental approval.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Nuclear Power Engineering (3)
desc: Nuclear reactor principles. Reactor heat transfer, heat generation and removal. Design and analysis of reactor power systems and plants. Pre: 411 (or consent) and 422.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Energy Conversion Systems (3)
desc: Energy conversion and its impact on the environment. Conventional, hydroelectric, nuclear fission and fusion, solar, wind, ocean, geothermal, and biomass power; energy storage, transmission and conservation. Pre: 322, 411, and 422 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Robotics (3)
desc: Principles and design methods for autonomous systems. Pre: senior standing.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Feedback-Control Systems (3)
desc: Analysis/design of feedback systems. Compensator design via root locus and Bode analysis. Routh/Nyquist stability. State space representation and introduction to MIMO formulation. Controllability/observability. Application to physical dynamic systems such as industrial robots. Pre: 375 or ECE 315 or consent.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Introduction to Nanotechnology (3)
desc: (3 Lec) Tools and techniques of micro- and nanotechnology in design, modeling, simulations, analysis, fabrication, testing and characterization; nano-materials, nano-structures, nano-composites, nano-coating, nano-optics, nano-electronics and nano-biotechnology. A-F only. Pre: senior standing or consent.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Advanced Materials Manufacturing (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Introduction to anisotropic materials, advanced manufacturing techniques for composite and intelligent materials, joining of composites, thin film processing and stereolithography, computer aided manufacturing and rapid prototyping, manufacturing process optimization, open-ended manufacturing projects. A-F only. Pre: 341, 342, and senior standing; or consent.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Corrosion Engineering (3)
desc: Basics of corrosion processes and emphasis on corrosion control. Thermodynamics and kinetics of corrosion, metal alloys and their behavior, corrosion control techniques (cathodic protection, anodic protection, coatings, and inhibitors). Pre: 341.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Experimental Methods in Materials Research (3)
desc: (1 Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Common experimental techniques in materials testing and research: x-ray diffraction, optical and electron microscopy, thermal and mechanical properties, electrochemical methods—theory and hands-on experience. Pre: 341 or CHEM 351 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as CHEM 435)
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Materials Selection for Design (3)
desc: Methodology for the selection of materials for mechanical applications to prevent mechanical failure and environmental degradation. Design considerations associated with the use of metals, ceramics, polymers, and composites. Pre: 341 and 371 (or CEE 370).
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Failures in Materials (3)
desc: Analysis of component failures due to imperfections, fatigue, brittle fracture, wear, corrosion, bending, impact, and overload. Fracture mechanics. Case studies. Pre: 331 or consent.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Scaling Methods in Engineering (3)
desc: Scaling methods and optimization under global constraints; multi-scale optimal design of mechanical, thermal, and natural systems; effectiveness of heat, fluid, and convective trees; theoretical design optimization of manmade and natural power systems; analysis of time dependent structures. A-F only. Pre: 371 and 422, or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Thermal Management of Electronic Systems (3)
desc: To introduce concepts in the thermal management of electronics, and to develop sound technical tools to approach modern electronic packaging and cooling applications. A-F only. Pre: 422 or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Introduction to Gas Dynamics (3)
desc: One-dimensional compressible flow involving change of area, friction, heat transfer. Normal and oblique shocks. Prandtl-Meyer flow. Application to nozzles, diffusers, airfoils. Pre: 322.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Mass Transfer (3)
desc: Elementary mass diffusion; diffusion in a stationary medium; diffusion in a moving medium; low and high mass transfer theories; simultaneous heat and mass transfer; condensation, evaporation, and boiling; transpiration cooling; species boundary layers; engineering and design of heat and mass exchangers; current refrigerants and environmental regulations. A-F only. Pre: 422 or consent.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Heat Transfer and Lab (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Steady and unsteady conduction; steady convection and radiation; heat exchangers. Emphasis on writing instruction. Pre: 322.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Astronautics (3)
desc: The space environment (vacuum, neutral, radiation, and plasma); motion in gravitational fields; orbit transfers; Earth-satellite operations; rocketry; propulsion analysis and performance; reentry dynamics; interplanetary trajectories; attitude dynamics and stabilization. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Power and Propulsion (3)
desc: Principles, performance, and design of gas turbine power plants and propulsion systems. Pre: 422 (or concurrent).
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Applied Thermal Engineering (3)
desc: Principles, design and analysis of practical thermal systems. Engineering applications. Valve, compressor, condenser and evaporator technologies. System integration and control. Thermal loads and thermal comfort. Pre: 422 (or concurrent). (Fall only)
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Applied Thermodynamics (3)
desc: Gas mixtures, generalized thermodynamic relationships, combustion and thermochemistry, chemical equilibrium, power and refrigeration cycles. Pre: grade of C or better in 311.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Computational Fluid Dynamics (3)
desc: Basic computational fluid dynamics; four important partial differential equations; introduction to finite element method: Interpolation and Galerkin method; finite element method for transport phenomena; some algorithms for parallel computing. A-F only. Pre: 422 (or concurrent ), and either 360, MATH 407 or PHYS 305; or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Advanced Mathematics for Engineers (3)
desc: Applications of ordinary differential equations, Laplace transform, vector field theory, matrices, line integrals. Pre: MATH 244 (or MATH 253A), and MATH 302 (or MATH 307).
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Dynamics Systems Laboratory (2)
desc: (1 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Analysis, design, fabrication, testing and characterization of engineering instrumentation. Computer-based data acquisition methods. Techniques and procedures associated with carrying out dynamic measurements within the constraints of cost, time and accuracy. Pre: one of 360, MATH 407, or PHYS 305 (or concurrent for any); and 375 (or concurrent).
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Dynamics of Machines and Systems and Lab (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr. Lab) Lumped-parameter modeling of dynamic systems. Methods of analysis, including transform techniques. Time and frequency response. Feedback control. Engineering instrumentation. Data acquisition. Dynamic measurements. Design and testing. Lab report writing. Pre: grade of C or better in all of CEE 271 (or ME 271) and MATH 302 (or MATH 307).
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Kinematics/Dynamics Machinery (3)
desc: Velocity and acceleration analysis of planar mechanisms; kinematic synthesis of linkages, cams, and gears; static and dynamic force analysis of mechanisms; balancing of machinery. Pre: CEE 271 or ME 271 (C or better), MATH 244 (or MATH 253A) and either MATH 302 or MATH 307
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Component Design (3)
desc: Design, analysis, and selection of machine components: shafts, screws, fasteners, welds, rolling contact bearings, journal bearings, gears, clutches, brakes, belts, and roller chains. Pre: 213, and either 371 or CEE 370.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Mechanics of Solids (3)
desc: Introduction to analysis and design of deformable bodies subject to loading. Stress, strain, consitutive relation, axially loading, torsion, statically indeterminate systems, Mohr’s circle, failure criteria, buckling, defection due to axial, shear, torsional, and flexural loading.
