Pre: C or better in all of the following: CEE 270; and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). (Crosslisted as CEE 370)
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Computer Methods in Engineering (3)
desc: Numerical solutions for algebraic and transcendental equations, simultaneous linear algebraic equations, integration and differentiation; integration of ordinary differential equations. Engineering applications. Pre: grade of C or better in all of ECE 160 (or ECE 110 or ICS 111), MATH 244 (or MATH 253A), and MATH 302 (or MATH 307).
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Manufacturing Processes Lab (2)
desc: (1 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Manufacturing laboratory: tension/ compression tests, cold rolling, welding, casting, statistical process control, programming and milling using a CNC machine. A-F only. Pre: 341 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DY College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Manufacturing Processes and Lab (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Energy requirements for manufacturing methods. Manufacturing methods to obtain components with desired size/shape/properties. Conduct manufacturing experiments. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. Pre: 331 or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Materials Science and Engineering (3)
desc: Electronic, atomic, and crystalline structure of materials and their effect on the mechanical, electrical, optical, and magnetic properties of engineering metals, ceramics, polymers, and composites. Pre: grade of C or better in all of CHEM 162 (or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A), MATH 242 (or MATH 252A), and PHYS 170.
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Mechanics of Fluids and Lab (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Incompressible and compressible ideal fluids, effects of viscosity. Similitude, boundary layer flow. Measurement techniques in thermodynamics and fluid mechanics. Hands-on experience with instrumentation. Open-ended design of thermofluid systems. Emphasis on writing instruction. Pre: grade of C or better in all of 311 and CEE 271 (or ME 271).
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Thermodynamics (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 Discussion) Basic laws, closed and open systems. Work, heat, concept of entropy. Properties of pure simple substances. Ideal gases. Introduction to power and refrigeration cycles. Pre: grade of C or better in all of CHEM 162 (or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A), PHYS 170 and MATH 244 (or MATH 253A).
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Applied Mechanics II (3)
desc: Dynamics of particles and rigid bodies; force, acceleration, impulse-momentum, work-energy. CE, CNST, ENGS, ME majors only. A-F only. Pre: C or better in CEE 270; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as CEE 271) D
metadata: DP College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Introduction to Engineering Design (3)
desc: (1 Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Introductory experience in communication, presentation, professional ethics, social responsibility, engineering economics, quality control, and computer-aided drafting. Teamwork and project required. Pre: PHYS 170.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: ME
title: Introduction to Engineering Design I (2)
desc: (1 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Introductory experience in analysis, synthesis, and design. Teamwork and project required. Pre: high school physics or consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Mechanical Engineering (ME)

subject: MATH
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Apprenticeship in Teaching (V)
desc: An experience-based introduction to college-level teaching; students serve as student teachers to professors; responsibilities include supervised teaching and participation in planning and evaluation. Open to graduate students in mathematics only. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. CR/NC only. Pre: graduate standing in mathematics and consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Maximum of 3 credit hours. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Directed Reading and Research for Plan B Masters Students (V)
desc: Maximum of 3 credit hours. Repeatable two times. Graduate standing in MATH. A-F only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Graph Theory (3)
desc: Connected graphs and digraphs. Graph embeddings. Connectivity and networks. Factors and factorizations. Coverings. Coloring. Applications.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Stochastic Processes (3)
desc: Stationary, Gaussian, and Markov processes. A-F only. Pre: 671 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Advanced Probability (3)
desc: Independence and conditioning, martingales, ergodic theory, Markov chains, central limit theorem. A-F only. Pre: 631 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Algebraic Number Theory (3)
desc: Number fields and rings of integers; primes, factorization, and ramification theory; finiteness of the class group; Dirichlet’s Unit Theorem; valuations, completions, and local fields. Further topics. Graduate students only. Pre: 611 (with a minimum grade of B-).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Recursive Functions and Complexity (3)
desc: Recursive, r.e., Ptime, and Logspace classes. Nondeterminism, parallelism, alternation, and Boolean circuits. Reducibility and completeness.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Set Theory (3)
desc: Axiomatic development, ordinal and cardinal numbers, recursion theorems, axiom of choice, continuum hypothesis, consistency and independence results.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Logic (3)
desc: Model theory, computability theory, set theory. In particular syntax and semantics of first order logic; incompleteness, completeness, and compactness theorems; Loewenheim-Skolem theorems; computable and computably enumerable sets; axioms of set theory; ordinals and cardinals. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: (Alpha) Topics in Mathematics (3)
desc: (B) logic; (D) analysis; (E) commutative rings; (F) function theory; (G) geometric topology; (H) operator theory; ((I) probability; (J) algebra; (K) special; (M) lattice theory and universal algebra; (N) noncommutative rings; (O) transformation groups; (P) partial differential equations; (Q) potential theory; (R) algebraic topology; (S) functional analysis; (T) number theory and combinatorics; (U) differentiable manifolds II. Repeatable up to nine credits for (U); unlimited times for the other alphas.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Analytic Function Theory (3)
desc: Continuation of 644. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 644.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Analytic Function Theory (3)
desc: Conformal mapping, residue theory, series and product developments, analytic continuation, special functions. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 644–645.)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Calculus of Variations (3)
desc: Simple variational problems, first and second variation formulas. Euler-Lagrange equation, direct methods, optimal control.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Functional Analysis (3)
desc: Linear topological spaces, normed spaces, Hilbert spaces, function algebras, operator theory. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Theory of Functions of a Real Variable (3)
desc: Continuation of 631. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 631.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Theory of Functions of a Real Variable (3)
desc: Lebesgue measure and integral, convergence of integrals, functions of bounded variation, Lebesgue-Stieltjes integral and more general theory of measure and integration. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 631–632.)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Differentiable Manifolds I (3)
desc: Differentiable structures on manifolds, tensor fields, Frobenius theorem, exterior algebra, integration of forms, Poincare Lemma, Stoke’s theorem.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Geometric Group Theory (3)
desc: Geometric, topological, and dynamical methods in the study of finitely generated infinite groups. Graduate students only. Pre: 621 (with a minimum grade of B-).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Topology (3)
desc: Continuation of 621. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 621.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Topology (3)
desc: Properties of topological spaces; separation axioms, compactness, connectedness; metrizability; convergence and continuity. Additional topics from general and algebraic topology. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 621–622.)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Universal Algebra (3)
desc: Introduction to basic techniques, including subalgebras, congruences, automorphisms and endomorphisms, varieties of algebras, Mal’cev conditions.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Lattice Theory (3)
desc: Introduction with applications to general algebra. Partially ordered sets, decomposition theory, representations of lattices, varieties and free lattices, coordinatization of modular lattices.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Ring Theory (3)
desc: Ideal theory in Noetherian rings, localization, Dedekind domains, the Jacobson radical, the Wedderburn-Artin theorem, additional topics.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Group Theory (3)
desc: Sylow theorems, solvable groups, nilpotent groups, extension theory, representation theory, additional topics.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Modern Algebra (3)
desc: Continuation of 611. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 611.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Modern Algebra (3)
desc: Modules, Sylow theorems, Jordan-Holder theorem, unique factorization domains, Galois theory, algebraic closures, transcendence bases. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 611–612.)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Numerical Analysis (3)
desc: Numerical linear algebra including iterative methods, SVD, and other matrix factorizations, locating eigenvalues, discrete approximation to partial differential equations. Recommended: 407, 411, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Partial Differential Equations (3)
desc: Classical existence and uniqueness theory for PDEs, qualitative properties, classification, boundary value and initial value problems, fundamental solutions, other topics.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Methods of Applied Mathematics (3)
desc:
Linear algebra, ordinary differential equations, and partial differential equations. Topics include spectral theory, matrix exponentiation, initial-value problems, dynamical systems, bifurcation theory, first-order PDEs, 
characteristics, Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary-value problems, Green’s functions.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Applied Dynamical Systems (3)
desc: Continuous and discrete dynamical systems; bifurcation theory; chaotic maps. Additional topics from PDEs and linear algebra. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Problem Solving for Teachers (1)
desc: Practicing teachers develop and improve their problem-solving skills by working on challenging mathematical tasks. Students improve their mathematics content knowledge by working on problems and learning to design challenge problems for their own classes. Practicing teachers in grades K-12 only. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. All 600-courses prerequisites graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Limited to advanced students who must arrange with an instructor before enrolling. Repeatable one time, up to six credits.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Mathematical Biology Seminar (1)
desc: Reports on research in mathematical biology, reviews of literature, and research presentation. Required for Certificate in Mathematical Biology. Repeatable one time. Pre: junior standing or higher and consent. (Cross-listed as BIOL 490)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Senior Seminar (2)
desc: Seminar for senior mathematics majors, including an introduction to methods of research. Significant portion of class time is dedicated to the instruction and critique of oral presentations. All students must give the equivalent of three presentations. CR/NC only. Pre: one 400-level mathematics course or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Combinatorial Mathematics (3)
desc: Finite configurations. Topics may include counting methods, generating functions, graph theory, map coloring, block design, network flows, analysis of discrete algorithms. Pre: 311 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Statistical Inference (3)
desc: Sampling and parameter estimation, tests of hypotheses, correlation, regression, analysis of variance, sequential analysis, rank order statistics. Pre: 471 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Probability (3)
desc: Probability spaces, random variables, distributions, expectations, moment-generating and characteristic functions, limit theorems. Continuous probability emphasized. Pre: 244 (or concurrent) or 253A (or concurrent), or consent. Recommended: 305 or 371 or 372; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Mathematical Logic (3)
desc: A system of first order logic. Formal notions of well-formed formula, proof, and derivability. Semantic notions of model, truth, and validity. Completeness theorem. Pre: 321 or graduate standing in a related field or consent. Recommended: 454.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Axiomatic Set Theory (3)
desc: Sets, relations, ordinal arithmetic, cardinal arithmetic, axiomatic set theory, axiom of choice and the continuum hypothesis. Pre: 321 or graduate standing in a related field or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Topics in Undergraduate Mathematics (3)
desc: Advanced topics from various areas: algebra, number theory, analysis, and geometry. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Complex Analysis (3)
desc: Analytic functions, complex integration, introduction to conformal mapping. Pre: 244 or 253A; recommended 331; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Differential Geometry (3)
desc: Properties and fundamental geometric invariants of curves and surfaces in space; applications to the physical sciences. Pre: 244 or 253A, and 311; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Vector Analysis (3)
desc: Vector operations, wedge product, differential forms, and smooth mappings. Theorems of Green, Stokes, and Gauss, both classically and in terms of forms. Applications to electromagnetism and mechanics. Pre: 244 or 253A, and 307 or 311, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Principles of Analysis II (3)
desc: Continuation of 431. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 431. Emphasis on writing instruction continues. Pre: 431 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Principles of Analysis I (3)
desc: Topology of Rn , metric spaces, continuous functions, Riemann integration, sequences and series, uniform convergence, implicit function theorems, differentials and Jacobians. Emphasis on teaching mathematical writing. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 431–432.) Pre: 311, 321, and 331; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Topology (3)
desc: General topology, including compactness and connectedness; the Jordan Curve Theorem and the classification of surfaces; first homotopy or homology groups. Pre: 321 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to the Theory of Numbers (3)
desc: Congruences, quadratic residues, arithmetic functions, distribution of primes. Emphasis is on teaching theory and writing, not on computation. Pre: 321 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Optimization: Theory & Methods (3)
desc: Introduction to theory and methods for optimization. Topics may include least square analysis, search methods, conjugate direction methods, linear programming, integer programming, and constrained optimization. Pre: 243 or 253A, and 307 or 311; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra (3)
desc: Continuation of 412. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 412. Emphasis on writing instruction. Pre: 412 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra (3)
desc: Introduction to basic algebraic structures. Groups, finite groups, abelian groups, rings, integral domains, fields, factorization, polynomial rings, field extensions, quotient fields. Emphasis on writing instruction. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 412–413.) Pre: 311 and 321; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Linear Algebra (3)
desc: Vector spaces over arbitrary fields, minimal polynomials, invariant subspaces, canonical forms of matrices; unitary and Hermitian matrices, quadratic forms. Pre: 307 or 311, and 321; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Numerical Analysis (3)
desc: Continuation of 407. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 407. Pre: 407 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Numerical Analysis (3)
desc: Numerical solution of equations, interpolation, least-squares approximation, quadrature, eigenvalue problems, numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 407–408.) Pre: 243 or 253A, and 307 or 311, and one semester programming; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Ordinary Differential Equations (3)
desc: Systems of linear ordinary differential equations, autonomous systems, and stability theory applications. Optional topics include series solutions, Sturm theory, numerical methods. Pre: 302 and 311, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Partial Differential Equations II (3)
desc: Laplace’s equation, Fourier transform methods for PDEs, higher dimensional PDEs, spherical harmonics, Laplace series, special functions and applications. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Partial Differential Equations I (3)
desc: Integral surfaces and characteristics of first and second order partial differential equations. Applications to the equations of mathematical physics. Pre: 243 or 253A, or consent. Recommended: 244 and 302.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Elementary Statistics (3)
desc: Estimation, tests of significance, the concept of power. Pre: 371 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Elementary Probability and Statistics (3)
desc: Problem-oriented introduction to the basic concepts of probability and statistics, providing a foundation for applications and further study. Pre: 216 or 242 or 252A or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Elementary Probability Theory (3)
desc: Sets, discrete sample spaces, problems in combinatorial probability, random variables, mathematical expectations, classical distributions, applications. Pre: 216, 242, or 252A; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Non-Euclidean Geometries (3)
desc: Hyperbolic, other non-Euclidean geometries. Pre: 351 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Foundation of Euclidean Geometry (3)
desc: Axiomatic Euclidean geometry and introduction to the axiomatic method. Pre: 243 or 253A, and 321 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Real Analysis (3)
desc: A rigorous axiomatic development of one variable calculus. Completeness, topology of the line, limits, continuity, differentiation, integration. Emphasis on teaching mathematical writing. Pre: 242 or 252A, and 321; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Advanced Mathematics (3)
desc: Formal introduction to the concepts of logic, finite and infinite sets, functions, methods of proof and axiomatic systems. Learning mathematical expressions in writing is an integral part of the course. Pre: 243 (or concurrent) or 253A (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Linear Algebra (3)
desc: Algebra of matrices, linear equations, real vector spaces and transformations. Emphasis on concepts and abstraction and instruction of careful writing. Students may receive credit for only one of 307 or 311. Pre: 242 or 252A, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Linear Algebra and Differential Equations (3)
desc: Introduction to linear algebra, application of eigenvalue techniques to the solution of differential equations. Students may receive credit for only one of 307 or 311. Pre: 242 or 252A, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Mathematical Modeling: Probabilistic Models Lab (1)
desc: Optional laboratory for 305. Pre: 305 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Mathematical Modeling: Probabilistic Models (3)
desc: Probabilistic mathematical modeling emphasizing models and tools used in the biological sciences. Topics include stochastic and Poisson processes, Markov models, estimation, and Monte Carlo simulation. A computer lab may be taken concurrently. Pre: 216 or 242 or 252A, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Mathematical Modeling: Deterministic Models Lab (1)
desc: Optional laboratory for 304. Pre: 304 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Mathematical Modeling: Deterministic Models (3)
desc: Deterministic mathematical modeling emphasizing models and tools used in the biological sciences. Topics include difference equations, qualitative behavior solutions of ODEs and reaction-diffusion equations. A computer lab may be taken concurrently. Pre: 216 or 242 or 252A, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Differential Equations II (3)
desc: Constant coefficient linear systems, variable coefficient ordinary differential equations, series solutions and special functions, Fourier series, partial differential equations. Pre: 302, 311 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Differential Equations I (3)
desc: First order ordinary differential equations, constant coefficient linear equations, oscillations, Laplace transform, convolution, Green’s function. Pre: 216 or 243 (or concurrent) or 253A (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Discrete Mathematics (3)
desc: Symbolic logic, sets and relations, algorithms, trees and other graphs. Additional topics chosen from algebraic systems, networks, automata. Pre: one semester of calculus from mathematics department; or consent. Recommended: one semester programming.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: History of Mathematics (3)
desc: The historical development of mathematical thought. Pre: 216 or 242 or 252A.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Accelerated Calculus III (4)
desc: Vector calculus; maxima and minima in several variables; multiple integrals; line integrals, surface integrals and their applications. Pre: 252A.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Mathematics (MATH) Office of Student Success

subject: MATH
title: Accelerated Calculus II (4)
desc: Integration techniques and applications, series and approximations, differential equations, introduction to vectors. Pre: 251A (with a minimum grade of B) or 241 (with a minimum grade of A and consent).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Mathematics (MATH) Office of Student Success

subject: MATH
title: Accelerated Calculus I (4)
desc: Basic concepts; differentiation with applications; integration. Compared to 241, topics are discussed in greater depth. Pre: assessment and consent, or a grade of A in 140X and consent.
metadata: FQ College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Mathematics (MATH) Office of Student Success

subject: MATH
title: Calculus IV (3)
desc: Multiple integrals; line integrals and Green’s Theorem; surface integrals, Stokes’s and Gauss’s Theorems. Pre: 243 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Calculus III (3)
desc: Vector algebra, vector-valued functions, differentiation in several variables, and optimization. Pre: 242 or 252A, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Calculus II (4)
desc: Integration techniques and applications, series and approximations, differential equations. Pre: 241 or 251A or a grade of B or better in 215; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Calculus I (4)
desc: Basic concepts; differentiation with applications; integration. Pre: 140X or 215 or placement exam.
metadata: FQ College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Applied Calculus II (3)
desc: Differential calculus for functions in several variables and curves, systems of ordinary differential equations, series approximation of functions, continuous probability, exposure to use of calculus in the literature. Pre: 215 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Applied Calculus I (4)
desc: Basic concepts; differentiation, differential equations and integration with applications directed primarily to the life sciences. Pre: 140X or placement exam
metadata: FQ College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Calculus for Business and Social Sciences (3)
desc: Basic concepts; differentiation and integration applications to management, finance, economics, and the social sciences. Pre: 134 or 161 or placement exam.
metadata: FQ College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Programming (2)
desc: (3 hr) Introduction to numerical algorithms and structured programming using Fortran, MATLAB, or other appropriate language. Pre: one semester of calculus (203, 215, 241, 242, 243, 244, 251A, 252A, or 253A) (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Precalculus and Elements of Calculus for Economics and the Social Sciences (3)
desc: Algebra review, functions with special attention to polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions, algebra of functions, techniques of graphing, differentiation and integration of algebraic functions, applications in economics and social sciences. A-F only.
metadata: FQ College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Precalculus (4)
desc: Algebra review. Polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic  functions, composed and inverse functions, techniques of graphing. Trigonometric functions, analytic geometry, polar coordinates, vectors, and related topics. Pre: 134 or 161 or placement exam.
metadata: FQ College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Precalculus: Elementary Functions (3)
desc: Algebra review, functions with special attention to polynomial, rational exponential and logarithmic functions, composed and inverse functions, techniques of graphing. A-F only. Pre: two years of high school algebra, one year of plane geometry.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Math for Elementary Teachers II (3)
desc: Understanding, communicating, and representing mathematical ideas; problem solving; reasoning and proof; and using symbolism. Patterns and algebraic thinking, place value and decimals, geometry, and mathematical modeling. Pre: 111.
metadata: FQ College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Math for Elementary Teachers I (3)
desc: Understanding, communicating, and representing mathematical ideas, problem solving, and reasoning. Number systems, place value, fractions, and properties of operations. Prospective elementary education majors only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MATH
title: Survey of Mathematics (3)
desc: Selected topics designed to acquaint nonspecialists with examples of mathematical reasoning. May not be taken for credit after 215 or higher.
metadata: FQ College of Natural Sciences Mathematics (MATH)

subject: MKT
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in an area of marketing under the direction of faculty member(s). A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in international management or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Seminar in Selected Marketing Topics (3)
desc: Selected topics in any aspect of marketing to increase exposure to the range of issues researchers commonly confront. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in business administration or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Seminar in Marketing Strategy (3)
desc: Focuses on theories of strategic marketing and planning. Explores the theoretical principles of marketing concepts, tools, and processes that can be used to help an organization develop a sustainable competitive advantage. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in business administration or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Seminar in Consumer Behavior (3)
desc: Focuses on consumer behavior theory. Provides in-depth review of important published work in traditional and cross-cultural consumer behavior fields. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in business administration or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Seminar in Marketing Theory (3)
desc: Focuses on the building blocks of theory, their use, and evolution within a marketing context. Explores marketing theories, theory construction, and the creation of marketing knowledge. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in business administration or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Advanced Seminar in Marketing (3)
desc: Significant topics, problems in marketing. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: BUS 623 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Patient Centered Communication Management in Health Care Organizations (3)
desc: Provides training on managing patient communications in general and shared decision making in particular. Increases ability to use tools available to improve patient-provider decision making quality and satisfaction. A-F only. Pre: BUS 623.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Digital Marketing Management (3)
desc: Examines digital marketing’s role in new product development; direct sales; marketing communications via the internet, social media, and mobile devices; and digital tools such as online tracking and analysis. Real activities provide opportunities for application. A-F only. Pre: BUS 623 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Services Marketing (3)
desc: Conceptual understanding of distinctive aspects of services, services management, and services research. Pre: BUS 623 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Creativity in Marketing (3)
desc: Thought processes that relate to creativity. Through a series of exercises, students experience enriched creativity and enhanced communication skills. Pre: BUS 623 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Marketing Research Management (3)
desc: Examines use of marketing research/data analytics to support marketing management. Topics include: research process; survey design; sampling; measurement; primary data analysis; customer data analytics; digital media analytics. Real world project reinforce learning. Pre: BUS 621, BUS 623, or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Strategic Brand Management (3)
desc: The study of branding and brand management. Explores how managers can formulate and implement integrated marketing strategies to build brand equity. Includes relevant theory and real world applications. Pre: BUS 623 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: International Marketing Management (3)
desc: Integrated and comparative approach to international marketing management. Emphasis on the development of a competitive strategy in a global environment. Applications to both developing and industrialized markets. Pre: BUS 623 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Japanese Marketing Systems (3)
desc: Specialized study of Japanese marketing systems, considers both global and domestic marketing activities in the context of the Japanese economy. Pre: BUS 623 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Advanced Marketing Management (3)
desc: A case course in the application of advanced marketing methods. Pre: BUS 623 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Sales Leadership (3)
desc: Sales managers participate in diverse activities including hiring, designing and implementing training programs, in-field coaching and development, motivating and compensating employees, and team building. Helps students develop knowledge and skills in these areas. A-F only. Graduate students only. Pre: BUS 623 or consent of instructor. (Alt. years)
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Consumer Behavior for Managers (3)
desc: Designed to help students better understand how consumers process information, form attitudes, and make decisions. Draws on theories from social sciences to help students manage consumer needs and satisfaction. A-F only. Graduate students only. Pre: BUS 623 or consent of instructor. (Alt. years)
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Imagination, Entrepreneurship and Business Problem-Solving (3)
desc: Application of creative process to problems encountered in venture creation/growth. Student problem-solving styles are characterized and implications drawn for generation of breakthrough ideas. Tools for facilitating creative solutions to marketing problems are investigated. Pre: junior standing and BUS 312; or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Marketing Analytics (3)
desc: Introduces current quantitative techniques and analytical approaches to better marketing decision-making. Students learn how to solve problems in a data-driven way using software tools. A-F only. Pre: BUS 310 and BUS 312; or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in a special area of major under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and the faculty advisor. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Marketing Strategies (3)
desc: Decision-making by the marketing executive; integration of all elements of the marketing program based on actual business situations. Pre: 311, 321; or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: International Marketing (3)
desc: Principles and topics related to international marketing, with emphasis on strategic planning and applications. Pre: BUS 312 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Marketing for New Ventures (3)
desc: Examines role of marketing in the formation and launch of entrepreneurial ventures within and outside of ongoing businesses. Emphasis on new product development and low cost, high impact marketing activities. Pre: BUS 312 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Customer Relationship Management (3)
desc: Focuses on the evolving field of customer relationship management. Students learn how to manage marketing information and decision-making systems that maximize customer retention and build long-term relationships. A-F only. Pre: BUS 311, or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Digital Marketing (3)
desc: Provides comprehensive understanding of digital marketing’s growing role in new product development; marketing research; direct sales; and marketing communications. Students learn multiple digital tools for analysis of customer behavior. Real-world projects provide opportunities for application. Pre: BUS 311 and BUS 312, or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Seminar in Marketing (3)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems in the field of marketing. May be repeated four times with change in topic. Pre: consent and usually senior standing.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Sales and Sales Management (3)
desc: Delves into selling and the sales management process. Through a variety of activities, students experience applying selling techniques, sales planning, recruiting and training salespeople, methods of motivating and compensating, territory management and sales team communications. Pre: BUS 312 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Professional Selling (3)
desc: Emphasis on selling technique, social-psychological principles of persuasion, and interpersonal communication. Lecture, discussion, and application of relevant principles and techniques. A-F only. Pre: BUS 312 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Retailing Management (3)
desc: Analysis of opportunities and challenges in physical and digital retailing management: physical layout and digital design; merchandise planning; organizational forms; expense analysis; integration of physical/digital programs. Pre: BUS 312 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Integrated Communication Campaigns (3)
desc: Management of integrated marketing communications campaigns. Includes: conducting target market and competitor research, developing creative content and media strategies, production of communication materials and completion of major real world project. Pre: 331 and BUS 312.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Marketing Communications (3)
desc: In-depth coverage of the major communication tools used in marketing such as advertising, sales promotion, public relations and the internet. Emphasis on integrated marketing communications. Pre: BUS 312 or consent.
metadata: Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Marketing Research and Data Analytics (3)
desc: Use of marketing research and marketing management and data analytics to support marketing management. Topics include: the research process; survey design; sampling; measurement; primary data analysis; customer data analytics; and digital media analytics. Pre: BUS 310 and BUS 312, or consent.
metadata: DS Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MKT
title: Consumer Behavior (3)
desc: Analysis of consumer behavior and motivation; principles of learning, personality, perception, and group influence, with emphasis upon mass communication effects. Pre: BUS 312 or consent. (Cross-listed as PSY 385)
metadata: DS Marketing (MKT) Shidler College of Business

subject: MBIO
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Advanced Topics in Quantitative Biology (V)
desc: Reflects faculty expertise and needs for graduate training in quantitative methods for biology, including statistical, computational, and analytic approaches. Format (lecture/lab/discussion) will vary by topic. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Topics in Marine Physiology, Behavior, and Organismal Biology (V)
desc: Lecture, discussion, and/or projects on selected topics related to the physiology, behavior, and biology of marine organisms. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Topics in Marine Education, Outreach, and Policy (V)
desc: Lecture, discussion, and/or projects on selected topics related to education, outreach, and policy of the marine environment. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Topics in Marine Conservation Biology (V)
desc: Lecture, discussion, and/or projects on selected topics related to marine conservation biology. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Topics in Marine Fisheries and Natural Resource Management (V)
desc: Lecture, discussion, and/or projects on selected topics related to marine fisheries and natural resource management. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis; (F) 1 credit. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only. Satisfactory/ Unsatisfactory only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Directed research and reading in various fields of marine biology. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Seminar in Marine Biology (1)
desc: Marine biology topics, literature, and concepts of current interest within one of several active fields considered in detail; (B) general marine biology; (C) marine fisheries and natural resource management; (D) marine conservation biology; (E) marine education, outreach and policy; (F) marine physiology, behavior and organismal biology; (G) marine population biology and ecology; (H) marine community and ecosystem ecology; (I) professional development for marine biologists; (J) seminar at HIMB. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Introduction to Quantitative Methods in Fisheries Science (4)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Fisheries and population models including growth, stock-recruitment, surplus production, age-structured and size-based, parameter estimation, uncertainty characterization, resampling methods, and scientific computing. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: MATH 215 or 216, or MATH 241 or 242, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Current Research in Marine Biology (1)
desc: Discussions with marine biology graduate faculty on current primary literature in marine biology. MBIO majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MBIO
title: Career Skills for Marine Biologists (1)
desc: Introduction to key professional skills including, but not limited to: grant writing, CV preparation, research logistics, data management, reproducible science, peer review, research ethics, publishing, career options, teaching, and professional presentations. MBIO majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Marine Biology (MBIO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: MAO
title: Fourth-Level Maori II (3)
desc: Continuation of 401. Conducted in Maori. Advanced reading, writing, and conversation. Cultural contemporary and historical topics. Pre: 401 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Fourth-Level Maori I (3)
desc: Continuation of 302. Conducted in Maori. Advanced reading, writing, and conversation. Cultural contemporary and historical topics. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Te Reo Waiata: Maori Language in Song (3)
desc: Survey and analysis of Maori song poetry texts, traditional and contemporary, and their development and performance over time. Pre: 102 or HAW 202, or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Modern Maori Literature and Culture (3)
desc: Survey of modern Maori and Hawaiian literature and culture from the mid-twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. Pre: 261 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Advanced Maori Language and Culture (3)
desc: Advanced Maori language and culture. Pre: 301. (Spring only)
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Advanced Maori Language and Culture (3)
desc: Advanced Maori language and culture. Pre: 202, no waiver. (Fall only)
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Maori Literature and Culture (3)
desc: Survey of literature concerning myths, traditions, poetry and song as well as contemporary literature (in English) relating to the Treaty of Waitangi, Maori prophetic sayings. Students who have previously taken this course as PACS 492 may not take this course. Pre: consent.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Intermediate Maori II (3)
desc: Continuation of 201. Meets three hours weekly. Pre: 201.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Intermediate Maori I (3)
desc: Continuation of 102. Meets three hours weekly. Pre: 102.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Beginning Maori II (3)
desc: Continuation of 101. Meets three hours weekly. Pre: 101.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MAO
title: Beginning Maori I (3)
desc: Listening, speaking, reading, writing, grammar. Meets three hours weekly.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Maori (MAO)

subject: MGT
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in an area of management under the direction of faculty member(s). Repeatable unlimited times for PhD students. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in international management or consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: PhD Seminar–Corporate Strategy and International Business (3)
desc: Objectives include: explore research topics in corporate strategy and international business, examine conceptual and empirical literature on management of the multinational corporation, and prepare students for comprehensive examination. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in international management or consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Cross-Cultural Management (3)
desc: Provides tools to compare and contrast management practices across nations and to examine the role of culture in shaping those practices. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in international management or consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Health Policy, Systems, and the Legal Environment (3)
desc: Covers health care policy topics including: analyzing health service needs, access, use, disparities; health professional supply; policy issues for health organizations; health care financing policy; health law/ethical issues. A-F only. Pre: BUS 622 and BUS 627. (Alt. years)
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Asian/Pacific Entrepreneurship (3)
desc: Innovative ventures, issues related to noticing opportunities, conceptualizing and developing a business model, starting and growing a new venture with specific emphasis on the Asian/Pacific region. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Entrepreneurship for Science and Technology (3)
desc: Recognizing and screening technology opportunities, the commercialization process, intellectual property acquisition, business model related to high technology strategies needed for growth in high tech firms. A-F only. Pre: 645 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: International Strategic Management (3)
desc: Analysis of the strategic management of firms engaged in multinational business including specific content on Asia. Permits students to focus on specific countries such as China and Japan. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: (Alpha) International Management and Industrial Relations (3)
desc: Selected topics in international management and industrial relations: (B) Chinese management systems; (C) Japanese management systems; (D) management of multinational corporations; (F) contemporary issues in international business foreign direct investment; (G) cross-cultural communication in international business; (H) interactive strategies in Asian culture; (I) international human resource management; (J) international joint ventures; (K) international management of technology; (M) Korean management systems; (N) multinational corporation and environmental issues; (O) strategy of the multinational corporation; (P) international transfer of technology. Repeatable four times per alpha. MBA or MAcc students only (except for (D). Pre: consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Negotiation (3)
desc: Theory and practice of negotiation. Exploration of appropriate strategies, tactics, and communication techniques. Study of dyadic multi-party, cross-cultural, and assisted negotiations. (Cross-listed as CEE 673)
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Corporate Entrepreneurship (3)
desc: Entrepreneurship behavior involving the founding of new business units within established companies; understanding and dealing with barriers to entrepreneurship in corporations; recognizing corporate entrepreneurship opportunities; and learning various approaches organizations can take to increase entrepreneurship. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Management Topics (3)
desc: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and trends in administration. May be repeated four times with change in topic. Pre: consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: International Business: Environment and Enterprise (3)
desc: Survey of the environment of international business with theory and policy focusing on strategic planning, international management and operational issues confronting the multinational corporations in the global environment. MBA or MAcc students only.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: New Venture Management (3)
desc: Technical aspects of entrepreneurship, components and requirements for developing a business plan.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Comparative Management (3)
desc: Cross-cultural analysis of the values and environmental constraints that shape management patterns and policies. Emphasis on Pacific area nations. MBA or MAcc students only.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: (Alpha) Advanced Organizational Behavior (3)
desc: (B) experiential learning (EL); (C) organizational development (OD) and major concepts in organizational behavior. MBA or MAcc students only.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Corporate Entrepreneurship (3)
desc: Exploration of the nature and role of entrepreneurship behavior inside larger, established organizations. An examination of obstacles to entrepreneurial activity and approaches to creating work environments that foster entrepreneurship. Pre: 320 or consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Asia Pacific Business Systems (3)
desc: Business systems in Asia Pacific countries including Japan, Korea, China, Taiwan, Singapore, and Hong Kong in terms of particular organization strategies and how they relate to the industrial trade policies. Pre: BBA core excluding BUS 345, or consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Family Business (3)
desc: The exploration of business, personal, and interpersonal issues associated with a family owned and managed company. Topics include: family psychology and organizational structure, life cycles in family business, strategic family and business planning, succession planning, family business conflict resolution, estate planning, the role of professional managers, and others. This is not a course about how to become an entrepreneur or how to start or manage a business. It is most appropriate for those students who are part of a family that owns and manages a business. Pre: BUS 315 or graduate status, or consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in a special area within the major field under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and faculty advisor. Repeatable up to six credits.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: History of American Business (3)
desc: The evolution of business enterprise from colonial times to the present. Emphasis on entrepreneurship, technological change, labor-management relations, government-business relations, and economic thought. Case studies of industrial development. (Cross-listed as HIST 378)
metadata: DH Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Entrepreneurial Ventures (3)
desc: Integrative course in entrepreneurship designed around the development of an original business concept and the completion of a comprehensive business plan for a new venture. Intended as final course for students completing entrepreneurship minor. Pre: 320 or consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Seminar in Management (3)
desc: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and trends in administration. May be repeated with change in topic. Pre: consent.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Comparative Management Systems: United States and Japan (3)
desc: Similarities and differences in managers, in process of management, and in relevant environmental constraints in Japan and the U.S. Pre: BUS 315.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Multinational Business Management (3)
desc: Introduction to the unique problems and challenges in managing multinational business enterprises. Systems approach to the management process in such multinational firms stressed. Pre: BUS 315.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Behavior in Organizations (3)
desc: Contributions made by sociology, psychology, and related behavioral sciences to the understanding and prediction of human behavior in organizations. Pre: BUS 315.
metadata: DS Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: MGT
title: Fundamentals of Entrepreneurship (3)
desc: Covers the role of new ventures and entrepreneurship in the world economy, the formation, funding, marketing, structure and implementation of business ventures.
metadata: Management (MGT) Management and Industrial Relations Shidler College of Business

subject: LING
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Apprenticeship in Teaching Linguistics (V)
desc: Experience-based introduction to college-level teaching; doctoral students serve as student teachers to professors; responsibilities include supervised teaching and participation in planning and evaluation. Repeatable one time. Pre: admission to doctoral program and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Areal Linguistics (3)
desc: Structures of languages of various areas of the world; diffusion. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: (Alpha) Seminar (3)
desc: Reporting and discussion of current research in linguistics. (E) ethnolinguistics; (F) phonology and phonetics; (G) general; (M) semantics; (Q) language acquisition; (R) written language; (S) sociolinguistics; (X) syntax; (Y) psycholinguistics. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Advanced Laboratory Research (3)
desc: Advanced laboratory methods for research in linguistics. Specialized and/or advanced uses of hardware, software, research designs, and analysis techniques. Specific topic varies: check with department. Combines lecture, laboratory work and discussion. Repeatable four times. Pre: 632 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Language Typology (3)
desc: Language typology deals with how and why the elements of language interact and function. Students acquire a broad overview of this grammatical make-up of languages in general and understanding of FunctionalTypological linguistics. Graduate students only. Pre: 320 and 422 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Techniques of Language Documentation (3)
desc: Students learn to conduct best practice digital language documentation projects, from equipment purchase to data collection to data annotation to archiving and presentation. Pre: 680 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to 12 credit hours.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: CR/NC only. Repeatable unlimited times. Maximum six credit hours. Pre: graduate standing and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Language Documentation (3)
desc: Covers history, method, and theory behind language documentation, and the role of language endangerment in the field. Discussion on skills required to undertake documentation; topics may vary depending on the emphases of the instructor. Pre: 320 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Developmental Linguistics (3)
desc: Survey of the literature in language acquisition; emphasis on relation to linguistic theory. Pre: 421 and 422, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Issues in Historical Linguistics (3)
desc: Continuation of 645. Addresses advanced topics in historical linguistics that have generated controversy rather than consensus. Pre: 645. Repeatable two times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: The Comparative Method (3)
desc: Introduction to historical-comparative linguistics; attention to both Indo-European and languages with few or no written records. Pre: 421 and 422, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: (Alpha) Topics in Linguistics (3)
desc: History of the discipline, schools of linguistic thought, current issues, etc. Repeatable unlimited times. (E) English linguistics; (F) phonology and phonetics; (G) general; (H) history of the discipline; (S) sociolinguistics; (X) syntax; (Y) psycholinguistics. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Hawai‘i Sign Language Linguistics: Documentation, Conservation, and Revitalization of HSL (3)
desc: Descriptive information on the phonological, morphological, and syntactic structures and lexicon of Hawai‘i Sign Language (HSL); language skills development in HSL; and guided research related to the documentation, conservation, and revitalization of HSL. Graduate students only. Pre: 320 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Linguistics of Sign Languages (3)
desc: Universals and uniqueness in the phonological, morphological, and syntactic structures of sign languages, taught inductively with emphasis on hands-on analysis. Opportunities exist for skills development in American or Ho Chi Minh City sign languages. Graduate students only. Pre: 320 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Laboratory and Quantitative Research Methods (3)
desc: Laboratory and quantitative methods for research on language. Introduction to hardware, software, research designs, and basic analysis techniques commonly used in quantitative language research. Combines lecture, laboratory work ,and discussion. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Language Data Processing (3)
desc: Preparation of language data for computer processing; use ready-made programs; write simple language processing programs using SNOBOL4. Applications to student’s research. Pre: 421 and 422, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Field Methods (3)
desc: Work with native speakers of lesser-known languages to develop techniques for data collection and analysis. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: 421 and 422 and one of 621 or 622; or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Discourse and Grammar (3)
desc: Usage-based examination of grammar in the context of spontaneous spoken language, including the role of discourse on synchronic and diachronic grammatical structure, discourse in interaction, and discourse in language documentation. Pre: 622 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Semantics and Pragmatics (3)
desc: Ways in which the interpretation of sentences in natural language depends upon the literal meaning of propositions and their logical (semantic) and conversational (pragmatic) inferences. Pre: 422 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Grammar (3)
desc: Grammatical theory and problems of analysis. Pre: 422 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Phonology (3)
desc: Phonological theory and problems of analysis. Pre: 421 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Practical Exercises in Data Science for Linguistic Research (1)
desc: Exercises in data science for linguistic research. Repeatable one time. Pre: 421 or 422, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Data Science for Linguistic Research (2)
desc: Introduction to data science for linguistic research. Repeatable one time. Pre: 421 or 422, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Language Acquisition and Language Revitalization (3)
desc: Provides training relevant to the study and revitalization of heritage languages and endangered languages. Pre: 320 or equivalent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: The Nature of Language (3)
desc: Language as a communication system, current theories of grammar, meaning, sociolinguistics, linguistic change and comparison.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Acoustic and Auditory Phonetics (3)
desc: Principles of acoustics and audition as they relate to speech sounds, use of computer-based analysis tools to investigate acoustic properties of speech. Pre: 421 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to 3 credits. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Children’s Speech (3)
desc: Child language acquisition, language milestones, multilingualism. Relation of cognitive development to language development. Emphasis on developing research skills, with an emphasis on written communication. Pre: 320.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Induction of Linguistic Structure (3)
desc: Phonological and grammatical structures of a previously uncodified language are determined by linguistic analysis of data obtained from speakers of the language. Pre: 102 or 320, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Polynesian Language Family (3)
desc: Introduction to the language family of Hawaiian, Samoan, Tahitian, Tongan, etc.; models of migration and settlement and linguistic evidence; subgrouping and reconstruction of Proto-Polynesian; linguistic characteristics of present-day languages; language endangerment and conservation in Polynesia. Pre: 320 with a grade of B or better, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Meaning (3)
desc: Theories of how literal and figurative language encode meaning and processes of meaning encoding and decoding. Open to non-majors. Pre: 102, 320, ICS 111, or PSY 100; or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Computational Modeling (3)
desc: Hands-on introduction to modeling language. Focuses on connectionism, relations between language perception,and motor control. Requires no programming experience. Open to non-majors. Pre: 102, 320, ICS 111, or PSY 100; or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Animal Communication (3)
desc: Investigates animal communication from the perspective of modern linguistics. Dispels common misconceptions about “talking animals” and shows how the cognitive, biological, and environmental needs and opportunities of animals determine what and how they communicate. Pre: 102 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Cognitive Linguistics (3)
desc: Conceptual systems and language from a cognitive science perspective. Linguistic evidence on conceptual structure, reasoning, categorization, and understanding. Open to non-majors. Pre: 102, 320, ICS 111, or PSY 100; or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Grammatical Analysis (3)
desc: Syntactic analysis and grammatical theory. Pre: 320 or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Phonological Analysis (3)
desc: Phonological analysis and theory. Pre: 410.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Morphology (3)
desc: Theory of word structure; analysis of a variety of morphological types. Pre: 320 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Language as a Public Concern (3)
desc: How does language serve as a proxy for larger social questions? Focuses on four main themes: language revitalization, discrimination on the basis of accent, gender miscommunication and the English Only Movement. A-F only. Pre: 102 or 320 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Language and Gender (3)
desc: The role of language in the construction of gender and in the maintenance of the gender order. Field projects explore hypotheses about the interaction of language and gender. No previous knowledge of linguistics required. A-F only. (Cross-listed as ANTH 413)
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Linguistic Anthropology (3)
desc: Introduction to the ethnographic study of speech and language. Pre: ANTH 152. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ANTH 414 and IS 414)
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Psycholinguistics (3)
desc: The mental processes involved in producing, understanding, and acquiring language. Students will conduct a small psycholinguistic experiment. Open to non-majors. Pre: one of 102, 320, or PSY 100; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Articulatory Phonetics (3)
desc: Intensive training in recognition, reproduction, and recording of human speech sounds; preparation for fieldwork with unrecorded languages and for clinical work in speech pathology.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Pidgin and Creole Languages (3)
desc: Nature, history, structure, and geographic distribution of pidgins and creoles. Pre: 102 or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as IS 347)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: The Philippine Language Family (3)
desc: Introduction; phonological and grammatical systems; historical developments; emphasis on Filipino, Cebuano, and Ilokano. Pre: grade of B or better in 102 or 320 and experience with a Philippine language, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Languages of the World (3)
desc: Survey of major language families; typological classification and language universals; writing systems, “contact” languages. Variety of grammatical structures illustrated by selected languages. Pre: 320 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Computer Applications (3)
desc: Background; uses for machine translation, dictionary programs, speech synthesis, grammar modeling, etc. Pre: 320 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: General Linguistics (3)
desc: Introduction to the formal analysis of language, focusing on phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, historical linguistics, language acquisition, and related topics.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Language Documentation for NonLinguists (2)
desc: Provides training in the fundamentals of language documentation and conservation for non-linguists. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only. Pre: proficiency in a lesser studied language and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: The Language of Children (3)
desc: Survey of findings about the child’s acquisition of language.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: (Alpha) Language in Hawai‘i and the Pacific (3)
desc: Introduction to the study of language and language-related issues, with a focus on Hawai‘i and the Pacific; (B) unit mastery; (C) lecture discussion with focus on writing as a grading criterion. A-F only.
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Logic and Language (3)
desc: Introduces logic as a way of understanding the meanings of everyday words and sentences, as well as the inferences that humans draw from them. Topics include propositional logic, first-order logic, elementary set theory, and relations.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Language as a Window to the Mind (3)
desc: Introduction to language-related phenomena, which gives insight into the organization of the human mind. Combines lecture, discussion and group projects.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Language Endangerment, Globalization, and Indigenous Peoples (3)
desc: Focus on language endangerment and globalization. Students are introduced to case studies on language endangerment from around the world and throughout history. Offered through the distance-learning Unit Mastery program. A-F only.
metadata: FGB College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Language and Symbolic Reasoning (3)
desc: Introduction to language as a formal symbolic system and to the techniques of analysis and reasoning that reveal its workings. A-F only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LING
title: Introduction to the Study of Language (3)
desc: Non-formal introduction to language, emphasizing the everyday use of language, its relevance to contemporary issues in society, and local language issues. Content studied through lecture, readings, and writing; emphasis on writing as a grading criterion
metadata: DS College of Arts, Languages & Letters Linguistics (LING)

subject: LIS
title: Seminar in International Librarianship (3)
desc: International and comparative librarianship; professional organizations; comparative methodology; research; periodicals; international agencies; influence of literacy and social, cultural, political factors.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable nine times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Directed Reading and/or Research (V)
