desc: Individualized program of directed reading and/ or research outside the scope of regularly titled courses. Enrollment requires approval before end of previous semester, with specification of goals, work requirements, number of credits, rationale. Repeatable unlimited times, credit earned up to six credits.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Practicum School Librarianship (V)
desc: Skill development and application of academic study through observation and practice in a fieldwork program with accompanying seminar. Required for school library certification in Hawai‘i. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. LIS majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 12 credits in LIS degree program and consent of practicum coordinator required.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Special Topics in Information Technology (3)
desc: Includes issues of topical interest in information technology. Concentrates on one major topic of current interest, such as digital archives, content management systems and informatics. Some topics may require prior background or knowledge. Repeatable unlimited times if course content is different.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Special Topics in Information Studies (3)
desc: Includes issues of topical interest in the information professions. Concentrates on one major topic of current interest, such as services for specific groups and special collections. Some topics may require prior background or knowledge. Repeatable unlimited times if course content is different.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Masters Seminar (3)
desc: Seminar for graduating students focused on the refinement and completion of the culminating portfolio and preparation for professional practice. Peer mentoring and student presentations. MLISc degree Plan B required course. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Internship (V)
desc: Field experience in library or information agency settings with supervision of professional librarians or information specialists. Available to classified students only. Selection based on academic advisor approval, application form, interview and possession of required competencies. Students must apply and be accepted before registration. Selection is by agency. Repeatable up to six credits. CR/NC only. Pre: 601 and consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Information Literacy and Learning Resources (3)
desc: Process approach to teaching information retrieval, analysis, and use. Emphasizes concepts, practices ineffective instructional design, selection of resources that meets learning needs. Required for Librarian HDOE licensure. A-F only. (Cross-listed as EDCS 686 and LTEC 686)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Services in Public Libraries (3)
desc: Planning and implementing services and programming in public and school libraries. Trends, issues, networking, public relations, outreach, competencies, services for the disabled and other special groups.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Books and Media for Young Adults (3)
desc: History and criticism of literature for young adults. Contemporary books and media. Trends in media for young adults. Developmental needs and interests of adolescents. Selection and evaluation. Research studies.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Books and Media for Children (3)
desc: History and criticism of children’s literature. Contemporary books and media. Trends in book publishing and media production. Developmental needs and interests of children. Selection and evaluation. Research studies.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Human Dimension in Information Systems (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion on human element in information systems, including physical, cognitive and affective behavior in interaction with information systems. Information retrieval, human-computer interaction and cognitive science research, quantitative and qualitative research methods. Research component. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Creating Digital Libraries (3)
desc: Principles, techniques, and technologies supporting the creation of user-centered digital libraries. Selection, organization, maintenance, access, and retrieval of digital collections. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Database Design and Creation (3)
desc: Designing and creating textual and/or directory databases from the viewpoint of information specialists and content providers. Needs analysis, file design, record content and structuring, software choice. Students implement prototype database. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Media Technology and Resources (3)
desc: Overview of the use of media technology and the development of media collections and services in libraries. Use and integration of new emerging technologies, including problems and issues.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Technology for Libraries and Information Centers (3)
desc: Survey of theories, concepts, methods and practices relating to the application of information technology to support the administration and use of information resources. Includes digital, printed and audiovisual materials. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Digital Instruction (3)
desc: Study and application of principles and practices that influence digital instruction related to information literacy in libraries and other information environments. Focus on application of instructional design and standards-based outcome assessment. Field research component.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Asian Informatics (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion on the transformative effects of information and communication technologies in East Asia. Topics include media, mobile devices, social media, publishing, e-government, and e-commerce. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Informatics (3)
desc: Sociotechnical concepts and processes underlying information systems, services, and use. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Archival and Special Collections Management (3)
desc: Management of archives, manuscript collections, and special collections using approaches and best practices from archival studies. Topics include management theory, appraisal theory, facilities issues, privacy, intellectual property, records management, advocacy, fundraising, reference, and educational outreach. Graduate standing only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Records Management (3)
desc: Management of records in all media formats. Selection of media format based on government and internal records requirements. Problems associated with electronic media such as legality and shelf life.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Moving Image Archives (3)
desc: Principles and technologies of processing, preservation, and accessibility of archival audiovisual materials in moving image archives. Topics include moving image repositories, critical analysis of archival footage, format identification, digitization strategies, equipment, and vendor considerations. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Digital Archives (3)
desc: The role of technology in archival theory and practice. Topics include digital preservation, authenticity assessment, arrangement and description, content management, and access systems. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Records, Archives and Memory (3)
desc: Introduction to records, archives, and memory including the global history and nature of records, archives, and the archival profession. Topics include cultural memory, ethics and values, tribal and indigenous records, archival theory, practice and perspectives.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Archival Arrangement and Description (3)
desc: Principles and techniques for arrangement and description of archival materials. Topics include basic metadata standards, authority sources, record context, series identification, scope and content.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Management of Libraries and Information Centers (3)
desc: Theories and principles of administration for effective management of libraries and information centers, with emphasis on planning, resource allocation, team skills, project management, assessment, leadership, outreach, and advocacy.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Government Documents (3)
desc: Survey of government documents at the federal, state/local and international levels in all formats. Covers methods of acquisition and organization, including depository arrangements. Current issues of government information dissemination policies and practices discussed. Pre: 601 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Asian Research Materials and Methods (3)
desc: Literature of Asia in Western and Asian languages; bibliography, reference tools, research methods, sources, published and archival repositories. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as ASAN 705)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Digital Librarianship (3)
desc: Lecture with demonstrations to introduce the essential types of digital resources and the software tools for finding high quality and relevant information efficiently from digital journal archives and reference databases. Pre: 601 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Traditional Literature and Oral Narration (3)
desc: Analysis of traditional literature including Asian and Pacific Island resources. Selection and evaluation of traditional literature emphasizing cultural values. Introduction to oral tradition, history and techniques of storytelling.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Multicultural Resources for Diverse User Groups (3)
desc: Examines resources and materials targeted for diverse user populations in libraries and community organizations, locally and globally. Surveys issues and trends related to diversity initiatives affecting the publishing industry, libraries, and cultural institutions worldwide. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Indigenous Librarianship (3)
desc: Development and delivery of information services with and for indigenous communities. Issues include cultural protocols, traditional knowledge organization and ethics of access. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Introduction to Hawai‘i and Pacific Librarianship (3)
desc: Overview of resources and issues concerning librarianship in Hawai‘i and the Pacific Islands. Reference strategies and materials to answer common research questions, collection development, and management issues. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Community Engagement (3)
desc: Explores how information professionals in libraries and other settings collaborate with community members and organizations. Provides an overview of theory and practice emphasizing critical analysis of policies, services, and trends. Required course for CALIS. A-F only. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Preservation Management (3)
desc: Introduction to preservation management. Focus on management strategies for preservation of materials in libraries and archives. Covers preservation planning, condition surveys, disaster planning, grantsmanship, and basic issues relating to deterioration. LIS majors only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Collection Management (3)
desc: Principles and issues of collection management and care. Criteria and tools for selecting and deselecting materials. Relationships with publishers/producers.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Navigating Information Organizations (3)
desc: Principles of effective management of information organizations, with emphasis on organizational information flows, team skills, communication, planning, resource allocation, assessment, outreach, and advocacy. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: History of Information (3)
desc: History of the recording, preservation, and transmission of knowledge. Development of libraries and other information organizations as instruments of cultural transmission.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Intellectual Freedom (3)
desc: Seminar surveying the core philosophical principles and practices of intellectual freedom with special application to librarianship and information sciences. LIS majors only. A-F only. Pre: departmental approval. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Foundations of the Information Professions (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion/survey of the information professions, development of professional identity, professional values and ethics, historical development, current issues in the information professions.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Metadata Creation for Information Organization (3)
desc: Theory and practice of metadata creation for organization of information resources, cataloging code for resource description and access, Library of Congress and Dewey Decimal Classification schemes, use of OCLC.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Resource Discovery (3)
desc: Techniques and strategies for discovery of information resources from professional online databases and the Web. Query formulation and use of advanced functions to match retrieved resources with user needs for research and reference work. A-F only. Graduate students only. Pre: 601.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Introduction to Reference and Information Services (3)
desc: Philosophy, principles, and practice of reference services in libraries, information centers and information literacy. Bibliographic control, reference research, reference interview, online searching, evaluation of bibliographic and Webliographic material. Field component. MLISc degree required course.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LIS
title: Library and Information Studies Workshop (V)
desc: Designed for in-service librarians and other information specialists needing to update their professional skills, focus on a particular topic, or learn new approaches and concepts. Repeatable for credit. Credits earned in these courses cannot be applied for graduate degrees.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Library and Information Science (LIS)

subject: LTEC
title: Dissertation Research (1)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable five times. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Advanced Qualitative Analysis in LTEC (3)
desc:
Advanced research methods focused on management and analysis of qualitative data using 
technology. Reviews of different qualitative designs, data types, analytical methods, and software. Focused study of one qualitative design. Includes independent research project. Repeatable one time. EDUC, LTEC PhD majors only. A-F only. Pre: 667 or graduate level qualitative research course. (Summer only)
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Mixed Methods Research Design (3)
desc: Mixed methods research is designed for PhD and masters students in education and social sciences considering combining qualitative and quantitative research. Covers philosophical and practical implications culminating in a mixed methods dissertation/thesis proposal. Repeatable one time. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as EDCS 780 and DIS 780)
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Seminar in Educational Technology Theory (3)
desc: Doctoral level seminar for advanced students examining the theoretical foundations of research in the learning sciences and technology. Repeatable unlimited times. LTEC PhD majors only. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Educational Technology Issues (3)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems. (B) instructional development; (C) online communities; (D) the future; (E) research. Repeatable unlimited times. LTEC PhD majors only. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Special Topics in Educational Technology (3)
desc: Issues of topical interest in educational technology. Concentrates on a topic of current interest, including the new technologies for learning and teaching, and innovative strategies for design and delivery of instruction. Repeatable unlimited times. LTEC majors only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Instructional Design Studio (3)
desc: Covers multiple instructional design models within the context of theory and research. Studio approach to focus on facilitating learning and improving performance by creating, using, and managing appropriate technological processes and resources. LTEC PhD majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable nine times.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Directed Reading and/or Research (V)
desc: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable for 3 credit hours maximum each time. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Practicum in E-learning (3)
desc: Practicum in e-learning in academic or non-academic settings, under close supervision, plus regular class meetings. Repeatable three times. LTEC majors only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Seminar in Technology Leadership (3)
desc: Supervised activity in application of research in learning design and technology to teaching/training experiences. Repeatable three times. LTEC majors only and consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: LTEC Training and Evaluation Practicum (3)
desc: Practicum in educational technology training and evaluation in formal and informal settings, under close supervision, plus class meetings in hybrid format. Repeatable unlimited times. LTEC majors only or consent. Pre: instructor consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Learning Design Studio (3)
desc: Practicum in instructional design, development, and technology in academic and non-academic settings, under close supervision, plus regular class meetings in seminar format. Repeatable three times. LTEC majors only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Information Literacy and Learning Resources (3)
desc: Process approach to teaching information retrieval, analysis, and use. Emphasizes concepts, practices ineffective instructional design, selection of resources that meets learning needs. Required for Librarian HDOE licensure. A-F only. Pre: LTEC majors or consent. (Cross-listed as EDCS 686 and LIS 686)
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Cognition and Technology (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary course that introduces a range of empirical research examining aspects of cognition such as attention, memory and learning, and how technologies can enhance and/or hinder these cognitive processes. Repeatable 3 times. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Social and Ethical Issues in Educational Technology (3)
desc: Examination of social and ethical issues as they relate to technology in instructional settings. Focus on social justice and societal impact. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: (Alpha) Technical Issues in Educational Technology (3)
desc: Applying theory of management in instructional technology support services and delivery systems. (B) management; (C) systems; (D) networks. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Designing Online Learning (3)
desc: Planning, needs assessment, standards and learning theory applied to the design of online learning and assessment plans. LTEC majors only or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Distance Education Technology (3)
desc: Technical and instructional considerations for developing, delivering, managing, and evaluating distance education including voice, video, print, hypermedia and data transmissions. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Quantitative Research in Educational Technology (3)
desc: Application of methodological and statistical concepts in a projects-based classroom framework. Formative and summative evaluation, measurements, descriptive, and inferential statistics. LTEC PhD majors only. EDUC PhD majors only with consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Qualitative Research in Educational Technology (3)
desc: Introduction to qualitative research traditions and designs. Emphasis will be on the use of digital technologies in data collection and analysis. LTEC PhD majors only. EDUC PhD majors only with consent. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Research Design: Multiple Methods and Traditions (3)
desc: Explores research methods used in educational technology with a focus on developing a design for dissertation research. Emphasis is on the use of digital technologies in data collection and analysis. LTEC PhD majors only. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Assessment and Evaluation in Educational Technology (3)
desc: Evaluation and assessment processes, sources, and instruments applicable to systematic appraisal of learning with technology. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Design Thinking for Creative Problem Solving (3)
desc: Using real-world problems, students learn an agile design and problem-solving process that is human-centered, iterative, and cultivates individual and group creativity. Repeatable three times. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Programming for Games and Simulations (3)
desc: Project-based exploration of the breadth of programming in the context of educational games and simulations. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: (Alpha) Authoring E-learning Environments (3)
desc: Conceptualization of instructional design and its application to the development for e-learning environments: (B) assisted instruction (CAI); (C) managed instruction; (D) virtual reality; (E) animation. Repeatable two times. LTEC majors only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Interactive Multimedia Production (3)
desc: The utilization and application of advanced authoring tools, combining video, animation, graphics, and sound to develop student-centered learning. Primarily for advanced LTEC students. LTEC majors only or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: (Alpha) Learning with Emerging Technologies (3)
desc: Exploration and evaluation of new tools and strategies for teaching and learning. (B) mobile learning; (C) free/open software; (D) educational games and simulations; (E) critical trends. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent. (Fall only for (B) and (D)) (Spring only for (C) and (E))
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Educational Technology in Informal Learning Environments (3)
desc: Exploring the nature, application, and use of educational technology in informal learning environments, such as museums, cultural institutions, tourist attractions, and visitor information centers. Focusing on the analysis, selection, and development of various media choices. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Facilitating E-learning Communities (3)
desc: Exploration of tools and design considerations for effective online communication and development of learning communities. Pre: LTEC major or consent
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Emerging Technologies for K-12 Teaching (3)
desc: Exploration and impact of emerging technologies in K-12 classroom teaching and learning and ramifications of these technologies on administrative structure of schools. A-F only. LTEC majors only or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Developing Online Learning (3)
desc: Design and development of online instruction for educational and training settings. Implementation of online course elements and strategies for content delivery, course management, student interaction, course evaluation and assessment of student learning. Repeatable one time. LTEC majors only or consent. A-F only. Pre: 673 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Digital Video Design (3)
desc: Development and utilization of digital video for the purpose of improving the teaching-learning process. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: E-learning Theory and Design (3)
desc: Principles of e-learning theory as well as design and development for instruction. Application to new media and web authoring. Repeatable one time. Pre: LTEC majors or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Visual Design (3)
desc: Theory and practice involved in planning educational/instructional graphic and photographic material for print and computer-based media. LTEC majors only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Instructional Design and Development (3)
desc: Basic concepts and techniques of instructional design and development, for application to solving instructional problems in real-life situations. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Introduction to Online Learning (3)
desc: Introduction to principles of online learning and their application in formal and informal instructional settings. LTEC majors only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Educational Technology Research and Evaluation (3)
desc: Review of existing research in media/ed technology, with activities leading to the preparation of final study or project proposal. Repeatable one time. LTEC majors only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Innovations in Educational Technology (3)
desc: Innovative technological advances and new media in the field of educational technology and their application in instruction. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Theory and Practice in Educational Technology (3)
desc: The profession of educational technology and the role of instructional designers. Theoretical and philosophical foundations underlying practice that include instructional systems theory, needs assessment, change theory, and relevant learning models. Practical applications of these theories to solve instructional problems in real-life settings. A-F only. Pre: LTEC major or consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Professional Development Education Technology IV (3)
desc: Specialized topics reflecting interests and needs of faculty in current issues of technology integration. Combined lecture, lab and discussion course. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Professional Development Education Technology III (3)
desc: Specialized topics reflecting interests and needs of faculty in current issues of technology integration. Combined lecture, lab and discussion course. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Professional Development Education Technology II (3)
desc: Specialized topics reflecting interests and needs of faculty in current issues of technology integration. Combined lecture, lab and discussion course. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Professional Development Education Technology I (3)
desc: Specialized topics reflecting interests and needs of faculty in current issues of technology integration. Combined lecture, lab and discussion course. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: PDET: Technology Skills for Educators (2)
desc: Exploring technology resources needed for integration into classroom instruction. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Professional Development in Educational Technology: Technology Skills for Educators (1)
desc: Exploring technology resources needed for distance learning and classroom integration. Repeatable two times.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Directed Activity (V)
desc: Individual work, supervised by instructor. May consist of reading, research, and/or projects. Repeatable two times, up to six credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Social Media: Links to Lifelong Learning (3)
desc: Exploration of social media and effects on individuals, communities, and world. Analysis and evaluation of impacts and ethical implications of social media, with emphasis on writing. Includes service learning and research project. Pre: upper division standing (junior or higher).
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Technology in Education (3)
desc: Planning and implementation of computer systems and applications for effective integration into classroom settings. Emphasis is on methods and strategies for using digital technologies to enhance standards-based learning by K-12 students. Pre: upper division standing.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Video Technology (3)
desc: Overview of video uses in educational contexts. Includes video planning, production, and simple editing procedures, as well as selection, evaluation, and integration into learning plans. Pre: upper division standing.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Technology for Teachers (3)
desc: Introduction to the application of educational technology in teaching and learning using strategies in design, selection, development, integration, and evaluation. Interactive delivery via distance education technologies. A-F only. Pre: basic teaching certification.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Educational Media Technology (3)
desc: Introduction to educational technology theory and practice with an emphasis on meaningful integration of technology and media into a variety of face-to-face and online learning environments for diverse populations. A-F only. Pre: upper division standing.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Technologies for Academic Success– Business (1)
desc: Virtual and hands-on analysis of technology resources and utilization in learning with an emphasis on business education. A-F only. Pre: 112 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LTEC
title: Technologies for Academic Success (3)
desc: Virtual and hands-on analysis of technology resources and utilization in learning.
metadata: College of Education Learning Design and Technology (LTEC)

subject: LWUL
title: American Legal Systems II (V)
desc: Introduces conceptual and historical foundations of systems of public and private ordering in the U.S. and its territories. Subjects include federalism, constitutional democracy, separation of powers, and the common law. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only.
metadata: Law-Ulu Lehua (LWUL) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWUL
title: American Legal Systems (V)
desc: Introduces foundational concepts in American legal systems. Engages students in legal analysis and techniques of legal advocacy. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. Pre: Ulu Lehua Scholars only.
metadata: Law-Ulu Lehua (LWUL) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: International Intellectual Property (V)
desc: Primer on the World Intellectual Property Organization and the treaties it administers. Will explore the various international legislative and judicial developments in intellectual property as well as analyze international methods to harmonize several regional and national laws to protect rights in trademarks, patents, and copyrights. Students will be exposed to issues of territoriality and jurisdiction, international antitrust issues, and international dispute resolution, and human rights implications of international intellectual property rights protections. Pre: LAW 535.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Pacific Islands Legal Systems (V)
desc: Study of substantive rules of one or more Pacific Islands jurisdictions, development of legal systems, relationship of legal systems to culture and tradition.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: International Economic Law (V)
desc: Problem-based course teaches theory and practice of interrelated global private regulation and public development consequences, as situated in cross-border transactions and dispute resolution in world law, international investment law, and international financial law.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: International Human Rights Advocacy (V)
desc: Applying international human rights law and legal skills to promote and protect human rights by way of United Nations Charter-based human rights mechanism, treaty-based mechanism, or other international human rights institutions.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Comparative Law (V)
desc: Introduction to the civil law tradition, particularly as exemplified by the legal systems of East and Southeast Asia. After a brief review of comparative law study and the historical development of the civil law, the course will examine the structure and role of the courts, judicial process, the legal profession and constitutional law and administrative law in Western Europe and in the Asian civil law countries.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Law and Society in China (V)
desc: Overview of the historical foundations of Chinese law and introduction to the present legal system in the People’s Republic of China. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as ASAN 686)
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: International Law (V)
desc: Evolving process of formulating rules to govern nations and peoples of the world in their attempts to solve problems recognized as requiring global solutions.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Emerging Hawai‘i Water Issues (V)
desc: Introduction to the legal framework for water resource management in Hawai‘i; case studies illuminate the litigation process and evolution of the public trust, precautionary principle, and other legal, scientific, and policy areas.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Legal History of Hawai‘i (V)
desc: Designed to acquaint the student with the unique legal history of Hawai‘i, emphasizing particular legal controversies that have shaped the law of our island society. LAW majors only.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: (Alpha) Topics-Native Hawaiian Law (V)
desc: Specific topic areas depend on current developments and issues in Native Hawaiian and Indigenous law in Hawai‘i, the nation, and internationally, and expertise of faculty and visiting faculty. (B) policy and governance; (C) business and economic development; (D) law and culture; (E) Indigenous peoples, (F) Indigenous environment and sustainability. Repeatable up to 9 credits. LAW students only.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Native Hawaiian Rights (V)
desc: Status and evolution of rights of Native Hawaiians to the land and its usufructs. Potential of utilizing native rights based on statute, custom, and use to develop new and expanded rights.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: International Business Transactions (V)
desc: An examination of the law, rules, and practices relating to transborder commercial transactions. Roughly half of the semester focuses on international sales transactions, the remaining portion focuses on domestic and multinational governance of the international business arena.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: (Alpha) Topics in International Legal Studies (V)
desc: Selected topics presented by faculty members or visiting scholars, focusing upon subjects in the Pacific and Asian area. (B) business; (C) China; (G) global; (H) Philippines; (I) India; (J) Japan; (K) Korea; (P) Pacific; (S) Southeast Asia; (T) Topic 10; (U) Topic 11; (V) Topic 12; (W) Topic 13; (X) Topic 14. LAW majors only for (B) and (H). Repeatable six times for (C), (I), (J), (K), (P), (S), (T), (U), (V), (W), (X); repeatable five times, up to 18 credits for (B), (H); not repeatable for (G).
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Law and Society in Korea (3)
desc: Provides students with an understanding of the law, society, and legal systems in Korea. Areas of law including constitutional, civil, criminal, and business are discussed. Emphasis on South Korea. Law majors only.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: International Criminal Law (3)
desc: Designed to give an understanding of international criminal law. Will review all aspects of international criminal law from substantive international crimes to criminal liability and sentencing by domestic and international tribunals. LAW majors only.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Asian Comparative Labor Law (V)
desc: Area studies of Asian legal systems and issues, focusing on administration of Asian labor laws in a comparative context. Possible effects on foreign direct investment and foreign migrant contract workers. Comparison of Chinese, Japanese and other legal approaches in dealing with common issues.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Asian Pacific Insolvency Law (V)
desc: Comparison of corporate insolvency law of selected Asian and Pacific island countries, with a focus on recently enacted laws and pending proposals that have followed the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis. Law students only. Recommended: LAW 515, LAW 554, LAW 562. (Alt. years)
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWPA
title: Law and Society in Japan (V)
desc: An extended historical review of the foundations of Japanese law in society: Japan’s adoption and adaptation of Chinese legal doctrines, continental European legal structures and ideas, and American influences. Consideration of the structure of contemporary law in Japan: a look at the various players in the legal system, some important legal doctrines, and the real-world operation of Japan’s laws today.
metadata: Law-Pacific and Asian Law (LWPA) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWLM
title: U.S. Legal Research and Writing (V)
desc: Introduction to the basic principles of American legal research and writing. Students review techniques of case and statutory analysis and learn to write a professional legal memoranda and client opinion letters. LL.M. students only.
metadata: Law-Master of Law (LWLM) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWLM
title: Introduction to American Law (V)
desc: General introduction to the fundamental principles and distinctive aspects of the American legal system and its institutions.
metadata: Law-Master of Law (LWLM) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWLW
title: Law Teaching Seminar II (V)
desc: Interdisciplinary seminar uses LP II assignments and additional readings to discover and deliver the theoretical and practical underpinnings of appellate advocacy and negotiation the methodologies used to teach them. Instructor approval required. Repeatable one time. (Spring only)
metadata: Law-Legal Writing (LWLW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWLW
title: Law Teaching Seminar I (V)
desc: Interdisciplinary seminar used LP 1 assignments and additional readings to discover and deliver the theoretical and practical underpinnings of substantive law assignments and the methodology used to teach them. Instructor approval required. Repeatable up to eight credits.
metadata: Law-Legal Writing (LWLW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWLW
title: Law Thesis (V)
desc: Intensive writing that satisfies the law school’s upper division writing requirement and results in advanced law paper of publishable quality, extending over two consecutive semesters of study. Repeatable one time, up to 4 credits. LAW majors only. A-F only.
metadata: Law-Legal Writing (LWLW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWLR
title: (Alpha) Advanced Legal Research (V)
desc: Designed to meet the needs of students who require an advanced course on research in a specific area of law. (E) environmental law research; (F) foreign law research; (H) Hawai‘i law research; (I) international and foreign law research; (P) prepare to practice; (Q) topic 5; (R) topic 6; (S) topic 7; (T) topic 8; (U) topic 9; (V) topic 10. Each alpha repeatable four times, up to 15 credits. LAW students only.
metadata: Law-Law Research (LWLR) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWLR
title: Scholarly Research Methods (V)
desc: Learn to plan the prewriting process for such scholarly assignments as Second Year Seminar (SYS), writing for law review, moot court competitions, and in any course involving a scholarly approach to research and writing. LAW majors only.
metadata: Law-Law Research (LWLR) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWLR
title: Legal Research (V)
desc: Provides a theoretical understanding of the process of law making and of developing and implementing a research plan. LAW majors only.
metadata: Law-Law Research (LWLR) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWJT
title: Asian-Pacific Law Journal (V)
desc: Students selected for the Asian-Pacific Law and Policy Journal editorial board have writing, researching, editorial and production responsibility for publication of the journal. Repeatable five times. CR/NC only.
metadata: Law-Journal and Team Credits (LWJT) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWJT
title: Law Review (V)
desc: Students selected for the Law Review editorial board have responsibility for editorial research, writing, and production of the  Law Review  published by the School of Law. Repeatable four times. CR/NC only.
metadata: Law-Journal and Team Credits (LWJT) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWJT
title: (Alpha) Moot Court Team (V)
desc: An honors program for students who prepare for and compete in national advocacy. Travel/registration fees required. (B) Black Law Students Association; (C) client counseling; (D) Hispanic Bar Association; (E) environmental law; (H) Native American; (J) Jessup international; (K) international environmental law; (M) intellectual property; (N) labor; (O) other; (S) space law; (T) trial team. Repeatable one time; up to four credits for (S) and (T). CR/NC only. Pre: selection by competition.
metadata: Law-Journal and Team Credits (LWJT) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: International Ocean Law (V)
desc: Examination of the history of international ocean law, including comprehensive coverage of modern problems and issues concerning the laws of the sea.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: Domestic Ocean and Coastal Law (V)
desc: Examination of U.S. and Hawai‘i ocean and coastal law covers modern issues concerning the protection and use of the native environment including challenges in Hawai‘i.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: Legal Aspects of Water Resources and Control (V)
desc: Legal aspects of water and water rights with focus on Hawai‘i.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: Environmental Law (V)
desc: Basic statutory law and policy questions and problems concerning the environment. Focus on federal Hawai‘i issues.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: Hazardous Waste Law (V)
desc: Examination of major federal statutes, regulatory and case law, and Hawai‘i counterparts. Policies behind hazardous waste laws and their impact on individuals, community, and businesses.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: Climate Change Law and Policy (V)
desc: Climate change is a core challenge that will influence law and policy well into the future. Students will study climate change science, litigation, law and policy at state, national, and international levels. (Once a year)
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: Environmental Litigation Seminar (V)
desc: Seminar on the techniques, law, and strategy involved in federal and state court environmental litigation.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: International Environmental Law (V)
desc: Study of the international regulation of activities and processes used to prevent environmental degradation and to preserve resources of environmental value.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: (Alpha) Topics in Environmental Law (V)
desc: Study of contemporary topics in environmental law to change periodically as to issues and topics. (B) advanced environmental law; (C) regulatory; (D) legislature; (E) policy; (F) judicial. Repeatable six times.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: Environmental Compliance and Regulated Industries (V)
desc: In depth study of the federal and state environmental laws that impact modern businesses and industries, and exploration of the compliance issues that arise under the statutes, regulations, and case law.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: Conservation Transactions (V)
desc: Real estate transactions are an important and growing conservation strategy; examines land transactions within the environment of conservation. (Once a year)
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LWEV
title: Wildlife and Natural Resources Law (V)
desc: Seminar covering federal and Hawai‘i laws that govern the management of wildlife resources, with a particular focus on wildlife conflicts arising in Hawai‘i.
metadata: Law-Environmental Law (LWEV) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LSJD
title: SJD Legal Writing Seminar (V)
desc: Provides SJD students with an overview of fundamentals for academic writing skills and opportunity to improve their writing of dissertations. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. LAW students only.
metadata: Law-Doctor of Juridical Science (LSJD) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LSJD
title: SJD Legal Scholarship (V)
desc: Provides SJD students with an overview of legal scholarship in a series of related fields. Students will be introduced to different research approaches and areas of legal analysis through presentations by instructor and other faculty. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. LAW students only.
metadata: Law-Doctor of Juridical Science (LSJD) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LSJD
title: SJD Directed Reading (V)
desc: Individual reading and research for SJD dissertation under supervision of faculty instructors. Repeatable two times, up to 36 credits. LAW students only.
metadata: Law-Doctor of Juridical Science (LSJD) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: (Alpha) Independent Study (V)
desc: Designed for law students participating in an international exchange program, visiting student program, or independent study while enrolled at UH Mānoa. Student must obtain departmental approval prior to registering. CR/NC only.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Internet Law and Policy (V)
desc: Explores the development and use of new technologies in the global economy, social culture, copyright law, cyberspace, e-commerce, privacy, security, trademarks, domain names, tort liability, criminal activity, speech, and social and ethical issues.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Integrity and Ethics in the Real World (3)
desc: Interactive course addressing important topical ethical issues in areas including the corporate, entertainment, medical, legal, political, education, and sports worlds. Renowned knowledgeable guests will discuss critical issues in their respective fields through panel conversations. LAW majors only. (Summer only)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: (Alpha) Workshops and Clinics (V)
desc:
(B) Prosecution Clinic; (C) Defense Clinic; (D) Elder Law Clinic; (E) Environmental Law Clinic; (G) Estate Planning Workshop; (H) Legal Aid Clinic; (I) Native Hawaiian Rights Clinic; (J) Family Law Clinic; (K) Entrepreneurship and Small Business Clinic; (M) Mediation Clinic; (N) Lawyering Skills Workshop; (P) Mediation Workshop; (Q) Immigration Clinic; (R) Child Welfare Clinic; (S) Hawai‘i Innocence Project I; (T) Hawai‘i Innocence Project II; (U) Medical Legal Partnership; (W) Advanced Elder Law Clinic (3). 
Repeatable one time for (K), (I), and (J); repeatable two times for (W); repeatable three times for (D) and (E); repeatable four times for (H). LAW majors only for (R), (S), (T), (U), and (W). CR/NC only for (N) and (W). Pre: 543 for (C); 561 or LWEV 582 for (E); 568 or consent for (J); 548 for (Q); 590D for (W). (Once a year for (K)) (Alt. years for (U))
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Labor and Employment Law (V)
desc: Employment law, statutory rights affecting the employment relation, and alternative contract provisions to secure the parties’ intentions. Focus on the practical application of labor and employment law. Materials relating to the unionized employment relationship. Emphasis on the labor arbitration process and possibly, to issues regarding internal union affairs.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Hawai‘i Legislative Process and Drafting Workshop (V)
desc: Workshop to learn policy development, procedure, legislative drafting, and legislative research skills applicable to Hawai‘i State Legislative process.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Civil Rights (V)
desc: Focuses on the civil rights of Americans and introduces alternative remedies and procedures for securing these rights.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Real Estate Development and Financing (V)
desc: Federal and state laws in the practice of real estate development and financing law. Condominium, securities, subdivision, consumer protection, and mortgage areas.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Land Use Management and Control (V)
desc: Survey course of public land use management. (Cross-listed as PLAN 680)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Directed Study and Research (V)
desc: Individual research and writing under the direction of faculty.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: State and Local Government Law and Finance (V)
desc: City, town, county, district governments: administrative organization; regulatory powers; police power; local governmental taxation; relationship between local, state, and federal government.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Jurisprudence (V)
desc: Relationships between the concepts of law and morality with views of legal and moral philosophers.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: International Protection of Human Rights (V)
desc: The growing body of international human rights laws, including procedural law and role of nongovernmental organizations.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Federal Courts (V)
desc: An examination of the jurisdiction and law-making powers of the federal courts, standing issues, appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, federal-question and diversity-of-citizenship jurisdiction of the federal district courts, immunities from suit in the federal courts possessed by governmental entities and officers, intervention by federal courts in state proceedings, and choice of law in the federal courts. Particular emphasis on relevant Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Pre: 533 (or concurrent).
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Sales (V)
desc: In-depth study of Uniform Commercial Code, Article 2–domestic sales of goods, including warranties, manner, time and place of performance, buyers’ and sellers’ remedies for breach of contract, limitations of freedom of contract.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Family Law (V)
desc: Legal forms of–and responses to–formation, maintenance, and dissolution of the family. Marriage, annulment, divorce, alimony, separation agreements, child custody and adoption, parentage.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Federal Income Taxation (V)
desc: Surveys the entire federal income tax system, with emphasis on those areas of greatest importance to non-tax lawyers. Students are expected to develop proficiency in the use of the Internal Revenue Code and Treasury Regulations.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Non-Profit Organizations (V)
desc: Examines the meaning, scope, and role of non-profit organizations in contemporary society, and focuses on selected non-tax laws and primary tax issues relevant to non-profits. Law students only. Recommended: 531 and 567. (Once a year)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Securities Regulation (V)
desc: An introduction to American securities regulation and focuses on the registration and reporting process required of public companies as well as securities litigation. Repeatable three times. Recommended: 531.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Pre-Trial Litigation (V)
desc: Theory and practice of civil pre-trial litigation with focus on pleading, discovery, and pre-trial motions. CR/NC only.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Trial Practice (V)
desc: Examination of sequential stages of pre-trial and trial practice in a problem setting. Topics include investigation, pleadings, motions, discovery, voir dire examination, opening statements, direct and cross examination, closing argument, selected evidentiary problems, post-trial motions, and appellate practice. Students engage in simulated exercises, and their work is critiqued. CR/NC only. Pre: 543 or consent.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Debtors’ and Creditors’ Rights (V)
desc: Bankruptcy laws and rules, laws of liens, receiverships.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Administrative Law (V)
desc: Procedure and remedies for resolving controversies between citizens and government officials exercising administrative power.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: High Growth Entrepreneurship (V)
desc: An interdisciplinary (JD-MBA) course examining legal, business, and technology issues related to building high growth companies. Student teams develop company feasibility reports and skills necessary to advise or build high growth businesses. Recommended: 531. Law, MBA, and ME students only. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as MGT 653 and ME 680)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Labor Law I (V)
desc: Regulation of union management relations under state and federal laws.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Corporate Finance (V)
desc: Provides an understanding of the basic financial concepts and tools for lawyers with transactional practices, preferred stock, common stock and convertible securities. Pre: 531 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Negotiable Instruments, Payment Systems and Credit Instruments (V)
desc: A study of the Uniform Commercial Code provisions that deal with commercial paper (Article 3), bank collections and deposits (Article 4), funds transfers (Article 4A) and letters of credit (Article 5), as well as material on alternative payment systems, including credit cards, electronic fund transfers and related federal law.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: (Alpha) Externship (V)
desc: Legal work for judges and attorney supervisors in public agencies, private law firms, and the legislature. (H) Hawai‘i; (P) outside Hawai‘i. Repeatable three times for (H). CR/ NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Secured Transactions (V)
desc: Introduction to Uniform Commercial Code, particularly Article 9– reducing risk of nonpayment by obtaining an interest in borrowers’ property.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Trusts and Estates (V)
desc: Deals primarily with the disposition of family wealth including: the making of wills; the creation, enforcement, administration, and termination of trusts; and intestate succession, including probate.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Corporate and Partnership Taxation (V)
desc: Examines tax aspects of formation, operation, reorganization, and liquidation of partnerships and corporations.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Admiralty Law (V)
desc: Introduction to U.S. maritime law and admiralty jurisdiction emphasizing development of rules of maritime law and rights of seamen and maritime workers.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Immigration Law (V)
desc: Introduction to U.S. Immigration and Nationality Law: a brief overview of historical development of immigration law; analysis of exclusion and deportation grounds and remedies; the study of both immigrant and nonimmigrant visa applications and petitions. Current law on asylum and refugee applications and U.S. citizenship and naturalization requirements.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Gender: Law and Conflicts (V)
desc: Examines how international law and domestic legal systems address and resolve conflicts regarding women’s rights, gender roles, and gender identity. Takes a comparative approach with emphasis on the Asia-Pacific region. (Cross-listed as PACE 637 and WGSS 647)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: (Alpha) Intercession-J Term (V)
desc: January term provides students the opportunity to explore contemporary legal topics with national and international experts. (B) alternative dispute resolution; (C) rule of law; (D) law practice; (E) diversity; (F) access to justice; (G) public law; (H) legal theory; (I) legal practice; (J) rights. Repeatable five times. (Once a year)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Licensing Intellectual Property (V)
desc: Theory and practice of the law relating to the transfer of rights in information and other intangibles are examined together with end user license agreements and the structure and negotiation of upstream licensing mechanisms. Repeatable up to three credits. Pre: 535 or departmental approval. (Once a year)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Race, Culture, and Law (V)
desc: U.S. cases and legal theory emphasizing law in the social construction of racial categories, shifts in race-based anti-discrimination law, and the interaction of culture and law in judicial decision-making.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Evidence (V)
desc: “Objection, your Honor!” This course examines the rules of evidence that govern trials in both federal and Hawai‘i courts and will focus on such topics as hearsay, witness examination, impeachment, physical and demonstrative evidence, expert testimony, writings, relevance, judicial notice, and presumptions.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Advanced Civil Procedure (V)
desc: Addresses various aspects of complex litigation and recent criticism of the civil litigation system itself. Theoretical in emphasis.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Criminal Procedure (V)
desc: Issues of free press and fair trial, illegal search and seizure, arrest and confession, speedy trial, double jeopardy are covered through student interactions as defense or prosecution attorneys and as judges.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Contract Drafting (V)
desc: Hands-on workshop class in drafting contracts, agreement, and similar documents for commercial/business purposes. LAW majors only. Pre: 506, or 509 and 510.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Equitable Remedies (V)
desc: Examines both practice aspects and theoretical underpinnings of equitable remedies. Frequently, compensatory damages cannot adequately protect clients or provide them with the relief they need. Topics include temporary restraining orders, preliminary and permanent injunctions, restitution and unjust enrichment, specific performance, and equitable defenses such as unclean hands, laches, and estoppel. Practice issues concerning appeal, jury trials, and the relationship of equity to law are also explored. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Conflict of Laws (V)
desc: Problems respecting the law applicable in transactions or to relationships with elements in more than one state.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Intellectual Property (V)
desc: A study of the law relating to property rights resulting from intellectual effort, including patents, copyright, trademarks, and trade secrets.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Constitutional Law II (V)
desc: Advanced course in constitutional law with special emphasis on rights secured by the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution of the U.S. Pre: 533.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Constitutional Law I (V)
desc: Introduction to judicial function in constitutional cases, jurisdiction of the U.S. Supreme Court, and discretionary barriers to judicial review.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Health Law (V)
desc: Introduction to medical jurisprudence, medical malpractice, informed consent, health care decisions, medical ethics, the health care industry, managed care, financing health care, and the role of government in health care. LAW majors only; NURS DNP majors only (Cross-listed as NURS 645)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Business Associations (V)
desc: After a brief survey of agency, partnerships, and other forms of business organization, the course will cover the fundamentals of corporations, and securities regulation, including disregarding the corporate entity, management and control of closely held corporations, merger, liability under the federal securities laws, takeovers, public registration, exemptions, and derivative suits.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Second-Year Seminar (V)
desc: Seminar required for spring semester of all second-year law students. Substantial paper required. Topics announced in previous fall semester. Placement by lottery.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Federal Indian Law (V)
desc: Examines Federal Indian Law, including fundamental concepts and the historical evolution of legal doctrines. Considers the implications of Native Hawaiian sovereignty within the framework of Federal Indian Law. (Once a year)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Group Directed Study (V)
desc: Designed for maximum flexibility, this course allows a professor to work with a small number of students on a reading/ discussion project of mutual interest. Repeatable up to 15 credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Legislation and Statutory Interpretation (V)
desc: The interrelationship between the legislative and judicial branches of government is explored through a review of Federal and Hawai‘i law-making processes, direct democracy, legislative drafting, and theories of the legislative process and statutory interpretation.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Advanced Torts and Insurance Law (V)
desc: Advanced study of several areas of tort law and an introduction to insurance law and policy. This course is of considerable importance to students interested in civil litigation and personal injury law. Recent important developments in Hawai‘i tort and insurance law will be included.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Law and Psychology (V)
desc: Approaches psychology as a problem solving tool that can facilitate legal analysis. Covers a variety of areas including jury decision-making, research methodology, social cognition, culture, and behavioral economics, among others. (Once a year)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Torts (V)
desc: Torts cover the statutory and common law of negligence, causation, defenses, damages, strict liability, intentional torts and tort policy and reform, with emphasis on national and Hawai‘i law.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Law, Aging and Medicine (V)
desc: Introduction to basic legal issues at the intersection of law, aging and medicine. Addresses various issues confronting elderly; issues confronting the general population including health care financing, decision-making, and bioethics.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Advanced Legal Studies (V)
desc: Faculty members or visiting scholars present selected topics focusing upon subject areas in their area of specialty or expertise. (B) business law; (C) Constitutional law; (D) criminal law; (E) critical legal; (F) education law; (G) health law; (H) intellectual property law; (I) practice of law; (J) public interest law; (K) topic 10; (M) topic 11; (N) topic 12; (O) topic 13; (P) topic 14; (Q) topic 15; (R) topic 16; (S) topic 17; (T) topic 18; (V) topic 19; (W) topic 20; (X) topic 21; (Y) topic 22; (Z) topic 23. LAW majors only for (X-Z). Alphas B-Q repeatable three times, up to 12 credits; alphas R-Z repeatable three times, up to 16 credits.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Real Property II (V)
desc: Contract of sale, equitable conversion, deed. Pre: 518.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Real Property I (V)
desc: Basic course in property ownership, development, regulation. Emphasis on theory.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Civil Procedure II (V)
desc: Continuation of 516. Pre: 516.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Civil Procedure I (V)
desc: Study of pre-trial, trial, and appellate procedures in the federal and Hawai‘i courts.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Business Reorganization in Bankruptcy (V)
desc: Examination of the rights and remedies available to a failing business and its creditors when the business seeks to reorganize its business and financial affairs under chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. The course is structured as a “practicum,” which tracks a single business through restructuring and emphasizes the practical and strategic aspects of lawyering. Recommended: 562.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Children, Parents and the Law (V)
desc: Exploration of fundamental concepts of law relating to children, ethical issues, and the role of lawyers in assisting children, and how the child’s rights and obligations are balanced with those of parents and state. (Once a year)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Criminal Law (V)
desc: Examination of substantive rules, enforcement procedures, and rationales of criminal law in the U.S.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Reparations and Reconciliation (V)
desc: Seminar addresses a legally and socially important contemporary issue-healing present-day wounds of historic injustice. Considers how to repair the continuing social damage of injustice. (Once a year)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Professional Responsibility (V)
desc: Introductory consideration of selected topics relating to functions, structure, and responsibilities of the legal profession and its future role in society.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Contracts II (V)
desc: Continuation of 509.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Contracts I (V)
desc: Law of private agreements. Explores the evolution and application of common law doctrines, and, where applicable, relevant provisions of the Uniform Commercial Code. Examines the bases of promissory liability, contract formation, mutual assent, defenses to enforcement, excuses, remedies and damages, and the rights and interests of third parties. Attention will be paid throughout the course to the role of contracts in a market society and the conflicting interests of certainty, freedom of contract and fairness.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Negotiation and Alternative Dispute Resolution (V)
desc: Lawyers negotiate settlements in almost all their cases. This class presents a “hands-on,” skill-building approach to the newest ideas, as well as centuries-old techniques, about the skill lawyers will use most often in their private practice- negotiation. The class also examines the rapidly developing field of alternative dispute resolution (ADR), including mediation, facilitation, arbitration, and court-annexed ADR. (Cross-listed as CEE 614)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Employment Discrimination (V)
desc: A study of the law of employment discrimination.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Lawyering Fundamentals II (V)
desc: A comprehensive program that teaches students the analytical and presentational skills necessary for excellent legal writing. Introduces skills and strategies for preparing written legal arguments and oral advocacy. Pre: 504.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Lawyering Fundamentals I (V)
desc: Comprehensive program that teaches students the analytical and presentational skills necessary for excellent legal writing. Introduces students to legal problem solving and writing through the types of documents lawyers prepare in practice.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Historic Preservation Law (V)
desc: Introduction to the protection of cultural, archaeological, and historical resources with emphasis on key federal and state laws. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as HWST 653)
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Organizing for Social Change (V)
desc: Examines conditions that lead people to become active, self-governing agents. Covered are strategies and tactics of organizers, history of social change movements, anti-subordination theories of justice and organizing case studies.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAW
title: Exchange Student Program (V)
desc: Designed for students accepted to participate in an exchange program while enrolled at William S. Richardson School of Law. Must obtain prior approval for the transfer credits. LAW majors only. CR/NC only.
metadata: Law (LAW) William S. Richardson School of Law

subject: LAIS
title: Hispanic Cultural Studies (3)
desc: Critical overview of contemporary theories on Hispanic culture. Issues of identity such as mestizaje, hybridity, and pluralism will be discussed from a hemispheric perspective. Pre: consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: (Alpha) Topics in Latin American and Iberian Studies (3)
desc:
Combined lecture-discussion on political, social, cultural themes of Iberia and Latin America; (B) Aztlán, Quetzalcóatl, Pachamama; (C) Luso-Hispanic pop culture. Repeatable one time for different alphas. Pre: 360 or LAIS 363 or LAIS 368 or 
LAIS 372 or LAIS 380, and SPAN 351, and SPAN 352; or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: New World Rituals and Ideologies (3)
desc: Study of cross-cultural patterns in ritual behaviors and creolization of African, indigenous, and Iberian ideological frameworks in the Americas. Topics may include syncretic religions (voodoo, candomble), Andean Christianity, spiritual conquest, conceptions of death, etc. Sophomore standing or higher. Minimum C- required grade for prerequisites. Pre: 360, or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as ANTH 478 and REL 478)
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: Colonial Latin American History (3)
