desc: Pre-Columbian civilizations: Spanish and Portuguese colonization; political, economic, social and religious evolution to 1810; independence. Pre: 360 or consent. (Cross-listed as HIST 478)
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: Studies in Culture: Portugal and Brazil (3)
desc: Surveys the cultures of the Portuguese-speaking world from pre-Lusitanian times, including connections with Africa, Asia, the U.S., and Hawai‘i. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: (Alpha) Indigenous Peoples of Latin America (3)
desc: Survey of the history and culture of the indigenous peoples of Latin America through a study of their literature, texts and practices. (B) Mesoamerica; (C) Andean South America. Repeatable one time for different alphas. Pre: sophomore standing or consent. (Cross-listed as ANTH 372 (Alpha))
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: Households in Cross-Cultural Perspectives: Home, Hale, Casa (3)
desc: Study of cross-cultural patterns in household and community level organizations in Latin America and elsewhere. Topics may include gender relations, kinship structures, political economy, impacts of colonialism, modernization, and globalization on households. Sophomore standing or higher. (Cross-listed as ANTH 368)
metadata: DS Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: Latin American Film (3)
desc: A survey of films from Latin America, the Silent Era to the present, and their representation of the cultural history of the region. Develops written communication skills. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: Spanish Film (3)
desc: A chronological survey of films from Spain, from the Silent Era to the present. Conceptually, a cultural history of Spain in the 20th century, as seen through films. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: U.S. Latino Culture and Literature (3)
desc: The culture and history of U.S. Latinos through an analysis of their literature and arts and their sociopolitical relationship to the U.S. mainstream culture. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LAIS
title: (Alpha) Studies in Culture (3)
desc: Politics of culture and representation. Will consider issues, traditions, movements, texts, and cultural icons for their significance for national and regional identity formation, intercultural relations and global flows of images, people, and capital. (B) Latin America; (C) Iberian Peninsula. Pre: sophomore or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA) Latin American and Iberian Studies (LAIS)

subject: LATN
title: Seminar in Roman Studies (3)
desc: Study of an author or phase in Roman studies. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. Pre: any two 300-level LATN courses, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Roman Satire (3)
desc: Selections from Horace and Juvenal. Pre: 201 and 202, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Roman Novel (3)
desc: Selections from Petronius and Apuleius. Pre: 201 and 202, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Roman Lyric (3)
desc: Selections from Catullus, Horace, and others. Pre: 201 and 202, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Roman Drama (3)
desc: Selections from Plautus, Terence, and Seneca. Pre: 201 and 202, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Roman Philosophy (3)
desc: Selections from Lucretius, Cicero, and Seneca. Pre: 201 and 202, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Roman Epic (3)
desc: Selections from Virgil, Ovid, and others. Pre: 201 and 202, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Roman Historians (3)
desc: Selections from Caesar, Sallust, and others. Pre: 201 and 202, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Intermediate Latin (3)
desc: Continuation of 201: emphasis on poetry. Pre: 201.
metadata: HSL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Intermediate Latin (3)
desc: Development of reading and translation skills. Emphasis on prose. Pre: 102 or equivalent.
metadata: HSL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Elementary Latin (3)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101.
metadata: HSL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LATN
title: Elementary Latin (3)
desc: Grammar and vocabulary, with reading of simple Latin.
metadata: HSL College of Arts, Languages & Letters Latin (LATN) Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: LLEA
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Independent study of approved reading and research with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: consent and departmental approval.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Learning and Teaching World Languages (3)
desc: Hybrid technology intensive course for pre- or in-service teachers of world languages. Topics: online learning, curriculum and lesson planning, assessment, language teaching approaches, technology for learning world languages. Junior standing or higher. (Cross-listed as SLS 455)
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Pre: limited to senior majors with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in major, and consent of department chair.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Directed Language Study (V)
desc: Study in European languages not taught regularly, depending on demand and staff. Pre: consent of department chair.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent of department chair.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Masterpieces of Medieval Welsh Literature (3)
desc: Key prose and poetry underlying the Arthurian tradition in Europe. Language instruction leading to reading knowledge of medieval Welsh. Pre: consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: (Alpha) Topics in Language (3)
desc: Study in English of topics, periods, etc., in the languages taught in the department: (B) comparison of Romance languages; (C) interpersonal communication; (D) social perspectives. Repeatable two times for different alphas (up to 9 credits). Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: (Alpha) Topics in Literature (3)
desc: Study in English of a topic, period, or genre; aesthetic considerations common to European literatures: (B) the modern novel; (C) European literature as a path to self-knowledge; (D) Middle Ages; (E) introduction to literary theory. MA candidates in European languages read works in their major in the original. Pre: graduate standing or consent of department chair.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Western Literature and Cultures in the Pacific (3)
desc: Impact of and reaction to western writings and cultural influences in the Pacific as represented in texts from the 16th century to the present. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Seminar in Research Methods (3)
desc: Study of basic research methods and tools, including technology. Print and electronic source materials. Information literacy. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: (Alpha) Fantasy and the Fantastic (3)
desc: Cross-cultural study of fantasy and the fantastic in short stories, fairy tales, films and novels from Europe and the Americas in English translation. Discussion of illusion, identity, time, the future, the bizarre and major concepts in fantasy literature. (B) fairies, devils and fantasy; (C) the fantastic, the strange and science fiction. Repeatable one time in different alphas. Pre: 270 or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Freaks and Monsters 2: The Ethics of Otherness (3)
desc: An interdisciplinary examination of corporeal Otherness. Unusual real and fictional bodies from fairground history, art, anatomy, literature, natural history and ethnology. Discussion of the moral, medical, philosophical and aesthetic dilemmas of spectacular difference. Pre: 270 or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Teaching Practicum in Large Lecture Courses (1)
desc: Supervised undergraduate teaching practicum in large-lecture LLEA courses. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only. Pre: completion of course in which practicum will be done and consent of instructor, no waiver.
metadata: Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Europeans in the Pacific (3)
desc: European presence in the Pacific, in relation to literature, art, culture, civilization. Not applicable to language requirement.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Freaks and Monsters (3)
desc: Monsters, freaks and otherness in literature, film, history and medicine. Suitable for non-literature majors.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Russian Film (3)
desc: A study of Russian film from the 1920’s to the present. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Russia: Faces of Asia (3)
desc: Survey in English of 19th-21st century representations of Asia in the contexts of the Russian Empire, the Soviet Union, and post-Soviet space. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Russia: Between Europe & Asia (3)
desc: Russian culture (literature, film, theater, music, arts, etc.) as an amalgam of European and Asian traditions and its impact on the world throughout history; develops written communication skills. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Russian Literature 1900–1950 (3)
desc: Study of significant works of twentieth century Russian literature with particular focus on its relationship to Europe and Asia. Students will work intensively on their own writing and research in close collaboration with their instructor. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: 19th-Century Russian Literature (3)
desc: Survey in English of major writers from Pushkin through Chekhov; lectures, discussions, short papers. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Russian Short Story (3)
desc: Origin and development (19th and 20th century); periods, themes, styles, and major authors. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Topics in Italian Literature in Translation (3)
desc: Introduction to Italian literature in translation, with varying topics in different iterations. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Italian Literature as Film (3)
desc: Exploration of the distinction between literature and film as artistic genres as well as study of major works of literature in respect to the present, from the Middle Ages through the 20th century. A-F only. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Italian Film (3)
desc: Study of Italian film history and technique. A-F only.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: German Literature, Culture and Film: 1989 to Present (3)
desc: Study of German literature, culture and film, 1989 to present. Credit cannot be earned for both 416 and GER 416. Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: German Fascism and Propaganda (3)
desc: Study of German Fascism and propaganda in German literature, art, film, and associated ethical issues. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: German Opera and Literature (3)
desc: Introduction to German opera, its history, and analysis. Developing critical skills through analysis of German opera music and literature. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Classical German Literature (3)
desc: Readings in translation from dramatic works of Lessing, Goethe, Schiller. Philosophic and aesthetic views of leading writers of the Enlightenment, Storm and Stress, and classical periods.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: German Cinema (3)
desc: Study of German film history, film theory, film analysis, and film style. Repeatable one time or take GER 320 one time for different topics. 6 cr. limit on GER/LLEA 320 courses. Sophomore standing only.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: Survey of French Civilizations (3)
desc: A historical survey of the development of French and Francophone cultures. The course is interdisciplinary, dealing with politics, music, art, other forms of cultural expression, and daily life.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: French Literature as Film (3)
desc: Exploration of the distinction between literature and film as artistic genres as well as study of major works of literature in respect to the present, from the Middle Ages through the 20th century. Pre: sophomore standing.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: French African Literature (3)
desc: Black African literature in French in 20th century. Major themes of negritude, national political unity, colonialism, traditional culture. Pre: junior standing or one course in French language or literature.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: French Literature Since 1800 (3)
desc: Rapid reading in translation; lectures, discussions, reports. Pre: junior standing or one course in French language or literature.
metadata: DL Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: French Culture for Americans (3)
desc: Study of the shared cultural and historical foundations of France and the U.S. both past and present. A-F only.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: LLEA
title: French Film (3)
desc: Study of French film history and technique. A-F only. Pre: freshman standing.
metadata: DH Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: CLAS
title: Gender and Sexuality in the Classical World (3)
desc: Critical examination of the construction of gender identity and sexuality in ancient Greece and Rome. Junior standing or higher. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as HIST 362)
metadata: DH Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: KOR
title: Research Seminar in Korean Language (3)
desc: Advanced study in history and dialects, phonology and morphology, syntax and semantics, sociolinguistics, or pedagogy, leading to a research paper. Repeatable four times. Pre: consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Research Seminar in Korean Literature (3)
desc: Advanced study of an author, school, period, genre, or problem leading to a research paper. Repeatable four times. Pre: consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Topics and Issues in Modern Korean Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics and issues in modern/contemporary Korean fiction, focusing on texts that problematize critical sociocultural issues in the evolving contexts of modern Korean intellectual history. Repeatable one time. Pre: 494 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Practicum: Teaching Korean as a Second Language (3)
desc: Designed for graduate students pursuing Korean language teaching, while developing practical teaching skills through class observation, action research and discussion under supervision. Pre: 635 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Major Authors in Modern Korean Literature (3)
desc: Advanced study of major Korean fiction writers from the 1910s to the present with emphasis on critical reading of their lives and writings to arrive at informed appraisal of their contribution to modern Korean literature. Repeatable one time. Pre: 494 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Research in Korean Language Acquisition (3)
desc: Integrating the conceptual aspects of statistics and scientific analysis of human language behavior into the study of Korean as a foreign language. Pre: 635 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Literary Translation of Korean (3)
desc: The art and craft of translating traditional and modern Korean literary works into English. Repeatable four times. Pre: 493 and 494, or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean Conversation Analysis (3)
desc: Theoretical framework of conversation analysis and review of Korean conversational structures, such as turn-taking, sequence organization, and repair organization; training for data collection, transcription, and data analysis. Pre: 451 and 452; or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Pedagogy of Teaching Korean as a Second Language (3)
desc: Identification and analysis of major problems in Korean language learning, teaching, testing, and materials development by examining theoretical issues and conducting classroom research; practical techniques of teaching and testing skills in listening, reading, speaking, writing and culture. Pre: 451 and 452; or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean Sociolinguistics (3)
desc: Variations in form and use depending on sociocultural factors. Role of language in politics, mass media, group identity, bilingualism, and intercultural communication. Pre: 470 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean Syntax and Semantics (3)
desc: Review of theoretical problems in Korean syntax and semantics; different approaches; and contributions of Korean linguistic study to syntactic and semantic theory. Pre: 452 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean Phonology and Morphology (3)
desc: Review of Korean vocalic and consonantal phonology. Phonological and morphological analysis of Korean derivation and inflection. Pre: 451 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: History and Dialects of Korean Language (3)
desc: Survey of various hypotheses on the genetic relationship of Korean; evolution of Korean from the 15th century to the present; Korean dialects. Pre: 451 and 452, or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: (Alpha) Analysis of Korean Academic Discourse (3)
desc: Co-taught by Korean faculty of professional schools and Korean instruction in domain of (B) economics; (C) political science; (D) computer science; (E) travel industry management; (G) business; (H) law; (I) medicine; (J) nursing and public health; and (K) others. Exclusively in Korean. Repeatable one time. Pre: 485 or 623 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Interdisciplinary Research in Korean (3)
desc: Combined lecture-discussion on preparing students to be able to conduct interdisciplinary research in Korean. Require advanced-level Korean proficiency. Pre: diagnostic assessment (equivalent to ILR Level 2) or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Comparative Studies of Contemporary South and North Korean Language (3)
desc: Comparing and analyzing language data to investigate language heterogeneity problems, its causes, and importance of comparative studies in NK/SK language differences; differences in language policy, grammar, and vocabulary, pronunciation, and discourse style. Pre: 621 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Media Research in Korean (3)
desc: Focuses on searching, analyzing, and evaluating media data for research in areas of student specializations. Students are required to write short analysis papers and a final research paper. Pre: diagnostic assessment (equivalent to ILR Level 2) or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: (Alpha) Korean Drama (3)
desc: Intensive and analytical reading of selected materials in Korean performing arts (e.g., spectacle, farce play, mask dance, staged narratives, theatrical drama): (M) modern; (T) traditional. Pre: 494 or consent for (M), 493 or consent for (T).
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: (Alpha) Korean Narrative (3)
desc: Intensive and analytical reading of selected works of Korean narrative (e.g., myth,  p’ansori , shaman song, essay, biography, fiction): (M) modern; (T) traditional. Repeatable one time with instructor consent for (M). Pre: 494 or consent for (M), 493 or consent for (T).
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: (Alpha) Korean Verse (3)
desc:
Intensive and analytical reading of selected works of Korean lyric and didactic verse (e.g.,  hyangga, changga, hanshi, sijo, kasa , free form): (M) modern; (T) traditional. Repeatable 
one time with instructor consent for (M). Pre: 494 or consent for (M), 493 or consent for (T).
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Directed Fourth-Level Reading (V)
desc: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. Primarily for graduate students from other departments. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent of department chair.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean Abroad (V)
desc: Supervised internship with Korean professional hosts in Korea. Students also undergo a one-week training module designed to prepare them to maximize the benefits of the overseas internship. Repeatable up to 3 times. CR/ NC only. Pre: 495, diagnostic assessment procedures; or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Internship Program (V)
desc: Supervised internship with Korean professional hosts on O‘ahu or in Korea. Students will also attend an on-campus preparatory and follow-up language class. A-F only. Pre: 486, diagnostic assessment procedures; or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Introduction to Modern Korean Literature (3)
desc: Critical Korean-language readings of 20th-century literature that emphasize context and the development of style. Includes an emphasis on writing instruction. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: DL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Introduction to Traditional Korean Literature (3)
desc: Critical readings from earliest times and presentations that emphasize genre, style, and context. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: DL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean for Academic Purposes: Social Science & Others (3)
desc: Focus on expanding students’ Korean literacy and cultural knowledge in Social Science and other disciplines, including politics, economy, society, writing in Korean. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean for Academic Purposes: Humanities (3)
desc: Focus on expanding students’ Korean literacy and cultural knowledge in various Humanities disciplines, including history, religion, language, education, and literature. Taught entirely in Korean. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean Proficiency Through Film (3)
desc: Study of Korean culture through films to elevate students’ Korean proficiency level and improve their knowledge of Korea. Emphasis on writing instruction. Requires a minimum of 16 pages of graded writing. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Language and Culture of Korea (3)
desc: Relation of Korean language to literature, history, philosophy, social structure, values, and interpersonal relationships; social and regional varieties. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: DH East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Structure of Korean: Syntax (3)
desc: Introduction to syntax and semantics. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Structure of Korean: Phonology/Morphology (3)
desc: Introduction to phonology, morphology, and history. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Selected Readings in Korean (3)
desc: Selected readings in various disciplines. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Media Analysis in Korean: Contemporary Ethical Issues in Korea (3)
desc: Focus on analyzing, comparing, and evaluating current ethical issues in South Korea and North Korea using media materials to develop professional language skills and to deepen knowledge and understanding of contemporary North Korea. A-F only. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Media Analysis in Korean: Contemporary Korean Culture (3)
desc: Focus on analyzing, comparing, and evaluating current media materials in South Korea to develop professional language skills and to deepen knowledge and understanding of contemporary Korean society. A-F only. Pre: 402, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean Composition (3)
desc: Training in modern structural and stylistic techniques; writing on designated themes. Repeatable one time. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Advanced Oral Communication in Korean (3)
desc: Fourth-year advanced Korean course to increase learners’ oral fluency and accuracy; with an emphasis on formal speaking. Covers linguistic proficiency as well as social and cultural proficiencies. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: High-Advanced Korean II (3)
desc: Continuation of 402. Emphasis on highest level of listening, speaking, reading and writing, with application to Korean culture using authentic materials and focusing on training in oral presentation skills. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: High-Advanced Korean: Korean Society (3)
desc: Emphasis on highest level of listening, speaking, reading and writing, with application to Korean society, using authentic materials. Pre: 402 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Fourth-Level Korean II (3)
desc: Continuation of 401. Pre: 401 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Fourth-Level Korean I (3)
desc: Continuation of 302. Pre: 302 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Directed Third-Level Reading (V)
desc: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. Offered if staff available. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Korean Proficiency Through TV Drama (3)
desc: Increasing Korean proficiency to advanced level through TV drama, which provides culturally and situationally rich contexts. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Readings in Chinese Characters II (3)
desc: Continuation of 307, covering an additional 250 basic Chinese characters. Pre: 307 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Readings in Chinese Characters I (3)
desc: Training intermediate and advanced learners of Korean to master the reading, writing and usage of some 250 basic Chinese characters as they are used in a wide variety of Korean reading texts. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Accelerated Third-Level Korean (6)
desc: Content of 301 and 302 covered in one intensive summer course. Five 3-hour sessions per week, Monday-Friday. Pre: 202, 205, placement test, or consent. (Summer only)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Third-Level Korean II (3)
desc: Continuation of 301. Pre: 301 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Third-Level Korean I (3)
desc: Continuation of 201 and 202. Major emphasis on comprehension of modern written Korean. Chinese characters. Pre: 202 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Intermediate Conversational Korean II (3)
desc: Continuation of 211. Pre: 201 or 211, or consent.
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Intermediate Conversational Korean I (3)
desc: Further development of listening and speaking skills. The student is expected to be able to comprehend and produce speech at the paragraph level. Pre: 102 or 112, or consent
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Accelerated Intermediate Korean (8)
desc: Content of KOR 201 and 202 covered in one intensive course. Four 2-hour sessions per week, Monday-Thursday, plus daily lab work. Pre: 102, 105, 112, placement test; or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Intermediate Korean II (4)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201 or placement test; or consent.
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Intermediate Korean I (4)
desc: Continuation of 101 and 102. Meets one hour, four times a week, plus lab work. Pre: 102 or placement test; or consent.
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Elementary Conversational Korean II (3)
desc: Continuation of 111. Pre: 101 or 111, or consent.
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Elementary Conversational Korean I (3)
desc: Development of basic skills (listening, speaking and grammar) of spoken Korean, with application to some familiar everyday topics. Pre: consent.
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Accelerated Elementary Korean (8)
desc: Content of KOR 101 and 102 covered in one intensive course. Four 2-hour sessions per week, Monday-Thursday, plus daily lab work. Pre: placement test or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Elementary Korean II (4)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101 or consent.
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KOR
title: Elementary Korean I (4)
desc: Listening, speaking, reading, writing, grammar. Meets one hour, four times a week, plus lab work. Pre: consent.
metadata: HSL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Korean (KOR)

subject: KRS
title: Seminar in Rehabilitation Counseling (V)
desc: In-depth study of professional concerns in rehabilitation counseling. A-F only. Pre: 703R and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Doctoral Seminar IV in Kinesiology (V)
desc: Designed to enable PhD students to gain a perspective of the discipline, both historically and philosophically, prepare them for the issues they may face in the real world, particularly higher education and help them initiate their dissertation. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. KRS majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Doctoral Seminar and Research III in Kinesiology (3)
desc: Provide the PhD student the opportunity to assume the role of director of a research project under the supervision of the faculty mentor. The research project will represent a piece of the ongoing line of research of the faculty mentor. Responsibilities will be comparable of a project director of research funded by a research grant. Repeatable three times or up to 12 credits. KRS majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 776 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Doctoral Seminar and Research II in Kinesiology (V)
desc: Provide the PhD student the opportunity to be involved in research, under the direction of the faculty mentor, as the assistant project director and as the project director for pilot studies. Student will gain experience in these roles with close supervision by the faculty mentor. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. KRS majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 775 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Doctoral Seminar and Research I in Kinesiology (V)
desc: Provide the PhD student the opportunity to assume the role of director of a research project under the supervision of the faculty mentor. The research project will represent a piece of the ongoing line of research of the faculty mentor. Responsibilities will be comparable of a project director of research funded by a research grant. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. KRS majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 776 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Seminar in College Counseling (3)
desc: In-depth study of professional concerns in college counseling. A-F only. Pre: 703U and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Seminar in Community Counseling (3)
desc: In-depth study of professional concerns in community counseling. A-F only. Pre: 703C and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Seminar in School Counseling (3)
desc: In-depth study of professional concerns in school counseling. A-F only. Pre: 703 (E or H) and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: (Alpha) Internship II (V)
desc: Supervised post-internship I experience in counseling and guidance activities at an approved site, including a weekly class meeting. Provides practical application of formal academic training: (C) community service; (E) elementary; (H) secondary; (R) rehabilitation; (U) college. Each alpha is repeatable three times. A-F only. Pre: 733 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: (Alpha) Internship I (V)
desc: Supervised post-practicum experience in counseling and guidance activities at an approved site, including a weekly class meeting. Provides practical application of formal academic training: (C) community service; (E) elementary; (H) secondary; (R) rehabilitation; (U) college. Each alpha is repeatable three times. Pre: 703 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Contemporary Issues in Counseling (3)
desc: Current issues and problems. (Meets EdD common required elective.) Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: (Alpha) Practicum in Counseling (V)
desc: Supervised clinical experience in counseling and guidance activities at an approved site, including a weekly class meeting. Provides practical application of formal academic training: (C) community service; (E) elementary; (H) secondary; (R) rehabilitation; (U) college. Each alpha is repeatable three times. Pre: 626 or 683, and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Directed Reading and/or Research (V)
desc: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent of instructor and department chair.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Promoting Physical Activity (3)
desc: Overview of the theoretical and applied study of physical activity epidemiology. Physical activity content includes benefits, factors that influence, levels, valid instruments to assess, and programs to promote physical activity. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as PH 695)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Theory and Techniques of Job Placement (3)
desc: Theory, process, and techniques of job readiness, job development, and job placement. Pre: 627 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Assistive Technology in Rehabilitation Counseling (3)
desc: Study of application of assistive technologies to enhance the lives of people with disabilities. Case studies provide the vehicle in guiding students toward integration of available information into reality of actual situations. Special emphasis on the importance of using a consumer-centered approach in providing assistive technology services. A-F only. Pre: 681 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Vocational Evaluation and Assessment in Rehabilitation (3)
desc: Theory, process, and techniques of vocational evaluation and assessment. Assessment methods and processes as they relate to vocational choice and adjustment of special groups. Pre: 681 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Ethical Issues for the Helping Profession (3)
desc: Developing ethical reasoning capabilities for resolution of ethical dilemmas likely to be encountered in counseling, psychology, and specialty practices (e.g., community, rehabilitation, school, mental health, alcohol and substance abuse, marriage and family counseling, and the like). A-F only. Pre: 606 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Psychopathology in Counseling (3)
desc: Discussion-oriented course (potentially Web-based). Examination of theory and practice of diagnosis in the assessment and treatment of mental disorders and the use of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV) multi-axial system. Case studies will illustrate diagnostic issues. A-F only. Pre: 606 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Case Management in Rehabilitation (3)
desc: Knowledge and skills required in case and case-load management in public as well as private sector rehabilitation sites. Emphasis on professional/ client relationship, interviewing process, decision-making, goal-setting, recording/documentation, time management, and other tasks. Pre: 680 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Medical and Psychosocial Aspects of Disability (3)
desc: Functional implications of chronic illnesses and disabilities on psychological, social and vocational areas of an individuals life. Case studies and presentations will stimulate discussion and help students to apply theoretical information into practical everyday context. Pre: 680 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Principles and Practice of Rehabilitation Counseling (3)
desc: Principles, practices of rehabilitation counseling; review of history and influence of legislation on vocational rehabilitation; current issues, developments, with emphasis on local situation. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Transdisciplinary Approach to Teaching the Motor Domain (3)
desc: Highlights a trans-disciplinary approach for effectively teaching students with disabilities in the motor domain. Important characteristics and components of this approach will be shared. Strategies for its implementation will also be addressed. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Assessment in Physical Activity (3)
desc: Overview of assessment purposes, types, practices and procedures used in physical education for those with disabilities. Frequently used motor assessments and practices in collection of data will be specifically addressed. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Research Methods in KRS (3)
desc: The use of experimental designs/models in physical education research with emphasis on understanding the concepts, applications, and interpretations of statistical analysis. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Consultation: Theory and Practice (3)
desc: Consultation in educational, business, health, community, and human services agencies. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Body Composition and Weight Management (3)
desc: Analysis of the theory and practice used in the assessment of body composition and human physique. Includes strategies for implementing changes in body composition. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Advanced Fitness Assessment and Exercise Prescription (3)
desc: Provides knowledge of field and laboratory techniques and procedures for aerobic and anaerobic fitness assessment, interpretation of testing results and individual exercise program/ prescription techniques. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Metabolic Analysis (3)
desc: Theory and practice of metabolic analysis of human performance examining each of the power systems used in energy production during exercise and how to use this information to prescribe exercise programs. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Physiology of Exercise (3)
desc: Physiological bases of modern physical training methods and sports science. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Biomechanics of Human Motion (3)
desc: Principles of motion as applied to sport and physical rehabilitation. Introduction to the technology used in the analysis of motion. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Marriage, Family, and Child Counseling (3)
desc: Theory/practice of marriage, family, and child counseling, including major model in clinical practice; supervised counseling project by each student. Liability insurance required. Pre: 629 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: American College Student (3)
desc: Study of psychosocial characteristics of American college students and college environment, from viewpoint of student personnel work. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Secondary Physical Education (3)
desc: Detailed examination of effective physical education curriculum and instruction in middle and high schools. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Seminar: Health/Exercise Science (3)
desc: Review of selected current literature in exercise/sport science and leisure studies. Practice of presentation in group setting.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Seminar in Physical Activity (3)
desc: Trends, research, and problems related to physical activity across the lifespan. A variety of topics and contexts will be addressed. Enrolled in KRS graduate program only. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Cross-Cultural Counseling (3)
desc: Significance of cultural factors in counseling relationships, delivery of counseling services in multicultural settings with attention to Hawai‘i. Emphasis on process of cultural learning and implications for counselor roles and functions. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Theory and Assessment of Personality (3)
desc: Personality testing; practice in administration and use of personality assessment; examination of psychometric and social issues. Pre: 630 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Elementary Physical Education (3)
desc: Content and pedagogy for teaching preschool/ elementary physical education. Students will learn appropriate content and pedagogy for learners in elementary school. Bit teaching and field experiences are included. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Inclusive Physical Activity (3)
desc: Advanced knowledge on issues of socio-cultural, learning styles, diversity, and exceptionalities, and how these influence instruction, engagement, and behavior in physical activity settings across the lifespan. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as SPED 634)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Crisis Intervention (3)
desc: Professional concerns about crisis intervention strategies, and counseling skills development. Crisis theory as applied to suicide, sexual assault/rape, natural and man-made disasters, personal loss, terminal illness, life cycle crisis, and the like. A-F only. Pre: 606 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Theory and Assessment of Intelligence (3)
desc: Theory and supervised experience in individual intelligence testing, psychological report writing; psychometric and social issues in intelligence testing. Pre: 630 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Problems of School Adjustment (3)
desc: Principles of behavior affecting interpersonal relationships in school with emphasis on application to actual situations. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Tests and Inventories in Guidance (3)
desc: Tests and inventories for the assessment of aptitudes, achievement, and interests. Applications to educational, instructional, and career guidance. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Counseling: Group Theory and Practice (3)
desc: Theories and techniques of group counseling and guidance as preparation for practicum and internship. Application in school, college, rehabilitation, and community settings. Pre: 626 or 683, and 606, and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Research in Evaluation in Counseling (3)
desc:
Framework for understanding basic statistics, methodology, and evaluation of research in counseling and related fields. Students will analyze research, 
conceptualize research, and apply research to practice. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Career Development and Vocational Counseling (3)
desc: Theory and practice in career development and vocational counseling with individuals and groups; utilization of educational, vocational, and social resources in career counseling. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Introduction to Practicum (3)
desc: Pre-practicum training for supervised experiences in school, community, and human service organizations. Focus on the counseling relationship. Includes a specialty observation-participation field experience.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Introduction to Community Counseling (3)
desc: Philosophy, organization, and function of community service agencies, programs, and institutions as related to professional work in counseling. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Administration in Kinesiology (3)
desc: Current problems, trends, and strategies in the administration of athletic training, physical education, recreation, sport and fitness programs in school and non-school settings. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as EDEA 623)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Athletic Training Capstone Experience (3)
desc: Capstone culminating experience preparing the student for the computer-based BOC Exam and for a career in athletic training. Follows the students’ didactic and clinical preparation in the 12 competency areas of athletic training. Repeatable one time. KRS majors only. A-F only. Pre: 611 or consent. Co-requisite: 612. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Advanced Therapeutic Exercise (3)
desc: Advanced concepts and evidence-based principles of rehabilitation programs. Enhancement of previously learned therapeutic exercise techniques and integration of therapeutic modalities and therapeutic exercise, including objective and functional goal setting and evaluation for appropriate progression and expedited return to activity. KRS majors only. Pre: 617 and 618 or basic therapeutic exercise and therapeutic modalities courses, or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Seminar in Athletic Training (1)
desc: Designed to provide the student with analytical skills and practical experience relative to research as it applies to sports related injuries. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: General Medical Conditions in Sports Medicine (3)
desc: An examination/evaluation of general medical conditions associated with sports medicine including pathology, care and treatment. Athletic Training majors only. Pre: PHYL 301, PHYL 302 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Therapeutic Interventions: Rehabilitative Exercise (3)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Concepts and principles of comprehensive rehabilitation programs (therapeutic goals and objectives, exercise selection, methods of evaluation and recording progress, progression and return to competition criteria, and physiological effects of tissue trauma and inactivity). Athletic Training majors only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Therapeutic Interventions: Modalities (3)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Physiology principles and operational procedures of contemporary therapeutic modalities as they relate to the care and treatment of athletic injuries. Athletic Training majors only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Advanced Orthopedic Assessment (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Advanced knowledge and skills of athletic training as they are specifically applied to the understanding, treatment, and rehabilitation of sport-related injuries. (e.g. epidemiology, legal, ethical concerns, sports psychology, pharm, drug abuse, health issues) Pre: ANAT/KRS 604 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: (Alpha) Clinical Examination of Pathology (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Examination, care and treatment of musculoskeletal, neurological, and neuromuscular conditions and pathology; (B) lower body; (H) head, neck and spine; (U) upper body. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Athletic Training Research Practicum (V)
desc: (1 Sem, 5 4-hr Practicum) Advanced research practicum in which the BOC certified or certification eligible graduate student deepens their understanding and enhances their critical thinking abilities in order to contribute to the advancement of the discipline and the athletic training profession. Repeatable four times, up to 12 credits. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Athletic Training Clinical Practicum (V)
desc: (1 Sem, 5 4-hr Practicum) Advanced clinical practicum in which the BOC certified or certification eligible graduate student experiences an enhancement of athletic training knowledge and refinement of athletic training skills. Repeatable up to 10 credits. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Athletic Training, Clinical Experience IV (3)
desc: (1 Sem, 5 3-hr Practicum) Culminating practicum requiring performance of duties and responsibilities of second year graduate athletic training students. A practical field experience in athletic training is required. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only. Pre: 611 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Athletic Training, Clinical Experience III (3)
desc: (1 Sem, 5 3-hr Practicum) Culminating practicum requiring performance of duties and responsibilities of second year graduate athletic training students. A practical field experience in athletic training is required. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only. (Fall only
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Athletic Training, Clinical Experience II (3)
desc: (1 Sem, 5 3-hr Practicum) Practicum includes duties and responsibilities of athletic training students. Practicum must be completed during second semester post admission to the program. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Athletic Training, Clinical Experience I (3)
desc: (1 Sem, 5 3-hr Practicum) Practicum requiring performance of duties and responsibilities of athletic training students. Must be completed during first semester post admission into program. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Muscular Strength and Power Development (3)
desc: Interpretation of scientific principles of muscular strength and power development. Examination of muscular adaptations to increased and decreased use. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Scientific Principles of Physical Conditioning (3)
desc: Application of physiological principles to physical conditioning and athletic performance. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Counseling: Theory and Practice (3)
desc: Theory and techniques of counseling and guidance as preparation for practicum and internship. Application in school, college, rehabilitation, and community settings. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Human Growth and Development—Life Span (3)
desc: Life span perspective on psychological, social, and physical development. Major theories and related research on human development; applications in policy planning and service delivery in counseling. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Upper Extremity, Head, Neck, and Spine (3)
desc: Human gross anatomy dissection of the upper extremity, head, neck, and spine. Emphasis is placed on muscles, function, innervation, and vascular supply. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in DRB or KRS graduate programs (including Biomed Sci-Anat/ RepoBiol & Phys majors) only or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as ANAT 604)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Lower Extremity, Thorax, and Abdomen (3)
desc: Human gross anatomy dissection of the lower extremity, thorax, and abdomen with emphasis on muscles, function, innervation, and vascular supply. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in DRB or KRS graduate programs (including Biomed Sci-Anat/ RepoBiol & Phys majors) only or consent. A-F only. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as ANAT 603)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Counseling in the Schools (3)
desc: History, philosophy, and organization of school counseling programs. Counselor role and functions, legal and ethical issues, contemporary issues, current methodology and resources. (Meets EdD common core elective.) Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Athletic Training Practicum IV (3)
desc: (5 2-hr Practicum) Advanced-level supervised experiences within the profession of athletic training. This practicum is a requirement for entry to the KRS Master’s Athletic Training Program. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Athletic Training Practicum III (3)
desc: Advanced-level supervised experiences within the profession of athletic training. This practicum is a requirement for entry to the KRS Master’s Athletic Training Program. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: AT Practicum II (3)
desc: Introductory-level supervised experiences within the profession of athletic training. This practicum is required for the KRS entry-level Graduate Athletic Training Education Program. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: AT Practicum I (3)
desc: Introductory-level supervised experiences within the profession of athletic training. This practicum is required for the KRS entry-level Graduate Athletic Training Education Program. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Introduction to Athletic Training Clinic (3)
desc: Introduction to the Professional Athletic Training Education Program and the Clinical Education Plan. Students are required to document all requirements and demonstrate proficiency in basic clinical skills. Repeatable one time. A-F only. ATEP Program students only. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Program Design in Strength Training and Conditioning (3)
desc: Designed to provide theoretical and practical experience in supervision of a strength training center. Content includes program design, exercise techniques, organization, testing, evaluation, methods of strength development, facility design and special populations. Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science, Health/Exercise Science and Lifestyle Management, and Physical Education majors only. A-F only. Pre: 152, 153, 353, 354, 354L, and 463; or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Practicum in Health and Exercise Science (4)
desc: Culminating 160 hours of supervised practicum experience in health, wellness, fitness assessment, lifestyle management, and/or exercise leadership. Qualifying hours are contingent upon instructor’s approval in the registered semester. Health and Exercise Science majors only. Pre: current CPR and First Aid Certification, 152, 332, 353, 354, and 463; or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Exercise Assessment and Conditioning Lab (4)
desc: Designed to provide knowledge of laboratory techniques and procedures for aerobic and anaerobic fitness assessment, interpretation of aerobic and anaerobic testing results, and individual exercise program/prescription. A-F only. Pre: 480 and EDEP 429, or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Sexual Health Education (3)
desc: Program planning, curriculum development and classroom teaching strategies in the areas of human sexuality, reproductive health, family planning, and family health. Focus on research-based curriculum and strategies to promote personal and social responsibility for health. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Drug Abuse, Violence, and Injury Prevention (3)
desc: Standards-based planning, teaching, and assessment on the scientific, socio-cultural, and attitudinal aspects of drug abuse, violence, and injury prevention. Focus on incidence and prevalence, roles, prevention, and high-risk populations. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Recreation Planning and Maintenance (3)
desc: Examination of social, economic, and environmental factors of recreation and tourism development. Emphasis on methods, processes, citizen participation, design issues/regulations, and land use. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 238 and 329; or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Commercial Recreation (3)
desc: Overview of leisure services and trends in commercial, private and employee recreation, and resort and recreational tourism. The social, economic, and environmental significance is examined. Pre: 428 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Introduction to Research in KRS (3)
desc: Research methods in the study of physical activity, types of research, statistical concepts and techniques, and reporting research results. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Nutrition in Exercise and Sport (3)
desc: Effects of physiologic demands of exercise on nutrition. Emphasis on physiologic and biochemical basis for nutrition recommendations to enhance exercise participation and optimize athletic performance. Pre: (FSHN 185, and KRS 113 or PHYL 103 or (PHYL 141/141L and 142/142L) or PHYL 301) with a minimum grade of C. (Cross-listed as FSHN 480)
metadata: DB College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Adapted Physical Activity in Early Childhood (3)
desc: Concepts of developmentally appropriate practice, importance of movement in overall development, and design of physical activity sessions and environments for young children with and without disabilities are covered. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Motor Development and Learning (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 1-hr. Lab) Motor development through the lifespan with an emphasis on fundamental principles and patterns. Areas such as memory, knowledge of performance, and motivation are incorporated and demonstrated through multiple writing assignments. Required field experience. Primarily for KRS majors. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Motor Learning and Performance (3)
desc: Basic consideration is kinesthesis, motor ability, fatigue, developmental factors, practice, motivation in relation to motor learning and human performance. Repeatable one time. Pre: EDEP 311 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Statistics (3)
desc: Basic elements for: descriptive statistics, probability, inference, regression, and correlation analysis. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Sociocultural Issues in Physical Activity (3)
desc: Contemporary and historical perspective on socio-cultural issues that influence health and physical activity settings. Understanding ethics and culturally responsive practice around race, gender, sexuality, class, etc. Emphasis on ethics and teaching writing for the profession. Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DS College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Learning Communities (3)
desc: Theory, basic research, interactive process, and methodology of the cooperative learning process known as Tribes. Will develop participants’ abilities to foster and facilitate learning communities in a variety of settings. Repeatable one time. (Summer only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Teaching Methods in Health Education (3)
desc: Experiences in developing standards-based, interactive learning opportunities to teach quality health education in schools. Focus on creating curriculum and assessments aligned with the National and State Standards for Health Education. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Fitness for Life (3)
desc: Students will gain knowledge, skills, and experience necessary to plan, implement, and evaluate Fitness for Life curriculum. Includes an emphasis on instruction and feedback in oral communication. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Sport Biomechanics (3)
desc: Concepts and scientific principles essential to efficient human movement; proper application of biomechanical principles to fundamental movements and selected complex motor skills. KRS majors only. A-F only. Pre: 353, and either PHYS 100, PHYS 151, or PHYS 170; or consent.
metadata: DB College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Disability and Diversity in Physical Activity (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 1-hr. Lab) Participants will explore issues related to individuals with exceptionalities, how these affect learning and behavior in the health and physical activity settings. Oral communication practice and skills are worth >30% grade. Required field experience. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Practicum in Camping (V)
desc: Supervised leadership at a camp setting with children and youth, including those with disabilities. Day or residential camps. One full week camping for each credit hour. Maximum of four credit hours. Pre: 437 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Camp Resources and Planning (2)
desc: (1 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Combined lecture-lab for camp counselors and camp leadership. Plan and evaluate camp experiences for children and youth, including those with disabilities. Includes field trips. Pre: 331 and 332, or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Coaching Athletics (3)
desc: Combined lecture-lab with emphasis on scientific principles, theory and practice, and professional qualities of the coach. Writing is integrated with the intent that students will enhance their communication skills through writing. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Emergency Care for the Professional Rescuer (3)
desc: Combined lecture-lab on advanced emergency care for injuries and illnesses and includes certifications for CPR/First Aid/AED. Class size of approximately 20 students. Open to all majors. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Evaluating and Marketing Leisure Services (3)
desc: Basic methods in marketing, planning, evaluating programs and problem-solving methods, survey research, research design, data analysis, and report generation for park, recreation, and tourism systems. A-F only. Pre: 329 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Current Issues in Leisure Services (3)
desc: Philosophical foundations and current and emerging issues in leisure services management and programming. Coverage of leisure research and its implications to practice. Repeatable one time. Pre: 238, 249, and 329; or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Curriculum and Supervision (3)
desc: Effective program development, planning, and supervision, including issues in legal liability and administration of all aspects of physical education programming in grades K-12. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 270 or consent. Majors only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Upper Extremity Assessment (3)
desc: An examination of the pathology of injuries to the upper extremities and their care and treatment designed for Athletic Training, Exercise Science and Allied Health professionals. Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science, Health/Exercise Science and Lifestyle Management, and Physical Education majors only. A-F only. Pre: 353 and 415, or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Lower Extremity Assessment (3)
desc: An examination of the pathology of injuries to the lower extremities and their care and treatment designed for Athletic Training, Exercise Science and Allied Health professionals. KRS majors only. A-F only. Pre: 353, 415; or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Administration in Athletic Training, Exercise Science, Allied Health (3)
desc: An examination of organization and administration in Athletic Training, Allied Health and Exercise Science. Content includes leadership and motivation models, legal liability, ethical considerations and management strategies for all aspects of Health Care Administration. KRS majors only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Fundamentals of Ergonomics (3)
desc: Introduction to ergonomics principles and their application in understanding and prevention of Muscular Skeletal Disorders encountered in the working environment including introduction to legal aspects of ergonomics. Post-Master’s Certificate in Nursing majors only. Pre: 463 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Prevent/Care of Athletic Injuries (3)
desc: An examination of the most recent practices and procedures in the prevention and care of athletic and sports injuries. Observational field experiences in athletic training will be required. KRS majors only. A-F only. Pre: 353.
metadata: DB College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Psychosocial Aspects of Sport (3)
desc: Examination and application of sociological and psychological theories to sport including the influence of race, ethnicity, gender, identity and human development, social class, disabilities, and sexual orientation on the sport experience. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: DS College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Seminar in Teaching Residency (3)
desc: Analysis and resolutions of issues in teaching residency; teaching strategies and techniques; curriculum planning; professional growth and development. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 402E, 402S, and 404 or consent; admittance to licensure track, pass Praxis II Core Academic Skills tests.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: (Alpha) Teaching Residency (9)
desc: Full-time supervised experience in elementary and secondary school level. School level corresponds to level of licensure desired. (E) elementary; (S) secondary. Each alpha can be taken one time. Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science, Physical Education, and Secondary Education-Physical Education majors only. A-F only. Pre: 402E (with a minimum grade of B-), 402S (with a minimum grade of B-), and 404 (with a minimum grade of B-); admittance to licensure track, pass Praxis II Core Academic Skills tests. Co-requisite: 406.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: K-12 Teaching Methods in Physical Education (3)
desc: Methods and materials in teaching physical education, including techniques, leadership skills, program evaluation, and designing course content using written communication skills. Repeatable one time, but credit earned one time only. A-F only. KRS majors only. Co-requisite: 402E.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Guidance and Classroom Management (3)
desc: Guidance principles applied to classroom management for teachers. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: (Alpha) Teaching Practicum in Physical Education (3)
desc: Field experience in teaching physical education activities in schools, K-12; techniques in leadership; selection of activities and program evaluation for K-12 licensure. (E) elementary; (S) secondary. KRS majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: admittance to licensure track; pass basic skills tests specified by the Hawai‘i Teacher Standards Board (www.htsb.org) or bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Advanced Health Concepts (3)
desc: Understanding health issues for individuals, families, schools, and communities, in regards to Hawaii K-12 schools. Focusing on the acquisition of functional health content and proficiency in health-related skills to enhance healthy behaviors in learners. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.
