metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Individual problems. Limited to senior majors in health education, physical education, athletic training, or recreation with a minimum GPA of 2.75 in major field. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Personal Health and Wellness (3)
desc: Core concepts in health allow students to take responsibility for their own health-related behaviors by developing basic competencies in identifying, analyzing, and responsibly deliberating contemporary ethical issues related to health and wellness. KRS majors only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Field Work in Strength and Conditioning I (1)
desc: Supervised practicum in strength training and conditioning. Students will be exposed to the theory and practice of designing and implementing both strength/power, and general conditioning programs. Repeatable one time. Pre: 152, 354 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Physical Fitness for Physical Education Teachers (1)
desc: Diagnosis and prescription for basic health and fitness problems, scientific principles of training, guidelines for exercise; essentials of scientifically based individualized physical fitness program. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Drugs and Society (3)
desc: Introduction to psychoactive drugs and their effects; drug regulations; education and rehabilitation programs; psycho-social variables related to the decisions to use/abuse drugs. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Teaching Techniques II: Secondary (3)
desc: Teaching techniques and methods of secondary physical education. Content to include invasion, net, field, and target activities. Emphasizes the tactical approach in a school-based experience. Primarily for KRS majors. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Teaching Techniques I: Elementary (3)
desc: Teaching techniques and methods of elementary physical education. Content to include basic skills and games in a school-based experience. Primarily for KRS majors. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Exercise and Sport Physiology Lab (2)
desc: Laboratory section to accompany KRS 354. Emphasis will be hands-on data collection and analysis of the physiological responses to exercise and physical training. Lab report development and scientific writing will also be emphasized. Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science, Health/Exercise Science and Lifestyle Management, and Physical Education majors only. A-F only. Pre: 113 or PHYL 103 or PHYL 142/142L (or concurrent), or BIOL 171/171L (or concurrent); or consent. Co-requisite: 354.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Exercise and Sport Physiology (3)
desc: Emphasis on physiological responses to exercises and physical training as related to strength, muscular endurance, cardio-respiratory endurance. Primarily for KRS majors, but open to others with consent. Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science, Health/ Exercise Science and Lifestyle Management, and Physical Education majors only. A-F only. Pre: 113 or PHYL 103 or PHYL 142/142L (or concurrent), or BIOL 171/171L (or concurrent); or consent. Co-requisite: 354L.
metadata: DB College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Structural Kinesiology (3)
desc: Gross human anatomy, emphasizing identification and description of parts of the musculoskeletal system; selected applications to motor activity. KRS majors only. A-F only. Pre: 113 or BIOL 171/171L or PHYL 103 or PHYL 141/141L or PHYL 301/301L.
metadata: DB College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Special Recreation (3)
desc: Special recreation as a professional field. Overview of special recreation services. Emphasis on recreation services for special populations. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 208 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Fieldwork in Recreation I (5)
desc: Initial supervised leadership experience in recreational agencies. One hour per week in class discussion sessions. For recreation majors only. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: consent of recreation advisor.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Coaching of Swimming (2)
desc: Theory and methods of coaching competitive swimming. Technical, organizational, and administrative aspects. Emphasis on stroke mechanics and training methods. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Coaching of Track and Field (2)
desc: Techniques and rules of sprints, distance runs, relays, hurdles, long jump, high jump, pole vault, shot put, discus, and javelin throws; conduct of track and field meets; specific conditioning and training problems. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Movement Education II (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 1-hr. Lab) Content and pedadogy for teaching Pre/K-5 physical education. Students will learn to plan and teach physical education for children. Peer bit and field teaching included. Repeatable one time, but credit earned one time only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Movement Education I (3)
desc: A movement-based approach to teaching basic motor skills in preschool/elementary physical education. Students actively participate and learn about developmentally appropriate content and pedagogy for children in grades P–5/6. Peer bit teaching is included. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Emergency Care and First Aid Training (3)
desc: Practicum in training of persons to become qualified in emergency care knowledge, basic life support, and first aid skills. First Aid and CPR certificates may be earned. KRS majors only.
metadata: DB College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Water Safety Training (3)
desc: Theory and methods of advanced lifesaving and water safety leading to American Red Cross Water Safety Instructor (WSI) certification. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 104 or consent. (Student to provide own swim attire approved by the instructor.)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Managing Recreation Services (3)
desc: Administrative framework and procedures pertinent to the operation of agencies providing recreational services to the various publics. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 208 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Music and Rhythm in Physical Education (3)
desc: Use of music in physical education programming (K-12), emphasizing selection of appropriate music for specific activities as expressive or creative movement, movement exploration, rhythmic gymnastics, and dancing. A variety of strategies for teaching dance will be shared. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Coaching of Volleyball (2)
desc: Theory and strategy of offensive and defensive volleyball coaching. Emphasis on coaching philosophy, selecting and developing an offense and defense, organizing practices, special situations, scouting, and training and conditioning. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Coaching of Baseball (2)
desc: Theory and strategy of offensive and defensive baseball coaching. Emphasis on coaching philosophy, selecting and developing an offense and defense, organizing practices, special situations, scouting, and training and conditioning. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Coaching of Basketball (2)
desc: Theory and strategy of offensive and defensive basketball coaching. Emphasis on coaching philosophy, selecting and developing an offense and defense, organizing practices, special situations, scouting, and training and conditioning. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Coaching of Football (2)
desc: Theory and strategy of offensive and defensive football coaching. Emphasis on coaching philosophy, selecting and developing an offense and defense, organizing practices, special situations, scouting, and training and conditioning. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Principles of Sports Medicine (3)
desc: Examines with some depth, principles of risk management and pathology of athletic injuries, major musculoskeletal structures, and concepts of evaluative skills, treatment, and rehabilitation for common athletic injuries. KRS majors only. A-F only.
metadata: DB College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention (3)
desc: Understanding standards-based planning, teaching, and assessment in health with a focus on advocacy, as well as the incidence, prevalence, and prevention of disease within sub-topics of health (mental, social, emotional, environmental, financial, etc.). KRS majors only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Performance Based Assessment in Health and Physical Education (3)
desc: Assessment and evaluative techniques applied to health and physical education, including test construction, performance-based assessment, measurement criteria and instruments, interpretation of data and content, as well as program evaluation.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Introduction to Health and Physical Education (4)
desc: Introduction to foundational knowledge for effective teaching, history, philosophy, and current practices in physical education. Provides the basis for later coursework in K-12 physical education. Required field experience. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Programming and Leadership (3)
desc: Factors in planning and leading recreation programs; characteristics and responsibilities of leadership in relation to nature, scope, and resources of a variety of programs. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 208 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Health Education Curriculum (2)
desc: Objectives of school health program, emphasizing scope and sequence of health instruction; critical examination of health curriculum guides from various states. Repeatable one time. Pre: 201 or 202.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Outdoor Recreation Management (3)
desc: Objectives and values of outdoor recreation; characteristics and determinants of programs; planning, organization, leadership, and facilities for recreational uses of natural environments. Repeatable one time. Pre: 208 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Safety and Risk Management (2)
desc: Understanding the fundamental principles and techniques of safety and accident-prevention programming emphasizing school, home, public places, on the job, and motor vehicle situations. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Human Development (3)
desc: Developmental processes across the life span. Life span perspective on psychological, social, and physical development. Human growth and development from conception to death with major theories and related research on maintaining healthy lifestyles. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Recreation Services in Contemporary Society (3)
desc: Theories and philosophies in recreation: history; contemporary issues; roles in modern society; relationship to health, physical education, and exercise science. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Introduction to Kinesiology (3)
desc: Kinesiology as a professional field. Overview of history, philosophy, and current trends in kinesiology. Survey of psychological and sociological foundations of kinesiology, exercise, fitness and sport. KRS majors or approval. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: School Health Problems: Secondary (2)
desc: Responsibilities of secondary school teacher in recognizing and meeting pupils’ needs, emphasizing health instruction, health services, healthful school living, school health policies. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: School Health Problems: Elementary (2)
desc: Responsibilities of elementary school teacher in recognizing and meeting pupils’ needs, emphasizing teacher’s role in health instruction, health services, school health policies. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Softball (1)
desc: Combined lecture-lab-physical activity with emphasis on basic skills, rules, etiquette, offensive and defensive strategies, position play, and game situations. Open to all students. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Track and Field for Physical Education (1)
desc: Knowledge, skills, and rules of various track and field events. Organization of track meets and strategy in competition. Primarily for KRS majors; others admitted on space-available basis. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Floor Exercise Gymnastics (1)
desc: An entry-level course designed to develop students’ knowledge of men’s and women’s gymnastics floor exercise routines, including injury prevention, skill progression, spotting techniques, and routine choreography. Primarily for KRS majors; others admitted on space-available basis. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Sport Proficiency II: Net, Field, and Target (3)
desc: Knowledge, skill development, position, and strategy of net, field and target sports. Sports like volleyball, tennis, softball, and golf are introduced within a tactical framework. KRS majors only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Sport Proficiency I: Invasion (3)
desc: Knowledge, skill development, and strategy of various invasion type games and sports. Sports like basketball, soccer, ultimate frisbee and/or others are introduced within a tactical framework. KRS majors only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Water Polo (1)
desc: Fundamentals of basic water polo skills, namely, ball handling, passing, shooting, dribbling plus a brief introduction into beginning techniques of individual offense and defense. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 104 or consent. (Student to provide own swimming attire approved by instructor.)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Yoga: Intermediate (1)
desc: Corrective work and improvement of basic techniques. Exercise sets and combinations designed to develop endurance, flexibility, muscle and nerve strength, meditation, and deep relaxation technique. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 170 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Yoga: Beginning (1)
desc: Experiencing yoga and its effects on body, mind and consciousness of individual. Encompasses exercise, breathing techniques, deep relaxation, meditation, practice in concentration, and yogic postures. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. KRS majors only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Wrestling: Beginning (1)
desc: Rules: fundamental defensive and offensive maneuvers and competitive strategy, i.e., takedowns, reversals, escapes, and pinning combinations; conditioning exercises. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Karate: Intermediate (1)
desc: Emphasis on improving the basic techniques (stances, punches, kicks, forms, and sparring); introduction to combination techniques. (Student to provide own gi.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 164.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Karate: Beginning (1)
desc: Rules, etiquette, basic stances, blocks, thrusts, kicks, ippon kumite, and selected kata. (Student to provide own gi.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: T’ai Chi Ch’uan (1)
desc: Classic forms of t’ai chi ch’uan. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Aikido (1)
desc: Rules, etiquette, basic rolls, simple holds and the breaking of such holds, specific physical conditioning exercises. (Student to provide own gi.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Judo (1)
desc: Rules, etiquette, method of falling and breaking the fall, simple throws and their counters, simple holds and breaking of such holds, randori. (Student to provide own gi.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Heavy Apparatus (1)
desc: Single and combination stunts on side horse, horizontal bar, parallel bars, still rings; techniques of spotting; safety procedures. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Tumbling and Rebound Tumbling (1)
desc: Single and combination stunts on tumbling mats and trampoline, balancing stunts; techniques of spotting; safety procedures. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Olympic and Power Lifting (1)
desc: Exercise technique and prescription with an emphasis on anaerobic exercise. Explores advanced periodization models and their utilization, mastery of Olympic lifts, and plyometric programs. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. KRS majors only. Pre: 152 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Weight Training (1)
desc: Kinesiology of lifting and weight training, various types of exercises and methods of training with resistance. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. KRS majors only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Adapted and Prescribed Exercises (1)
desc: Small group and individual guidance and instruction for students recommended by student health service. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Basketball (1)
desc: Rules, passing, shooting, dribbling, rebounding, individual defensive and offensive maneuvers; team offense and defense. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Volleyball: Intermediate (1)
desc: Combined lecture-lab-physical activity with emphasis on improving skills and knowledge through practice and cognitive activities relative to serving, passing, spiking, digging, blocking, and offensive and defensive strategy. Open to all students. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 135 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Volleyball: Beginning (1)
desc: Combined lecture-lab-physical activity with emphasis on beginner skills and knowledge relative to serving, passing, spiking, digging, blocking, and offensive and defensive strategy. Open to all students. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Tennis: Advanced (1)
desc: Improving upon the strokes introduced in 130 and 131; advanced competitive strategy; problems in rules; officiating; elements of tournament play. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 131 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Tennis: Intermediate (1)
desc: Corrective work in three basic strokes and in net play; the lob, drop shot, overhead smash, and half-volley; applying spin in basic strokes; basic strategy in singles and doubles play. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 130 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Tennis: Beginning (1)
desc: Rules, etiquette, grip, forehand and backhand strokes, serving, volleying; singles and doubles play. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Social Dance: Latin (1)
desc: Social dances of a Latin flavor including rhumba, cha-cha, tango, samba, and others. Basic steps, rhythm pattern, styling, and variations are taught. Social etiquette is stressed. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: DA College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Social Dance: Ballroom (1)
desc: Social dances including fox trot, waltz, swing, and other popular dances. Basic steps, rhythm pattern, styling, and variations are taught. Social etiquette is stressed. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: DA College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Dances of Hawai‘i: Advanced (1)
desc: Advanced techniques in hula movements. Selected dances taught will be more complex, including work with instruments. Individual choreography will be emphasized. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 124 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Dances of Hawai‘i (1)
desc: Background and fundamentals of hula. Selected dances with and without instruments. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: DA College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Folk and National Dances (1)
desc: Popular dances of various national groups, including square dances. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: DA College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Badminton (1)
desc: Rules, etiquette, grip, forehand and backhand strokes, serving, smash, drive, net play, offensive and defensive strategy; singles and doubles play. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Bowling (1)
desc: Rules, etiquette, arm swing, approach, execution, scoring, spare pickups. Students pay charge for use of alley. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Human Physiology and Anatomy (5
desc: Introduction to human physiology and anatomy designed to serve the needs of those interested in pursuing health-related careers. Structure and function of major systems examined (gross anatomy, microanatomy, physiology, and pathology). (Spring only)
metadata: DB College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Golf: Advanced (1)
desc: Improving drive, fairway wood shots, long iron shots, control shots, trouble shots, putting, course management, competitive strategy, problems in rules. Greens fees paid by students for play on courses. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 111 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Golf: Intermediate (1)
desc: Corrective work on basic swing mechanics and rhythm; adjustments for bunker play, uphill lies, downhill lies, short game around and on the green; handicapping and match play competition. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 110 and consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Golf: Beginning (1)
desc: Rules, etiquette, grip, stance, drive, normal iron shots, approach shots, putting. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Aqua-Aerobic Fitness (1)
desc: Combined lecture-lab-physical activity with emphasis on aerobic fitness improvement through total body aquatic workouts with music, and development of individualized aquatics fitness program. Open to all students. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: SCUBA Diving: Beginning (1)
desc: Learning watermanship, equipment handling skills, and the knowledge to become safe divers. Additional costs for equipment, diver manual, dive tables, and certification fee. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Swimming: Advanced (1)
desc: Correct techniques used in competitive swimming, racing starts, correct turning techniques, long-distance swimming. (Student to provide own swimming attire approved by instructor.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 104 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Swimming: Intermediate (1)
desc: Perfecting and integrating basic strokes with added emphasis for speed and distance. (Student to provide own swimming attire approved by instructor.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Pre: 103.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Swimming: Beginning (1)
desc: Adjusting to and immersing in water, floating, sculling; correct arm stroke, leg kick, breathing techniques and their coordination. (Student to provide own swimming attire approved by instructor.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Aerobic Fitness (1)
desc: Aerobic fitness improvement upon completion of course by regularly attending and practicing safe workout routines. Learn fitness components, names of muscles and exercises associated with each one. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: KRS
title: Physical Fitness (1)
desc: Conditioning exercises and activities to develop and maintain physical efficiency. Motor fitness tests administered to measure status and progress. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: JOUR
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Individual research projects. Pre: senior standing and consent of department chair.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Internship (3)
desc: Internship in media or PR operations under professional and faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. JOUR majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: 300 and 330, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Innovation and Entrepreneurship in Journalism (3)
desc: Exploration of the leading edge of the journalistic ideology today as well as a projection of future forms, styles, and strategies, with writing skills as the foundation of such exploratory activities. JOUR majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 150, 200, 250, 300, and 330.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Advanced Video Journalism (3)
desc: Advanced experience in field and studio production of short and long form video journalism; with emphasis on social media fundamentals and content distribution across multiple digital platforms. A-F only. Pre: 330 or instructor consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Global Communication (3)
desc: Problems and opportunities of communication in a variety of international contexts, focused on journalistic issues. JOUR majors only, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Advanced Multimedia Journalism (3)
desc: Advanced fundamentals of multimedia writing and reporting, including finding and developing journalistic story ideas, photojournalism, audio storytelling, design, infographics, and cross-platform digital convergence. JOUR majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 250, 300, and 330.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Broadcast Projects/Production (3)
desc: Applied, problem-based application of skills and knowledge of visual story telling to the production of broadcast newscasts. JOUR majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 250, 300, 330; and ICS 101 or ICS 110 or ICS 111 or LTEC 112.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Media Ethics (3)
desc: Ethics and social responsibility for media professionals. Application of ethical theories and principles to case studies and research projects through writing assignments. JOUR majors only. Pre: one DS course. (Cross-listed as PACE 405)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Special Topics (3)
desc: Topics of interest to faculty and students; taught by regular and visiting faculty. Repeatable one time for different topics. JOUR majors only. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Publication Layout and Design (3)
desc: Visual display concepts and procedures for newsletters, brochures, newspapers, magazines. Pre: upper division standing.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Advanced Photojournalism (3)
desc: Computer experience in the creation, manipulation, and editing of color news, feature, sports, and documentary images. Study of the ethical and legal dimensions of electronic imaging. Pre: 307 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: (Alpha) Journalism Workshops (V)
desc: Intensive workshops in practice-based journalism, focused on building skills and making public projects in: (B) emerging media; (C) reporting; (D) editing; (E) multimedia journalism; (F) public relations. Repeatable in different alphas up to 6 credits. JOUR majors only, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Practicum (V
desc:
Working on campus student or quasi-professional publications under professional and 
faculty supervision. CR/NC only. Repeatable two times, up to six credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Communication and Law (3)
desc: An exploration of key legal issues related to the practice of journalism in Hawaiʻi, including comparisons with other jurisdictions in the United States and elsewhere. JOUR majors only, or consent. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Journalism History and Trends (3)
desc: Development of the news media and trends that may affect the future of journalism.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Video Journalism (3)
desc: Fundamentals of video journalism using digital video cameras for writing, reporting, editing, and producing news stories, with significant attention to oral communication skills. A-F only. Pre: 200.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Interpretive Journalism (3)
desc: Writing articles of news analysis, editorials, and critical reviews.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Magazine Writing (3)
desc: Writing nonfiction articles for magazines, newspapers, and newsletters; preparing material for specific audience; marketing articles. Pre: 250.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Visual Journalism: Multimedia (3)
desc: Fundamentals of visual journalism; visual theory, principles, and tools to create multimedia journalism projects for online, emerging media, and print platforms. JOUR majors only, or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Advanced Editing (3)
desc: Intensive training in editing, planning, and organizing stories and visual elements for publication; news judgment; managing projects. JOUR majors only, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Photojournalism (3)
desc: Production, selection, and use of digital photographs for publications. Storytelling action and feature photography with digital cameras, worked up through Adobe Photoshop and InDesign programs. Students must have a digital camera. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Reporting (3)
desc: Theory and practice of information gathering using a variety of primary and secondary sources, finding information online, use of databases and interviews for news stories, with emphasis on writing. JOUR majors only, or consent. A-F only. Pre: 250.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Media Writing (3)
desc: Fundamentals of writing for various news media and public relations; ethics. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Introduction to Multimedia Journalism (3)
desc: Fundamentals of multimedia reporting: finding and developing story ideas, photojournalism, audio storytelling, design, infographics, and cross-platform digital convergence. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JOUR
title: Journalism and Society (3)
desc: News literacy, and the role of journalism in society–its influence, rights and responsibilities; issues and trends.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Journalism (JOUR)

subject: JPN
title: (Alpha) Research Seminar in Japanese Linguistics (3)
desc: (C) Japanese/English contrastive analysis; (G) structure; (H) historical change; (K) history of Japanese language studies (Kokugo-gakushi); (M) morphophonemics; (P) pedagogy; (S) sociolinguistics. Pre: 451, or 601 and 602 for (C); 634 for (G); 631 for (H) and (K); 601 for (M); 632 for (P); and 633 for (S).
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: (Alpha) Research Seminar in Japanese Literature (3)
desc: (M) modern; Pre: 611 (P) pre-modern; Pre: 612, 613, or 614.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent of chair.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: (Alpha) Topics in Japanese Linguistics (3)
desc: (C) Japanese/English contrastive analysis; (G) structure; (H) historical change; (K) history of Japanese language studies (Kokugo-gaku-shi); (M) morphophonemics; (P) pedagogy; (S) sociolinguistics. Pre: 601 and 602 for (C); 634 for (G); 631 for (H) and (K); 601 for (M); 632 for (P); 633 for (S).
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Kambun (3)
desc: Introduction to kambun [the Japanese manner of reading and writing classical Chinese], with critical reading of kambun by Japanese authors. A-F only. Pre: 461 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Traditional Literary Theory (3)
desc: Reading and analysis of major works of literary theory and criticism from the classical, medieval, and Edo periods. A-F only. Pre: 466 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Topics in Japanese Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics in Japanese literature, primarily of the modern period. English translations of original texts will be provided whenever available. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 640)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Advanced Japanese Syntax and Semantics (3)
desc: Theoretical problems in description of Japanese; contributions of Japanese linguistic study to syntactic theory. Pre: 602 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Advanced Japanese Sociolinguistics (3)
desc: Variations in language form and use depending on social factors. Pre: 601 or 602 (or concurrent), and 606; or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Teaching Japanese as a Second Language (3)
desc: Practical overview of major problems; motivation; adult second language learning; communicative and linguistic competence; practical classroom techniques of teaching and testing. Pre: 604 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: History of the Japanese Language (3)
desc: Survey, theories of origin; related topics in linguistic methodology. Pre: 461 and 601, or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Introduction to Japanese Manuscripts and Xylographs (3)
desc: Introduction to Classical Japanese writing system as found in the xylographs and manuscripts of the Heian and Kamakura periods; reading and analysis of the texts in original script. Repeatable one time. Pre: 461 or 466, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Practicum: Teaching Japanese Language (Alpha) (3)
desc: For graduate students who are planning to teach Japanese as a foreign language. Through lectures and discussions on language learning and teaching, and through observation and teaching of a Japanese language class, students will learn to make informed decisions about curriculum and instruction, and will develop instructional skills and practices for analyzing their teaching experiences. (B) beginning level Japanese instruction; (C) advanced level Japanese instruction. Each alpha may be taken one time. Pre: 604 or EALL 601, or consent. (Once a year for (B) and (C)).
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Classical Japanese Literature (3)
desc: Critical reading and analysis of Heian literature; emphasis on prose. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: 466 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Medieval Japanese Literature (3)
desc: Critical reading and analysis of Kamakura and Muromachi literature, emphasis on prose. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: 466 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Edo Literature (3)
desc: Critical reading and analysis; emphasis on prose. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: 466 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: (Alpha) Modern Japanese Literature (3)
desc: Representative literary works, emphasis on fiction; (B) Meiji–Taisho (1868–1926); (C) Showa–Heisei (1926–present). Each alpha repeatable one time with consent. Pre: 485 or consent
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: (Alpha) Japanese Poetry (3)
desc: Historical survey of major poetic types. Repeatable one time with consent. (B) classical; (C) medieval and Edo; (D) modern. Pre: 466 or consent for (B) and (C); 485 or consent for (D).
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Japanese Sociolinguistics (3)
desc: Introduces theories of language use and provides training in the methodology and analysis of Japanese sociolinguistics. Pre: 407 and 475 or equivalent, or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Research Methodology in Japanese Linguistics and Language Teaching (3)
desc: Japanese-specific training in the formulation of testable hypotheses, in basic statistical and other evaluation techniques, and in the organization and presentation of ideas and data in paper, abstracts, etc. Pre: 407 or equivalent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Introduction to Japanese Language Pedagogy (3)
desc: Training in the identification and analysis of general problems in Japanese language learning, teaching, and testing by examining theoretical issues and conducting classroom research. Pre: 407 or equivalent, and 451; or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Japanese Syntax and Semantics (3)
desc: Introduction to theories of syntax, sentence structure, parts of speech, constituency, grammatical relations and case marking, word order, passives, causatives, tense, aspect, and embeddings. Pre: 451 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Japanese Phonology and Morphology (3)
desc: Introduction to the phonology and morphology of modern colloquial Japanese. Pre: 451 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Directed Fourth-Level Reading (V)
desc: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. Primarily for graduate students from other departments. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: (Alpha) Internship Program (3)
desc: Analysis of intercultural communication processes under faculty supervision through participation in an organization serving native speakers of Japanese. (B) business, repeatable one time; (C) travel industry internship. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 370 or consent for (C); 431 for (B).
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Project Work in Japanese (3)
desc: Enhances Japanese language skills through a field-based research project on a topic of the individual student’s choice. Interviews, surveys, observations, written materials and A/V-assisted oral presentations. Repeatable one time. Pre: 402 or 405 or equivalent, or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Advanced Japanese Language Study (3)
desc: Advanced course in spoken and written Japanese stressing intensive research using the Internet, electronic mail in Japanese and conventional media. Oral presentations, written reports and journal writing. Repeatable one time. Pre: 485 or equivalent and consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Advanced Readings in Modern Japanese Contemporary Topics (3)
desc: Advanced course to foster speed, accuracy, and attention to content in reading modern discursive texts. Pre: 407D and 407E, or consent.
metadata: DH East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Advanced Readings in Modern Japanese Literature (3)
desc: Advanced course to foster speed, accuracy and attention to stylistic issues in modern Japanese literature. Pre: 407D and 407E, or consent.
metadata: DL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Introduction to Japanese Sociolinguistics (3)
desc: Application of general linguistics to social phenomena such as group identity, language and gender, dialects and intercultural communication. Pre: 350 and 370, or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Okinawan Language and Literature (3)
desc: Focuses on Okinawan literature across various genres and periods. Will require weekly reaction papers, the midterm reading/writing project, and a final research project report. Pre: 202, 205, or consent.
metadata: DL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Okinawan Language and Culture (3)
desc: Focuses on the language, heritage, and folk culture of Okinawa. Pre: 202, 205, or consent.
metadata: DH East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Readings in Classical Japanese (3)
desc: Introduction to major genres of prose and poetry. Repeatable one time with permission. Pre: 461 or consent.
metadata: DL East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Introduction to Classical Japanese (3)
desc: Basic classical Japanese grammar to develop reading skills. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Fourth-Level Japanese Abroad (4)
desc: Continuation of 458. Pre: 401 or 458.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Fourth-Level Japanese Abroad (4)
desc: Intensive course of full time instruction on the fourth-year level in Japanese language and culture in Japan. Pre: 302, 305, 359, or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Introduction to Japanese Pedagogical Grammar (3)
desc: Introduction to teaching of basic Japanese grammatical patterns. Pre: 350 or LING 320, and 401, 403, 404 or 405; or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Structure of Japanese (3)
desc: Introduction to phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics of modern colloquial Japanese. Pre: 302 or 305; and 350 or LING 320; or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Advanced Business Writing (3)
desc: Training in advanced business writing for bilingual and other advanced learners. Japanese writing intensive. Pre: 421 or consent.

subject: JPN
title: Japanese to English Translation (3)
desc: Training in techniques of translating Japanese into English. Pre: 407D or 407E, or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: English to Japanese Translation (3)
desc: Training in techniques of translating English in Japanese. Pre: 407D or 407E, or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN

desc: Training in listening and speaking for bilingual and other advanced learners. Emphasis on formal Japanese such as academic lectures, news, exchanges in business settings, public speaking, etc. Pre: 421 or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Japanese Composition (3)
desc: Writing skills refined through practice in various styles (essays, letters, etc.). Pre: 401, 404, or 405; or consent.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Fourth-Level Spoken Japanese (3)
desc: Training in oral communication skills in varied social contexts. Pre: 402 or 405.
metadata: East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL) Japanese (JPN)

subject: JPN
title: Japanese Aural Comprehension (3)
desc: Training in comprehension of spoken material presented in news broadcasts, documentary narration, formal lectures, etc. Pre: 402, 405; or consent. May be concurrent with 407.

subject: JPN

subject: JPN
title: Directed Third-Level Reading (V)
desc: For those who need special assistance, e.g., reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.

subject: JPN
title: Language in Japanese Society (3)
desc: Introduction to basic concepts and issues surrounding language in Japanese society. Covers historical, cultural, and sociolinguistic dimensions of the Japanese language. Topics are closely linked with contemporary ethical issues. Pre: 301 or consent.

Pre: 202, 205, 212, or placement test; or consent. (Fall only)

title: Intermediate Japanese Abroad (4)

title: Intermediate Japanese II (4)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201 or placement test; or consent.

subject: CUL
title: International Cultural Studies: Research Project (3)
desc: Directed reading and research culminating in a project that engages issues in international cultural studies. Types of projects include scholarly essays, community-based projects, performances or exhibitions. Written statement of purpose and selfevaluation required. A-F only. Pre: 609 and 610.
metadata: College of Social Sciences International Cultural Studies (CUL)

subject: CUL
title: International Cultural Studies: History and Theory (3)
desc: Seminar on the history and theory of interdisciplinary cultural studies. The politics of culture are examined in comparative perspective, focusing on their significance for identity formation, intercultural relations, and global flows of images, people and capital. Approaches to the study of media and popular culture are taken up in terms of their relevance for contemporary issues, especially in Hawai‘i and the Asia/Pacific/U.S. region. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences International Cultural Studies (CUL)

subject: CUL
title: Faculty Seminar Series (1)
desc: Seminar consists of a series of presentations by certificate faculty on topics of ongoing research. Presentations will open current debates about theory and method in cultural studies. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences International Cultural Studies (CUL)

subject: IS
title: Topics in Biocultural Diversity and Conservation (3)
desc: Biological, cultural, and linguistic conservation are intimately linked, but rarely studied simultaneously. Adopts a trans-disciplinary view of diversity and conservation of nature, cultures, and languages, along with issues in anthropology, law, and ethics. (Fall only)
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Laboratory B in Applied Evolutionary Ecology: Biodiversity Loss, Biological Invasions and Emerging Disease (3)
desc: Practical laboratory/ field rotation on the ecological and evolutionary underpinnings of the coupled process of biological invasion, disease emergence and biodiversity loss. Continuation of 650 and 651L. A-F only. Pre: 650 and 651L, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Laboratory A in Applied Evolutionary Ecology: Biodiversity Loss, Biological Invasions and Emerging Disease (2)
desc: Combined lecture-laboratory on the ecological and evolutionary underpinnings of the coupled process of biological invasion, disease emergence and biodiversity loss. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Principles of Applied Evolutionary Ecology: Biodiversity Loss, Biological Invasions and Emerging Disease (3)
desc: Combined lecture-discussion on the ecological and evolutionary underpinnings of the coupled process of biological invasion, disease emergence and biodiversity loss. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Integrative Seminar in Gerontology (V)
desc: Integrative seminar. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Student Success

subject: IS
title: Field Study in Gerontology (V)
desc: Individually designed field experience for advanced certificate in gerontology students. Placements arranged at community programs, research sites, and special projects at the Center on Aging. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Directed reading and research. Repeatable one time.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Environmental Practicum (3)
desc: Field experience in study and abatement of environmental problems under faculty direction. Project proposal, narrative activity log, and documentary report are required. Pre: upper division standing, courses in appropriate discipline, and consent.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Introduction to Linguistic Anthropology (3)
desc: Introduction to the ethnographic study of speech and language. Pre: ANTH 152. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ANTH 414 and LING 414)
metadata: DS Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: The Humboldt Brothers’ Legacy (3)
desc: Life and thought of the two Humboldt brothers. Alexander (1769-1859) helped to lay the foundations of modern science, including geology, geography, botany, zoology, physiology and anthropology. Older, less well-known Wilhelm (1767–1835) was an influential statesman, classical scholar, man of letters, humanist, political philosopher, anthropologist and linguist, and founded the University of Berlin. Review of the two polymaths’ impact on modern science in the Americas, the Pacific and Asia. A-F only. Pre: upper-division or consent.
metadata: DH Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Ocean Internships and Research (V)
desc: Students carry out marine-related internships, practica, research projects or field experience on-or off-campus with faculty guidance. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: minimum cum GPA of 2.5, junior or senior standing in any field of study and IS 100/BIOL 104 or consent, project proposal. (Cross-listed as BIOL 400)
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Directed reading and research. Repeatable two times.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: British Life and Culture (3)
desc: For Study Abroad Program students participating in the UH Mānoa Semester in London. Emphasis is placed on understanding within historical contexts important issues for contemporary British society—particularly those of class, power, gender, and race. A-F only. Pre: participation in London Semester Program.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: People, the Ocean and the Environment (3)
desc: People’s impact on quality of coastal and ocean environments, especially Hawaiian; scientific, legal, socioeconomic aspects. Ocean pollution, ocean technology. Pre: OCN 201, ORE 202, or ZOOL 200; or consent.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Pidgin and Creole Languages (3)
desc: Nature, history, structure, and geographic distribution of pidgins and creoles. Pre: LING 102 or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as LING 347)
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Human Values and the Environment (3)
desc: Examination of nature-culture dynamic over a range of contexts–literary ecology, systems ecology, political ecology, eco-feminism, environmental ethics–in order to articulate new possibilities for interdisciplinary understanding of the human place in nature. A-F only. Pre: any ENG DL or PHIL or GEO course, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as SUST 340)
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Science and Culture (3)
desc: Cultural studies of science from historical, philosophical, sociological and literary perspectives. Examination of intersections of science, race, gender and environment. A-F only. Pre: upper division or consent.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Information Technology and Culture (3)
desc: Investigation of the impact of information technologies on contemporary culture from a variety of perspectives. A-F only. Pre: upper division or consent.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Student Success

subject: IS
title: Ethnohistory (3)
desc: Review of ethnohistory, i.e. the interdisciplinary, holistic and inclusive investigation of the histories of native peoples drawing not only on documented sources, but also on ethnography, linguistics, archaeology, ecology and other disciplines as an alternative to conventional Eurocolonial history. A-F only. Pre: HIST 152, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as ANTH 327)
metadata: DS Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Native Americans and Native Hawaiians (3)
desc: Comparative-contrastive examination of similarities and differences between Native Americans and Native Hawaiians as the only indigenous peoples of the U.S. with special attention to sociohistorical parallels and mutual contacts since contact with Europeans. Perspective is explicitly interdisciplinary by drawing not only on sociology and history, but also on archaeology, ethnology, linguistics and still other disciplines. A-F only. Pre: HIST 152 and an introductory course in cultural anthropology, political science or sociology; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: DS Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Independent Study Tutorial (V)
desc: Independent study tutorial. A-F only.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Ethics, Aging & Society (3)
desc: Addresses ethical issues in gerontology and long-term care for older adults as raised by public policy, health care problems, and social attitudes toward elders. Explores established practices and new directions for ethics in aging. A-F only. (Cross-listed as COA 305)
metadata: DH Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Field Study (V)
desc: Pre-arranged systematic field investigation of selected topics. Pre: written proposal approved by Honors director and appropriate faculty member. Repeatable up to 16 credits.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Personal Development for Effective Teams (3)
desc: Exploration and application of basic leadership theories and processes which foster personal and interpersonal development via cognitive experiential classroom methods and mentoring relationships with experienced peer leaders. (Cross-listed as ENGR 250)
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Introduction to Applied Gerontology: Helping Yourself and Others to Thrive in Later Life (3)
desc: Introduction to essential information on aging and the field of gerontology. Counters ageist stereotypes, develops skills for translating research into practice, and provides an introductory survey course for the undergraduate certificate in aging. A-F only. (Crosslisted as COA 206)
metadata: DS Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Marine Option Program Seminar (1)
desc: Overview of ocean issues and organizations involved with marine activities, management, education, research, and business. Exploration of internships, research, and career opportunities. Preparation of resumes, proposals, and professional presentations. Not a BIOL major elective. (Cross-listed as BIOL 104)
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: IS
title: Mānoa International Exchange (V)
desc: Designed for students accepted for participation in an international exchange program while enrolled at UH Mānoa. Repeatable unlimited times, credit for 12 credits only. CR/NC only. Pre: admittance to an international exchange program.
metadata: Interdisciplinary Studies (IS) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: INS
title: Life Insurance (3)
desc: Treatment of the risk of premature death through use of various life insurance policies. Policy forms, calculation of premiums, reserves, non-forfeiture values, underwriting, regulation of policy provisions, related coverage. Pre: 300.
metadata: Insurance (INS) Shidler College of Business

subject: INS
title: Property and Casualty Insurance (3)
desc: Treatment of risk of financial loss of personal and business property and resulting loss of income occasioned by fire and allied perils. Forms of insurance used by individual business executives and firms including crime, transportation, liability, and worker compensation. Pre: 300.
metadata: Insurance (INS) Shidler College of Business

subject: INS
title: Principles of Insurance (3)
desc: Risk management and insurance application to business and personal financial decision-making. Introduction to basic risk management concepts and techniques. Analyze various types of insurance: including life, property, casualty, liability, health, disability, and long-term care.
metadata: Insurance (INS) Shidler College of Business

subject: STE
title: Directed Reading and/or Research (V)
desc: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. Pre: written consent.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Professional Studies IV (3)
desc: Collaborative problem solving of issues and concerns encountered in current teaching experiences. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Clinical Partnership and Practice IV (V)
desc: Full-time supervised teaching experience. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Clinical Partnership and Practice III (V)
desc: Supervised experience in instructional planning and practice teaching. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Clinical Partnership and Practice II (V)
desc: Team collaboration on responding to identified school need; supervised experience in mini-teaching. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to 12 credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Professional Studies II (V)
desc: Development of pedagogical skills in planning and implementing instruction for target subject area/grade level. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Clinical Partnership and Practice I (V)
desc: Supervised field study of a school. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to 12 credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Professional Studies I (V)
desc: Development of theoretical and practical knowledge base and skills for understanding, analyzing, and responding to teaching issues and problems. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Master of Education in Teaching Program Seminar (1)
desc: Mandatory program seminar for Master of Education in Teaching (MEdT) teacher candidates; access to tools and skills necessary for distance education program success, introduction to the teaching profession. CR/NC only. Pre: admission into the MEdT program, or consent.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Practicum in Curriculum Development: Natural Science (3)
desc: For in-service teachers to upgrade subject matter and develop teaching methods and materials for instruction. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: teaching experience.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Practicum in Curriculum Development: Natural Science (2)
desc: For in-service teachers to upgrade subject matter and develop teaching methods and materials for instruction. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: teaching experience.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Common Core State Standards in Mathematics: Content and Curriculum for Teachers (V)
desc: Professional development for K-12 teachers to upgrade their knowledge of mathematics content and develop their instructional strategies to be consistent with the mathematical practices of the Common Core State Standards. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Common Core State Standards in ELA: Content and Curriculum for Teachers (V)
desc: Professional development for K-12 teachers to upgrade their knowledge of ELA content and develop their instructional strategies to be consistent with the ELA practices of the Common Core State Standards. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Newspaper in the Classroom (2)
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Directed Activity (V)
desc: Individual work supervised by instructor. May consist of reading, research, teaching, and/or projects. Pre: consent of division director.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Issues in Computer Education (3)
desc: Integration of microcomputers into school curriculum and key issues related to microcomputer use in education. Pre: LTEC 442 or consent. (Cross-listed as EDCS 480)
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Educating Exceptional Students in Regular Classrooms, Secondary (3)
desc: Teaching secondary students with disabilities and those who are gifted/talented. Meeting academic/social needs, classroom management, motivation, peer interaction, collaboration between special and regular educators. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Education of Exceptional Children in Regular Classroom (3)
desc: Practices that facilitate teaching special needs students in regular classrooms. Techniques for meeting academic needs, managing behavior, motivating students, increasing peer interactions, communication between special and regular educators. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Hawaiian Studies, Methods (3)
desc: Examination of issues in Hawaiian and U.S. views of education and their application to the teaching of Hawaiian studies. Field experience required. A-F only. Pre: 312C, 312D; or consent. Co-requisite for BEd students: 317.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Multicultural and Social Justice Education (3)
desc: Exploring social justice and multilingual, multicultural education with attention to Hawai‘i as our place of learning and teaching. (Cross-listed as EDCS 440)
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Office and Marketing Technology (3)
desc: Understanding and use of word processing, spreadsheet, and database software for business applications. Explore software across the office and marketing content areas.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Foundations of Vocational Education (3)
desc: Historical and philosophical foundations of vocational technical education, overview of federal and state legislation and contemporary practices. Special emphasis on vocational education program in Hawai‘i.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Cooperative Vocational Education (3)
desc: Planned work-experience program for special areas of vocational technical education. Acceptable type of wage-earning employment. Minimum of six 40- hour weeks or 240 work hours required. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Advanced Supervision of Student Teaching (3)
desc: Advanced principles and methods: clinical supervision, observation recording, analysis, interpretation of classroom teaching; human resources supervision in student teaching. Pre: 420, successful supervision of two or more student teachers, and consent.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Family and Community Centered Programs (3)
desc: Knowledge and appreciation for the complex characteristics of children, families, and communities. Analysis and development of skills for creating respectful, reciprocal relationships with diverse children and families from diverse backgrounds. Lecture/lab. Pre: 318 (or concurrent), or HDFS 331 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Supervision of Student Teaching (3)
desc: Principles and methods; role of supervisor; human resources supervision in student teaching. Open to teachers interested in pre-service teacher education. Pre: three years teaching experience and consent.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Foundations of Early Childhood Education, Ages 3–8 (3)
desc: Planning child-centered, responsive programs for children. Focuses on play, learning environments, integrated thematic instructional design, guidance, assessment, and family engagement in early childhood and early elementary to promote enjoyment, growth, and development. A-F only. Pre: 318.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Teaching and Learning for Diverse Young Children Lab (3)
desc: Continuation of 415L. CR/ NC only. Co-requisite: 416. (Cross-listed as EDCS 416L)
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Teaching and Learning for Diverse Young Children (3)
desc: Continuation of 415: focuses on the design, implementation, evaluation of meaningful, challenging integrated curriculum that promotes comprehensive developmental and learning outcomes for diverse young children (pK-3). Pre: 415 or consent. (Cross-listed as EDCS 416)
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Observation and Assessment in Early Childhood Education Lab (3)
desc: Field experience in early childhood settings to facilitate young children’s growth and learning. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Observation and Assessment in Early Childhood Education (3)
desc: Introduction to the purposes, theories, and methods of early childhood assessment. Emphasizes observation, documentation, and assessment to provide evidence of children’s development and learning and how to use assessment to guide teaching and learning. Pre: 318 or consent. Corequisite: 415L.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Supervision of the Observation-Participation Student (2)
desc: Basic guidelines for developing effective team relationships between the professional teacher and the observation-participation student. Pre: two years’ teaching experience and consent.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Seminar in Teaching Residency (3)
desc: Analysis and resolution of current ethical issues and practices in classrooms; teaching skills and strategies; curriculum planning, professional growth and development; and integration of teaching experiences with professional standards. Instruction in preparing an extensive written portfolio. A-F only. Pre: successful completion of all required courses or consent. Co-requisite: 405(B, C, D, F, G, H, I, J, K, M, O, or P)
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Teaching Residency (V)
desc: Full-time student teaching experience in school. Student teachers will receive training and evaluation for oral communication, organization, and planning skills. Subject field: (B) visual and performing arts; (C) business and marketing; (D) language arts; (F) industrial arts; (G) mathematics; (H) science; (l) social studies; (J) foreign languages; (K) music; (M) home economics; (O) elementary education; (P) English as a second language. CR/NC only. Pre: successful completion of all required courses; departmental consent.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Teaching in the Subject Field (3)
desc: Purposes, procedures, curricula, evaluation in elementary or secondary school subject field. Develops written communication skills: (B) visual and performing art; (C) business and marketing; (D) language arts; (E) physical education; (F) industrial arts/agriculture; (G) mathematics; (H) science; (I) social studies; (J) foreign languages; (K) music; (M) home economics; (N) interdisciplinary; (P) English as a Second Language. Repeatable five times for different alphas. A-F only. Pre: 401 or consent. Co-requisite: 402.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Educational Inquiry (V)
desc: Study and discussion of general school-related topics and issues, e.g., dimensions of elementary and/ or secondary schooling, school governance, curriculum design and development, the student learner, classroom management; (B) service learning; (C) exploratory education; (D) international field study; (E) minor in education. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Teaching Practicum (V)
desc: Observation, analysis, participation and teaching in middle or high school. A seminar accompanies the field experience. Subject field: (B) visual and performing arts; (C) business and marketing; (D) language arts; (E) physical education; (F) industrial arts/agriculture; (G) mathematics; (H) science; (I) social studies; (J) foreign language; (K) music; (M) home economics; (N) interdisciplinary; (O) elementary; (P) English as a Second Language. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only. Pre: admission to COE Teacher Education Program and departmental consent.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Principles & Methods of Literacies Within and Across the Disciplines (6-12) (3)
desc: Examines different literacy strategies for learning content that will engage diverse adolescents across and within all disciplines. Includes a disciplinary literacies framework that influences lesson planning, classroom culture, and assessment practices. Emphasis on teaching writing. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: WGSS
title: Marriage and Family: Feminist Perspective (3)
desc: Sex-role socialization, motherhood, work-family conflicts. Alternative family structures in U.S. and other countries. Recommended: at least one WS course. Pre: 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 300; or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 452)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender Violence Over the Lifecycle (3)
desc: Examines the problem of violence, particularly sexual violence, over the life cycle. Offers gendered perspective in activities aimed at prevention and treatment of violence, and cross cultural perspectives. Pre: 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, SOC 300; or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 446)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: U.S. Women’s Literature and Culture (3)
desc: Reading of selected works of U.S. women’s literature and cultural texts (such as art and film). Emphasis on historical and cultural context and diverse expressions of women’s gendered identities. (Cross-listed as AMST 455 and ENG 455)
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender and Consumption in a Global World (3)
desc:
Students learn theories of the global economy, histories of consumerism, constructions
