of gendered public spaces, and how the cultural production of consumers and consumer culture functions in the process of globalization. A-F only.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Feminist Methods and Research (3)
desc: Overview of feminist issues with dominant theories of knowledge and major methodologies employed in the social sciences; and exploration of role of gender theory and feminist politics in feminist research. Pre: 151 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Feminist Theory (3)
desc: Contemporary debates in feminist theory concerning gender, race, and class; subjectivity and representation; gender and colonialism; bodies, sexualities and “nature.” Pre: any 300 level WS or POLS course, or consent. (Crosslisted as POLS 339)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender and Environmental Philosophy (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary approach to feminist perspectives on environmental issues; critical analysis of eco-feminism as political movement with reference to race and coloniality; cross-cultural comparison of differently-imagined relationships to non-human others, with emphasis on ethics and writing. Pre: any course 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS or any course 200 or above with a DB or DP designation, or consent. (Cross-listed as PHIL 438)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender and Violence (3)
desc:
Interdisciplinary course will examine western constructs of gender 
violence on its correlates with ethnicity, class, sexuality, nation, and empire. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: one of 151, 202, 360, 361, 439, 460, 462, or consent
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender, Justice and Law (3)
desc: Exploration of landmark U.S. Supreme Court cases related to sex and gender. Topics may include sex discrimination, sexual orientation discrimination, privacy, and reproductive freedom. A-F only. Pre: one of 151, 175, 176, 202, 360, 381, or consent. (Cross-listed as AMST 436 and POLS 368)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Crime (3)
desc: Women’s relations with the criminal justice system; types of women’s offenses; responses to women’s crime; women as victims; women as workers in the criminal justice system. Recommended: at least one WS course. Pre: 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 300; or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 435)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Madness (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary critical examination of the relationship between gender and mental health. Psychological research, feminist theory, autobiography, literature, and cinema. Pre: one of 202, 245, PSY 202; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: STE
title: Directed Study (V)
desc: Individual work supervised by instructor. May consist of reading, research, observation/participation, teaching, and/or projects. Repeatable up to 12 credits. Pre: consent of instructor.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Student Teaching Modified (6)
desc: Modified student teaching for individuals who have had prior extensive teaching experience or wish to repeat student teaching. CR/NC only. (C) elementary; (D) secondary. Pre: extensive teaching experience; requirements listed under “student teaching”; approval of review committee; consent. Co-requisite: 391.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Seminar for Student Teaching (V)
desc:
With student teaching as context, examination of knowledge, skills, and dispositions for teaching; standards-based planning, teaching, assessment, and reflection; inclusive classroom management; professional growth and development; integration of research, 
theory, and practice. Emphasis on writing instruction and ethical issues in teaching. (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary (2); (D) secondary; (M) dual preparation in elementary education and multilingual learning (2); (S) dual preparation in elementary and special education (1). Repeatable nine times for (D). CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Student Teaching (V)
desc: Full-time supervised experience in school. (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary; (D) secondary; (M) dual preparation in elementary education and multilingual learning; (S) dual preparation in elementary and special education. CR/NC only. Pre: completion of all other program requirements, passing Praxis II exam(s). Co-requisite for D: 391D.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Managing Classrooms (3)
desc: Analysis of the factors that contribute to learning in the classroom and the development of teacher behaviors that promote such learning. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Home Economics Education (3)
desc: Curriculum design. Current educational philosophies and practices in home economics education. Teaching materials and techniques.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Multicultural Perspectives in Education (3)
desc: Concepts and methods to develop sensitivity and awareness of cultural influences on behaviors related to schooling. Examines intersections of Native Hawaiian culture with Asian and/or Pacific Islanders fostering multicultural respect and understanding through cross-cultural analysis. A-F only. DS
metadata: DS College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Music in the Elementary School (2)
desc: Goals, concepts, literature, materials, procedures, and evaluation for teaching music in grades K–6. For students in elementary education. Not intended for elementary music majors.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Teaching Marketing and Distribution (3)
desc: Theory and methods of teaching marketing and distribution courses. Pre: MKT 341 or MKT 351.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Teaching Business and Office Education (3)
desc: Theory and methods of teaching business and office education courses. Pre: ACC 201 and either ACC 200 or ACC 202.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Management of Industrial/Agricultural Facilities (3)
desc: Organization of instruction; handling supplies; maintaining equipment and tools; purchasing materials; keeping records; making inventories.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Methods of Instruction, Industrial/ Agricultural Education (3)
desc: Techniques of individual and group instruction in laboratory and related classes, evaluation of various methods.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Personal and Social K-6 Health Skills (V)
desc: Standards-based planning, teaching, assessment in health education. Developing interactive learning opportunities to teach personal and social responsibility for health through curriculum integration. Training, practice and evaluation of oral communication skills; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Performing Arts Expression, K-6 (V)
desc: Standards-based teaching, with, in, through, and about music, dance, and drama. Developing verbal and non-verbal communication skills through creative expression with an emphasis on planning, teaching, and assessing preK-6 lessons that integrate the performing arts; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Responsive Pedagogy for Multilingual Learners (3)
desc: Introduction to the teaching of multilingual learners (MLL) in an elementary school context. Teacher candidates will learn specific strategies and methods for teaching non-native speakers of English. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Curriculum, Materials, and Assessment Development for Multilingual Learners (3)
desc: Introduction to the development of curriculum materials, and assessments for diverse and multilingual learners. Teacher candidates will develop their ability to organize, develop, and assess learning around standards-based subject matter and language learning objectives. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Visual Art, Elementary (V)
desc: Scope and organization of art in pK-6 school curriculum, creative use of art media through laboratory experience; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Mathematics, Elementary II (V)
desc: Inquiry-based approach to concepts and algorithms of fractions, decimals, graphing, and probability and statistics. Laboratory experiences with appropriate manipulatives; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only. Pre: 324B or consent for (B); 324C or consent for (C).
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Mathematics, Elementary (V)
desc: Inquiry-based approach to concepts and algorithms of whole numbers and introduction to geometry/ measurement. Laboratory experiences with appropriate manipulatives; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only. Pre: MATH 111 and MATH 112.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Science, Elementary (V)
desc: Science education in elementary school; methods and materials; laboratory activities selected from new science curricula; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. Each alpha repeatable one time, up to 3 credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Social Studies, Elementary (V)
desc: Purposes, methods, curriculum, and assessment in teaching social studies. Focus: enriching children’s understanding of the communities of which they are a part through inquiry, investigation, collaboration, and expository skills. Emphasis on writing instruction; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Social Studies and Science in Early Childhood Education (3)
desc: Assessment, instructional methods, and materials for teaching social studies and science to children in preschool through grade 3. Emphasis on developmentally appropriate practices and lesson planning for teaching social studies and science. A-F only. Pre: 417, and 315 (or concurrent) or SPED 315 (or concurrent). (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Instructional and Assessment Methods for Multilingual Learners (3)
desc: Introduction to language use and development as it relates to multilingual learners (MLL). Candidates analyze and apply strategies to create inclusive and collaborative classrooms for learners at various levels of English language development. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Children’s Literature (2)
desc: Acquaintance with wide range of children’s books; criteria for evaluation of literature; using literature in the classroom.
metadata: DL College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Child Development from Prenatal Through Age Eight (3)
desc: Growth and development of children from prenatal through age eight. Historical and current issues through a research-based ecological, cross-cultural perspective. Focus on children’s optimal development and how this informs teaching practices in early education. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Field Experience (V)
desc: Supervised field experience in schools. Minimum of 2 full days per week in classrooms, plus mandatory seminar scheduled by UH Mānoa field supervisor. Taken in conjunction with professional education courses; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. Repeatable two times or up to 9 credits per alpha. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Field Experience (V)
desc: Supervised field experience in schools. Minimum of 8 hours per week in conjunction with professional education courses. Repeatable two times, up to three credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: Field Training – Blended ECE (4)
desc: Students spend 15 hours per week in settings appropriate to concurrently enrolled classes; supervision provided by participating teacher and college supervisor. Repeatable two times. A-F only. (Cross-listed as SPED 315)
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Principles and Methods of Writing Instruction (V)
desc: Second of two methods courses focusing on theories and research-based practices related to writing instruction in elementary classrooms. Emphasis on writing instruction; lecture/lab; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Principles and Methods of Reading Instruction (V)
desc: First of two methods courses focusing on theories and research-based practices related to reading instruction in elementary classrooms. Emphasis on writing instruction; lecture/lab; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: STE
title: (Alpha) Introduction to Teaching, Elementary (V)
desc: Standards-based planning, assessment, instruction, reflection; inclusive classroom management; unique multicultural environment; issues in education and curriculum. Developing knowledgeable, effective, caring professionals to support student’s academic, social, emotional, physical needs. Emphasis on writing instruction; lecture/lab; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education School of Teacher Education (STE)

subject: ITM
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in an area of information technology management under the direction of faculty member(s). A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in international management or consent.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: International IT Organizational Research Methods (3)
desc: Overview of current survey methodology and analysis in global information systems research. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in international management or consent.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Research Seminar in E-Business in the Asia Pacific Region (3)
desc: Overview of the current research issues in e-business with focus on the Asia Pacific region. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in international management or consent.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Doctoral Seminar in Information Systems (3)
desc: Extensive and critical review of the IS research literature. Can be retaken for credit. Repeatable three times. A-F only. Pre: CIS 703 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in ITM under the direction of a faculty member. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Capstone Course (V)
desc: Individual- or team-based project with a client organization, conducted under faculty supervision, as capstone project to complete masters level work in the Masters of Science in Information Systems. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: students must complete 15 semester hours and core masters courses before capstone.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Management of Health Information Technology and Population Health (3)
desc: Covers latest trends/innovations in HIT designed to reduce costs, improve quality/access, and reduce outcome disparity through population health management. Includes management of financial, organizational, and professional barriers to effective HIT. A-F only. Graduate students only. (Alt. years)
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Digitally-Enabled Business Processes (3)
desc: Business process analysis, design, and implementation of new business processes enabled by digital platforms. Concepts, methods, and techniques to support prototyping and user interface design are considered. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Enterprise System Architecture and Management (3)
desc: Foundations of enterprise information systems design and architecture to support business strategy, processes, data, and IT/IS services; integrating cloud-based and loT infrastructure; management and maintenance of organizational IS/IT infrastructure and operations. MIS, ICS, MIS-BBA majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Business Intelligence and Data Analytics (3)
desc: Addresses business intelligence and data analytics at operational, tactical, and strategic levels using basic data science techniques, including visual, descriptive, diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive analytics methods and hands-on learning using current software tools. A-F only. Pre: 619 or consent.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Enterprise Data and Information Management (3)
desc: Framework of policies, people, processes, and technologies to control, protect, deliver, and enhance the organizational data assets; best practices and technologies for database management, data warehousing, and data curation; support of enterprise data governance. MIS, ICS, MIS-BBA majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Project Management, Information Technology and Change (3)
desc: Lectures and discussions to contextualize knowledge and techniques of project management in organizational change, globalization and outsourcing, global teamwork, intercultural awareness, negotiation and leadership. Semester long group project. Open to all graduate students. (Once a year)
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Current Topics in Information Systems (3)
desc: Selected current practices and trends in decision sciences and MIS. Repeatable three times. ACC, CIS, and BUS majors only.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Advanced Security (3)
desc: Designed around the plan-protect-respond cycle. Security threats, cryptographic security, access control, identity management, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, host hardening, and application security. Repeatable one time. Pre: 431 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Networking and Security (3)
desc: Basic concepts in networking and security. Network standards and technologies. Network planning and design. LANs and WANS, wireless networking. Security threats and countermeasures. Security planning and policies. A-F only.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in special area of major under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and the faculty advisor.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: (Alpha) Advanced Topics in Information Systems (3)
desc: Computerized management information systems, operations research or business statistics: (B) software systems economics; (C) advanced topics in programming; (D) web-based application development; (E) advanced technology in MIS; (F) systems development; (G) database systems; (H) advanced business applications; (J) ethics of technology; (K) business intelligence. Repeatable with permission of department chair. Pre: varies with topic.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Electronic Commerce (3)
desc: Survey of electronic commerce technologies and business strategies, with an emphasis on technology and application development. The development of web-based and multimedia applications; the impacts of EC on business strategy; legal and ethical issues. A-F only. Pre: BUS 311 or consent.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Information Systems in Organizations (3)
desc: Practice of information systems in organizations. Capstone course for MIS majors. A-F only. Pre: 353 and 354 (or concurrent), and BUS 311.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Current Topics in ITM (3)
desc: Repeatable three times with permission of department chair. Pre: varies with topic.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Database Systems (3)
desc: Introduction to database management and data structures, including database planning and design, normalization, relational and network data models, and physical organization and implementation. A-F only. Pre: 353.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Information Systems Analysis and Design (3)
desc: Analysis and design of systems in organizations. Includes role of general systems concepts, systems development life cycle, identifying systems requirements, logical and physical design. A-F only. Pre: 352 and BUS 311.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Programming Application Systems (3)
desc: Introduction to applications programming. Fundamentals, essential logic, file handling, report writing. Emphasis on systems development and disciplined programming. A-F only. Pre: ICS 101, or LTEC 112 and 113, (or equivalent), or consent.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Supply Chain Processes (3)
desc: Improving organization productivity with an emphasis on analyzing supply chain processes and principles in terms of scheduling, inventory, quality control techniques, through most current practices. Pre: BUS 310 and 311.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Project Management (3)
desc: Project management application and techniques such as planning methods; PERT/CPM forecasting; risk analysis; application in information technology projects and other areas. Pre: BUS 310 and 311.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ITM
title: Using Computers and Applications (3)
desc: Using Windows computers browsers, Microsoft Office (or equivalent) and other applications. A-F only.
metadata: Information Technology Management (ITM) Shidler College of Business

subject: ICS
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable eight times. Pre: candidacy for PhD in computer science.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: graduate standing and consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Advanced Special Topics in Security (3)
desc: Current topics and upcoming issues relevant to the field of information assurance and cyber security. Repeatable unlimited times. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: (Alpha) Topics in Computer Science (3)
desc: Reflects special interests of faculty in various areas of computer science. (B) area 1; (C) area 2; (D) area 3; (E) area 4; (G) general. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics and different areas. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Seminar in ICS (1)
desc: Series of talks on advanced research topics. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Digital Video Information (3)
desc: Principles and techniques of technical and context analysis of digital video information. Video capture and editing tools, compression and analysis algorithms, visual culture, narrative structure, juxtaposition of multimedia elements and their effects on information transmission. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Virtual and Augmented Reality (3)
desc: Students will learn the science, engineering, art, and applications of virtual reality and augmented reality, with an emphasis on the construction of working virtual environments. Graduate students only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Advanced Computer Vision (3)
desc: Fundamental problems and core concepts and techniques in computer vision, covering both theoretical and practical issues in the field. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Numerical Computation (3)
desc: Selected topics in numerical analysis, mathematical software, and scientific computation; examples include sparse matrix methods, finite element methods, mathematical programming. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computer Graphics (3)
desc: Selected advanced topics in computer graphics. Substantial project required. Pre: 481 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Bioinformatics: Microarrays (3)
desc: Introduction to the basic principles of biology relevant for microarray gene expression data and to Bio-conductor. Collaborative open-source project to develop a modular general framework for the analysis of cDNA arrays and gene chips. A-F only. Pre: 311 or background in biology, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Bioinformatics: Sequences Analysis (3)
desc: To expose students to bioinformatics at the biological sequences analysis level (DNA, RNA, proteins). Several bioinformatics methods and algorithms are introduced. Students are required to present one paper and to participate in a small group project. A-F only. . Pre: graduate standing, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Evolutionary Computation I: Survey of Methods (3)
desc: Evolutionary computation surveys in the field to prepare students for research. Topics include diverse engineering applications, theory, and concepts including search spaces, representation, objective functions, variation operators, selection, and population based search. Pre: 211 (B or better) and 241 (C or better) and admitted to a graduate program or capable of graduate-level work in computer sciences, or consent. (Once a year: fall)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Social Computing (3)
desc: Participative analysis of online communities and user-generated content collections. Theoretical and practical aspects of online interaction, identity, trust, and virtual social capital. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Social Informatics (3)
desc: An advanced introduction to the design of human-computer systems and other technological artifacts for supporting human collaboration in learning, work and social contexts, and to theoretical perspectives and empirical studies of collaboration that inform such design. A-F only. Pre: 464 or 465 or 664 or 665 or 667 or LIS 677; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: HCI Design Methods (3)
desc: Advanced analytical and empirical methods for the design and evaluation of usable, useful, and robust human computer interfaces. Students will apply selected methodologies to a major system design project. Pre: 464 or 465, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: User Interfaces and Hypermedia (3)
desc: Advanced concepts in construction of interfaces between computers and their users. Hypermedia information structures, guidelines, problems, and tradeoffs. Discussion of selected readings, implementation of prototypes. Pre: 465 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Human-Computer Interaction II (3)
desc: Studies of human performance in designing and using information systems. Emphasizes concepts and methodologies from human factors, psychology, and software engineering relating to human performance. Pre: graduate standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Pattern Recognition (3)
desc: Nature of the problem in pattern recognition and clustering; explanation of various algorithms. Pre: graduate standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Advanced Artificial Intelligence (3)
desc: Current issues in artificial intelligence, including expert systems, knowledge representation, logic programming, learning, natural language processing. Pre: graduate standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computer Architecture I (3)
desc: Models of computation, high-performance processors, pipelined machines, RISC processors, VLIW, superscalar and fine-grain parallel machines. Data-flow architectures. Hardware/software tradeoffs. Pre: ECE 461. (Cross-listed as ECE 660)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Security and Trust III: Cyber Security and Commerce (3)
desc: Tools and methods for security managers. Tools and methods to secure and monetize services and applications. Network as a computer and as a market. Problems of cyber war, cyber crime, cyber bullying. Graduate students only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computer Networks (3)
desc: Elementary principles of modern computer networking. Detailed coverage of overall architecture and the physical, data link, and network layers, with emphasis on the network layer. ICS majos only. Pre: graduate standing in ICS, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Advanced Parallel Algorithms (3)
desc: Design and analysis of parallel algorithms, with emphasis on advanced techniques and latest advances in parallel algorithms. Pre: graduate standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Advanced Theory of Computation (3)
desc: Advanced topics in formal languages, automata, computability, computational complexity. Pre: 441 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Information Theory in Machine Learning (3)
desc: Basics of information processing and learning in the brain; neural networks; learning algorithms based on information maximization; applications in molecular biology and bioinformatics. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in computer science or mathematics background, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Machine Learning (3)
desc: Introduction to key theoretical concepts of machine learning. Practical experience with decision free methods, artificial neural networks. Bayesian belief networks and contemporary statistical methods including regression, clustering and classification. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Principles of High Performance Computing (3)
desc: Principles of high performance computing for single-processor and parallel architectures. Detailed coverage of parallel architectures and exposure to shared-memory, distributed-memory, and hybrid parallelism. Hands-on experience with message-passing and multithreaded programming. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in computer science or closely related field, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Advanced Data Management (3)
desc: Exploration of information retrieval and object-relational tools and methods for the management of distributed multimedia database systems. Pre: graduate standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Advanced Cryptography (3)
desc: Taxonomy of security properties: methods for defining and proving security. Randomness, pseudorandomness, and indistinguishability. Functional encryption and obfuscation. Zero knowledge. Pre: graduate standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Network Science (3)
desc: Modeling human-made and natural systems as networks to understand their structure and dynamics. Computational and statistical methods and research results they enabled. Use of network analysis software. Applications to topics of interest to students.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Analysis of Algorithms (3)
desc: Analysis and design of algorithms: modeling, comparison, measures, applications. Pre: graduate standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Information Architecture and Web Design (3)
desc: User-centered design of websites; survey Information Architecture (IA) systems (organization, navigation, labeling, searching); gain experience in methodologies for creating IA, tools for IA, web standards and usability tests. ICS and LIS majors only. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in ICS or LIS or related field or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Medical Informatics I (3)
desc: Introduction to the field of medical informatics, which is found at the intersection of clinical science, public health, information science, computer technology and communications technology. Concentration on current issues. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Advanced Software Engineering (3)
desc: Fundamental software engineering procedures, including planning, estimation, design, testing, process definition and improvement, and software quality assurance. Measurement techniques are used to support empirically-driven software process improvement throughout the course. Pre: graduate standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Theory of Operating Systems (3)
desc: Advanced study in operating systems theory and design with emphasis on case studies and distributed systems.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Compiler Theory and Construction (3)
desc: Design and implementation of compilers, syntactic and semantic descriptions of programming languages, algorithms for syntactic analysis and object code generation. Pre: 312 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Intelligent Autonomous Agents (3)
desc: Theory, methods and practical applications of autonomous agent systems, including common applications of both software and hardware (robotic) agents. In-depth practical experience with autonomous agents through programming assignments and projects. Pre: 313 or ECE 467 (or equivalent), graduate standing; or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ECE 606)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computer Project (V)
desc: Individual or small group projects in system design or application under faculty supervision. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Special Topics in Security (3)
desc: Special topics in security oriented toward juniors and seniors. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: at least two 300-level ICS courses or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Special Topics (3)
desc: Reflects special interests of faculty. Oriented toward juniors and seniors. Repeatable one time for BS/CS students. Pre: at least two 300-level ICS classes or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Video Game Design and Development (3)
desc: Students will team design, build, and demonstrate video games or related interactive entertainment environments and applications. Topics will include emerging computer science techniques relevant to the development of these types of environments. Junior standing or higher. Pre: any 110(Alpha) or 111 or CINE 215. (Cross-listed as CINE 487)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Data Visualization (3)
desc: I ntroduction to data visualization through practical techniques for turning data into images to produce insight. Topics include: information visualization, geospatial visualization, scientific visualization, social network visualization, and medical visualization. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 110(Alpha) or 111 or CINE 215. (Cross-listed as CINE 484 and DATA 484)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computer Vision (3)
desc: Introductory course in computer vision. Topics include image formation, image processing and filtering, edge detection, texture analysis and synthesis, binocular stereo, segmentation, tracking, object recognition and applications. A-F only. Pre: (212 or ECE 205) and (311 or ECE 367) and 314; or consent. Once a year.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Computer Graphics (3)
desc: Fundamentals of computer graphics including graphics hardware, representation, manipulation, and display of two- and three-dimensional objects, use of commercial software. Pre: MATH 307 or MATH 311; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Bioinformatics Algorithms and Tool Development (3)
desc: Study of commonly used bioinformatic algorithms, with an emphasis on string, tree, and graph algorithms. Presentation of probabilistic and clustering methods. Implementation of the studied algorithms and design of applications. Pre: 475 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Sequences and Genomes Analysis (3)
desc: Introduction to bioinformatics to computer sciences students by focusing on how computer sciences techniques can be used for the storage, analysis, prediction and simulation of biological sequences (DNA, RNA and proteins). A-F only. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Probability, Statistics, and Queuing (3)
desc: A hands-on introduction to probability, statistical inference, regression, Markov chains, queuing theory. Use of an interactive statistical graphics environment such as R. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Cognitive Science (3)
desc: Introduces basic concepts, central problems, and methods from cognitive science. Identifies contributions from disciplines such as cognitive psychology, linguistics, artificial intelligence, philosophy, and neuroscience. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Design for Mobile Devices (3)
desc: Lecture introducing design issues, programming languages, operating systems and mark-up languages for internet-enabled mobile devices, such as cell phones and PDAs. A-F or Audit. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Hypermedia (3)
desc: Basic issues of interactive access to information in various formats on computers. Available hardware and software: editing, integration, programming. Implementation of a sample information system. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Human Computer Interaction I (3)
desc: Application of concepts and methodologies of human factors, psychology and software engineering to address ergonomic, cognitive, and social factors in the design and evaluation of human-computer systems. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Artificial Intelligence for Games (3)
desc: Techniques to stimulate intelligence in video games: movement, pathfinding with A* search, decision/behavior trees, state machines, machine learning, tactics. Extend games with your own AI implementations; experience “shootout” contests for the best AI algorithm/implementation. Pre: (212 or ECE 205) and (311 or ECE 367) and 314 and (PHYS 151 or PHYS 170). (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Artificial Intelligence (3)
desc: Survey of artificial intelligence: natural language processing, vision and robotics, expert systems. Emphasis on fundamental concepts: search, planning, and problem solving, logic, knowledge representation. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Security and Trust II: Information Assurance (3)
desc: Channel security. Trojan and noninterference. Basic concepts of cryptology. Cryptographic primitives. Protocols for authentication and key establishment. Pre: 222 and 355.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Software Design for Robotics (3)
desc: Sensors, actuators, signal processing, paradigms of robotic software design, introduction to machine learning, introduction to computer vision, and robot-to-human interaction. A-F only. Pre: two ICS 300-level courses or consent. Recommended: 312 and 313. (Once a year: spring)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Data Networks (3)
desc: Network analysis, architecture, digital signal analysis and design; circuit switching, packet switching, packet broadcasting; protocols and standards; local area networks; satellite networks; ALOHA channels; examples. Pre: (212 or ECE 205) and (311 or ECE 367) and 314; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Parallel Algorithms (3)
desc: Introduction to parallel models of computation and design and analysis of parallel algorithms. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Analytical Models and Methods (3)
desc: Applications of mathematical methods in computer science with emphasis on discrete mathematics, numerical computation, algebraic models, operations research. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Theory of Computation (3)
desc: Grammars, sequential machines, equivalence, minimalization, analysis and synthesis, regular expressions, computability, unsolvability, Gödel’s theorem, Turing machines. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Big Data Analytics (3)
desc: Concepts, tools, and techniques for analyzing and mining massive data sets. Data cleaning and pre-processing. Data analysis and mining techniques. Big Data platforms. Big Data visualization. Pre: 321.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Machine Learning Fundamentals (3)
desc: Introduction to machine learning concepts with a focus on relevant ideas from computational neuroscience. Information processing and learning in the nervous system. Neural networks. Supervised and unsupervised learning. Basics of statistical learning theory. Pre: 235, or consent. Recommended: MATH 307. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as DATA 435)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Data Science Fundamentals (3)
desc: Introduction to critical statistical and probabilistic concepts that underlie data science as well as tools that play a central role in the daily work of a data scientist. A-F only. Pre: 211 or consent. (Cross-listed as DATA 434)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Concurrent and High-Performance Programming (3)
desc: Principles of concurrent and high performance programming. Multi-threading in C and Java for shared-memory programming. Distributed memory programming with Java. Introduction to cluster computing. A-F only. Pre: (212 or ECE 205) and 332 and (311 or ECE 367) and 314; or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computer Architecture (3)
desc: Memory management, control flow, interrupt mechanisms, multiprocessor systems, special-purpose devices. Pre: 331 or ECE 361/361L.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Digital Forensics (3)
desc: Provides students with the knowledge of underlying principles and skills to identify, preserve, and extract electronic evidence for further analysis. Pre: 355 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computer System Security (3)
desc: Information flow, confinement, information assurance, malicious programs, vulnerability analysis, network security, writing secure programs. A-F only. Pre: 355 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computer Security and Ethics (3)
desc: Theoretical results, security policy, encryption, key management, digital signatures, certificates, passwords. Ethics: privacy, computer crime, professional ethics. Effects of the computer revolution on society. A-F only. Pre: 355 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Application Frameworks (3)
desc: Experience producing applications with at least two different applications frameworks. A-F only. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Data Security and Cryptography I (3)
desc: Secret communication and confidentiality data storage. Elements of cryptography and cryptanalysis. Classical ciphers. Symmetric key cryptography. Public key cryptography. Data security in cyber space. Pre: 222 and 355.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Network Science Methodology (3)
desc: Computational and statistical methods for analyzing network models of social, technological, information, and biological networks. Introduction to relevant data analytics and graph analysis software packages. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) or consent. (Cross-listed as DATA 422)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Database Systems II (3)
desc: Very large database systems, data integration, data warehousing, designing big data systems, parallel query processing, distributed transactions. Pre: 321 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: The Science, Psychology and Philosophy of Systems Design (3)
desc: Scientific, psychological and philosophical bases of systems design, including a survey of human-factors and ergonomic standards; the nature of innovation and creativity as it relates to systems design. Web-enhanced course. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Programming for the Web (3)
desc: Introduction to emerging technologies for construction of World Wide Web (WWW)-based software. Covers programming and scripting languages used for the creation of WWW sites and client-server programming. Students will complete a medium-sized software project that uses languages and concepts discussed in class. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Software Engineering II (3)
desc: Continuation of 314. Project management, quality, and productivity control, testing and validation, team management. Team-oriented software-implementation project. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computing Ethics for Lab Assistants (3)
desc: A lecture/discussion/internship on ethical issues and instructional techniques for students assisting a laboratory section of ICS 101. The class uses multiple significant writing and oral presentation activities to help students learn course content. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence Programming (3)
desc: Introduction to the theory of Artificial Intelligence and the practical application of AI techniques in Functional (Common LISP and/or Scheme) and Logic (Prolog) programming languages. Students gain practical experience through programming assignments and projects. A-F only. Pre: (215 or 212 or ECE 205) and (311 or ECE 367) and 314; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Security and Trust I: Resource Protections (3)
desc: Security and trust in computers, networks, and society. Security models. Access and authorization. Availability and Denial-of-Service. Trust processes and network interactions. Pre: 241 or (MATH 301 and 372).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Network Design and Management (3)
desc: Overview of the internet and its capabilities; introduction to HTTP, TCP/IP, ethernet, and wireless 802.11; routers, switches, and NAT; network and wireless security; practical experience in designing and implementing networks. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Operating Systems (3)
desc: Operating system concepts and structure, processes and threads, CPU scheduling, memory management, scheduling, file systems, inter-process communication, virtualization, popular operating systems. A-F only. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Logic Design and Microprocessors (4)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Basic machine architecture, microprocessors, bus organization, circuit elements, logic circuit analysis and design, microcomputer system design. Pre: (212 or ECE 205), (311 or ECE 367), and 314; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Database Systems I (3)
desc: Introduction to relational database systems, data modeling, query processing, transaction processing, storage, and indexing. Pre: (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Software Engineering I (3)
desc: Problem analysis and design, team-oriented development, quality assurance, configuration management, project planning. These topics are covered in the sequence 314-414. Pre: (211 or ECE 205) and [241 or ECE 362 or (MATH 301 and 372)]; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Programming Language Theory (3)
desc: Syntax, semantics, control structures, variable binding and scopes, data and control abstractions. Programming in functional (LISP) and logic (Prolog) programming styles. Pre: (212 or ECE 205), (311 or ECE 367), and 314; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Machine-Level and Systems Programming (3)
desc: Machine organization, machine instructions, addressing modes, assembler language, subroutine linkage, linking to higher-level languages, interface to operating systems, introduction to assemblers, loaders and compilers. Pre: (212 or ECE 205) (or concurrent), (311 or ECE 367), and 314; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Algorithms (4)
desc: (4 1-hr Lec) Design and correctness of algorithms, including divide-and-conquer, greedy and dynamic programming methods. Complexity analyses using recurrence relations, probabilistic methods, and NP-completeness. Applications to order statistics, disjoint sets, B-trees and balanced trees, graphs, network flows, and string matching. Pre: 211, and [(241 or ECE 362) and (MATH 216 or 242 or 252A)] or (MATH 301 and 372); or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Computer Science Careers: An Exploration of the Specialties of Computer Science (1)
desc: Exploration of the specialties of computer science. Meets every two week for 2.5 hours to explore specific areas in computer science. CR/NC only. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science II (3)
desc: Includes program correctness, recurrence relations and their solutions, relations and their properties, divide and conquer relations, graph theory, trees and their applications, Boolean algebra, introduction to formal languages and automata theory. Pre: 141 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Machine Learning Methods (3)
desc: Introduction to contemporary mathematical methods for empirical inference, data modeling, and machine learning. A-F only. Pre: MATH 241, MATH 203, MATH 215, or MATH 251A. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as DATA 235)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Basic Concepts of Computer Science (3)
desc: What is the subject of computer science? What is a computer? Understand the basic models of computation and the concepts of computability, complexity, and network computation, and learn to use them in practice. A-F only. Pre: 141 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Scripting (3)
desc: Introduction to scripting languages for the integration of applications and systems. Scripting in operating systems, web pages, server-side application integration, regular expressions, and event handling for languages such as Perl, JavaScript, PHP, Python, shell scripting. A-F only. Pre: 211 (or concurrent), or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Program Structure (3)
desc: Program organization paradigms, programming environments, implementation of a module from specifications, the C and C++ programming languages. Pre: 211 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Computer Science II (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr. Lab) Reinforce and strengthen problemsolving skills using abstract data types and introduce software development practices. Emphasize the use of searching and sorting algorithms and their complexity, recursion, object-oriented programming, and data structures. Pre: 111 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Information Systems in Society (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion critically explores sociopolitical dimensions of Information and Communication Technology (ICT), and the information professions. A-F only. Pre: departmental approval. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science I (3)
desc: Includes logic, sets, functions, matrices, algorithmic concepts, mathematical reasoning, recursion, counting techniques, and probability theory. Pre: MATH 215 or 241 or 251A.
metadata: FQ College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Computer Science I (4)
desc: Overview of the fundamentals of computer science emphasizing problem solving, algorithm development, implementation, and debugging/testing using an object-oriented programming language. Pre: Recommended: computer experience.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: (Alpha) Introduction to Computer Programming (3)
desc: Basic concepts needed to write computer programs. Simple program design and implementation using a specific programming language; (C) C; (D) through animations; (P) Python. Each alpha repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. ((P) Cross-listed as DATA 110P)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Computer Science Principles (3)
desc: General course that provides a broad overview of computer science. Will address abstraction, data and information, algorithms, programming, the Internet and the global impact of computers.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Data Science (3)
desc: Overview of the field of data science. Introduction to subjects such as data format, processing, visualization, and storage. Special emphasis on historical and wider context, and simple practical examples. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: ICS
title: Digital Tools for the Information World (4)
desc: Fundamental information technology concepts and computing terminology, productivity software for problem solving, computer technology trends and impact on individuals and society. Emphasizes the utilization of operating systems and the production of professional documents, spreadsheets, etc.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Information and Computer Sciences (ICS)

subject: IND
title: Modern Indonesian Literature (3)
desc: Selected readings, 1900 to present. Discussion and composition. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: History of Indonesian (3)
desc: Social and linguistic development of Indonesian from roots in earlier Malay to contemporary form and function. Pre: 202 and 452, or consent.
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Structure of Indonesian (3)
desc: Introduction to grammar; some sociolinguistic background. Pre: 302 or equivalent, or consent.
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Fourth Level Indonesian Conversation (1)
desc: Topic-based course aimed to enhance students’ listening and speaking skills in the Indonesian language. Pre: 302, 306, or consent. Co-requisite: 405. (Fall only)
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Fourth Level Indonesian (2)
desc: Online course consists of modular, thematic, proficiency-based units exploring the language of the contemporary Indonesian media with an emphasis on reading, writing, and listening comprehension. Pre: 302, 306, or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Fourth-Level Indonesian (3)
desc: Continuation of 401. Pre: 401 or 405.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Fourth-Level Indonesian (3)
desc: Continuation of 302. Conducted in Indonesian. Meets three hours a week. Readings in various materials; speaking in various settings. Pre: 302 or 308, or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Third Level Indonesian Conversation (2)
desc: Topic-based course aimed at enhancing students’ listening and speaking skills in the Indonesian language. Not open to students who have taken 302. Pre: 301 or 307, or consent. Co-requisite: 306. (Spring only)
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Third Level Indonesian Conversation (2)
desc: Topic-based course aimed to enhance student’s listening and speaking skills in the Indonesian language. Not open to students who have taken 301. Pre: 202, 204, or consent. Co-requisite: 305. (Fall only)
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Third Level Indonesian (2)
desc: Online course consists of modular, thematic, proficiency-based units exploring colloquial and formal Indonesian with a strong emphasis on listening and writing comprehension. Not open to students who have taken 302. Pre: 301 or 305 (or equivalent), or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Third Level Indonesian (2)
desc: Online course consists of modular, thematic, proficiency-based units exploring the language of the contemporary Indonesian media with an emphasis on reading, writing, and listening comprehension. Not open to students who have taken IND 301. Pre: 202, 204, or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Third-Level Indonesian (3)
desc: Continuation of 301. Pre: 301.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Third-Level Indonesian (3)
desc: Continuation of 202. Conducted in Indonesian. Meets three hours a week. Reading, discussion, composition, and projects. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Intermediate Indonesian II (3)
desc: Second semester of intermediate Indonesian. Emphasis on the continued development of competence in both oral and written language for more advanced communication, travel, and further study. Pre: 201.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Intermediate Indonesian I (3)
desc: The first semester of intermediate Indonesian. Emphasis on the continued development of competence in both oral and written language for more advanced communication and travel. Pre: 102 or equivalent.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Elementary Indonesian II (3)
desc: Second semester of elementary Indonesian. Emphasis on the continued development of communicative competence in both oral and written language. Pre: 101.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IND
title: Elementary Indonesian I (3)
desc: First semester of elementary Indonesian. Emphasis on the development of communicative competence in both oral and written language and exposes students to the culture of Indonesia.
metadata: HSL Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures Indonesian (IND)

subject: IP
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Directed Studies (V)
desc: Study of a Pacific, South Asian, or Southeast Asian language through vernacular readings in various academic fields. Repeatable. Pre: third-level language and consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Folklore (3)
desc: Theory and method of comparative and analytical folklore study, with special applications to Pacific traditions. Pre: ANTH 152 or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: (Alpha) Hawaiian and Indo-Pacific Teaching Practicum (3)
desc: An experienced-based introduction to various approaches in language teaching methodologies and techniques. Students’ skills in teaching the Hawaiian or an Indo-Pacific language are developed through supervised teaching, class planning and evaluation. (B) Southeast Asian languages. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. Pre: 402-level of the language practicum or consent; (B) CAM 402 or IND 402 or THAI 402 (or concurrent) and consent of instructor or equivalent language skills.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: The Writings of Carlos Bulosan (3)
desc: Intensive study of the major writings of Carlos Bulosan; his literary and cultural milieu with thematic concentration on aesthetics and the issues of diasporic experiences (e.g., immigration, assimilation, nation, etc.) and transnationalism. Pre: 361 or 363 or 396 or 431 or any ENG DL.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Rizal’s Literary Works in Translation (3)
desc: Interpretation and analyses of Rizal’s novels Noli and Fili as they relate to the social, political, and historical context of the Spanish regime in the Philippines. Pre: one DL course, or consent.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: (Alpha) Topics in Samoan Literature (3)
desc: (B) Writings of Albert Wendt; (C) Samoan women writers. Pre: SAM 227 or one of ENG 270-272; or consent for (B). Pre: SAM 227 or one of ENG 270-273 or WGSS 245; or consent for (C).
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Ilokano Literature in Translation (3)
desc: Overview of Ilokano literature from the early writings to the major works of contemporary writers. A-F only. Pre: ILO 201 or consent.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Directed Fourth-Level Language Study (3)
desc: Continuation of 401.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Directed Fourth-Level Language Study (3)
desc: Continuation of 302. Pre: consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Third-Level Language Study (V)
desc: Third-level study of a South Asian, Southeast Asian, or Pacific language. Contact hours and credits determined by student interests and faculty resources. Repeatable up to six credits. Pre: at least 6 credits of intermediate study of the same language.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Philippine Literature and Folklore in Translation (3)
desc: Philippine folk literature translated into English: epics, myths, legends, and other folklore. Classic works of vernacular writers. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as ENG 376)
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Polynesian Folklore in Translation (3)
desc: Traditional Polynesian genres (legends, myths, folktales, fables, proverbs, songs, riddles, jokes) examined in translation and culturally and structurally interpreted. Pre: one of ENG 270-272.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Literary Cultural Relations (Philippines and Southeast Asia) (3)
desc: An appreciation, a reexamination, and an analysis of the literary and cultural relations among the various nation states of Southeast Asia. Various texts are examined to establish the connections of these nation states. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Theories in Ilokano Studies (3)
desc: Examines the various theories employed in the study of Ilokano society, language, and culture from a variety of historical periods. A-F only. Junior standing or higher, or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Philippine Visual Art from Burial Jars to Burning Effigies (3)
desc: Introduction to the arts and material culture of the Philippines from the pre-colonial to the contemporary period through the examination of sculpture, metalwork, ceramics, textiles, and painting from various ethnolinguistic groups. Sophomore standing or higher. (Cross-listed as ART 382)
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Critical Discourses in IPLL Studies: Philippines (3)
desc: Revaluation and analysis of critical discourses in Philippine languages and literatures and an examination of alternative perspectives to the prevailing studies on Philippine culture; an appreciation of emerging knowledge on the Philippines. Pre: sophomore standing or higher, or consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Philippine Diasporic Literatures (3)
desc: Appreciation, reexamination, and analysis of Philippine literature of exile; a reevaluation of Philippine writing from the diaspora. Sophomore standing or higher or consent.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Philippine Games, Sports and Martial Arts (3)
desc: Introduces an experiential approach in the study of Philippine traditional games, sports, and martial arts. It also focuses on the historical and socio-cultural aspects of games, sports, and martial arts. Sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Classical Hindu Mythology (3)
desc: Study of major myths of Epic Sanskrit literature, primarily with focus of the Ramayana and Mahabharata. Literary sources will be tapped for appreciating myths and epics, especially with reference to dharma, karma, ways of life. Sophomore standing or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as REL 374)
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Vedic Hindu Mythology (3)
desc: Study of major Hindu myths of the Vedic Sanskrit literature within the perspective of ancient Indian civilization. Literary sources will be tapped for understanding creation, cosmogony and celestial, atmospheric and terrestrial divinities. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as REL 373)
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: (Alpha) Study Abroad (3)
desc: (B) Samoa; (C) Tahiti; (E) Vietnam. Repeatable one time for (B) and (C). Pre: instructor consent for (C).
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Introduction to South/Southeast Asian Film, History, Theory and Appreciation (3)
desc: Study and analysis of South/Southeast Asian films– history, forms, development, theoretical framework and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical and aesthetic context. (B) Filipino. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only for (B).
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Literatures of Ancient India (3)
desc: Survey of South Asia literature from ancient times to the early medieval period; focusing on Sanskrit, Prakrit and Tamil poetry traditions. Readings in English translation. (Cross-listed as CLAS 366)
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: South Asian Literature in Translation (3)
desc: Survey of traditional and modern literatures of South Asia; literature written originally in English.
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Philippine Popular Culture (3)
desc: Explores the ethics of Philippine popular culture forms; teaches students how to produce, act, and perform in a select media form; and engages students in writing a critical analysis of these pop cultural expressions. A-F only. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Philippine Contemporary Literature in English (3)
desc: Critical survey of 20th-century Philippine literature written in English; cultural values. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as ENG 375)
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Philippine Drama: History, Art, Culture (3)
desc: Survey of Philippine drama from the perspective of sociocultural and historical experiences of the people in the country and in the diaspora. Emphasis is on ethical inquiry and the teaching of writing and oral communication. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only.  (Fall only)
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Southeast Asian Literature in Translation (3)
desc: Survey in English of traditional and modern literatures of Southeast Asia. (Cross-listed as ASAN 361)
metadata: DL Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: (Alpha) Southeast Asian Food, Music, and Rituals (3)
desc: Study and analysis of the art and culture of Southeast Asian food, music, and rituals—history, forms, social development, influences, and impact, with an emphasis on oral and written communication. (P) Philippine; (V) Vietnamese. Sophomore standing or consent for P. A-F only.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Bollywood Dance, Music, and Film (3)
desc: Unique course combining mind and body, discussion and dancing. Learn and perform Bollywood dances and the richness of their Indian poetic, classical, and folk traditions. Understand “Bollywood” in the context of cross-cultural fusion and globalization. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as ASAN 303)
metadata: DA Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Directed Third-Level Language Study (3)
desc: Continuation of 301.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Directed Third-Level Language Study (3)
desc: Continuation of 202. Pre: consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: History of Early India (3)
desc: Historical survey of India and South Asia from Mohenjo-Daro to the Mughal Empire, tracing political, social, religious, economic, cultural, and intellectual developments from ancient times to the 18th century. (Cross-listed as HIST 301)
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Intermediate Language Study (V)
desc: Intermediate study of a South Asian, Southeast Asian, or Pacific language. Contact hours and credits determined by student interests and faculty resources. Repeatable up to eight credit hours. Pre: at least six credit hours of elementary study in the same language.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: (Alpha) Introduction to Indo-Pacific Language and Culture (3)
