desc: Introduction in English to language(s) and culture(s) of Indo-Pacific country or region. (B) Indian; (C) Southeast Asian; (D) Polynesian; (E) Philippines. Sophomore standing or higher for (C). Pre: 101 and 102 courses in relevant language or consent for (B), (D), and (E).
metadata: DH Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Topics in Indo-Pacific Literature/Culture (V)
desc: Study of a literature or culture of the Indo-Pacific area through readings in various fields in English. Repeatable up to six credit hours. Pre: consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Directed Intermediate Language Study (4)
desc: Continuation of 201.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Directed Intermediate Language Study (4)
desc: Continuation of 102. Pre: consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Introductory Language Study (V)
desc: Introductory study of a South Asian, Southeast Asian, or Pacific language. Contact hours and credits determined by student interests and faculty resources. Repeatable up to eight credit hours. Pre: consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Directed Elementary Language Study (4)
desc: Continuation of 101.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: IP
title: Directed Elementary Language Study (4)
desc: Directed study of a South Asian, Southeast Asian, or Pacific language not regularly listed by the department. Pre: consent.
metadata: Indo-Pacific Languages (IP) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Ilokano for the Mass Media (3)
desc: Ilokano as the medium for print journalism, for radio show programming, and for television production. Pre: 302 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Structure of Ilokano (3)
desc: Introduction to phonology, morphology, and syntax. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: DH Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Ilokano Interpretation Field Practicum (3)
desc: Provide extensive practical training in consecutive, simultaneous, sight and telephonic interpreting. It requires observation and study of interpretation strategies and techniques in relevant situations. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Introduction to Ilokano for Interpreters (3)
desc: Techniques for interpreting Ilokano into English and vice versa. A-F only. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Fourth-Level Ilokano (3)
desc: Continuation of 401. Pre: 401 or exam, or consent.
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Fourth-Level Ilokano (3)
desc: Continuation of 302. Conducted in Ilokano. Advanced reading, writing, and conversation. Contemporary Ilokano literature; cultural and historical topics. Pre: 302 or equivalent.
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Contemporary Ilokano Literature (3)
desc: Conducted in Ilokano, this course explores the literary landscape of Ilokano literature from the perspective of Ilokano writers based in the Philippines as well as those outside of the country. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Ilokano Aural Comprehension (3)
desc: Training in listening comprehension of different authentic and simulated materials as presented in documentaries, soap operas, radio and television news and other broadcasts, formal lectures, plays, natural conversations, songs, and student-created sitcoms and dramas. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Third-Level Ilokano (3)
desc: Continuation of 301. Pre: 301 or exam, or consent.
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Third-Level Ilokano (3)
desc: To further acquire and develop Ilokano language skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, utilizes ethnographic and sociolinguistic approaches in order to further examine and interrogate the relationship of language and culture. Pre: 202 or exam, or consent.
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Intermediate Ilokano (4)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201 or consent.
metadata: HSL Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Intermediate Ilokano (4)
desc: Continuation of 102. Meets four hours weekly; three of four hours devoted to drill and practice. Pre: 102 or consent.
metadata: HSL Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Ilokano for Health Sciences (3)
desc: Development of listening, speaking, reading, writing and other communication skills designed specifically for Nursing, Dentistry, Dental Hygiene, Public Health and Social Work students. Culture integrated with language study.
metadata: Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Beginning Ilokano (4)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101 or consent.
metadata: HSL Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ILO
title: Beginning Ilokano (4)
desc: Listening, speaking, reading, writing. Structural points introduced inductively. Meets four hours weekly.
metadata: HSL Ilokano (ILO) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: HRM
title: Human Resources Leadership in Healthcare Organizations (3)
desc: Builds on previous leadership and management courses, focus on development of individual leadership skills emphasizing ethical and critical decision making, effective working relationships, and a systems-perspective relevant to healthcare organizations. A-F only. Pre: BUS 626. (Alt. years)
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Human Resource Management Capstone (3)
desc: The final course in the MHRM curriculum. It provides students opportunity to integrate and apply previous course content to their professional organization offering a value-added opportunity to enhance organizational performance. MHRM majors only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Human Resource Management-Topics (3)
desc: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and trends in human resources. Repeatable four times with change in topics. MHRM majors only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: International Human Resources (3)
desc: Exploring global trends in human resources with focus on the Asia Pacific region. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Negotiations and Labor Relations (3)
desc: Theory and practice of negotiation. Exploration of appropriate strategies, tactics, and communication techniques. Study of dyadic multi-party, cross-cultural, and assisted negotiations. MHRM majors only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: The Staffing Process (3)
desc: Recruiting and selection to optimize organizations including job design, job analysis, recruitment and selection methods, such as types of interviews and assessment centers, within legislative environment. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Compensation (3)
desc: Survey of compensation methods and procedures including job evaluations, incentive systems, salary administration, fringe benefits, appropriate legislation, policies and strategy issues of compensation systems. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Finance for Human Resource Management (3)
desc: Intends to give HR professionals a basic overview of the vocabulary and concepts of financial decision-making. Topics include: understanding financial information, budgeting, the finance of retirement and employee benefit and business valuation. MHRM majors only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Advanced Organizational Behavior (3)
desc: Organizational development (OD) and major concepts in organizational behavior. MHRM majors only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Training and Development (3)
desc: Covers issues in design, delivery, and assessment of training, theoretical background of training and development process, types of training process, cross cultural and other types of diversity training and development of training modules. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Human Resource Management (3)
desc: Analysis and critical evaluation of basic issues, policies, and trends in personnel administration. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Seminar in HRM (3)
desc: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and trends in HRM. Repeatable one time for different topics. Pre: consent.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Training and Development (3)
desc: Analysis of the current concepts and practices in the design, delivery, and assessment of training. A-F only.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Labor Management Relations (3)
desc: Review and analysis of basic factors that distinguish employment relations; examination of the development of recent legislation and programs at federal, state, and municipal levels. Specific consideration given to current problems on the mainland and Hawai‘i. Pre: consent.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Negotiation and Workplace Dispute Resolution (3)
desc: Theory and practice in negotiating; design and operation of different kinds of workplace dispute resolution (such as mediation, arbitration, and various alternatives); features exercises on bargaining and negotiation and advocacy and decision skills. (Spring only)
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: The Staffing Process (3)
desc: Contemporary practices and trends in personnel planning for a competent work force; legal constraints, recruitment and selection, differential placement, training, career programming. Pre: 351.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Personnel Compensation (3)
desc: Selected topics. Emphasis on trends, recent issues, job evaluation, incentive systems, salary administration, executive compensation, profit sharing, benefit programs, retirement plans. Pre: 351.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in a special area within the major field under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and faculty advisor.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Labor Problems (3)
desc: Problems and economics of labor; history, structure, government, activities of trade unions.
metadata: DS Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Organizational Change and Effectiveness (3)
desc: Identify and evaluate methods to promote an effective change transition through efficient integration of corporate goals with the organizational culture.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Leadership and Group Dynamics (3)
desc: Explore frameworks leaders can use to get things done in their teams. Examine how leaders can engage employees, improve decision-making, manage interpersonal dynamics, and adapt to changing internal and external contexts. Emphasis on writing instruction.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Human Resource Management (3)
desc: Survey of the field covering recruitment, selection, training, appraisals, grievance handling, communications, discipline, safety, compensation, and benefits.
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HRM
title: Career Development (1)
metadata: Human Resources Management (HRM) Shidler College of Business

subject: HDFS
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Independent reading and research on a topic, done under supervision of a faculty member; outcomes contracted in writing with faculty member at beginning of semester. Repeatable two times or up to nine credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Capstone Portfolio (3)
desc: Preparation of a senior portfolio to be used as assessment of competence relative to national FCS standards. Includes extensive instruction on writing. HDFS majors only. Pre: (230, 340, 360, 380, 380L, and 492 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Internship (4)
desc:
Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills in supervised work at an approved internship site and through analytical writing assignments and class discussions. 
Repeatable one time. HDFS majors only. A-F only. Pre: (230, 340, 360, 380, and 380L) with a minimum grade of C.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Topics in Family Resources (V)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics, problems. Offered by visiting faculty and/or for extension programs. Repeatable.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: WGSS
title: Seminar in the Biology of Women (3)
desc:
Embryological, anatomical, and physiological development of human female; hormonal, neural, and behavioral determinants of female sexual behavior; psychobiology of pregnancy, ovariectomy, and menopause. Pre: 350 or BIOL 172 or BIOL 350, or 
consent.
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: The Anthropology of Sexuality (3)
desc: Explores the intersection of sexuality research and queer theory with other anthropological concerns such as identity, race, gender, religion, economy, politics, and globalization. A-F only. Pre: junior standing or consent. (Cross-listed as ANTH 426)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender, Sexuality and Digital Media (3)
desc: Students learn how gender and sexuality are constructed online and produce a website to post their analysis and contribute to knowledge production about gender and sexuality in cyberspace. A-F only.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Feminist Issues in Philosophy (3)
desc: Examination of basic feminist issues in philosophy, and of responses to them. Pre: any course 200 or above in PHIL or WS, or consent. (Cross-listed as PHIL 418)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Work (3)
desc: Gender and race of paid and unpaid work in the formal and informal sectors of the economy; carework in households; unemployment; ethics of revaluing feminized work; labor rights: scope: local and global. Pre: one 300-level WGSS or ES course, or SOC 300; or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 418 and SOC 418)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women, Gender, & Sexuality in Performance (3)
desc: Feminist and performance studies approaches to performances by women and other genders; focus on the representation and status of women Pre: THEA 311 or consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 414) DH
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender and Politics in U.S.-Okinawa Relations (3)
desc: Examines gender in Okinawa in relation to historical dynamics in the Asia-Pacific region with attention to issues such as militarism and violence, colonialism and memory, and tourism and commodification of indigenous culture. A-F only. Pre: 151 or consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 410)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Pre: consent. Repeatable eight times, up to 45 credits.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Co-ops, Communes, Collectives (3)
desc: Theory and practice of democratic organizations: women’s and feminist organizations; co-ops, communes, and collectives; indigenous people’s organizations; workplace democracy and social change. A-F only. Pre: any 100- or 200-level POLS course or POLS 390 (or concurrent) or WS 151, or consent. (Cross-listed as POLS 394)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Sexualities (3)
desc: Multi-disciplinary course draws from psychology, sociology, biology, history, cultural anthropology, law, Hawaiian, ethnic, feminist, gender, and queer studies to explore human sexualities with emphasis on the U.S., Hawai‘i and the AsiaPacific regions. A-F only. Pre: one of 151, 202, 315 or 350; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender and Race in U.S. Society (3)
desc: Historical and sociological studies of race and gender in U.S. society; grassroots feminist and racial/justice activism on the continent and in Hawai‘i. A-F only. Pre: 151 or ES 101 or junior standing. (Cross-listed as ES 390)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Politics (3)
desc: Women’s role in political institutions and processes in the U.S. and other countries; female and male approaches to power; feminist political goals and actions. Pre: 151 (or concurrent) or 362 (or concurrent) or any 100 level POLS course (or concurrent); or consent. (Cross-listed as POLS 384)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Island Feminisms: Art, Literature, and Culture (3)
desc: Examines island feminisms and explores ways women have engaged in various forms of cultural production (art, literature, film). Interdisciplinary, intersectional, and transnational. Key themes discussed: settler-colonialism, race, gender, and sexuality.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Gender, Sexuality and Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of literary constructions of gender and sexuality; emphasis on teaching gender and sexuality through writing and oral communication. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as ENG 382)
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and the Media (3)
desc: Media portrayal of women and men; role of the media in reproducing gender inequality. Women as producers and consumers of media. Feminist alternatives to mainstream media. Pre: one of 151, 362, SOC 362.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Sustainability, Technoscience, and Social Justice (3)
desc: Examines politics of sustainability and technoscience with an explicit attention to social justice and power relations in society. A-F only. Pre: 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or consent. (Fall only) (Crosslisted as SOC 367 and SUST 367)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Sociology of Gender (3)
desc: Effect of sex and gender roles (both traditional and nontraditional) on attitudes and behavior within the family and educational, economic, and governmental systems. Recommended: at least one WS course. Pre: 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course; or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 362)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Seminar: Women and International Development (3)
desc: Topics: Women’s role, status, work and treatment in the Third World; economic development, changing work/family roles, agriculture and business, improvement/deterioration in gender equity across the Third World global feminization of poverty. Open to nonmajors. Pre: a 100 level economics course or any women’s studies course; or consent. (Cross-listed as ECON 361)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Pacific/Asian Women in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Adaptive strategies of Hawaiian, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Filipino, Samoan, and Southeast Asian women in Hawai‘i; feminist anthropological and historical analysis. Pre: any ANTH, SOC, or WS course. (Cross-listed as ES 365)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Religion (3)
desc: Examining roles of, and attitudes toward, women in major religious traditions through autobiographies, films, and primary texts. Pre: 149 or REL 149 or REL 150 or HIST 151 or WGSS 151. (Cross-listed as REL 356)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women, Ideas, and Society (3)
desc: Status of women in American society today in light of the cultural, historical, and philosophical forces that have produced it. Pre: HIST 151 and HIST 152; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Sex Differences in the Life Cycle (3)
desc: Human sex differences, their biological basis and significance, ethical considerations of genetic, hormonal, and behavioral determinants of sexual differentiation; biology of gender, sexuality, parenting, menopause, and aging. Pre: one semester of biological sciences. (Cross-listed as BIOL 350)
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: HDFS
title: Family Economics (3)
desc: Study of personal family resources and its interaction with the economy. Focuses on contemporary economic problems that affect the welfare of families. Pre: 360 or an ECON course, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Consumer Communications (3)
desc: Development, production, analysis, and evaluation of consumer materials for print media. Use of desktop publishing computer programs. Pre: 360 or an ECON course, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Family Public Policy (3)
desc: Cross-national survey of family public policy; analysis, revision, and development of family public policy; impacts of policy on consumers and families. Pre: 352.
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Community Program Development (3)
desc: Concepts and theories of community program development; principles, practices, and procedures in administration and supervision of volunteer services surveyed and analyzed. Pre: 352.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Family Life Education Methodology (4)
desc: Lecture, discussion and hands-on course, with service learning on Family Life Education Methodology. Repeatable one time. Pre: 341 or 442, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Contemporary Family Issues (3)
desc: Investigation of current issues with impact upon family quality of life, with emphasis on the interdependent nature of families and their environments. A-F only. Pre: 340 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Marriage Development (3)
desc: Marital interaction and development; divorce and remarriage; resources and techniques for marital adjustment, enrichment, and growth. Pre: 340.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Mindfulness and Skillful Living (3)
desc: Lecture, discussion, and experiential activities of principles and practice of an evidence-based contemplative science discipline. Focuses on development of writing skills and ethical applications to daily life, with implications for youth, families, and society. Pre: completed DS course (with a minimum grade of C).
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Partnerships with Families and Professionals (4)
desc: Lecture, discussion and hands-on course, prepares students for direct, educational work with parents and children and for continued graduate work in child and family studies, counseling, psychology, social work and/or family life education. A-F only. Pre: 341 or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Research Methodology Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Test design, computer use, data analysis. FDM, HDFS, or TPSS majors only. Co-requisite: 380.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Research Methodology (3)
desc: Fundamental scientific methodology, design and data collection; introduction to statistics and program evaluations, analysis of ethical issues. FDM, HDFS, or TPSS majors only. Pre: 230 or FDM 200 or TPSS 200/SUST 211, or consent. Co-requisite: 380L.
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Soft Skills for Success in the Workplace (3)
desc: Employers regard soft skills as key criteria when hiring and retaining employees. Students learn critical skills essential to work place success. This class prepares students to be work ready.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Consumer Economics (3)
desc: Consumer rights, responsibilities, and resources; consumer decision-making; factors affecting consumer functioning within economy. Pre: 360 or an ECON course, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Family Financial Planning (3)
desc: Analytical approach to family financial planning from the perspective of changing family demands over the life cycle. Pre: 360 or an ECON course, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Family Resource Management (3)
desc: Concepts, principles, and practices in managing family and household resources. Pre: 230 or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Community Needs and Resources (3)
desc: Theory and practice in determining community needs and resources; community resources development based on needs identification. Pre: any FG course.
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Leadership and Group Process (3)
desc: Exploration of leadership research and theories and their application to leadership development; designed to enhance personal and interactive leadership. Pre: any FG course.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Parenting (3)
desc: Parenting theories, methods, skills, issues, and resources; parent-child relations in various cultural contexts. Pre: 340 or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Intimacy, Marriages and Families (3)
desc: Study of intimate relationships, marriages and families, their dynamics, strengths, growth and development, challenges, choices and opportunities, in the context of social change and cultural diversity. Pre: 230 or PSY 100 or SOC 100; or consent
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Middle Age and Aging (3)
desc: Change and continuity in midlife and late life from theoretical and applied perspectives. Written assignments communicate information about physical and psychological age-related events, as well as social attitudes, values, to scholarly and community audiences. Pre: 230. (Cross-listed as COA 334)
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Adolescence and Early Adulthood (3)
desc: Problems, concepts, and research related to development from puberty through early adulthood. Examination of biological, cognitive, social, and cultural factors affecting the individual. Pre: 230 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Childhood (3)
desc: Intensive investigation into developmental aspects of 6–12 year old children. Historical and current issues, research, and examination of the role of schools and other community resources. Focus on optimal development. Pre: 230 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Infancy and Early Childhood (3)
desc: Growth and development from prenatal period to age 5. Historical and current issues and research based on ecological, cross-cultural perspective. Focus on optimal development. Pre: 230 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: HDFS
title: Human Development (3)
desc: Concepts, issues, theories of human growth and development from conception to death; systems approaches to inquiry into factors affecting growth and development.
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Human Development & Family Studies (HDFS)

subject: TIM
title: Food and World Cultures (3)
desc: An integrated cross-cultural approach to the study of foods and cultures. Examine history, concepts, principles of cultures and cuisines, the background of food tradition including habitat, social status, religious beliefs, gender, and other environmental considerations. A-F only.
metadata: FGB Honors (HON) Office of Student Success School of Travel Industry Management Travel Industry Management (TIM)

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish II (3)
desc: Continuation of 201. Oral practice and grammar study; increasing emphasis on reading and written composition. Pre: 201 or 258.
metadata: HSL Spanish (SPAN)

subject: SOC
title: Introduction to Sociology (3)
desc: Basic social relationships, social structures, and processes.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Sociology (SOC)

subject: SOCS
title: Street Science: Evaluating and Applying Evidence in Daily Life (3)
desc: Develops necessary tools for effective reasoning and problem-solving through use and application of analytic techniques, including question formation, understanding/interpreting data presented in the public sphere, and evaluating the validity of sources. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Social Sciences (SOCS)

subject: REL
title: Religion and the Meaning of Existence (3)
desc: Basic ideas and issues in contemporary religious thought about the meaning of existence.
metadata: DH Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Religion (REL)

subject: PSY
title: Survey of Psychology (3)
desc: An overview of the field: psychophysiology, perception, learning, cognition, stress, personality, social psychology.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Psychology (PSY)

subject: POLS
title: History of Political Thought (3)
desc: Theories, approaches, concepts, and issues developed or raised in history of political philosophy and thought. Pre: any 100- or 200-level POLS course, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Political Science (POLS)

subject: POLS
title: Introduction to Political Science (3)
desc: Discussion of politics as an activity and of political problems, systems, ideologies, processes.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Political Science (POLS)

subject: MUS
title: Music in World Cultures (3)
desc: Folk, popular, and art music from major regions of the world, with emphasis upon Asia and the Pacific; representative styles and regional characteristics.
metadata: FGC Honors (HON) Music (MUS) Office of Student Success

subject: MICR
title: Microbiology Laboratory (2)
desc: (2 2-hr Lab) Primarily for students in nursing and dental hygiene. Pre: 130 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Microbiology (MICR) Office of Student Success

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Computer Science II (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr. Lab) Reinforce and strengthen problem-solving skills using abstract data types and introduce software development practices. Emphasize the use of searching and sorting algorithms and their complexity, recursion, object-oriented programming, and data structures. Pre: grade of “B” or higher in 111 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Information and Computer Sciences (ICS) Office of Student Success

subject: ICS
title: Introduction to Computer Science I (4)
desc: Overview of the fundamentals of computer science emphasizing problem solving, algorithm development, implementation, and debugging/testing using an object-oriented programming language. Pre: Recommended: computer experience.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Information and Computer Sciences (ICS) Office of Student Success

subject: ICS
title: Digital Tools for the Information World (4)
desc: Fundamental information technology concepts and computing terminology, productivity software for problem solving, computer technology trends and impact on individuals and society. Emphasizes the utilization of operating systems and the production of professional documents, spreadsheets, etc.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Information and Computer Sciences (ICS) Office of Student Success

subject: HWST
title: Hawai‘i: Center of the Pacific (3)
desc: An introduction to the unique aspects of the native point of view in Hawai‘i and in the larger Pacific with regards to origins, language, religion, land, art, history, and modern issues.
metadata: DH Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ERTH
title: Dynamic Earth (3)
desc: The natural physical environment; the landscape; rocks and minerals, rivers and oceans; volcanism, earthquakes, and other processes inside the Earth; effects of human use of the Earth and its resources. Field trip.
metadata: DP Earth Sciences (ERTH) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ES
title: Introduction to Ethnic Studies (3)
desc:
Concepts and theories analyzing ethnic group experiences in relation to colonization, immigration, racism, and social class. Emphasis on cultural perspectives and values 
rooted in the experiences of peoples indigenous to Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ENG
title: Composition I (3)
desc: Introduction to the rhetorical, conceptual and stylistic demands of writing at the university level; instruction in composing processes, search strategies, and writing from sources. Students may not earn credit for both ENG 100 and 190. Pre: placement.
metadata: FW English (ENG) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ECON
title: Principles of Macroeconomics (3)
desc: An introduction to macroeconomics–the study of the overall economy. Topics include the determination of national income, causes and effects of inflation, unemployment, and income inequality; causes and consequences of international differences in economic growth; sources of business cycle expansions and contractions; role of government policy in stabilizing the economy and promoting long-term growth; financial markets and monetary policy; taxes, spending, consequences of budget deficits, determination of trade imbalances, exchange rate fluctuations, and balance of payment crises.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ECON
title: Principles of Microeconomics (3)
desc: Examination of the decision-making process of both households and firms. Analysis of the functioning of a competitive market system, using supply and demand models and the role of government in cases where the market system fails. Additional topics include the effects of international rate on the welfare of a nation and the effects of different competitive market structures on society.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: COMG
title: Principles of Effective Public Speaking (3)
desc: Combined lecture/laboratory providing extensive practice in preparing and presenting effective public speeches with special emphasis on organization, outlining, audience analysis, analytical reasoning, and delivery skills.
metadata: Communicology (COMG) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: COMG
title: Personal and Public Speech (3)
desc: Develops communication skills necessary to function effectively in today’s society. Students will enhance their communication skills in one-on-one situations, public speaking, and small group situations. Ideal for new majors and non-majors.
metadata: DA Communicology (COMG) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: BOT
title: Plants, People, and Culture (3)
desc: Ethnobotany. Interactions between plants and people: use in religious, medical, and shamanic traditions; roles in cultural formation, destruction, and revolution; plant domestication and food systems; roles in human migration; cultural components of plant conservation. (Fall only)
metadata: FGC Botany (BOT) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BOT
title: General Botany (3)
desc: Growth, functions, and evolution of plants; their relations to the environment and particularly to humans and human activities.
metadata: DB Botany (BOT) College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ASTR
title: Survey of Astronomy (3)
desc: Introduction to the astronomical universe: sky and celestial objects, planetary motion, planets and the Solar System, Sun and stars, the Milky Way and galaxies, cosmology and the universe.
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ART
title: Survey of Global Art II (3)
desc: Art produced in Asia, Africa, Native America, Europe, and the Pacific Islands, from the 15th century to the present. Religious and philosophical ideas expressed in architecture, painting, prints, sculpture, applied art, body art, and textiles. (Spring only)
metadata: FGB Art & Art History (ART) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ART
title: Survey of Global Art I (3)
desc: Art produced in Asia, Africa, Native America, Europe, and the Pacific Islands, from prehistory to the 15th century. Religious and philosophical ideas expressed in architecture, painting, prints, sculpture, applied art, body art, and textiles. (Fall only)
metadata: FGA Art & Art History (ART) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ART
title: Introduction to the Visual Arts (3)
desc: Nature of the world’s visual arts and their influences on personal expression. Lectures, demonstrations, and studio practice. (Not for art majors or minors)
metadata: DA Art & Art History (ART) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: AMST
title: Introduction to Indigenous Studies (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary survey that examines the histories, politics, popular representations, self-representations, and contemporary issues of the indigenous peoples of the U.S. and its territories, including Native Americans, Alaska Natives, Kanaka Maoli, Chamorro, and Samoans.
metadata: DH American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: WGSS
title: 20th-Century Chinese Women Writers (3)
desc: A survey and critical examination of contemporary Chinese women writers from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Traces a genealogy of women’s writing from the early 1920s up until now through novels, poetry, drama, and film. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 364 and EALL 364)
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: 20th-Century Literature by Women (3)
desc: Twentieth-century women writers and their works; novels, short stories, poems, autobiographies. Interrelations of gender and literature. Pre: (one of 151, 175, 176), and 245; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: South Asian Migrants: Culture and Politics (3)
desc: Historical and contemporary experiences of South Asian migrants in North America, Pacific, Caribbean, and/or African diasporas; causes and patterns of migration, inter-ethnic relations policies; role of race, gender, culture in community, identity formation. A-F only. Pre one ES or WS course in the 100, 200 or 300 level; or consent. (Once a year (Cross-listed as ES 339)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Social Policy (3)
desc: Social and economic policies affecting women in families, education, social services, government, health care, the economy; public policy implementation and development; policy impact on women. Pre: 151 or any 200- or 300-level course, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course; or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 318)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Sex and Gender (3)
desc: Cross-cultural theories and perceptions of sexual difference; linkage between biology and cultural constructions of gender; relationship of gender ideology to women’s status. Pre: ANTH 152 (or concurrent) or ANTH 301 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as ANTH 315)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: U.S. Women’s History (3)
desc: History of U.S. women and gender relations. Topics include women’s work in and outside the household, women’s involvement in social movements, changing norms about gender and sexuality, and shared and divergent experiences among women. (Cross-listed as AMST 316 and HIST 361)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Indigenous Women’s Health (3)
desc: Examines issues of indigenous women’s health pre and post colonial in Hawai‘i, Asia, and the Pacific regions. A-F only. Pre: one of 151, 202, 305; or HWST 107, HWST 270 or HWST 285; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Health (3)
desc: Explores current issues in the conceptualization and delivery of health care for women. Pre: 151 or 202, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or POLS 110; or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 305)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women, War, and the Military (3)
desc: The military as it includes and excludes women as soldiers, nurses, wives, prostitutes, and victims. Women and war economics; feminism, war, and peace. Pre: one of 151, 362, 375 or SOC 362; or consent
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: AMST
title: America and the World (3)
desc: Examines America’s role in world history and the influence of world affairs on U.S. culture and society. Focuses on U.S. interdependence with African, European, Native American, Asian, and Polynesian civilizations, from 1492 to present.
metadata: FGB American Studies (AMST) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: HON
title: Senior Honors Project (3)
desc: Original research, creative work, performance or other form of scholarly project appropriate to a major and supervised by a faculty member. Limited to candidates for Honors degree. Repeatable one time for each major. A-F only.
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: Honors Thesis Proposal (3)
desc: Library research skills; scholarship of research and creative work; methodological and ethical issues; development of individual proposal or prospectus for Senior Honors Project. Limited to candidates for the Honors degree. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only.
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: Honors Workshop (0)
desc: Supplemental workshop for students beginning independent work on their senior honors thesis. HON students only. Junior or senior standing only. CR/NC only.
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: Honors Colloquium (3)
desc: Weekly meetings for discussion of enduring issues and problems of an interdisciplinary nature. Limited to candidates for Honors degree. CR/NC only.
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: Junior Seminar (3)
desc: Project-based experiential learning involving community-based research or creative work. Focus on project design, practical skills, and teamwork. Significant portion is dedicated to writing instruction. Multi-disciplinary topics vary each semester. Honors Program students only. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: WGSS
title: Sexual Identity in Literature (3)
desc: Selected themes in major works of various types, cultures, periods. Requires a minimum of 3,000 words of writing. Pre: ENG 100, 100A, or ESL 100.
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women Writers of World Literature (3)
desc: Major women writers of world literature examined in context of female literary tradition. Pre: ENG 100, 100A, or ESL 100; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Women Philosophers (3)
desc: Introduces students to the ideas of women philosophers. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: any course 100 or above in PHIL or WS, or consent. (Alt. years) (Crosslisted as PHIL 218)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Psychology of Gender (3)
desc: Survey of topics in psychology relevant to women’s lives: socialization of gender, mental health, violence against women, achievement motivation, lifespan issues, domestic violence. A-F only. Pre: 151 or PSY 100. (Cross-listed as PSY 202)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Culture, Gender, and Appearance (3)
desc: Social construction of gender within culture and its visual expression through appearance. Analysis of role, identity, conformity, and deviance in human appearance. Repeatable one time. Open to nonmajors. (Cross-listed as FDM 200)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: History of Gender, Sex and Sexuality in Global Perspective, 1500 CE to the Present (3)
desc: Explores how gender, sex, and sexuality become key elements in human society from 1500 CE to present. Examines world cultures from multiple perspectives, stressing issues and forces of continuing influence. A-F only.
metadata: FGB College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: History of Gender, Sex, and Sexuality in Global Perspectives to 1500 CE (3)
desc: Explores how gender, sex, and sexuality become key elements in human society from prehistory to 1500 CE. Examines ancient world civilizations from multiple perspectives stressing issues and forces still influential today. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: FGA College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Introduction to Women’s Studies (3)
desc: Introduction to feminist interdisciplinary analysis from global and critical perspectives; relationships between women and men from Asia-Pacific, Hawaiian, and other cultures. Focus on gender, race, class, sexual dynamics, and women’s negotiations with institutional dynamics. Honors students only. A-F only. Pre: departmental approval.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Introduction to Women’s Studies (3)
desc: Introduction to feminist interdisciplinary analysis from global and critical perspectives; relationships between women and men from Asia-Pacific, Hawaiian, and other cultures, with a focus on gender, race, class, and sexual dynamics; exploration of women’s negotiations with institutional dynamics.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: WGSS
title: Introduction to the World’s Goddesses (3)
desc: Cross-cultural analysis of the religious narratives, beliefs, practices, iconography, and sacred sites related to female deities in the Americas, Polynesia, Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Europe from prehistory to 1500 C.E. (Cross-listed as REL 149)
metadata: FGA College of Social Sciences Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS)

subject: HON
title: Peer Mentoring (3)
desc: Students develop understanding of dynamics of leadership skills within the contexts of paired to large groups. Significant portion is dedicated to writing and oral communication instruction. Honors Program students only. Pre-semester training sessions, on-going training and supervision. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 101 or departmental approval.
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: From Ideas to Page: Learn The Publication Process (3)
desc: Learn the publication process through a “hands on” experiential learning, emphasizing diverse knowledge systems, writing, and ethics. Learn how to solicit contributions, review, and edit articles as part of the Horizons Undergraduate Journal publication cycle. Repeatable one time. Honors students only. Pre: consent of Honors director and instructor. (Spring only)
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: Experiential Learning and Scholarly Engagement (3)
desc: Students develop an understanding of theory and practice of experiential learning through direct engagement and focused scholarly reflection while assimilating and synthesizing new knowledge and developing critical thinking skills. Repeatable two times. Honors Program approval only. A-F only.
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: Off Campus Study Project (V)
desc:
Honors students participating in off campus study (via Study Abroad Center, MIX, or NSE) enhance their experience through a project at the host site, designed with and 
approved with consultation with Honors advisor. Repeatable one time, up to three credits. Honors students only. Pre: consent of Honors director and Study Abroad director.
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: Civic Engagement and Social Justice (3)
desc:
Seminar on history, theory, and practice of civic engagement in the U.S. and abroad. Involves comparative study of social justice movements, historically and today. Focus on role of university 
students in social justice movements. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 101 or 291, or departmental approval. DS
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: Public Policy-Making (3)
desc: Students develop understanding of theory, practice, and ethical issues of public policy-making. Combines lecture/discussion and fieldtrips. Students develop policy analysis and strategic plans that identify issues, interests, and methods of influence. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 101 or 291(Alpha), or departmental approval. (Cross-listed as POLS 386)
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: (Alpha) Sophomore Seminar (3)
desc: Special inquiry-based study of multi-disciplinary topics in particular historical, cultural, geographical, environmental, or other contexts. Emphasis on primary sources and/or fieldwork and extensive instruction in writing. (B) biological science; (H) humanities; (P) physical science; (R) arts; (S) social science; (T) literature. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Cross-listed as IS 291) DB for (B); DH for (H); DP for (P); DA for (R); DS for (S); DL for (T)
metadata: DA DB DH DL DP DS Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HON
title: Introduction to Research and Creative Work at Mānoa (3)
desc: Combines lectures by instructors and faculty guests with workshops and hands-on experience in small group projects, including bibliographic searches, laboratory science, social surveys and interviews. A significant portion is dedicated to writing instruction. Honors Program students only. A-F only.
metadata: Honors (HON) Office of Academic Excellence

subject: HIST
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Teaching History (1)
desc: HIST 100-level faculty supervisors mentor their Teaching Assistants who teach the discussion labs. Course addresses issues of teaching strategy, grading and historical content. Enrollment limited to current Teaching Assistants in the World History Program. Repeatable seven times. Pre: History graduate Teaching Assistants assigned to 151-152.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Chinese Historical Literature (3)
desc: Reading and use of numerous genres of Chinese historical literature and documents. Chinese bibliography. Knowledge of Chinese required. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Institutional History of Korea (3)
desc: Major political, economic, and social institutions. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Individual research topics. (1) American; (2) Pacific; (3) Japanese; (4) European; (5) English; (6) Chinese; (7) Russian; (8) Hawaiian; (9) South Asian; (10) Southeast Asian; (11) Korean. Restricted to plan A (thesis) students. Maximum 2 credit hours. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Hawaiian Historical Research: Documents and Methods (3)
desc: Research and writings emphasizing the interpretation of Hawaiian and English language primary sources. Development of source materials, approaches, and methods in Hawaiian history. A-F only. Graduate standing only. Pre: HAW 301 with a B or better, or instructor consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar in History of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Reading seminar with short papers required. Covers Kingdom of Hawai‘i and 20th-century Hawai‘i in alternate years. Repeatable one time. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Topics in Histories of Oceania (3)
desc: Reading and research on major issues, topics, and themes in the history of Oceania. Repeatable three times. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Cross-listed as PACS 675)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Topics on War in History (3)
desc: Research seminars on topics on war in history. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Korean History (3)
desc: Reading major interpretive works, and research in selected topics. (B) reading; (C) research. Repeatable one time per alpha. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Japanese History (3)
desc: Problems, principal sources of bibliographic information. (B) traditional period to c.1600; (C) early modern 1600–1868; (D) 1868 to present; (E) 20th-century diplomatic. Repeatable one time per alpha.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar in South Asian History (3)
desc: Graduate-level reading and research seminar on topics in Indian and South Asian history. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar: Islam and Islamic Civilization (3)
desc: Readings on the rise, spread, and development of Islamic cultures and civilizations throughout the world down to modern times. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 354.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Chinese History (3)
desc: Problems and readings in political, social, and cultural history. (B) early; (C) middle; (D) modern. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar: Vietnamese History (3)
desc: Reading and research seminar on Vietnamese history. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The Seas in Southeast Asian History (3)
desc: Seminar on the seas in Southeast Asian history. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar in Modern Southeast Asian History (3)
desc: Graduate level reading seminar in modern Southeast Asian history. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Historiography of Southeast Asia (3)
desc: Examination of contested boundaries of Southeast Asia, the various historiographic traditions, the colonial legacy, and the current issues emerging from a dialogue of historians from the “region” and the outside world. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Topics in Southeast Asia (3)
desc: Reading and research seminar on themes about the past and present of Southeast Asia in a comparative framework. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar: Comparative Asia (3)
desc: This reading seminar in the comparative history of modern Asia will introduce graduate students to themes, particularly in social, cultural, and intellectual history, which lend themselves to comparison across the region. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Advanced Topics in American History (3)
desc: Seminar in advanced research and readings: (B) social and intellectual; (C) foreign relations; (F) the West; (K) business, labor, and technology. Repeatable one time for (B), (C) and (K). Pre: graduate standing and consent. ((B) Cross-listed as AMST 646); ((F) Cross-listed as AMST 614); ((K) Cross-listed as AMST 647)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Research in American History (3)
desc: (B) early America; (C) the Republic to 1877; (D) industrial America; (E) recent America; (F) foreign relations. Repeatable one time. Pre: appropriate 400 level course or consent
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Advanced Readings in American History (3)
desc: Interpretations and literature of important themes and problems. (B) early America; (C) the Republic to 1877; (D) industrial America; (E) recent America. Repeatable one time per alpha. Pre: appropriate 400-level U.S. history course or consent for (D) and (E); graduate standing or consent for (B) and (C). (Alt. years for (B)) ((B) Cross-listed as AMST 610)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Advanced Readings in Russian History (3)
desc: (B) early Russia; (C) modern. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Atrocity Crimes: Law and History (3)
desc: Seminar on history of mass atrocity and international justice in the modern world. Topics include postWWII Allied war crimes prosecution, post-cold war ad hoc international criminal tribunals, and contemporary international law and national legal systems. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Topics in Historical Methods and Theory (3)
desc: Seminar covering one specific approach to historical methods or theory. The goal is a deep engagement with a particular historical approach via research and reading not bounded by region, time, or specialty. Repeatable one time. Graduate standing only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Topics in European Colonialism (3)
desc: Selected topics for comparative advanced reading and research. (D) early modern; (E) modern. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Research in European History (3)
desc: Selected topics for advanced research. (B) ancient; (C) medieval; (D) early modern; (E) modern; (G) intellectual. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Introduction to Cultural Studies (3)
desc: Graduate seminar designed to introduce history students to the multidisciplinary theories that are appropriate to cultural studies. A-F only. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Ethnographic History (3)
desc: Critical inquiry into historical representations of the “other” and ways in which modern historians have used culture and other anthropological concepts to write and think about the past.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Advanced Readings in European History (3)
desc: Selected topics for advanced reading; (B) ancient; (C) medieval; (D) early modern; (E) modern; (G) intellectual. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years: spring for (D)); (Alt. years: fall for (E))
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Topics in World History (3)
desc: Selected themes— feudalism, economic and industrial development, etc.— important in global history. Topics pre-announced. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar in World History (3)
desc: Analysis, research, and discussion of themes and issues in study of history of humankind. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar on Water in History (3)
desc: Explores how various forms of salt, fresh, and brackish water have played transformative roles in the evolution of human communities throughout history. (Cross-listed as SUST 610)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Advanced Topics in Environmental History (3)
desc: Introduction to leading themes, methodologies, and topics in world environmental history. Drawing on new and influential scholarship, readings explore the diverse forces that shape humans’ adaptation to and impact on the natural world. Repeatable one time. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar in Digital History (3)
desc: Examines the various ways that the production, presentation, and learning of history through digital media is changing the way people access and process information about the past. Graduate standing only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Seminar in Historiography (3)
desc: History of history and historians; philosophies of history.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Individual projects in various fields. History majors with consent. Maximum 5 credit hours. (1) American; (2) Pacific; (3) Japanese; (4) European; (5) English; (6) Chinese; (7) Russian; (8) Hawaiian; (9) South Asian; (10) Southeast Asian; (11) Korean.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Senior Tutorial in History (3)
desc: Analysis of sources and evaluation of methods of historical writing. Students undertake a major research and writing project in field of special interest. Capstone course requires a 20-25 page minimum final research paper. A-F only. Pre: 396(B or C).
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) History Colloquium (3)
desc: Extensive or intensive treatment of special problems. (B) Philippines and Indonesia; (C) U.S. foreign relations; (D) history in Oceania; (E) Chinese traditional government. Recommended for honors students. Pre: 372 (or concurrent) or consent for (C); consent for (B) and (E).
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Women and Revolution (3)
desc: Conditions under which women’s activism and participation in protest and revolutionary movements developed in the 19th- and 20th-centuries. Cross-cultural comparisons (Cross-listed as ASAN 492 and WGSS 492)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: World Maritime History (3)
desc: Survey of world maritime history from earliest times to the present, with emphasis on the evolution of nautical technology, motives from maritime enterprises, and the impact of cross-cultural encounters between oceanic peoples. (Cross-listed as AMST 489)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of 20th-Century Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Formation of an American Hawai‘i with its unique local culture from 1898 to the present. Pre: upper division standing.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The Hawaiian Kingdom 1819–1893 (3)
desc: Transformation of Hawai‘i into a state influenced by American and European ideas and institutions and Asian peoples, with an emphasis on instruction on writing.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: United States in the Pacific (3)
desc: Growth of economic and political interests and policies.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Histories of Oceania II (3)
desc:
Examines Oceania’s histories of protest during the colonial and post-colonial eras as responses to empire expansion. 
Explores ethical issues concerning these movements, emphasizing Hawai‘i experiences and their intersection with those across Oceania.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Histories of Oceania I (3)
desc:
Explores the diverse, interconnected histories of Oceania from 
ancestral origins through the early colonial period. Topics include voyaging, orality, land, gender, power, exchange, cross-cultural encounter, disease, colonization, resistance, and historiography. Additional focus on oral communication. DH
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: American Environmental History (3)
desc: Survey history of the complex relations between American societies and diverse U.S. ecosystems, from European contact and colonization to the present. (Cross-listed as AMST 425 and SUST 481)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Latin America Since Independence (3)
desc: Political, economic, and social development since 1825; case studies from Brazil, Mexico, and Cuba.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Colonial Latin America (3)
desc: PreColumbian civilizations: Spanish and Portuguese colonization; political, economic, social, and religious evolution to 1810; independence. (Cross-listed as LAIS 468)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of American Workers (3)
desc: Conditions of labor in major phases of American development; response of labor and community to changing work environment. Capitalism, unionism, race, gender, law, etc. Emphasis on 20th century. (Cross-listed as AMST 431)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Race and Racism in America (3)
desc: Racial ideas and ideologies, and their effects throughout American history. (Cross-listed as AMST 440)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Constitutional History of the U.S. (3)
desc: Origins, development of Constitution, Colonial to modern times.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The American West (3)
desc: Lecture/ discussion surveying the conquest, colonization, and consolidation of North American frontiers and the post-frontier development of the American West.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Slavery and Freedom (3)
desc: Examines the history of slavery, race, and abolition in the Americas from a comparative, global perspective, and traces the legacy of slavery in the post-emancipation societies of the New World. (Cross-listed as AMST 432)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Music, Industry, and Society (3)
desc: History of U.S. music and recording industry. How industry relates to economy as a whole, and how it reflects broad patterns and trends in American culture and society. (Cross-listed as MUS 440)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The Cold War (3)
desc: Cold War as a global struggle. Topics will include U.S.-Soviet economic and political rivalry, Capitalism vs. Communism as practical policy and ideology, and the force of Third World anti-colonial nationalism.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Viva Las Vegas! (3)
desc: Upper-division lecture on the historical and cultural significance of Las Vegas in twentieth-century America. Open to non-majors.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: American Television History (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion examining the impact of television on American society, culture and politics. Analyzed in depth are family sitcoms, presidential politics, Vietnam and the presentation of gender and ethnicity. Open to non-majors.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The U.S.: 1948 to the Present (3)
desc: The atomic age and the Cold War, the age of anxiety, the 1960s, the Vietnam War, the Reagan-Bush era, and beyond.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The United States 1920–1948 (3)
desc: The Roaring Twenties, the Depression, New Deal, coming of World War II, America during the war, origins of the Cold War.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Transformation of America 1877–1920 (3)
desc: Selected themes that explain major changes in American life during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including the westward movement, consolidation of capitalism, world power diplomacy, popular culture, progressivism, and World War I.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: American Civil War Era 1841–1877 (3)
desc: The crisis of the Union: antebellum society and culture, slavery, reform, sectionalism, the Civil War and Reconstruction.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The Early American Republic (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion on the Constitution, the growth of partisan politics, the market revolution, religious revivalism, abolitionism and the expansion of slavery in the U.S. during the age of Jefferson and Jackson.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Early America (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion on Native Americans, Africans, and Europeans in North America from contact to independence. Social, cultural, and economic themes and intersections of race, class, and gender explored.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Native American History (3)
desc: Lecture/ discussion on the history of North American Indians from the seventeenth century to the present. Open to non-majors.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: African American History (3)
desc: Lecture/ discussion on the origins of racial slavery, slave and free black culture, slave resistance and antislavery, post-emancipation black life, the rise of Jim Crow, the Harlem Renaissance, and the Civil Rights Movement.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The American Revolution (3)
desc: Lecture/ discussion on the origins, development, and consequences of the American Revolution, explored within the context of the broader revolutionary Atlantic world.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Russia in Asia and the Pacific (3)
desc: Russian/Soviet Siberia and Central Asia; Russian American Company and the Pacific; evolving relations with Asian and Pacific powers.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Modern Russia (3)
desc: Creation of the Soviet Union, Stalinization, the Cold War, the collapse of the empire, the post-Soviet era.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Colonial Medicine (3)
desc: Evolution of Western medical traditions; challenges created by European expansion and colonial interactions; development of modern racial and gender theories. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) History and Film (3)
desc: Explores the many relationships between history and film including how film has reflected and shaped society in the past and our relationship to the past. (B) United States; (C) Europe: emphasis on writing as historians and film critics; (D) Asia/Pacific; (E) world/ comparative: significant attention paid to developing writing skills that involve critically comparing history-related cinematic representations across regions and cultures. Repeatable one time for different alphas. (Once a year for (D))(C Cross-listed as CINE 452C); (E Cross-listed as CINE 452E)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) History and Literature (3)
desc: Explores the many relationships between history and literature, including how literature has reflected and shaped society in the past and our relationship to the past; (B) United States; (C) Europe; (D) Asia/ Pacific; (E) World/Comparative; (F) Provisional topics. Repeatable one time for different alphas, not repeatable for (C).
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Topics in African History (3)
desc: Selected themes important in African history, including, for example, the politics, economics, societies, and cultures of pre-colonial, colonial, or modern Africa. Topics to be pre-announced. Repeatable one time. (Once a year)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Imperial Spain and Portugal (3)
desc: The influence of Spain and Portugal on people and cultures in Europe, Africa, America, and Asia; Portugal’s captivity and the defeat of the Spanish Armada.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Europe, 1914-1945: War, Peace, and Revolution (3)
desc: Explores war and peace in Europe, from the start of the Great War through the formal end of World War II. Topics include key battles, civilians, peace movements, treaties, the Shoah, Fascism, and Soviet Revolution.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: French Revolution and Napoleon (3)
desc: Causes, course, and conduct of the Revolutionary and Napoleonic periods, their impact upon Europe; emphasis on the conflict of ideologies inherent in the Revolutionary process.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The History of the Holocaust (3)
desc: The origins and progression of the Holocaust, the almost complete destruction of European Jews, and other Nazi genocidal policies. Open to non-majors.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)
