subject: HIST
title: Nazi Germany (3)
desc: Origins, establishment, and impact of Hitler’s Third Reich. Recommended: 344. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: War and Violence in Early Modern Europe (3)
desc: History of the intellectual, social, and cultural causes and consequences of violence, including military conflicts.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Expansion of Europe (3)
desc: Historical processes in modern European colonization from 16th to 20th century; impact on non-Europeans in Asia and Africa. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: 20th-Century Europe (3)
desc: Contemporary problems and their historical background.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The Darwinian Revolution (3)
desc: Social and intellectual origins of evolutionary thought and its continuing impact; emphasis on Darwin and the Victorian scientific community.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: World Environmental History, 1500 to Present (3)
desc: Explores interactions between humans and the natural world from early modern era to the present. Topics include invader species and biotic exchange; environmental politics; and the ecological impact of industrialization, urbanization, science, technology, war, etc.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Christianity to 1500 (3)
desc: Historical analysis of the main traditions of Christianity and elements of diversity within Europe and in relation to other parts of the world. Focus on the interpretation of primary sources and discussion of cultural issues. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: ZOOL
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Foundations of Evolution and Ecology II (4)
desc: Graduate level introduction to evolution and ecology emphasizing foundational literature, modern models and inference, and major questions in evolution and ecology. This is the second semester continuation of 780. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Foundations of Evolution and Ecology I (4)
desc: Graduate level introduction to evolution and ecology emphasizing foundational literature, modern models and inference, and major questions in evolution and ecology. Topics include population ecology, community ecology, the genetics of populations, systematics, and speciation. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Conservation Biology (V)
desc: Advanced topics in conservation and environmental biology. Repeatable three times, up to twelve credits. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as BOT 750)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Ecology (V)
desc: Advanced topics in ecology; discussion of literature and in depth survey of specific areas. Repeatable three times up to nine credits. Graduate students only. Pre: instructor consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Systematics and Evolution (V)
desc: Selected problems of current or historic interest. Repeatable three times, up to nine credits. Pre: consent
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Animal Physiology (V)
desc: Selected problems in environmental physiology, electro-physiology, or neurophysiology. Basic concepts and measurements of function at the organismic or cellular level. Repeatable three times, up to nine credits.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Fish and Fisheries Biology (V)
desc: Lecture-discussion of various aspects. Repeatable up to nine credits. ZOOL majors only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Invertebrate Zoology (V)
desc: Comparative morphology, development, taxonomy, phylogeny. Repeatable three times, up to nine credits.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Animal Behavior (V)
desc: Lecturediscussion of selected topics. Repeatable three times, up to nine credits. ZOOL majors only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Nerve/Muscle Physiology (V)
desc: Advanced treatment of selected topics under current active investigation. Repeatable unlimited times. ZOOL majors only. Pre: a graduate course in physiology, neurology, or related subjects and consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Biometry (V)
desc: Selected advanced topics in experimental design or data analysis for biologists. Repeatable unlimited times. ZOOL majors only. Pre: 631 and 632, or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Directed research and reading in various fields of zoology. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Zoology (1)
desc: Reports on research or reviews of literature. Graduate students required to take this or one topics course (710–719) per year. (B) general zoology; (C) zoology literature; (D) animal behavior; (E) ecology; (F) animal physiology; (G) development biology; (H) marine biology; (I) systematics and evolution. Each alpha is repeatable five times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Conservation Biology (3)
desc: Theories and concepts of ecology, evolution and genetics for conservation of biological diversity. Topics will include restoration ecology, management planning, laws and policies, biological invasions. (Cross-listed as BOT 690 and NREM 690)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Scientific Teaching Tools to Promote Active Learning (2)
desc: Graduate level course to train students in the pedagogical tools to enhance active learning in STEM classes. Includes discussions of the primary literature, demonstrations and practice using scientific teaching techniques. BOT or ZOOL or MBIO majors only. Graduate students only. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as BOT 670)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Population Biology (3)
desc: Theory and applications of population biology; behavior of population models, as revealed by analytical methods and computer simulation; application to population problems such as endangered species; discussion of classical and current literature in population biology. Pre: one of the following: 620, 623, BOT 456, NREM 680, PEPS 671; or consent. (Cross-listed as BOT 652)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Cellular Neurophysiology (3)
desc: Biophysical and membrane mechanisms of conduction, synaptic transmission, and other electrical responses of nerve cells. Pre: consent. (Alt years: spring)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Advanced Biometry (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Discussion) Multivariate statistical methods: multiple regression and correlation; multiway anova; general linear models; repeated measures and multivariate anova; loglinear analysis and logistic regression. Pre: 631 or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Introduction to Statistical Modeling in Biology (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Discussion) Statisticalmethods for biological research. Covers: probability; likelihood-based inference; hypothesis testing; linear and generalized linear models; common statistical tests; statistical programming. Pre: MATH 215 or 216 or 241 or 251A or NREM 203 (or equivalent), or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Evolution in Marine Systems (3)
desc: Fundamental elements of modern evolutionary theory and research, with a strong focus on marine organisms and ecosystems. A-F only. Pre: instructor approval. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Quantitative Field Ecology (3)
desc: (1 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab, 1 Discussion) Formal quantitative approach in identifying, designing, performing, analyzing, and interpreting ecological field problems. A-F only. Pre: 439, 439L, and 631; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Marine Ecology (3)
desc: Principles of ecology of marine biota and environment. Pre: graduate standing in zoology, oceanography, or botany; or consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Seminar on Science Teaching (2)
desc: Effective teaching methods, organization of courses, lectures, laboratory exercises; development and evaluation of examinations; computers and audiovisual aids. Open to graduate students in various science disciplines. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as NSCI 619)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Topics in Development and Reproductive Biology (V)
desc: Discussion and survey of literature on specific topics; some field and lab work may be required. Repeatable three times.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Fish Behavior and Sensory Biology Laboratory (1)
desc: Laboratory study of fish sensory systems and behavior. A-F only. Pre: 430, 606, BIOL 306, BIOL 465; or consent. Co-requisite: 608. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Fish Behavior and Sensory Biology (2)
desc: Lectures, readings and presentations on sensory systems and behavior of fishes. A-F only. Pre: 430, 606, BIOL 306, BIOL 465; or consent. Co-requisite: 608L. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Genetics of Behavior and Evolution (1)
desc: Introduction to concepts and techniques in the genetics of behavior. Techniques include next gen sequencing, GWAS, and more. Students may use real data to analyze associations between genotype and phenotype. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Principles of Animal Behavior Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Group or individual research projects depending on interest of students. Pre: 606 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Animal Behavior (3)
desc: Lectures and critical discussions on the mechanisms of animal behavior, social and interspecific behaviors, behavioral ecology, and evolutionary theory. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Zoology (1)
desc: Reports on research, reviews of literature, or research experience. Required of students majoring in zoology or entomology. (B) general zoology; (D) animal behavior; (E) ecology; (F) physiology; (G) developmental biology; (H) marine biology. Repeatable 2 times per alpha, credits earned for 3 credits only. Pre: 306 or equivalent or consent for (D).
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Biogeography (3)
desc: Distribution of plants and animals and processes that cause, maintain, and modify them. Approach is synthetic and dynamic. Pre: BIOL 172.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: BIOL
title: Evolutionary Biology (3)
desc: Process of evolution: genetic basis, natural selection, population genetics, speciation, the fossil record. Pre: 171 and 172. Recommended: a BIOL or ZOOL course at 300 or 400 level.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ZOOL
title: Biology of the Invertebrates Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Pre: BIOL 172 and CHEM 161, or consent. Co-requisite: 475.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: BIOL
title: Biology of the Invertebrates (3)
desc: Body plans, development, cellular construction, physiological integration, natural history, and ecology of invertebrate animals. Emphasis on marine species, especially local ones. Pre: 172 and CHEM 161, or consent. Corequisite: 485L.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Fish Diversity Laboratory (1)
desc: (2 2-hr Lab) Overview of the major orders and families of fishes of the world; introduction to local Hawaiian fishes; coverage of basic fish anatomy; introduction to field and laboratory techniques in fish research. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 171, 172, and 465 (or concurrent). (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Fish Diversity (3)
desc: Survey of fish biodiversity focusing on major lineages, their phylogenetic relationships, and their geographic distribution in light of evolutionary history. Taught spring semester in alternate years. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 171 and 172. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ZOOL
title: Avian Biology (3)
desc: Broad coverage of the morphology, physiology, ecology, behavior, and evolution of birds, emphasizing the relation of birds to general theory in biology. Pre: BIOL 265.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: HIST
title: Medieval Cultures (3)
desc: Topical study of cultural and cross-cultural issues in the medieval period (circa 300-1500). Class discussion and written work emphasize analysis of primary source documents using cultural and world history theories. Regional focus and readings vary by semester. Repeatable one time.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Crisis and Conflict in the Middle East (3)
desc: In depth study and analysis of major crises and conflicts in the Middle East since World War II: the Arab–Israeli Wars, revolutions in the Arab countries, the Turkish experiment with secularism, the Iranian/ Islamic revolution, Afghanistan, the Gulf War. Recommended: 354 or 355.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Persia, Greece, and Rome in the Classical Age (3)
desc: Historical examination of the interaction between the Achaemenid and Parthian empires of Persia and the classical societies of the Mediterranean, such as the Greek city-states, Macedonia, the Hellenistic, and Roman Empires. Recommended: 151. (Cross-listed as CLAS 430)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: War Crimes Trials in History (3)
desc: Explores war crimes trials in history since the end of WWII to the present. Involves extensive source analysis, discussion, research, and writing. Repeatable one time.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Japanese Cuisine and Foodways (3)
desc: Explores the history of Japanese cuisine and investigates the cultural, economic, and geopolitical aspects of food-ways in Japanese domestic and international identity.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Women in East Asian History (3)
desc: Survey of the changing political, social, economic, and cultural positions of women in China, Japan, and Korea from ancient times to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Twentieth Century Japan (3)
desc: Problems of Japan’s political, economic, and social development since institutional consolidation of Meiji state (c.1890).
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Okinawa (3)
desc: Survey of social, cultural, economic, and political history from earliest times to present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Tokugawa Japan (3)
desc: Japanese history and culture, 1600–1867. Recommended: 321.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: China in World History (3)
desc: Interpretative survey of China’s changing position, significance, and function in the evolution of world history as a way to provide a better understanding of its past and present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: People’s Republic of China (3)
desc: Salient developments from 1949 to the present. Social revolution and modernization, critically relevant foreign relations. Recommended: 312 or 419.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The Search for Modern China (3)
desc: Origins, development, and meaning of modern revolution in China, 19th century to People’s Republic. Recommended: 311 and 312.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: China’s Foreign Relations (3)
desc: Systematic review from traditional times, with emphasis on modern and contemporary history, analyses of foreign policy formulation, objectives, and implementation. Recommended: 312.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Chinese Intellectual History (3)
desc: Interpretive survey of Chinese thought from 1600 to the contemporary period, with special emphasis on the themes of cultural collision and change.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Chinese Intellectual History (3)
desc: An interpretive survey of Chinese ideas and values in their cultural, social and political settings from classical age to 1600.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Local History of 20th-Century China (3)
desc: Sociopolitical change and continuity at local and regional levels since 1900, stressing provincial reform, Hsien and sub-Hsien politics, warlordism, Kuomintang tutelage, and the Chinese Communist movement and rule.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Society and Culture in Traditional China (3)
desc: Ch’ing government and Chinese society from local and regional perspectives; modes of control and disorder during the 19th century.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Twentieth-Century China (3)
desc: An examination of the political, intellectual, economic, cultural, and social transformations of China in the twentieth century. This lecture studies critical events in the making of modern China and explores important issues in the modernization of Chinese life in the twentieth century.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Islamic Southeast Asia (3)
desc: History of the coming of Islam to Southeast Asia, the spread of its ideas, and its role in the lives of Muslim communities living in the region. GPA of 2.0 or higher. (Spring only)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Modern Indonesia (3)
desc: Indonesia from 14th century to present. Emphasis on period from late 18th-century Western colonial impact to struggle for independence and problems of nationhood.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Modern Malaysia (3)
desc: History of Malay peninsula and northern Borneo, emphasizing developments since 18th century: trade, commerce, foreign migrations, pluralism, nationalism, and Islam.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Modern Philippines (3)
desc: Survey of major developments from pre-colonial through Spanish and American colonial periods, the revolution, Japanese occupation, and post-war republic. (Cross-listed as ASAN 406)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Vietnam: History and Memory (3)
desc: Survey of Vietnamese history with particular attention to the multiple ways that the Vietnamese past has been remembered and represented by different peoples. Open to non-majors.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of the Indian Ocean World (3)
desc: Explores the transnational history of the Indian Ocean world, especially the region connected by the western monsoon. Topics include travel, trade, religion, colonialism, nationalism, diaspora, and globalization, including actors like slaves, sailors, women, and merchants. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as SUST 401)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Digital History in the Global Village (3)
desc: History of the digital age in global perspective connecting people, media, and technology. Faculty and students will use digital media to introduce innovative approaches to doing history. (Fall only)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: (Alpha) Historical Theories and Methods (3)
desc: Examination of the nature of historical understanding, research, and writing, and of recent trends in historical scholarship; preparation for senior thesis, including significant discipline-specific writing instruction and a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. (B) historiography; (C) education. Pre: any 300- or 400-level HIST course.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Science Since 1700 (3)
desc: Continuation of 394; science, technology, and society since 1700.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Science to 1700 (3)
desc: Evolution of scientific thought and its cultural context. Antiquity to 1700.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: U.S. Military History (3)
desc: Survey of development of American military forces from War of Independence to war in Vietnam.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: War and Peace Since 1850 (3)
desc: Continuation of 391, from 1850 to present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Warfare to 1850 (3)
desc: Classical and guerrilla warfare, revolution, and military systems and institutions.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The Asia-Pacific War (3)
desc: Explores WWII in the Asia-Pacific region, focusing on the intersection of the grand strategy, military operations, and war crimes. Involves source analyses and discussions.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Caribbean History (3)
desc: Survey of the history of the Caribbean region from 1500 to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: American Empire (3)
desc: Examines the interplay between an “American culture of empire” and the rise of the U.S. as a superpower. Topics: imperialism and political culture, social movements and international affairs, race, gender and class relations. (Cross-listed as AMST 365)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of American Business (3)
desc: The evolution of business enterprise from colonial times to the present. Emphasis on entrepreneurship, technological change, labor-management relations, government-business relations, and economic thought. Case studies of industrial development. (Cross-listed as MGT 348)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: American Thought and Culture: 20th Century (3)
desc: Continuation of 373: the 20th century. (Cross-listed as AMST 344)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: American Thought and Culture: To 20th Century (3)
desc: Politics, family, philosophy, technology, etc.; their interrelationship within the total society. Pre-Colonial to end of the 19th century. (Cross-listed as AMST 343)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: U.S. Foreign Relations From 1898 (3)
desc: Survey of U.S. foreign relations from the wars of 1898 to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: U.S. Foreign Relations to 1898 (3)
desc: Survey of U.S. foreign relations from initial encounters between Europeans and Native Americans through the 1890s.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Gender and Sexuality in the Classical World (3)
desc: Critical examination of the construction of gender identity and sexuality in ancient Greece and Rome. Junior standing or higher. (Once a year) (Crosslisted as CLAS 362)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: U.S. Women’s History (3)
desc: History of U.S. women and gender relations. Topics include women’s work in and outside the household, women’s involvement in social movements, changing norms about gender and sexuality, and shared and divergent experiences among women. (Cross-listed as AMST 316 and WGSS 311)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The World of Mekong (3)
desc: Historical survey, from BC period to present, of the peoples of the Mekong region, an area covering southwestern China, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, and southern Vietnam. Open to nonmajors.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Survey of African History (3)
desc: The history of Africa from earliest times to the present: the rise of indigenous civilizations, European and Muslim impact, colonialism and nationalism, and current issues.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The Making of the Modern Middle East (3)
desc: Survey of developments that created the system of nation-states in the Middle East. History of the Ottoman Empire and the Republic of Turkey; Egypt; the Arab world; Israel and Iran. Recommended: 354.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Introduction to Islamic History (3)
desc: Muhammad, the Arab conquests, the Caliphate; fundamentals of Islam; classical Islamic civilization; development of Islam into modern times with emphasis on the Middle Eastern heartland.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: France and Empire (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion exploring the history of France’s relationship with imperialism from the Renaissance to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Iberia in Asia and the Pacific (3)
desc: Comparative exploration of the Iberian empires–Spain and Portugal–and their political, economic, and cultural interactions with indigenous societies in Asia and the Pacific. A-F only.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: British Empire (3)
desc: Origins and expansion of the British empire between the seventeenth and twentieth centuries. Includes imperial policies affecting Britain, Australia, India, Ireland, and Southern Africa. Open to non-majors.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Modern Britain 1688-1945 (3)
desc: Interaction of 17th-, 18th-, and 19th-century intellectual, political, economic, and social changes, which together produced the British Empire and modern Britain.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Tudor-Stuart Britain (3)
desc: Traces major developments in British politics, society, and culture between the late Medieval and Modern Eras.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Modern France (3)
desc: Political, social, economic, cultural, and intellectual developments in France from Revolution and Napoleon to the present. Assignments emphasize engagement with course concepts through oral communication and individual and group presentation.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: France in the Old Regime (3)
desc: Major social, political, and intellectual developments: Renaissance, Reformation, religious wars, Richelieu, Louis XIV, Enlightenment, and Revolution.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Modern Germany (3)
desc: Political, social, economic, and cultural history since 1547. Rise of Austria and Prussia, unification, Bismarckian era, World War I and Weimar Republic, Hitler’s Third Reich, post-World War II.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Reacting to the Past (3)
desc: Exploration of moments of crisis and the clash of ideas in their historical context through the use of simulation games. Junior standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The History of Economic Thought (3)
desc: Introduces major western economic theorists and ideas since around 1700. Considers the history of views on work, poverty, the market and government, and the relationship of those doctrines to society, philosophy, and public policy. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as ECON 342)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Comparative Economic History (3)
desc: Comparative historical study of economic ideas and change since around 1700. Considers the histories of capitalism, poverty, industrialization and labor in Europe, Asia, the U.S., and other regions. (Cross-listed as ECON 341)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Renaissance and Reformation (3)
desc: Political, social, cultural, and intellectual developments in Europe from 1300 to 1600. Emphasis on cultural and intellectual history and its impact on social and political developments; humanism and its influence on thought and reforming movements, Protestant and Catholic Reformations. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: European Intellectual History (3)
desc: Continuation of 337. European thought from French Revolution to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: European Intellectual History (3)
desc: Undergraduate seminar on great debates in Western thought. Discussion of primary source materials; the scientific revolution and Enlightenment.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Medieval Europe 1050–1350 (3)
desc: Main trends in European economy, society, religion, politics, thought, and the arts; interactions with Byzantine and Islamic worlds.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Early Medieval Europe 300–1050 (3)
desc: Formation of European societies in relation to Byzantine and Islamic cultures. Writing exercises develop historical thinking and the analysis of primary sources through workshops with peer and instructor feedback on drafts and revisions.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Ancient Rome: The Empire (3)
desc: Political, social, and cultural history from Augustus to 476 A.D. Emphasis on literary and archaeological materials. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Ancient Rome: The Republic (3)
desc: Political, social, cultural history from the Etruscans to Augustus. Emphasis on discussion of literary and archaeological materials. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Ancient Greece II (3)
desc: Political, social, and cultural history of the Classical and Hellenistic periods.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Ancient Greece I (3)
desc: Political, social, and cultural history of the Minoan, Mycenean, and Archaic periods.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of North Korea (3)
desc: History of North Korea in terms of industrialism, militarism, nationalism, and state power, from 1945 to today. Focus on construction of national sovereign identity and comparison with postcolonial world.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Modern Korea (3)
desc: Continuation of 327. From 1400 to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Premodern Korea (3)
desc: Survey of political, economic, social, and cultural developments from earliest times to 1400. Ethical issues in nationhood, central hegemony, myth-making, warfare, and memory politics are discussed.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: The Samurai of Japan (3)
desc: A social, military, and cultural history of Japan’s samurai (warrior) class.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Way of Tea in Japanese History and Culture (3)
desc: History and culture of Japan as revealed in study and practice of the tea ceremony: Zen, aesthetics, calligraphy, architecture, ceramics, gardens, politics. Includes an emphasis on Oral Communication skills. (Cross-listed as ASAN 323)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Japan (3)
desc: Continuation of 321. Period from 1700.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Japan (3)
desc: Survey of culture, government, economics, and institutions, to 1700.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of China (3)
desc: Continuation of 311. Period since the 17th century.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of China (3)
desc: Chinese civilization to the 17th century.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: East Asian Civilizations (3)
desc: Continuation of 309. Period after 1500.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: East Asian Civilizations (3)
desc: Characteristics of East Asian civilizations as they developed in pre-modern China; variant patterns in Japan and Korea; the modernization process to 1500.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Modern Southeast Asia (3)
desc: Continuation of 305, from 18th century to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Early Modern Southeast Asia (3)
desc:
Traces the development of Southeast Asia from early beginnings 
to the 19th century. Ethical issues and effective writing based on essays and ethical responses will form an important part of the course. DH
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Modern India (3)
desc: Historical survey of India and South Asia from the Mughal Empire to the new millennium, tracing political, social, religious, economic, cultural, and intellectual developments from the 18th century to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of Early India (3)
desc: Historical survey of India and South Asia from Mohenjo-Daro to the Mughal Empire, tracing political, social, religious, economic, cultural, and intellectual developments from ancient times to the 18th century. (Cross-listed as IP 300)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Topics in History (3)
desc: Introduction to methods of historical inquiry; current issues in World, American, European, or Pacific history. Emphasis on teaching writing. Repeatable one time. A-F only
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of the Philippines (3)
desc: Traces developments in Philippine history and society from precolonial to contemporary times and explores ways in which the peoples of the Philippines embraced, resisted or negotiated new modes of thought, behavior and social organization influenced by the Spanish, American, and Japanese regimes as well as the postcolonial global order.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Oceania Survey (3)
desc: Survey of major events, themes, and issues that make up the diverse histories of Oceania, including Hawai‘i, from ancestral origins to the present, with an emphasis on instruction in writing.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: History of the Hawaiian Islands (3)
desc: Survey of state and local history from Polynesian chiefdoms to Hawaiian Kingdom to American territory and state.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Introduction to American History (3)
desc: Interpretive survey from 1865 to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Introduction to American History (3)
desc: Interpretive survey from earliest settlement to 1865. A-F only.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Atlantic History: Colonies to Revolutions (3)
desc: Comparative and historical survey of colonialism and revolutions in the Atlantic World from 1500 to 1830. (Alt. years)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Civilizations of Asia (3)
desc: Continuation of 241. Survey of major civilizations of Asia from 1500 to the present; East Asia, Southeast Asia, South Asia.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Civilizations of Asia (3)
desc: Survey of major civilizations of Asia from earliest times to 1500; East Asia, Southeast Asia, South Asia.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Modern European Civilization 1800- (3)
desc: Continuation of 231. Major political, social, economic, and cultural trends from Napoleon to the present.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: European Civilization 1500-1800 (3)
desc: Political evolution and major economic, social, and cultural development of European states. 1500–1800.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Early European Civilization (3)
desc: Political evolution and major economic, social, and cultural development of European states before 1500, including classical and medieval eras. A-F only. (Alt. years)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: World Cultures in Perspective (3)
desc: Continuation of 161A. Development of civilization from 1500 to the present. Offered as discussion and/ or problems course. Alternative for 151 and 152; students in Honors program only.
metadata: FGB History (HIST) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: HIST
title: World Cultures in Perspective (3)
desc: Development of civilizations from prehistoric origins to 1500. Offered as discussion and/or problems course. Alternative for 151 and 152; students in Honors program only.
metadata: FGA History (HIST) Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: HIST
title: Global Environmental History (3)
desc: Explores the influence of nature–climate, topography, plants, animals, and microorganisms–on human history and the way people, in turn, have influenced the natural world around them. (Cross-listed as SUST 157)
metadata: FGC College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: World History of Human Disease (3)
desc: Examines how disease has affected humans in terms of society, culture, politics, religion, and economics. Explores the impact over a broad range of time periods, from pre-history to the present/future.
metadata: FGC College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: Issues in World History (3)
desc: In examining aspects of the histories of Africa, Asia, the Americas, Europe and Oceania, this course highlights the myriad ways in which global contact has transformed our world and narratives of the past.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: World History since 1500 (3)
desc: Continuation of 151. Historical narratives and global perspectives on human societies and cross-cultural interactions from 1500 to present; includes ways to think about the past and ways to use primary sources.
metadata: FGB College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HIST
title: World History to 1500 (3)
desc: Historical narratives and global perspectives on human societies and cross-cultural interactions from prehistory to 1500; includes ways to think about the past and ways to use primary sources.
metadata: FGA College of Arts, Languages & Letters History (HIST)

subject: HNDI
title: Third-Level Hindi: Film (3)
desc: Continuation of 202. Advanced listening, reading, writing, conversation skills, language structure, and culture integrated in a variety of communicative and creative activities based on selected Hindi-Urdu films. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: Hindi (HNDI) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: HNDI
title: Third-Level Hindi: Culture (3)
desc: Continuation of 202. Advanced listening, reading, writing, conversation skills, language structure, and culture integrated in a variety of communicative and creative activities based on selected cultural themes. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: Hindi (HNDI) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: HNDI
title: Intermediate Hindi II (3)
desc: Prepare your proficiency for traveling to India. Create audio-visual presentations, documentaries, movie parodies, poetry, plays, dance, or projects from your majors/minors. Develop critical, cross-cultural, and creative skills. Bollywood built into course content. Pre: 201.
metadata: HSL Hindi (HNDI) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: HNDI
title: Intermediate Hindi I (3)
desc: Improve your communicative and cultural proficiency. Make Bollywood your language coach. Talk about cross-cultural values and practices of food, family, and friendship. Project-based course that builds bridges to your majors, minors, and other interests. Pre: 102.
metadata: HSL Hindi (HNDI) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: HNDI
title: Elementary Hindi II (3)
desc: Build on your 101 skills. Content includes Bollywood Film Festival at Honolulu Museum of Art. Create your own audiovisual projects–make movie trailers, write children’s books, or perform at South Asian events.
metadata: HSL Hindi (HNDI) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: HNDI
title: Elementary Hindi I (3)
desc: Learn to express yourself in Hindi-a language that comes with a beautiful script, ancient philosophy, spicy food, and Bollywood! The course is communicative, creative, flexibly personalized for student interests. No textbook to buy.
metadata: HSL Hindi (HNDI) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: HSSW
title: Pacific Cultures in Health/Social Welfare (3)
desc: The study of cultures and their implications in the health and social welfare context for a number of countries in the Pacific region.
metadata: College of Health Sciences & Social Welfare Health Sciences and Social Welfare (HSSW)

subject: HSSW
title: Southeast Asian Cultures in Health/ Social Welfare (3)
desc: The study of cultures and their implications in the health and social welfare context for a number of countries in Southeast and South Asian region.
metadata: College of Health Sciences & Social Welfare Health Sciences and Social Welfare (HSSW)

subject: HWST
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. (F) Full-time. S/U for (F) only. Repeatable up to six credits; Repeatable unlimited times for (F). Pre: 700 for (F).
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Practicum Research Plan B (V)
desc: Practicum for Plan B. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Kūkulu Aupuni: Sovereign Hawaiian State, Domestic Kingdom Law, Governance and Politics (3)
desc: Research seminar on the subject of domestic law, governance, and politics of the Hawaiian Kingdom and the historical relevance of this to the contemporary case for independent, sovereign state continuity under public international law. A-F only. (Alt. years)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Kūkulu Aupuni: Envisioning the Nation (3)
desc: A research seminar designed to provide an overview of community activism and Native Hawaiian empowerment in Hawai‘i in contexts that range from local to international, and to provide a foundation for further study and professional growth. A-F only. Pre: 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Huaka‘i Huli Heiau Hawai‘inuiākea: Study Abroad on Polynesian Temples (6)
desc: Comparative study of Hawaiian/Polynesian temple design taught over a 3-week period in Hawai‘i and Polynesia. Travel costs to be paid by student. Pre: 670 (with a minimum grade of B) and HAW 302 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent. (Summer only)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Kumu Kahiki: Pacific Life Narratives in Mixed Media and Literature (3)
desc: Research seminar in relevant literary traditions, histories of interaction, colonization, and literary politics in the Pacific region through the examination of life narratives in mixed media and literature. A-F only. HWST majors only. Pre: 603 (or concurrent) or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Kumu Kahiki: Comparative Hawaiian and Tahitian Cosmogonies (3)
desc: Seminar comparing Gods/myths from Ancient Tahiti by Teiura Henry (600 pages) with the six volumes of Hawaiian historians Kamakau and Malo. A-F only. Pre: 341 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Kānāwai Lawai‘a: Hawa‘i’s Ocean and Fisheries Laws (3)
desc: Seminar on pre-contact, customary laws on fishing and ocean stewardship, their codification in written laws during the Hawaiian Kingdom period, and changes and impacts through U.S. annexation and statehood, including current models of ocean governance. (Alt. years: Fall) (Cross-listed as SUST 652)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: ‘Āina Waiwai: Water, Food Sovereignty, and Ancestral Abundance (3)
desc: Topical graduate seminar focuses on indigenous perspectives on water, food sovereignty, Hawaiian terrestrial and marine food production systems, and ancestral abundance. Seminar perspective to change each term. Repeatable two times. Pre: 207/SUST 217 and HAW 202 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawaiian Geography and Resource Management (3)
desc: Seminar in geography of Hawai‘i from a Native Hawaiian perspective that will enable the researcher to define and develop resource management methods consistent with Native Hawaiian understandings and traditions. A-F only. Pre: 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent). (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Mo‘olelo ‘Ōiwi: Historical Perspectives (3)
desc: Research seminar for developing interpretations of the past from Native Hawaiian and foreign world views with particular emphasis on understanding the meaning of culturally-based knowledge systems. A-F only.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Pono Science: Ethical Implications of Science in Hawai‘i (1)
desc: Support student dialogue on the foundations of pono science. Through discussions and structured guidance, students will explore Hawaiian ethics, implications of research, and decolonizing methodology. Repeatable three times. Graduate students only.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: ‘Ike Maka-Visual/Cultural Knowledge (3)
desc: Graduate seminar and visual studio that carefully examines and develops critical consciousness–from a Kanaka Maoli viewpoint–visual hegemony, rhetorical tropes; and representation–imag(in)ing and reimag(in)-ing. HWST majors only. A-F only. Pre: 620 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: ‘Ike Pono-Visual/Cultural Interpretations (3)
desc: Graduate seminar and visual studio that examines (from a Kanaka Maoli viewpoint) colonial imaging; collecting and site of contestation; resilience and resistance; and re-righting. A-F only. Pre: 107, and one course from 220-225, and one course from 320-325; or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Writing a Hawaiian Thesis (3)
desc: Seminar to help fashion student’s research and thesis proposal. To be taken by all HWST MA students as they begin designing their capstone project. Course will be team-taught by HWST faculty. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 601 and 602; 603 (or concurrent).
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Review of Hawaiian Literature (3)
desc: Seminar in review of Hawaiian literature to understand the significance of secondary sources in Hawaiian subjects. This makes up part of the Hawaiian Studies graduate core. A-F only. Pre: 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawaiian Archival Research (3)
desc: Research seminar aimed at familiarizing students with the rich historical primary sources existent in various archives in Honolulu. A-F only. Pre: 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Indigenous Research Methodologies (3)
desc: Reading seminar for developing a Native Hawaiian epistemology from sources in comparative indigenous thought. A-F only. Pre: 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Individual reading/research. Pre: instructor consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Kānāwai II: Practical Application of Rights (3)
desc: Historical analysis of land use, race and self-determination; introduced to legal case briefing, analysis of legal precedent, practical impacts of rules and regulations and the sociopolitical factors that influence law and law enforcement. A-F only. Pre: 390 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Kumu Kānāwai: Western Law and Hawai‘i (3)
desc: The rise of Western law in Hawai‘i, its contribution to nation building and colonialism. Pre: 342 or 343 or 390; or consent.
metadata: DH Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Modern Pacific Women’s Poetry (3)
desc: Critical examination of modern indigenous women’s poetry from the Pacific Islands. Thematic concentration on land, family, sexual and national oppression. Pre: 107, 270, or consent.
metadata: DL Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawaiian Political Speech: Ha‘i ‘Ōlelo Ku‘e (3)
desc: Senior seminar in short, extemporaneous speeches in persuasive, passionate and dynamic styles of Native Hawaiian orators. A-F only. Pre: 107, 270, 341, 342, or HAW 202; or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Senior Capstone Project in Hawaiian Studies (2)
desc: Capstone seminar designed to provide a culminating academic experience through in-depth examination, analysis, articulation, and projects relevant to a HWST area of concentration. Repeatable one time. HWST majors only. Senior standing only. A-F only. Pre: 341, 342, [343 or 390 or 490 (or concurrent)] and [207/SUST 217 or 285 or 307/SUST 317 or 356/SUST 356] and [222 or 224 or 225 or 372 or 478]. (Fall only)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Senior Seminar in Hawaiian Studies (3)
desc: Critical examination of existing research; individual or team development, execution, and evaluation of selected projects. Repeatable three times. Pre: senior major in Hawaiian studies or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawaiian Aquatic Medicine (4)
desc: Identification, extraction and preparation of complexes of aquatic herbs to formulate a healing combination to contribute to maintaining overall health. A-F only. Pre: 107, 285; or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Mahi Lā‘au Lapa‘au: Hawaiian Medicinal Horticulture (4)
desc: The science of planting and harvesting Hawaiian medicinal plants and exploring production and marketing strategies. Pre: 107, 285 and 385; or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Mele Au Hou: Music and Native Identity (3)
desc: Presents Hawaiian music as it has been an avenue for native social, cultural and political expression in traditional and contemporary society. A-F only. Pre: 107 or 343 or 390; or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: ‘Ike Akua Papakū Makawalu: Ancestral Understanding of Elements (3)
desc: Uses Dr. Pualani Kanahele’s Papakū Makawalu methodology to analyze akua as elements and as a paradigm for understanding ancestral knowledge. Senior standing or higher. Pre: 270, 372 (or concurrent), and HAW 301 (or concurrent).
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Mālama ‘Āina Field Methods Course (V)
desc: Intensive field methods program to research Mālama ‘Āina strategies. Introduces students to a variety of field techniques including land research, historical documents, ecological surveys, and Papakūmakawalu. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356, or consent. (Summer only)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawai‘i & Indigenous Economies (3)
desc: Students will map out indigenous economies by articulating cultural similarity and diversity between academic experience and professional experiences. A-F only. Pre: 107 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hui Konohiki Practicum (3)
desc: A “hands-on” internship in an environmental or resource-management organization in Hawai‘i. The experience will be broadened and supplemented by classroom lectures, discussion and analysis from traditional Hawaiian, scientific and economic perspectives. A-F only. Pre: 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as SUST 460)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Strategies in Hawaiian Resource Use (3)
desc: Analyzing diverse land and water use strategies of O‘ahu, from traditional Hawaiian, scientific and economic perspectives, through classroom and on-site lectures. Topics include traditional Hawaiian methods, modern development, threatened ecosystems, ecotourism and scientific research. A-F only. Pre: 207/SUST 217 or 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356. (Cross-listed as SUST 459)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Natural Resource Issues and Ethics (4)
desc: Overview of the history of land, resources and power in Hawai‘i; players and processes influencing land and natural resources policies today explored from Native Hawaiian and other viewpoints. Extensive use of case studies. Pre: 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356 (Cross-listed as NREM 458 and SUST 456)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: ‘Āina Mauliola: Hawaiian Ecosystems (3)
desc: Comprehensive analysis of traditional Hawaiian and modern resource management practices. Rigorous overview of the dominant physical and biological processes from the uplands to the oceans in Hawai‘i. Pre: 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356. (Cross-listed as SUST 457)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Kia‘i Kanaloa–Guarding Our Ocean Resources (4)
desc: Students will actively monitor and practice coastal and ocean stewardship in support of local communities and practitioners while also exploring how the Hawaiian worldview can plan a role in aloha ‘âina conservation movements. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356. (Spring only)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Ola I Ka Wai; Water and Sovereignty in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Focus on Hawaiian relationships with Ka Wai Ola a Kane (water), traditional and contemporary water management practices, as well as contemporary resource management issues and native Hawaiian community advocacy for water. Pre: 307 and HAW 202 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Wehe Ka ‘Āina: Cultivating a Sovereign Land Base (3)
desc: A Mālama ‘Āina and Kukulu ‘Aupuni course that identifies modern options in land access for reestablishing or resuming Hawaiian traditional and customary practices relating to food sovereignty and self-sustainability. HWST majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 207/SUST 217 and 343 and 351; HAW 202 (or concurrent). (Alt. years)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawaiian Institutions (3)
desc: Comprehensive analysis of institutions like Bishop Estate/Kamehameha Schools, OHA, Lili‘uokalani Trust, Department of Hawaiian Home Lands and The Queen’s Hospital. Pre: 342.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Introduction to Indigenous Research Methods (3)
desc: Survey course introduces students to a range of methods by beginning with a critical analysis of dominant research methodologies from the perspective of Indigenous scholars. Junior/senior standing only.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Ceded Lands: Focus on Crown and Government Lands (1848 to Present) (3)
desc: Inventorying “Ceded Lands” in Hawai‘i with emphasis on historical, legal, and cultural changes from the Kingdom through statehood. A-F only. Pre: 440 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Mâhele Land Awards (3)
desc: Practical guide to the researching of land awards and change in title for a single ahupua‘a, 1848 to present. Focus on field trips. Pre: 342.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Visiting Artist Seminar (4)
desc: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Explore indigenous concepts through the media of a visiting indigenous master artist by looking at traditional media in indigenous cultures, and the possibilities for contemporary expression in other media. Repeatable one time. HWST majors only. A-F only. Pre: 107, one course in 220 level (222, 224, 225), one course in 320 level (322, 324, 325); or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Native Hawaiian Rights and Practices (3)
desc: Students will strengthen their cultural, political, and legal foundations by: (1) reviewing Hawai‘i’s historical traditions and customs, (2) learning legal analysis techniques, and (3) applying those techniques to issues that govern native Hawaiian “rights” today. Sophomore or higher standing. Pre: 107, 270, and 341 (or concurrent) and HAW 102. (Fall only)
metadata: DH Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Issues in Modern Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Cultural and political aspects of the current Hawaiian movement; historical colonization; conflicts over tourism, the military, and agriculture; forms of native self-determination. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 107 and HAW 202.
metadata: DH Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: La‘au Lapa‘au: Ho‘i Ka Mana i Loko (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 Lab) Advanced study and preparation of Hawaiian medicinal herb combinations. Pre: 107 and 285; or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Pana Paemoku o Kanaloa: The Northwestern Hawaiian Islands (3)
desc: Will look at the use of the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands during pre-contact times, the historical period of the Kingdom of Hawai‘i, after the islands were ceded to the U.S., and the contemporary politics that surround the region today. A-F only. Pre: 107 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Pana O‘ahu: Famous Place Names (3)
desc: A survey of the famous place names in each ahupua‘a of O‘ahu, including accounts of mythical heroes, heiau, fishponds, wind, rain names, and their metaphoric value in Hawaiian literature. Pre: 270, 341, and HAW 202
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Aloha Kanaloa-Marine Resources and Abundance (3)
desc: Undergraduate course exposing students to the resources and processes of the ocean, research, and management approaches, as well as a Hawaiian worldview of oceanic elements. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 107. (Cross-listed as SUST 356)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Mālama Loko I‘a (4)
desc: Study of traditional Hawaiian fishpond management with hands-on experience at He‘eia fishpond near Kāne‘ohe, merging traditional Native knowledge and ways of seeing with Western science. A-F only. Pre: 107 and 207/SUST 217. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Mahi‘ai Kalo II: Advanced Taro (3)
desc: In depth-study of taro cultivation techniques and systems. A-F only. Pre: 351.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Mahi‘ai Kalo I: Taro Cultivation (3)
desc: Historical, cultural and philosophical foundations of the cultivation and uses of taro. A-F only. Pre: 107 and 207/SUST 217. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Myths of Hawaiian History (3)
desc: Thematic exploration of some common myths of Hawaiian history, including infanticide, slavery, feudalism, constant warfare, human sacrifice, and a limited pre-contact population, to determine the role of myth making in perceptions of Hawaiian history. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 107 and HAW 202.
metadata: DL Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Chiefs of Post-Contact Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Survey of Hawaiian chiefs from 1778 to the present, including genealogy, political function, and historical impact. Pre: 107, 341, or HAW 201.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawaiian Genealogies (3)
desc: Survey of major Hawaiian chiefly lineages from the four main islands: Hawai‘i, Maui, O‘ahu and Kaua‘i. Political history from the Kumulipo to Western contact. Pre: 270 and HAW 202.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Native Hawaiian Traditions in Literature (3)
desc: Discusses theoretical frameworks, main features, and cultural contexts of Hawaiian literature. Pre: 107, 270, and HAW 202; or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Advanced Hawaiian Printmaking Studio (4)
desc: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Advanced Native Hawaiian perspective in imagery in print and the material, technical, and conceptual aspects of hand printed imagery. Lecture-lab with studio work time. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 107 and 225, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Advanced Hawaiian Painting and Drawing Studio (3)
desc: Advanced research and expression of personal relationship to specific Hawaiian paradigms through visual culture and language. Students will further their definitions, analysis skills, research, and understandings through painting and drawing media. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 107 and 224, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Advanced Hawaiian Fiber Arts Studio-Hana No‘eau Ma‘awe (4)
desc: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Examine the customary and contemporary use of fiber materials and the skills used in Hawaiian culture. Research and explore advanced techniques within the media used in traditional Hawai‘i. A-F only. Repeatable one time. Pre: 107 and 222, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Advanced Art Media (3)
desc: Examine and explore advance techniques within the media and the customary and contemporary uses of a variety of material and skills used in traditional Hawaiian everyday life. Repeatable six times. A-F only. Pre: 107 or 220, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Malama ‘Āina Resource Management Visual Technologies (3)
desc: Requires a broad set of knowledge systems. Will introduce students to a variety of visual technologies for use in resource management and the ethical application of these technologies. Pre: 107. (Cross-listed as SUST 317)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Perspectives in Hawaiian Studies (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary lectures and discussions examining traditional and contemporary experiences in Hawaiian society and setting; resources, methods, and techniques. Repeatable one time. Pre: HAW 202 or consent.
metadata: DH Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Lā‘au Lapa‘au: Hawaiian Medicinal Herbs (4)
desc: Presentation of Hawaiian medicinal herbs including basic philosophy, identification, utilization, and preparation of such herbs for human ailments. Pre: 107 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Ho‘okele II Laboratory (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Hands on experience on voyaging skills and sailing canoes to accompany 282. Pre: 282 (or concurrent).
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Ho‘okele II: Hawaiian Navigation (3)
desc: Hawaiian and other Oceanic canoe design, navigation, Pacific weather, sailing dynamics for canoes, and sail planning strategies used by Polynesian Voyaging Society navigators for long voyages.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Ho‘okele I Laboratory (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Stargazing laboratory to accompany 281. Pre: 281 (or concurrent).
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Ho‘okele I: Hawaiian Astronomy (3)
desc: Introduction to Hawaiian views of astronomy and the stars used by Polynesian Voyaging Society navigators. Introduction and comparison to various Pacific island non-instrument navigation systems and star names. Restricted to majors.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Papahulilani Hawaiian Astronomy I (3)
desc: Introduction to Hawaiian ancestral understandings of the movements of the sun, moon and stars, and their use in ordering the Hawaiian year in planting, fishing, and ceremony. Repeatable one time. Pre: (107 and 270) with a minimum grade of B.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawaiian Mythology (3)
desc: Survey of gods, ‘aumākua, kupua, mythical heroes, heroines, and their kinolau as the basis of traditional Hawaiian metaphor. Pre: 107 and HAW 102.
metadata: DL Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Introduction to the Literature of Native Hawaiians and Other Indigenous People Written in English (3)
desc: Surveys literature of Native Hawaiians and other Indigenous Peoples, especially to focus on the situational impetus from which these texts were created. Pre: 107. (Fall only)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Introduction to Hawaiian Printmaking Studio (4)
desc: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Introduction to Native Hawaiian perspective and world view in images used in print and the basic material, technical, and conceptual aspects of hand printed imagery through the indigenous eyes. A-F only. Pre: 107 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Introduction to Hawaiian Painting and Drawing Studio (3)
desc: Research and express personal relationship to specific Hawaiian paradigms through Hawaiian visual culture. Introduction to painting and drawing media and exploration of various materials and techniques as applied to individual student styles. A-F only. Pre: 107 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DA Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Introduction to Hawaiian Fiber Arts Studio-Hana No‘eau Ma‘awe (4)
desc: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Introduction to a variety of fibers used in the Hawaiian culture. Emphasis on cultivation, preparation, uses and conservation of the fibers. Areas explored are kapa, plaiting, netting and twining. A-F only. Pre: 107 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Introduction to Hawaiian Visual Culture Studio (3)
desc: Introduction to a variety of material (fiber, bone, wood, and stone) and skills in the media used in the Hawaiian culture. Research and explore basic techniques within the media with emphasis on cultivation, preparation, uses, and conservation. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 107 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawaiian Perspectives in Ahupua‘a (3)
desc: Examination of the ahupua‘a system as it was conceptualized by the ancient Hawaiians, and exploration of its relevance in modern society; an introductory class to the mālama ‘āina track designed to build critical writing skills. A-F only. Pre: 107. (Cross-listed as SUST 217)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HWST
title: Hawai‘i: Center of the Pacific (3)
desc: An introduction to the unique aspects of the native point of view in Hawai‘i and in the larger Pacific with regards to origins, language, religion, land, art, history, and modern issues.
metadata: DH Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian Studies (HWST)

subject: HAW
title: Noi‘i Pepa Laeo‘o (Thesis) (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. Pre: consent of instructor and graduate chair.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Papahana Laeo‘o (V)
desc: Research for Plan B project/non-thesis. May include but not limited to internship with cultural practitioner. Repeatable up to six credits. HAW majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: consent of graduate advisor.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Noi‘i Mele (3)
desc: Intensive study focusing on original compositions of Hawaiian poetry and song. Pre: 402 and 484, or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: ‘Ōlelo Ni‘ihau (3)
desc: Intensive, advanced study and analysis of traditional Hawaiian Ni‘ihau dialect through face-to-face conversations with Ni‘ihau native speakers, listening to audio recordings and watching video recordings of Ni‘ihau native speakers. Pre: (402 and 453) with a minimum grade of B- or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Pilina ‘Ōlelo (3)
desc: In-depth examination and research into the grammar of Hawaiian including discussion of theories of language and incorporation of meta-language. Pre: 452 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Ke A‘o ‘Olelo Hou ‘Ana (Teaching Hawaiian As a Second Language) (3)
desc: Survey of existing texts and teaching resources; analysis of student clientele and needs; review of pedagogical approaches for heritage and non-heritage learners; syllabus and materials development; practicum. Pre: 401 and 452 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: (Alpha) Nā Mea Kākau/Nā Haku Mo‘olelo (3)
desc: Intensive study of an individual author, his/her works and nuances of his/her works. (E) J. H. Kanepu‘u; (I) S. M. Kamakau. Pre: 601 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Mo‘olelo Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Intensive study, research, and analysis of Hawaiian history. Repeatable two times with consent of advisor. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Kuana‘ike (3)
desc: The examination of Hawaiian ways of speaking, as contrasted with English focusing on those features that are uniquely Hawaiian and can be said to constitute a Hawaiian worldview. Section 1 taught in Hawaiian; Section 2 taught in English. Pre: 402 or consent for Section 1.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Nā Mana‘o Politika Hawai‘i (Hawaiian Political Thought) (3)
desc: Study of Hawaiian political thought in writing from ca. 1825 to the present, with emphasis on theory and research methods. Pre: 402, 428, and POLS 303; or consent. (Cross-listed as POLS 612)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Ka Hana Noi‘i (Research Methods) (3)
desc: Research methodology course utilizing active research in the major repositories of Hawaiian language materials and Hawaiian-related knowledge. A-F only. Pre: 604 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Haku Palapala Noi Laeo‘o/Writing a Hawaiian Master’s Proposal (3)
desc: Seminar to select and develop students’ research topic, proposal, and organizational plan for Plan A or B completion. Majors are encouraged not to take this course in their first semester of the program. A-F only. (Once a year)
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Kākā‘ōlelo Oratory (3)
desc: A survey of oral performance styles to build increased oral skills. Pre: graduate standing and 601, or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Kākau Mo‘olelo (3)
desc: Analyzes various genres of written Hawaiian literature. HAW majors only. Pre: graduate standing and 402, or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Directed Studies (V)
desc: Study of Hawaiian language through vernacular readings in various academic fields. Repeatable up to 6 credits. Pre: 302 and consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Ka Mākau‘Ōlelo A‘o Kula Kaiapuni Hawai‘i (1)
desc: Assess the linguistic competence of prospective Hawaiian language immersion teachers to assure that all teachers entering the state DOE Hawaiian Immersion Program meet the requirements of the program with respect to Hawaiian language proficiency. CR/NC only. Pre: 402 (or concurrent), and 463 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: ‘Ōlelo No‘eau (3)
desc: Survey and analysis of traditional proverbs and their kaona or symbolic meanings. A-F only. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge Hawaiian (HAW)

subject: HAW
title: Kahua Hanakeaka (Hawaiian Medium Stage Production) (3)
