metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Nature-Based Tourism Management (3)
desc: Principles of nature-based tourism, including a survey of impacts, objectives, planning, and management systems. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 324/TIM 324 or TIM 101. (Cross-listed as TIM 415 and SUST 415)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Environmental Hazards and Community Resilience (3)
desc: Investigation of the forces behind natural and technological hazards, and human actions that reduce or increase vulnerability to natural disasters. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Resource Management in Southeast Asia (3)
desc: Challenges associated with the management of land, water resources, fisheries, forests and agriculture in modern Southeast Asia. Case studies are used to illustrate current problems and evaluate potential management solutions. A-F only. Pre: junior standing or higher. (Cross-listed as ASAN 413)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Environmental Impact Assessment (3)
desc: Introduction to analytical methods for identifying, measuring, and quantifying the impacts of changes or interventions in resource, human-environment, and other geographic systems. Pre: junior standing or higher, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Past Global Change and the Human Era (3)
desc: Study of past environments to understand present and future global change. Focus on terrestrial Quaternary environments and global processes. Pre: junior standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as SUST 413)
metadata: DP College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Human Role in Environmental Change (3)
desc: Human impacts through time on vegetation, animals, landforms, soils, climate, and atmosphere. Special reference to Asian/Pacific region. Implications of long-term environmental change for human habitability. Pre: with a minimum grade of B, one of 101, BIOL 101, BIOL 123 and either 322 or BIOL 310; or consent. (Cross-listed as BIOL 410)
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Cultural Biogeography (3)
desc: Coevolution of human societies and plants over the last 10,000 years. Foraging, farming and urban societies economies; spread and modification of selected plants; issues of preservation of genetic resources and traditional plant knowledge. The form and function of gardens. A-F only. Pre: junior standing or higher, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Conservation and Evolutionary Biogeography (3)
desc: Theories and techniques for the analysis of spatial microevolutionary patterns, taught from an interdisciplinary perspective. Examples and readings emphasize Hawai‘i and the Pacific region. Pre: either 309, BIOL 265 or BIOL 487, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Water in the Environment (3)
desc: Water fluxes in the environment. Occurrence and movement of water; methods of quantification. Water balance of soil-plant system: precipitation, interception, infiltration, runoff, soil moisture, evapotranspiration, and groundwater recharge. Pre: 101 or 300 or 400 or 401 or 402 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent.
metadata: DP College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Climate, Air Quality, & Policy (3)
desc: Examination of air quality problems from scientific and policy perspectives. Includes case studies that explore economic, political, technical, and legal aspects of pollution control. Pre: junior standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as SUST 404)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Fluvial Geomorphology (3)
desc: Introduction to the single most important geomorphic agent shaping the terrestrial environment. Focus on fluvial process, fluvial dynamics, fluvial landforms, and sediment transport. Pre: 101/101L or 303 or ERTH 101/101L.
metadata: DP College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Agricultural Climatology (3)
desc: Analyzing climatic data; relation to photosynthesis, phenological development, and crop yields. Crop-weather models as guides to improved land-use planning and agronomic practices. Pre: 101 or 300 or 400 or 401 or 405 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent.
metadata: DP College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Climate Change (3)
desc: Approaches to the study of past and future climate change. Pre: 101 or 300 or 401 or 402 or 405 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent.
metadata: DP College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Vegetation and the Climate System (3)
desc: Role of vegetation in the climate system; links to hydrology and biogeochemical cycling; vegetation and climate history; evolution of terrestrial ecosystems; effects of global warming. Pre: 101 or 300 or 401 or 402 or 405 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent.
metadata: DP College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Limited to senior majors with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in geography.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: GIS and Spatial Analysis for Social Sciences (3)
desc: Introduction to spacial analysis and GIS for social science studies, using open-source GIS tools to collect, visualize, and analyze social data; public health, socio-economic and social media data. Requires basic knowledge about GIS.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Introduction to GIS (3)
desc: Design, implementation, and use. Database construction and documentation. Techniques for spatial data manipulation and display. Evaluation of existing systems. Student research projects.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Statistical Methods in Geography (3)
desc: Quantitative statistical methods will be explored for describing and interpreting geographic/environmental phenomena. Topics will include data display, measurement, sampling, spatial statistics, dimensional analysis, nonparametric and parametric models. Pre: 101 or 102 or 151 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Map Design and Production (3)
desc: (3 2-hr Lab) Compilation, design and production of maps for presentations, research, and illustration using artists and mapping software. Pre: junior standing or higher, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Introduction to Cartography and Air Photo (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of cartography: compilation and measurement from aerial photographs, alternate forms of data presentation, symbolism, design, and map projection.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: UAV and Aerial Photography (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to UAV (unmanned aerial vehicle systems) and the measurement, interpretation, analysis, and use of photography acquired by UAV and other aerial systems.
metadata: DY College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Regional, physical, cultural geography. Detailed study of people and resources.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography of Honolulu (3)
desc: Development of Honolulu and O‘ahu from 1778. Evolution of function, land use, and social patterns. Contemporary planning and environmental issues arising from urban growth.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography of the Pacific (3)
desc: Physical character of the Pacific; cultural, political, economic geography of Melanesia, Micronesia, Polynesia (except Hawai‘i).
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography of Southeast Asia (3)
desc: An investigation of the development context of Southeast Asia including socioeconomic, cultural, and environmental resources. Problems and prospects for change. (Cross-listed as ASAN 356)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography of South Asia (3)
desc: Introduction to physical and human geography of India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Himalayan kingdoms. Environmental, economic, social, cultural, and political factors in development.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography of China (3)
desc: Topics: environmental parameters and resource base, ecological control and resource management, institutional and technological transformation of agriculture, industrial potential and industrial location, settlement patterns and rural urban symbiosis.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography of Japan (3)
desc: Regional synthesis of physical and cultural features; economic, social, political geography; origins and development of cities.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography of North America (3)
desc: Overview of the physical and cultural geography. Regions and characters. Patterns of population, natural resources, industry, agriculture, and transportation/ communication networks. Pre: 101 or 102 or 151, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Politics, Nations, and States (3)
desc: Examines the political organization of space in the sovereign state system. Contemporary and historical analyses of boundaries, geopolitics, homelands, nations, nationalism, and territory. Pre: sophomore standing or higher, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Culture and Environment (3)
desc: Critically examines changing views of nature, nature-culture relationships, and perceptions of the environment across different cultures. (Cross-listed as SUST 330)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography, Environment, and Society (3)
desc: Examines the geography of resources and environmental change with a holistic and multi-scale perspective. Social approaches to resolving environmental problems. (Cross-listed as SUST 326)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography of Global Tourism (3)
desc: Tourist landscape in relation to resources, spatial patterns of supply and demand, impacts of tourism development, and models of tourist space. Flows between major world regions. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as TIM 324)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Globalization and Environment (3)
desc: Debates on globalization and development, population and resources; root causes of environmental degradation; impacts of globalization on environmentalism and environmental change; social approaches to managing environmental change. Junior standing or higher. (Cross-listed as SUST 322)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Economic Geography (3)
desc: Examines how factors of production like land, labor and capital; economic activities like consumption, trade, production, and investments; and institutions like state, markets, and corporations alter economic space. A-F only. Pre: 102 or 151. (Fall only)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Tropical Agrarian Systems (3)
desc: Analysis of environmental potential and constraints and of spatial organization of economy and society of tropical agrarian systems. Emphasis on change through colonial and post-colonial periods.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Introduction to Planning (3)
desc: Perspectives on planning; planning tools and methods; specific Hawai‘i planning–research problems from a multidisciplinary approach. Pre: junior standing or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Introduction to Biogeography (3)
desc: Introduction to ecosystem concept; environmental adaptations for energy and nutrient transfer; characteristics, dynamics, productivity, and distribution of principal vegetation communities. Human dominance. Pre: sophomore standing or higher, or consent.
metadata: DB College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Water and Society (3)
desc: Interaction of people with water at household, community, regional, national, and international scales, from cultural, political, economic, and biophysical perspectives. Pre: sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as SUST 315)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: General Geomorphology (3)
desc: Introduction to geomorphological concepts, process mechanics, and relationships between forms and processes. Emphasis on various subdisciplines of geomorphology: coastal hillslopes, fluvial, aeolean, and glacial. Pre: 101 and 101L, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 101L.
metadata: DP College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Global Environmental Issues (3)
desc: Use and abuse of natural resources and humanity’s progress toward developing a sustainable relationship with its supporting environment. A-F only. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as SUST 314)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Introduction to Climatology (3)
desc: Elements and controls of climate. World patterns of insolation, temperature, evaporation, precipitation, atmospheric circulation. Climatic classifications. Pre: 101 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200, or consent.
metadata: DP College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Geography and Contemporary Society (3)
desc: Elements of economic geography and resource management, population and urban geography; application to current problems of developed and underdeveloped worlds.
metadata: FGC College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: Digital Earth (3)
desc: Cartographic representation and meaning in a digital age. Earth models, map projections, coordinate systems, scale, distance, and direction. Data types and transformations in graphic and digital representation. Manual, automated, and web-based map making and analysis.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: World Regional Geography (3)
desc: World’s major cultural regions; geographic aspects of contemporary economic, social, political conditions.
metadata: FGB College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: The Natural Environment Lab (1)
desc: A survey of field and laboratory methods commonly used by physical geographers. Pre: 101 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as SUST 102L)
metadata: DY College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: GEO
title: The Natural Environment (3)
desc:
Introduction to physical geography including weather, climate, 
vegetation, soils, geology, and landforms. Environmental issues and natural hazards. (Cross-listed as SUST 102) DP
metadata: DP College of Social Sciences Geography and Environment (GEO)

subject: FR
title: Seminar in French Literature (3)
desc: Study of authors or a period. Repeatable two times with consent. Pre: consent of instructor and French graduate advisor.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent of department chair.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: The Theater in France (3)
desc: Historical development; major dramatists who have influenced movements or established techniques. Pre: 6 credit hours at 400 level.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Seminar: The Novel in France (3)
desc: Novels which have influenced movements or established techniques. Repeatable two times with consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Seminar in Medieval Literature (3)
desc: Genesis and evolution of literary genres from the 12th to 15th centuries. Epic, romance, lyric poetry, prose, and drama.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: History of the French Language (3)
desc: Origins and development of French language in its cultural context. Contrastive analysis.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Advanced French-English Translation: Practice and Theory (3)
desc: Advanced practice in translation into French and from French to English in various fields (literature, business, medicine, other), with reflection on choices. Readings in translation theory. Repeatable one time.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Philosophic Currents in 18th Century (3)
desc: Philosophic movements and their impact on the social, political, and literary life of the period and the modern era.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Masterpieces of the 17th Century (3)
desc: Dramatic or prose works of the classical period.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: French Renaissance (3)
desc: Poetry, theater, prose. Emphasis on Montaigne and Rabelais. Lectures, discussions, reports.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Seminar in 20th-Century French Literature (3)
desc: Authors and movements of modern period.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: French for Reading Proficiency (3)
desc: Reading of scholarly and technical French for graduate students; open to undergraduates with consent of department chair. Not applicable to undergraduate language requirement. Repeatable two times with consent. CR/NC only.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Independent study of approved readings and research with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: (Alpha) Seminar in French Literature (3)
desc: (B) French literature by period; (C) Francophone literature; (D) French film; (E) topic in French literature. Repeatable two time per alpha. Pre: 331 (or concurrent) and 332 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Intensive Fourth-Level French Abroad (V)
desc: Intensive course of formal instruction on the fourthyear level in French language, culture and literature in a French-speaking country. For semester programs only. Pre: 360 or equivalent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Fourth-Level French Abroad (3)
desc: Continuation of 458.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Fourth-Level French Abroad (3)
desc: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction on the fourth-year level in French linguistics, civilization, culture, and literature in a French-speaking country. Pre: 359 or 360 or equivalent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: 20th Century French Prose and Poetry (3)
desc: Study of representative prose and poetry of the major trends of 20th century France: modernism, surrealism, existentialism, postmodernism and multiculturalism. Pre: 332 or consent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: 20th-Century French Theater (3)
desc: Major French playwrights and their works: Claudel, Giraudoux, Anouilh, Sartre, Camus, etc. Pre: 332 or consent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: 19th Century French Prose and Poetry (3)
desc: Study of representative prose and poetry of the major trends of 19th century France: romanticism, realism, symbolism, aestheticism. Pre: 332 or consent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Masterpieces of 18th-Century Literature (3)
desc: Pre: 332 or consent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Masterpieces of 17th-Century Literature (3)
desc: Principal works of major dramatists: Corneille, Moliere, Racine. Principal movements and major authors of non-dramatic prose and poetry. Pre: 331 or consent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Masterpieces of 16th-Century Literature (3)
desc: Samplings from all major writers of the period. Readings in original text in editions giving modern French equivalents for difficult words. Pre: 331 or consent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Advanced Language Study: French (3)
desc: Advanced course in spoken and written French with intensive review of alternative grammatical structures and shades of meaning in the modern language. Graduates who have not taken prerequisites may request consent. Pre: 306 or 405 (or equivalent); or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Masterpieces of Medieval Literature (3)
desc: Samplings from epic, novel, verse and prose, tale, lyric poetry, chronicle, theater, didactic literature. Elementary readings in original text in editions giving modern French translation. Pre: 331 or consent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: French-English Translation (3)
desc: Practice in techniques based on contrastive linguistics. Translation of texts from various fields from French into English and the reverse. Pre: 306 or 309, and 312; or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Advanced Oral and Written Expression (3)
desc: Further development of listening, comprehension, speaking, and writing skills through viewing of French videotapes, reading French newspapers, frequent oral and written reports. Pre: 311 and 312, or 306, or 358, or 360; or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Independent study of approved reading with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: (Alpha) Topics in French Literature (3)
desc: (B) French film; (C) the Fantastic; (D) Francophone literature. Repeatable two times with consent. Pre: 311 or 312, or consent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Survey of French Civilization (3)
desc: A historical survey of the development of French culture. The course is interdisciplinary, focusing on the relations between politics, literature, science, and the arts. A-F only. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: DH French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Contemporary French Civilization (3)
desc: Survey of culture and institutions of modern France. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: DH French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Intensive Third-Level French Abroad (V)
desc: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in French language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in a French-speaking country. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Third-Level French Abroad (3)
desc: Continuation of 358.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Third-Level French Abroad (3)
desc: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in French language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in a French-speaking country. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Survey of French Literature (3)
desc: Continuation of 331. Pre: 311 (or concurrent) and 312; only 311 may be concurrent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Survey of French Literature (3)
desc: Major authors and movements. Pre: 311 (or concurrent) and 312; only 311 may be concurrent.
metadata: DL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Advanced Conversation (3)
desc: Systematic and advanced practice for control of spoken French, advanced development for accurate, mature expression. Pre: 311 or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Composition (3)
desc: Emphasis on strengthening facility with language through further training in syntax, structure, and composition writing. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Conversation (3)
desc: Systematic practice for control of spoken French. Further development of vocabulary for accurate, mature expression. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Business French (3)
desc: Reading and writing commercial materials. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Structure of French (3)
desc: Structure of contemporary French as analyzed by descriptive linguists. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: DH French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Reading in French (3)
desc: Development of language skills through reading of cultural and literary texts. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: French Phonetics (3)
desc: Analysis of phonological system; methods of teaching pronunciation; understanding various types of spontaneous speech. Drills in pronunciation, intonation, stress, and rhythm. Pre: 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
metadata: DH French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Intermediate French Abroad (3)
desc: Continuation of 258.
metadata: HSL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Intermediate French Abroad (3)
desc: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction on the second-year level in French language and culture in a French-speaking country. Pre: 102 or 110 or consent.
metadata: HSL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Intensive French-Intermediate (6)
desc: Content of 201-202 covered in one semester. Pre: 102 or 110 or consent.
metadata: HSL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Intermediate French (3)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201.
metadata: HSL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Intermediate French (3)
desc: Reading, conversation, laboratory drill, composition. Pre: 102 or 110 or consent.
metadata: HSL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Intensive French-Elementary (6)
desc: Content of 101-102 covered in one semester.
metadata: HSL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Elementary French (3)
desc: Conversation, grammar, and reading. Pre: 101 or consent.
metadata: HSL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FR
title: Elementary French (3)
desc: Conversation, grammar, and reading.
metadata: HSL French (FR) Languages and Literatures of Europe and the Americas (LLEA)

subject: FSHN
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation in nutrition. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate standing only. Satisfactory/ Unsatisfactory only. Pre: candidacy for PhD in Nutrition.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Diet and Cancer Seminar (1)
desc: Presentation-discussion of selected research topics in the field of diet-cancer relationships including: nutritional epidemiology of cancer, diet and supplement intervention trials, and cellular/molecular effects of diet on cancer pathophysiology. Repeatable one time. Pre: 685 and 689, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Dietary Fiber, Bioactive Food Components and Health (3)
desc: Lecture/discussion of current research on gut physiology, gut microbes, dietary fiber, bioactive food components, and their impact on health, including colorectal cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, heart disease, diabetes, and immune function. Pre: 485 and 486 (or equivalent), statistics, physiology; or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Epidemiology of Diabetes and Obesity (2)
desc: Provides an overview of the epidemiology and prevention of metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and associated complications. Discusses methodological issues associated with evaluating these in epidemiologic studies. A-F only. Pre: 663 (with a minimum grade of B-) or consent. (Cross-listed as PH 749)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Topics in Food Science (1)
desc: Advanced topics in food science and technology, from basic to applied research, including current issues in food science and technology and critical analysis of current research literature. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Plan B Master’s Project (3)
desc: Independent study for students working on a Plan B Master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in nutritional sciences.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Nutritional Epidemiology (3)
desc: Dietary, biochemical, anthropometric and clinical methods used for evaluating nutrition and diet in the etiology and epidemiology of disease. Pre: 685 and PH 663, or consent. (Cross-listed as PH 689)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Indigenous Peoples’ Food Systems, Environment and Health (3)
desc: Explores Indigenous Peoples’ food systems as local food resources Indigenous People acquire through specific cultural knowledge of traditional territories. Global forces transforming these food systems and their impact on population health and nutrition are explored. Graduate students only. (Cross-listed as PH 688)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Advanced Lab Techniques (3)
desc: (1 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Advanced laboratory techniques used in food science and human nutrition research. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent and 477 and MBBE 402/402L; or BIOC 441. (Cross-listed as ANSC 687 and MBBE 687)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Advanced Child and Adolescent Nutrition (3)
desc: Addresses nutrition, growth, and development in children and adolescents and nutrition-related issues, such as childhood obesity and chronic disease risk factors, with a focus on current research in the Pacific region. Pre: 370 or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as PH 686)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Nutrition and Disease: Cellular and Molecular Aspects (3)
desc: In-depth lecture, discussion, and student presentations on selected topics relating nutrition to the etiology and prevention of chronic diseases at the cellular and molecular level. Repeatable one time. Pre: (485 and 486) with a minimum grade of C; statistics; or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Supplemental and Nutritional Approaches in Disease Prevention and Treatment (3)
desc: Examines a variety of issues associated with nutritional and supplemental approaches to reduce disease incidence, morbidity, and mortality in relation to public health prevention strategies. PH majors only. (Cross-listed as PH 684)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Global Nutrition (2)
desc: Examination of global food and nutrition problems, programs, issues, policies, and strategies for improvement. A-F only. Pre: statistics and consent. (Alt. years: fall) (Cross-listed as PH 683)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Topics in Nutritional Sciences (V)
desc: Advanced topics in nutritional sciences, from basic to applied research, including current issues in nutrition and critical analysis of current research literature. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Seminar in Food and Nutritional Sciences (1)
desc: Student presentation of literature reviews and research. Repeatable five times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Advanced Topics in Dietetics (1)
desc: Advanced topics in professional dietetics practice. Students will further their knowledge and skills in professional practice areas of dietetics; including clinical, community, and food systems management. Repeatable one time. MS Nutritional Sciences students only.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Grant Writing for Graduate Students (1)
desc: Combined lecture/discussion on grants and grant writing. Designed to introduce graduate students to grants and grant proposal writing through lectures, class discussion, writing assignments, and peer review. Open to CTAHR graduate students only; others with consent. (Cross-listed as ANSC 657 and TPSS 657)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Information Research Skills (1)
desc: Examines the use of libraries and information technology for scholarly investigation in support of scientific research; provides experience utilizing and critically evaluating a variety of print and electronic sources in basic and applied sciences. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as ANSC 652, NREM 652, and TPSS 652)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: DNA and Genetic Analysis (3)
desc: Combined lecture-lab for students interested in genetic analysis of humans, animals, and other species. Molecular techniques, such as PCR, DNA marker identifications, transgenics, expression analysis and functional genomics, are included. Open to nonmajors. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Cross-listed as ANSC 650 and MBBE 650)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: International Nutrition (3)
desc: Analysis of major nutrition problems in developing countries. Comparative review of the design, implementation, and evaluation of programs to intervene in the development of malnutrition. Pre: 185 or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Advanced Food Safety (3)
desc: Real and perceived food hazards, their ethical issues and implications, advanced emerging topics in food safety, and controls, including laws and regulations of food safety issues and public perception of food safety will be discussed. A-F only. Pre: graduate student status with undergraduate courses in biochemistry, microbiology, food processing, physics and organic chemistry. Basic food science knowledge is required; or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Advanced Food Science II (3)
desc: Advances in sensory quality and evaluation, deterioration of foods and food safety, as well as food processing technology. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: graduate student status with undergraduate courses in organic chemistry, microbiology, additional biological sciences, physics, and biochemistry. Basic knowledge of food science is expected; or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Advanced Food Science I (3)
desc: Advanced topics in chemical and physical characteristics of foods as well as their role in human nutrition. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: graduate student status with undergraduate courses in organic chemistry, microbiology, additional biological science, physics, and biochemistry. Basic knowledge of food science is expected; or consent. (Cross-listed as MBBE 607)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: The Science of Food Systems (2)
desc: (1 50-min Lec, 1 2-hr discussion) Discussion of food systems as they apply to animal science, food science, and human nutrition. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Cross-listed as ANSC 601)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Science Capstone (3)
desc: Field practicum designed to integrate knowledge from previous FSHN courses to develop novel and innovative food products. Students deal with shelflife, marketing, packaging, labeling, sensory evaluation, and quality assurance. Repeatable one time. FSHN majors only. A-F only. Pre: (381 and 460) with a minimum grade of C, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Field Experience (4)
desc: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Placement with an approved cooperating supervisor/employer. Writing a learning plan and field report. A-F only. Pre: senior standing in FSHN. (Cross-listed as ANSC 492)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Topics in Food Science and Human Nutrition (V)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics, problems, or laboratory experiments. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: instructor approval.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Obesity, Science, and Issues (2)
desc: In-depth study of obesity, including research, etiology, treatment, and prevention. Pre: 485 with a minimum grade of C.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Nutritional Biochemistry II (3)
desc: Metabolism and biochemistry of vitamins, minerals, and dietary fiber, including chemical structure, digestion, absorption, transport, and cellular/ molecular functions in human nutrition; relevance to establishing nutrient requirements and to mechanisms of chronic disease. Pre: 485 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Nutritional Biochemistry I (3)
desc: Metabolism and biochemistry of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins, including chemical structure, digestion, absorption, transport, cellular/molecular functions in human nutrition; integration of metabolic pathways; energy metabolism and balance, including relevance to chronic disease. Pre: 185; PHYL 142/142L or PHYL 302/302L; BIOC 341 or higher (or concurrent) or MBBE 402 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Nutrition in Exercise and Sport (3)
desc: Effects of physiologic demands of exercise on nutrition. Emphasis on physiologic and biochemical basis for nutrition recommendations to enhance exercise participation and optimize athletic performance. Pre: (185, and PHYL 103 or 141 or 301) with a minimum grade of C. (Cross-listed as KRS 480)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Analysis Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Application of different chemical and physical methods for the identification and quantitation of food components. Co-requisite: 477.
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Analysis (2)
desc: Principles of sample preparation and chemical and physical analysis of food components using current methodology. Pre: 430; and CHEM 162 or higher; and BIOL 402 or MBBE 402 or PEPS 402.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Cultural Aspects of Food Habits (3)
desc: Study of eating from behavioral perspectives. Implications for health practitioners and health education. Pre: two classes from ANTH 151 or higher or SOC 100 or higher or PSY 100 or higher.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Applied Human Nutrition (3)
desc: Application of basic nutrition principles; includes sources and functions of essential nutrients and food patterns compatible with nutrient needs, health, disease prevention, and sustainability. Intended for undergraduate and graduate students. Pre: CHEM 161 (or higher) or BIOC 241 (or higher); PHYL 141, BIOL 171; or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Nutrition Counseling Skills (2)
desc: Theory and practice in nutritional counseling. Combined lecture and discussion on nutrition/dietary counseling. Knowledge and theories. Application through lab experiences including role playing, case presentations, and performing actual counseling sessions. A-F only. Pre: 467 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Medical Nutrition Therapy II (3)
desc: Understanding of the pathophysiology of disease processes and nutritional intervention, using medical terminology and case studies. Dietetics majors only. Pre: 467 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Medical Nutrition Therapy I (V)
desc: Development of dietary, anthropometric and clinical lab assessment skills measuring nutritional status. Understanding pathophysiology of disease processes, medical terminology and nutritional intervention, utilizing case studies. Dietetics majors only. Pre: (389 and 486) with a minimum grade of C or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Processing Operations (3)
desc: Principles and applications of food dehydration, thermal processing, low temperature preservation, chemical and biochemical preservation, irradiation, packaging, manufacturing, plant sanitation, water and waste management. Pre: 403 and 430, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Culture and Child Health in the Pacific (3)
desc: In-depth study of Pacific culture, land, people, and history and its relationship to child health. Explores cultural competency, cultural safety, and multidisciplinary approaches to promote a healthy Pacific. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. Pre: 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Child Health and Nutrition Monotiring (1)
desc: Covers topics related to health and nutritional status monitoring and surveillance, including epidemiology, biostatistics, health and nutrition surveillance systems, and the uses of technology for conducting these activities. Repeatable one time. Pre: 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Childhood Anthropometric and Dietary Assessment Field Techniques (1)
desc: Teaches techniques for measuring anthropometry and collecting dietary intake in children. Online course imitates hands-on training through partnering with local organizations and the use of technology. Repeatable one time. Pre: 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Foundation of Childhood Obesity Prevention in the Pacific (3)
desc: Provide students with a basic overview of the causes and effects of childhood obesity, evidence-based approaches, community-based research, and policies to prevent childhood obesity as it relates to the Pacific region. Pre: 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Community Nutrition and Nutrition Education (4)
desc: (4 Lec) Concepts and methods of nutrition program planning and nutrition education; analysis of nutritional problems of local, national, and international communities; strategies used to educate groups or individuals. A-F only. Pre: (370 and either HDFS 380 or NREM 310) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Quality Control (3)
desc: Fundamental principles of quality control in the food industry: measurement of quality parameters, utilization and integration of the individual test procedures into grades and standards of quality, sampling, and reporting results.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Safety (3)
desc: Discussion of potential microbiological, parasitic, chemical, and natural food hazards; food laws and standards; and related aspects of consumer protection. Pre: (181, BIOL 171, and CHEM 272) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Chemistry Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Application of different chemical methods in the study of food constituents—proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, pigments, enzymes, etc. Pre: 430 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Chemistry (3)
desc: Chemical properties of food constituents studied in relationship to their effects on processing, nutrition, and spoilage. Pre: CHEM 161 and 161L or consent.
metadata: DP College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Sensors and Instrumentation for Biological Systems (3)
desc: Design course focused on fundamentals of electronic interfacing, control and automation, including biological processes. Topics include sensor physics, basic instrumentation, digital communication, and programming of microcontrollers and other portable computer systems. Pre: (ECE 160, ECE 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
metadata: DP College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Engineering (3)
desc: Principles and applications of thermodynamics, electricity, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, psychrometry, and material and energy balances of food processing and preservation. Pre: (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, PHYS 151 or PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as BE 411 and MBBE 411)
metadata: DP College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Microbiology of Foods (3)
desc: Microorganisms encountered in foods; types of food spoilage; microbial hazards in food; methods of food preservation. Pre: (MICR 130 and MICR 140L, or MICR 351 and MICR 351L) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Nutritional Assessment (3)
desc: Addresses concepts and uses of nutrition assessment tools at individual and community levels. Students will be introduced to national surveys and new, more sophisticated body composition measurements. Includes an emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. Pre: (185 and 370 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Experimental Foods Laboratory (1)
desc: Experimental approach to study food preparation, food formulation, and sensory evaluation with laboratory exercises in a certified kitchen environment. Applying basic food science research design to conduct experiments, interpret data and write reports. A-F only. Pre: (181/181L, CHEM 161/161L) with a minimum grade of D. Co-requisite: 381.
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Experimental Foods (3)
desc: Experimental approach to study food preparation problems. Applying basic food science research design to conduct experiments, interpret data and write reports. Subject matter used to practice critical thinking and problem solving skills. A-F only. Pre: (181/181L, CHEM 161/161L) with a minimum grade of C. Co-requisite: 381L.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Lifespan Nutrition (3)
desc: Physiological changes and nutritional requirements during human life stages: prepregnancy, pregnancy, infancy, childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and older adulthood. Includes an emphasis on writing instruction. Pre: B or better in 185; C or better in CHEM 161/161L; C or better in PHYL 142/142L (or concurrent)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Applied Professional Skills in Nutrition (1)
desc: Will apply skills in technology, research, and career development to nutrition. Students will identify evidence-based nutrition information and demonstrate their academic skill sets for future professional success through technology. Pre: 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Humans, Food, and Animals: Ethics, Issues, and Controversies (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Ethical issues and other controversies related to human and animal needs; their impact on resource sustainability and quality of life are explored from scientific perspectives. A-F only. Pre: 181 or 185 or ANSC 200 or ANSC 201. (Cross-listed as ANSC 350)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Marketing Nutrition and Food (2)
desc: (1 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Fundamental marketing principles applied to nutrition and food. Will include concepts such as the psychology of food purchasing decisions and consumer behavior. Field trips and group projects included. Open to non-majors. Pre: 181/181L, 185, 312; or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Service Production and Operations (3)
desc: Principles and procedures of menu planning, quantity food production, production scheduling, recipe adaptation, equipment operation, and formula costing. Principles of procurement including purchasing, selection, storage of equipment and quantity foods. Pre: (181 and 181L) with a minimum grade of C, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Service Systems Management (3)
desc: Critical and essential aspects of management and effective leadership practices to direct and delivery quality foodservices. Focus on the role and competencies of the Registered Dietitian (RD) working in these environments. Pre: (181 and 181L (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Comparative Nutrition (3)
desc: Digestive systems and nutrient functions, interrelationships and metabolism are compared among animal species, including humans. An intermediate, general nutrition course for Food Science and Human Nutrition and Animal Science majors. Pre: (ANSC 200 (or concurrent), CHEM 161/161L or higher) with a minimum grade of C. (Cross-listed as ANSC 244)
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: The Science of Human Nutrition (3)
desc: Integration of natural science concepts basic to the study of human nutrition. Emphasis on nutrient requirements of healthy individuals, food sources, functions of nutrients.
metadata: DB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Preparation Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Experiments in foods emphasizing ingredient function and standard preparation methods for food groups. Co-requisite: 181.
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Introduction to Food Preparation (3)
desc: Lectures, discussions, and demonstrations on how food components contribute to the functional, sensory, and safety characteristics of foods, and what changes occur in foods due to preparation, processing, and storage. Co-requisite: 181L.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Culture and Cuisine: The Global Diversity of Food (3)
desc: A timeline of the world history of food and how it relates to culture, diversity, ethnicity, and religion. International food demonstrations and tastings included.
metadata: FGB College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FSHN
title: Food Service Safety and Sanitation (2)
desc: Principles and procedures of sanitation and safety in the food service industry, including the study of foodborne illnesses, biological, chemical, physical hazards and cross-contamination as they may occur during the flow of food.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Food Science & Human Nutrition (FSHN)

subject: FIN
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in a special area of major under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by department chair and the faculty advisor. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in international management, or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Asian Finance (3)
desc: Provides in-depth review of scholarly journal articles and working papers relevant to Asian-Pacific financial markets to prepare PhD students for scholarly research work focusing on market microstructure, corporate finance, investments. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in business administration, or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Corporate Finance (3)
desc: Covers research issues in corporate finance and financial markets. Topics include capital structure theory, corporate governance, corporate innovations, and mergers and acquisitions, etc. Student develop academic research papers that lead to dissertation work. A-F only. Pre: student status in PhD in business administration, or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Seminar in Investments (3)
desc: Covers research issues in investments. Topics include empirical asset pricing tests, characteristics of asset returns, behavioral finance, and investment issues that overlaps with corporate finance, accounting, and economics, etc. A-F only. Pre: PhD student status in business administration, or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Foundations of Finance (3)
desc: First PhD course in finance. Covers basic theory and empirical methodology in asset pricing, provides a concise framework of conceptual knowledge to understand the literature on financial theory and related empirical evidence. A-F only. Pre: graduate students only.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Healthcare Financial Management (3)
desc: Focus on important accounting and financial management principles relevant to management of health services organizations. Designed around a series of cases that examine the issues that confront healthcare managers. A-F only. Pre: BUS 629. (Alt. years: fall only)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Research Seminar (3)
desc: Students either program a model or write a paper with high practical or scientific merit. Outcome enhances the chances for employment. Represents the culminating experience for students in this program. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Seminar in Finance (3)
desc: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and issues in finance. Pre: BUS 629 or consent. May be repeated with change in topic.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Mortgage/Weather Derivatives (3)
desc: Covers the real estate market, mortgage backed securities (MBSs) and real estate derivatives. Focuses on modelling weather, climate change, and weather derivatives. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Financial Modelling (3)
desc: Addresses advanced techniques in financial modelling and related fields. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Interest Rate/Credit Models (3)
desc: Addresses specific properties of interest rate modelling as mean reversion as well as latest developments in credit risk modelling. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Insurance and Risk Management (3)
desc: Introduces students to topics in the actuarial science and latest developments in risk management. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Financial Forecasting (3)
desc: Focus on financial forecasting and financial econometrics as volatility and correlation modeling. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Financial Derivatives (3)
desc: Will familiarize the students with the mathematical foundation and the application of Futures, Swaps, and Options. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Portfolio Optimization (3)
desc: Introduces students to principles of capital markets, classical portfolio theory, and focus on portfolio optimization. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Programming in Finance (3)
desc: Addresses programming principles, and programming languages used in financial modeling. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: PDEs and Stochastic Calculus (3)
desc: Covers PDEs (Partial Differential Equations) and calculus in a stochastic environment. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Advanced Capital Markets (3)
desc: Regulatory structure over capital market institutions, market developmental issues, market microstructure issues, and corporate governance, and creation of capital market infrastructure. Seminar format. Pre: BUS 629 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Entrepreneurial Finance (3)
desc: Assessment of financial needs, arranging venture financing, assessing value to the entrepreneur and the investor(s), financial aspects of strategic planning, analyzing the tradeoffs between alternative financing choices and flexibility and control, harvesting the investment. Pre: BUS 629 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: International Banking (3)
desc: Commercial, investment, and merchant banking in the international arena. Includes international lending, Euromarkets, global gap management, Forex activities, and international risk management. Pre: BUS 629 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: International Financial Management (3)
desc: Financial decision-making in an international setting: analysis of direct foreign investment; economic, accounting, and regulatory environments, including taxation; international money and capital markets; import and export financing; multinational working capital management; and risk aspects of international finance. Pre: BUS 629 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: (Alpha) Advanced Topics in Finance (3)
desc: Major current financial issues and problems. (C) Japanese financial management; (D) portfolio management theory; (F) stocks, bonds, and modern instruments. Pre: BUS 629 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Investment Analysis and Management (3)
desc: Techniques of security analysis, theories of investment, and the analysis of investment decisions related to portfolio planning. Pre: BUS 629 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Problems in Business Finance (3)
desc: Application of financial principles and analytical techniques to financial problems. Case method. Pre: BUS 629 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: International Monetary Systems and Global Financial Markets (3)
desc: Supply and demand for capital in national and international markets. Nature of capital movements and role of capital in industrialization of regions and nations.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: (Alpha) Advanced Topics in Finance (3)
desc: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and issues in finance. (B) equity research and corporate valuation methods; (C) Japanese financial management; (D) financial analysis; (E) retirement and employee benefit planning; (F) finance estate planning. Repeatable four times for (D). Shidler College of Business students only. A-F only for (E) and (F). Pre: 311 and BUS 314 for (B); BUS 314 or BUS 629 for (C); 311 or 629, or consent for (D); 301 for (E) and (F). (Fall only for (B))
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Seminar in Financial Planning (3)
desc: A capstone course for financial services and planning track. This is a case study course intended to provide students the opportunity to integrate concepts from earlier courses and develop a comprehensive view of the financial planning process. A-F only. Pre: 301 and 311 and two of the following courses: 490E, 490F, ACC 401, INS 300.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Special Topics in Finance, Real Estate or Insurance (3)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems in the field of finance and finance-related fields. Repeatable two times in different topics. Pre: BUS 314 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Enterprise Risk Management (3)
desc: Overview analyzing various primary risks faced by corporations and developing important risk management techniques with an emphasis on enterprise risk management. Combined lectures, case studies, and discussions. BUS majors only. A-F only. Pre: BUS 314 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Asian Finance (3)
desc: Financial systems, regulatory structure over financial institutions in the Asia-Pacific region. Major financial policy issues for financial sector reforms in the region. Seminar format. A-F only. Pre: BUS 314 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Banking and Capital Markets (3)
desc: Covers the analytical skills necessary to work in the financial services industry, in particular in the bank treasury department or the fixed income capital market sector. A-F only. Pre: BUS 314 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Bank Financial Management (3)
desc: Analysis of financial institution management within the domestic economy and regulatory environment. Topics include federal reserve activities, interest rates, regulation, lending, investments, and asset/liability management. Pre: BUS 314.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Security Analysis and Portfolio Management (3)
desc: Security analysis and portfolio management from standpoint of the professional analyst and institutional investor. Recent advances in security valuation models, portfolio selection, and techniques for appraising portfolio performance. College restriction: Shidler students only. A-F only. Pre: 311.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Options and Other Derivatives (3)
desc: Options and other derivatives. Equity options, index options and options on futures. Black-Scholos Model. Trading strategies and tactics. Contemporary developments in financial engineering. A-F only. Pre: 311 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Reading and research in a special area of major under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and the faculty advisor. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Financial Aspects of New Ventures (3)
desc: Examination of underlying business models for new ventures, how to determine corresponding financial requirements, and approaches to resource acquisition. Students explore a range of financing sources and related issues of valuation and deal structure. College restriction: Shidler students only. Pre: junior standing and BUS 314, or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: International Banking (3)
desc: Commercial, investment, and merchant banking. Includes theory and practical applications. Topics include international lending, Euromarkets, global gap management, Forex activities, and global risk management. Pre: BUS 314 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: International Business Finance (3)
desc: Financial management of foreign and international business operations: the regulatory environment of international finance, financing international transactions, international capital markets, taxation. Financial decision-making in the firm. Pre: BUS 314 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Investments (3)
desc: Introduction to various investment media and capital markets. Topics include the analysis of security returns using techniques such as beta, filter rules, and portfolio theory. Pre: BUS 314 or consent.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Corporate Financial Management (3)
desc: Development and analysis of modern financial theory and its implications for management decisions: market efficiency, capital asset pricing, firm investment decisions, capital structure, dividend policy, and cost of capital. Pre: BUS 314.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Problems of Business Finance (3)
desc: Application of financial principles to cases involving important financial decisions; emphasis on writing. Pre: BUS 314.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: FIN
title: Personal Financial Planning (3)
desc: Focuses on principles and techniques for handling personal financial decisions, including: personal budgeting, obtaining credit, life and casualty insurance, buying a home, buying an automobile, savings and investments, and retirement planning.
metadata: Finance (FIN) Shidler College of Business

subject: ZOOL
title: Comparative Physiology (3)
desc: Physicalchemical cellular mechanisms underlying function of organ systems; general principles inferable from study of adaption to diverse environments. Pre: BIOL 171 and 172, and MBBE 402 (or concurrent) or BIOC 441 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: FIL
title: Filipino Contemporary Literature: 1980s-Present (3)1
desc: Survey of literature from the 80s (1986) to the present. Co-curricular cultural activities included. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: DL Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Filipino Contemporary Literature (3)
desc: Selected readings in poetry, short stories, and plays from early 1900s to present. Co-curricular cultural activities included. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: DL Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Structure of Filipino (3)
desc: Introduction to phonology, morphology, syntax. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: DH Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Filipino Translation Techniques (3)
desc: Techniques of bilingual translation: Filipino to English and English to Filipino. A-F only. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Advanced Filipino Aural Comprehension (3)
desc: Continuation of 315. Training in comprehension and analysis/criticism of spoken authentic materials through films. Pre: 315 or consent.
metadata: DL Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Fourth-Level Filipino II (3)
desc: Advanced reading in current literature; discussion of cultural implications; advanced conversation and composition. Meets three hours weekly. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Fourth-Level Filipino I (3)
desc: Advanced reading in traditional literature; discussion of cultural implications; advanced oral communication and composition. Meets three hours weekly. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Filipino Film: Art and History (3)
desc: Study and analysis of Filipino films: its history, forms, development and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical, and aesthetic context. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: DH Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Filipino Aural Comprehension (3)
desc: Training in comprehension of spoken authentic/ simulated authentic materials presented in news broadcasts, songs, documentary narration, formal lectures, radio and television soap operas, etc. Pre: 202 or consent.
metadata: Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Accelerated Third-Level Filipino (6)
metadata: Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Third-Level Filipino II (3)
desc: Conversation, advanced reading, and composition on contemporary issues. Meets three hours weekly. Pre: 202 or 225, or consent.
metadata: Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Third-Level Filipino I (3)
desc: Conversation, advanced reading and composition on traditional culture and indigenous knowledge. Includes emphasis on developing oral communication and written skills. Meets three hours weekly. Pre: 202 or 225, or consent.
metadata: Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Filipino for Education (4)
desc: Continuation of 202 or 224.
metadata: HSL Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Filipino for Education (4)
desc: Continuation of 102. Lessons focus on various aspects of Philippine culture and specialized topics that cater to the needs of teachers intending to teach Filipino immigrant students or teach Filipino as a second language. Meets five hours a week; daily lab work. Pre: 102.
metadata: HSL Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Intermediate Filipino (4)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201 or consent.
metadata: HSL Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Intermediate Filipino (4)
desc: Continuation of 102. Meets four hours weekly, includes one hour out-of-class field experience (Co-curricular cultural activities) weekly. Pre: 102 or consent.
metadata: HSL Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Beginning Filipino (4)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101 or consent.
metadata: HSL Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FIL
title: Beginning Filipino (4)
desc: Listening, speaking, reading, writing skills. Structural points introduced inductively. Meets four hours weekly, includes one hour out-of-class field experience (Co-curricular cultural activities) weekly.
metadata: HSL Filipino (FIL) Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: FDM
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to 15 credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Field Study in the Fashion Industry (V)
desc: Study tours to various centers of the world to examine historical and modern apparel and textiles. Merchandising and design methods and operations examined. Repeatable up to 12 credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: ZOOL
title: Animal Physiology (5)
desc: Lecture/laboratory introduction to animal physiology, especially vetebrates. Topics include nerve and muscle physiology, metabolism, circulation, respiration, excretion, thermoregulation in a project-driven format. Labs develop skills in experimental biology, morphology, data analysis, and scientific writing. A-F only. Pre: BIOL 275.
metadata: DB DY College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Developmental Biology Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Labs) Analysis of animal development by experimental methods, using local organisms. Pre: 420 (or concurrent) and BIOL 275, or consent. Recommended: BIOL 407.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Developmental Biology (3)
