desc: Fundamental principles, methods, concepts, and significance of developmental biology, emphasizing experimental methods. Pre: BIOL 275. Recommended: BIOL 407.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: FDM
title: Internship (4)
desc: Examination of issues and opportunities associated with careers in fashion and related businesses and industries. Topics include interpersonal skills development, job search and interview strategies, and ethical issues in the workplace. FDM majors only. A-F only. Junior standing or higher. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Topics in Fashion (V)
desc: Study and discussion of special topics, problems. Offered by staff and visiting faculty. Repeatable five times.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: International Apparel Trade Issues (3)
desc: Theories, concepts, problems of international trade of textile and apparel products. Issues of importing and exporting apparel products globally. Social, economic, and ethical factors affecting textile and apparel trade.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Costume Museum Management (3)
desc: Investigation of skills and techniques needed for handling textile and apparel artifacts in museums and other collections. Active involvement in documenting, researching, interpreting, and exhibiting costumes and textiles. Involves written work and oral presentations. Repeatable one time. FDM majors only. A-F only. Pre: 210, 269, or 418.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Entrepreneurship in Retail (3)
desc: Application of principles, procedures and techniques of organizing a small retail business in a brick-and-click world. Students develop, write, and evaluate business plans creatively using low and high tech resources and oral communication skills. Junior standing or higher. FDM majors only; open to non-majors with instructor’s consent. Pre: one FS or FQ course, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Fashion Show Production (4)
desc: Application of principles and procedures related to the promotion of fashion apparel. Preparation and presentation of fashion information through shows, displays, media, and written communications. Repeatable one time. Pre: 101. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Runway Design Collection Studio (3)
desc: Development of runway collection. Topic includes: inspirational research, developing aesthetic design, sketching, draping, drafting, patternmaking, muslin proofs, fittings, garment construction, and portfolio. FDM 420 enrollment required to showcase a collection in an annual fashion show. Repeatable three times. Pre: 210, 221, 315, 316, and 330. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Costumes/Cultures of East Asia (3)
desc: Development of ethnic dress of China, Japan, and Korea as a visual manifestation of culture. Students will be trained in written communication skills to describe and report important designs of these ethnic dresses related to culture.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Product Lifecycle Management (3)
desc: Application of principles of apparel production management, including methods engineering (detail construction for ordering), story boards and color tables, production measurements, costing, and PLM computer applications. A-F only. Pre: 338 (Once a year)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Merchandise Planning and Control (3)
desc: Theories, problems, and procedures of financial and assortment planning and control of merchandise inventories. FDM majors and merchandising minors only. Pre: 371.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Retail Buying and Merchandising (3)
desc: Theories and procedures in selecting, buying and selling apparel and textiles. Types of merchandising organizations, analysis of consumer demand, brick-and-click opportunities and challenges, development of an image, operation location, store and floor layout. FDM majors only. Pre: 101 and 221.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Writing for the Fashion Industry (3)
desc: Analysis and creation of different types of writing in the fashion industry, with emphasis on creating a professional writing style. A-F only. Pre: 101, 200 or 210, and 221.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: 3D Retail Store Design (3)
desc: Visual merchandising concepts and planning; use of a virtual 3D store modeling software package. Visual Retailing/ Mockshop, to design store interiors, fixtures, lighting, signage, window displays, and planograms. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: 2D/3D Computer Aided Design (3)
desc: Exploration of CAD applications from the design to the pattern-making process. Use of Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop for fashion illustration. Use of OptiTex PDS pattern design software featuring 2D and 3D CAD. Repeatable one time.
metadata: DA College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Advanced Apparel Design and Construction Techniques (3)
desc: Principles of advanced techniques for garment construction with emphasis on new, difficult-to-handle fabrics. Repeatable one time. Pre: 205 and 215.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Textiles Quality Assurance Laboratory (1)
desc: Examination of textile properties through standardized textiles testing laboratory equipment. FDM majors only. A-F only. Pre: 221 or consent. Co-requisite: 321. (Spring only)
metadata: DY College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Textiles Quality Assurance (3)
desc: Chemical nature and structure of fibers and fabrics, their properties and finishes. FDM majors only. A-F only. Pre: 221 or consent. Co-requisite: 321L. (Spring only)
metadata: DP College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Specialty Market Design: Group Collection Development (3)
desc:
Advanced study in the specialty market design, pattern making, and 
construction for fashion design majors. Different specialty designs, such as swimwear, menswear, or others, will be offered each semester. Repeatable five times. Pre: 215, 221, and 301. Recommended: 315, 330. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Draping Essentials (3)
desc:
Principles of pattern making through draping muslin models on standard 
garment forms. Pre: 205 and 215. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Fashion Forecasting/Marketing (3)
desc: Principles and practices in fashion trend forecasting, including environment in analysis, consumer research, competitive analysis, color and textile forecasting, style directions, and digital marketing trends. Adapting fashion trend forecasts to apparel lines. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: one FW or FG course, or consent.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Textiles I (3)
desc: Introduction to fibers, fabric structure, and finishes related to selection and care. Interrelationship between textile characteristics, properties, and end uses. Open to non-majors. A-F only.
metadata: DP College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: BIOL
title: Corals and Coral Reefs (3)
desc:
The biogeography, evolution, ecology, and physiology of corals and coral reefs, and the application of this information to the management of coral reefs. Emphasis will be placed on processes such as dispersal, the evolution and operation of mutualisms, calcification, 
reproduction, and the maintenance of diversity. Pre: 265 (or concurrent) or 301 (or concurrent). (Spring only)
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ZOOL
title: Directed Study (V)
desc: Pre: written consent.
metadata: College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Parasitology Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 340. Pre: 340 (or concurrent) and BIOL 275.
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: BIOL
title: Parasitology (2)
desc: Animal parasites of man, and domestic and wild animals; systematics, comparative morphology, life history, pathology, treatment, control. Pre: 275.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Biology of the Vertebrates Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 325. Pre: 172 and 172L. Co-requisite: 325.
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Biology of the Vertebrates (3)
desc: Introduction to the evolution and systematics of vertebrates, with emphasis on comparative morphology, physiology, and ecology. Pre: BIOL 171 and 172. Co-requisite: 325L.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Ethology Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Application of methods in the study of animal behavior by demonstrations, labs and projects. Pre: 306 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Ethology (3)
desc: Introduction to animal and human ethology and sociobiology; emphasis on social and interspecific behavior, its causes and adaptive significance. Lab optional. Pre: 171 and 171L and 172 and 172L or ANSC 201; or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ZOOL
title: Marine Biology Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory, field trips to accompany 200. Pre: 200 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Marine Biology (3)
desc: Biology and ecology of marine plants and animals; coral reefs, the deep sea, rocky shores, marine mammals, fisheries, aquaculture, pollution, and conservation of marine resources.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Principles of Zoology Laboratory (1)
desc: Laboratory to accompany 101. Pre: 101 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: ZOOL
title: Principles of Zoology (3)
desc: Structure, development, physiology, reproduction, evolution, behavior, and ecology of animals.
metadata: DB College of Natural Sciences Zoology (ZOOL)

subject: FDM
title: Fashion Illustration (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles and techniques of sketching the fashion figure including garment details and fabric drape. Development of a personal style of illustration. Introduction to use of computers for illustration. Pre: 101.
metadata: DA College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Flat Pattern Design (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of pattern making for women’s apparel through manipulation of pattern blocks. Pre: 205.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Western World Fashion History (3)
desc: Historic study of dress as related to customs and cultures in the Western world, in sociohistorical and contemporary contexts. Emphasis on 19th and 20th centuries. Pre: 101.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Basic Apparel Construction (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles, concepts, and procedures for quality construction and custom fitting of clothing.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Culture, Gender, and Appearance (3)
desc: Social construction of gender within culture and its visual expression through appearance. Analysis of role, identity, conformity, and deviance in human appearance. Repeatable one time. Open to nonmajors. (Cross-listed as WGSS 200)
metadata: DS College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FDM
title: Introduction to the Fashion Industry (3)
desc: Introduction to the fields of apparel design and merchandising including theories of fashion change, apparel industry operations, current industry issues, literature of the field, professional competencies, careers in apparel and related businesses. A-F only.
metadata: College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources Fashion Design & Merchandising (FDM)

subject: FMCH
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Family Medicine and Community Health (FMCH) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: FMCH
title: (Alpha) Electives in Family Medicine and Community Health (V)
desc: Fourth-year elective in which medical students may do study of selected topics within the field of family medicine and community health: (B) primary care preceptorship; (C) topics in community health; (D) sub-internship in family medicine; (E) extramural elective in family medicine and community health-miscellaneous; (F) sports medicine preceptorship; (G) longitudinal underserved care preceptorship (6). MED majors only for (G). CR/NC only. Pre: 531 or 532. (Spring only for (G))
metadata: Family Medicine and Community Health (FMCH) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: FMCH
title: Family Medicine and Community Health Longitudinal Clerkship (10)
desc: 5.5-month ambulatory clerkship. Students learn history taking, physical exam skills, and management of family medicine patients. Emphasis on behavioral care, caring for the underserved, sports medicine, preventive care, and common acute/chronic ambulatory problems. Repeatable one time. Co-requisite: third-year standing and concurrent registration in 532 courses.
metadata: Family Medicine and Community Health (FMCH) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ESEE
title: Seminar for Student Teaching (2)
desc: Seminar to support student teaching experiences and prepare teacher candidates to transition into a full time teacher, examine ethical issues in the field, prepare for employment, and demonstrate ability to meet professional standards. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Student Teaching in Elementary and Special Education Classrooms (10)
desc: Full-time student teaching in grades K-6 in an elementary school inclusion classroom, or a combination of general education and special education settings. The experience is directed by a qualified mentor teacher and has university-provided supervision. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Field Experience III: Elementary and Special Education Classroom Settings (4)
desc: Teacher candidates are immersed in a general education, inclusion, or a self-contained special education field setting. A mentor teacher and a field supervisor from the university provide support and oversight. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Field Experience II: Elementary and Special Education Classroom Settings (4)
desc: Teacher candidates are immersed in a general education, inclusion, or a self-contained special education field setting. A mentor teacher and a field supervisor from the university provide support and oversight. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Field Rounds (2)
desc: Field-based course engages teacher candidates in a variety of purposeful observation and reflection activities aligned with course work. Field settings are appropriate to concurrent classes; supervision provided by participating site personnel and college supervisor. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Field Experience I: Response to Intervention in Reading (4)
desc: Teacher candidates in this field based course will use an evidencebased practice in reading within a response to intervention (Rtl) framework. Supervision provided by participating site personnel and college supervisor. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Planning and Instruction, Literacy III: Writing and Visual Arts in Inclusive Settings, K-6 (3)
desc: Methods, programs, and strategies for planning, teaching, and assessing writing for elementary students in inclusive settings, grades K-6. Visual arts methods are integrated to develop visual literacy. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Planning and Instruction, Literacy II: Teaching Children to Read in Inclusive Settings, Grades 4-6 (3)
desc: Teacher candidates demonstrate essential reading comprehension strategies, engaging students in complex text by planning, instructing, and assessing elementary students in grades 4-6, in inclusive settings. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Planning and Instruction, Literacy I: Teaching Children to Read in Inclusive Settings, K-3 (3)
desc: Overview of principles and practices for teaching reading (phonemic awareness, phonics, fluency, vocabulary, comprehension) to diverse students, grades K-3; including planning, instruction, and assessment. Writing assignments include lesson reflections, case studies, modules, and reading responses. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Planning and Instruction: Integrating Social Studies and the Performing Arts (3)
desc: Social Studies and Performing Arts integrated content in diverse K-6 classrooms. Teacher candidates engage with social issues through collaborative, expressive, aesthetic, creative, and critical pedagogy. Candidates perform, present, and teach to develop oral communication skills. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Planning and Instruction: STEM (3)
desc: Examination of content, processes, strategies, and issues related to teaching and learning of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) content for inclusive elementary classrooms, K-6. Teacher candidates focus on planning, teaching, and assessing STEM. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Planning and Instruction: Mathematics in Inclusive Settings (3)
desc: Prepares beginning elementary school teachers of mathematics, K-6. Candidates learn to differentiate instruction based on learner needs, planning to facilitate inclusion of students with disabilities in the general education environment through evidence-based practices. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Planning and Instruction: Science (3)
desc: Examination of content, processes, strategies, and issues related to the teaching and learning of science in elementary settings, K-6. Candidates learn to differentiate instruction based on learner needs, using evidence-based practices. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Planning and Instruction: Introduction to Inclusive Teaching (3)
desc: Teacher candidates engage in reflective, procedural, and research writing to differentiate instruction based on learner needs, planning to facilitate inclusion of students with disabilities in the general education environment through evidence-based practices. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Assessment II: Formal Assessment (3)
desc: Understand techniques in the assessment, planning, and instructional process appropriate for students with mild/moderate disabilities. Inclusion of students with disabilities in the general education environment is stressed. Significant instruction on writing individualized education programs. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Assessment I: Foundations of Assessment (3)
desc: Introduction to foundational aspects of assessment and emphasizes the importance of linking assessment with planning and instruction. Candidates develop knowledge, skills, and dispositions important for designing, implementing, and analyzing effective assessments for diverse learners. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Learner in the Environment III: Behavior Project Implementation (3)
desc: Teacher candidates demonstrate the ability to establish, maintain, and (when necessary) restore the classroom as an effective environment for teaching and learning. Candidates demonstrate ability to identify maladaptive student behaviors and implement effective, research-based interventions. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Learner in the Environment II: Classroom and Behavior Management (3)
desc: Teacher candidates explore the ethical implications for establishing, maintaining, and restoring the classroom as an effective environment for teaching and learning. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ESEE
title: Learner in the Environment I: Social and Cultural Contexts for Learning (3)
desc: Knowledge and skills related to the context of teaching. Teacher candidates will examine the impact of culture, family, school, classroom, and individual characteristics on learning, and orally present, in varied formats, acquired knowledge and competencies. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Exceptional Students and Elementary Education (ESEE)

subject: ES
title: Special Topics in Ethnic Studies (3)
desc: Selected themes in ethnic studies exploring current issues and new topics; taught by regular and visiting faculty. Repeatable two times. Pre: one 300-level DS or DH course.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Hawai‘i’s Labor History (3)
desc: Conditions of work under varying political, social, and economic transformations in Hawai‘i; anthropological, sociological, and historic data. Pre: one DS or DH course or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Oral History: Theory and Practice (3)
desc: Literature, methodology, ethics and project design of oral history research. Students develop and execute an oral history project. (Cross-listed as ANTH 493)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Politics of Multiculturalism (3)
desc: The development of ethnic relations and political approaches to multiculturalism in two multiethnic nations: Canada and the U.S. A-F only. Pre: SOC 300 or one 300 level ES course, or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 492)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Peoples of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Critically examines the historical and contemporary experiences of various people of Hawai‘i using anthropological and ethnic studies approaches. Emphasis on cultural perspectives and values of peoples indigenous to Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia. Pre: junior standing or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ANTH 486)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Practices and Methods in Oceanic Ethnic Studies (3)
desc: Engagement with theoretical elements and qualitative and quantitative research methods of Oceanic Ethnic Studies: theories of class, race, indignity, migrancy, diaspora and political economy; community-based and participatory research methods. A-F only. Pre: one upper division ES or SOCS course or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Latinx Experience in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Examines historical, socio-cultural, and contemporary Latinx presence; relations among Latinx, other immigrant, and Indigenous communities; causes and patterns of immigration; racism and discrimination; ethnicity and identity issues; struggles for justice. Pre: one DH or DS course, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Global Ethnic Conflict (3)
desc: Ethnic conflicts cause most wars on our globe today. Examines causes of ethnic conflict, including climate change. Will evaluate approaches to building peaceful relations between groups and developing sustainable relationships with the environment. Junior standing or higher. Pre: one DS or DH course or consent. (Crosslisted as SUST 461)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Racism and Ethnicity in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: The historical and contemporary social processes involved in inter-ethnic relations in Hawai‘i. Pre: SOC 300 or one ES 300 level course, or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 456)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: (Alpha) Topics in Comparative Ethnic Conflict (3)
desc: Causes and dynamics of ethnic conflicts with attention to problem resolution; (B) Middle East; (C) Hawaiian sovereignty in Pacific context. Pre: one DS or DH course, or consent for (C). ((C) Cross-listed as SUST 455)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Filipino Americans: Research Topics (3)
desc: A research seminar on the study of Filipino Americans. Special themes in film/video/media, the performing arts, or literature may be offered. Pre: junior standing or consent. (Cross-listed as AMST 401)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Contemporary Diasporas in Comparative Perspective (3)
desc: Compares the circumstances under which contemporary Asian, Pacific Islander, or African migrants form diasporas across the globe; focus on a particular ethnic group to examine its site-specific experiences. A-F only.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Filming Social Change (3)
desc: Introduction to visual documentary theory and methods. Basic instruction in using digital video technology and hands-on production to tell visual stories and examine social issues related to diverse peoples, cultures, and communities through video projects. A-F only. Pre: one DH or DS course, or consent. (Cross-listed as COM 425)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Mixed Race Identities, Multiracial Experiences (3)
desc: Critically examines historical and contemporary issues surrounding mixed race identities and experiences through themes that resonate in localized contexts within the continental U.S. and Oceania. Pre: one DH or DS course, or consent.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: American Ethnic and Race Relations (3)
desc: Surveys ethnic and race relations in the U.S. Focus on historical conflicts and critical issues such as racism, immigration, affirmative action, changing economic structures, and the role of government. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Women and Work (3)
desc: Gender and race of paid and unpaid work in the formal and informal sectors of the economy; carework in households; unemployment; ethics of revaluing feminized work; labor rights: scope: local and global. Pre: one 300-level ES or WGSS course, or SOC 300; or consent. (Cross-listed as SOC 418 and WGSS 418)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Race, Class, and the Law (3)
desc: Historical context and implications of landmark court decisions and legal issues affecting social change in ethnic communities in Hawai‘i and the continental U.S. Pre: one DS or DH course or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to 6 credits. Pre: consent only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Multiethnic Popular Culture: Hip Hop (3)
desc: Historical, social, cultural, and political aspects of the formation and development of Hip Hop culture in Hawai‘i and other Pacific islands. Special attention to the significance of Hip Hop in facilitating cultural interactions. Junior standing or higher. Pre: one DS or DH course or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Change in the Pacific—Polynesia (3)
desc: Impact of cultural and physical change and their interrelationship. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Oceanic Gender, Sexual, and Kinship Identities (3)
desc: Oceania-centric perspective. Analysis of imperialism, colonialism, gender, sexuality, race, ethnicity, and queer(ed) relations and identities in Hawai‘i and the Pacific. Junior standing or higher. Pre: one DS or DH course, or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 371)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Gender and Race in U.S. Society (3)
desc: Historical and sociological studies of race and gender in U.S. society; grassroots feminist and racial/justice activism on the continent and in Hawai‘i. A-F only. Pre: 101 or WGSS 151 or junior standing. (Cross-listed as WGSS 390)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Social Movements in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Examines, through writing and collaboration, interethnic movement building among Native Hawaiian, other Pacific Islander, and Asian peoples of Hawai‘i through intersectional theories of social change to evaluate strategies to create just and sustainable futures. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Fieldwork in Ethnic Studies (V)
desc: Supervision of individual student research projects pertinent to ethnic studies, including service learning, civic engagement, internship, oral history, or supervised practicum experience in teaching select ethnic studies courses. Repeatable to total of 6 credit hours. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Issues of Diversity in Higher Education (3)
desc: Examines issues of diversity within higher education. Examines different dimensions of diversity including ethnicity, gender, national origin, age, and sexual orientation. Will utilize national and local case studies. Junior class standing or higher. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Filipino Americans: History, Culture and Politics (3)
desc: An introduction to the study of Filipino Americans in the U.S. and the diaspora. The course pays special attention to labor migration, cultural production and community politics. Pre: sophomore standing. (Cross-listed as AMST 373)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Asian American Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of Asian American literature by writers from a variety of backgrounds. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as ENG 372)
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Literatures of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Writings of various ethnic groups in Hawai‘i, ancient to contemporary. Songs, stories, poetry, fiction, essays that illustrate the social history of Hawai‘i. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as ENG 370)
metadata: DL College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Pacific/Asian Women in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Adaptive strategies of Hawaiian, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Filipino, Samoan, and Southeast Asian women in Hawai‘i; feminist anthropological and historical analysis. Pre: one ANTH, SOC, or WGSS course. (Cross-listed as WGSS 360)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Immigration to Hawai‘i and U.S. (3)
desc: Historical overview: “push and pull factors”; effect of changing economy; experiences of various ethnic groups; problems of recent immigrants; immigration policies in the U.S. and Hawai‘i. Pre: one DS course.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Economic Change and Hawai‘i’s People (3)
desc: Hawai‘i’s economic transformation from sustainable communal subsistence through mercantile capitalism, plantation capitalism, and global finance capital and impact on its people. Alternative sustainable enterprises for a self-sufficient island economy. Pre: one DS or DH course. (Cross-listed as SUST 351)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Land Tenure and Use in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Dynamics of change: indigenous Hawaiian land tenure; Great Mahele and Kuleana Act; ethnic succession of land ownership; concentration of ownership today; effects of land development on ethnic communities. Pre: one DS or DH course. (Cross-listed as SUST 341)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: South Asian Migrants: Culture and Politics (3)
desc: Historical and contemporary experiences of South Asian migrants in North America, Pacific, Caribbean, and/or African diasporas; causes and patterns of migration, inter-ethnic relations policies; role of race, gender, culture in community, identity formation. A-F only. Pre one ES or WGSS course in the 100, 200 or 300 level; or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as WGSS 339)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: American Indian Experience (3)
desc: Provides a comprehensive look at the indigenous foundation of life and society in the Americas and elaborates on historical and contemporary importance of American Indian rights issues. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Filipinos in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Historical and contemporary experiences; immigration; traditional culture and values; plantation experience; labor organizing; development of Filipino community; racism; discrimination; and ethnic identity. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Power and Place: Chinatowns (3)
desc: Historical and contemporary experiences of Chinese in Hawai‘i and the U.S. continent with a focus on Chinatowns; urbanization; economic development, community organizing; comparative racialization. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Japanese in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Issei roots in Japan; the role of Japanese in labor, politics, and business; sansei and perspectives on local identity and culture. The Japanese in light of changing economic, social, and political conditions in Hawai‘i today. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Hawai‘i and the Pacific (3)
desc: Hawai‘i as part of the Pacific community: selected historical and contemporary problems of Pacific areas; cultural and economic imperialism, land alienation, and the impact of development on Pacific peoples. Pre: one DS or DH course. (Cross-listed as SUST 321)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Asian America (3)
desc: History of selected Asian immigrant groups from the 19th century to the present. Topics include: immigration and labor history, Asian American movements, literature and cultural productions, community adaptations and identity formation. Pre: junior standing or higher. (Cross-listed as AMST 318)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Ethnicity and Community: Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Site visits to museums, social welfare units, etc., as well as guest lecturers from the community including police, health, education. Pre: one DS or DH course. (Summer only)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Race, Indigeneity, and Environmental Justice (3)
desc: Introduction to environmental justice, explores the premise that all people have a right to a life-affirming environment. Will examine environmental racism, and the geographical dimensions of race and indigeneity. Pre: one DS or DH course, or consent. (Cross-listed as SUST 318)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: African American Experience II (3)
desc: Black sociopolitical perspectives of the Reconstruction period, Jim Crow, intellectual and cultural awakenings, civil rights movements, and contemporary issues as examined through students’ written analysis and creative projects. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: African American Experience I (3)
desc: Afrocentric perspective. Analysis of the black political/cultural diaspora, including ancient African kingdoms, the slavery experience, organized resistance, emancipation struggles, the Civil War and Reconstruction. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Ethnic Identity (3)
desc: Individual and group problems of identity, identity conflict, culture conflict, inter-ethnic relations. Critical review of available material on Hawai‘i. Pre: one DS or DH course.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Hawaiians (3)
desc: The sustainable social system, culture, spirituality, language, land stewardship, and governance of Native Hawaiians. Transformation of the sustainable Hawaiian social system by a capitalist economy. Resiliency, land issues, and Native Hawaiian quest for sovereign governance. (Cross-listed as SUST 222)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Introduction to Race and Ethnic Relations (3)
desc: Race and ethnic relations in world perspective; social, economic, and political problems associated with perception, existence, and accommodation of these groups within the wider society. (Cross-listed as SOC 214)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Race, Class, Gender in Popular Culture (3)
desc: Contemporary issues of race, class, and gender in popular culture (film, television, music, social media, sports, etc.). Introduction to critical media analysis and social science theories and methods.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ES
title: Introduction to Ethnic Studies (3)
desc:
Concepts and theories analyzing ethnic group experiences in relation to colonization, immigration, racism, and social class. Emphasis on cultural perspectives and values 
rooted in the experiences of peoples indigenous to Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Ethnic Studies (ES)

subject: ELI
title: Practicum for International Teaching Assistants (3)
desc: Extensive practice for international teaching assistants in speaking in classroom situations with emphasis on oral skills, American cultural expectations and classroom management. CR/NC only. Pre: 080.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English Language Institute (ELI)

subject: ELI
title: Advanced Academic Writing for Graduate Students (0)
desc: Introduction to academic writing conventions common at the graduate level. Students explore academic writing in their disciplines, develop clarity of written expression, and improve command over textual, rhetorical, and discursive conventions common in academic writing. Pre: 075 or placement by examination.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English Language Institute (ELI)

subject: ELI
title: Advanced Academic Reading (0)
desc: Further development of skills and strategies for dealing with the high demands of academic reading by focusing on becoming efficient and autonomous readers. Instruction and practice of developing critical reading strategies and building field-specific vocabulary. Pre: 075 or placement by examination. CR/NC only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English Language Institute (ELI)

subject: ELI
title: Advanced Academic Listening and Speaking (0)
desc: Further development of the academic English-language listening/speaking skills and strategies required at the university. Instruction and practice of effective note-taking skills, critical listening strategies, delivery of effective academic presentations and leading of academic discussions. Pre: 070 or placement by examination.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English Language Institute (ELI)

subject: ELI
title: Intermediate Academic Listening and Speaking (0)
desc: Introduction to the academic English language listening/speaking demands required at the university. Instruction and practice of effective note-taking skills, listening strategies, delivery of presentations, and participation in academic discussions. Designed as a bridge to ELI 080. CR/ NC only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English Language Institute (ELI)

subject: ESL
title: Composition I for Second Language Writers (3)
desc: Extensive practice in writing expository essays; linguistic devices that make an essay effective. (Fulfills composition requirement for nonnative speakers of English only.)
metadata: FW College of Arts, Languages & Letters English as a Second Language (ESL)

subject: ENG
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Pre: graduate standing and consent. Repeatable nine times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Special Topics (3)
desc: Content to be announced. Repeatable five times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Comparative Literature (3)
desc: Introduction to comparative literature; relationship of English to other literatures; sources and influences. (B) African lit. and literary theory; (F) folklore and literature; (G) theory/practice of poetry; (H) contemporary drama; (I) mythic method; (J) postmodern fiction; (M) modernism; (N) colonial/ postcolonial; (P) postmodernism and postcolonialism; (W) medieval women writers. Repeatable one time for different alphas.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Cultural Studies (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected issues in cultural studies and cultural and social theory; topics to be announced. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Hawaiian Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected issues, genres, and traditions in Hawaiian literature written in English or translated from Hawaiian into English. Repeatable one time. Pre: HAW 102 (or concurrent) or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Literatures of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Introduction to comparative literature; relationship of Hawaiian to other literatures; sources and influences. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Pacific Literatures (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected issues in the literatures of the Pacific in English, or translated into English. Topics to be announced. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Cultural Studies in Asia/ Pacific (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected issues in cultural studies in Asia and the Pacific; topics to be announced. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Life Writing (3)
desc: Intensive study of critical and theoretical issues raised by various forms of life writing (biography, autobiography, oral history, diaries, etc.) and of their history and methodology. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Film Theory and Criticism (3)
desc: Classic theories of representation and aesthetics; modern and contemporary cultural, psychoanalytic, and aesthetic theories as they apply to film.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Literary Genres (3)
desc: Study of one or more authors, English or American literature. (C) neoclassicism; (D) tragedy; (E) modern American short story; (F) sonnet and sonnet sequences; (G) Rest., 18th century dramatic comedy; (H) 18th century literature and art; (I) medieval drama; (J) narrative theory and criticism; (K) reinventing the author; (M) laughter and the comic arts; (N) nature of romance; (O) Victorian novel; (P) Jacobean drama; (Q) science fiction; (R) essay, past and present; (S) Eng. hymn in Western culture; (W) 18th century British women novelists; (Y) English romanticism; (Z) English novel and criticism. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Shakespeare (3)
desc: Intensive study of Shakespeare.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Major Author (3)
desc: Study of one or more authors, English or American. (C) George Eliot; (D) Emily Dickinson; (M) Milton; (S) Chaucer and his backgrounds; (T) Austen; (U) Yeats and his circle; (X) Beowulf; (Y) Faulkner’s narrative; (Z) Virginia Woolf. Repeatable one time for different alphas. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Seminar in American Literature (3)
desc: Study of authors or a period. (B) American modernism; (C) race in American literature; (D) 19th century American poetry; (E) American literature naturalism; (F) African American literature and theory; (G) American transcendentalism; (H) 19th century American novel; (J) contemporary American poetry; (N) poetry by 20th century American women; (P) women writers and multiculturalism; (Q) Asian American literature and theory; (R) relocating American literature; (S) early American literature; (T) H. Melville and T. Morrison. Repeatable one time for different alphas.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Seminar in English Literature (3)
desc: Study of authors or a period. (C) re-reading Chaucer; (N) 14th century poetry; (P) extended Victorian lyric; (Q) modern British fiction; (R) early 17th century poetry; (S) dominant Victorians: the 1840s; (T) Baroque and English literature; (U) literature and social change; (X) literature and history; (Y) studies in satire. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Literary Criticism (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics in literary theory and its practical application; topics to be announced. Repeatable two times. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Techniques in Contemporary Literature (3)
desc: The study, from the point of view of the creative writer, of works written within the last 25 years. (B) techniques in fiction; (C) techniques in poetry; (D) techniques in creative nonfiction. Repeatable one time in each ENG graduate degree. Pre: 613 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Creative Writing (3)
desc: Advanced study in creative writing focused on thesis and dissertation projects. Repeatable one time in each English graduate degree. Pre: 613 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Rhetoric (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics in the history of rhetoric, rhetorical theory, or rhetorical criticism; topic to be announced. Repeatable one time. Pre: 625C or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Seminar in Composition Studies (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected issues in composition studies. Repeatable one time. Pre: 625C or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: graduate standing and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Individual reading or research. Repeatable with consent of Graduate Director. Pre: graduate standing and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Supervised Practicum (3)
desc: Applies course work in literature, creative writing, cultural studies, or composition and rhetoric to hands-on activities engaging publics outside of the university under direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. ENG majors only. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: MA Final Project (V)
desc: Individual reading and research towards preparation of MA project. 3 credit hours required. CR/NC only. Repeatable one time. Pre: 625 and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Biography (3)
desc: Study of one or more authors, English or American literature. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Literary Theory and Criticism (3)
desc: (B) classical period through 18th century; (C) Romantic and post-Romantic.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Theories and Methods (3)
desc: Required course in the MA student’s area of concentration. (B) theories and methods of literary study; (C) introduction to composition and rhetoric; (D) foundations of creative writing; (E) theories in cultural studies. Repeatable in different alphas. ENG majors only. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Graduate Writing Workshop (3)
desc: Advanced practice and critical evaluation of the writing of poetry, fiction, or creative nonfiction. (B) poetry; (C) fiction; (D) nonfiction. Repeatable one time in each English graduate degree. Pre: graduate standing plus 411 for (B); 414 for (C); 412 for (D); or consent
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Elements of Creative Writing (3)
desc: Intensive discussion of the craft and technique of creative writing through readings in poetry, fiction, creative nonfiction, and creative writing pedagogy. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Theory and Practice of Teaching Composition (3)
desc: Major contemporary theorists and classroom practices that evolve from their theories; observation and applications. A-F only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Old English (3)
desc: Structure of the language, relation to present English; reading of selected prose and poetry.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: HWP Summer Institute WAC (V)
desc: Practicum in the current best approaches to teaching writing across the curriculum. Participants write, read published theory and research in composition, and demonstrate effective writing lessons. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: HWP Summer Writing Institute (V)
desc: Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. Pre: two ENG DL courses or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Internship (3)
desc: Faculty supervised participation in the operations of an organization. A-F only. Pre: two ENG DL courses, junior standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Study Abroad (V)
desc: Intensive study in the English language of selected topics, issues or writers from the host country in a UH Mānoa-approved study abroad location. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: two ENG DL courses or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Literature and Sexuality and Gender (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions and issues in the construction and representation of sexuality and gender in specific genres, social and cultural contexts, or thematic/figurative clusters. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 483)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Literature and Popular Culture (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected problems, issues, traditions, writers, movements, or genres in the field of popular literature and/or popular culture. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Literature and Folklore (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, or genres in folklore and oral traditions and their performance and transformations within specific social and cultural contexts. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Hawaiian and/or Pacific Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, writers, movements, and genres in the field of Hawaiian and/or Pacific literature. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course. (Cross-listed as PACS 474)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Postcolonial Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of postcolonial literatures and of historical, cultural, and theoretical issues such as colonialism, migration, assimilation, national identity, or transnationalism. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Asian American and Asian Diaspora Literatures (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, genres, or writers relating to Asia. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Life Writing (3)
desc: Intensive study of forms and theories of life writing in forms such as biographies, autobiographies, oral histories, diaries, journals, letters, film, drama, and portraiture with a focus on the ethical questions these materials present. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Film (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics in film, e.g.: genres, major filmmakers, film theory/criticism, or film and literature. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: U.S. Women’s Literature and Culture (3)
desc: Reading of selected works of U.S. women’s literature and cultural texts (such as art and film). Emphasis on historical and cultural context and diverse expressions of women’s gendered identities. (Cross-listed as AMST 455 and WGSS 445)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: John Milton (3)
desc: Intensive study of the works and literary milieu of John Milton. Pre: two ENG DL courses or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: William Shakespeare (3)
desc: Intensive study of the works and literary milieu of William Shakespeare. Repeatable one time. Pre: two ENG DL courses or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Geoffrey Chaucer (3)
desc: Intensive study of the works and literary milieu of Geoffrey Chaucer. Pre: two ENG DL courses or consent
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Single Author (3)
desc: Intensive study of the works and literary milieu of a single author considered significant by most scholars in English Studies. The English Department maintains a list of versions focusing on specific authors. Repeatable one time for a different author, with consent. Pre: two ENG DL courses or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in 20th and 21st Century Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in texts written from the 20th century to the present. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in 19th Century Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in texts written during the 19th century. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in 18th Century Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in texts written during the period 1660-1830, the “long” 18th century. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in 16th and 17th Century Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in texts written during the period 1500-1700. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Medieval Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in Old/Middle English literature from 500-1500, including works in modern translation. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Comparative Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in the field of comparative literature. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Literature and Culture (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in regard to cultural studies and the reading and interpretation of cultural texts. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Creative Writing (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics, questions, themes, writers, or modes of creative writing in a workshop setting. Repeatable one time. Pre: 313 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Fiction Workshop (3)
desc: Writing, evaluating fiction. Repeatable one time. Pre: 313 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Form and Theory of Fiction (3)
desc: Narrative techniques for students interested in writing fiction. Pre: 313 or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Nonfiction Writing (3)
desc: Workshop analysis of nonfiction as a literary form. Significant attention paid to developing writing skills. Repeatable one time. Pre: 306, 311, or 313; or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Poetry Workshop (3)
desc: Writing, evaluating poems. Repeatable one time. Pre: 313 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Form and Theory of Poetry (3)
desc: Poetic theories and techniques for students interested in writing poetry. Pre: 313 or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Studies in Composition/Rhetoric/ Language (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics, questions, themes, issues, and/or writers in composition, rhetoric, and/or English language. Repeatable one time. Pre: 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Professional Editing (3)
desc: Discussion and practice in the professional editing of articles, reports, books; logic, clarity, coherence, consistency of tone and style, grammar and punctuation. Pre: 303, 306, 311, 313, or 405; or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Writing for Digital Media (3)
desc: Combined lecture/lab on writing and rhetoric in computermediated communication. May include online technical writing, courseware development, social media content creation. Pre: two ENG DL courses or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Advanced Argumentative Writing (3)
desc: Advanced study of both the philosophical and practical dimensions of written reasoning. Emphasis on argument as a process of inquiry. Pre: FW and either 200 or one ENG DL course, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Teaching Composition (3)
desc: Theory, observation, and practice in teaching writing, especially the use of one-on-one and small group instruction. Pre: two ENG DL courses; or consent. Recommended: 306.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: English in Hawai‘i (3)
desc: English language in Hawai‘i viewed historically and in a multicultural context, with attention to politics, religion, race, and education, from 1820 to present. Pre: two ENG DL courses or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Fairy Tales and Their Adaptations (3)
desc: Comparative analysis of selected tales of magic and their adaptations across history, cultures and media such as book illustration and film. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Children’s Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of children’s literature; may include study of children’s book illustration. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Gender, Sexuality and Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of literary constructions of gender and sexuality; emphasis on teaching gender and sexuality through writing and oral communication. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 381)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Popular Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of popular literature genres, such as detective fiction, science fiction, the thriller, the romance, and westerns. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Folklore, Wonder Tales, and Oral Traditions (3)
desc:
Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of folktales, legends, ballads, wonder 
tales, and other folklore genres in various cultures; consideration given to folklore/literature relationships. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Native Hawaiian Literature in English (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of Native Hawaiian literature, ancient to contemporary, in translation and in English, that demonstrate the depth and breadth of the Native Hawaiian literary tradition. Pre: one DL course.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Philippine Literature and Folklore in Translation (3)
desc: Philippine folk literature translated into English: epics, myths, legends, and other folklore. Classic works of vernacular writers. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as IP 396)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Philippine Contemporary Literature in English (3)
desc: Critical survey of 20th-century Philippine literature written in English; cultural values. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as IP 363)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Race, Ethnicity, and Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of race and ethnicity as the basis for literary inquiry. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: African American Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of African American literature by writers from a variety of backgrounds. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Asian American Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of Asian American literature by writers from a variety of backgrounds. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 372)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Literature of the Pacific (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the literature of the Pacific, including Pacific voyagers and contemporary writings in English by Pacific Islanders. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as PACS 371)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Literatures of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Writings of various ethnic groups in Hawai‘i, ancient to contemporary. Songs, stories, poetry, fiction, essays that illustrate the social history of Hawai‘i. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 370)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Non-fiction (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of non-fiction such as essays, biographies, autobiographies, speeches, political and legal documents, conversion and captivity narratives, testimonials, science writing, and travel writing. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Film (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the form, function, and development of cinematic narrative techniques. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Drama (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the form, function, and development of the genre of drama. Emphasis on types of writing and revision, and oral presentation. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Poetry (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the analysis of imagery, sound, language, form, and structure in poems. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: American Literature Since Mid-20th Century (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of American literature since approximately 1950. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: American Literature Mid-19th to Mid20th Century (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry and drama in American literature from the middle of the 19th century to the middle of the 20th century. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: American Literature to Mid-19th Century (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry, and drama in American literature through the middle of the 19th century. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: British Literature After 1900 (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry, and drama in English from 1900 to the present. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: 19th Century British Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of 19th century prose and poetry in English. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Restoration/18th Century British Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry, and drama in English from 1660 to 1780, exclusive of Milton. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Renaissance British Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry, and drama in English from 1500 to 1660. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Medieval Literature (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of literature before 1500. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Literatures of the World (3)
desc: Basic concepts and representative texts for the transhistorical, transnational, and/or comparative study of literatures in English and in translation from regions around the world. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Backgrounds of Western Literature (3)
desc: Sources of European and American literary themes and allusions; myth, legend, and folklore of Western cultures; e.g., Classical texts, Arthurian romances, King James Bible. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Introduction to English Studies (3)
desc: Introduction to English Studies, including reading and writing about the purpose, practice, and potential of literary and rhetorical study of texts; consideration given to Hawaiian and/or Pacific texts in cultural and historical context. Restricted to ENG majors/minors and Secondary Education-English majors only. Prerequisite to 400-level work for ENG majors. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Creative Writing (3)
desc: Basic principles of the craft as developed through writing in two of the following genres: fiction, poetry, drama, screenwriting, and creative nonfiction. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Autobiographical Writing (3)
desc: Writing clear, effective prose based on the writer’s own experiences and ideas with a focus on the ethical questions such writing entails. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Technical Writing (3)
desc: Combined lecture/ lab preparing students to write about technical subjects for specialists and laypersons. Introduces theory of technical communication and document design and teaches students to make use of relevant technology. A-F only. Pre: FW and either 200 or one ENG DL course; or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Rhetoric, Composition, and Computers (3)
desc: Introduction to computer-based writing and reading technologies. Study of principles of traditional and online composition. Writing traditional and multimedia essays. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Argumentative Writing (3)
desc: Theory and practice of written argument; emphasis on the role of invention in argumentative discourse and on the nature of rhetorical proof. Pre: FW and either 200 or one ENG DL course, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Modern English Grammar (3)
desc: Introduction to the structure of present-day English for native speakers and others with advanced competency. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: History of the English Language (3)
desc: Basic concepts and methods for the study of the English language; general history of the language; grammar and usage, issues of language diversity and standardization; English as a world language. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: (Alpha) Introduction to Rhetoric (3)
desc: History of theory and practices of rhetoric from Classical to contemporary periods; e.g., Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, Quintilian, Augustine, Sidney, K. Burke, DeMan; (B) Classical-Renaissance; (C) EnlightenmentContemporary. Repeatable one time for different alphas. Pre: one ENG DL course or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Introduction to Literature: Creative Writing and Literature (3)
desc: Study of significant works through analytical and creative writing. Repeatable one time. Pre: FW. No waiver.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Introduction to Literature: Culture and Literature (3)
desc: Study of significant works of selected cultures and cultural formations. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction. Repeatable one time. Requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. Pre: FW.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Introduction to Literature: Genre (3)
desc: Study of significant works of selected genres. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction. Repeatable one time. Requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. Pre: FW.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Introduction to Literature: Literary History (3)
desc: Study of significant works of selected historical periods. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction. Repeatable one time. Requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. Pre: FW.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Business Writing (3)
desc: Practice in informative, analytical, persuasive writing. Pre: FW. Students may not earn credit for both ENG 209 and BUS 209.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Composition II (3)
desc: Further study of rhetorical, conceptual, and stylistic demands of writing; instruction develops the writing and research skills covered in Composition I. Pre: FW.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Composition for Transfer Students to UHM (3)
desc: Introduction to the rhetorical, conceptual and stylistic demands of writing at the university level; instruction in composing processes, search strategies, and writing from sources. Restricted to students with more than 24 credits. Students may not earn credit for both ENG 100 and 190. A-F only. Pre: placement.
metadata: FW College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENG
title: Composition I (3)
desc: Introduction to the rhetorical, conceptual and stylistic demands of writing at the university level; instruction in composing processes, search strategies, and writing from sources. Students may not earn credit for both ENG 100 and 190. Pre: placement.
metadata: FW College of Arts, Languages & Letters English (ENG)

subject: ENGR
title: Field Experience (1)
desc: Supervised internship in engineering practice under professional and faculty direction. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. Pre: junior standing in engineering and consent.
metadata: College of Engineering Engineering (ENGR)

subject: ENGR
title: Engineering Management (3)
desc: Introduction to engineering management of projects and its outcomes. Development of professional skills for the systematic formulation of problems and solutions to efficiently deduce project viability. Emphasis on collaborative teamwork and performance evaluations and improvements. Senior standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: College of Engineering Engineering (ENGR)

subject: ENGR
title: Junior Vertically Integrated Project (V)
desc: Team-based research project for junior-level students. Project topic varies by instructor. Students are expected to continue working in this project as a senior. Repeatable unlimited times. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 296 or consent. (Cross-listed as ECE 396)
metadata: College of Engineering Engineering (ENGR)

subject: ENGR
title: Career Development Seminar (1)
