desc: Examine the emergent theories, issues, practices, and problems relevant for educational leaders in school organizations. Integrates the aspects of management and administration within the context of leadership.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: (Alpha) Education Law (3)
desc: Status and functions of educational institutions and personnel relative to their legal rights and responsibilities. Includes interpretation of important court decisions, statutes, equity measures. (H) higher education: specific for higher education students; (K) K-12: specific for K-12 students. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: Educational Statistics (3)
desc: Statistical inference including applications of parametric and nonparametric methods to educational problems.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: Administration in Kinesiology (3)
desc: Current problems, trends, and strategies in the administration of athletic training, physical education, recreation, sport and fitness programs in school and non-school settings. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as KRS 623)
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: (Alpha) Education Finance (3)
desc: Educational revenues, apportionments, budgetary procedures, costs, business management, economics of education, measures of productivity. (H) higher education: specific for higher education students; (K) K-12: specific for K-12 students. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: School-Community Relations (3)
desc: Application of principles, techniques, policies, organization of school-community information program. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: Survey Research Design and Analysis (3)
desc: Survey study designs, survey sampling, questionnaire construction, interviewing, pre-tests, pilot studies, logic of measurement and association, table construction, and elaboration models. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as EDEP 602 and SOC 608)
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: Qualitative Research Methods in Education (3)
desc: Introduction to methods of qualitative research in education. (Meets PhD common core requirement.) (Cross-listed as EDEP 613)
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: Research in Education Administration (3)
desc: Develops basic concepts of research on educational administration: methodology, status of particular topics, communication, and application of findings to problems of school administration. (Meets PhD common core inquiry methods requirement.) Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: Introduction to Education Administration (3)
desc: Develops view of administrative process and organization elements in context of system of personal, social, and physical variables. Emphasis on role and functions of school administrator. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Planned individualized study, reading, research, teaching, and/ or projects under direct supervision of instructor. A-F only. Repeatable up to six credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: (Alpha)Topics in Emergent Paradigms of Leadership (3)
desc: Exploration, application, analysis and synthesis of advanced leadership concepts including emergent theories, issues, trends and empowering approaches. (B) survey of emergent paradigms; (C) Asian Pacific American leadership; (D) gender and leadership; (E) ethics and leadership; (K) issues and problems in leadership. Repeatable one time per alpha. Pre: 360 (or equivalent) and consent.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: Peer Leadership Education and Mentoring (3)
desc: Theoretical explorations and a supervised practicum experience in student peer leadership education and mentoring in a variety of curricular and co-curricular contexts. Pre: 360 (or equivalent) and consent.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDEA
title: Dynamics of Student Leadership (3)
desc: Theoretical approaches and an experimental orientation toward leadership in student organizations via classroom activities and practicum experiences with student organizations.
metadata: College of Education Educational Administration (EDEA)

subject: EDUC
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation.
metadata: College of Education Education (EDUC)

subject: EDUC
title: Internship in College Teaching (V)
desc: Introduction to college-level teaching; doctoral students serve as apprentices to professors; responsibilities include supervised teaching, planning and evaluation. Repeatable up to six credits. CR/NC only. Pre: admission to PhD candidacy and consent.
metadata: College of Education Education (EDUC)

subject: EDUC
title: Field Project (V)
desc: Practicum experience in area of specialization. Variable credit: minimum of 3 credit hours, maximum of 6 credit hours. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Education (EDUC)

subject: EDUC
title: EdD Conference (1)
desc: Capstone for the Doctoral Degree in Professional Education Practice. Involves a conference presentation of research project results to an audience of faculty, fellow graduate students, and interested members of the public. Restricted to students in the Doctoral Degree in Professional Educational Practice. CR/NC only. Pre: other approval.
metadata: College of Education Education (EDUC)

subject: EDUC
title: Professional Doctorate Practicum: Individual Applied Research Project (6)
desc: Practicum in conducting individual practitioner research within the EdD. Includes the formulation of individual applied research project, developing a plan of action, selection of appropriate methods, implementation of plan and composition of practitioner research report. Repeatable three times. Restricted to students in the Doctoral Degree in Professional Educational Practice. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Education (EDUC)

subject: EDUC
title: Professional Doctorate Practicum: Consultancy Project (3)
desc: Practicum in the EdD program in professional practice; involves a group consultancy project requiring independent research and reflective activity embedded in a group project dealing with a problem of practice. Repeatable three times. Restricted to students in the Doctoral Degree in Professional Educational Practice. A-F only. Pre: other approval.
metadata: College of Education Education (EDUC)

subject: KRS
title: Sexuality & Health (3)
desc: Examines concepts, theories, and skills-based practices of sexuality and health. Topics on underserved populations, disability, reproductive health, family planning, and family health. Utilizes research-based curriculum/strategies to promote personal and social responsibility for health. (Cross-listed as DIS 651)
metadata: College of Education Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science (KRS)

subject: EDCS
title: Social Emotional Learning (SEL) Pedagogy and Practice (3)
desc:
Introduces concepts, theories, and pedagogies of Social Emotional Learning 
(SEL), health and wellness, and trauma informed teaching with an emphasis on culture, social justice, and equity in Hawai‘i and our global community. A-F only. (Summer only) (Cross-listed as DIS 650 and KRS 650)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDUC
title: Action Research in Education (3)
desc: Theory and practice in collaborative action research; critical inquiry into current educational work in schools with goals of improvement of teaching and participation in school and curriculum reform.
metadata: College of Education Education (EDUC)

subject: ECON
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: MA Capstone Research (3)
desc: Student applies theoretical and quantitative techniques, critical thinking, and communicative skills to prepare a written and oral presentation of original research on a topic of his or her choice. A-F only. Pre: 606, 607, 627, 628, and consent of graduate chair.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Research Seminar (3)
desc: Selected issues emphasizing research techniques. Required for students who have passed the two theory qualifying exams and have not passed the comprehensive exam. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent of department chair
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Advanced Topics in Economics (V)
desc: Reflects interests of visiting and permanent faculty, focusing on specialized methods or topics in economics. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: 606 or 607, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Strategic Behavior and Experimental Economics (3)
desc: Experimental economics: methodology. Experimental game theory. Market experiments. Applications include: topics in industrial organization, provision of public goods, asset markets, auctions. Repeatable one time. Pre: 606 and 608, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Health Economics and Policy (3)
desc: Economic analysis of health-care policy; efficient design of health-care financing schemes; private and public demand for health, health insurance, and medical care; provider behavior. Pre: 604 (or concurrent) or 606 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Economics of Population (3)
desc: Economic determinants and consequences of population change. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Labor Economics and Policy (3)
desc: Supply of and demand for labor; implications for labor markets and unemployment level. Pre: 606 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Applied International Finance (3)
desc: Surveys empirical research in international macroeconomics, finance and econometric methods: including balance of payments adjustment, international equilibrium, international prices, interest rates and exchange rates, models of exchange rate determination, capital flows, balance of payments crises. Pre: 607 and 629 (or concurrent), or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: International Macroeconomics (3)
desc: Advanced international monetary and macroeconomic theory: balance of payments, output, price and exchange rate determination, international aspects of growth and economic fluctuations, alternative exchange rate regimes, international capital flows. Pre: 607 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Advanced International Trade and Investment (3)
desc: Surveys theoretical and empirical research on topics such as regionalism and multilateralism, trade and wages, foreign direct investment and multinational firms, trade and the environment, and trade and economic growth. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: 660 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: International Trade and Welfare (3)
desc: Classical and new theories of international trade: why nations trade, gains from trade, patterns of trade, and trade policy effects under perfect and imperfect competition. Empirical trade and other special topics. Pre: 606 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Public Economics (3)
desc: Theoretical and empirical analysis of public-sector allocation. Adverse selection, moral hazard, networks, auctions, public choice and political mechanisms; tax and mandate incidence; economics of education and local public goods; social insurance programs. Pre: 606 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Foundations of Public Policy (3)
desc: Microeconomic principles for expenditure and tax policies. Externalities, public goods, non-convexities, regulation; cost-benefit analysis, general equilibrium, shadow-pricing; rent-seeking, corruption; optimal taxation, incidence, excess burden; dynamic public finance, national debt, social security. Pre: 604 or 606; or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Marine Resource Economics (3)
desc: Seminar on the economics of the marine environment. Topics include fisheries management, ocean recreation, shipping, and coral reef protection. Pre: 606 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Environmental Resource Economics (3)
desc: Principles of policy design and evaluation for environmental resources management, forestry and watershed conservation, and sustainable economic development. Pre: 604 or 606; or consent. (Cross-listed as SUST 638)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Resource Economics (3)
desc: Analysis of problems of development and management of natural resources with emphasis on resources in agriculture and role in economic development. Pre: 608 and 629. (Cross-listed as NREM 637 and SUST 637)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Renewable Energy Economics and Policy (3)
desc: Analysis of economic and policy aspects of renewable energy use, and interactions of markets for renewable energy and other energy options. Evaluations of policies to develop renewable energy options. Pre: college calculus and principles of microeconomics; or consent. (Cross-listed as SUST 636)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Disasters and Economic Policy (3)
desc: Economic analysis of disasters. The economics of prevention and mitigation, as well as post-disaster economic consequences and policy, will be examined. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Econometrics II (3)
desc: Specification, statistical estimation, inference and forecasting of econometric models. Includes advanced topics for single-equation models, pooled models, qualitative dependent variables, simultaneous systems, distributed lags, and time series. Pre: 628, AREC 626, or consent. (Cross-listed as AREC 634)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Econometrics I (3)
desc: Review of probability, estimation, small sample and asymptotic properties. Bivariate and multiple regression and matrix algebra formulation. Regression diagnostics. Introduction to heteroskedastidity, autocorrelation, simultaneity, dichotomous variables, advanced topics.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Mathematics for Economics (3)
desc: Sets, functions, limits, convexity, continuity; constrained and unconstrained optimization; difference and differential equations; matrix algebra; simultaneous equations; comparative statics; Kuhn-Tucker theory; game theory; mathematical programming.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Microeconomic Theory III (3)
desc: Game theory and strategic behavior. Economics of information and incentives principal-agent theory. Economic design. Applications include: theory of contracts; incentive compatible mechanism for provision of public goods; auction theory. Pre: 608 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Economic Development of Japan (3)
desc: Analysis of growth from Meiji period to present. Problems of population change, capital formation, income distribution, industrial structure. Pre: 610 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Economic Development Policy (3)
desc: Analysis of policies for the promotion of industrial and agricultural development. Project evaluation, industrial regulation, public administration, investment and capital market policies, land-use policies, trade policies, pricing, and stabilization. Pre: 604 or 606; or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Economic Development (3)
desc: Nature and causes of economic growth and structural change. Roles of macroeconomic policy and foreign trade. Pre: 606 and 607, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Macroeconomic Theory II (3)
desc: Models of economic growth and fluctuations; stochastic and dynamic macroeconomic models; econometric testing of rational expectations models; theory of public debt; current topics in macroeconomic theory. Pre: 607 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Microeconomic Theory II (3)
desc: General equilibrium analysis: production, consumption and Walrasian equilibria; Pareto efficiency, fundamental theorems of welfare economics; externalities; public goods; game theory; information theory. Pre: 606 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Macroeconomic Theory I (3)
desc: Neoclassical theory of real and monetary equilibrium, economics of J. M. Keynes, standard IS/LM models and aggregate demand/supply analysis in the closed and open economy, theory of rational expectations.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Microeconomic Theory I (3)
desc: Theory of the firm: production, costs, duality; theory of the market: competition, monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition; theory of the consumer: preferences, expenditures, duality; expected utility theory.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Microeconomics for Business and Policy Analysis (3)
desc: Theory of the consumer, firm, and market. Perfect competition and efficiency. Market power and firm strategy. Market efficiencies. Role of the government. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies (1)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Advanced Directed Research (V)
desc: Economics majors and minors conduct research, under faculty supervision, on a topic of their choice. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: minimum GPA of 3.0 in economics and consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Contemporary Economic Issues (3)
desc: Economic analysis of current events. Topics announced each semester, e.g., environmental pollution, crime control, racial discrimination, traffic congestion. Pre: 300 or 301 or consent
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Land and Housing Economics (3)
desc: Microeconomics explains urban land and housing phenomena, and analyzes selected land and housing issues relevant to Honolulu. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Law and Economics (3)
desc: Legal issues of property rights, contracts, torts, and crime. Efficiency of U.S. legal process. Economics of law enforcement, juries, prosecutors; evolution of legal rules. Pre: 301.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Industrial Organization (3)
desc: Theoretical and empirical analysis of contemporary topics in industrial organization. Uses economic theory to analyze important issues facing firms, and examines the practical challenges of empirical applications of theory. Pre: 301.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: International Macroeconomics (3)
desc: The determination of output, price levels, exchange rates and the balance of payments for economies that are integrated with the global economy; theory and application to historical and/or contemporary policy issues. Pre: 300.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: International Trade and Welfare (3)
desc: Theory of international specialization and exchange; general equilibrium, tariffs, quotas, common markets. Pre: 301.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Project Evaluation and Resource Management (3)
desc: Principles of project evaluation and policy analysis. Shadow pricing, economic cost of taxes and tariffs; public policy for exhaustible, renewable, and environmental resources. Pre: 301. (Cross-listed as SUST 458)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: State and Local Finance (3)
desc: Fiscal institutions, operations, and policy questions within state and local governments in U.S. grant programs and other links with central government. Pre: 301.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Public Economics (3)
desc: Welfare economics, public expenditure and policy evaluation, public finance by debt and taxes. Pre: 301.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Development Economics (3)
desc: Theoretical foundation and empirical evidence for analyzing key issues facing today’s developing world. Topics include characteristics of underdeveloped economies, economic growth, structural change, poverty, inequality, education, population growth, foreign aid and financial sector. Pre: 300 or 301, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Monetary Theory and Policy (3)
desc: Micro-foundations and critical analysis of monetary and macroeconomic theory and policy. Topics include the causes and consequences of inflation, optimal monetary policy and international monetary systems, bank risk and insurance, and national debt and taxation. Pre: 300 or 301 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Health Economics (3)
desc: Private and public demand for health, health insurance, and medical care; efficient production and utilization of services; models of hospital and physician behavior; optimal public policy. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Economics of Population (3)
desc: Determinants and consequences of growth and structure of human populations. Relationships between economic factors and fertility, population growth and economic growth. Pre: 301 (or concurrent).
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Labor Economics (3)
desc: Economic analysis of labor market. Investment in human capital, education, health, migration, etc. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business and Economic Analysis (3)
desc: Introduction to quantitative decision-making methods for effective agribusiness management in resource allocation, scheduling, logistics, risk analysis, inventory, and forecasting. Emphasis on problem identification, model formulation and solution, and interpretation and presentation of results. Pre: 130 or NREM/SUST 220, and 321 or NREM 310; or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as NREM 429)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Econometrics II: Prediction and Causal Inference (3)
desc:
Prediction types, error measures, training and test data, cross validation, 
machine learning, regression trees, random forests, boosting, classification, forecasting time series, modelbased versus design-based causality, potential outcomes framework, matching, difference-in-differences, panel data, synthetic controls. A-F only. Pre: 425 (with a minimum grade of B- or better).
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Econometrics I: Data Exploration and Regression Analysis (3)
desc:
Types of data, exploratory data analysis, generalizing from random samples, simple and multivariate regression, non-linear relationships, measurement error, extreme values, weights, correlated and heteroskedastic errors, 
instrumental variables, models for binary or discrete dependent variables. A-F only. Pre: 321 or MATH 241 or BUS 310 or NREM 310 or (MATH 251A and NREM 203) or (MATH 371 and MATH 373) or (MATH 471 and MATH 472); or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Mathematical Economics (3)
desc: Mathematical techniques applied to theories of the consumer, the firm, markets. Linear programming, input-output analysis. Pre: 300, 301; MATH 203, MATH 215, MATH 241, or MATH 251A.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Pacific Island Economies (3)
desc: Historical and current economic development of the Pacific islands (excluding Hawai‘i). Analysis of selected economic issues such as tourism, population growth, etc. Pre: 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: The Chinese Economy (3)
desc: The Chinese economy during the imperial and republican periods, under Mao, and into the present reform era, with a brief comparison to Taiwan and Hong Kong. Pre: 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Asian Economic Development (3)
desc: History and economic development. Resources, population, and income, saving, investment, and consumption patterns. Role of government and private enterprise. Pre: 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Global Economic Crisis and Recovery (3)
desc: Causes and consequences of financial and economic crises: crisis origins and global transmission; macroeconomic and regulatory policy responses; recovery challenges. Pre: 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Economic History of the United States (3)
desc: U.S. economy from colonial times: government policies, institutions, industries, financial markets, economic growth, economic crises. Pre: 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: The Ocean Economy (3)
desc: Examination of society’s interaction with the ocean. Topics include: ocean recreation, shipping, boat building, ports, offshore energy production, aquaculture, fishing, coastal construction, and coral reef protection. Pre: 120 or 130, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as SUST 412)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Economics majors and minors participate in faculty supervised reading of economic literature. Enables students to self-study topics not covered in the department’s scheduled course offerings. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Contemporary Topics in Economics (3)
desc: Economic analysis of current events. Topics announced each semester. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: 120 or 130 or 131.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Cooperative Education (V)
desc: Economics majors and minors, under the supervision of faculty members, work at paid positions with public agencies, private companies, and campus organizations. The Econ Co-op integrates academics with practical work experience. Repeatable two times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Internship for Economics (V)
desc: Economics majors and minors work at paid positions with public agencies, private companies, and campus organizations. Students combine academic work with practical experience. Repeatable two times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Trade Policy and Globalization (3)
desc: Political economy of the world trading system. Case studies of trade cooperation and conflict under the World Trade Organization and other institutions. Future challenges, including investment policies, environmental and labor standards. Pre: 120, 130 or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Seminar: Women and International Development (3)
desc: Women’s role, status, work and treatment in the Third World; economic development, changing work/family roles, and improvement/ deterioration in gender equity across the Third World; global feminization of poverty; efforts to promote gender equity. Open to non-majors. Pre: a 100 level economics course or any women’s studies course; or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 361)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Environmental Economics (3)
desc: Nature and causes of environmental degradation/economic solutions, with emphasis on relevant ethical issues and decision-making. Topics include air and water pollution, toxic waste, deforestation, soil erosion, biodiversity, global warming, and sustainable development. Pre: 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Games and Economic Behavior (3)
desc: Introduces students to the study of strategic behavior with applications to economics, business, and public policy. Simple economic models of strategic decision making are used to analyze provision of public goods; competition, cooperation, and coordination among firms; bargaining between employers and labor unions; international trade negotiations; reputation as a competitive advantage, and others. Pre: 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Network Economics (3)
desc: Fundamental questions about the connections in the social, economic, and technological worlds. Topics include: matching markets, traffic, financial and social networks; and the political and economic consequences of the internet and other large networks. Pre: 120 or 130 or 131.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Sustainable Development (3)
desc: Transdisciplinary introduction to sustainable development. Interactions between environment, economy, and public policy, especially in Hawai‘i. Topics include: curse of paradise, global warming, energy use, health, poverty, population, water resources, traffic congestion, biodiversity, pollution controls. Pre: 120 or 130 or 131, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as SUST 350)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: The History of Economic Thought (3)
desc: Introduces major western economic theorists and ideas since around 1700. Considers the history of views on work, poverty, the market and government, and the relationship of those doctrines to society, philosophy, and public policy. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as HIST 342)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Comparative Economic History (3)
desc: Comparative historical study of economic ideas and change since around 1700. Considers the histories of capitalism, poverty, industrialization and labor in Europe, Asia, the U.S., and other regions. (Cross-listed as HIST 340)
metadata: DH College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Financial Markets and Institutions (3)
desc: The determination of asset prices; the risk and term structure of interest rates; efficient markets hypothesis; risk management and financial derivatives, asymmetric information models of financial market structure, innovation, regulation and deregulation; and financial crises. Pre: 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Energy Economics and Policy (3)
desc: Analysis of economic and policy aspects of energy use, and interactions of markets for various nonrenewable and renewable energy options. Evaluations of policies to develop alternative energy sources. Pre: 120 or 130 or 131. (Cross-listed as SUST 336)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Economics of Global Climate Change (3)
desc: Nature and causes of global climate change and economic solutions. Topics include valuing climate change impacts, energy solutions, environmental implications, societal adaptation, and international cooperation. A-F only. Pre: 120 or 130 or 131, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as SUST 332)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Statistics (3)
desc: Basic elements; descriptive statistics, probability, inference, distributions, hypothesis testing, regression, and correlation analysis.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Tourism Economics (3)
desc: Examines tourism from an economic perspective. Topics include: the determinants of consumer demand for leisure travel, structure of competition among suppliers of tourism services, benefits and costs of tourism development to the host community, government’s role in the taxation, subsidy, regulation and protection of the tourism industry, tourism’s impact on the environment, and sustainable tourism development. Pre: 120 or 130 or 131; consent. (Cross-listed as TIM 320)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: The Japanese Economy (3)
desc: Analysis of Japan’s growth past and present. Does Japan’s economy look different in terms of its international trade structure, industrial structure, labor market, savings patterns, government policies, etc.? Does it matter? Pre: 120 or 130, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: The Economy of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Descriptive understanding of the history of development of Hawai‘i’s economy; current economic problems; future prospects. Emphasizes the written communication of the intuition behind economic concepts in practice in Hawai‘i. Pre: 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Intermediate Microeconomics (3)
desc: Develops basic techniques and fundamental concepts of microeconomic theory. Learn to use economic reasoning to understand the social consequences of decisions made by individual consumers, producers, and governments. Analyze the nature of market outcomes under alternative market structures, and further discuss possible welfare-improving government policies when markets fail to be efficient. Special attention is paid to the analysis of strategic behavior and markets with public goods and externalities. Pre: 130 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Intermediate Macroeconomics (3)
desc: Develops basic techniques and fundamental concepts used to study the overall macroeconomy and policies that affect it. Study the determinants of national income and long-run growth; causes and consequences of unemployment, inflation, and business cycle fluctuations; determination of foreign exchange rates and current account imbalances, and the role of government policy in various settings. Pre: 131 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Data Analysis and Visualization (3)
desc: Develops basic techniques of data analysis and visualization. Introduces sources of economic data; methods of preparing data from various file/data formats for analysis; methods of visualization: bubble plots, scatterplot matrices, heatmaps, hexbins, rug plots, etc. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Principles of Macroeconomics (3)
desc: An introduction to macroeconomics–the study of the overall economy. Topics include the determination of national income, causes and effects of inflation, unemployment, and income inequality; causes and consequences of international differences in economic growth; sources of business cycle expansions and contractions; role of government policy in stabilizing the economy and promoting long-term growth; financial markets and monetary policy; taxes, spending, consequences of budget deficits, determination of trade imbalances, exchange rate fluctuations, and balance of payment crises.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Principles of Microeconomics (3)
desc: Examination of the decision-making process of both households and firms. Analysis of the functioning of a competitive market system, using supply and demand models and the role of government in cases where the market system fails. Additional topics include the effects of international rate on the welfare of a nation and the effects of different competitive market structures on society.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Economics (3)
desc: One semester survey of the principles of microeconomics and macroeconomics to enable students in all disciplines to understand current economic events.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Economics (ECON)

subject: EALL
title: Dissertation Research (1)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Seminar in Comparison of East Asian Languages (3)
desc: Comparison of lexicon, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, etc., of two or more East Asian languages, contact influence on them. Pre: CHN 451, CHN 452, or JPN 451; or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Seminar in Comparative East Asian Literature (3)
desc: Comparison of authors, modes, topics, and genres in poetry and prose; theoretical and practical criticism. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Special Topics in East Asian Literary Culture & Society (3)
desc: In-depth study of selected topics and issues in modern/contemporary East Asian literary and cultural studies using an interdisciplinary, inter-regional, and transnational approach, from an intercultural perspective. Repeatable two times in different topics, but need consent for second repeat. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 665)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Contemporary Chinese Documentary: Record, Expression, Cultural Space (3)
desc: Introduction to contemporary Chinese independent documentary with these goals: to achieve in-depth understanding of Chinese society through documentary; be familiar with theoretical debates on documentary form; and understand documentary as a cultural discourse. Pre: 473 or 476, or instructor consent. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Topics in 20th Century Chinese Literary and Cultural Studies (3)
desc: Critical scholarship in Chinese literature and cultural studies, broadly defined to include the People’s Republic of China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and others. Reading knowledge of Chinese desirable but not required. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 612)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: (Alpha) Bibliographical and Research Methods (3)
desc: Traditional and modern references and other library materials basic to research in all areas of East Asian studies: (C) Chinese; (J) Japanese; (K) Korean. Pre: CHN 402 for (C); JPN 407 (alpha) for (J); KOR 402 for (K).
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Introduction to East Asian Linguistics (3)
desc: Introduction to cross-linguistic comparison of the writing systems, dialects, history, phonology, morphology, and syntax of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean. Pre: CHN 451 and 452, or JPN 451, or KOR 451 and 452; or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Current Issues in East Asian Language Pedagogy (3)
desc: Survey on East Asian language pedagogy designed to develop students’ familiarity with and facility in addressing the major issues, initiatives, and innovations in the field. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Senior Colloquium in East Asian Literature (3)
desc: Comparative perspectives; some works studied in the original. Pre: third-level East Asian language.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Perspectives on Chinese Cinema (3)
desc: Introduction to Chinese cinema studies, with emphasis on the theoretical and critical approaches to Chinese film. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Transnational Chinese Popular Culture (3)
desc: Survey of contemporary Chinese popular entertainment forms that are produced and appreciated transnationally. Examples include martial arts genres, kung fu films, commercial novels, ballroom dancing, karaoke culture, music videos and rock music. Material will be selected based upon availability and readings will include critical essays from the fields of popular culture, media studies, and literary criticism. Pre: any 300- or 400-level DL or DH course. (Cross-listed as ASAN 474)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Topics in Chinese Cultural Studies: Visual Culture–Chinese Diaspora (3)
desc: Multidisciplinary and historically located study of Chinese culture through the examination of literary/visual texts and critical essays from cultural studies. Specific topics will depend upon term. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: one DH or DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 473)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: East-West Cultural Encounters (3)
desc: Critical examination of encounters between Western and East Asian cultures across time. In addition to literary texts, the course may use sources from other media, and focus on a specific era, region, or genre. Pre: an EALL course at 200 level or above; or a DH or DL course at 200 level or above; or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Modern Korean Women Writers and Culture (3)
desc: Study of fiction by modern Korean women writers in the changing context of Korean culture. A-F only. Pre: sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Topics in Japanese Cultural Studies (3)
desc: Multi-disciplinary and historically located study of Japanese culture through the examination of literary and visual texts. Specific topics will depend upon the term. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Topics in Modern Japanese Literature (3)
desc: Reading and analysis of English translations of selected important works in modern Japanese literature. No knowledge of Japanese required. Repeatable two times in different topics with consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Topics in Traditional Japanese Literature (3)
desc: Reading and analysis of English translations of selected important works in the classical tradition. No knowledge of Japanese required. Repeatable two times in different topics with consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: The City in Modern Chinese Literature and Visual Arts (3)
desc: Study of the fictional and visual representations of the city in the changing contexts of Chinese modernization from the late imperial age to the beginning of the 21st century. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: (Alpha) Traditional Chinese Fiction in Translation (3)
desc: Survey of pre-modern Chinese fiction in translation. (B) short story; (C) novel. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: 20th-Century Chinese Women Writers (3)
desc: A survey and critical examination of contemporary Chinese women writers from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Traces a genealogy of women’s writing from the early 1920s up until now through novels, poetry, drama, and film. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent. (Crosslisted as ASAN 364 and WGSS 346)
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: (Alpha) 20th-Century Chinese Literature and Culture (3)
desc: Survey of 20th-century Chinese literature in translation. Includes a variety of genres from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong: (B) 1919–1949; (C) 1949–present; emphases on writing instruction. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Chinese Literature: Pre-modern (3)
desc: Survey of all major genres from the ninth century till the end of the Qing. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Chinese Literature: Ancient (3)
desc: Survey of all major genres from antiquity until the ninth century. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Literary Traditions of East Asia (3)
desc: Selected works of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean literature in English; relationships and parallels. Pre: one DH or DL course, or consent.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Chinese Film: Art and History (3)
desc: Study and analysis of Chinese film; its history and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical, and aesthetic contexts. (Cross-listed as ASAN 330)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: (Alpha) Japanese Film: Art and History (3)
desc: Study and analysis of Japanese film; its history and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical, and aesthetic contexts. (B) 1900-1960; (C) 1960-present; (D) special topics. Pre: upper division standing or consent. (Cross-listed as ASAN 325)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Korean Literature in Translation– Modern (3)
desc: Survey of 20th-century Korean literature with emphasis on development and cultural context; all readings in English translation. Students write essays about the readings.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Korean Literature in Translation– Traditional (3)
desc: Survey of Korean literature from earliest times with emphasis on development and cultural context; all readings in English translation. Students write essays about the readings.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Survey of Japanese Literature–KIC (3)
desc: Survey of traditional and modern Japanese literature in translation, covering all major genres. Only offered at Konan University in Japan. Not open to students with 271 or 272.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Japanese Literature in Translation– Modern (3)
desc: Survey from mid-19th century to present; emphasis on fiction.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Japanese Literature in Translation– Traditional (3)
desc: Survey of all major forms from the earliest era to mid-19th century.
metadata: DL College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EALL
title: Introduction to Chinese Language and Culture (3)
desc: Provides students with interesting perspectives on and some general knowledge of Chinese language, literature, and culture.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: EPET
title: Capstone Project: Producing a Science Satellite (4)
desc: Develops a space mission with a multidisciplinary team of engineers and scientists. Will build a small spacecraft and payload and seeks to answer important science questions. Emphasizes review report and proposal writing. A-F only. Pre: 400. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as ME 401)
metadata: Earth and Planetary Exploration Technology (EPET) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: EPET
title: Space Mission Design (4)
desc:
Covers all aspects of spacecraft design, subsystems, science payload, systems engineering, project management, budgets, and ethical issues that are important to consider in producing a fully successful mission. A-F only. Pre: 
301. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as ME 400)
metadata: Earth and Planetary Exploration Technology (EPET) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: EPET
title: Space Science and Instrumentation (4)
desc:
Essential techniques for remote compositional analysis of planets; understanding spectroscopy, mineralogy, and geochemistry of planetary surfaces and their measurement. Design of space flight instrumentation. A-F only. Pre: 201, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 101L 
and ERTH 105, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 107; and CHEM 161 and PHYS 272. (Fall only) (crosslisted as ME 301)
metadata: Earth and Planetary Exploration Technology (EPET) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: EPET
title: Space Exploration (4)
desc: Introduction to science and engineering of Solar System exploration with laboratory exercises. Covers planetary science, model-based systems engineering, mission planning, constraints on payload and spacecraft design, human spaceflight technology. Research projects emphasize written communication. A-F only. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as ME 201)
metadata: Earth and Planetary Exploration Technology (EPET) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: DIS
title: Mixed Methods Research Design (3)
desc: Mixed methods research is designed for PhD and masters students in education and social sciences considering combining qualitative and quantitative research. Covers philosophical and practical implications culminating in a mixed methods dissertation/thesis proposal. Repeatable one time. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as EDCS 780 and LTEC 780)
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Directed Reading and/or Research (V)
desc: Directed reading and/or research. Repeatable three times. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Portfolio/Field Work (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary community experience and portfolio in disability and diversity studies. Repeatable three times. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Seminar on Disability Issues (3)
desc: In-depth explorations of current and compelling interdisciplinary topics related to advancing the social, political, educational, and economic integration of individuals with disabilities of all ages. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Advanced Interdisciplinary Assessment (3)
desc: Assessment methods and techniques to instructional research-based practices and supports across disciplines, cultures and PK-12 that address barriers to learning for all students with the context of the Comprehensive Student Support System (CSSS). A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Interdisciplinary Assessment (3)
desc: Assessment methods and techniques to instructional research-based practices and supports across disciplines, cultures and PK-12 that address barriers to learning for all students with the context of the Comprehensive Student Support System (CSSS). A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Interdisciplinary Team Development (3)
desc: Develop knowledge and skills to participate effectively on interdisciplinary teams for the common goal of promoting service integration and coordination of education, social, health, mental health, and other services with individuals with disabilities and their families. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Interdisciplinary Disability and Diversity Issues (3)
desc: Develop understanding of current issues faced by individuals with disabilities and their families within the disability paradigm and across cultures.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Special Topics in Disability and Diversity Studies (V)
desc: Explores disability and diversity across time to gain an understanding and context of issues such as difference, culture, identity, community, privilege, and oppression and how the past affects the present and future. Repeatable two times. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Multicultural Issues in Disabilities (3)
desc: Provide background and understanding of various Pacific Rim cultural issues in the conceptualization and treatment of individuals with disabilities and their families. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Disability History Through the Ages (3)
desc: A historical overview of disability that visits diverse perspectives, attitudes, and treatment toward individuals with disabilities through many centuries, societies, and cultures throughout the world; and how people with disabilities perceived themselves. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Practicum in Applied Behavior Analysis (V)
desc: Supervised field experience in applied behavior analysis. The format is a combination of fieldwork and seminar meetings. Repeatable four times or up to 15 credits. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Supporting Multilingual Learners (3)
desc: Strategies for identifying and adopting best practices that support all students in inclusive learning environments with an emphasis on STEM curriculum for English Language Learners; (B) science; (C) technology; (D) math. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Introduction to Research in Curriculum and Teaching (3)
desc: Classroom-based research covers the fundamentals of qualitative, quantitative, Action Research, mixed methods, and Curriculum Based Assessment. Exploratory, explanatory, and confirmatory research will be highlighted culminating in an outline for Plan B/Thesis proposal. (Cross-listed as EDCS 606)
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Disability History and Culture: From Homer to Hip Hop (3)
desc: How have people over many centuries, and from broad geographical perspectives perceived and treated individuals with disabilities? An overview of the history of the conditions in which people with disabilities lived. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Accessible Learning Technology (3)
desc: Focuses on creating accessible technology and instructional media, developing long-term resources, advancing accessible social interaction between students and students with instructors, and using case studies as examples of good practices. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DIS
title: Foundations in Disability and Diversity (3)
desc: Focuses on disability as a category of diversity and identity, as well as diversity within disability. Different strategies used to increase the freedom or liberty of people with disabilities are critically examined. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Disability and Diversity Studies (DIS)

subject: DRB
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Developmental and Reproductive Biology (DRB) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: DRB
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Developmental and Reproductive Biology (DRB) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: DRB
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Research experience in developmental and reproductive biology. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Developmental and Reproductive Biology (DRB) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: DRB
title: DRB Research Rotation (3)
desc: Introductory laboratory research experience under the supervision of faculty. Repeatable two times. A-F only.
metadata: Developmental and Reproductive Biology (DRB) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: DRB
title: Applied Developmental and Reproductive Biology (3)
desc: Combined lecture-lab on current technologies and methods for mammalian reproduction and developmental biology. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent), 613/614 (or concurrent); or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: Developmental and Reproductive Biology (DRB) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: DRB
title: Stem Cell Biology (3)
desc:
Seminar designed to teach graduate students and advanced undergraduate 
students about current topics relating to stem cell biology, as well as the application of stem cells to modern medicine. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Developmental and Reproductive Biology (DRB) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: DRB
title: Developmental and Reproductive Biology Scientific Investigations (3)
desc: Discussion of current research in developmental and reproductive biology. A-F only.
metadata: Developmental and Reproductive Biology (DRB) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: DRB
title: Seminar in Developmental and Reproductive Biology I (1)
desc: Presentations of current research carried out by developmental and reproductive biology graduate program faculty.
metadata: Developmental and Reproductive Biology (DRB) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: DRB
title: Fertilization and Early Development (2)
desc: Lecture on the basics of vertebrate and invertebrate fertilization and early embryonic development. Open to all graduate students. (Fall only)
metadata: Developmental and Reproductive Biology (DRB) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: DH
title: Directed Reading, Field Work, or Research (V)
desc: Individualized program of directed reading, field work, or research for major under supervision in related areas of dentistry and dental hygiene. Pre: consent.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Dental Hygiene Pediatric Training Clinical II (4)
desc: Advanced clinical application and knowledge in the care of pediatric patients 0-5 years of age. DH majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Community-Based Practice Capstone (2)
desc: Provides an opportunity to synthesize, analyze, and develop solutions to an oral health care problem affecting children ages 0-5 years. Requires one credit to be spent in fieldwork to meet course requirements. DH majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Community-Based Dental Hygiene Care of Vulnerable and Special Needs Children (1)
desc: Emphasizes community-based oral health promotion, dental disease risk reduction and management in children 0-5 years of age with a focus on vulnerable and special needs populations. DH majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Management of Pediatric Dental Emergencies (1)
desc: Focus on the management of dental emergencies in children. DH majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Dental Hygiene Pediatric Training Clinical I (4)
desc: Field experience. Clinical application and knowledge in the care of pediatric patients 0-5 years of age. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Interprofessional Collaborative Practice Simulation Lab (1)
desc: Focus on interprofessional practice principles and competencies while providing students an opportunity to participate in interprofessional team simulations to address health care issues of children. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Pharmacological Principles and Clinical Therapeutics in Pediatric Dental Care (1)
desc: Focus on pharmacological principles and clinical therapeutics in pediatric dental care. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Advanced Health and Diagnostic Assessment for Pediatric Patients (1)
desc: Focus on advanced health and diagnostic assessment for pediatric patients. Includes behavior management techniques as well as oral habits and subsequent malocclusions and speech difficulties. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Pediatric Growth and Development (1)
desc: Focus on the normal growth and development of children based on current clinical practice guidelines and evidence in pediatric research. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Advanced Clinical Dental Hygiene II Clinic (4)
desc: Application of knowledge of expanded functions in periodontics with emphasis on principles, techniques, procedures in pain-anxiety control, soft tissue curettage, host factors, and modification of behavior. A-F only. Pre: 475 and 475L. Co-requisite: 480. (Spring only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Advanced Clinical Dental Hygiene II (2)
desc: In-depth knowledge, communicated via oral delivery, on development of expanded functions in periodontics with emphasis on principles, techniques, procedures in pain-anxiety control, soft tissue curettage, host factors, and modifications in behavior. A-F only. Pre: 475 and 475L. Co-requisite: 480L. (Spring only
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Advanced Dental Hygiene I Clinic (4)
desc: Application of knowledge of expanded functions in periodontics with emphasis on principles, techniques, procedures in pain-anxiety control, soft tissue curettage, host factors, and modification of behavior. A-F only. Pre: 380, 380L, 389, and 391. Co-requisite: 475. (Fall only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Advanced Clinical Dental Hygiene I (2)
desc: An in-depth knowledge and clinical application of expanded function in periodontics with emphasis on principles, techniques, procedures in pain-anxiety control, soft tissue curettage, host factors, and modification of behavior. A-F only. Pre: 380, 380L, 389, and 391. Co-requisite: 475L.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Community Health (3)
desc: Introduction and application of the principles of health education and dental public health into practice in schools, community agencies, and private dental offices (inclusive of problem assessment, planning, implementation and evaluation processes); epidemiology and biostatistics. A-F only. Pre: 361. (Fall only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Periodontology II (2)
desc: Continuation of DH 390. Normal periodontium, etiology, pathogenesis, clinical manifestations and epidemiology of periodontal diseases, and mode of periodontal therapy. Emphasis on writing. A-F only. Pre: 390. (Spring only)
metadata: DB Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Periodontology I (2)
desc: Normal periodontium, etiology, pathogenesis, clinical manifestations and epidemiology of periodontal diseases, and mode of periodontal therapy. Emphasis on writing. A-F only. Pre: 240, 251, and 366. (Fall only)
metadata: DB Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Pain Control and Local Anesthesia in Dentistry (2)
desc: Basic concepts of pain control and local anesthesia in dentistry with appropriate emphasis on psychological preparation, pharmacological preparation, and safe and effective administration of anesthesia in the practice of dental hygiene. Pre: 231, 250 and PHRM 203. Co-requisite: 240, 251, and 366. (Spring only)
metadata: DB Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Clinical Dental Hygiene II Clinic (3)
desc: Continuation of 375. Clinical application of dental hygiene concepts and skills; emergency procedures; team approach to dentistry; planning, implementing and evaluating total oral hygiene care to patients. A-F only. Pre: 375, 375L, and 389. Co-requisite: 380.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Clinical Dental Hygiene II (2)
desc: Continued development of dental hygiene concepts, skills, emergency procedures, team approach to dentistry, planning, implementing and evaluating oral hygiene care of patients. Review and analyze dental periodicals and conduct a case study. Emphasis on writing. Pre: 375, 375L, and 389. Co-requisite: 380L. (Spring only)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Clinical Dental Hygiene I Clinic (4)
desc: Clinical instruction and application of dental hygiene concepts and skills; emergency procedures; team approach to dentistry; planning, implementing, and evaluating total oral hygiene care of patients; review and critical analysis of current dental periodicals and research. A-F only. Pre: 240, 240L, 281, 281L, and 389. Co-requisite: 375.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Clinical Dental Hygiene I (2)
desc: Development of dental hygiene concepts and skills; emergency procedures; team approach to dentistry, planning, implementing and evaluating total oral hygiene care of patients; review and critical analysis of current dental periodicals and research. A-F only. Pre: 240, 240L, 281, 281L, and 389. Co-requisite: 375L.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Expanded Functions in Dental Hygiene Lab/Clinic (1)
desc: (2 1.5-hr Lab/Clinic) Application of basic concepts of expanded functions in dental hygiene. A-F only. Pre: 369. Co-requisite: 370.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Expanded Functions in Dental Hygiene (2)
desc: Basic concepts of expanded functions in dental hygiene. A-F only. Pre: 369. Co-requisite: 370L.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Dental Materials Lab/Clinic (1)
desc: Laboratory and clinical application of concepts in the science of dental materials. A-F only. Pre: 231. Co-requisite: 369.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Dental Materials (1)
desc: Science of dental materials and its application to dentistry and dental hygiene. A-F only. Pre: 231. Co-requisite: 369L.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Oral Pathology (1)
desc: The study of the nature and causes of diseases, the progress and termination or associated alterations of tissue with emphasis on diseases affecting the teeth and the structures of the oral cavity. Pre: 366. (Fall only)
metadata: DB Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: General Pathology (2)
desc: The study of the nature and causes of diseases, the progress and termination or associated alterations of tissue with emphasis on diseases an tissue alterations associated with the human body organ systems. Pre: 250 and 251 (or concurrent). (Spring only)
metadata: DB Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Health Education and Promotion (2)
desc: Provides an overview of the concepts and application of health education and health promotion theories and principles as applies to individuals, groups and the larger public. Pre: open to non-nursing majors with consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as NURS 361)
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Dental Radiography Lab/Clinic (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab/Clinic) Preparation and evaluation of radiographic survey of patients with varying dentition; methods, and indications of safety considerations in clinical application of roentgen rays. A-F only. Pre: 231. Co-requisite: 281.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Dental Radiography (2)
desc: Basic principles of radiation and fundamental information to understand and safely use radiation in dental radiography. A-F only. Pre: 231. Co-requisite: 281L.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Oral Histology and Embryology (1)
desc: Cells and tissues as they relate to the oral cavity and the embryological development of the head, neck, and related oral structures. Pre: 250. (Spring only)
metadata: DB Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: General Histology (2)
desc: Cells, tissues, the organs they make up, and their embryologic origin. Pre: 231 (or concurrent). (Fall only)
metadata: DB Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Basic Dental Hygiene II Lab/Clinic (3)
desc: Laboratory and clinical experiences in basic dental hygiene skills and competencies including history taking, examination, patient care plan, oral prophylaxis, application of caries preventive agents, and clinic procedures. A-F only. Pre: 238 and 238L. Co-requisite: 240.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Basic Dental Hygiene II (2)
desc: Basic dental hygiene theory and skills including competencies in health history taking, examination, patient care plan, oral prophylaxis, application of caries preventive agents, plaque control and support procedures. A-F only. Pre: 238 and 238L. Co-requisite: 240L.
metadata: DB Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Basic Dental Hygiene I Lab (2)
desc: Application of preliminary dental hygiene clinical and support procedures including instrumentation, vital signs, and team concepts in dentistry. A-F only. Co-requisite: 238.
metadata: DY Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Basic Dental Hygiene I (2)
desc: Relationship to dentistry, problems, trends, issues; role and functions of dental hygienists to prevent and control chronic oral diseases; preliminary dental hygiene clinical, includes team concepts in dentistry. Emphasis on teaching writing for the profession. A-F only. Co-requisite: 238L.
metadata: Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Oral Anatomy and Tooth Morphology Lab (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) Application of DH 231 didactic concepts to laboratory activities and practices. A-F only. Pre: PHYL 141, PHYL 141L, PHYL 142, PHYL 142L, and either BIOC 141 or CHEM 161. Co-requisite: 231.
metadata: DY Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DH
title: Oral Anatomy and Tooth Morphology (2)
desc: The study of the structure and functions of the head and neck with emphasis on structures in or related to the oral cavity; of tooth morphology. A-F only. Pre: PHYL 141, PHYL 141L, PHYL 142, PHYL 142L, and either BIOC 141 or CHEM 161. Co-requisite: 231L.
metadata: DB Dental Hygiene (DH) Nancy Atmospera-Walch School of Nursing

subject: DNCE
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Individual projects: tutorial. Repeatable up to six credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: (Alpha) Professional Internship (V)
desc: Internship program where students will work for or with a professional theatre company under supervision of a UH faculty member, plus possible supervisor(s) from the theatre company. Students must participate hands-on in production activities of that company and receive a satisfactory (or better) review from their supervisor(s); (B) entertainment design: costume, lighting, scenery, props, sound, or other related disciplines; (C) performance: acting, directing, dance, choreography, or other related disciplines. Repeatable eight times per alpha, up to nine credits per alpha. A-F only. Pre: 345 or 353 or 356 for (B); 621 or 682 or DNCE 371 for (C). (Cross-listed as THEA 696 (Alpha))
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Dance Colloquium (1)
desc: Forum for presentation and discussion of current intellectual and artistic activities in the dance field. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Internship: Youth Theater/Dance (V)
desc: Supervised leadership experiences in dance/theater program with children. Students spend nine hours per week in supervised setting and three hours in weekly class meeting. Pre: 490, THEA 470, or THEA 476; or consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 693)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Practicum in Teaching (V)
desc: Supervised teaching experience at the introductory or undergraduate level. Students will teach an appropriate level course in their field of expertise under faculty supervision. Repeatable up to nine credits. THEA or DNCE majors only. (Cross-listed as THEA 692)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Seminar in Teaching Dance/Theater (3)
desc: Pedagogy and classroom experience in teaching technique and theory. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as THEA 691)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Directed Choreography (1)
desc: Concert choreography for selected performance settings under the direction of a faculty advisor. Repeatable six times. Pre: 372 (or concurrent) or 671 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Seminar in Choreographic Methods (3)
desc: Graduate level course designed for students with prior choreographic experience. Students will research, create, revise, and perform new works based on a variety of choreographic methodologies. Repeatable one time. Pre: 371, 372; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Dance Performance (V)
desc: Graduate performance in various dance styles and settings. By audition only. Repeatable six times. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Advanced Choreography (3)
desc: Advanced analytic and creative study. Pre: 372 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Movement Analysis (3)
desc: Movement analysis in indigenous, critical race, critical dance frameworks for enhancing scholarly and artistic abilities. Pre: 260 (or concurrent) and 360 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Advanced Topics in Dance (V)
desc: Readings, research, and/or field movement experiences. Repeatable one time if topic changes. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Business for the Arts (3)
desc: Seminar offering overview and foundation for launching or advancing enterprises in the arts. A focus on the processes and method for creating economically successful grants and project development applications. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 658)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Dance and Performance Theory: Oceania (3)
desc: Dance content and historico-social context of principal dance traditions. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Dance and Performance Theory: Asia (3)
desc: Dance content and historico-social context of principal dance traditions. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Seminar: Dance Theory and Criticism (3)
desc: Major theories of dance and dance criticism; emphasis on Western ideas. Pre: 452 and 453, or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)
