subject: DNCE
title: Seminar in Dance Research (3)
desc: Research materials and methods; preparation for thesis and scholarly research reporting. Required for graduate concentrations in dance. (Alt. years)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Seminar in Performance Studies (3)
desc: Special topics. Repeatable up to two times when topics change. Pre: THEA 615 or consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 617)
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Directed Work (V)
desc: Individual projects, tutorial. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Senior Project (1)
desc: Individual choreographic project; student choreographs, performs, and oversees all technical aspects of a creative project; tutorial. A-F only. Pre: 372, senior standing, and consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Creative Dance (3)
desc: Dance activities for young people. Appropriate for teachers, group workers, recreation majors, and others working with children. Also adults with special needs. Supervised field activities.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Dance Repertory (V)
desc: Preparation of standard and new works for performance. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Improvisation II (1)
desc: Advanced-level dance improvisation. Repeatable two times. Pre: 370 or consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Dance Performance (1)
desc: Performance in various dance styles and settings. Repeatable eight times.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Teaching Dance Technique (3)
desc: Principles, techniques, and materials used in the teaching of dance technique. A-F only.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Topics in Dance (V)
desc: Readings, research, and/or field and movement experiences. Repeatable if topic changes unlimited times. Pre: upper division standing and consent.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Field Experiences in Dance (V)
desc: Field experiences in relevant contexts under professional and faculty supervision. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. Pre: upper division standing and consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Costumes II: Intermediate Costume Design (3)
desc: Advanced costume design for theatre and dance. Introduction to collaborative process in costume. Intensive work on rendering skills, applied to various design problems. Cost analysis and organizational techniques. Pre: 356 or consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 456)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Dance Histories II (3)
desc: Development of selected dance forms from 1900 to present, emphasis on writing and ethics. Pre: upper division standing or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Dance Histories I (3)
desc: Development of selected dance histories prior to 1900. Pre: upper division standing or consent.
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Topics in Costume Construction (3)
desc: Costume production techniques, both Western and Asian, for theatre and dance. Topic rotation includes: understructures and armatures, patterning, tailoring, dyeing, fabric modification, millenery and crafts, within the context of current industry practice. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: 354, 356, or consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 446)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Musical Theater Dance Forms (3)
desc: Theatrical dance forms used in 20th-century musical theater. Pre: 100 level or above dance technique class, 421, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as THEA 439)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Advanced Movement for Actors (3)
desc: Detailed development of material presented in 435. Focus on Bartenieff fundamentals and movement analysis as it applies to the physical interpretation of theatrical roles. Pre: 435 or THEA 435, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as THEA 436
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Movement for Actors (3)
desc: Training actors to discover experientially the sources of movement; to teach skills for analyzing movement for its mechanical, anatomical, spatial, and dynamic content; and then to apply these skills in a role. Pre: THEA 222 or consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 435)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Taiji (T’ai Chi) for Actors II (3)
desc: Intermediate-level Taijiquan (T’ai Chi Ch’uan) movement training. Repeatable two times. Pre: 334 or consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 434)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Movement Workshop (V)
desc: Special workshops in movements relating to specific departmental theatrical productions beyond the scope of movement taught in 437 and 438. Repeatable one time. Pre: one of 435 or THEA 435, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as THEA 433)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Advanced Contemporary Dance Technique (3)
desc: Advanced contemporary dance technique. Repeatable six times. Pre: 331 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Advanced Ballet Technique (3)
desc: Advanced ballet technique. Repeatable six times. Pre: 321 or consent
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Hula/Chant Ensemble III (2)
desc: Ancient style; hâlau protocol. Repeatable nine times. Pre: 412. (Cross-listed as MUS 413)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Hula/Chant Ensemble II (2)
desc: Ancient style. Pre: 312 or consent. (Cross-listed as MUS 412)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Oceanic Dance II (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at intermediate level. Repeatable up to 12 credits. Pre: 311 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Philippine Dance II (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at intermediate level. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. Pre: 307 or consent
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Okinawan Dance II (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at intermediate level. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. Pre: 306 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Korean Dance II (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at intermediate level. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. Pre: 305 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Balinese Dance II (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at intermediate level. Repeatable up to eight credits. Pre: 304 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Japanese Dance II (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at intermediate level. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. Pre: 303 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Chinese Dance II (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at intermediate level. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Asian Dance II (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at intermediate level. Repeatable up to eight credits. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Choreography II (3)
desc: Intermediate techniques and theories for dance-making; includes an emphasis on instruction and feedback in oral communication. Pre: 371 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Choreography I (3)
desc: Elementary techniques and theories for dance-making; includes an emphasis on instruction and feedback in oral communication. Pre: 370 or consent
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Movement Improvisation (3)
desc:
Introduces movement improvisation to all levels and disciplines. 
Movement studies will explore improvisation approaches, devices, elements, exercises, and implications to gain skills in and appreciation for the art of improvisation. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as THEA 370)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Visual Media for Dance (3)
desc: Introductory theory of dance for camera. Includes emphasis on practical applications in digital media, choreography, performance, documentation, and feedback in oral communication. (Alt. years)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Dance Kinesiology (3)
desc: Practical information for dance students on diet and nutrition, anatomy, training and conditioning, and injury prevention. Pre: 260 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Costumes I: Beginning Costume Design (3)
desc: Basic principles and approaches to costume design for theatre and dance. Visual communication methods, creative process, historical research, and organizational practices. Repeatable one time. Pre: THEA 240, or consent. (Cross-listed as CINE 356 and THEA 356)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Introduction to Costume Construction (4)
desc: Workshop on basic principles of costume construction for theatre and dance. Professional practices, materials, and methods. (Cross-listed as THEA 354)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Scenic I: Beginning Scenic Design (3)
desc: Workshop introducing the basic principles and approaches of scenic design for theatre and dance, with emphasis on the creative process. Pre: a course in THEA or DNCE, production experience, or consent. (Consent required for production experience option) (Cross-listed as CINE 353 and THEA 353)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Lighting I: Beginning Lighting Design (3)
desc: Basic principles of lighting design and associated technologies. Includes functions and properties of light, lighting and control equipment, working procedures, and drafting and paperwork techniques. Pre: DNCE/ THEA 240 or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as THEA 345)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Taiji (T’ai Chi) for Actors I (3)
desc: Basic Taijiquan (T’ai Chi Ch’uan) movement training. Repeatable two times. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as THEA 334)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: High Intermediate Contemporary Dance Technique (3)
desc: Intermediate modern dance technique. Repeatable four times. Pre: 231 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Intermediate Ballet Technique (3)
desc: Intermediate ballet technique. Repeatable four times. Pre: 221 or consent.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Hula/Chant Ensemble I (2)
desc: Ancient style. Pre: upper division standing or consent. A-F only. (Cross-listed as MUS 312)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Oceanic Dance I (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at the introductory level.

desc: Performance and techniques at the introductory level.

desc: Performance and techniques at the introductory level.

desc: Performance and techniques at the introductory level.

desc: Performance and techniques at the introductory level.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

title: Chinese Dance I (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at the introductory level.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Asian Dance I (V)
desc: Performance and techniques at the introductory level. Repeatable up to eight credits.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Movement Fundamentals (1)
desc: Organized somatic systems as a framework for understanding movement and dance techniques. Required for majors. Repeatable two times.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Global Perspectives on Dance (3)
desc: Overview of global perspectives on dance, with emphasis on Asia and the Pacific, and related concepts. Includes practical dance performance workshop. Develops written communication skills.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Introduction to Stage Production (3)
desc: Survey class introducing theater management, lighting, costuming, scenery, and other aspects of theatre that relate to producing stage performances. (Cross-listed as THEA 240)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Principles of of Design (3)
desc: Introduction to general design principles as applied to theatre. Will introduce the language and tools of visual literacy and visual communications via individual projects and collaboration. Repeatable two times. (Cross-listed as THEA 245)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Introduction to Stage Production (3)
desc: Survey class introducing theater management, lighting, costuming, scenery, and other aspects of theatre that relate to producing stage performances. (Cross-listed as THEA 240)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Intermediate Contemporary Dance Technique (3)
desc: Low intermediate modern dance technique. Repeatable three times.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Low Intermediate Ballet Technique (3)
desc: Low intermediate ballet technique. Repeatable three times.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Live on Stage (3)
desc: Students view locally produced theatre and dance productions and write performance reviews. Readings, writing, and class discussion will guide students to understand each performance. Performances include theatre, dance, musical theatre, opera, and performance art. Repeatable one time. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as THEA 152)
metadata: DH College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Music Theory for Dancers (3)
desc: Elements of music and relationship to dance; emphasis on rhythmic analysis. (Alt. years)
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Introduction to Dance (3)
desc: Survey the development of major dance styles and their relationship to contemporary choreography, emphasis on teaching writing.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Ballroom Dance (1)
desc: Introduction to those with or without ballroom dance experience. Students will learn the fundamentals of various ballroom dances. Repeatable five times.
metadata: College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Jazz Dance Technique (1)
desc: Introduction to jazz dance technique. Repeatable two times.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Hip Hop Dance (1)
desc: Introductory lecture/lab geared towards those with or without Hip Hop dance experience. Students will learn the fundamentals of various Hip Hop dance styles. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned to eight credits.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Beginning Contemporary Dance Technique (3)
desc: Introduction to contemporary dance technique. Repeatable three times.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Beginning Ballet Technique (3)
desc: Introduction to classical ballet technique. Repeatable three times.
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: DNCE
title: Introduction to Philippine Dance (V)
desc: Beginning techniques of Philippine dance. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. DA

title: Introduction to Okinawan Dance (V)
desc: Beginning techniques of Okinawan dance. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. DA

subject: DNCE
title: Introduction to Korean Dance (V)
desc:
Beginning techniques of Korean dance. Repeatable three 
times, up to 12 credits. DA

subject: DNCE
title: Introduction to Japanese Dance (V)
desc: Beginning techniques of Japanese dance. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. DA
metadata: DA College of Arts, Languages & Letters Dance (DNCE)

subject: EDCS
title: Mixed Methods Research Design (3)
desc: Mixed methods research is designed for PhD and masters students in education and social sciences considering combining qualitative and quantitative research. Covers philosophical and practical implications culminating in a mixed methods dissertation/thesis proposal. Repeatable one time. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as DIS 780 and LTEC 780)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Curriculum and Program Evaluation (3)
desc: Critical examination of theoretical and methodological positions on curriculum and educational program evaluation. Pre: classified doctoral student or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Seminar in Curriculum and Instructional Theories (3)
desc: Analysis and critical examination of models and curriculum theory and theories of instruction leading to generation of theories by seminar members. Pre: classified doctoral student or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Issues and Trends in Curriculum (3)
desc: Uses problem-centered approach and field experiences. Topics include historical review of curriculum development since 1900, examination of current curriculum practices at all levels of education, and prediction of future directions in curriculum theory and design. Pre: classified doctoral student or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Dissertation Research and Writing (3)
desc: Intended for doctoral students at any point of their doctoral program to develop their dissertation prospectus, proposals, comprehensive examinations, and/or initial dissertation drafts. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Research on Teaching and Teacher Education (3)
desc: Examination of alternative approaches and multidisciplinary perspectives on research on teaching and learning in and out of school, on educational change, and on teacher education and professional development. Pre: classified PhD student or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Qualitative Data Analysis (3)
desc: Advanced seminar in qualitative research methods with an emphasis upon qualitative data analysis, theory construction, data presentation and reporting. Pre: 632, a course in introduction to qualitative research methods; or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable up to 36 credits.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Directed Reading and/or Research (V)
desc: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: written consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Plan B Master’s Project (V)
desc: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: School and District Literacy Leadership (3)
desc: Exploration and application of school and district-wide roles of the literacy specialist, such as collaborating with other educators to: (1) design and implement literacy programs, and (2) provide research-supported professional development. A-F only. Pre: 605 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Information Literacy and Learning Resources (3)
desc: Process approach to teaching information retrieval, analysis, and use. Emphasizes concepts, practices ineffective instructional design, selection of resources that meets learning needs. Required for Librarian HDOE licensure. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as LTEC 686 and LIS 686)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Museums and Education (3)
desc: ) Overview of museum education including museum learning theories, informal learning programs, audience research, national and international policies and reports, and community projects. Pre: AMST 683 (or concurrent) or consent. (Cross-listed as AMST 685)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Curriculum Design in Early Childhood Education (3)
desc: Designed to help classroom teachers understand sources and principles of curriculum in early childhood education and to provide experience in evaluating, selecting, and developing appropriate curriculum for young children.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Curriculum (3)
desc: Curriculum trends and issues related to school organization, program, administration, faculty. Required for Plan B MEd candidates in their final semester or summer session. Repeatable one time. (B) early childhood; (D) middle-level; (G) K-14. Pre: 622 (any alpha), and 606 or EDEF 678 or EDEP 408, and 632 or EDEA 604 or EDEP 429 or EDEA 608; or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Seminar in Issues in ECE (V)
desc: Concepts and inquiry regarding the application of early childhood educational principles and approaches to programs serving children between birth and age five. Study and discussion of topics and problems presented in required summer courses and by invited experts in early childhood education. Restricted to masters in Early Childhood Education. Repeatable six times. A-F only. (Two times a year)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Ethnomathematics (3)
desc: Research and practice in ethnomathematics from an interdisciplinary framework. Analysis of ethnomathematics content knowledge and pedagogy; connections among curriculum, standards, and classroom practice; examination of theory and research; and building sustainable campus-community networks. Topics vary. Repeatable three times. A-F only. Pre: teaching experience or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: (Alpha) Mathematics in the Schools (3)
desc: School mathematics, K-12 content, curricula, pedagogy, and standards; trends and issues; theory and research. (B) number and operation; (C) patterns, functions and algebra; (D) geometry and measurement; (E) probability and statistics; (F) integrated math content. Each alpha represents a different K-12 content area. Repeatable three times for (F). Pre: teaching experience or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Theory/Practice in Cooperative Occupational Education (3)
desc: Theory and practices of coordinating cooperative education in high school and community college. Pre: teaching experience or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Reading for English Language Learners (3)
desc: Presents key concepts and theories in teaching reading to K-12 English language learners. Topics include instructional decisions in teaching reading to ELLs, the interrelationship of language skills, strategies, and teaching academic content. A-F only. Pre: 601 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: (Alpha) Classroom and School Literacy Assessment (3)
desc:
Advanced use of formative and summative assessments to monitor/lead classroom and 
school literacy programs. Focus on diversity, leadership, state/national initiatives, and practical applications in schools or other educational contexts. (B) general; (C) multilingualism. May take each alpha one time only.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Literacy Assessment, Instruction, and Intervention (3)
desc: Application of formative assessments to better monitor/guide struggling readers and writers. Topics include diversity and state/national initiatives. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Seminar In Multicultural Literacy (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary examination of research and issues in the teaching and learning of literacy in diverse multicultural settings. A-F only. Pre: course in teaching language arts of multicultural education, teaching experience, or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Diversity Issues (1)
desc: Examination of principles in multicultural education and diversity. (D) middle level; (G) K-14; (R) reading K-12. Each alpha repeatable five times. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: (Alpha) Seminar in Foreign Language (3)
desc: Study in trends, research, and problems of implementation of language education instruction. (B) French; (C) German; (D) Japanese; (F) Spanish. Pre: teaching experience, and consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: (Alpha) Seminar (3)
desc: Study in trends, research, and problems of implementation in teaching field. (C) English; (H) mathematics; (I) literacy; (J) science; (K) social studies; (M) interdisciplinary education; (N) art; (P) place-based education. Each alpha repeatable two times. COE-related majors only for (P). Pre: teaching experience or consent for all alphas except for (P); graduate and/or undergraduate courses in education and/or social sciences or consent for (P). (K Cross-listed as PACE 640, P Cross-listed as SUST 641)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Business and Marketing Education Curriculum (3)
desc: Theory, philosophy, objectives, and development of business and marketing education curriculum. Pre: STE 390D or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: (Alpha) Curriculum and Instruction in Studio Art (3)
desc: Understanding art methods and materials related to art education for teachers grades K-12. Writing curricula, integrating visual arts across the curriculum, developing evaluation methods observing stages of artistic growth among students of multiple ages/abilities. (B) painting, drawing, printing; (C) fiber arts, ceramics, sculpture; (D) photography, technology, collage; (E) Combination of any three of B, C, and/or D. Previous BA, BS, BEd, and BFA only. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: teaching experience or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Qualitative Research Methods (3)
desc: Methods of qualitative research in education or related social science from an interdisciplinary framework.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Cultural Diversity and Education (3)
desc: Examines issues, theories, perspectives and practices in multicultural education and promotes awareness, encourages knowledgeable reflection and develops skills necessary for multicultural practitioners. A-F only. (Cross-listed as EDEF 630)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Function of Play in Early Childhood Education (3)
desc: Review of research and theory illuminating the nature, purposes, and meaning of play as a critical aspect of early childhood education. (Summer only)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Teaching and Learning with Art Objects, Museums, Collections, and Site Visits (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary inquiry and examination of the role of physical objects and site visits in schools and other educational contexts, through visits to local art museums and related sites.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Art Education K-12 (3)
desc: Principles, goals, and objectives in teaching and learning art K-12; curriculum, instruction, and assessment in art education; laboratory experiences in art media. Pre: student teaching or teaching experience.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Social Studies Curriculum (3)
desc: Examination and evaluation of social science content, societal values and research findings as basis for development and revision of social studies materials, texts, curriculum guides, methodology. Pre: STE 322 or equivalent, social studies teaching experience, or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: School Mathematics Curriculum (3)
desc: Analysis of research related to teaching and learning school mathematics, application of research to classroom practices. Appraisal of recent curriculum trends; critical examination of assumptions underlying proposed curriculum changes. Pre: teaching experience or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Science and Science Curriculum, PK-12 (3)
desc:
Application of recent developments in science, sustainability, curriculum development, and learning theory to pre-kindergarten through secondary school. Science philosophy, content and methodology stressed, including inquiry, nature of science, sustainability, and 
science literacy. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as SUST 623)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: (Alpha) Curriculum Leadership (3)
desc: Foundation for critical study of curriculum development and improvement from the perspective of teacher leaders. Online/hybrid sections available; (B) early childhood; (D) middle school; (G) K-14. Pre: teaching experience or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Social and Cultural Constructions of Childhood (3)
desc: Seminar examines the interrelated socially constructed concepts of children and childhood and places them in the larger contexts informed by sociological, anthropological, historical, critical, and technological perspectives. A-F only. Graduate students only.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Early Childhood Education: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: Analysis and practical application of selected early childhood education program and/ or instructional materials. Restricted to majors. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: 415 and 416, or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Early Literacy and Language Development (3)
desc: Theory and practice for PK-3 early literacy and language development. Focus is on content knowledge and pedagogical strategies that support the optimal development of oral language, reading, and writing skills in PK-3 classrooms. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Early Career Teaching, K-12 (3)
desc: Focuses on research and practice related to the first five years of teaching. Especially recommended for beginning teachers and graduate students interested in this stage of teaching development. Repeatable one time.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Literacy Across the Disciplines (3)
desc: Explores theoretical and practical principles of literacy and sustainability across academic disciplines, investigating the role of language and literate practices of reading, writing, speaking, visualizing, and representing in social, cultural, and educational contexts. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Cross-listed as SUST 608)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: New Literacies Leadership +(3)
desc: New approaches to analyzing 21st century literacies K-12, including visual, media, digital, and critical literacies as well as developing leadership practices in multi-literacies pedagogy. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Introduction to Research in Curriculum and Teaching (3)
desc: Classroom-based research covers the fundamentals of qualitative, quantitative, action research, mixed methods, and curriculum based assessment. Exploratory, explanatory, and confirmatory research will be highlighted culminating in an outline for Plan B/Thesis proposal. (Cross-listed as DIS 606)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Literacy Coaching and Leadership (3)
desc: Exploration and application of literacy specialist roles. Includes teaching, coaching, providing resources, advocating for all students, and collaborating with other professionals. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Effective Writing Practices (6)
desc: Analysis and practical application of principles and strategies of effective writing and informed writing instruction in K-12 classrooms. Pre: teaching experience and consent. (Summer only)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Children’s Literature in the Elementary Curriculum (3)
desc: In-depth examination of traditional and current books/media, birth through young adult, with emphasis on applications in schools or other educational contexts. Focus on use of narrative, exposition, and other genres across the curriculum. A-F only. Pre: student teaching or teaching experience or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Advanced Topics in Writing and Oral Language (3)
desc: Current theories and teaching strategies of writing and oral language throughout the lifespan within various social contexts. Focus on teaching writing and oral language as tools for learning and to demonstrate learning. Pre: student teaching or teaching experience or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Advanced Topics in Reading (3)
desc: Current theories and teaching strategies of reading throughout the lifespan within various social contexts. Topics include psychological, sociological, and cultural foundations of reading; 21st century literacies; emergent literacy; diversity; multilingual learners, formative assessment; state/national initiatives. Pre: student teaching or teaching experience or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Language, Learning and Teaching (3)
desc: Examines the role that language plays in the social construction of knowledge within various disciplines, K–adult. Collaborative group learning strategies will be modeled. A-F only. Pre: student teaching or teaching experience or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Difficulties in Learning Mathematics (3)
desc: Identification, analysis, and remediation of difficulties in learning mathematics. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Problem Solving in Mathematics Education (3)
desc: Experiencing and learning to teach heuristics of solving mathematical problems; designing curricula, classroom organization, evaluative measures for problem solving. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Issues in Computer Education (3)
desc: Integration of microcomputers into school curriculum and key issues related to microcomputer use in education. Pre: LTEC 442 or consent. (Cross-listed as STE 480)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Gender Issues in Education (3)
desc: Examines historical and current gender issues in education as they intersect with ethnicity and class. We pay close attention to the writing process and the skills needed to compose a well-written research paper. Pre: WGSS 151 or consent. (Cross-listed as EDEF 453 and WGSS 453)
metadata: DS College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Programs for Infants/Toddlers (3)
desc: Examination of current theory, research, issues, and models in programs for infants and toddlers, including criteria for evaluation and planning. A-F only. Pre: (HDFS 230 (or concurrent), HDFS 331 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B-; or consent. (Cross-listed as SPED 451)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Methods and Materials in Science (3)
desc: Selecting and using methods and materials, demonstrations and simulations, open-ended experimentation, inquiry and discovery, task analysis measurement tools and techniques, activities from various curricula, opportunity for individualized goals and projects. Repeatable one time. Pre: STE 323, STE 404(H), teaching experience; or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Multicultural and Social Justice Education (3)
desc: Exploring social justice and multilingual, multicultural education with attention to Hawai‘i as our place of learning and teaching. (Cross-listed as STE 440)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Interdisciplinary Science Curriculum (3)
desc: Conceptual schemes and processes for integrating science curricula within the sciences and with subject areas. Methods and models of curricular integration such as interdisciplinary, culturally relevant, place and community-based learning. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as SUST 433)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Adolescent Literature and Literacy (3)
desc: Selection and interpretation of young adult literature, including multicultural literature for middle level and high school students. Theory and teaching strategies for integrating literacy instruction in the literature program for diverse student populations. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Collaborative Language and Learning (3)
desc: Examination of language (talking, reading, and writing) processes within a collaborative teaching framework in the secondary curriculum. Field experience may be required. A-F only.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Teaching and Learning for Diverse Young Children Lab (3)
desc: Continuation of 415L. Co-requisite: 416. (Cross-listed as ITE 416L)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Teaching and Learning for Diverse Young Children (3)
desc: Continuation of 415: focuses on the design, implementation, evaluation of meaningful, challenging integrated curriculum that promotes comprehensive developmental and learning outcomes for diverse young children (pK-3). Pre: 415 or consent. (Cross-listed as STE 416)
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Foundations in the Field of Early Childhood Education (Birth to 8 Years) Lab (3)
desc: Direct experience with children in early childhood settings in order to apply concepts from 415 and gain perspective on the role of the practitioner in ECE settings.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: EDCS
title: Foundations in the Field of Early Childhood Education (Birth to 8 Years) (3)
desc: Emphasizes interrelated historical and philosophical roots and socio-cultural context and their influence on policy and practice in early childhood education settings. A-F only. Pre: HDFS 331 or consent.
metadata: College of Education Curriculum Studies (EDCS)

subject: CAAM
title: Nutrition for Clinicians (1)
desc: Provides in-depth lectures and case studies reviewing the role of nutritional therapy in health and illness. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: MDED 554 or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Complementary and Alternative Medicine Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CAAM
title: Introduction to Integrative Medicine (3)
desc: Overview of integrative (complementary) medicine covering Traditional Chinese Medicine, Ayurvedic medicine, naturapathy, traditional healing practices, homeopathy, nutrition and diet, herbs and dietary supplements, environmental health, mind-body, energy, spiritual, and positive psychology. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: Complementary and Alternative Medicine Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CAAM
title: Clinical Nutrition (3)
desc: Overview of applied clinical nutrition that includes nutrients, dietary recommendations for healthy populations, and medical nutrition therapies for patients with diet related diseases or conditions. Repeatable one time. Junior standing and higher. Pre: CHEM 151 (or higher) or PHYL 141 or BIOL 171 or approval from instructor; highly encouraged: FSHN 185 or any other basic nutrition course.
metadata: Complementary and Alternative Medicine Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CAAM
title: Mindfulness Meditation and Stress Reduction (1)
desc: Practice mindfulness meditation to reduce burnout and live life in the present moment. Learn life skills to handle life better and be more resilient. Respond rather than react to life. No experience necessary. Repeatable nine times.
metadata: Complementary and Alternative Medicine Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CAAM) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: COMG
title: Seminar in Health Communication Research (3)
desc: Contemporary interpersonal and/ or public communication issues in health communication research. Topics include communication functions such as information management, interpersonal influence, relational management, emotional management, social influence. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Artificial Intelligence and Communication (3)
desc: Comprehensive understanding of the role and function of computer technology (including. A.I.) within the field of communication. Basic methodological and analytical issues of research related to semi-intelligent artifacts as information source or receiver. COMG majors or consent. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Research on Intercultural Communication (3)
desc: Functional approach to the study of communication in intercultural settings. Examination of culture-based variables and their impact on social influence, relational management, and message processing. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: (601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Seminar in Relational Communication (3)
desc: Contemporary research in interpersonal relations. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: (601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Issues in Message Processing (3)
desc: Contemporary research in verbal and nonverbal message processing. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: (601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Seminar in Persuasion and Influence (3)
desc: Contemporary research in persuasion and influence. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: (601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Seminar in Special Topics in Communicology (3)
desc: Substantive areas in communication that are of current interest and the focus of research, but not addresed in other COMG courses. Topics vary each semester. Content to be announced. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: (601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B), or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Research in Intergroup Communication (3)
desc: Theory, concepts, research, and application of communication processes between members of different social groups. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Approaches to Instructional Communication (3)
desc: Seminar on communication theories and models in instructional environment; emphasis on message processing, classroom dynamics, cognitive and metacognitive processes associated with learning, and learning assessment. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Advanced Research Methods in Communicology (3)
desc: Advanced focus on survey, laboratory, and field study design, data collection, and data analysis. Emphasis on control of variance through design and statistical analysis. Appropriate preparation for graduate theses and dissertations. A-F only. Pre: 602 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable three times. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Only three credits can count toward degree.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Foundations of Intercultural Communication (3)
desc: Major models, theories, and concepts of intercultural communication; basic methodological and analytical issues of research related to intercultural communication; research on intercultural communication. Graduate standing only. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Relational Communication (3)
desc: Major models and theories of interpersonal communication; research on interpersonal relationships; interaction and functions of human communication. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Creating Understanding (3)
desc: Theory and research on human communication, social cognition, comprehension, and creation of understanding. Discussion of information and message processing theories, metacognition, prediction, inference-making, and communication systems. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent); or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Persuasion and Social Influence (3)
desc: Theories of persuasion and resistance to persuasion; assessment of attitudes and measurement of change. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Business Communication (3)
desc: Analysis of communication issues in business through discussion of verbal/nonverbal messages, interpersonal relationships, conflict, and persuasion. Focus on interviewing, group communication, and public speaking skills. A-F only. Pre: 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Practicum for Instructional Communication (1)
desc: Combined seminar and lecture/ discussion format on techniques and procedures for teaching communication skills and their related components in a laboratory setting. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. COMG majors only. Pre: COMG GTA or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Research Methods in Communicology (3)
desc: Design and analysis of quantitative research in communicology. Focus on measurement issues, research design, descriptive and inferential statistics. COMG majors only. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Theories in Communicology (3)
desc: Major theoretical foundations; humanistic and social scientific perspectives. Examination of the research and the development of different models of human communication. COMG majors only. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies (V)
desc: Enrollment for degree completion. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. A-F only. Pre: master’s Plan B candidate and consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Pre: consent of department chair and instructor.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Health Communication (3)
desc: Develop understanding of the process through which communication influences health outcomes, and learn how to design effective health communication programs using theory and research. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Teaching Speech (6)
desc: For communicology majors who lead, under supervision, a freshman seminar section of communicology. Pre: senior standing and consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Communicating Social Support (3)
desc: Survey of major theories, concepts, research, and application regarding communication and social support in interpersonal relationships. (Cross-listed as PSY 477)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Relational Management (3)
desc: Survey and critical discussion of current theory and research in relational management. Focus on written analysis of the role of communication in the initiation, maintenance, decline, and dissolution of different types of relationships. Pre: 381 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Deceptive Communication (3)
desc: Survey of major social scientific theories, concepts, and research findings on deceptive communication, in a lecture/discussion format. Emphasis is on how people create deceptive messages, induce deception, and strategies used to detect deception. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Verbal Communication (3)
desc: Roles of language in human communication and social relationships; language variation, change, and social consequences. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Nonverbal Communication (3)
desc: Understanding communication beyond the words themselves. Review of theory and research on gestures, facial expressions, touch, personal space, and physical appearance. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Theories and Research in Strategic Communication (3)
desc: An in-depth overview of theories related to strategic communication and scientific approaches to attitude formation and changes. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 301 or 364 or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Human Communication and Technology (3)
desc: Analysis of evolving communicative exchanges in the Internet age including how people communicate with computer technology: focus on personal, interpersonal, and cultural effects associated with technology use. Pre: 60 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Conflict Management (3)
desc: Examination of the theories, assumptions, practices, models, and techniques of managing interpersonal conflicts. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Political Communication (3)
desc: Survey of interpersonal and mass communication theories in the political context. Topics may include communication in public opinion processes, elections, debates, political campaigning and advertising. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Social Identity and Intergroup Communication (3)
desc: Surveys theory and research on communication between members of different social groups, highlighting how communication influences and is influenced by social identity. Applies concepts to intergenerational, health, family, educational, multilingual, and computer-mediated contexts. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Internship (V)
desc: Analysis and application of communication knowledge and behaviors in organizational settings. Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Research on Communication Behavior (3)
desc: Survey of research on communication behavior. Verbal and nonverbal data collection; analysis of research data. Students design and implement a research project. Repeatable three times. Pre: 301 and 302.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Evolution and Human Communication (3)
desc: Analysis of the role of human communication in mate attraction, intrasexual competition, cooperation, family dynamics, and coalition formation; discussion on the biological function of language, laughter, yawning, and emotion expressions. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Interrogation and Interviewing (3)
desc: Survey of theory and research on the communicative demands of obtaining reliable information from others. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Special Topics in Culture and Communication (3)
desc: Contemporary research and theory on intercultural communication. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Culture and Communication (3)
desc: Survey of major factors affecting interpersonal communication between members of different cultures. Emphasis upon interaction between U.S. and Asian-Pacific peoples. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Interpersonal Relations (3)
desc: Theory and research on the development, maintenance, and termination of interpersonal relationships. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Family Communication (3)
desc: Focuses on the role of interaction patterns (both constructive and destructive) in the evolution of family communications. The impact of family dynamics upon these interaction patterns is given equal attention. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Creating Understanding (3)
desc: Introduction to theory and research on human communication, comprehension, and creation of understanding. Discussion of information and message processing theories. Topics include prediction, inference-making, communication systems, and deception. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Persuasion (3)
desc: Theories, concepts, strategies, and processes of persuasion and social influence in contemporary society. Focus on analyzing, developing, and resisting persuasive messages. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Leadership and Organizational Communication (3)
desc: Principles and practices of organizational communication and its relationship to networks, leadership, power, conflict, cultures, and other contemporary views of organizational work, change, and development. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Argumentation and Debate (3)
desc: Adapting communication theory to forensic strategies for social action. Practice in formal argument. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Group Decision-Making and Leadership (3)
desc: Study of decision-making within the small group. Effects of organization, leadership, membership, and goals on achieving group purposes. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Professional Presentations (3)
desc: Extends application of public speaking skills to professional contexts: group sales, press conferences, and corporate annual reports. Emphasis on organization, preparation, and delivery. Pre: 151 or 251, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Instructional Communication (3
desc: Analysis of and practice in using models of communication in the classroom. Extends application of oral communication skills to various instructional and teaching contexts. Emphasis on organization, preparation, and delivery. Pre: 151 or 251; or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Research Methods (3)
desc: Introduction to methods of inquiry in the field of communication. Topics include research design and problem formulation, sampling, analytic and observational techniques, and data interpretation. Ethical issues in communication research will be discussed. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Introduction to Communicological Theories (3)
desc: Introduction to the theoretical perspectives that are the foundations of the communication discipline. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Interviewing (3)
desc: Principles and practice; training in informational, persuasive, employment, appraisal, and research interviewing. Pre: one of 151, 170, 181, 185, 251 or 301; or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Principles of Effective Public Speaking (3
desc: Combined lecture/laboratory providing extensive practice in preparing and presenting effective public speeches with special emphasis on organization, outlining, audience analysis, analytical reasoning, and delivery skills.
metadata: DA College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Multicultural Communication Skills (3)
desc: Expose students to practical skills needed for effective intercultural communication. Offer guidelines for improvement in diverse cultural settings such as business, education, counseling, and healthcare.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Introduction to Interpersonal Communication (3)
desc: Introduction to basic principles of interaction between two people. Emphasis is on enhancement of skills in a variety of interpersonal contexts.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Introduction to Nonverbal Communication (3)
desc: Beginning course on the fundamental components of nonverbal communication. Aspects of body movements, facial expressions, eye behavior, physical appearance, voice, touch, space, smell, time, and environmental features will be examined in a lecture/discussion format. Extensive practice in skills.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Personal and Public Speech (3)
desc: Develops communication skills necessary to function effectively in today’s society. Students will enhance their communication skills in one-on-one situations, public speaking, and small group situations. Ideal for new majors and non-majors.
metadata: DA College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: COMG
title: Everyday Communication with Numbers: A Survival Guide (3)
desc: Understanding, communicating, and evaluating quantitative information in everyday contexts. Topics include describing and interpreting data, basic statistics, and evaluating the validity of results.
metadata: FQ College of Social Sciences Communicology (COMG)

subject: CSD
title: Advanced Practicum in Audiology III (3)
desc: Clinical practice in administering tests and interpreting results, counseling of individuals with impaired hearing; use of various rehabilitation techniques. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: 603, 617, 717, and consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Advanced Practicum in Speech Pathology III (V)
desc: Clinical practice in diagnostic and therapeutic procedure with various types of speech and language problems in different clinical settings. Repeatable unlimited times, up to 18 credits.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Seminar in Audiology–Rehabilitative Procedures (3)
desc: Procedures and philosophies presented in recent literature dealing with rehabilitative phases of audiology. Pre: 603 and consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Seminar in Audiology–Diagnostic Procedures (3)
desc: Study of diagnostic procedures as reflected in current literature. Pre: 603 and consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Advanced Practicum in Audiology II (2)
desc: Clinical practice in administering tests and interpreting results; counseling individuals with impaired hearing; use of various rehabilitation techniques. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: 603, 617, and consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Advanced Practicum in Speech Pathology II (6)
desc: Clinical practice in diagnostic and therapeutic procedures with various types of speech and language problems in different clinical settings. Repeatable unlimited times, credit earned for 12 credits only
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: (Alpha) Special Topics in Audiology and Speech-Language Pathology (3)
desc: (B) study of contemporary developments in speech/language pathology; (C) study of contemporary developments in audiology. Repeatable for credit for different alphas unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Dysphagia: Disorders of Swallowing (3)
desc: Explores the dynamics of normal and disordered swallowing across the life span with emphasis on the adult population. CSD majors only. A-F only. Pre: 601 (with a minimum grade of B-). (Summer only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Electrophysiologic Audiometry (3)
desc: Study of early, middle, and late auditory evoked potentials with emphasis on the auditory brainstem response. Pre: 603 or consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Disorders of Fluency (3)
desc: Contemporary developments and theoretical issues in diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment of disorders of fluency such as stuttering in both children and adults.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Amplification: Assessment and Applications (3)
desc: Comprehensive study of amplification. Assessment, fitting, evaluation, electroacoustic evaluation, dispensing. Personal instruments and instructional-educational systems. Pre: 603 and consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: (Alpha) Directed Study (V)
desc: To allow student and faculty advisor to design research/study units outside existing academic structure in specialized area. Repeatable unlimited times. (B) language pathology; (C) audiology. Pre: 603 for (C).
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Research–Audiology (3)
desc: Required of all CSD graduate students following the non-thesis (Plan B) program and emphasizing audiology. Pre: 600 and consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Research–Speech Pathology (1)
desc: Required of all CSD graduate students following the non-thesis (Plan B) program and emphasizing speech-language pathology. Repeatable three times. Pre: 600 and consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Adult Neurogenic Language and Cognitive-Communication Disorders (3)
desc: Study of acquired adult language and cognitive communication disorders associated with stroke, traumatic brain injury, and dementia. Application of evidence-based procedures and strategies for assessment and intervention, review of current literature, and discussion of professional issues. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Voice Disorders (3)
desc: Contemporary development and theoretical issues in the diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment of vocal system disorders in children and adults; current literature and clinical practice issues are addressed. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Audiology Practicum for SpeechLanguage Pathology (1)
desc: Clinical practice in administering tests, interpreting results; counseling of individuals with impaired hearing; use of various rehabilitation techniques. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Advanced Practicum in Speech Pathology I (3)
desc: Clinical practice in diagnostic and therapeutic procedures with various types of speech and language problems in different clinical settings. Repeatable unlimited times, credit earned for six credits only.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Language Development for Children with Hearing Deficiencies (3)
desc: Language acquisition by hard-of-hearing and deaf children; methods of stimulating growth. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Child Language Disorders (3)
desc: Study of the etiology, behavioral characteristics and treatment methods for child language disorders. Examination of methods, test, and instruments employed in diagnosis of child language disorders. Includes identification of language deficits and writing intervention goals. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Disorders of Phonology and Articulation (3)
desc: Study of the etiology, assessment, and remediation of disorders and articulation. A-F only.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Seminar in Motor Speech Disorders (3)
desc: Provides in-depth examination of various motor speech disorders, including apraxia of speech and dysarthria. Emphasis is on assessment/treatment of these diagnoses. Review of current treatment literature, anatomy/physiology, practical exercises in treatment planning. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Audiological Foundations for SpeechLanguage Pathology (3)
desc: Instrumentation; special tests of hearing.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Neuroscience in Communication Sciences and Disorders (3)
desc: Explores the neuroanatomy and neurophysiology of the human nervous system as it relates to communication and swallowing and how neurological pathologies lead to behavioral deficits in those areas. CSD majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Research Methods (3)
desc: Research methods applicable to the field of speech-language pathology and audiology; analysis and reporting of data. Required of all CSD graduate students. Pre: previous coursework in inferential statistics and consent.
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Basic Statistics for Health-Related Professionals (3)
desc: Provides students from behavioral sciences and health-related professions with an overview of normal distribution, central tendency, variability, sampling, hypothesis testing, frequency distribution, correlation, regression, and t-test. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Introduction to Audiometry and Auditory Disorders (3)
desc: Covers anatomy and physiology of the auditory system, acoustic, basic knowledge of auditory disorders and testing procedures, and introduction to rehabilitative audiology. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Summer only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Introduction to Communication Sciences and Disorders (3)
desc: Information and theoretical foundations serve as an introduction to the field of communication disorders. Will provide an overview of the normal processes and disorders of speech, language, hearing, and swallowing. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Introduction to Clinical Methods in Communication Sciences and Disorders (3)
desc: Provides observation and discussion of the clinical management of individuals with communication disorders, and practical experience related to clinical procedures and requirements. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Acoustics and Psychoacoustics of Speech and Hearing (3)
desc: Provides an understanding of the fundamental processes underlying the production and perception of speech. Students gain an understanding of the physical and psychological aspects of sound and their measurement. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Spring only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Speech and Language Development (3)
desc: Will develop an understanding of children’s acquisition of speech, language, and normal communication development from birth through adolescence. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Phonetics (3)
desc: Introduction to the fundamentals of phonetic and phonological development. International Phonetic Alphabet Transcription of English speech sounds; phonological developments and models; cultural variations; analysis interpretation and other considerations related to speech sound development and production. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CSD
title: Anatomy and Physiology of the Speech and Hearing Mechanism (3)
desc: Will overview anatomy and physiology of speech and hearing. Students gain exposure to structures and functions of respiration, phonation, resonance, articulation, deglutition, and hearing systems required for normal communication and swallowing. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: CIS
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Communication and Information Sciences (CIS) Interdisciplinary Programs

subject: CIS
title: Directed Reading and/or Research (V)
desc: Individualized program of directed reading and/or research outside the scope of regularly titled courses. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent. Plan must include goals and rationale.
metadata: Communication and Information Sciences (CIS) Interdisciplinary Programs

subject: CIS
title: Interdisciplinary Seminar in Communication and Information Sciences (1)
desc: Exploration of relationships between disciplines in social sciences, science and technology, and humanities. Faculty and student presentations. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication and Information Sciences (CIS) Interdisciplinary Programs

subject: CIS
title: Data Science Foundations (3)
desc: All aspects of data science: the methodology and processes; ethics and regulatory issues; programming tools; data acquisition, cleaning, analysis and mining; visualization, publication, curation, and preservation; applications in various fields. Graduate students only.
metadata: Communication and Information Sciences (CIS) Interdisciplinary Programs

subject: CIS
title: Special Topics in Communication and Information Sciences (V)
desc: Seminar reflecting research interests of faculty and current interdisciplinary topics in communication and information sciences. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.
metadata: Communication and Information Sciences (CIS) Interdisciplinary Programs

subject: CIS
title: Communication/Information Research Methods (3)
desc: Current research methodologies in decision sciences, computer science, library science, and communication. Emphasis on methodologies suitable for interdisciplinary analysis. Pre: consent .
metadata: Communication and Information Sciences (CIS) Interdisciplinary Programs

subject: CIS
title: Communication/Information Technologies (3)
desc: Technological concepts underlying data communications; information processing and computers; communication channels and networks, information storage and retrieval, and computer hardware and software. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication and Information Sciences (CIS) Interdisciplinary Programs

subject: CIS
title: Communication/Information Theories of Society (3)
desc: A critical review of major theoretical and empirical traditions in communication and information sciences. Focus on European, American, Third World, and applied research. Pre: consent.
metadata: Communication and Information Sciences (CIS) Interdisciplinary Programs

subject: CIS
title: Directed Reading and/or Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Communication and Information Sciences (CIS) Interdisciplinary Programs

subject: COM
title: Thesis (V)
desc: Repeatable up to six credits. Pre: 611 and 612, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Directed Reading and Research (V)
desc: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable up to six credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communication Practicum (V)
desc: Supervised work experience, study of an organization, and career planning. Required of Plan B students in the main communication program. Repeatable up to six credits. CR/NC only. Pre: 611 and 612, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communication Research Seminar (3)
desc: General research seminar in communication. In-depth coverage of specific research methods to develop, refine, or interpret graduate students’ thesis or dissertation projects. COM, CIS majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: 611 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communication Topics (3)
desc: Coverage in depth of some area of theory and research. Repeatable one time. Pre: 611 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: ICT Policy and Planning (3)
desc: Processes and methods of planning appropriate to the information and communication sectors, including future economic, social, political, technical, and environmental perspectives. Pre: 611 (or concurrent) or consent. (Cross-listed as PUBA 628)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Intervention in Multicultural Organizations (3)
desc: Describes the array of communication-related intervention programs designed to enhance effectiveness in multicultural organizations at home and abroad. A-F only. Pre: 623 or 643 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Global Communication and Journalism (3)
desc: Analysis of the emerging global media landscape as digital technologies enable the sharing of news, information, and commentary across geographical and cultural borders. Focuses on causes, characteristics, and consequences. Pre: 612 (or concurrent).
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Intercultural Communication (3)
desc: Problems and opportunities of intercultural communication from theory and research, consulting and training, and policy and program perspectives. Pre: 611 (or concurrent) or consent.
