metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Social Media (3)
desc: Systematic study from a social science perspective of current and emerging social media. Attention to user needs and impact. Pre: 612 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Information and Communication Technologies (3)
desc: Information and communication technologies, structures, processes, and networks as an area of research and study in the social sciences. Pre: 611 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Strategic Organizational Communication (3)
desc: Theories, concepts, and applications of strategic communication and public relations to achieve organizational goals. Pre: 611 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communication Inquiry (3)
desc: Introduction to inquiry and the array of quantitative and qualitative research methods commonly used in communication.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communication Theories (3)
desc: Systematic study of major theories of communication and current status of communication research.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies (1)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Special Problems (V)
desc: Independent study of selected topics under faculty supervision. Repeatable up to three credits. Pre: COM major and junior standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: (Alpha) Communication Internship (V)
desc: Application of communication skills and knowledge. Under faculty supervision, interns participate in operations of an organization and analyze communication processes and effects; (B) community setting; (C) Communication program activity. Maximum of three credits per semester; six credits total toward major; each alpha repeatable up to three credits. Pre: COM major or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Senior Thesis Project (3)
desc: Completion of the thesis project appropriate to the selected focus area within the context of a seminar. Emphasis on ongoing process of writing, editing, review, and revision. Pre: COM major and senior standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communicating Creativity (3)
desc: The role of communication in fostering or inhibiting creativity. Exploration of theoretical bases for shared scientific or artistic creativity in communication research. COM major or consent. Pre: 201 and senior standing, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communication Seminar (3)
desc: Application of theoretic and methodological criteria to researchable questions. Topics will vary. Pre: 201 and senior standing, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Capstone Project in ICTs and Policy (3)
desc: Written research or media project focused on specific ICT and policy problems, including social media, digital games, and the internet. COM majors only. A-F only. Pre: 310 and 320 and 330; and 432 or 438; or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Capstone in Communication in Communities (3)
desc: Synthesize knowledge, apply research findings in service to community, and develop proposal for intervention or campaign through assignments that emphasize the development of writing skills. COM majors only. A-F only. Pre: 310 and 320 and 330; and 340 or 421; or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Capstone in Media Arts Design and Development (3)
desc: Design, development, and evaluation of computer-based media arts communication. Emphasizes authoring and production of such media elements as video, audio, and graphics. COM majors only. A-F only. Pre: 310 and 320 and 330 and 337, or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Political Communication in the Digital Era (3)
desc: An examination of how various aspects of digital media platforms, such as affordances and communication processes impact political outcomes. COM majors or consent. Sophomore standing or higher. (Fall only)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Special Topics in Communication (3)
desc: Topics of relevance to the focus areas of Communication in Communities, Media Arts, and ICTs & Policy; taught by regular and visiting faculty. Repeatable on different topics to six credit hours. COM majors only or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Building Communication Theory (3)
desc: Major theories of communication in terms of requirements for a theory, theory development, associated research, and application. Pre: COM major and junior standing, or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communication and Gender (3)
desc: Theories and issues related to gender and communication applied to organizational, intercultural, and technology mediated communication. COM majors only or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Telecommunication in the Pacific Hemisphere (3)
desc: Development of international telecommunication, with special emphasis on the wireless communication, the internet, and emerging technologies. COM majors only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Media Effects (3)
desc: Social, political, economic, and cultural effects of mediated communication are examined to understand their impact on human behavior. COM majors only or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Video Scriptwriting (3)
desc: Application of communication theory to creating and revising commercial and dramatic script material for video production. Pre: 331 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Social Media (3)
desc: Combined lecture-discussion on the sociocultural, political, psychological, historical and policy dimensions of social media for societies past, contemporary, and future. COM majors only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Studio Production (3)
desc: Studio production ranging from three-camera studio production to broadcast and magazine show formats to on-line web production. Fundamental knowledge of lighting, sound, blocking, and equipment competency. Pre: COM major or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Filming Social Change (3)
desc: Introduction to visual documentary theory and methods. Basic instruction in using digital video technology and hands-on production to tell visual stories and examine social issues related to diverse peoples, cultures, and communities through video projects. A-F only. Pre: one DH or DS course, or consent. (Cross-listed as ES 425)
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Public Relations Campaigns (3)
desc: Synthesizing and applying the principles and techniques of public relations to create comprehensive campaigns. COM majors only. A-F only. Pre: 421 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Public Relations Strategies (3)
desc: Exploring the practice and effects of public relations. Strategic management functions, including use of communication technologies, communication with diverse publics, ethics and social responsibility will be emphasized. COM majors only or consent. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communication in Multicultural Organizations (3)
desc: Cultural diversity in multicultural and multinational organizations is examined regarding communication-related aspects of working life. COM majors only or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Survey of Inquiry Methods in Communication (3)
desc: Exploration of quantitative and qualitative research methods commonly used in communication studies and related professional work. Pre: COM major or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Emerging Topics in Communication (3)
desc: Emerging communication topics of interest to faculty and students. Repeatable one time on different topics, up to six credits. COM majors only. A-F only.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Digital Cultures (3)
desc: Introduction to the social, cultural, and ethical implications of information and communication technologies by studying new and emerging media including games, interactive media, and virtual worlds. COM majors or consent. Pre: 330.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Computer-Mediated Communication (3)
desc: Combine lecture-discussion on the evolution of computer-mediated communication from the 1970s to current day. Examines the development of online communities, technologies, and their networked online and offline social practices. COM majors only or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Intercultural Communication (3)
desc: Problems and opportunities of communication in a variety of intercultural contexts. Focus on theory, research, and managing intercultural effectiveness. Pre: COM major or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Public Relations Writing (3)
desc:
Enhance students’ professional writing skills in the contemporary public relations field and equip students with the foundations of essential techniques for persuasive 
communication. COM majors or consent. A-F only. Pre: 201 (with a minimum grade of B).
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Media Arts Techniques (3)
desc: Combined lecture-lab providing an orientation to, and examination of, procedures and techniques of media arts production. Emphasis on new media literacy, human-computer interaction, and basic electronic media tools for communication design. Pre: 310 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Techniques of Video and Digital Cinema (3)
desc: Orientation to techniques of production. Emphasis on history, language, and theory of the creative process and application to media productions. Pre: 310 or consent.
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Information and Communication Technology Concepts (3)
desc: Combined lecture discussion on basic technical concepts related to ICTs embedded in sociocultural context. Pre: 201 (or concurrent) or consent
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communicating Sustainability (3)
desc: Application of scientific communication theory, strategic communication, and multimedia techniques to select issues of environmental sustainability. COM majors only. A-F only. Pre: 201 or consent. (Crosslisted as SUST 325)
metadata: College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Communication and Communities (3)
desc: Combined lecture-discussion on communication within organizational communities and between organizations and their communities with attention to intercultural issues in local, global, and online interactions. Pre: 201 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Media Arts (3)
desc: Combined lecture-discussion on theories and criticism of visual media, covering aesthetic development and delivery through multimedia and cinematic principles. A-F only. Pre: 201 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DA College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: COM
title: Introduction to Communication (3)
desc: An overview of communication emphasizing intercultural, organizational and international communication and media arts with introduction to multimedia, ICTs, and public relations perspectives.
metadata: DS College of Social Sciences Communication (COM)

subject: CLAS
title: Persia, Greece, and Rome in the Classical Age (3)
desc: Historical examination of the interaction between the Achaemenid and Parthian empires of Persia and the classical societies of the Mediterranean, such as the Greek city-states, Macedonia, the Hellenistic, and Roman Empires. Recommended: HIST 151. (Cross-listed as HIST 430)
metadata: DH Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Art of Greece and Rome (3)
desc: Minoan and Mycenaean arts; Greece and Rome. Pre: ART 175 or consent. (Cross-listed as ART 373)
metadata: DH Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Literatures of Ancient India (3)
desc: Survey of South Asian literature from ancient times to the early medieval period; focusing on Sanskrit, Prakrit, and Tamil poetry traditions. Readings in English translation. (Cross-listed as IP 366)
metadata: DL Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Archaeology of Ancient Rome (3)
desc: Examines the archaeology of the Roman world from the Etruscan period to the reign of the emperor Constantine. Pre: sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Archaeology of Ancient Greece (3)
desc: Introduction to the field of Greek archaeology and methods of archaeological research in the Mediterranean. Pre: sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Greek and Roman Epic (3)
desc: A survey of Greek and Roman epic literature, beginning with Homer’s Iliad and Odyssey and proceeding through the Hellenistic Greek and Roman periods. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DL Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Ancient Roman Literature in Translation (3)
desc: Major writers: emphasis on Vergil, satire, and novel. Pre: sophomore standing or higher or consent.
metadata: DL Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Ancient Greek Literature in Translation (3)
desc: Major writers: emphasis on Homer, drama, and philosophy. Assignments are essay-based and attention is given to developing academic writing skills. Pre: sophomore standing or higher or consent.
metadata: DL Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: The Greek and Roman Novel (3)
desc: Survey of Greek and Roman novels, a collection of highly entertaining texts that offer windows into various aspects of life in the ancient world. Pre: sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DL Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Greek and Roman War Literature (3)
desc: Survey of war-related literature from Greece and Rome, its major themes, and how it reflects the wide range of social, political, intellectual, and literary perspectives on war found in the ancient world. Pre: sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as PACE 325)
metadata: DL Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Nature in the Ancient World (3)
desc: Study of the relationship between the Greeks and Romans and the natural environment. Particular attention will be given to the place of nature in ancient science, philosophy, literature, and “real life.” Assignments are essay-based. Pre: sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DH Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Greek and Roman Drama (3)
desc: Survey of Greek and Roman drama, both tragedies and comedies, tracing the history of a genre that contains some of the wittiest and most agonizing moments in ancient literature. Pre: sophomore standing or higher.
metadata: DL Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: History of the Written Word (3)
desc: A hands-on history of writing beginning in Ancient Greece and Rome. Content includes the development of the alphabet, scripts, books, libraries, and writing in ancient culture. Sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphics II (3)
desc: Decipherment of hieroglyphs and reading of Middle Egyptian literary texts, including Tale of Sinuhe. Pre: 305 or permission of instructor. (Spring only)
metadata: Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphics I (3)
desc: Decipherment of hieroglyphs and reading of Middle Egyptian literary texts. (Fall only)
metadata: Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Biblical Hebrew II (3)
desc: Reading of selected prose passages from the Hebrew Bible; essay-based analysis of literary forms, with attention given both to stories important to the development of the Abrahamic religions and writing-based interpretation of religious traditions. Pre: REL/CLAS 301 with C- or better. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as REL 302)
metadata: DL Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Biblical Hebrew I (3)
desc: Orthography and structure of Biblical Hebrew, history and development of Hebrew as the sacred language of Judaism, overview of religious and historical development of the Hebrew Bible. Pre: sophomore standing or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as REL 301)
metadata: Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: World Myth to 1500 C.E. (3)
desc: Reading and analysis of myths and legends from around the globe, from before the dawn of writing to 1500 C.E. Students will learn to interpret traditional stories from several theoretical and cross-cultural perspectives. A-F only.
metadata: Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Greek and Latin Elements in Scientific Terminology (3)
desc: Important roots, prefixes, and suffixes for building a scientific vocabulary.
metadata: Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Greek and Latin Elements in English (3)
desc: Important roots, prefixes, and suffixes for building a literary vocabulary.
metadata: Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Greek, Roman, and Ancient Mythology (3)
desc: Combines readings and analyses of myths from the ancient world including Europe, Asia, Africa, and Hawai‘i, with an emphasis on comparative analysis of cultures and religions.
metadata: DL Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CLAS
title: Ancient Egypt: Mummies, Pharaohs, and Gods (3)
desc: An overview of ancient Egyptian civilization through lectures and class discussion on Egyptian literature, archaeology, history, religion and society.
metadata: DH Classics (CLAS) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Religions & Ancient Civilizations

subject: CEE
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: candidacy for PhD in civil engineering.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Directed Readings or Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Selected Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering (3)
desc: Highly specialized topics in structures, soils, hydraulics, sanitary, water resources, applied mechanics, transportation. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Plan B Master’s Project (3)
desc: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. CR/NC only. Pre: graduate standing in CEE or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Seminar in Civil and Environmental Engineering (1)
desc: Discussions and reports on literature, research, developments and activities in civil engineering. One unit of all graduate students for each graduate degree. Student presentations are required. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Advanced Concrete Technology (3)
desc: Composition and hydration of concrete, chemical, and mineral admixtures, fresh and hardened properties, mix proportions, high performance concretes, durability and retrofitting technology, non-destructive testing, and advanced material characterization techniques. A-F only. CEE majors only. Graduate students only. Pre: 375 (with a minimum grade of C). (Spring only)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Prestressed Concrete (3)
desc: Behavior of prestressed concrete members, including prestress losses. Analysis and design of prestressed beams, slabs, and composite sections. Anchorage zone design; continuous systems. Recommended: 485 or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Finite Elements in Structures (3)
desc: Finite element method in structural engineering. Extension of structural theory. Virtual work. One- two-, and three-dimensional elements; axisymmetric elements; plate bending. Application to linear problems. Recommended: 681 or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Advanced Structural Steel Design (3)
desc: Load and resistance factored design (LRFD); steel building modeling and analysis; moment-resisting frames; bracing systems; beam-columns; moment connections; composite construction; and plate girders. A-F only. Pre: 486 or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Advanced Reinforced Concrete Design (3)
desc: Slender columns; biaxial bending; combined shear and torsion. Building lateral load resisting frame analysis and design—shearwalls, rigid frames. Floor system analysis and design—flat slabs, joist systems. Computer applications. A-F only. Recommended: 485 or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Modern Structural Analysis (3)
desc: Fundamentals of modern structural analysis theory, with emphasis on frame structures. Virtual work. Member stiffness/flexibility. Matrix formulation of stiffness and flexibility methods. Computer modeling issues. A-F only.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Smart Structures Technology (3)
desc: Fundamentals of sensor technologies for structural engineering applications. Control devices and strategies for protection of structures against extreme events, i.e. earthquakes, strong winds, etc. Structural health monitoring and smart sensor networks. Smart materials for civil structures. CE majors only. A-F only. Pre: 675.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Structural Dynamics II (3)
desc: Elastic and inelastic response of structures due to earthquakes. Seismic design criteria. Code design procedures. Advanced topics in time- and frequency-domain dynamic analysis of structures. A-F only. Pre: 675.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Structural Dynamics I (3)
desc: Response of single and multi degree-of-freedom systems due to dynamic forces. Direct integration of equations of motion. Response spectrum analysis. Application to earthquake loading. Systems with distributed mass and elasticity. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Project Management Systems (3)
desc: Project integration and PMIS; organizational power; conflict, strategic, and life-cycle management in construction management; matrix structure compared to projectized structure; project success; team building; change and culture in construction organizations; competitive bidding. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Continuum Mechanics (3)
desc: Cartesian tensors in mechanics; coordinate transformations; analysis of stress and strain; principal values, invariants, equilibrium and compatibility equations; constitutive relations; field equations. Problems in elasticity. A-F only. Recommended: 370 or ME 371, or consent. (Cross-listed as ME 671)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Pavement Design and Rehabilitation (3)
desc: Pavement engineering with emphasis given to understanding fundamental issues such as historical development of pavement design, approaches used for design of new pavements and overlays, understanding of construction issues and their effects on pavement performance, and various design factors: environmental, loading and materials characterization. Introduction of pavement management systems. A-F only. Recommended: 461 or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Advanced Transportation Modeling and Statistics (3)
desc: Demand modeling, discrete choice and activity-based modeling. Demand forecasting by simulation. Transportation surveys and sampling methods. Application of cluster, factor, regression, logistic and ARIMA analyses to transportation. A-F only. Recommended: 305 and 464, or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Intelligent Transportation Systems (3)
desc: Definition, technologies and their attributes. Analysis and implementation based on FHWA’s User Services. Automated incident detection algorithms. Machine vision applications to traffic engineering. A-F only. Recommended: 462 or 464, or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Systems Analysis for Engineers (3)
desc: Optimization used in design and management of systems for minimizing resources or optimizing outcomes. Evaluation of alternatives, economic efficiency and effectiveness analysis. Logistics. Open to engineering students. Computer applications and labs. Recommended: 462 or 464, or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Earth Pressures (3)
desc: Estimation of lateral earth pressures; analysis and design of retaining walls and excavation support systems. A-F only. Pre: 355 (with a minimum grade of D) and 455 (with a minimum grade of D).
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Marine Geotechnics (3)
desc: Principles of geotechnical engineering applied to marine environments; marine geology; surveying and sampling methods; seabed sediment types, properties, and behavior; coastal and offshore foundations. A-F only. Pre: 355 (with a minimum grade of D).
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Slope and Earth Structures (3)
desc:
Classification of landslides and triggering mechanisms; field 
investigation procedures; limit equilibrium slope stability methods; numerical techniques; seepage and dynamic considerations; case studies. A-F only. Pre: 355 (with a minimum grade of D). (Alt. years)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Advanced Soil Mechanics (3)
desc: Soil continuum mechanics principles; elastic, plastic, and Cam clay soil behavior; critical state and strength; interpretation of laboratory test results. Repeatable two times. A-F only. Pre: 355 (with a minimum grade of D). (Alt. years)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Deep Foundations (3)
desc: Analysis and design of deep foundations; driven piles and drilled shafts. A-F only. Pre: 355 (with a minimum grade of D) and 455 (with a minimum grade of D). (Alt. years)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Seepage, Drainage, and Dewatering (3)
desc: Theory of seepage, field and laboratory methods of measurement; graphical and numerical methods; design of drainage structures; construction dewatering. A-F only. Pre: 355 (with a minimum grade of D).
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Membrane Separations (3)
desc: Applications of membrane separations to desalination, power generation, and ultrapure water systems. Discussion of reverse osmosis, osmosis-driven processes, ultrafiltration, microfiltration, electrodialysis and ion exchange technologies. Membrane fouling and concentration polarization from practical/theoretical standpoints. A-F only. Pre: 635 or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Water Quality Modeling (3)
desc: Mathematical formulation of pollutant transport and mixing in the water environment. Kinetics formulation and parameter identification, model calibration and verification. Design projects. A-F only. Recommended: 422 and 431, or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Hazardous Waste Remediation (3)
desc: Introduces the national problems dealing with the contamination of groundwater and presents remedial measures. Such measures include pump and treat (PAT) technology, in-situ bioremediation, soil vapor extraction, air sparging, electrokinetics, hydraulic fracturing, reactive walls, and phytoremediation. A-F only.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Environmental Microbiology (3)
desc: Combined lecture-discussion on major topics in environmental microbiology, microbial ecology, and a broad understanding of microbial processes in natural and engineered environments. CEE majors only. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing in CEE or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Environmental Chemistry (3)
desc: Basic concepts of chemistry as related to the environment, with more emphasis on water. Topics include chemical kinetics, equilibrium, acid-base, precipitation and dissolution redox reactions, sorption, organic chemicals in the environment. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Biological Treatment (3)
desc: Fundamentals of applied microbiology and biochemical reactor engineering, quantitative description of microbial growth, operational theory and design basis of aerobic, anoxic and anaerobic treatment processes. Applications for water, wastewater, air, solid wastes, and soil. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as BE 634)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Physical and Chemical Treatment (3)
desc: Introduction to physical and chemical processes for water and wastewater treatment: Review of momentum and mass transfer, chemical reactions, colloidal chemistry, coagulation and flocculation, granular filtration, sedimentation, carbon adsorption, gas transfer, disinfection and oxidation. A-F only.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Groundwater Hydrology (3)
desc: Groundwater occurrence, movement, quality, and resource evaluation, development, and management. Emphasis on saltwater encroachment, well evaluation, aquifer protection, recharge with wastewater, and Hawai‘i type hydrology. Recommended: 424 or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Surface Water Hydrology (3)
desc: Deterministic and probabilistic methods include reliability of empirical distributions, multiple regression analysis, extreme value analysis and domain of attraction. Short-memory models for stochastic simulation of streamflows include autoregressive, Markov chain and moving average models. Time series analysis of hydrologic data is discussed. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Hydrologic Processes in Soils (3)
desc: Hydrologic properties in soils and the processes involved in water infiltration drainage and solute transport. Emphasis on key parameters required for modeling. Recommended: 424 or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as BE 664 and NREM 660)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Groundwater Modeling (3)
desc: Introduction to the finite-difference method; steady-state and transient groundwater flow in saturated and unsaturated media; applications to groundwater recharge and aquifer evaluation. A-F only. Pre: 627 or consent. (Cross-listed as ERTH 656)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Fluid Mechanics (3)
desc: Theory of fluid dynamics in differential form, covering equation of motion, vortex generation, flow in rotating frame, potential theory, laminar flow, and introduction to turbulence.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Organizations: Theory and Change (3)
desc: Explores characteristics and structural, human resources, political, and cultural frames of organizational theory. Focus on organizational change strategies and theories. Discusses how to use these frames and theories in everyday management of public service organizations. BE, CEE, ECE, ME majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as PUBA 603)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Parallel Computing for Engineers (3)
desc: Concepts and techniques in high performance parallel computing. Topics include parallel language and algorithms, parallelizing pre-existing serial codes, statistical analysis, and techniques up to increase computational speed and accuracy for problems requiring large memory size. A-F only.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Negotiation and Alternative Dispute Resolution (V)
desc: Lawyers negotiate settlements in almost all their cases. This class presents a “hands-on,” skill-building approach to the newest ideas, as well as centuries-old techniques, about the skill lawyers will use most often in their private practice-negotiation. The class also examines the rapidly developing field of alternative dispute resolution (ADR), including mediation, facilitation, arbitration, and court-annexed ADR. (Cross-listed as LAW 508)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Cost Engineering and Quality Control (3)
desc: Study and applications of cost/schedule control systems criteria, earned value analysis, probabilistic cost estimating, construction risk management, construction quality control, and operations research in construction. Recommended: 472 or 474, or consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Operations Management (3)
desc: Linear programming, simplex method, graphical representation: dual; degeneracy; transportation problem; assignment problems; data envelopment analysis; applications; case studies; managerial reporting; LINDO software. Graduate students only. A-F only. Pre: 476 (or equivalent) (with a minimum grade of B-), and consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies (1)
desc: CR/NC only
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Special Problems (V)
desc: Individual investigation in civil and environmental engineering topics as approved by instructor. Pre: senior standing, and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or minimum GPA of 3.0 in engineering.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Special Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering (3)
desc: Will reflect special interests of visiting and/or permanent faculty. Repeatable one time. Pre: junior or senior standing, and consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Senior Design Project (3)
desc: (Lec/Lab) Design problem involving several areas of civil engineering and requiring a team approach for a solution. Oral communication skills will be assessed through multiple presentations to an industry panel. A-F only. Pre: senior standing in CEE or CNST and 489B. (Spring only)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Structural Steel Design (3)
desc: Basic properties of steel; behavior and design of steel beams, columns, and connections; introduction to rigid frames. Pre: 381.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Reinforced Concrete Design (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Behavior and design of reinforced concrete beams, one-way slabs and columns. Laboratory section includes design and hands-on manufacturing and testing of reinforced concrete members. A-F only. Pre: 375 and 381.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Structural Loads (3)
desc:
Introduction to the minimum load requirements for buildings and other 
structures used in current structural design codes. Derive and apply dead, live, rain, soil, snow, wind, earthquake, flood, inundation, and other loads to structural systems. CEE majors only. A-F only. Pre: 305 and 381.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Field Experience (1)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Undergraduate Structural Research (3)
desc: Individual research project for undergraduate students in the structures track. Topic to be determined by consultation with structural faculty advisor. A-F only. Pre: senior standing and consent.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Construction Planning and Scheduling (3)
desc: To teach the theory and the practice of planning, scheduling, and reporting a construction project through the use of bar chart and CPM. Format to include lectures, text, outside speakers, site visits, discussions, case study, and computers. Pre: 375.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Construction Estimating and Bidding (3)
desc: Estimating science; techniques of estimating quantities and pricing of work for construction contracting; classification of costs, analysis of plans and specifications for estimating; computerized estimating; cash flow, bidding strategy, preparation and submission. CEE, CNST, ECE, ME, OE majors only. A-F only. Pre: 375.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Construction Equipment and Methods (3)
desc: Methods and equipment used on horizontal/ heavy engineering projects. Available equipment, their production, and how they are used to excavate, move, process, and place the earth. Pre: 375 and senior standing.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Construction Project Management (3)
desc: Introductory treatment of the management of construction. Construction supervision, contract documents, estimating and bidding, organization, planning and scheduling, administration, business methods, safety, and labor. CE, CEM, CNST, ECE, and ME majors only. A-F only. Pre: 375. (Cross-listed as ARCH 432)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Construction Methods (3)
desc: Methods of construction, primarily buildings. Construction types: light and heavy wood; steel; plain, reinforced, and prestressed concrete; masonry. Foundations; associated details of frames, walls, roofs, floors, openings, finishes. Disasters, failures, and their causes. Industrialization of the building process. CE, CEM, CNST, ECE, ME majors only. Pre: 375.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Urban and Regional Transportation Planning (3)
desc: Application of travel demand forecasting models to transportation planning. Evaluation and decision-making. Term projects. Pre: 361.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Traffic Engineering (3)
desc: Design/analysis of signalized, unsignalized intersections, urban networks. Traffic impact studies; analysis steps and applications. Design/redesign options. Parking studies: demand, alternative designs (lot layouts). Pre: 361.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Pavement Engineering (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Design principles of flexible and rigid pavements; HMA mixture design, equipment and construction; and application of life cycle cost analysis (LCCA) in pavement engineering. Includes laboratory sessions for aggregate testing and Superpave mix design. A-F only. Pre: 355 (or concurrent), 375 (or concurrent), and 361.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Climate Modeling, Data Analysis and Applications (3)
desc: Introduction to regional and global climate modeling for environmental scientists and engineers. Learn principles of climate modeling, how to access and use climate data for sustainable engineering and environmental management solutions, and effectively communicate results. A-F only. Senior standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as ATMO 449 and SUST 449)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Geotechnical Engineering II (3)
desc: Continuation of 355 field exploration, lateral earth pressures, bearing capacity theory, slope stability, use of geosynthetics. A-F only. Pre: 355.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Infrastructure: Project Impacts, Policy and Sustainability (3)
desc: Evaluation of infrastructure impacts. Impacts regulation and mitigation. Effects of environmental and other policies on infrastructure. Infrastructure relations to sustainability. Energy consumption, transportation efficiency and infrastructure recycling. Lectures and presentations by experts and enrolled students. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: senior standing, open to engineering, science, urban planning, and economics majors. (Cross-listed as SUST 444)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Principles of Sustainability Analysis (3)
desc: Key principles of sustainability and its analysis. Quantification of environmental impact/assessment using target plots, mass/energy balances, and life cycle analyses (cradle to gate/grave) applied to products, processes, or systems. Use of SimaPro. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as OCN 441 and SUST 441)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Vulnerability & Adaptation on Coastal Infrastructure (3)
desc: Assessing vulnerability of coastal communities to climate change stressors and providing technical engineering solutions for adaptation. Senior standing or higher. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as SUST 440)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Water/Wastewater Treatment Design (3)
desc: Physical operations, chemical and biological processes, design flow and process loading rates, pilot plant testing, and treatment plant design. Engineering majors only. Pre: 330.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Water and Wastewater Engineering (3)
desc: Hydrologic fundamentals of water demand and supply; water and wastewater distribution; collection systems; quality characterization; analytical methods for water quality management. Pre: 330.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Applied Hydrology (3)
desc: Surface water hydrology topics include hydrologic cycle, hydrographs, regression methods, urban rain-runoff process, flood frequency analysis, flood routing and hydrology for detention basin design. Groundwater hydrology topics include seawater intrusion, theory of groundwater flow and solutions to steady and unsteady aquifer flows. A-F only. Pre: 305 and 320.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Environmental Fluid Mechanics (3)
desc: Introduction to basic concepts of pollutant transport phenomenon through theoretical modeling, lab and field experiments and observations. Specific topics include mass balance, jets and plumes, mixing and transport in rivers, reservoirs, groundwater and estuaries; non point course pollution. A-F only. Pre: 320, and MATH 244 or MATH 253A (or equivalent). (Alt. years)
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Engineering Hydraulics (3)
desc: Hydraulics of closed conduits and open channels with emphasis on engineering applications. Topics also include pump hydraulics, bridge hydraulics, urban drainage engineering, and flood plain management. A-F only. Pre: 320.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Computer Methods in Engineering Systems (3)
desc: Numerical solutions of engineering problems using digital computers. Regression analysis; numerical differentiation and integration; solutions of algebraic, transcendental, and differential equations; and analysis of large structural systems. Pre: computer programming and senior standing.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Engineering Economics (3)
desc: Economic analysis in engineering and management decision-making, interest, depreciation, income tax, cost classification, break-even analysis, economic comparisons of alternatives, benefit-cost analysis. BENG, CE, CEM, CNST, ECE, and ME majors only. A-F only. Pre: ECON 120 (with a minimum grade of C-) or 130 (with a minimum grade of C-), and senior standing. (Cross-listed as BE 405)
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Structural Analysis (3)
desc: Analysis of statically determinate plane and space trusses and frames; deflections; introduction to matrix methods; computer applications. A-F only. Pre: 370 with a minimum grade of C or better.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Construction Materials (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Concrete properties, role of aggregates, concrete mix design, supplementary cementitious materials, chemical admixtures, behavior of concrete, concrete testing, field practices. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. Pre: 305 (or concurrent); and 370 with a minimum grade of C or better.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Mechanics of Materials Lab (1)
desc: Tension, compression, and torsion of bars, and bending of beams. CEE and CNST majors only. A-F only. Pre: 370 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Mechanics of Solids (3)
desc: Introduction to analysis and design of deformable bodies subject to loading. Stress, strain, constitutive relation, axially loading, torsion, statically indeterminate systems, Mohr’s circle, failure criteria, buckling, defection due to axial, shear, torsional, and flexural loading. Pre: C or better in all of the following: 270; and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). (Crosslisted as ME 371)
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Fundamentals of Transportation (3)
desc: Transportation modes: land, air, water, pipelines. Tourist, urban transportation. Geometric design, human factors, vehicular flow models, capacity analysis. Overview: traffic impact, air quality, parking studies. A-F only. Pre: 271.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Geotechnical Engineering I (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to geotechnical engineering: soil characterization, index properties, seepage and flow in soil, stresses in soils, compressibility, consolidation, shear strength. Substantial emphasis on writing lab reports. A-F only. Pre: 320, 370.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Environmental Engineering (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Parameters and indices of environmental quality; materials balances; chemical kinetics; ideal reactor models; water and air pollution control; solid and hazardous waste management; emphasis on instruction in writing lab reports. A-F only. Pre: 271.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Fluid Mechanics Fundamentals (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Compressible and incompressible fluid properties; fluid statics; kinematics, energy and momentum considerations in steady flows; application of steady flow concepts to various fluid processes; with an emphasis on instruction in writing lab reports. A-F only. Pre: 271.
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Applied Probability and Statistics (3)
desc: Description of sample data; correlation and regression; probability and statistical distributions; estimations of population parameters; fitting distributions to histograms; hypothesis testing. A-F only. Pre: MATH 244 or MATH 253A.
metadata: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Applied Mechanics II (3)
desc:
Dynamics of particles and rigid bodies; force, acceleration, impulse-momentum, work-energy. CE, CNST, ENGS, ME majors only. A-F only. Pre: C or better in 270; MATH 
244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as ME 271)
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CEE
title: Applied Mechanics I (3)
desc: Forces, resultants, and equilibrium; analysis of trusses, frames, and machines; centroids, moments of inertia; friction. A-F only. Pre: grade of C or better in all of the following: PHYS 170; MATH 242 or 252A; and either MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent).
metadata: DP Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) College of Engineering

subject: CHN
title: (Alpha) Research Seminar in Chinese Literature (3)
desc: Study of authors, a genre, a period, or a problem. (M) modern; (T) traditional. Repeatable one time for (M). A-F only for (M). Pre: EALL 611, WGSS 613, WGSS 615, or WGSS 650; or consent for (M); 612, or consent for (T). (Cross-listed as WGSS 753 (Alpha))
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: (Alpha) Research Seminar in Chinese Language (3)
desc: (B) teaching methods; (C) structure; (D) classical grammar; (E) sociolinguistics. Pre: 643 for (B) and (E); 452 for (C) and (D).
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Advanced Classical Chinese (3)
desc: Pre: 661 and consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Advanced Classical Chinese (3)
desc: Pre: 660 and consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Second Semester Classical Chinese (3)
desc: Builds on the foundation laid in 461; introduces complex syntactic patterns, advanced vocabulary; teaches sophisticated reading strategies and cultural literary contexts; exposes students to a wide range of intermediate level texts. Repeatable two times. Pre: 461 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Current Topics in Chinese Grammar (3)
desc: Current approaches to Chinese grammar and related issues and debates, focusing on the papers published by leading Chinese linguists employing these approaches. Pre: 452, 455, or 456; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: (Alpha) Topics in Chinese Language (3)
desc: Extensive studies of selected topics (B) teaching and testing: specific problems in teaching Chinese including characters and cultural elements; proficiency and communicative ability; (C) cognitive grammar. A-F only for (C). Pre: 451 and 452, or consent. Once a year.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Practicum: Teaching Chinese Language (3)
desc: For graduate students pursuing teaching Chinese language. Students gain practical skills and hands-on experiences in creating instructional and assessment materials and teaching an actual Chinese language class using the self-developed materials effectively. Pre: 643 or consent. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Methods in Teaching Chinese as Second Language (3)
desc: Problems in language learning and teaching. Practice in preparing and presenting lessons with materials based on comparative linguistic analysis. Materials, teaching aids, test construction. Pre: 451 and 452, or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Contrastive Analysis of Mandarin and English (3)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Chinese Syntax and Semantics (3)
desc: Verbal categories, aspects, focus devices, resultative and directional compounds, coverbial constructions. Interaction between syntax and semantics. Pre: 452 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Chinese Dialects (3)
desc: Synchronic description of a Chinese dialect other than Cantonese and Mandarin; contrastive and comparative studies with Mandarin. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: 451 and 452, or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: (Alpha) History of Chinese Language (3)
desc: (B) phonology; (C) syntax. Pre: 451, LING 421, or consent for (B); 452 or consent for (C).
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Traditional Chinese Fiction (3)
desc: Formal and thematic analysis of short stories, historical romances, and novels. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: (Alpha) Chinese Poetry (3)
desc: Critical study of major traditional Chinese poetic forms. (B) ancient (to 5th century); (C) medieval (5th–10th century). Pre: 461 or consent for (B), 610B or consent for (C).
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Introduction to Study of Contemporary Chinese Linguistics (3)
desc: Panoramic overview of major perspectives in contemporary Chinese linguistics. Readings on recent developments of fields. Report on selected research papers and present analysis of linguistic phenomena of interest. Pre: 452 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Directed Fourth-Level Reading (V)
desc: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. Primarily for graduate students from other departments. Pre: consent
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Overseas Internship in China (V)
desc: Supervised internships in a Chinese-speaking institution in China. Students must pass 486 with a B- or higher and be accepted to the Flagship Capstone Year in China to take this. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. CR/NC only. Pre: 461 and 485 and 486 (with a minimum grade of B- or better) and proficiency assessment and acceptance to Flagship Capstone year in China.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Internship Program (V)
desc: Faculty supervised participation in the operations of an organization in a position making use of students’ Chinese language skills in Hawai‘i. Students must achieve a grade of B- in CHN 302 to take this course. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. CHN majors only. Junior/senior standing only. Pre: 302 (with a minimum grade of B-) or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Oral Fluency Through Chinese Films (3)
desc: Increasing Chinese proficiency through film, which offers authentically rich cultural contexts. Focus on oral communication. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: DH Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Flagship Experience Abroad (V)
desc: Designed for students participating in the Flagship Capstone Year in China taught entirely in Chinese. Students will take two courses taught in Chinese in their field at Nanjing or Beijing Union University. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. CR/NC only. Pre: 486 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Flagship Media and Society Abroad (3)
desc: Designed for students participating in the Flagship Capstone Year in China taught entirely in Chinese. Students will improve their knowledge of Chinese media, how it operates, and its effects on Chinese society. A-F only. Pre: 486 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Flagship Rhetoric and Composition Abroad (3)
desc: Designed for students participating in the Flagship Capstone Year in China taught entirely in Chinese. Students will improve their knowledge of and ability to use Chinese to effectively communicate in writing. A-F only. Pre: 486 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: (Alpha) Readings in 20th Century Chinese Literature (3)
desc: Representative works of writers from People’s Republic of China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. (B) short stories; (C) poetry and drama; (D) novels and essays. Repeatable two times. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: DL Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Academic (3)
desc: Focus on academic reading, writing, speaking, and listening with emphasis on writing instruction in order to train students to the Superior (according to ACTFL standards) level of language proficiency. Repeatable one time when taken in China as part of the UH Chinese Flagship Program. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Professional Chinese (3)
desc: Focus on professional reading, writing, speaking, and listening in order to train students to the Superior (according to ACTFL standards) level of language proficiency. Repeatable one time when taken in China as part of the UH Chinese Flagship Program. Pre: 402 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Language and Culture of China (3)
desc: Extensive exposure–chiefly through tape recordings, classroom conversation, and outside readings–to history, culture, and institutions. Pre: 202 or 204, or consent.
metadata: DH Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Introduction to Classical Chinese (3)
desc: Analysis of basic structural patterns through selected readings in various texts. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Chinese Words and the Lexicon (3)
desc: Defines properties of the Chinese lexicon, introduces its principles, approaches, and methodologies in Chinese lexicology, outlines similarities and differences between the Chinese and English lexicons, and advances students’ Chinese language proficiency. Pre: 202 or 205, or consent. (Alt. years: fall)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Chinese Semantics and Communication (3)
desc: Study of the meaning of Chinese sentences in isolation, in discourse contexts, and in written texts. Pays equal attention to theoretical issues and practical problems in Chinese semantics and communication. Pre: 202 or 204, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Chinese Pragmatics and Discourse (3)
desc: Introduction to pragmatics and discourse analysis of Mandarin Chinese; some discussion of usage and linguistic geography. Pre: 202, 204; or consent.
metadata: DH Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Study of Chinese Characters II (3)
desc: Continuation of 453. Pre: 453 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Study of Chinese Characters I (3)
desc: Origin, structure, and evolution. Pre: 402, 461; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Structure of Chinese (3)
desc: Introduction to syntax and semantics of Mandarin Chinese; some discussion of usage and linguistic geography. Pre: 202 or 204; or consent.
metadata: DH Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Chinese Language and Linguistics (3)
desc: Covers major areas of linguistic description as applied to Chinese language, with significant attention paid to developing writing skills on demonstrating knowledge of the basics of Chinese linguistic features and analyzing Chinese language phenomena. Pre: 202, 204, or 205; or consent.
metadata: DH Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Fourth Year Reading and Writing: Contemporary Social Issues (3)
desc: Asynchronous web-based course with focuses on (i) authentic texts covering a variety of contemporary social issues, and (ii) writing expository/argumentative essays by referencing and reflecting on the readings, along with interacting with peers. Pre: 401 (or concurrent) or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Fourth Year Reading and Writing: Advanced Topics (3)
desc: Asynchronous web-based course with focuses on (i) reading selected texts across a broad range of genres, and (ii) writing expository and argumentative essays by referencing and reflecting on the readings, along with interacting with peers. Pre: 401 (or concurrent) or equivalent or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: (Alpha) Chinese Translation (3)
desc: Training in techniques; theory of translation. (B) Chinese–English; (C) English–Chinese. Pre: consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Advanced Mandarin Conversation II (3)
desc: Continuation of 411. Pre: 411 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Advanced Mandarin Conversation I (3)
desc: Systematic practice on academic topics of conversation. Lab work. Pre: 302 or 303, or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Fourth-Year Chinese for Business Professionals (6)
desc: Accelerated, intensive advanced course focusing on specialized advanced listening, speaking, reading, and writing communicative needs of business professionals in the Chinese business context. Pre: 305 (or equivalent) or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Accelerated Fourth-Level Mandarin (6)
desc: Content of 401 and 402 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, three times a week. Pre: 302 or 303 or 305; or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Fourth-Level Mandarin II (3)
desc: Continuation of 401. Pre: 401 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Fourth-Level Mandarin I (3)
desc: Extensive reading in academic topics. Meets one hour a day, three times a week. Pre: 302 or 303 or 305; or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Directed Third-Level Reading (V)
desc: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in their area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing (3)
desc: Web-based training in Chinese reading and writing to develop skills at the advanced level. Activities combine independent work with communicative activities on the course web site. Ideal for in-service professionals seeking language development and maintenance. Repeatable one time. Pre: 301 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Advanced Chinese Listening and Writing (3)
desc: Web-based training in Chinese listening, reading, and writing to develop skills at the advanced level. Activities combine independent work with communicative activities on the course website. Features language exchange with native speakers. Repeatable one time. Pre: 301 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Chinese Dialect Studies (V)
desc: Advanced Cantonese or other Chinese dialects. Repeatable one time. CR/NC for native Chinese speakers. Pre: consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Mandarin Conversation II (3)
desc: Continuation of 311. Pre: 311 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Mandarin Conversation I (3)
desc: Systematic practice on everyday topics of conversation. Lab work. Pre: 202 or 204 or 252; or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Third-Year Chinese for Business Professionals (6)
desc: Accelerated, intensive advanced course focusing on general advanced listening, speaking, reading, and writing communicative needs of business professionals in the Chinese business context. Pre: 205 (or equivalent) or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Accelerated Third-Level Mandarin (6)
desc: Content of 301 and 302 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, three times a week. Pre: 202 or 204 or 205 or 252; or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Third-Level Mandarin II (3)
desc: Continuation of 301. Pre: 301 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Third-Level Mandarin I (3)
desc: Vocabulary building and extended mastery of sentence structures of modern Chinese through reading and related conversation. Meets one hour a day, three times a week. Pre: 202 or 204 or 205 or 252; or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Reading and Writing Chinese II (3)
desc: Continuation of 251. Pre: 251 or consent.
metadata: Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Reading and Writing Chinese I (3)
desc: For students who have completed the conversational Mandarin courses up through 212 and wish to continue on to 301, or others who can handle daily conversation in Mandarin but cannot read or write in the language. Pre: 212 or consent.

subject: CHN
title: Intermediate Conversational Mandarin II (3)
desc: Continuation of 211. Pre: 201 or 211, or consent.

desc: Further development of listening and speaking skills in Mandarin. The student is expected to be able to comprehend and produce speech at the paragraph level. Pre: 102 or 103 or 112, or consent.

title: Intermediate Chinese for Business Professionals (8)
desc: Accelerated, intensive intermediate course focusing on everyday listening, speaking, reading, and writing communicative needs of business professionals in the Chinese business context. Pre: 105 (or equivalent) or consent.

subject: CHN
title: Accelerated Intermediate Mandarin (8)
desc: Content of 201 and 202 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, four times a week. Pre: placement test and 102 or 103 or 105; or consent.

subject: CHN
title: Intermediate Mandarin II (4)
desc: Continuation of 201. Pre: 201 or consent.

subject: CHN
title: Elementary Conversational Mandarin II (3)
desc: Continuation of 111. Pre: 101 or 111 or consent.

title: Elementary Conversational Mandarin I (3)
desc: Development of basic skills (listening, speaking and grammar) of spoken Mandarin with application to some familiar everyday topics.

subject: CHN
title: Elementary Chinese for Business Professionals (8)
desc: Accelerated, intensive elementary course focusing on everyday listening, speaking, reading, and writing communicative needs of business professionals in the Chinese business context. Pre: consent. (Fall only)
metadata: HSL Chinese (CHN) East Asian Languages and Literatures (EALL)

subject: CHN
title: Accelerated Elementary Mandarin (8)
desc: Content of 101 and 102 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, four times a week. Pre: placement test.

title: Elementary Mandarin II (4)
desc: Continuation of 101. Pre: 101 or consent.

subject: CHEM
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: candidacy for PhD degree and consent of dissertation chair.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Special Topics: Biochemistry (V)
desc: Theory and applications. A-F only. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Special Topics: Physical Chemistry (V)
desc: Theory and applications. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics. Pre: consent.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Special Topics: Organic Chemistry (V)
desc: Theory and applications. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics. Pre: consent.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Special Topics: Inorganic Chemistry (V)
desc: Theory and applications. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics. Pre: consent.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: candidacy for MS degree and consent of thesis chair.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: (Alpha) Chemistry Seminar II (1)
desc: Continuation of 691. Current topics in: (D) physical; (E) organic; (Q) biochemistry; (Z) inorganic chemistry. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: (Alpha) Chemistry Seminar I (1)
desc: Current topics in (D) physical; (E) organic; (Q) biochemistry; (Z) inorganic chemistry. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Enzyme Reaction Mechanisms (3)
desc: The chemical mechanisms of reactions catalyzed by enzymes in biochemical pathways, with an emphasis on the major types of cofactor and metal catalyzed reactions. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Crystallography (3)
desc: Crystal symmetry. Elementary x-ray physics. Diffraction theory and its application to crystal and molecular structure determination. Pre: 352 and MATH 244 or MATH 253A.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Astrochemistry–A Molecular Approach (3)
desc: Formation of astrobiologically important molecules and their precursors in the interstellar medium and in our solar system: first principles and latest trends. Pre: consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as ASTR 657 and ERTH 657)
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Quantum Chemistry (3)
desc: Rigorous introduction to quantum mechanics, including operator formalism, matrix formation, group theory, and perturbation theory; introduction to the electronic structure of atoms and molecules. Pre: graduate standing in CHEM.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Chemical Kinetics and Reaction Dynamics (3)
desc: Kinetics and chemical reaction dynamics of elementary reactions relevant to combustion processes, astrochemistry, chemical vapor deposition and planetary sciences. Pre: graduate standing in CHEM. (Spring only)
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Chemical Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics (3)
desc: Includes statistical thermodynamics, with application to chemical systems. Pre: graduate standing in CHEM.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Synthesis II (3)
desc: Continuation of 642, and is the second half of a two-semester course in Modern Organic Synthesis. Pre: 642 and a minimum required grade for prerequisites of B. (Spring only)
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Physical Organic Chemistry (3)
desc: Theory of molecular structure, stereochemistry, and reaction mechanisms. Pre: 601 or consent.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Synthesis I (3)
desc: Modern synthetic methods with emphasis on the design and execution of multi-step sequences. Pre: graduate standing or consent
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Structure Determination (3)
desc: Interpretation of chemical and physical (primarily spectral) data in the identification of organic compounds. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Methods of Instrumental Analysis (V)
desc: Theory, instrumentation, applications. Three areas each semester-one credit hour per area. Repeatable unlimited times in different areas. Pre: 333 and graduate standing in CHEM or consent.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Organometallics II (3)
desc: Introduction to the principles of catalysis and the classes of catalytic reactions effected by organometallic compounds. A-F only. Pre: 622 and a minimum required grade for prerequisites of B.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Coordination Chemistry (3)
desc: Survey of Lewis acids and bases, coordination numbers, geometries, stereochemistry, ligand field theory, formation constants, and bioinorganic chemistry. Pre: 601 and 602 (or concurrent).
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Organometallics I (3)
desc: Reactivity and reaction mechanisms of compounds containing metalcarbon bonds. Pre: 352 and 427.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Chemical Applications of Spectroscopy (V)
desc: Introduction to magnetic resonance, infrared, UV, and visible spectroscopy, emphasizing applications to organic and inorganic chemistry. Three topics each semester–1 credit hour per topic. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics. Pre: graduate standing in CHEM.
metadata: Chemistry (CHEM) College of Natural Sciences

subject: CHEM
title: Theory of Chemical Bonding (3)
