Mathematical, observational, experimental results on effects of mutation, selection, and systems of mating on distribution of genes. Analysis of non-experimental populations. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as CMB 650)   Professional Development Courses for Science Teachers 
 See other science professional development courses NSCI 501, 502, 503, 504, 505, and 619 under the Natural Sciences (NSCI) course listing in this section of the Catalog.
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Biological Directed Research (V)
desc: Development and completion of a research project under the direction of a faculty advisor. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits, up to 6 credits apply towards BA and BS BIOL major requirements. A-F only. Pre: 2.5 GPA minimum, written proposal and consent.
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Mathematical Biology Seminar (1)
desc: Reports on research in mathematical biology, reviews of literature, and research presentation. Required for Certificate in Mathematical Biology. Repeatable one time. Pre: junior standing or higher and consent. (Cross-listed as MATH 490)
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Topics for Biologists (3)
desc: Focuses on the use of computational tools and approaches to analyze the enormous amount of biological data (DNA, RNA, protein) available today. A-F only. Pre: (171 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as MBBE 483)
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Life in the Soil Environment Lab (1)
desc: Laboratory to accompany 480. Technical examination of bacteria, fungi, protists, nematodes, arthropods, and other invertebrate, and the essential functional roles these organisms contribute to sustainability of the planet. Repeatable one time. Pre: 171L and 172L, or MICR 351L, or consent. Co-requisite: 480. (Crosslisted as TPSS 480L)
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Life in the Soil Environment (3)
desc: An interdisciplinary study of the diverse life in the soil beneath our feet that includes bacteria, fungi, protists, nematodes, arthropods, invertebrate, viruses, and the essential functional roles these organisms contribute to sustainability of the planet. Repeatable one time. Pre: 375 or TPSS/PEPS/SUST 371, or MICR 351, or consent. (Cross-listed as TPSS 480)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: The Biology of Cancer (3)
desc: Integrative, in-depth focus on the genetics, cell biology, and molecular basis of cancer. Combination of classroom lectures and problem-based discussions in small groups. Addresses ethical implications of cancer research and treatment. A-F only. MCB or BIOL majors only. Senior standing or higher. Pre: 407 (or concurrent) and 408 (or concurrent) or consent. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as MCB 472)
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: The Rise of Fishes: An Evolutionary History (3)
desc: The origins and early evolution of fishes, with a focus on morphological innovations that have led to lineage divergence and adaptive radiation, and the nature of underlying processes associated with novel character trait evolution. A-F only. Pre: 265. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Psychoactive Drug Plants (3)
desc: Taxonomy, ecology, biochemistry, distribution, cultural history, and contemporary use of mind-altering drug plants; examples from primitive, traditional, and modern societies. Pre: junior standing, one semester of biological science, and either ANTH 200 or GEO 151; or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Wildlife and Plant Conservation (3)
desc: Principles of conservation biology and wildlife management techniques, illustrated with animal, plant, and ecosystem examples. Examination of ethical, cultural, legal, political, and socio-economic issues impinging on conservation policy and practice. Group project and field trips. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 265/265L or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Human Role in Environmental Change (3)
desc: Human impacts through time on vegetation, animals, landforms, soils, climate, and atmosphere. Special reference to Asian/Pacific region. Implications of long-term environmental change for human habitability. Pre: with a minimum grade of B, one of 101, 123 or GEO 101 and either 310 or GEO 322; or consent. (Cross-listed as GEO 410)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Molecular and Cellular Biology Laboratory (2)
desc: (2 3-hr Lab) A laboratory to accompany 407 and 408. Pre: 407 (or concurrent) or 408 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as MCB 408L)
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Molecular Cellular Biology II (3)
desc: Cell structure and function. Structure, chemistry, and functions of organelles and macromolecules. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 407; or consent. (Cross-listed as MBBE 408 and MCB 408)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Molecular Cell Biology I (3)
desc: Relationship between structure and function at macromolecular level. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 275/275L and CHEM 273, or consent. (Cross-listed as MCB 407)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Biology of Marine Organisms (3)
desc: Biology, physiology, and ecology of marine organisms and marine ecosystems, and the physical and chemical factors, which influence them. Cannot be used to satisfy BS-MB major requirements. Credit granted for only one of ZOOL 200, BIOL 301, or BIOL 406. Junior standing or consent. A-F only. Pre: 171 and 172. (Spring only)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Topics in Marine Biology (3)
desc: Current themes in marine biology and experience in scientific assessment. Emphasis on teaching writing and oral communication. Repeatable two times. MBIO majors only. A-F only. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 301/301L or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Field Problems in Marine Biology (4)
desc: Integrated program of intensive lectures, laboratory experiments, and field research that focus on the biological processes that shape the lives of marine organisms. A-F only. Limited space; enrollment by consent; GPA considered. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 301/301L and consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Principles of Biochemistry (4)
desc: Molecular basis of living processes in bacteria, plants, and animals; emphasis on metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 275/275L, and CHEM 273; or consent. (Cross-listed as MBBE 402)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Molecular Biotechnology (3)
desc: General principles, applications, and recent advances of the rapidly growing science of biotechnology. Topics include impact of biotechnology on medicine, animal sciences, environment, agriculture, forensics, and economic and socio-ethical issues. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 275 or consent. (Cross-listed as MBBE 401)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Ocean Internships and Research (V)
desc: Students carry out marine-related internships, practica, research projects or field experience on-or off-campus with faculty guidance. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: minimum cum GPA of 2.5, junior or senior standing in any field of study and IS 100/BIOL 104 or consent, project proposal. (Crosslisted as IS 400)
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: (Alpha) Teaching Internship (2)
desc: Teaching internship in the Life Sciences that includes the preparation and demonstration of laboratory experiments or classroom activities. (B) general; (C) oral emphasis, includes emphasis on instruction in oral communication. Repeatable one time. Pre: consent
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Communicating in Biological Sciences (3)
desc: Combined lecture/lab impart essential knowledge and skills in technical writing, poster design, and oral presentations for effective communication for life science majors. Research papers, lab reports, project proposals, conference presentations are covered. A-F only. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 171/171L, 172/172L, and ENG 100.
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Genetics Laboratory (2)
desc: (1 4-hr Lab) Experiments with a variety of organisms to illustrate principles discussed in BIOL 375. Pre: 275/275L, 375 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Genetics (3)
desc: Genetic concepts at advanced undergraduate level; genetic transmission, recombination, gene action, mutation, population and evolutionary genetics. A-F only. Pre: 275 or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Biological Field Studies (V)
desc: Biological survey, collection, and analysis techniques will be reviewed and applied through field studies. Students will be introduced to the uniqueness of the Hawaiian environment and its diversity of life. Emphasis on diversity, evolution and ecology. Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 265/265L (or equivalent), or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Island Ecosystems (3)
desc: Characteristics of island biota; examples from Hawai‘i and the Pacific. Impact of island and continental cultures; policy and ecosystem endangerment; contemporary legislation, policy, and management practices. Pre: one semester of biological science or consent. Not a BIOL major elective.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Sex Differences in the Life Cycle (3)
desc: Human sex differences, their biological basis and significance, ethical considerations of genetic, hormonal, and behavioral determinants of sexual differentiation; biology of gender, sexuality, parenting, menopause, and aging. Pre: one semester of biological science. (Cross-listed as WGSS 350)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Genetics, Evolution and Society (3)
desc: The role of genetics in evolution, medicine, behavior, plant and animal breeding and technology; its impact on today’s society. Not a BIOL major elective. Pre: one semester of biological science at college level or consent. (Cross-listed as CMB 351)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Marine Mammal Biology (3)
desc: Overview of marine mammal science, significance and roles of marine mammals in their ecosystems, and marine conservation issues. Current research topics in marine mammal science will also be covered. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 171/171L, 172/172L, and 265, 265L; or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Environmental Issues (3)
desc: Global environmental problems in historical perspective; physical, biological, sociocultural views. Pre: one of 101, 123, or GEO 101; or consent. (Cross-listed as SUST 309)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Ecology (3)
desc: General survey of the principles of ecology. Focus on processes influencing the distribution and abundance of organisms, interactions among organisms, and interactions between organisms and the environment. A-F only. Pre: BIOL 171; BIOL 172 or BOT 201. (Cross-listed as BOT 305)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Biotechnology: Science and Ethical Issues (3)
desc: Introduction to the concepts, goals, ethical issues and consequences of biotechnology using real-life case studies of GMOs, cloning, DNA fingerprinting, gene therapy and genetical engineering. Pre: 171 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent. (Cross-listed as MBBE 304)
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Marine Ecology and Evolution Lab (2)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 301. MBIO majors only. A-F only. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 301 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Marine Ecology and Evolution (3)
desc: Ecological and evolutionary factors creating and maintaining patterns of biological diversity in major marine ecosystems. Emphasis on the biphasic life histories of many marine organisms. The development of quantitative skills and critical thinking. MBIO majors only. A-F only. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 265, 301L (or concurrent), and OCN 201; or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Service Learning for Biology Majors (V)
desc: Directed participation on tutorials and related activities in public schools and approved community and UH Mānoa organizations. A-F only. Repeatable one time. Pre: 265/265L, 275/275L, and consent.
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Cell and Molecular Biology Lab (2)
desc: (1 4-hr Lab) Laboratory for Cell and Molecular Biology. A-F only. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 275 (or concurrent) and CHEM 272.
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Cell and Molecular Biology (3)
desc: Integrated cell and molecular biology for life science majors. Modern advances in recombinant DNA technology. A-F only. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 171/171L and CHEM 272. (Cross-listed as MCB 275)
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 265. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction, and requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 265 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Ecology and Evolutionary Biology (3)
desc: Principles of ecology and evolution for life science majors stressing integrated approach and recent advance. A-F only. Pre: C (not C-) or better in 171/171L, 172, 172L (or concurrent).
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Biology II Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 172. Pre: CHEM (131, 151, 161, 171, or 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 172 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Biology II (3)
desc: Anatomy, physiology, and systematics of plants and animals; behavior; ecosystems, populations, and communities. Pre: CHEM (131, 151, 161, 171, or 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 172L (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Biology I Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 171. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction, and requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. Pre: CHEM (131, 151, 161, 171, or 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 171 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Biology I (3)
desc: Introductory biology for all life science majors. Cell structure and chemistry; growth, reproduction, genetics, evolution, viruses, bacteria, and simple eukaryotes. Pre: CHEM (131, 151, 161, 171, or 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 171L (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Hawaiian Environment Science (3)
desc: Characteristics of science and interaction with society illustrated by topics in geology, astronomy, oceanography, and biology of Hawaiian Islands. Not a BIOL major elective.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Marine Option Program Seminar (1)
desc: Overview of ocean issues and organizations involved with marine activities, management, education, research, and business. Exploration of internships, research, and career opportunities. Preparation of resumes, proposals, and professional presentations. Not a BIOL major elective. (Cross-listed as IS 100)
metadata: Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Biology & Society Laboratory (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Explores connections between biological principles and everyday life with a focus on the environment. Topics include environmental health and sustainability with examples from Hawai‘i. Not a BIOL major elective. Pre: BIOL 101 (or concurrent). (Cross-listed as SUST 111L)  DY
metadata: DY Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BIOL
title: Biology and Society (3)
desc: Characteristics of science, historical development of scientific concepts, and interaction of society with science illustrated by topics from biological science. Not a BIOL major elective.
metadata: DB Biology (BIOL) College of Natural Sciences

subject: BE
title: Seminar (1)
desc: Use of computer and video technology in technical presentation, review of current biosystems engineering research. Pre: consent.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Hydrologic Processes in Soils (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Hydrologic properties in soils and the processes involved in water infiltration drainage and solute transport. Emphasis on key parameters required for modeling. Recommended: CEE 424 or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as CEE 625 and NREM 660)
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Biosystems Modeling (3)
desc: Introduction to system thinking, procedures for developing system models, characteristics of important agricultural system models, computer approach to evaluation and optimization of system models. Pre: one of MATH 215, MATH 241, MATH 251A; or consent. (Crosslisted as AREC 610)
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Biological Treatment (3)
desc: Fundamentals of applied microbiology and biochemical reactor engineering, quantitative description of microbial growth, operational theory and design basis of aerobic, anoxic and anaerobic treatment processes. Applications for water, wastewater, air, solid wastes, and soil. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as CEE 634)
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Biological Instrumentation (3)
desc: System integration for computer-based control, automation, and study of biological systems. Topics include physical, chemical, and biological sensors, actuators, digital interfacing/communication, image analysis, and structured code for microcontrollers and other portable computers. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as MBBE 625)
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Experimental Methods in Cause-Effect Modeling (3)
desc: Factorial designs and fractional factorial designs for screening variable and response optimization. Response surface methodology. Experimental designs appropriate to building and testing multi-variable behavior relationships. Sequential experimental designs.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Biofuel and Bioenergy (3)
desc: Overview of biofuel/bioenergy production, biorefinery concept; renewable feedstocks; thermochemical and biochemical conversions of biomass to biofuel; biodiesel production; algal-biofuel; environmental impacts, life-cycle analysis; value-added processing of biofuel residues; selected case studies; term paper and presentation. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Instrumentation and Measurement (3)
desc: Measurement concepts and operating principles applied to the selection and use of instruments important to scientists and engineers dealing with biological systems, including automatic data acquisition and processing. Pre: CHEM 151, MATH 241, and ME 311; or consent.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Research in the area of biosystems engineering. Pre: consent.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Internship (4)
desc: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Placement with an approved cooperating supervisor/employer. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Biological Engineering Topics (V)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems. Offered by visiting faculty and/or for extension programs. Repeatable nine times.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Senior Engineering Design II (3)
desc: (1 1-hr Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Continuation of 481 with emphasis on written/oral communication and engineering ethics. Properties of biological materials; risk and reliability; guest lectures on design by engineers; project completion with submission of a final design report. A-F only. Pre: 481 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Senior Engineering Design I (3)
desc: (1 1-hr Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) First course in a two-semester major open-ended design experience for senior students in biological engineering, with heavy emphasis on teaching written/oral engineering communication. Design process; project management; methodology; modeling; optimization; engineering economics. A-F only. Pre: (350/350L, 373, CEE 320 (or concurrent) or ME 322 (or concurrent), ME 311, ECE 211) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Bioprocess Design and Analysis (3)
desc: Combined lecture/computer lab on theory and practice of bioprocess design and analysis, involving biological basics and engineering principles of bioprocessing, computer-aided unit operations, process integration, and economic evaluation. A-F only. Pre: 373, or 437 (or concurrent) or 460 (or concurrent); or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Bioreactor Design and Analysis (3)
desc: Application of mass/energy balances and reaction kinetics for the design and analysis of bioreactors for microbial, plant, and animal cell cultures. Pre: 373 or CEE 320 or ME 322; or consent. (Cross-listed as MBBE 460)
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Bioremediation: Principles and Practices (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Soil environment, fate and transport of contaminants; microbial ecology, metabolism, and energy production; biodegradation of selected compounds. In situ treatment, solid-phase bioremediation, slurry-phase bioremediation, and vapor-phase biological treatment. Open to nonmajors. Repeatable one time. Pre: 260, CHEM 161, PHYS 170; or consent.
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Biosystems Unit Operations (3)
desc: Introduction to unit operations in biological, environmental, food, and manufacturing processes. Integration of biology and chemistry into engineering using basic concepts in mass and energy conservation and transport in reacting and non-reacting systems. A-F only. Pre: (373; and either CEE 320 or ME 322) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent.
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Environmental Biotechnology (3)
desc: Environmental impact and control; the microorganism and its nutrition and growth conditions; microbial growth and substrate removal kinetics; bioreactors; biological treatment systems; biodegredation of xenobiotic organic chemicals; case studies. A-F only. Pre: 373 or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Sensors and Instrumentation for Biological Systems (3)
desc: Design course focused on fundamentals of electronic interfacing, control and automation, including biological processes. Topics include sensor physics, basic instrumentation, digital communication, and programming of microcontrollers and other portable computer systems. Pre: (ECE 160, ECE 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Cross-listed as ECE 422 and MBBE 422)
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Food Engineering (3)
desc: Principles and applications of thermodynamics, electricity, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, psychrometry, and material and energy balances of food processing and preservation. Pre: (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, PHYS 151 or PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as FSHN 411 and MBBE 411)
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Biomass Conversion to Biofuels and Bioenergy (3)
desc: Overview of biofuel/bioenergy production; fundamental concepts in biofuel/ bioenergy production; renewable feedstocks; thermochemical and biochemical conversions of biomass to biofuel/bioenergy; biodiesel production; environmental impacts, economics and life-cycle analysis; value-added processing of biofuel residues; selected case studies. A-F only. Pre: 373 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Engineering Economics (3)
desc: Economic analysis in engineering and management decision-making, interest, depreciation, income tax, cost classification, break-even analysis, economic comparisons of alternatives, benefit-cost analysis. BENG, CE, CEM, CNST, ECE, and ME majors only. A-F only. Pre: ECON 120 (with a minimum grade of C-) or 130 (with a minimum grade of C-), and senior standing. (Cross-listed as CEE 405)
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Transport Phenomena (3)
desc: Fundamental principles and applications relating to mass, momentum, and energy transfers in biosystems and other systems for engineers and scientists. Pre: 260, CEE 270, MATH 243 or 253A, ME 311 (or concurrent).
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Dynamic Systems Modeling Laboratory (1)
desc: Industry field trips and lab experiences to illustrate behavior of representative dynamic systems in biological engineering. Data acquisition and model validation. A-F only. Co-requisite: 350.
metadata: DY Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Dynamic Systems Modeling (3)
desc: Introduction to analytical and numerical solutions for systems of differential equations. Modeling and computer simulation of representative dynamic systems encountered in biological engineering. A-F only. Pre: (260, ECE 110 or 160, MATH 243 or 253A, CEE 270) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent. Co-requisite: BE 350L.
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Mass and Energy Balances (3)
desc: Introduction of the principles of mass and energy conservation; development of systematic approaches to apply these principles in calculations for design and analysis of biochemical, chemical, and physical processes. Pre: (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or 171 or 181A, PHYS 170, and MATH 242 or 252A) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent.
metadata: DP Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Introduction to Applications in Biological Engineering (V)
desc: Discussion and investigation of special topics, problems and applications of biological engineering. Pre: consent.
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Introduction to Biological Engineering (2)
desc: Discussion and experimental investigation of physical and chemical principles underlying representative biological processes and systems. Bioproduction, energy conversion processes, physiological systems, biological treatment, biosensors, biomechanics, and related natural and engineered systems. A-F only. Pre: MATH 140X or consent.   (Once a year)
metadata: DY Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Introduction to Quantitative Biology (3)
desc: Quantitative approach to applied topics in biology including synthesis and metabolism, kinetics, physiological systems, cellular processes and signaling, informatics, and emerging technologies for health, biological production/processing, and discovery. Pre: MATH 241 (or concurrent) and CHEM 162 (or concurrent), or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DB Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BE
title: Introduction to Sustainable Engineering (3)
desc: Sustainability and its social and technical significance; global population growth; resource management and quantification; designs for sustainable society; challenges interfacing technology and culture/religion; green and ecological engineering; life cycle analyses; engineering ethics; selected case studies. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Bioengineering (BE) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: BIOC
title: Highlights of Organ-System Biochemistry (1)
desc: Provides highly interactive, small group discussions on concepts of biochemistry important to the various organ systems; such as cardiac, respiratory, hematology, gastrointestinal, endocrine, musculoskeletal and neurological systems, and relevant to clinical medicine. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Pre: MDED 554. (Fall only)
metadata: Biochemistry (BIOC) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: BIOC
title: Topics in Biochemistry (V)
desc: Fourth-year elective in which medical students take an in-depth study of selected topics in biochemistry. Pre: fourthyear medical student or consent.
metadata: Biochemistry (BIOC) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: BIOC
title: Directed Research and Reading (V)
desc: Independent research or selected reading of current literature in the area of biochemistry and biophysics. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Biochemistry (BIOC) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: BIOC
title: Basic Biochemistry (4)
desc: Principles of biochemistry, applicable to medicine and real-life situations, involving metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids, and vitamins. Taught by biomedical researchers. Evaluated based on exams, quizzes, homework, and group presentation.
metadata: DB Biochemistry (BIOC) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: BIOC
title: Elements of Biochemistry (3)
desc: Biochemical principles and concepts as applied to living systems, including sufficient organic chemistry to understand these principles. Pre: 141 with C or better, or consent.
metadata: DP Biochemistry (BIOC) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: BIOC
title: Fundamentals of Biochemistry (3)
desc: Biological chemistry stressing integration of concepts of general, inorganic, and biochemistry and application to life chemistry. Pre: beginning algebra and high school science.
metadata: DP Biochemistry (BIOC) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ATMO
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Seminar in Meteorology (1)
desc: Participation in departmental seminars and presentation of a seminar on research results. Includes written critiques of departmental seminars. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Special Topics in Meteorology (V)
desc: Concentrated studies on selected atmospheric problems. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. Pre: 600 or consent.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: General Circulation of the Atmosphere (3)
desc: Theory, observations, large-scale analyses, and global model simulations that describe characteristic large-scale circulation of the Earth’s atmosphere. Includes zonally averaged climatology, asymmetric features of the general circulation, and El NinoSouthern Oscillation phenomenon. Repeatable one time. Pre: 600 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Tropical Climate Dynamics and Modeling (3)
desc: Overview of current progress in tropical climate dynamics with a particular focus on large-scale atmosphere-ocean interactions; introduction of basic numerical techniques for students to construct and run immediate tropical atmosphere and ocean models. Pre: 600.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Climate and Climate Variability (3)
desc: Physical basis of climate, numerical climate models, paleoclimatic indicators, modern instrumental climate records, assessment of human impact on climate, predictions of future climate. Repeatable one time. Pre: 600 or OCN 620, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Numerical Weather Prediction (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Fundamental methods and techniques in numerical weather prediction: time differencing, spatial finite differencing, spectral methods, numerical stability, explicit and implicit methods. Modern operational and research forecast models. Hands-on laboratory includes simple to complex dynamic models, with a term project. Repeatable one time. Pre: 600 or OCN 620; MATH 407 or 408; or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Large-Scale Ocean-Atmosphere Interactions (3)
desc: Lecture/seminar introduces physical oceanography and meteorology students to the stateof-the-art theories and observations of large-scale ocean-atmosphere interaction, as well as conveying the fundamental understanding that has been developed during the past 30 years. Emphasis will be on phenomena such as El Niño/Southern Oscillation, the North Atlantic Oscillation, the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, and global climate change. Repeatable one time. Pre: 600 or OCN 620, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as OCN 666)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Small-Scale Air-Sea Interaction (3)
desc: Observations and theory of small-scale processes which couple the atmosphere and ocean boundary layers, including introduction to turbulence theory and parameterization of turbulent fluxes. Pre: MATH 402 and 403 (or their equivalents) and either 600 or OCN 620; or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as OCN 665)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Advanced Statistical Methods in the Geosciences (3)
desc: Methods for numerous multivariate analyses will include singular spectrum, extended empirical orthogonal function, singular-value decomposition, canonical correlation, discriminant and cluster analysis. Other advanced topics include wavelet analysis, statistical downscaling and Bayesian analysis. A-F only and audit. Pre: 631 or consent. (Every 3rd year)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Statistical Meteorology (3)
desc: Probability; frequency distributions of atmospheric variables; linear models; time series analysis (frequency and time domain); principal component analysis; statistical weather forecasting and verification. Pre: MATH 371. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Radar Meteorology (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Radar hardware, electromagnetic propagation and scattering, radar equation, signal processing, precipitation estimation and polarimetric applications, Multi-Doppler wind synthesis, mobile and spaceborne radars, forecasting, and data assimilation applications. A-F only. Pre: 620 (with a minimum grade of B- or higher) or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Physical Meteorology (3)
desc: Molecular kinetics, atmospheric thermodynamics, cloud physics, precipitation processes, atmospheric electricity, scattering and absorption of solar radiation, absorption and emission of infrared radiation, radiative transfer. Pre: 302 or consent.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Monsoon Meteorology (3)
desc: Synoptic components of monsoons, regional and temporal variability, numerical models, research exercises. Pre: 610 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Tropical Cyclones (3)
desc: Lecture covering fundamentals of tropical cyclone structure, motion, and impacts on society. Observations from satellites, aircraft, ships and buoys, and numerical simulations focusing on storm structure and track. Some forecasting exercises. Repeatable one time. Pre: 600 and 610, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Satellite Data Applications (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr. Lab) Principles and practices of satellite remote sensing as used in the atmospheric sciences, specifically clouds, aerosols, precipitation, ocean and land cover datasets from various satellites. Develop skills including data manipulation, analysis, and visualization using Matlab. A-F only. Pre: 620 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Tropical Climate and Weather (3)
desc: Climate and general circulation of the tropics; El Niño and Southern Oscillation; intraseasonal oscillation; trade winds; tropical weather systems; energy balance; typhoons. Pre: 303 or consent.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Mesoscale Meteorology (3)
desc: Scale analysis. Observational and theoretical aspects of mesoscale circulation systems. Pre: 600 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Cumulus Dynamics (3)
desc: Dynamics of convective systems: tornadoes, waterspouts, squall lines. Interactions with synoptic scale. Pre: 620 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Atmospheric Dynamics II (3)
desc: Overview of dynamic meteorology, numerical weather prediction, geophysical fluid instabilities, approximate dynamical systems, atmospheric general circulation, stratospheric dynamics. Pre: 600 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Atmospheric Dynamics I (3)
desc: Governing equations for moist atmospheric motions, approximations, basic theoretical models, boundary layer dynamics, atmospheric waves, quasi-geostrophic theory for mid-latitudes. Pre: 402, and either MATH 402 or MATH 405; or consent.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Undergraduate Thesis (3)
desc: Capstone for senior Meteorology majors. Undergraduate thesis project includes literature review, experiment or research design, data collection and analysis, technical writing of a final thesis paper and oral presentation of the paper. Junior and senior standing only. A-F only. Pre: 302, 303 (or concurrent).
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Climate Modeling, Data Analysis, and Applications (3)
desc: Introduction to regional and global climate modeling for environmental scientists and engineers. Learn principles of climate modeling, how to access and use climate data for sustainable engineering and environmental management solutions, and effectively communicate results. A-F only. Senior standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as CEE 449 and SUST 449)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Tropical Analysis Lab (4)
desc: (2 Lec 2 3-hr Lab) Techniques of portraying and analyzing atmospheric structure and weather systems in tropical and equatorial regions; forecasting tropical systems. Pre: 303 or concurrent.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Meteorological Analysis Lab (4)
desc: (2 4-hr Lab) Techniques and methods of forecasting extratropical systems with analyzing atmospheric structure and weather systems. Students will be instructed on how to communicate and discuss a weather forecast and how to present a research paper. Pre: 303 or concurrent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Tropical Meteorology (3)
desc: History; tropical clouds and hydrometeors; typhoons; monsoons; local and diurnal effects. Pre: 303.
metadata: DP Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Synoptic Satellite Meteorology (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Satellite applications to synoptic meteorology and forecasting, including orbital elements, ephemerides, viewing geometry, radiation, satellite sensors, and interpreting satellite data. Pre: 302.
metadata: DP Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Applied Atmospheric Dynamics (3)
desc: Advanced concepts in dynamics: vorticity, cyclogenesis, jet streams, fronts, mesoscale circulations. Pre: 303.
metadata: DP Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Undergraduate Directed Reading (V)
desc: Individual reading in Atmospheric Sciences. Repeatable one time, up to three credits. ATMO students only. Junior and senior standing only. A-F only. Pre: consent
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Undergraduate Internship (V)
desc: Experiential approach to earth science; students serve as interns to field professionals; responsibilities include supervised field work. Open to undergraduate SOEST majors. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. Pre: junior/senior standing and consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Programming for Meteorologists (3)
desc: Scientific programming in Fortran 77, graphics software and meteorological applications. A-F or Audit. Pre: 302 (or concurrent) and MATH 241; or consent.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Global Environmental Change (3)
desc: Global environmental change problems such as carbon dioxide and the greenhouse effect, acid rain, chlorofluorocarbons and the ozone layer, global deforestation and the effect on climate, etc. Pre: 200, OCN 201, ERTH 101, ERTH 103, or ERTH 170; or consent. (Cross-listed as OCN 310)
metadata: DP Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Meteorological Instruments and Observations (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Each week targets a different meteorological instrument and culminates in a lab exercise and report. The focus is on accurate measurement and scientific-style writing. A-F only. Pre: 302 and PHYS 272/272L
metadata: DP Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Introduction to Atmospheric Dynamics (3)
desc: Scalar and vector development of basic laws of hydrodynamics, equations of motion, kinematics, divergence and vorticity, viscosity and turbulence, introduction to numerical weather prediction, general circulation. Pre: 302 and MATH 244.
metadata: DP Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Atmospheric Physics (3)
desc: Energy and thermodynamics, statics and stability, physical processes of cloud formation, radiation and Earthatmosphere heat balance, kinetic theory, optical effects. Pre: 200, MATH 242, and PHYS 272; or consent.
metadata: DP Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Atmospheric Processes and Phenomena (3)
desc: Atmospheric variables, gas laws, radiation processes, thermodynamics, conservation laws, dynamic approximations, clouds and precipitation, convection, atmospheric circulations, mid-latitude and tropical weather systems, forecasting, climate. Pre: PHYS 170 (or concurrent).
metadata: DP Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Introduction to MET Undergraduate Directed Research (V)
desc: Students gain familiarity with ATMO research. Students can select 1-3 credits per semester for maximum 6 credits over 4 semesters. Students must pre-arrange research and reading content with instructor. Repeatable three times, up to six credits. Freshman and sophomore standing only. CR/NC only. Pre: instructor approval.
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Introduction to Quantitative Earth and Environmental Science (3)
desc: Introduction to pre-calculus math and physics applied to Earth and environmental science. Students work on real-world problems and engage in participatory learning. Preparatory for classes in calculus and physics. Pre: MATH 134, 161, or MATH assessment exam (with score required for MATH 140X). (Fall only) (Cross-listed as ERTH 150 and OCN 150)
metadata: FQ Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Pacific Climates and Cultures (3)
desc: Highlights the interface between the observed weather and climate of the Pacific and the past and future culture of the people of the Hawaiian and Pacific islands. A-F only. (Alt. years)
metadata: Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Introduction to Weather and Climate Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Exercises with meteorological data and measurement systems. Characteristics of Hawaiian winds, temperatures, and rainfall
metadata: DY Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ATMO
title: Introduction to Weather and Climate (3)
desc: Introductory physical science course for all undergraduates in any major. A non-mathematical introduction to basic atmospheric variables, Earth’s past climates, global warming, air pollution, El Nino, hurricanes, tornadoes, and forecasting weather in Hawai‘i.
metadata: DP Atmospheric Sciences (ATMO) School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology

subject: ASTR
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astro-ph Seminar (1)
desc: Seminar discussions of the most recent research papers covering all areas of astronomy. Student lead discussion sessions and discuss papers of their choice during the semester. ASTR majors only. Graduate students only. CR/NC only. (Fall only)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Star Formation (2)
desc: Molecular clouds, collapse processes, physics of circumstellar disks and accretion, properties of young stars, outflows and jets, formation of binaries, extrasolar planets and planet formation, meteorites and the early solar system. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Scientific Grant Writing (1)
desc: Principles of scientific grant writing are taught by working on draft proposals through a mix of lectures, discussions, and hands on activities. The final proposal will be reviewed and evaluated via a review panel. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astrobiology Seminar: Origin, Evolution and the Role of Water for Life in the Universe (1)
desc: Interdisciplinary research topics in astrobiology as they relate to the theme of water: formation in space, role in creating pre-biotic molecules, delivery to earth, and terrestrial planet habitability. Repeatable three times. Pre: graduate level sciences and ideas, or consent.
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astronomy Seminar III (V)
desc: Selected advanced topics in astronomy and astrophysics. Available for 1 to 3 credit hours by arrangement. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astronomy Seminar II (V)
desc: Selected advanced topics in astronomy and astrophysics. Available for 1 to 3 credit hours by arrangement. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astronomy Seminar I (V)
desc: Selected advanced topics in astronomy and astrophysics. Available for 1 to 3 credit hours by arrangement. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astrochemistry-A Molecular Approach (3)
desc: Formation of astrobiologically important molecules and their precursors in the interstellar medium and in our solar system: first principles and latest trends. Pre: consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as CHEM 657 and ERTH 657)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Active Galaxies (3)
desc: Phenomenology of active galactic nuclei, black holes, accretion flows and jets, emission mechanisms, host galaxies, and cosmic evolution. Pre: 635 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: General Relativity (3)
desc: Introduction to gravity and general relativity. Tensor basics, classical scalar, vector and tensor field theories. Exact symmetric Einstein equation, gravito-magnetic weak field, and radiation solutions. Pre: consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Fundamentals of Astrophysics (3)
desc: Applications of fundamental physics to astrophysical situations. Elements of general relativity. Basics of hydrodynamics and shock waves. Radiative processes, high energy astrophysics. Modern dynamics. Pre: consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astronomical Instrumentation (3)
desc: Design and operation of astronomical instrumentation. Physics of optical and infrared detectors. Wavefront sensors and adaptive optics. Radio and infrared interferometry. Optical design: methods and software. A-F only. Pre: 633 (with a minimum grade of B-). (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astrophysical Techniques (3)
desc: Telescopes, positional astronomy, photon detection, error analysis, photometry, spectroscopy. Pre: consent. (Fall only)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Radiative Transfer Stellar Atmospheres (3)
desc: Excitation, ionization, and radiative transfer in stellar atmospheres; model atmospheres, formation of line and continuum radiation. Pre: consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: The Solar System (3)
desc: Survey of observational data and physical concepts on planets and smaller bodies; formation of planetary systems; solar activity. Pre: consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Cosmology (3)
desc: Geometry and evolution of the universe. Dark matter. Early universe. Formation of large–scale structure, galaxies, and clusters. Cosmological models. Pre: consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Galaxies (3)
desc: Observations and stellar dynamics of elliptical and spiral galaxies including our galaxy, globular clusters, and dark matter. Galaxy formation and evolution. Pre: consent. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Stellar Interiors and Evolution (3)
desc: Structure and evolution; energy sources, radiative processes; relations to observables. Pre: consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: The Interstellar Medium (3)
desc: Astrophysics of diffuse matter, HII regions, molecular clouds, etc. Pre: consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Senior Research Project (1)
desc: Seminar focusing on development of professional skills for astronomical research, and on scientific writing as a tool for organizing research. A final paper describing a supervised research project is required. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Pre: 301; 399 (or concurrent) or PHYS 399 (or concurrent).
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: The Solar System (3)
desc: Observations and physical nature of planets and moons, asteroids, comets, and other small bodies; formation of the Solar System; discovery of other planetary systems; solar activity. Pre: 300; and PHYS 152 or 274; and MATH 216, 242, or 252A. (Alt. years)
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Galaxies & Cosmology (3)
desc: Survey of extragalactic astronomy and cosmology, including: galaxy morphology and kinematics; luminosity functions; dark matter; properties of galaxy groups/ clusters; gravitational lensing; redshifts; cosmological models; the Big Bang; thermal history of the Universe; structure formation. A-F only. Pre: 300 (or concurrent); PHYS 152 or PHYS 274; MATH 216 or MATH 242 or MATH 252A. (Alt. years)
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Stellar Astrophysics (3)
desc: Advanced survey of stellar astrophysics, including application of astrometry, photometry, and spectrometry to determine fundamental stellar properties; stellar structure and evolution of single and binary stars; astrophysical distance determination methods; stellar nucleosynthesis. Pre: 242 and 300, and PHYS 480.
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Directed Study (V)
desc: Individual reading, observation, or experimentation in astronomy and astrophysics. Repeatable four times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: History of Cosmology and Scientific Thought (3)
desc: History and intellectual context of astronomical discovery; the evolution of ideas of space, time, and motion from the Babylonians to relativistic cosmologies; emphasis on the interaction of astronomy with the history of ideas. Pre: any ASTR or PHYS course. (Spring only)
metadata: Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astronomical Spectroscopy (3)
desc: Introduction to astronomical spectroscopy. Stellar atmospheres, line formation, elements of radiative transfer. Phases of interstellar medium. Emission line diagnostics. Doppler shift and kinematics. A-F only. Pre: 210 or 242; PHYS 152 or 274; MATH 216 or 242 or 252A. (Spring only)
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Observational Astronomy Projects (3)
desc: Astronomical observational research projects. Students use astronomical data and process telescopic observations to produce scientific results, and present these orally and in writing. Students prepare for independent research projects and present research plans orally. A-F only. Pre: 300 and 300L. (Spring only)
metadata: DY Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Observational Astronomy Laboratory (2)
desc: Optical and near-infrared astronomy laboratory. Error analysis, properties of light, data, and image processing. Astrometric, photometric, and spectroscopic measurement. A-F only. Pre: 300 (or concurrent); PHYS 152 or 274; PHYS 152L or 274L; MATH 216, 242, or 252A. (Fall only)
metadata: DY Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Observational Astronomy (3)
desc: Principles and techniques of optical and near-infrared astronomical observation. Astronomical coordinate systems. Telescopes, cameras, spectrographs, and detectors. Astrometry, photometry, and spectroscopy of astronomical objects. A-F only. Pre: 210 or 242; PHYS 152 or 274; MATH 216, 242, or 252A. (Fall only)
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Astrobiology (3)
desc: Are we alone in the universe? Modern astronomical, biological, and geological perspectives on this fundamental question. Searches for life on Mars, oceans on Europa, planets orbiting other stars. Space exploration and colonies, interstellar spaceflight and communication. Pre: 110 or 210, or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Evolution of the Universe (3)
desc: The Big Bang, origin of the elements, formation and evolution of galaxies and stars. Pre: 110 or 210 or 241 or 242, or consent
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Foundations of Astrophysics II: Galaxies and Stars (3)
desc: Stellar and galactic astrophysics. Stellar magnitudes, colors, distances, and spectra. Galactic structure and evolution, active nuclei, large-scale structure, Big-Bang cosmology. Stellar interiors, nuclear “burning,” main-sequence and evolved stars. Introduces computer programming. A-F only. Pre: 241, PHYS 274 (or concurrent), and MATH 243 (or concurrent) or 253A (or concurrent). (Spring only)
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Foundations of Astrophysics I: The Solar System (3)
desc:
Solar system astrophysics. Dynamics of planets, satellite systems, asteroids and comets; 
planetary atmospheres and internal structure; thermal balance; the Sun as a star. Introduces numerical computing. A-F only. Pre: PHYS 170, MATH 242 or 252A, and PHYS 272 (or concurrent). (Fall only)
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Foundations of Astronomy (3)
desc: A rigorous overview of modern astronomy: solar system, stellar, galactic and extragalactic astronomy and cosmology. For science and engineering students. Pre: 110; PHYS 151 or PHYS 170.
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Voyage through the Solar System (3)
desc: An illustrated voyage through the Solar System based on recent scientific results. The class highlights the origin, evolution, and current knowledge of the eight planets, their moons, asteroids, comets, and one star, the Sun. Field trip. (Cross-listed as ERTH 105)
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Introduction to Archaeoastronomy (3)
desc:
Astronomy and celestial lore in ancient cultures: Neolithic Europe, Mayan, Mesoamerican, Egyptian, Mesopotamian, American Indian, Chinese, and Polynesian. Concepts of the cosmos, calendars, eclipse predictions, motion of celestial bodies, and navigation. 
Construction of simple observing tools.
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Survey of Astronomy Laboratory (1)
desc: Observations of constellations and the night sky, the sun and moon, planets, stars, and deep-sky objects; laboratory and observational experiments illustrating basic concepts in astronomy. Offered in the evening. Pre: 110 (or concurrent), or consent.
metadata: DY Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASTR
title: Survey of Astronomy (3)
desc: Introduction to the astronomical universe: sky and celestial objects, planetary motion, planets and the Solar System, Sun and stars, the Milky Way and galaxies, cosmology and the universe.
metadata: DP Astronomy (ASTR) College of Natural Sciences

subject: ASAN
title: Orientalism and Visual Culture (3)
desc:
Investigates artistic representations, appropriations, and exchanges constructed on the basis of East/Orient vs. West/Occident differences. Includes analysis of: Orientalizing artistic traditions throughout history, history and concept of Orient, post-colonial critique 
of Orientalism. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. 2-3 years) (Cross-listed as ART 792)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: MAIA Capstone (3)
desc: Capstone experience for MAIA students that emphasizes practical applications of Asia knowledge. Should be taken in final semester or after completion of all or most of MAIA core requirements. MAIA majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Asian Research Materials and Methods (3)
desc: Bibliography, reference tools, and research methods in sources on Asia in Western and Asian languages. Discussion of published and archival repositories. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as LIS 645)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable nine times.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Individual problems and research. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Asian Studies Master’s Plan B Culminating Experience (1)
desc: Students work with their advisor to select, revise, and defend a portfolio of work produced in seminars before a three-person faculty committee. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. ASAN majors only. Graduate students only. Pre: any 600(Alpha) or 750(Alpha).
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Topics in Buddhist Studies (3)
desc: Seminar on selected topics in Buddhist studies. Repeatable three times. Pre: PHIL 360, PHIL 406, REL 475, or REL 490; or consent.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Field Study in Asia (V)
desc: With prior consent and supervision of an Asian Studies faculty, students design, conduct, and write the results of a field research project. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. Graduate students only.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: International Relations in Asia (3)
desc: How well do international relations theories explain interstate relations in Asia? How do international issues interact with domestic politics? Covers Japan, China, Korea, ASEAN nations, India, and touches on Russia, Australia, and New Zealand. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Chinese Foreign Policy (3)
desc: Examination of China’s rise and world view, review of China’s regional relations, China and U.S. relations, formation of a new world order. Pre: 600, 608, or POLS 645C, or consent.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Conflict and Cooperation in Asia (3)
desc: Explores conflict and cooperation among Asian nations. Topics may include economic integration, business networks, space and cyberspace, military alliances, territorial disputes, transnational crime, environmental cooperation, soft power, and regional institutional architecture. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Law and Society in China (V)
desc: Overview of the historical foundations of Chinese law and introduction to the present legal system in the People’s Republic of China. Repeatable one time. (Cross-listed as LWPA 586)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Special Topics in East Asian Literary Culture & Society (3)
desc: In-depth study of selected topics and issues in modern/contemporary East Asian literary and cultural studies using an interdisciplinary, inter-regional, and transnational approach, from an intercultural perspective. Repeatable two times in different topics, but need consent for second repeat. A-F only. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as EALL 665)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Topics and Issues in Modern Korean Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics and issues in modern/contemporary Korean fiction, focusing on texts that problematize critical sociocultural issues in the evolving contexts of modern Korean intellectual history. Repeatable one time. Pre: KOR 494 or consent.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: South Asia Now (3)
desc: Views South Asia as an interactive region. Examines common historical and cultural, economic, and political themes, including global interactions. Focus upon present state of the region. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Major Authors in Modern Korean Literature (3)
desc: Advanced study of major Korean fiction writers from the 1910s to the present with emphasis on critical reading of their lives and writings to arrive at informed appraisal of their contribution to modern Korean literature. Repeatable one time. Pre: KOR 494 or consent.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: East Asia Now (3)
desc: Views East Asia as an interactive region. Examines common historical and cultural, economic and political themes including various experiences with the West. Focus upon present state of the region. A-F only.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Marriage and Family in East Asia (3)
desc: Examines gendered/generational practices, expectations, and ideologies of marriage, childrearing, and caregiving; state’s role in legitimizing certain kinds of families; how transnational marriage migration is changing notions of belonging, relatedness, and national identity in East Asia. Graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Asian Cities: Historical Evolution of Urban Form (3)
desc: Examination of the impact of economy, society, and history on urban form; case studies of the evolution of Asian urban form. Pre: 312 or PLAN 310. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as PLAN 649)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Topics in Japanese Literature (3)
desc: Intensive study of selected topics in Japanese literature, primarily of the modern period. English translations of original texts will be provided whenever available. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as JPN 640)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Culture & Urban Form in Asia (3)
desc: Cultural and historical impact on urban form, contention of tradition and modernity in urban space, spatial expression of state and society, perception and utilization of urban design, evolution of urban form in selected Asian capitals. Pre: 312, ARCH 341, PLAN 310, or PLAN 600. (Cross-listed as ARCH 687 and PLAN 636)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Seafood in Southeast Asia (3)
desc: Seafood production in Southeast Asia, including both regional fisheries and aquaculture. Case studies used to illustrate challenges to the implementation of sustainable seafood production and emerging approaches, such as community supported seafood. (Cross-listed as GEO 633)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Southeast Asia Now (3)
desc: Examines the ways global influences are shaping the cultural developments in the diverse societies of contemporary Southeast Asia. (Spring only)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Asian Security Cultures (3)
desc: Comparative study of conceptualizations, practices and institutions of national security in Asia in light of their geographic and historic contexts. (Once a year)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Ethnic Nationalism in Asia (3)
desc: Contemporary theories of ethnic and cultural nationalism from perspective of Asia. Issues of nationstate, power hierarchies, modernity, and identity in contemporary societies.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Capitalism in Contemporary Asia (3)
desc: Historically grounded theoretical examination of capitalism in 20th-century Asia; multidisciplinary approach to fundamental change in political and economic structures and institutions, prospects for the future.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Culture and Colonialism (3)
desc: Analysis of theories and debates (cultural studies, feminist writings, post-colonial issues). Case studies of the transformation and creation of “traditional” cultures under colonialism. Pre: 310 or 312, or consent.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Gender in Asian Performing Arts (3)
desc: Performance is a rich site for gender construction, critique, and articulation in Asia. This seminar examines gender reflected in traditional music, dance, and theatre, including character role and performer persona; approaches of performance and culture studies, and an “Asian way.” A-F only. (Once a year
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Problems/Issues of Contemporary Asia (3)
desc: Analysis from multidisciplinary perspective: rural development, urbanization, international relations, ethnicity, religion, language, etc. Repeatable one time with different topics.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Topics in 20th Century Chinese Literary and Cultural Studies (3)
desc: Critical scholarship in Chinese literature and cultural studies, broadly defined to include the People’s Republic of China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and others. Reading knowledge of Chinese desirable but not required. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as EALL 611)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Comparative Muslim Societies in Asia (3)
desc: Will compare Muslim societies and cultures in Asia with each other and with the so-called “core” Middle Eastern Muslim societies.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Politics and Development: China (3)
desc: Consists of three parts: key theories for socialist transition as basis for seminar discussion, policy evolution to illustrate the radical changes, and emerging and prominent current development and practice. (Cross-listed as POLS 645C and PLAN 608)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Practicum in Asian Studies (V)
desc: Repeatable with consent up to nine credits.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: (Alpha) Approaches to Asian Studies (3)
desc: Major issues in and approaches to the interdisciplinary study of Asia and Asian regions; resources for the advanced study of Asia at UH; developing a research focus; preparing and presenting research proposals. (C) China; (I) South Asia; (J) Japan; (K) Korea; (P) Philippines; (S) Southeast Asia; (Z) Inter-Asia. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Directed Reading (V)
desc: Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Religions of Island Southeast Asia (3)
desc: A comparative, interdisciplinary examination of indigenous beliefs, Islam, Christianity, and Hinduism in island Southeast Asia, and how they have been adjusted because of economic and social change.
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Food, Culture, and Politics in Asia (3)
desc:
Examines Asia’s role in the development of global foodways. Topics include the relationship between spices and imperialism, global popularity of Asian cuisines, Asian-influenced “hapa” cuisine in Hawai‘i, McDonaldization in Asia, and food security and 
sustainability. A-F only.
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Women and Revolution (3)
desc: Conditions under which women’s activism and participation in protest and revolutionary movements developed in the 19th- and 20th-centuries. Cross-cultural comparisons. (Cross-listed as HIST 492 and WGSS 492)
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: (Alpha) Topics in Asian Studies (3)
desc: Selected topics in Asian studies. (C) China; (G) Asia; (I) South Asia; (J) Japan; (K) Korea; (P) Philippines; (S) Southeast Asia; (Z) Other. Each alpha is repeatable two times.
metadata: DS Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Contemporary Chinese Development (3)
desc: Development and planning in contemporary China: economic policy and institutional structure in the development and urbanization process; urban and rural transformation in a socialist economy. Pre: upper division standing or consent.
metadata: DS Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Imperialism, Colonialism, and Nationalism in Southeast Asia (3)
desc: Theoretical and historical analysis of a global, nineteenth, and twentieth century phenomenon using an interdisciplinary approach organized around lectures, readings, and discussions. (Fall only)
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Asia Through Fiction (3)
desc: Explores core values and cultural principles of the four major Asian region as represented in major works of fiction from those regions. (Spring only)
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Film, Culture, and Modernity in Southeast Asia (3)
desc: Examines interplay between tradition and modernity; religion and secularism; individual and collective; youth, wisdom, and the world; and role of gender identification/community response as they find articulation in medium of film across Southeast Asia. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only.
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Culture and Economy of Southeast Asia (3)
desc: An exploration of the cultural and economic development of the countries of Southeast Asia from early times to the present day, with an emphasis on the effects of outside influences.
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Music Cultures: India (3)
desc: Approaches the cultural study of music and performance through a specific focus on South Asia. Junior standing or higher. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as MUS 478H)
metadata: Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Transnational Chinese Popular Culture (3)
desc: Survey of contemporary Chinese popular entertainment forms that are produced and appreciated transnationally. Examples include martial arts genres, kung fu films, commercial novels, ballroom dancing, karaoke culture, music videos and rock music. Material will be selected based upon availability and readings will include critical essays from the fields of popular culture, media studies, and literary criticism. Pre: any 300- or 400-level DL or DH course. (Cross-listed as EALL 474)
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Topics in Chinese Cultural Studies: Visual Culture–Chinese Diaspora (3)
desc: Multidisciplinary and historically located study of Chinese culture through the examination of literary/visual texts and critical essays from cultural studies. Specific topics will depend upon term. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: one DH or DL course or consent. (Cross-listed as EALL 473)
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Introduction to Contemporary Asian Cinema (3)
desc: Acquaint students with significant films from the major countries in Asia and how these films reflect and comment on profound social, political, and historical changes that have occurred in recent decades.
metadata: DH Asian Studies (ASAN) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ASAN
title: Japan Cool: Anime, Manga, and Film (3)
