desc: Architectural design with emphasis on space planning, building materials, technology, climatic responses, and codes including complex functional requirements, multi-story design issues, vertical transportation, structure, and finishes. Production of complete schematic design documents. Detailed writing instruction. ENVD majors only. A-F only. Pre: 341.
metadata: Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: Intermediate Design Studio I (4)
desc: Building and site design with emphasis on site development, analysis, and climatic response. Introduction to sustainable design, land use ordinances, description and delineation of property and land features, and urban and community design influences. ENVD majors only. A-F only. Pre: 200 and 202.
metadata: Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: Introduction to Environmental Systems B (3)
desc:
Introduction to environmentalism; focusing on the impact of building systems of the 
global environment; the role of environmental regulations/certifications, and understanding of sustainable principles (economic, social, and natural systems). ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. Pre: 220 and PHYS 151/151L.
metadata: Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: World Architecture and Urbanism B (3)
desc: Investigation of the history and theory of architecture from the 15th century C.E. to the present. Investigation of architecture in relationship to social, political, technological, and material forces. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. Pre: HIST 152.
metadata: DH Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: World Architecture and Urbanism A (3)
desc: Investigation of the history and theory of architecture in the world’s major cultural regions, from early agricultural settlements to 1500 C.E. Investigation of architecture in relationship to social, political, technological, and material forces. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. Pre: HIST 151.
metadata: DH Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: Introduction to Environmental Systems A (3)
desc: Introduction to building systems, including structural, environmental, life-safety, building envelope, building materials and building assemblies. Development of design skills with emphasis on elevating skills in assessing and selecting appropriate building systems. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. Pre: 132 or 102, and MATH 140X.
metadata: Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: Beginning Design Studio II (4)
desc: Development of designs and processes to study precedents and explore solutions responding to human needs in built and natural environments. Analysis and representation of architectonic space and form using hand and computer techniques. ENVD majors only. A-F only. Pre: 201.
metadata: DA Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: Collaboration in Environmental Design (3)
desc: Investigation of the various disciplines in the environmental design field, including architecture, landscape architecture, interiors, historic preservation, urban design, and construction management. Emphasis given to collaborative methods to address critical issues. Open to non-majors. A-F only. Pre: 100.
metadata: Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: Design Fundamentals Studio I (4)
desc: Introduction to creative design processes focusing on the investigation of composition within defining perceivable space. Hands-on exploration of materials and structures as an introduction to design processes. ENVD majors only. A-F only.
metadata: DA Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARAB
title: Third-Level Arabic II (3)
desc: Continuation of third-level Arabic I. Emphasis on developing writing and interaction ability at advanced levels of proficiency. Course includes extensive reading, composition exercises, listening skills, conversation practice and extensive review of Arabic grammar. Developing fluency is the main objective of this course. Classes meet 3 hours weekly. Pre: 301 (or equivalent), or consent.
metadata: Arabic (ARAB) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ARAB
title: Third-Level Arabic I (3)
desc: Develop proficiency in reading/listening comprehension in Modern Standard Arabic. The instructional materials consist of authentic written, visual and audio materials. Classes meet 3 hours weekly. Pre: 202 (or equivalent), or consent.
metadata: Arabic (ARAB) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ARAB
title: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic (4)
desc: Designed for students who have successfully completed three semesters of Arabic. Focus is on intensive practice of interactive functional skills such as listening comprehension and fundamental conversation strategies. Pre: 201 or exam or consent. (Spring only)
metadata: HSL Arabic (ARAB) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ARAB
title: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic (4)
desc: Designed for students who have successfully completed a year of Elementary Arabic. Focus is on acquisition of more complex grammatical structures, expanding vocabulary, and developing competence in a wide range of communicative situations. Pre: 102 or exam or consent. (Fall only)
metadata: HSL Arabic (ARAB) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ARAB
title: Elementary Modern Standard Arabic (4)
desc: Focuses on developing proficiency in the standard written Arabic language as well as formal spoken Arabic. It introduces a wide range of situation-based texts and topics that build vocabulary, grammar, and general communicative competence. Pre: 101.
metadata: HSL Arabic (ARAB) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ARAB
title: Elementary Modern Standard Arabic (4)
desc: Designed to provide students with basic knowledge of Modern Standard Arabic. Focuses on developing proficiency in the standard written Arabic language, as well as formal spoken Arabic.
metadata: HSL Arabic (ARAB) College of Arts, Languages & Letters Indo-Pacific Languages and Literatures

subject: ANTH
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable nine times.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: (Alpha) Research Seminar (3)
desc: Selected problems in current research. (B) archaeology; (C) medical; (D) ethnography; (E) social; (G) biological. Repeatable nine times. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Japan (3)
desc: Japan examined through three dimensions of cultural anthropology: cultural/symbolic, social/organizational, and individual/psychological. Selected topics analyzed and interpreted in terms of conjunctions of these dimensions. Pre: 483 or 484.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Seminar in Research Design and Proposal Writing (3)
desc: Research design and proposal writing. For students preparing for advanced research. Pre: graduate standing and consent.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Seminar in Research Methods in Cultural Anthropology (3)
desc:
Ethnographic research methods. Introduction to the approaches and techniques of participatory research, including the collection, analysis, and interpretation of social and 
cultural data. Politics and ethics of research practice. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing in anthropology or consent.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable nine times, up to 12 credits.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Directed Reading or Research (V)
desc: Repeatable nine times, up to 12 credits. Pre: graduate standing and consent.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Professional Skills Develop in Anthropology (3)
desc:
Seminar prepares graduate students for entry into profession, including employment 
opportunities, research, presentations, ethics and outreach. Required of all Plan B students. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Applied Cultural Anthropology Practicum (3)
desc: Applies course work in cultural anthropology to hands-on activities under the direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. Repeatable one time. ANTH majors only. Graduate students only. Pre: 681.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Applied Cultural Anthropology (3)
desc: Theory, methods, and results of application of cultural anthropological concepts to practical problems. Graduate students only.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Recording Historic and Cultural Resources (3)
desc: Techniques in recording and evaluation of historic buildings and other resources, with an emphasis on field recordings and state and federal registration procedures. Graduate students only or consent. (Cross-listed as ARCH 676 and PLAN 676)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Applied Method and Theory in Hawaiian Archaeology (3)
desc: Graduate seminar focused on method and theory in the practice of applied archaeology in Hawai‘i. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Applied Archaeology Practicum (V)
desc: Applies course work in archaeology to handson activities under the direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. MA track in Applied Archaeology students only. Repeatable one time, up to 12 credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Archaeology Field Methods (V)
desc: (5 7-hr Lab) Laboratory and field training in the principles and practice of methods of archaeology—survey, mapping, excavation, conservation. Repeatable one time, up to 12 credits. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Biomedicine and Culture (3)
desc: Examination of the social and cultural foundations of, and responses to, the values, technologies, and practices of modern medicine. Pre: graduate standing. (Alt. years)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Archaeological Data Analysis (4)
desc: Advanced introduction to the fundamental principles of statistics as applied to the analysis of archaeological data. (Alt. years)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Global Aid (3)
desc: Examines ideologies of development, humanitarian, and global health interventions from an anthropological perspective. Explores the disjuncture between discourses that portrays global aid as easing suffering and those that accuse it of maintaining relationships of domination. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Archaeological Perspectives on Southeast Asia (3)
desc: Prehistory and protohistory of Southeast Asia, and of Southeast Asian contacts with East Asia, india, Australia, and Oceania. Pre: background in archaeology or Southeast Asian history or consent.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Paleoanthropology of Asia (3)
desc: Survey of the Asian paleoanthropological record, particularly in its paleoenvironmental setting; Out of Africa I; modern human origins. Pre: graduate standing and relevant background in anthropology or related field. (Alt. years)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Advances in Extinctions (3)
desc: To delve deeply into the primary literature that focuses on the subjects of extinction and conservation broadly speaking, with particular emphasis on the 6 mass extinction events, including the Anthropocene. (Alt. years)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Historic Preservation (3)
desc: Federal, state, and local laws and regulations that regulate and provide protection to significant archaeological and historical resources in Hawai‘i and the region. (Alt. years: spring only) (Cross-listed as AMST 645 and ARCH 645).
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: (Alpha) Methods and Theory in Archaeology (3)
desc: Focused seminars pertaining to distinct areas of archaeological method and theory. (B) analytical; (C) environment/landscape; (D) applied archaeology; (E) economic/resources; (F) survey/locational. Repeatable two times. Pre: 603.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Advanced Pacific Islands Archaeology (3)
desc: Advanced theoretical and methodological examination of archaeological research in Oceania, a region including the islands of Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. (Fall only)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: (Alpha) Theory in Social and Cultural Anthropology (3)
desc: Major theoretical problems in (B) kinship; (C) cognitive systems; (D) religion; (E) political institutions; (F) law and social control; (G) economics; (H) ecology; (I) other to be announced. Repeatable nine times. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Contemporary Anthropological Theory (3)
desc: Graduate seminar that examines the history of theory in sociocultural anthropology from 1960 to present. Designed to be taken in sequence after 601. Pre: 601 or concurrent. (Once a year)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Cultural Geographies of Tourism (3)
desc: Social and cultural analysis of tourism practices, with emphasis on Hawai‘i, Asia and the Pacific. Tourism in relation to consumer culture, transnational flows of people and images, post-colonial politics, performance and identity formation. (Cross-listed as GEO 610)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: History and Memory (3)
desc: History and collective memory as culturally formed and politically contested realities. The role of narrative, ritual, and media technologies in shaping representations of the past. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Infectious Disease (3)
desc: The role of human behavior, including its social and cultural determinants, in understanding the distribution of infectious diseases and in shaping preventive and therapeutic strategies. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Discursive Practices (3)
desc: Emphasizes linguistic, semantic, and interactional aspects of culture, exploring ways that discourse constructs social action and social realities, examining processes by which culture is produced as meaningful behavior in actual situations. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Biological Anthropology Core (3)
desc: Human evolution and human variability in extant and previously existing populations; emphasis on history of physical anthropology, evolutionary systematics, primate biology and behavior, paleontology, anthropological genetics, climatic adaptation, growth, and nutrition. A course in the graduate core of anthropology. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Archaeology (3)
desc: Development of critical and analytical skills in assessment of archaeological literature; emphasis on the science, theory, explanation, and paradigms that comprise archaeology. A course in the graduate core of anthropology. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Linguistic Anthropology (3)
desc: Investigation of mutual influences of linguistic theory and methodology and anthropological theory and methodology. A course in the graduate core of anthropology. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Ethnology (3)
desc: Survey, in historical perspective, of theory in social and cultural anthropology, from the origin of anthropology to 1976. A course in the graduate core of anthropology. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Senior Thesis II (3)
desc: Preparation of a major paper in anthropology with a committee of one chairperson and one other. Second semester of a two-semester sequence with 495. May be taken concurrently with 495. Optional for majors. Pre: 490 and senior standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Senior Thesis I (3)
desc: Preparation of a major paper in anthropology with a committee of one chairperson and one other. First semester of a two-semester sequence with 496. May be taken concurrently with 496. Optional for majors. Pre: 490 and senior standing.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Oral History: Theory and Practice (3)
desc: Literature, methodology, ethics and project design of oral history research. Students develop and execute an oral history project. (Cross-listed as ES 493)
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Special Topics in Southeast Asian Art History: Monuments and Nationalism in Southeast Asia (3)
desc: Focused study of particular periods, regions and critical themes in Southeast Asian art and architectural history. Monuments and nationalism in Southeast Asia. A-F only. Pre: ART 175, or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ART 490D)
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: History of Anthropology (3)
desc: Development of anthropological ideas, focusing on theoretical issues concerning culture, society, and human nature. Required of majors. Pre: 152.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Chinese Culture: Ethnography (3)
desc: Critical interpretations of ethnographic and biographic texts depicting individual and family lives in different socioeconomic circumstances, geographical regions, and historical periods of modern China.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Okinawa and Its Diaspora (3)
desc: Explores the ties of identity that exist within and between Okinawa and its diasporic populations. Pre: 152. (Alt. years)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Peoples of Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Critically examines the historical and contemporary experiences of various people of Hawai‘i using anthropological and ethnic studies approaches. Emphasis on cultural perspectives and values of peoples indigenous to Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia. Pre: junior standing or consent. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as ES 486)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Pre-European Hawai‘i (3)
desc: Pre-European society and culture from an anthropological viewpoint. Pre: junior standing or consent.
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Japanese Popular Culture (3)
desc: Explores contemporary Japanese popular culture through themes such as gender, consumerism, globalization and nostalgia. Rather than a survey of popular culture genres, the course is organized thematically around issues and problematics.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Japanese Culture and Behavior (3)
desc: Sociocultural factors in Japanese behavior. Social structure; traditional institutions
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology and the Environment: Culture, Power, and Politics (3)
desc: Investigates environmental problems from an anthropological perspective, and examines the cultural politics of contestations over resources, rights, and the meanings of nature. Pre: 152 or 415 or consent. (Alt. years) (Crosslisted as SUST 482)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Applied Anthropology (3)
desc: The application of anthropological methods and concepts to solving practical human problems such as homelessness, domestic violence, maternal morbidity, conflict over resources, and the loss of indigenous languages. Includes a significant service-learning component. Pre: 152.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: New World Rituals and Ideologies (3)
desc: Study of cross-cultural patterns in ritual behaviors and creolization of African, indigenous, and Iberian ideological frameworks in the Americas. Topics may include syncretic religions (voodoo, candomble), Andean Christianity, spiritual conquest, conceptions of death, etc. Sophomore standing or higher. Minimum C- required grade for prerequisites. Pre: LAIS 360, or consent. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as LAIS 478 and REL 478)
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Spatial Analysis in Archaeology (3)
desc:
Lecture/lab. Introduction to the use of Geographical Information Systems (GIS) and spatial statistics in archaeological research. Topics include: map creation; spatial database management; spatial analysis; image processing, data reporting; and data display. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 466 or 666, or instructor 
approval. (Alt. years)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Faunal Analysis in Archaeology (3)
desc: Analysis of archaeologically recovered faunal collections with emphasis on identification and interpretation of nonhuman vertebrate remains. Pre: 210.
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Lithic Artifact Assemblage Analysis (4)
desc: Combined lecture/lab on the manufacture and analysis of stone tools. Students work with experimental collections and engage in stone tool production. The ways in which lithics enlighten us about past human behavior are discussed. Pre: 210 and 380, or consent.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Ceramic Analysis in Archaeology (3)
desc: Concepts, methods, and approaches used in the analysis of ancient pottery. Emphasis placed on ceramic technology, stylistic analysis. Pre: 210.
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Field Mapping (3)
desc: Techniques for field measurement and recording of cultural and physical data. Field sketching, Brunton surveying, plane table mapping, oblique photo compilation, topographic mapping, and representation of field data. Pre: junior standing or higher, or consent. (Cross-listed as GEO 472)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Biomedicine and Culture (3)
desc: Examination of the social and cultural foundations of, and responses to, the values, technologies and practices of modern medicine. Pre: junior standing or higher, 152, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Quantitative Archaeology (4)
desc: Combined lecture/lab. Introduction to the basic principles of statistics as applied to the analysis of archaeological data. Exploratory data analysis approach. A-F only. ANTH majors only. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 210. (Alt. years)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Science, Sex, and Reproduction (3)
desc: Explores anthropology’s critical analysis of approaches to reproductive health and procreation, primarily in developing countries. Examines sex and reproduction as sites of intervention from public health, development, and biomedical specialists, while also considering local strategies. Junior standing or higher. Pre: 152 or 301 or WGSS 151. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as WGSS 465)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Hawaiian Archaeology (3)
desc: Archaeological perspective in Hawai‘i’s past; origins of Hawaiians; early settlement and culture change; settlement patterns and material culture; historic sites preservation. Pre: junior standing and consent.
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Global Health and Development (3)
desc:
Seminar explores the definitions and histories of development and global health initiatives 
in developing countries from an anthropological perspective. Reading materials include scholarly and popular texts that propose and critique solutions to global poverty. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: 152 or 301. (Alt. years)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: East Asian Archaeology (3)
desc: Prehistory and protohistory of China, Japan, and Korea from earliest human occupation to historic times. Geographical emphasis may vary between China and Japan/Korea. Pre: junior standing or consent.
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Southeast Asian Archaeology (3)
desc: Prehistory and protohistory of Southeast Asia and of Southeast Asian contacts with East Asia, India, Australia, and Oceania. Pre: junior standing or consent. (Crosslisted as ASAN 461)
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Asian Paleoanthropology (3)
desc: Neogene-Quaternary paleoenvironmental reconstructions; human evolution in East Asia during the Pleistocene; Out of Africa I; modern human origins. Pre: sophomore standing, recommend 310, or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: DB Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Extinctions (3)
desc: An extraordinary number of plants and animals have gone extinct. Delves deeply into the primary literature that focuses on extinction and conservation from the beginning of the earth to the present day. Pre: 215 or consent. (Alt. yrs: fall)
metadata: DB Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Forensic Anthropology (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Application of physical anthropology to problems in human identification. Determination of age, sex, ancestry, etc., of the skeleton and preparation of reports for legal medicine. Pre: 215 and 215L.
metadata: DB Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Melanesia (3)
desc: Close study of cultures of Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, Solomon Islands, New Caledonia, and Fiji through anthropological ethnography. Pre: 152 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Polynesian Cultures (3)
desc: Analysis of Polynesian cultures from their origins to contemporary states. Pre: junior standing or consent.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Southeast Asian Cultures (3)
desc: Cultures of Southeast Asia from hunting and gathering groups to high civilizations; kinship, economic, political, and religious systems; recent developments. Pre: junior standing or consent.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Sacred Places (3)
desc: Lectures and seminars provide a cross-cultural survey of sites which societies recognize as sacred and their cultural, ecological and conservation aspects. Pre: junior standing or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as REL 445)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Spiritual Ecology (3)
desc: Lectures and seminars provide a cross-cultural survey of the relationships between religions, environment and environmentalism. Junior standing or higher. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as REL 444)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Buddhism (3)
desc: Selected aspects of national, regional and local manifestations of Buddhism are explored through the perspective of anthropology with an emphasis on the daily lives of monks, nuns and lay persons in their socio-cultural contexts. Pre: 422, REL 207, REL 475, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as REL 443)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Globalization and Identity in the Himalayas (3)
desc:
Examines the influence of local culture and global flows on identity formation in the 
Himalayan region. Topics include: Hindu caste and gender, constructions of ethnicity, Tibetans and tourists, Sherpas and mountaineers, development ideologies, and consumerism. Pre: 152 or 301 or ASAN 202 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: The Agriculture of Identity: Food and Farming in Anthropological Perspective (3)
desc: Exploration of agriculture from the perspective of anthropology, with a focus on alternatives to industrial agriculture, especially in the context of Hawai‘i. Readings include academic writing and also literary non-fiction and journalism. A-F only. Pre: 152. (Alt. years)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Indigenous Crops/Food Systems (1)
desc: Schemes for managing sequences and combinations of crops and crop production activities. Ecosystem and social determinants. Multiple cropping. Analysis of alternative cropping systems. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Consumer Cultures (3)
desc: Examines the practices and meanings of consumption in the contemporary world. Topics include social class, branding, fandom, global-local nexus. A-F only. Pre: 152 or consent. (Alt. years)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of the Body (3)
desc: Exploration of the history and development of theories of the body via topics such as phenomenology, perception, bodily rituals, gender, sex, race, colonialism, power, pain, medicalization, immunology, reproductive health and cyborgs. Pre: 152 (or concurrent) or 301 (or concurrent).
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Food, Health, and Society (3)
desc: How human groups identify, collect, create, and transform foods; how they shape those into dietary behaviors, and the influence of those behaviors on health. Pre: junior standing or higher or consent.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: The Anthropology of Sexuality (3)
desc: Explores the intersection of sexuality research and queer theory with other anthropological concerns such as identity, race, gender, religion, economy, politics, and globalization. A-F only. Pre: junior standing or consent. (Cross-listed as WGSS 426)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Social and Cultural Change (3)
desc: Various approaches to examples of social and cultural change in non-literate societies; evolution, diffusion, acculturation, revolution, etc. Historical features and social processes of colonialism. Pre: 152.
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Magic, Witchcraft, and Religion (3)
desc: Cults, legends, millennial movements, myths, possession, rituals, sacred healing, shamanism, sorcery, spirits, symbolism, witchcraft, and other forms of religious and symbolic expression and experience, from small scale to highly urban societies. Pre: 152. (Cross-listed as REL 422)
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Communication and Culture (3)
desc: Anthropological introduction to communication; intercultural and interspecies comparisons; verbal and nonverbal. Ethnography of communication, discourse and structural analyses, ethnomethodology. Pre: 152.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Indigenous Anthropology (3)
desc: Exploration of how anthropology studies indigenous groups throughout the world. An examination of the changing contexts of anthropological practice as calls for reflexivity lead anthropology of all backgrounds to bring insights from their “homes.” Issues include the question of objectivity, the emicetic distinction, and the ethics of different kinds of anthropological research and the role of anthropologists in indigenous self-determination. Repeatable one time. Pre: 152.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Political Anthropology (3)
desc: Character of political institutions and their development in nonWestern and non industrial societies. Pre: 152.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Wealth, Culture, and Economic Anthropology (3)
desc: Analysis of economic activities in non-Western, non-industrial societies; production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services in a variety of cultures. Pre: 152.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Introduction to Linguistic Anthropology (3)
desc: Introduction to the ethnographic study of speech and language. Pre: 152. (Once a year) (Cross-listed as LING 414 and IS 414)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Language and Gender (3)
desc: The role of language in the construction of gender and in the maintenance of the gender order. Field projects explore hypotheses about the interaction of language and gender. No previous knowledge of linguistics required. A-F only. (Cross-listed as LING 415)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Evolutionary Anthropology (3)
desc: Lecture discussion providing an overview of evolutionary theory in anthropology: focus on the evolution of culture, behavioral ecology, and cultural diversity; emphasis on archaeological and ethnographic research and explanatory models. Pre: 210 or 215, or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Museum Anthropology (3)
desc: Anthropological study of museums and related sites of cultural production (historic sites, memorials, theme parks). Junior standing or higher. (Alt. years)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Ethics in Anthropology (3)
desc: Seminar surveying ethical cases, problems, issues and questions from the inception of anthropology to the present. Junior standing or higher or consent.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Directed Reading or Research (V)
desc: Repeatable nine times. Pre: major or minor in Anthropology.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: (Alpha) Undergraduate Seminar (3)
desc: Selected problems in current research. (B) archaeology; (C) ethnography; (D) social anthropology; (E) applied; (F) psychological; (G) biological. Repeatable nine times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Skeletal Biology Laboratory (1)
desc: Laboratory to accompany 384. Co-requisite: 384.
metadata: DY Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Skeletal Biology (3)
desc: Introduction to the human skeleton and methods for analyzing archaeological human remains including age, sex, ethnicity, paleodemography, skeletal and dental variation, paleopathology, population studies. Corequisite: 384L.
metadata: DB Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: How Archaeology Works (3)
desc: Uses archaeological examples to illustrate social science research techniques. Students learn how to create, analyze, and evaluate data through lab-based exercises, and examine ethical issues inherent in anthropological practice. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher. Pre: 210 or instructor consent.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Archaeological Field Techniques (V)
desc: Archaeological survey and excavations; field trips, mapping, photography. May focus on terrestrial or underwater. May be taught entirely in the field at a national or international archaeological site. Repeatable one time with consent. Pre: 210.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Archaeological Lab Techniques (4)
desc: Laboratory analysis and evaluation of field data; preservation and restoration of artifacts. Preparation for publication. Repeatable two times. Pre: 210 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Archaeology Practicum (V)
desc: Students will gain practical archaeological experience (e.g., materials processing, analysis, documentation, conservation) under the direction of practicing archaeological professionals in the local community and in collaboration with supervising archaeological faculty. Repeatable two times, up to 6 credits. ANTH majors or minors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: 210 or consent of instructor.
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Race and Human Variation (3)
desc: Human genetic and physical variation; latitudinal, longitudinal, and altitudinal variation across human populations; history of racism; contemporary issues in race and racism. Pre: sophomore standing, recommend 152 and 215; or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: (Alpha) Indigenous Peoples of Latin America (3)
desc: Survey of the history and culture of the indigenous peoples of Latin America through a study of their literature, texts and practices. (B) Mesoamerica; (C) Andean South America. Repeatable one time for different alphas. Pre: sophomore standing or consent. (Cross-listed as LAIS 372 (Alpha))
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Ethnographic Field Techniques (V)
desc: Problems and techniques of social-cultural anthropological fieldwork; ethnographic literature; work with informants. Repeatable one time. Pre: 152 OR 301.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Households in Cross-Cultural Perspectives: Home, Hale, Casa (3)
desc: Study of cross-cultural patterns in household and community level organizations in Latin America and elsewhere. Topics may include gender relations, kinship structures, political economy, impacts of colonialism, modernization, and globalization on households. Sophomore standing or higher. (Cross-listed as LAIS 368)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Pacific Island Cultures (3)
desc: Introduction to cultures of Polynesia, Micronesia, and Melanesia from time of first settlement to emergence of modern nation states. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Aggression, War, and Peace (3)
desc: Biocultural, evolutionary, and cross-cultural perspectives on the conditions, patterns, and processes of violence, war, nonviolence, and peace. Pre: 152. (Cross-listed as PACE 345)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Virtual Worlds (3)
desc: Anthropological study of computer mediated interaction. Focus on the ethnography of massively multiplayer online games, text-based chat rooms, and blogs. Pre: 152 or consent. (Once a year)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Climate Change and Cultural Response: Past, Present, and Future (3)
desc: Climate change is a reality, yet there is much uncertainty about how it will affect our lives. Investigates cultural response to climate change, using studies of the past to plan for the future. (Alt. years: spring) (Cross-listed as SUST 333)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Surfing (3)
desc: Applies cultural anthropology to assess surfing as an indigenous Hawaiian and modern globalized activity. Discusses the history of surfing, surfing culture, and the impacts of surfing tourism on coastal development, reef ecology, and ocean safety. A-F only. (Fall only)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Food Origins, Food Culture (3)
desc: Lectures and discussion offer an anthropological introduction to how humans created and transformed food through time. Sophomore standing or higher. (Spring only)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Ethnohistory (3)
desc: Review of ethnohistory, i.e., the interdisciplinary, holistic and inclusive investigation of the histories of native peoples drawing not only on documented sources, but also on ethnography, linguistics, archaeology, ecology and other disciplines as an alternative to conventional Eurocolonial history. A-F only. Pre: HIST 152, or consent. (Alt. years) (Cross-listed as IS 322)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: American Folklore and Folklife (3)
desc: Examination of the history and ethics of folklore studies and the dynamics and social functions of traditional culture in diverse communities through topics such as ritual, storytelling, games, gossip, belief, music, and cultural tourism. Junior standing or higher. (Cross-listed as AMST 326)
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Origins of Cities (3)
desc: Combined lecture/ discussion on the emergence and development of ancient cities in comparative perspective and the dynamics of (pre)modern urban life. Examples are drawn from the Near East, Mediterranean, Africa, India, China, and the Americas. A-F only. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Pacific Islands Archaeology (3)
desc: Origins of Pacific peoples; chronology of settlement; sequences of culture in Australia, Melanesia, Micronesia, and Polynesia. Pre: sophomore standing or consent.
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Tourism (3)
desc: Anthropological perspectives on the subject of the global phenomenon of tourism. Includes issues of cultural performance, identity, and commoditization. Open to nonmajors.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Sex and Gender (3)
desc: Cross-cultural theories and perceptions of sexual differences; linkage between biology and cultural constructions of gender; relationship of gender ideology to women’s status. Pre: 152 (or concurrent) or 301 (or concurrent). (Crosslisted as WGSS 315)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Visual Anthropology (3)
desc: Historical development of documentary films of non-Western peoples; critical examination of ways in which ethnographic films represent different cultures. Pre: 152 (or concurrent).
metadata: DH Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Human Origins (3)
desc: Theory of evolution, evolutionary systematics, and taxonomy; evolutionary biology of primates; fossil records for primate and human evolution. Laboratory included. Pre: 215, ZOOL 101; or consent.
metadata: DB Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Culture and Health (3)
desc: Social and cultural aspects of medicine; the relationship of medicine to the beliefs, social systems, ecological adaptations, and cultural changes of human groups.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Contemporary Social Issues (3)
desc: Contemporary issues in the field of anthropology and in society, including race, ethnicity, gender, inequality, colonialism and decolonization, health disparities and environmental change, from the perspective of cultural anthropology, biological anthropology and archaeology.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Quantitative Reasoning for Anthropologists (3)
desc: Achieve basic quantitative literacy and to familiarize them with statistical reasoning so that they are prepared to carry out anthropological (and other social science) research. A-F only.
metadata: FQ Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology Laboratory (1)
desc: Laboratory to accompany 215. Co-requisite: 215.
metadata: DY Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology (3)
desc: Human evolution, primatology, human genetics, biological variation, human adaptability, growth and development. Co-requisite: 215L.
metadata: DB Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Archaeology (3)
desc: Introduction to prehistoric archaeology; methods and techniques of excavation and laboratory analysis; brief survey of theory in relation to change and diversity in prehistoric human groups.
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Polynesian Surf Culture Field Lab (1)
desc: 175 co-requisite lab. Surfing sites are visited, ancient and modern Polynesian surfing practices and surfboard design and technology are discussed. Shoreline assessments emphasize ocean safety. Social issues surrounding surfing sites in Hawai‘i are analyzed. A-F only. Co-requisite: 175. (Fall only)
metadata: Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Polynesian Surf Culture (3)
desc: Examines environmental and cultural factors in the development of Polynesian surf culture, surfing’s decline due to Western influence, and its revitalization as a modern recreational activity. Business practices of the surfing industry are critically analyzed. A-F only. Co-requisite: 175L. (Fall only)
metadata: DS Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Culture and Humanity (3)
desc: Introduction to cultural anthropology. How humans create, understand, order and modify their natural, social, supernatural and physical environments, and make meaning and order. Restricted to students in the Honors Program.
metadata: FGB Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ANTH
title: Culture and Humanity (3)
desc: Introduction to cultural anthropology. How humans create, understand, order and modify their natural, social, supernatural and physical environments, and make meaning and order. Open to non-majors, required for ANTH majors. A-F only.
metadata: FGB Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANTH
title: Emerging Humanity (3)
desc: Introduction to human biological evolution and the archaeology of culture in the world prior to AD 1500. Restricted to students in the Honors Program.
metadata: FGA Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences Honors (HON) Office of Student Success

subject: ANTH
title: Emerging Humanity (3)
desc: Introduction to human biological evolution and the archaeology of culture in the world prior to AD 1500. Open to nonmajors, recommended for majors.
metadata: FGA Anthropology (ANTH) College of Social Sciences

subject: ANSC
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Pre: consent. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Advanced Laboratory Techniques (3)
desc: (1 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Advanced laboratory techniques used in food science and human nutrition research. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent and MBBE 402/402L, and FSHN 477; or BIOC 441. (Cross-listed as FSHN 687 and MBBE 687)
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Grant Writing for Graduate Students (1)
desc: Combined lecture/discussion on grants and grant writing. Designed to introduce graduate students to grants and grant proposal writing through lectures, class discussion, writing assignments, and peer review. Open to CTAHR graduate students only; others with consent. (Cross-listed as FSHN 657 and TPSS 657)
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Information Research Skills (1)
desc: Examines the use of libraries and information technology for scholarly investigation in support of scientific research; provides experience utilizing and critically evaluating a variety of print and electronic sources in basic and applied sciences. Pre: consent. (Cross-listed as FSHN 652, NREM 652, and TPSS 652)
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: DNA and Genetic Analysis (3)
desc:
Combined lecture-lab for students interested in genetic analysis of humans, animals, and other species. Molecular techniques, such as PCR, DNA marker identifications, transgenics, expression analysis and functional genomics, 
are included. Open to nonmajors. Pre: graduate standing or consent. (Cross-listed as FSHN 650 and MBBE 650)
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Growth Biology of Meat Animals (2)
desc: Growth and development of meat-producing animals; skeletal muscle, adipose tissue, and bone; protein turnover, lipid metabolism, and bioenergetics; regulation of animal growth. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Physiology of Reproduction (3)
desc: Comparative differentiation, development, growth, and function of the reproductive systems of mammals and birds; external factors that influence response; artificial insemination. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Advanced Animal Nutrition (3)
desc: An advanced course in the nutrition of mono-gastric, ruminant, avian, and aquatic species. Topics include digestive system structures, utilization of nutrients, energy metabolism, and experimental techniques used in the study of animal nutrition. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Seminar in Animal Sciences (1)
desc: Topics of current interest and current research related to nutrition, genetics, and physiology. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Experimental Design (4)
desc: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Design of experiments and variance analyses in biological and agricultural research. Pre: graduate standing or consent. Recommended: ZOOL 632. (Cross-listed as TPSS 603)
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: The Science of Food Systems (2)
desc: (1 50-min Lec, 1 2-hr Discussion) Discussion of food systems as they apply to animal science, food science, and human nutrition. Repeatable one time. Pre:graduate standing or consent. (Cross-listed as FSHN 601)
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Directed Study or Research (V)
desc: Limited to exceptional undergraduate students, generally with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in major. Exceptions may be granted for students with high achievement in last three semesters. Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: junior or senior standing.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Field Experience (4)
desc: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Placement with an approved cooperating supervisor/employer. Writing a learning plan and field report. A-F only. Pre: senior standing in ANSC. (Cross-listed as FSHN 492)
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Topics in Animal Sciences (V)
desc: Study and discussion of significant topics, problems. Offered by visiting faculty and/or for extension programs. Repeatable five times, up to 18 credits. Pre: junior or senior standing.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Aquaculture Business Planning and Entrepreneurship (2)
desc:
Practical aspects of planning and developing an aquaculture business from conceptualization to a final business plan. Topics include species/technology, project planning, business structuring, permitting, contracts, production plans, financial planning and analysis, market/competition analysis, capital acquisition, intellectual property and 
legal issues. Pre: 450 or OCN 450. Must have strong interest in hands-on rearing aquaculture animals and flexible time for live animal care.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Comparative Endocrinology (3)
desc: Structure and function of endocrine systems across vertebrate groups, surveying how hormones mediate adaptive responses to dynamic environments and coordinate key aspects of growth, development, metabolism, osmoregulation, and stress. Pre: 301 (with a minimum grade of C).
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Aquaculture Production Laboratory (4)
desc: Intensive, hands-on course involving the culture of larvae and juveniles of marine shrimp, freshwater prawns, molluscs, fish, and their food. Must have strong interest in hands-on rearing and flexible time for continuous live animal care. Lab fee required.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Reproduction and Artificial Insemination Lab (1)
desc: Reproductive anatomy and physiology of domestic animals, estorus synchronization, breeding soundness, and artificial insemination laboratory, field trips. One week offisland field trip. Repeatable one time. ANSC majors or consent. Pre: 301 and 462.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Reproduction and Artificial Insemination (3)
desc: Introductory exploration of anatomy, development, and physiology of reproduction of domestic animals and artificial insemination. Repeatable one time. Pre: 301 (with a minimum grade of C).
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Biology and Culture of Shrimp and Prawns (2)
desc: Aspects of the biology and culture of the freshwater prawn Macrobrachium rosenbergii and marine shrimp Penaeus (sp) species. Scientific research results and case studies presented and analyzed. Pre: 450 or consent.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Companion Animals and Society (3)
desc: Explore human and companion animal relationships in biological, social, cultural, economic, legal, health, and welfare contexts to prepare students for careers in the various animal-related fields in Hawai‘i, the Pacific rim, and worldwide. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. Pre: BIOL 171 (with a minimum grade of C), or consent.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Meat Science and Muscle Biology Lab (1)
desc: (1 3-hr Lab) Livestock and poultry slaughter, carcass evaluation, meat chemistry, muscle physiology and biochemistry, meat microbiology, and meat processing. Pre: 454 (or concurrent).
metadata: DY Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Meat Science and Muscle Biology (3)
desc: Development, growth, function, carcass evaluation of muscle tissue. Pre: 301 (or concurrent).
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Animal Diseases and Their Control (3)
desc: Disease problems of livestock, poultry, and companion animals; their economic significance, causes, public health implications, and control. Pre: 200 (or concurrent), and BIOL 171/L or ZOOL 101/L.
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Physiology of Domestic Animals (3)
desc: Functions and relationships of organs and organ systems of domestic animals excluding reproduction and lactation. Problem-based learning and case studies are emphasized. Pre: 301 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent.
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Aquaculture Production (3)
desc: Theory and practice of aquaculture: reproduction, yield trials, management, economics and business case studies of fish, crustaceans, and molluscs. Field classes held at commercial farm and hatchery. Pre: 321 and 445: or BIOL 172/L and CHEM 162/L or higher. (Crosslisted as OCN 450)
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Genes and Animal Biology (3)
desc: An understanding of animal biology at the level of genes and their regulations; emphasis on gene structure, recombinant DNA, transgenic animals and functional genomics being used for agricultural, nutritional and biomedical sciences. Open to nonmajors. A-F only. Pre: (301, BIOL 171 or ZOOL 101) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Genetics and Animal Breeding (3)
desc: Review and application of genetic principles to livestock, poultry, companion, aquatic, and laboratory research animals. Current practices and future developments. Pre: (BIOL 171/171L or ZOOL 101/101L, and MATH 140X or higher) with a minimum grade of C. Recommended: biochemistry and genetics or equivalent.
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Tropical Dairying (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles involved in economical milk production in the tropics, including management, recordkeeping, breeds, breeding, selection, culling, feeding, housing, milking, quality control, and raising young animals. Pre: 321 and 445.
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Swine Production (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of efficient pork production, including comparative breed evaluation, breeding, feeding, management, marketing, and business aspects. Problems and practices associated with tropical environment emphasized. Pre: 321 and 445.
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Health Sciences & Social Welfare

subject: ANSC
title: Beef Production (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of economic beef production, including beef breeds, selection, breeding, management systems, feeding, and marketing under tropical conditions. Pre: 321 and 445.
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Horses and Horsemanship (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Origin of species, breeds, nutrition, care, management. Lab on management practices with work on light horses. Pre: 200, or 201 (or concurrent).
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Humans, Food, and Animals: Ethics, Issues, and Controversies (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Ethical issues and other controversies related to human and animal needs; their impact on resource sustainability and quality of life are explored from scientific perspectives. A-F only. Pre: 200 or 201 or FSHN 181 or FSHN 185. (Cross-listed as FSHN 350)
metadata: Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Applied Animal Nutrition (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Application of the principles of nutrition to feeding of farm animals; composition and nutritional value of feed stuffs; nutritional requirements of beef cattle, dairy cattle, horses, poultry, and swine. Pre: (201 (or concurrent), and 244 or FSHN 244) with a minimum grade of C.
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Domestic Animal Anatomy Laboratory (1)
desc: Laboratory to accompany 301, with an emphasis on teaching scientific and technical writing. Dissection and identification of anatomical arrangements of tissues and organ systems of domestic animals. A-F only. Pre: 200 (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of C. Corequisite: 301. (Fall only)
metadata: DY Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Anatomy of Domestic Animals (3)
desc: Micro and gross anatomical arrangements of tissues and organ systems of domestic animals. Pre: 200 (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of C. Co-requisite: 301L.
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Comparative Nutrition (3)
desc: Digestive systems and nutrient functions, interrelationships and metabolism are compared among animal species, including humans. An intermediate, general nutrition course for Food Science and Human Nutrition and Animal Science majors. Pre: (200 (or concurrent), CHEM 161/161L or higher) with a minimum grade of C. (Cross-listed as FSHN 244) DB
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Principles and Practices of Animal Science (3)
desc: Biology, behavior, and management of  animals of economic and social importance. Topics include physiology, genetics, nutrition, reproduction, behavior, care, and management to achieve productivity, performance, and welfare. (lecture, discussion, and field trips)
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANSC
title: Humans, Animals, and Agriculture (3)
desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to animal agriculture, animal science, and the use of animals by humans. Ethics and importance of human use of animals in agriculture are emphasized.
metadata: DB Animal Sciences (ANSC) College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources

subject: ANAT
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ANAT
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times. Pre: admission to candidacy (master’s program).
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ANAT
title: Directed Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ANAT
title: Seminar in Anatomy Teaching (V)
desc: Effective teaching methods, organization of courses in anatomical sciences, development and evaluation of exams, experience in teaching with audiovisual/ computer aids. Open to graduate students in physiology or KRS. CR/NC only. Repeatable eight times, up to 32 credits. Pre: 603 and 604.
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ANAT
title: Human Embryology (2)
desc: Systematic study of human development, including implantation, placentation, basics of development of each organ system with reference to pertinent congenital anomalies and their surgical repair. Pre: 603 or 604. Recommended: gross anatomy course.
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ANAT
title: Upper Extremity, Head, Neck, and Spine (3)
desc: Human gross anatomy dissection of the upper extremity, head, neck, and spine. Emphasis is placed on muscles, function, innervation, and vascular supply. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in DRB or KRS graduate programs (including Biomed Sci-Anat/ RepoBiol & Phys majors) only or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (Cross-listed as KRS 604)
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ANAT
title: Lower Extremity, Thorax, and Abdomen (3)
desc: Human gross anatomy dissection of the lower extremity, thorax, and abdomen. Emphasis is placed on muscles, function, innervation, and vascular supply. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in DRB or KRS graduate programs (including Biomed Sci-Anat/ RepoBiol & Phys majors) only or consent. A-F only. (Spring only) (Cross-listed as KRS 603)
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ANAT
title: Independent Study in Anatomy (1)
desc: Elective course for advanced medical students. (B) human gross anatomy; (C) histology; (D) research in anatomy and developmental biology. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. Pre: consent for (B) and (C); MDED 551 for (D).
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ANAT
title: (Alpha) Unit VII Anatomy Electives (V)
desc: Advanced study of human anatomy by dissection and individual observation of surgical procedures. (C) topics in reproductive biology. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only. Pre: FMCH, MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, SURG 531 or 532; or consent.
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: ANAT
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
metadata: Anatomy (ANAT) John A. Burns School of Medicine

subject: AMST
title: Dissertation Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Thesis Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Directed Reading/Research (V)
desc: Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ARCH
title: (Alpha) Preservation Field Study (6)
desc: On-site historic preservation field study. Site will rotate. Academic and hands-on preservation training. (B) Hawai‘i; (C) Asia; (D) Pacific. Each alpha repeatable up to 18 credits. Pre: consent.
metadata: Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: AMST
title: Research Seminar (3)
desc: Themes, problems, and issues not addressed in other American studies graduate courses; emphasis upon research methods. Repeatable unlimited times.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Indigenous Studies Practicum (3)
desc: Applies course work in Indigenous studies to hands-on activities under the direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Museum Studies Practicum (3)
desc: Applies coursework in museum studies to hands-on activities under the direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. Museum studies certificate students only. A-F only. Pre: consent.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Museums and Education (3)
desc: Overview of museum education including museum learning theories, informal learning programs, audience research, national and international policies and reports, and community projects. Pre: 683 (or concurrent) or consent. (Cross-listed as EDCS 685)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Museums and Collections (3)
desc: Work of museums and professionals (registrars, collections managers, conservators, curators and others) in the care of collections, interpretive studies of museum displays; field trips. Pre: 683 (or concurrent) or consent.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Museums: Theory, History, Practice (3)
desc: History and theory of museums and related institutions (art galleries, historic houses, zoos, parks). Relationship between museums, collections, and communities. Introduction to governance, planning, legal, and ethical concerns.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Vernacular Architecture (3)
desc: Methods and approaches in the study of vernacular architecture, cultural landscapes, and material culture, with an emphasis on traditions and innovations in the Americas. (Cross-listed as ARCH 650)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Historic Building Technology (3)
desc: History of buildings, building technologies, materials, and finishes, including construction techniques and methods of investigating older buildings. Emphasis on North American building practices c.1600–c.1960. (Cross-listed as ARCH 680)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Elements of Style (3)
desc: The manifestations, visual characteristics, and social/cultural meaning of “style” in American architecture and decorative arts from the early settlement period through the present. (Cross-listed as ARCH 679)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: ARCH
title: Historic Preservation Planning (3)
desc: Local-level historic preservation, with an emphasis on historic districts, design guidelines, regulatory controls, and community consensus-building. (Cross-listed as PLAN 677)
metadata: Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: Recording Historic and Cultural Resources (3)
desc: Techniques in recording and evaluation of historic buildings and other resources, with an emphasis on field recordings and state and federal registration procedures. Graduate students only or consent. (Cross-listed as ANTH 676 and PLAN 676)
metadata: Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: ARCH
title: Preservation Field Seminar (3)
desc: Provides participants with basic knowledge of the field of historic preservation as well as the fundamental knowledge of how to document, conserve, and preserve both tangible and intangible cultural properties. Repeatable three times. (Summer only)
metadata: Architecture (ARCH) School of Architecture

subject: AMST
title: African American Literature (3)
desc: Cultural and social imagination of blacks and whites as revealed in literature, poetry, and drama.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: 20th Century U.S. Literature (3)
desc: Selected works of 20th-century literature as cultural documents.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Indigenous Curation and Museums: Practice Meets Theory (3)
desc: Seminar explores the history, evolution, and contemporary movement towards indigenous curation within museums, emphasis on the Americas and Oceania, as shaped by colonialism, globalization, multiculturalism, selfdetermination, and nationalism. (Fall only)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Comparative Methods in American Studies (3)
desc: Examines approaches to American studies that use comparison as a primary method. Comparison of histories, institutions, of phenomena between the U.S. and another country as well as among communities in the U.S. Graduate standing only. Co-requisite: 600 or 601 or 602, or consent. (Every 2-3 years)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Advanced Topics: America and the World (3)
desc: Historical and contemporary issues in America’s global relationships.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Globalization and Transnationalism (3)
desc: Examines the socioeconomic and cultural meanings of globalization and transnationalism. Emphasis on how the deployment and flows of power beyond the nation-state have an impact on regional, national, and/ or local communities and cultures.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Transpacific Studies (3)
desc: Critical analysis of regional formation in and across the Pacific and the role of the U.S. therein; migrations within and across the Pacific; political, military, economic, cultural, and environmental dynamics of transpacific exchanges.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Arts in America: Modern to PostModern (3)
desc: Survey of the literature of the field.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Film in America (3)
desc: Examination of various roles of motion picture film in America with particular respect to art form, cultural artifact, document, and myth.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Field Mastery (3)
desc: Prepares students to achieve specialization in an American Studies-related academic field. Repeatable two times with different contents. Graduate students only. A-F only.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: American Intellectual Traditions (3)
desc: Examination of intellectual figures and movements in American history.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Advanced Topics: Business/Labor/ Technology (3)
desc: Readings and research on American business, labor, and technological history. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing and consent. (Crosslisted as HIST 639K)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Advanced Topics: Social/Cultural/ Intellectual (3)
desc: Readings and research on American social and intellectual history. Repeatable one time. Pre: graduate standing and consent. (Cross-listed as HIST 639B)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Historic Preservation (3)
desc: Federal, state, and local laws and regulations that regulate and provide protection to significant archaeological and historical resources in Hawai‘i and the region. (Alt. years: spring only) (Cross-listed as ANTH 645 and ARCH 645)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Revolutions and Social Movements (3)
desc: Examines the role of social movements in transforming American society and culture.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Writing for Publication (3)
desc: Advanced seminar designed to convert graduate research projects into publishable scholarly articles. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: American Punishment (3)
desc: Examines the history of American criminal punishment, from the birth of the penitentiary to the rise of the prison-industrial complex. A-F only. Graduate students only.  (Cross-listed as SOC 638)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Public History and Commemoration (3)
desc: Approaches to public presentations of history and examination of various ways in which historic memory is constructed in sites such as museums, memorials, and theme parks.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Technologies of War and Media (3)
desc: Critical examination of the relationship between war and media with particular attention to the overlapping histories of technologies of perception and destruction in the modern era and to the military-entertainment complex today. Graduate students only or consent.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Mass Media (3)
desc: Appraisal of major media of communications in American society with attention to political, educational, cultural, and ethical implications.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Environment and Society (3)
desc: Technological development in cultural perspective; its relation to the American environment, science, capitalism, public policy, and values.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Material Culture (3)
desc: Physical artifacts considered as documents of American cultural and regional development.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Wilderness in America (3)
desc: American wilderness as both physical setting and social construction. A-F only. Pre: graduate standing or consent
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: American Architecture (3)
desc: Cultural analysis of the evolution of American architecture from the Colonial period to the present involving sociopolitical and economic, as well as aesthetic, considerations. (Cross-listed as ARCH 623)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Indigenous Identity (3)
desc: Interdisciplinary and comparative focus on how Indigenous identity is constructed, negotiated, asserted, ascribed, and deconstructed within and without Indigenous communities with attention to the U.S. Graduate students only. Pre: graduate level standing or higher.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Slavery and Modern Memory (3)
desc: Exploration of contemporary resonances of slavery in the Americas through literature, historical scholarship, memory and trauma studies, and the visual and performing arts. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Cross-listed as HIST 619)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: American Sexualities (3)
desc: Aspects of sexual identity within the context of American culture.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Social and Cultural Diversity in America (3)
desc: Examination of selected subcultures in America.
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Gender and the African Diaspora in the Americas (3)
desc:
Explores the impact of the African Diaspora on the cultures and histories of the Americas through interdisciplinary and feminist scholarship and 
cultural sources including fiction, foodways, film, poetry, religion, music, and dance. A-F only. Graduate standing only. (Cross-listed as WGSS 616)
metadata: American Studies (AMST) College of Arts, Languages & Letters

subject: AMST
title: Performance, Culture, and Theory (3)
